headline: Research Scientists to Use Network Much Faster Than Internet
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Fiber Optics', 'Research', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)']
abstract: The Pacific Research Platform will allow West Coast universities to connect on a high-speed network tens or hundreds of times faster than is typical now.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A series of ultra-high-speed fiber-optic cables will weave a cluster of West Coast university laboratories and supercomputer centers into a network called the Pacific Research Platform as part of a five-year $5 million dollar grant from the National Science Foundation.

headline: Inmate’s Suit Over Abortion Denial Ends With Her Decision to Have Child
abstract: A lawsuit brought by a pregnant inmate seeking access to an abortion was dismissed by a federal judge on Friday after the woman said she had changed her mind and would carry the child.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Ala. — A lawsuit brought by a pregnant Alabama inmate seeking access to an abortion was dismissed by a federal judge on Friday after the woman said she had changed her mind and would carry the child.

headline: Lawmakers on Azerbaijan Trip Cleared
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The House Ethics Committee announced that it had cleared 10 lawmakers and 32 House employees of any wrongdoing associated with a trip to Azerbaijan.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee announced Friday that it had cleared 10 lawmakers and 32 House employees of any wrongdoing associated with a trip they took in May 2013 to Azerbaijan, even though investigators found inconclusive evidence suggesting that the approximately $200,000 worth of airfare and other bills were improperly paid for by the Azerbaijan government. Six lawmakers were ordered to return rugs and other gifts they received during the trip. And the investigators urged the Department of Justice to examine “possible criminal” efforts to mislead the lawmakers about who actually paid for the travel.

headline: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., Pioneer of the Private Equity Industry, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Kohlberg, who founded K.K.R., shunned hard-edged tactics, focusing on smaller, friendly deals.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Kohlberg Jr., a veteran financier who pioneered the $2.6 trillion leveraged-buyout industry but later rejected its hunger for huge and aggressive deals, died on Thursday at his home in Martha’s Vineyard. He was 90.

headline: Food Program Gets Emergency Cash
abstract: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said that it had averted a suspension of aid to 440,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan after the United States gave $65 million.
lead_paragraph: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said Friday that it had averted an imminent suspension of food aid to 440,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan after the United States provided a $65 million infusion. In a statement, the agency, the World Food Program, said the American money would enable it to maintain, albeit at a reduced level, food voucher assistance to the refugees, who all live outside camps in Jordan. “This timely contribution has helped us avoid major cuts, but unless other donors step up to the plate, it will be only a matter of months before we face the same situation again,” Muhannad Hadi, the agency’s regional director, said in a statement. The agency, which assists 80 million people in 80 countries, has been vexed by recurring financial travails as humanitarian crises have expanded in the Middle East and Africa.

headline: Maine Court Considers Vetoes by Gov. LePage
abstract: The Maine Supreme Court heard arguments over whether Mr. LePage vetoed 65 bills within the proper time frame.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Me. — The contentious standoff between Gov. Paul R. LePage of Maine and the State Legislature moved to the courts Friday as the two sides battled over whether the governor vetoed 65 bills within the proper time frame.

headline: For Prisoners, a Path to Society
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Pell Grants', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The Obama administration is wise to restore limited access to Pell education grants for prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives and liberals who clash on just about everything else agree that the harsh drug sentencing laws that swept the country starting four decades ago have been wholly counterproductive, driving up prison costs to bankrupting levels, undermining confidence in justice and decimating communities. But as Congress seeks to reform federal sentencing policies, it should revisit other outdated policies that trap people with criminal convictions at the margins of society — and indeed have driven many of them back to jail — by denying them jobs, housing and education.

headline: New York City to Reroute Garbage Truck Ramp Planned on East Side
abstract: Following an aggressive campaign by activists, a new $30 million ramp will be built to avoid bisecting playgrounds.
lead_paragraph: Score one for the neighbors.

headline: Lynn Anderson, Singer of ‘Rose Garden,’ Dies at 67
abstract: Ms. Anderson recorded her signature song, “(I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden,” on a fluke.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Anderson, who skyrocketed to country music stardom in 1970 singing her signature song, “(I Never Promised You a) Rose Garden,” died on Thursday in Nashville. She was 67.

headline: Republicans Audition for Big Money
abstract: Presidential candidates are making their pitch to the Koch brothers and other wealthy donors, who are hoping to dominate the election process.
lead_paragraph: A definitive event in the plutocratic spending binge now engulfing presidential politics is taking place in Orange County, Calif., this weekend. The Koch brothers and 450 of their most affluent allies are auditioning a select group of Republican candidates, who are vying to get a share of the whopping $889 million pledged by these donors for the presidential race next year.

headline: Third Person Dies of Legionnaires’ Disease in the Bronx
abstract: The death is part of an outbreak of the airborne illness that has infected at least 57 people in recent weeks in the borough, New York City officials said.
lead_paragraph: A third person died of Legionnaire’s disease in the Bronx on Friday, health officials said, part of an outbreak of the airborne illness that has emerged during the hottest weeks of the year as many seek relief with air-conditioning systems that help spread the bacteria.

headline: Samuel DuBose’s Death in Cincinnati Points to Off-Campus Power of College Police
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The shooting of Mr. DuBose, a black man, has prompted officials to reconsider a policy that allowed a university force to patrol an area far more complex than its campus.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Six years ago, with crime creeping upward in the tree-lined, if slightly downtrodden, neighborhoods encircling the University of Cincinnati campus, the city and the university quietly signed an agreement giving the 72-member campus police force authority to patrol nearby residential streets.

headline: New Meningitis Strain in Africa Brings Call for More Vaccines
abstract: An international consortium is seeking five million doses of the vaccine against Type C meningitis and says they must arrive by January to be effective.
lead_paragraph: Meningitis may be poised for a ferocious comeback in Africa, international aid organizations are warning, and vaccine manufacturers must step up production if the outbreak is to be averted.

headline: Contenders Use Late Deals to Pad the Margins of Their Rosters
abstract: With many of the biggest names already traded, the flurry of deals in the final hours before the nonwaiver deadline mostly helped contenders round out their rosters.
lead_paragraph: The shelves were not exactly empty for general managers on Friday, but the snazziest items were already gone. The flurry of deals in the final hours before the nonwaiver deadline mostly helped contenders at the margins of their rosters.

headline: The Glow of the Special Olympics
abstract: Athletes from around the world competed in Los Angeles this week.
lead_paragraph: Athletes from around the world competed in Los Angeles this week.

headline: Special Olympics and the Burden of Happiness
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Intellectual Disabilities', 'Discrimination', 'Special Olympics', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: Behind all the sports and smiles is an urgent human rights mission.
lead_paragraph: When Special Olympics athletes get their medals — and the competitions are designed so that many, many do — the music swells, they pump their fists and their parents and teammates clap and yell. At the 2015 Special Olympics World Games across Los Angeles this week, the medals ceremonies went on for hours, a cascade of triumphant moments, one after another after another.

headline: Woman Arrested After Jumping Over White House Barricade

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A woman was arrested on Friday evening after she jumped over a barricade in front of the White House fence, a spokesman for the Secret Service said.

keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: By court order, the State Department released the second cache of emails that Mrs. Clinton sent and received during her tenure in President Obama’s cabinet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new batch of emails released on Friday portray Hillary Rodham Clinton when she was secretary of state, dealing with everything from political unrest in Honduras and a freeze on Israeli settlements in the Palestinian territories to minor details of her schedule and even a shipment of apples to her office.

headline: Concern Mixes With Trust Issues for Sheldon Richardson
abstract: For the third consecutive day, the Jets were forced to discuss the questionable decision-making of one of their best players, defensive lineman Sheldon Richardson.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first eight minutes of Coach Todd Bowles’s news conference on Friday were devoted to a subject he had thought he would not have to address again. Willie Colon answered questions about it, as did Brandon Marshall and Damon Harrison.

headline: Should We Charge Patients for Medical Research?
keywords: ['Research', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Medicine and Health', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: It could subsidize promising experiments. But is it ethical?
lead_paragraph: A FEW months ago, we got a call from a former oncology professor of ours. He had developed an experimental precision diagnostic test that he thought would be able to determine which chemotherapies would be most effective against a patient’s cancer. He wanted to conduct a research trial to evaluate the effectiveness of the new test. But there was one big problem: The research had no funding.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Spent Millions Before Candidates Announced, Filings Show
abstract: Acting as shadow campaigns, the political committees backing the major presidential candidates supported them with tens of millions of dollars in chartered planes, luxury hotel suites, opposition research, high-priced lawyers and more, spending reports showed Friday.
lead_paragraph: Acting as shadow campaigns, the political committees backing the major presidential candidates supported them with tens of millions of dollars in chartered planes, luxury hotel suites, opposition research, high-priced lawyers and more, spending reports showed Friday.

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For all the hype surrounding the Yankees’ top prospects, the nonwaiver trading deadline was an opportunity to test the patience and resolve of a franchise that has rarely been known for either.

lead_paragraph: Rowdy Roddy Piper, a professional wrestler whose athleticism and antics in the ring helped raise the profile of World Wrestling Entertainment in the 1980s, has died, his agent said on Friday. He was 61.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) BIRDMAN OR (THE UNEXPECTED VIRTUE OF IGNORANCE) (2014) Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton, in an Oscar-nominated performance), a washed-up Hollywood superhero, floats down to earth to deliver himself from his past by staging a Broadway adaptation of a Raymond Carver short story. Then a pompous theater actor (Edward Norton) comes along and threatens to steal the show. Riggan’s fresh-from-rehab daughter (Emma Stone) has taken on the role of his assistant. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this best-picture winner “a funny, frenetic, buoyant and rambunctiously showboating entertainment” in which the director Alejandro G. Iñárritu “himself rises high and then higher still.” Riggan, Mr. Scott added, “isn’t the only man on the move: So is Mr. Iñárritu, who has staged and shot the movie so that it looks like everything that happens, from airborne beginning to end, occurs during one transporting continuous take. The camera doesn’t just move with the story and characters, it also ebbs and flows like water, soars and swoops like a bird, its movement as fluid as a natural element, as animated as a living organism.” Mr. Iñárritu won the Oscar for best director, and Emmanuel Lubezki for cinematography.

headline: Tibetan Who Called for Dalai Lama’s Return Is Said to Be Freed From Chinese Prison
abstract: Runggye Adak was jailed for eight years after calling for the spiritual leader’s return to Tibet in a speech at a major festival.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Tibetan man who was imprisoned for eight years after calling for the Dalai Lama’s return to Tibet at a popular festival has been released, according to overseas Tibet advocacy groups.

headline: Mark Karpeles, Chief of Bankrupt Bitcoin Exchange, Is Arrested in Tokyo
abstract: The police said they believed Mr. Karpeles had manipulated transaction records on a computer system that Mt. Gox used to swap Bitcoins for dollars.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Since the collapse last year of Mt. Gox, the exchange that served as the largest hub for storing and trading the virtual currency Bitcoin, law enforcement officials and angry clients have been asking what happened to nearly half a billion dollars in Bitcoins that the company said had vanished from its computer systems.

headline: Turning Point: Hilary Swift
abstract: In the midst of a street protest, a young photographer learned the value of staying close and sticking to the story.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Swift, a photography intern with The New York Times, has previously worked for the Reno Gazette-Journal in Nevada and The Free Lance-Star in Virginia. Ms. Swift, 22, participated in the 2014 Eddie Adams Workshop and the 2015 New York Portfolio Review. Her conversation with Elijah Walker has been edited.

lead_paragraph: I didn’t think much about it at the time: I was appearing in a short television segment and had quickly brushed my hair, then slapped on some concealer. I figured my glasses would cover the circles under my eyes.

headline: My Dinner With Longevity Expert Dan Buettner (No Kale Required)
abstract: The “Blue Zones Solution” author, an expert on the diets of people who live to age 100, prepares a meal for a reporter who lives on cheeseburgers and martinis.
lead_paragraph: Dan Buettner and I were off to a good start. He approved of coffee.

headline: Censure and Clashes After West Bank Attack
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'ARSON', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Palestinians clashed with Israeli forces while thousands of Israelis flocked to rallies, all of them protesting a firebombing that killed a Palestinian toddler.
lead_paragraph: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — Palestinian youths clashed with Israeli forces while thousands of Israelis flocked to rallies, all of them protesting an arson attack that killed a Palestinian toddler — a rare instance of mutual shock in a land attuned to bitter violence.

headline: A Late Summer Night’s Dream on Michigan’s Mackinac Island
abstract: The island’s Mission Point Resort is offering a Shakespearean-themed package from Aug. 27 to 31.
lead_paragraph: New at Mission Point Resort on Mackinac Island in Michigan will be a Shakespearean-themed two-night package from Aug. 27 to 31 called “Stratford on the Straits.”

headline: 120 Degrees and No Relief? ISIS Takes Back Seat for Iraqis
abstract: One of the country’s largest recent grass-roots protests shut down traffic in Baghdad on Friday night, and more protests took place Saturday in southern Iraq.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In the Iraqi summer, when the temperature rises above 120 degrees Fahrenheit, electricity becomes even more of a political issue than usual. This past week, at the top of Iraqis’ agenda, it has even eclipsed war with the Islamic State.

headline: U.S. Declassifies FISA Court Documents about the Protect America Act
keywords: ['Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the Obama administration has declassified and released documents related to the Protect America Act in late 2007 and early 2008. The documents fill in a gap in the historical record regarding the evolution of the Bush administration’s post-9/11 warrantless surveillance program.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the Obama administration has declassified and released documents related to the Protect America Act in late 2007 and early 2008. The documents fill in a gap in the historical record regarding the evolution of the Bush administration’s post-9/11 warrantless surveillance program.

headline: Hot Hot Hot
abstract: Welcome to the August 2015 edition of the Times Insider crossword pack.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — It’s hot outside. You want to be either poolside or, lacking a pool, somewhere in air-conditioning with a cool beverage and a crossword puzzle. So let’s get to it: We have four puzzles that may or may not take your mind off the heat.

headline: New Orleans Hospital Is Replaced, With Hope of Preserving Its Mission
abstract: Charity Hospital, which was ruined by Hurricane Katrina, has been replaced with a $1.1 billion hospital, but there are concerns over whether it will continue its history of serving the poor.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — After Hurricane Katrina, the shrunken medical staff of the state-owned Charity Hospital worked out of tents, an abandoned Lord & Taylor department store and eventually a cramped interim hospital with scaled-back services. As best they could, they continued Charity’s centuries-old mission of caring for poor and uninsured residents, mostly black, whom other hospitals typically turned away.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Review: Twitter Problems
abstract: Two technology journalists from The New York Times assess the week’s major news stories from Silicon Valley, including earnings announcements from Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: We are trying something new. Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, will review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe even a few jokes about the most important developments in the industry.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Puns and Anagrams with Mel Taub.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — For those of you just joining us, the deal here is that this particular variety puzzle looks like a crossword and it smells like a crossword (seriously; put your nose right against the paper or screen), but it is only a crossword in the sense that it crosses words.

headline: Small Pool of Rich Donors Dominates Election Giving
abstract: Presidential candidates have grown deeply dependent on the contributions of a tiny slice of the richest Americans as “super PACs” have raised money much more quickly than hopefuls could have on their own.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than four hundred families are responsible for almost half the money raised in the 2016 presidential campaign, a concentration of political donors that is unprecedented in the modern era.

headline: Joel S. Marcus on Taking the Ego Out of Leading
abstract: The chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities talks about the value of trying to let employees persuade you when you’re making decisions.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Joel S. Marcus, chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Providing the Soundtrack for Life’s Last Moments
abstract: A harpist makes it her mission to use the strains of beautiful music to ease the strain of the final days for the dying and their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been called an angel more times than I care to admit. That’s what happens when you walk down hospital hallways with a harp and have a job that primarily serves people who are dying.

abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: The Treat That Could Bite Your Dog Back
abstract: Problems have been reported with a brand of shrink-wrapped dog bone, but the real problem may be that all bones can represent a hazard to dogs.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler chatted recently with a woman named Muriel Mateer, who did something in late July that nearly had disastrous consequences: She gave her dog a bone. Specifically, she gave her dog a Real Ham Bone, a shrink-wrapped canine treat that is, in fact, a real pork femur, made by Dynamic Pet Products of Washington, Mo.

headline: Mets’ Relationship With Yoenis Cespedes? It’s a Rental
abstract: Even if Cespedes leads the Mets to the playoffs for the first time since 2006, the trade with Detroit may not be viewed as a long-term success.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ union with Yoenis Cespedes seems certain to be brief. Cespedes, the slugging outfielder acquired for two prospects on Friday, is a free agent after this season. The Mets have three other outfielders signed for 2016 and an aversion to the kind of lavish deal Cespedes will command.

headline: Converse Treads Carefully in Updating Well-Worn Chuck Taylor Brand
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Sneakers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The classic All Star has been a boon to Nike, which bought Converse in 2003. But as the shoe gets an update, the company is being cautious not to damage its appeal.
lead_paragraph: Nike came out with a new product last Tuesday, an updated and — for my feet — more comfortable version of an old canvas basketball sneaker known as the Converse Chuck Taylor All Star.

headline: Flooding Spurs Disaster Zones in Myanmar
abstract: President Thein Sein declared four regions in western and central Myanmar as disaster zones as the government continued to face criticism for its slow response to floods and landslides across the country.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Myanmar’s president on Friday declared four rural regions to be disaster zones, as floods and landslides continued to cause severe damage and the government faced criticism for its slow response to the emergency.

headline: Former White Sox Organist’s Offbeat Approach Resonated for Decades
abstract: The former Chicago White Sox organist Nancy Faust’s tradition of playing each player’s state song apparently began the long, surprisingly intricate history of walk-up music.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, just before she was hired as the organist for the Chicago White Sox, Nancy Faust received a letter from a team official.

headline: Vahé Alaverdian
abstract: A master falconer on telemetry, living off the land and the romance of the American South.
lead_paragraph: Vahé Alaverdian is a master falconer whose company, Falcon Force, has a staff of more than 30 raptors, which are used to scare off, but not kill, nuisance birds (starlings, gulls, pigeons, etc.) at vineyards, farms, airports, historical sites and amusement parks.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ and the Republican Hopefuls
abstract: Brash characters abound in the musical “Hamilton” and the Republican debate.
lead_paragraph: HOW fitting that the Republican presidential candidates will hold their first debate this Thursday on the same night as the Broadway opening of “Hamilton,” the groundbreaking new musical about the founding fathers. At a time when so many American politicians are sanitized, cautious, even boring, the characters on the debate stage and the Broadway stage are remarkably in sync: brazen, unpredictable, even outrageous.

headline: Republican Hypocrisy on Iran
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Opponents of the nuclear deal have turned what should have been a thoughtful debate into a vicious battle against President Obama.
lead_paragraph: The exaggerations and half-truths that some Republicans are using to derail  President Obama‘s important and necessary nuclear deal with Iran are beyond ugly. Invoking the Holocaust, Mike Huckabee, a contender for the Republican presidential nomination, has accused Mr. Obama of marching Israelis “to the door of the oven.” Tom Cotton, a senator from Arkansas, has compared Secretary of State John Kerry, who helped negotiate the deal, to Pontius Pilate.

headline: How to Fight Doping in Sports
abstract: To win back trust in sports, athletes must be much more transparent about their biological, physiological and performance data.
lead_paragraph: FEW sports performances are regarded without suspicion these days. Nowhere was this more evident than in the recent Tour de France, where the winner, Chris Froome of the British Team Sky, spent three weeks responding to skeptics about his exceptional performances, which rivaled those of doped champions, including Lance Armstrong.

headline: Is New Orleans Safe?
abstract: The state’s master plan could avert a watery demise. But it would cost many billions.
lead_paragraph: New Orleans — THIS city always had a different rhythm. It was the opposite of New York: After a stevedore was overheard saying, “If you can’t make it in the Big Easy, you can’t make it anywhere,” the phrase “The Big Easy” made its way from the African-American community into Newsweek, and spread. For decades, the city’s ambitious young men and women loved it yet fled, while those who did move here found places for themselves in existing spaces, slipping into its crevices, embracing it.

headline: President Obama’s Racial Renaissance
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How our first black president can leave black Americans better off.
lead_paragraph: WE finally have the president we thought we elected: one who talks directly and forcefully about race and human rights.

headline: Palm Oil Company Is Accused of Exploiting Liberia’s Ebola Crisis
keywords: ['Palm Oil', 'Ebola Virus', 'Land Use Policies', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: During the height of the Ebola outbreak, a community signed over large swaths of farming land. Now, some are questioning the benefits, and ethics, of the deal.
lead_paragraph: KABADA, Liberia — Standing in his garden, Alex Wloh wistfully cradled a few ears of corn in his hands. A mile or so away, field workers had been planting palm seedlings where he and his fellow villagers used to grow crops like rice, cassava and vegetables.

headline: Congress Should Look Beyond the Gas Tax
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: If lawmakers want to improve the country’s deteriorating highways, bridges and mass transit systems, they will have to get creative.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Washington are so scared of raising the inadequate federal gas tax that they keep passing short-term bills to move money from other taxes to fund transportation projects. They should develop the kind of courage legislatures in red states like Utah, Nebraska and South Dakota have shown and raise the gas tax.

headline: Why the Economy Is Not Ready for an Interest Rate Increase
abstract: The Fed’s misplaced optimism sends the wrong message to Americans who are still not getting ahead.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve talked up the economy last Wednesday, in a statement that emphasized improvements in employment, housing and consumer spending. Unfortunately, the optimism is misplaced.

headline: A New Abortion Furor
abstract: Readers discuss the Planned Parenthood officials caught on video and how Republicans are handling the abortion issue.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the videos of officials at Planned Parenthood discussing fetal tissue.

headline: Joe Biden Said to Be Taking New Look at Presidential Run
abstract: The vice president’s advisers are reaching out to Democrats who have not yet committed to Hillary Rodham Clinton or are concerned she is vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his associates have begun to actively explore a possible presidential campaign, which would upend the Democratic field and deliver a direct threat to Hillary Rodham Clinton, several people who have spoken to Mr. Biden or his closest advisers say.

headline: Our Sex-Crazed Congress
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases']
abstract: House Republicans want to kill a family planning program that prevents abortions and saves lives.
lead_paragraph: TO appreciate the dumbing down of American politics, consider this: Conservative Republicans, indignant about abortion, are trying to destroy a government program that helps prevent 345,000 abortions a year.

headline: The Tortured Tale of Hillary Clinton and The Times
abstract: The Times began paying close attention to Hillary Clinton long before she declared for the presidency, and many of her supporters are not happy.
lead_paragraph: The history of the Clintons and The New York Times over the decades is like an airport baggage carousel — with a difference. New pieces keep barreling down the chute, but none of it ever seems to get removed.

headline: The Donald’s Gifts for Jeb Bush
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The former governor may be the biggest beneficiary of Trump’s splash into the Republican presidential candidate pool.
lead_paragraph: THE most important question of the moment, as the Republican Party prepares for the first of 1,162 or so presidential primary debates, isn’t really what Donald Trump will say or do on stage.

headline: Grand Jury Indicts Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, on Felony Charges
abstract: Mr. Paxton has been charged by a grand jury in connection with securities fraud and with failing to register with the state securities board.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ken Paxton, the Republican attorney general of Texas and a former state legislator, has been indicted by a grand jury on charges of securities fraud and of failing to register with the state securities board, officials said.

headline: Giants Undertake Major Renovation Projects on Both Sides of the Ball
abstract: The 2015 renovation may be the final chance for Coach Tom Coughlin, who brought back Steve Spagnuolo, the architect of the team’s Super Bowl-winning defense in the 2007 season, to help.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — There are still four Super Bowl trophies in a shimmering case just inside the front door of the Giants’ offices and training complex. Thirty-foot banners commemorating those defining victories dominate the indoor practice grounds.

headline: Taliban Leader Urges Unity, Playing Down Peace Talk
abstract: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, the Taliban’s new leader, declared that “jihad would continue” in Afghanistan in an audio recording released Saturday, though his message contained signs of hope for the Afghan government and Western diplomats.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two days after acknowledging that its supreme commander, Mullah Muhammad Omar, was dead, the Taliban released an audio recording said to be from the group’s new leader.

headline: Ohio State’s Ascent Reinvigorates the Big Ten
abstract: As the Big Ten football teams gathered in Chicago last week to preview the season, the implied understanding was that the road to the conference championship will go through Columbus, Ohio, again.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In January, the Big Ten felt united as perhaps never before. After years of perceived decline in its signature sport, football, the conference had seen its champion — Ohio State — become the first league team to play for the national title since the 2007 season, and the first to win one since the 2002 season.

headline: Aja Zanova, Top Czech Skater Who Defected to West, Dies at 84
abstract: Zanova was a world champion figure skater whose defection from Czechoslovakia as a teenager in 1950 made headlines around the world.
lead_paragraph: Aja Zanova, a world champion figure skater whose defection from Czechoslovakia as a teenager in 1950 made headlines around the world, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 84.

headline: In Case You Missed It: Top Articles of the Week
abstract: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 24 to July 30.
lead_paragraph: Catch up with the most-read sports stories in The New York Times from July 24 to July 30.

keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Olympic Games', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Testosterone', 'Gender', 'Halls of Fame']
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Missing the Point in a Biological Controversy

headline: Bronx Residents Anxious After 4th Death From Legionnaires’ Disease
abstract: As the number of cases climbed to 65, city officials said tests revealed the outsides of five building were contaminated.
lead_paragraph: The largest outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in New York City in at least three years has claimed its fourth victim, health officials said on Saturday, reinforcing concerns among some residents and elected leaders that the city had not adequately prepared to combat the airborne illness.

headline: Highly Coordinated
abstract: When “don’t look down” isn’t an option.
lead_paragraph: When “don’t look down” isn’t an option.

headline: A.& P. Bankruptcy Means New York, Chain’s Birthplace, Will Lose Last Store
abstract: Once the company’s plan for liquidating is approved, the A.&P. on Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx will shut. And the chain, born just before the Civil War, will vanish from New York.
lead_paragraph: Linda Fisch stopped at the A.&P. on Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx on Thursday and bought eight prepackaged containers of cottage cheese and fruit. She did not realize the store had become a footnote to history.

headline: In Compromise, Pro Football Hall of Fame Offers to let Junior Seau’s Daughter Speak at Ceremony
abstract: Bowing to pressure from fans and media, the Hall of Fame will allow Sydney Seau to be interviewed onstage, but not allowed to give a speech, when her father’s bronze bust is unveiled during an induction ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Sydney Seau may speak after all — sort of.

headline: Inflation Paranoia as a Tribal Marker
abstract: Wrong is right, derp is truth.
lead_paragraph: Derp — views that just keep being repeated in the face of overwhelming contrary evidence — has always been with us, but the derp quotient has really soared since the crisis of 2008, which made nonsense of doctrines too dearly held to be reconsidered. This is especially true of inflation derp: has any prominent figure who warned of runaway inflation from the Fed’s efforts admitted having learned anything from being wrong year after year?

headline: Dr. James Jude, Who Helped Develop Use of CPR, Dies at 87
abstract: Dr. Jude was a resident at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine when he recognized that external manual pressure could revive a stalled heart, a discovery that led to the widespread use of CPR.
lead_paragraph: Dr. James Jude, a thoracic surgeon whose recognition that external manual pressure could revive a stalled heart, and who used that insight to help develop the lifesaving technique now known as cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, died on Tuesday at his home in Coral Gables, Fla. He was 87.

headline: Literally Speaking
abstract: Matt Ginsberg wants us to take him literally.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — A very literal puzzle today from Matt Ginsberg, where the circled squares do exactly what the entire phrase describes. I do love an obedient crossword puzzle.

headline: After Deal, Europeans Are Eager to Do Business in Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The rush to restart trade with Iran could make it more complicated to renew sanctions if the nuclear deal brokered by the United States falls apart.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Before the ink was even dry on the Iran nuclear deal, European leaders and executives were heading to the airport to restart trade with an Iranian market described in almost feverish terms as “an El Dorado” and potential “bonanza.”

headline: Dry Days Bring Ferocious Start to Fire Season
abstract: Officials are warning about the potential for more catastrophe in the months ahead, as drought, heat and climate change leave the landscape ever thirstier.
lead_paragraph: WALLA WALLA, Wash. — Another summer of record-breaking drought and heat has seized the West, setting off costly and destructive wildfires from Southern California, where a single blaze burned more than 30,000 acres of national forest east of Los Angeles, to Montana, where a fast-moving fire in Glacier National Park recently forced tourists to flee hotels, campgrounds and vehicles.

headline: Laos, Destination in Illegal Ivory Trade, So Far Eludes Global Crackdown
abstract: International efforts to curb illegal trade are not impacting Laos, where criminal gangs are said to take advantage of the weak rule of law and officials are thought to profit from trafficking.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — When the authorities in Thailand recently intercepted huge stashes of ivory stuffed inside shipments of beans and tea leaves, the seizures were described as groundbreaking international police work.

headline: Bay Area’s Disjointed Public Transit Network Inspires a Call for Harmony
abstract: A recent study recommended a variety of changes to the region’s convoluted network of transportation systems, but a uniform overhaul has been difficult to achieve.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There is much to relish about the Bay Area, from the intoxicating landscape to the blissful lack of humidity.

headline: Inquiry Faults Huma Abedin, Close Aide to Hillary Clinton
abstract: The State Department inspector general has determined that Ms. Abedin, the close confidant of Mrs. Clinton, must return more than $9,000 for overpayments she received during her time working for the department under Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department inspector general has determined that Huma Abedin, the close confidant of Hillary Rodham Clinton, must return more than $9,000 for alleged overpayments made to her during her time working for the department when Mrs. Clinton was secretary of state, according to her lawyer and Senate documents.

headline: Jets Offer Support and Tough Love to Sheldon Richardson
abstract: Mike Maccagnan, general manager for the Jets, said “a level of trust” was damaged when Richardson failed to tell the team about his July 14 arrest.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The first few days of Mike Maccagnan’s first training camp as the Jets’ general manager had been largely quiet — except for Sheldon Richardson’s latest off-the-field infractions, Muhammad Wilkerson’s simmering contract dispute and Devin Smith’s broken ribs.

headline: Medical Marijuana Dispensary Plan in the South Bronx Stirs Anxiety and Hope
abstract: Residents and community leaders are asking whether it will provide an economic boost to the Hunts Point neighborhood or become a magnet for trouble.
lead_paragraph: The Hunts Point neighborhood in the South Bronx has struggled to clean up its act for years. Prostitution is still a problem, but it is far less prevalent, residents say, than it once was.

headline: Enigmatic Cespedes Is Charged With Lighting Up New York Again
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes, one of baseball’s most exciting players, who is tasked with reinvigorating a lackluster franchise, has been described as quirky but infectious.
lead_paragraph: The first time Yoenis Cespedes walked through the Mets’ clubhouse, he made an impression, intentional or not. He gave firm handshakes, looked his new teammates in the eye and introduced himself. He wore a necklace with a pendant the size of a baseball that showed his number, 52.

headline: Buddy Emmons, Virtuoso of the Steel Guitar, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Emmons, an in-demand and influential performer, was also responsible for the evolution of his instrument.
lead_paragraph: Buddy Emmons, the inventive musician who reimagined and popularized the pedal steel guitar in jazz, country, and western swing bands beginning in the mid-1950s, performing with many of music’s biggest stars, died on July 21 in Hermitage, Tenn., near Nashville. He was 78.

headline: Training Officers to Shoot First, and He Will Answer Questions Later
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Firearms']
abstract: When police officers shoot people under questionable circumstances, William J. Lewinski often appears as an expert witness who says they had no choice but to fire.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The shooting looked bad. But that is when the professor is at his best. A black motorist, pulled to the side of the road for a turn-signal violation, had stuffed his hand into his pocket. The white officer yelled for him to take it out. When the driver started to comply, the officer shot him dead.

headline: Preparing for Debate, Republicans Test Themselves Against Donald Trump
abstract: The Republican rivals of Donald J. Trump are determined not to let the encounter on Thursday become about him.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush is spending hours in sessions from Florida to Maine preparing policy answers for Thursday’s first Republican debate — but he is also being mindful to avert any display of disdain for the man he will stand beside, Donald J. Trump, who has infuriated Mr. Bush by criticizing Mexican immigrants. (Mr. Bush is married to one.)

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Makes His Presence Felt, Indirectly, in a Win
abstract: The Mets hypothesized that pitching to Cespedes would require so much attention from opponents that their other batters would benefit. Lucas Duda hit behind Cespedes on Saturday, and crushed two home runs.
lead_paragraph: The Citi Field crowd leapt from its seats and threw up its hands and roared in anticipation, watching a screaming line drive jump off Yoenis Cespedes’s bat. The second-largest crowd in the park’s history, 42,996 fans, had come to watch his Mets debut. He had been heralded as their offensive savior, and a home run would tie the score in the sixth inning.

headline: Stepping From Class AAA to Majors, Young Yankees Pitchers Can’t Deliver
abstract: Bryan Mitchell and Diego Moreno, the two young pitchers the Yankees turned to instead of making a trade, were not ready for their opportunity in a loss to Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When General Manager Brian Cashman decided he did not want to trade his top prospects for the starting pitchers his first-place team needs at the moment, it was a show of faith in the farm system, particularly the pitchers he will be counting on now.

headline: Obama to Unveil Tougher Environmental Plan With His Legacy in Mind
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The rules are meant to sharply cut planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions from power plants and ultimately transform America’s electricity industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the strongest action ever taken in the United States to combat climate change, President Obama will unveil on Monday a set of environmental regulations devised to sharply cut planet-warming greenhouse gas emissions from the nation’s power plants and ultimately transform America’s electricity industry.

headline: Mary Williams, Abraham Clayman

Miller and Robert S. Clayman of Bethesda, Md. Timothy J. Reilly, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Vermont secretary of state to solemnize the marriage, officiated at the vacation home of the bride’s mother in South Londonderry, Vt.

headline: Alisa Rashish, John Segal: A Life of Bicycles, Built for Two
abstract: After two near misses in two different parks, it took a mutual friend to bring them together.

headline: Why Some Start-Ups Are Called Tech Companies and Others Are Not
abstract: For as long as there has been a commercial Internet, there has been fuzziness about what is or is not a tech company. And the question has only become more complicated with the rise of start-ups like Uber that deliver real-world services aided by technology.
lead_paragraph: After Charles Lindbergh flew across the Atlantic in 1927, a company called Seaboard Air Line Railroad attracted an unusual amount of attention from investors who thought it was in the aviation business.

headline: Copwatch vs. Cops: After Freddie Gray
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'Cameras']
abstract: In a year of violent police encounters, a 25-year-old movement to document law enforcement has new urgency. This is the story of Copwatch as told by Michael Brown’s neighbor and Freddie Gray’s friend.
lead_paragraph: In a year of violent police encounters, a 25-year-old movement to document law enforcement has new urgency. This is the story of Copwatch as told by Michael Brown’s neighbor and Freddie Gray’s friend.

headline: Six Things Google Remembers About My Parenting That I’d Almost Forgotten
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: A mother’s search history is the Internet version of “This Is Your Life.”
lead_paragraph: I’ve been a parent for six years. That is six short years full of long days. Our children are born tiny, helpless, things, then we blink and they’re fully formed human beings, and we can hardly remember what it was like when they didn’t sleep, pee or pretty much do anything the way we thought they should. Or at least, we can’t remember what it is they used to not do the way we thought they should, because we are so caught up in whatever it is they’re doing or not doing now.

lead_paragraph: In a year of violent police encounters, much of the conversation has been about cameras: Who should have them, what can they achieve and how can they improve the broken relationship between the police and African-American communities?

headline: Stephen Harper of Canada, Hoping to Extend Conservatives’ Hold, Calls Elections
abstract: The prime minister broke with political tradition by formally opening the campaign in the middle of summer during what is a holiday weekend in most of the country.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada called federal elections on Sunday, hoping to extend his Conservative Party’s decade-long hold on power despite questions about its ethics and a struggling economy.

headline: 1965: Fists Fly in Athens Assembly
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A session in the Greek Parliament turns rowdy.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In its second attempt in three days, Premier George Athanasiades-Novas’s government tonight got the quorum it has been seeking to submit itself to a confidence debate in Parliament. But it did so in a session marked by fist fights and efforts to drag Foreign Minister George Melas down from the rostrum where he had been speaking. Police were called in to protect the minister from anti-government deputies who claimed he had abused one of their members.

headline: Iran Capitalizing on a Taste for America’s Biggest Brands
abstract: “We’re trying to get as close as we can to the McDonald’s experience,” says the owner of Mash Donald’s, one of an increasing number of Iranian knockoffs of American food culture.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Despite the smiling clown, a symbol of the Great Satan’s love for meat, buns and fries, there were no angry mobs punching fists in the air, shouting “Death to America”; nor did the smell of burned American flags permeate this Tehran neighborhood.

headline: Tiny Island of Réunion Awash in Intrigue Over Vanished Malaysian Plane
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Ever since what could be a part from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was found, just about every piece of flotsam on the island has attracted scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, Réunion — Ever since Johnny Begue and his friend stumbled on a barnacle-encrusted airplane wing flap last week — one that appears to be from the same kind of plane as Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared without a trace more than a year ago — just about every piece of flotsam kicked up along the shores of this island in the Indian Ocean has attracted scrutiny.

lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton took aim at Jeb Bush in her speech at the National Urban League conference in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Friday, it overshadowed a noteworthy address by one of her rivals.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (13) LA DONNA DEL LAGO Joyce DiDonato, above, sings Elena, the lady of the lake, and Juan Diego Flórez is Giacomo, the king of Scotland, in Paul Curran’s staging of this Rossini melodrama, based on the poem by Sir Walter Scott and conducted by Michele Mariotti. “The wondrous Ms. DiDonato and Mr. Mariotti, the fast-rising young Italian conductor, seemed almost in competition to see who could make music with more delicacy,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times of this production from the Metropolitan Opera and the Santa Fe Opera, presented here by “Great Performances at the Met.” “Ms. DiDonato sang Rossini’s beguiling phrases with soft yet penetrating richness, subtly folding ornaments and runs into the long melodic arcs. And Mr. Mariotti drew hushed gentle and transparent playing from the inspired Met orchestra.”

headline: ‘Poster Child’ for New York’s Paid Sick Leave Law Failed to Follow It
abstract: After publicly embracing sick leave, the owner of Bombay Sandwich Company did not pay an ill employee for a missed workday in January.
lead_paragraph: Shiv Puri embraced New York City’s paid sick leave law last year and was heralded as a trailblazer among employers. At City Hall, Mayor Bill de Blasio praised him as “a great example to business owners all across the city.”

keywords: ['Empire State Building (Manhattan, NY)', 'Lighting', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Art', 'Documentary Films and Programs']

lead_paragraph: The artists Louie Psihoyos and Travis Threlkel projected digital images of endangered species onto the Empire State Building in an event meant to draw attention to the creatures’ plight.

headline: 2 Proud Daughters of the Bronx Share More Than a Name
abstract: Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor and the actress Sonia Manzano don’t have to trumpet that they’re from the block, but they want the borough’s children to think bigger.
lead_paragraph: The sounds of summer drifted through the air on the Bronx side of the High Bridge, from the squeals of children running along sun-dappled paths to the slaps of flip-flops hitting the pavement as boys with towels slung over their shoulders walked to the public swimming pool on the Manhattan side. Two women chatting on a bench stopped midsentence as two other women, smiling and familiar looking, ambled past.

headline: Kerry Warns Egypt Human Rights Abuses Can Hurt Fight Against Terrorism
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry told the Egyptian authorities on Sunday that they would not be able to defeat terrorism at home unless they showed greater respect for human rights.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry told Egyptian officials on Sunday that they would not be able to defeat terrorism at home unless they showed greater respect for human rights.

headline: France and Britain Seek Help on Calais Migrants From E.U.
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The interior ministers called on Sunday for other European Union countries to help solve the root causes of the migrant crisis at the port of Calais.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a letter published on Sunday, the interior ministers of Britain and France called on other European Union countries to help solve the underlying causes of the migrant crisis at the port of Calais, where thousands of people have been trying to force their way onto trucks and trains bound for Britain through the tunnel linking the two countries.

headline: Eric Schlosser to Publish Book on American Prison System
abstract: Eric Schlosser, who wrote “Fast Food Nation,” will explore how rising incarceration rates are intertwined with social factors like growing inequality.
lead_paragraph: Eric Schlosser, author of the best-selling exposé of the fast food industry, “Fast Food Nation,” will publish a new book that investigates America’s expanding prison system and explores how rising incarceration rates are intertwined with social factors like growing inequality.

headline: Donald Trump Campaign Fires Adviser Linked to Racially Charged Facebook Posts
abstract: The adviser, Sam Nunberg, had been accused of using a racial slur in posts in 2007 to disparage the daughter of the Rev. Al Sharpton. He denied he was the author of the posts.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has fired a campaign adviser after racially charged Facebook posts under his name emerged last week, Mr. Trump’s campaign manager said.

headline: Review: ‘The Economics of Inequality,’ by Thomas Piketty
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Income Inequality', 'Income', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Mr. Piketty follows up “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” last year’s landmark economic analysis, with a slightly revised version of a book he wrote in 1997.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2001 two French economists, Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez, circulated a seminal research paper (formally published two years later) titled “Income inequality in the United States, 1913-1998.” They used data from income tax receipts to do two things that you can’t do with standard data on the distribution of income, which come from household surveys. First, they gave us a portrait of the economic stratosphere — the incomes of the now-famous 1 percent. Second, they gave us historical depth, reaching all the way back to the late Gilded Age.

headline: Freshwater’s Wrong Turn (Wonkish)
abstract: Hubris did it.
lead_paragraph: Paul Romer has been writing a series of posts on the problem he calls “mathiness”, in which economists write down fairly hard-to-understand mathematical models accompanied by verbal claims that don’t actually match what’s going on in the math. Most recently, he has been recounting the pushback he’s getting from freshwater macro types, who seem him as allying himself with evil people like me — whereas he sees them as having turned away from science toward a legalistic, adversarial form of pleading.

headline: Puerto Ricans Brace for Crisis in Health Care
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: More than 60 percent of Puerto Ricans receive Medicare or Medicaid, but planned cuts to a program and the loss of doctors to the mainland are raising fears that the system is near collapsing.
lead_paragraph: MAYAGÜEZ, P.R. — The first visible sign that the health care system in Puerto Rico was seriously in trouble was when a steady stream of doctors — more than 3,000 in five years — began to leave the island for more lucrative, less stressful jobs on the mainland.

headline: Political Consultant for Uber to Advise Other Start-Ups
abstract: Bradley Tusk, a former campaign manager for New York’s last mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, is starting Tusk Ventures, a political consulting firm geared toward helping start-ups work with — and in some cases, beat back — government regulators.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the ride-hailing app, seems capable of the impossible: fighting City Hall and winning.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Dre will release his first album in 16 years — but it won’t be the much anticipated “Detox.” The album is titled “Compton A Soundtrack by Dr. Dre,” and will be available Aug. 7 on Apple Music.

lead_paragraph: Jerry Berrigan, a Roman Catholic peace activist who, like his better-known brothers Philip and Daniel, was arrested frequently for protesting the Vietnam War and other conflicts, died on July 26 at his home in Syracuse. He was 95.

lead_paragraph: A prominent American gynecologist illegally killed a lion in an authorized hunt this year in Zimbabwe, wildlife authorities there said Sunday.

headline: Giants G.M. Says ‘Heart Goes Out’ to Jason Pierre-Paul
abstract: Jerry Reese offered support for the injured and absent defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul but avoided the subject of Eli Manning’s contract negotiations.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Addressing reporters for the first time since the Giants’ training camp opened last week, General Manager Jerry Reese offered support on Sunday for Jason Pierre-Paul, the defensive end who is absent from camp because of a fireworks accident.

headline: Review: Garth Fagan Dance Honors Geoffrey Holder Along With Carmen de Lavallade
abstract: Lincoln Center Out of Doors hosted a day of events honoring Mr. Holder, who would have been 85 on Saturday, a program that also featured Carmen de Lavallade, his widow.
lead_paragraph: The prodigious dancer, choreographer, painter, designer and actor Geoffrey Holder, who died in October — but not before reportedly dancing on his deathbed — would have been 85 on Saturday. Lincoln Center Out of Doors hosted a day of events in his honor, culminating in a performance by Garth Fagan Dance at Damrosch Park, with a prelude by Mr. Holder’s partner of 59 years, Carmen de Lavallade.

headline: Review: Jeremy Denk in a Full-Blooded Performance at Mostly Mozart
abstract: As part of this event, Jeremy Denk played Brahms’s left-hand arrangement of Bach’s Chaconne in D minor.
lead_paragraph: A Google search for scores written for one hand alone reveals a considerable repertory for each hand. The best-known works are for the left hand, like the concertos by Ravel and Korngold, composed for the pianist Paul Wittgenstein, who lost his right arm in World War I. Injury is often a motivating factor behind such compositions; Scriabin wrote for left hand after an injury to his right. Brahms dedicated his transcription for left hand of the Chaconne in D minor (from Bach’s Partita in D minor for solo violin) to Clara Schumann, who had injured her other hand.

headline: Talking to the Taliban
abstract: Fledgling peace talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban have been postponed indefinitely.
lead_paragraph: Fledgling peace talks between the Afghan government and the Taliban have been postponed indefinitely.

headline: R-Rated Comedies, ‘Vacation’ Among Them, Continue to Struggle
abstract: The underwhelming box-office results for “Vacation” follow poor turnout for raunchy summer comedies like “Entourage,” “Magic Mike XXL” and “Ted 2.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Raunchy comedy is having a rough run at the box office.

headline: Review: Cecilia Bartoli Has Dramatic Depth as ‘Norma’ at Salzburg Festival
abstract: Her performance comes from the incisiveness, colorings and inflections of her singing.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — During the mid-1990s, when Cecilia Bartoli was known for scintillating performances of roles like Rossini’s Cenerentola (Cinderella), the suggestion that this light-voiced mezzo-soprano might take on the daunting title role of Bellini’s “Norma” someday would have seemed absurd. Maria Callas had defined the role for late 20th-century audiences as a supreme test for a fiercely intense, formidable soprano. Some powerhouse mezzo-sopranos, like Shirley Verrett and Grace Bumbry, had made the leap. But a perky Cinderella singing Norma? No way.

headline: Review: Karen Oberlin’s ‘His Aim Is True,’ a Tribute to Elvis Costello
abstract: Ms. Oberlin’s show at Stage 72 at the Triad celebrates Mr. Costello’s work as a cryptic genre unto itself, a code to be cracked or not.
lead_paragraph: Karen Oberlin’s extensively researched, beautifully executed tribute to the music of Elvis Costello answers a question that has been gnawing at me for years: Why have so few of Mr. Costello’s songs achieved the status of modern standards? For all this time, I had assumed that his raw, unwelcoming voice, with its strangulated diction, was the reason. Surely, a better-equipped singer could untangle his knotty lyrics and sharpen the melodic profiles of songs that Mr. Costello presented as impassioned downbeat mystery stories.

headline: Review: ‘Significant Mother’ Puts a Son in an Awkward Situation
abstract: This comedy on CW, about an older woman who is dating her son’s best friend and roommate, is a sex farce with implausible underpinnings.
lead_paragraph: When is progress the opposite of progress? When it’s “Significant Mother,” a new comedy on CW that tried for the cutting edge but ended up dull and dimwitted.

headline: Review: ‘Beats of the Antonov’ Examines Sudan’s Civil Wars
abstract: Part of PBS’s “POV” series and directed by Hajooj Kuka, this film offers a close-up look at the wars and frames them as battles over cultural identity.
lead_paragraph: In a recent series of opinion columns filed from the Nuba Mountains in southern Sudan, Nicholas Kristof of The New York Times decried the lack of attention paid to the Sudanese government’s brutal daily bombing of its own people. As if in response, on Monday PBS’s “POV” documentary series presents “Beats of the Antonov,” a film shot on the front lines of Sudan’s continuing civil wars.

headline: Seattle Art Fair Receives a Boost From Tech’s Big Spenders
abstract: Dealers at the inaugural fair wanted to harness the newfound wealth of the tech class, and curators hoped to highlight a connection between Pacific Northwest and Pacific Rim culture and artists.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Paul Allen came ready to shop. Mr. Allen, a billionaire co-founder of Microsoft and one of this city’s major cultural patrons, strolled the aisles of the inaugural Seattle Art Fair on Thursday, looking to add to his formidable art collection.

headline: Review: License and Restriction in a Work by La Monte Young at Dia Chelsea
abstract: Four cellists and eight trumpeters performed a 90-minute work by the Minimalist composer within “Dream House,” a four-walled installation at Dia Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Some kind of tension, real or metaphorical, is primary for the life force of any music. La Monte Young’s music can have lots of tension with very few notes, and the performance of one of his early pieces at Dia: Chelsea’s “Dream House” on Friday had it in every aspect of its experience.

headline: Robin Phillips, Director, Dies at 75; Revitalized Canada’s Stratford Festival
abstract: Mr. Phillips, a British theater director, added productions and brought in stars like Maggie Smith during his tenure as artistic director in the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Robin Phillips, a British theater director who helped rejuvenate Canada’s best-known theater, the Stratford Festival, as artistic director from 1975 to 1980, died on July 25 in Woodstock, Ontario. He was 75.

headline: Finland Unnerved by Trial of Police Detective on Drug Charges
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Drug Cartels', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Smuggling']
abstract: The case of the head of Helsinki’s police antidrug squad accused of running his own drug cartel has shocked a nation that prides itself on its moral uprightness.
lead_paragraph: Members of Finland’s National Bureau of Investigation were working to crack a drug smuggling ring, when they intercepted phone calls and text messages between a suspected supplier and buyer emanating from Pasila, a district of Helsinki.

headline: American Pharoah Wins Haskell Invitational
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Haskell Invitational']
abstract: American Pharoah, the first Triple Crown champion in 37 years, became the eighth horse to win his next start after sweeping the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont.
lead_paragraph: OCEANPORT, N.J. — Victor Espinoza was curious as he gave American Pharoah his head and let the colt slingshot around the far turn at Monmouth Park, a charming racetrack on the Jersey Shore. Espinoza peeked beneath one shoulder, glanced over the other, then narrowed his eyes between his colt’s ears and stared down the stretch.

headline: Toward the Back of a Ship
abstract: Our new job is to find David Steinberg a girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Ladies and gentlemen, I beg of you: We need to find David Steinberg a girlfriend. Somebody nice, who appreciates a young man who has a way with words. Because if you read his notes, they are infused with an ACHE and a LONGing that, frankly, are starting to make me weep. So if you have a lovely niece or daughter who is single and of college age, please let me know.

headline: A Resurgent Didi Gregorius Helps the Yankees Pound the White Sox
abstract: Gregorius, who had the unenviable task of replacing Derek Jeter, drove in two runs and scored twice on Sunday, and he is batting .472 in his last 11 games.

abstract: Seattle’s Ramu Tokashiki, the third Japanese woman to play in the W.N.B.A. and the most successful yet, has become a growing fan favorite.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — The first English word the Japanese forward Ramu Tokashiki learned from her Seattle Storm teammates is unprintable here. Used in jest, it has become Tokashiki’s favorite saying. But another favorite English word is “confidence,” something she has built during her first W.N.B.A. season. Tokashiki has become one of the league’s best rookies and a blooming fan favorite, while hoping to change the perception of women’s basketball in Japan.

headline: Greece’s Market Reopens, European Banks Report Results, and Tesla Announces Earnings
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Company Reports', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: This week the Athens Stock Exchange reopens, several of Europe’s biggest banks will report their first-half results, and Tesla Motors will announce its second-quarter earnings.
lead_paragraph: The Athens Stock Exchange reopened on Monday after a five-week closure that followed a decision by the Greek authorities to shut Greek banks and impose capital controls. The banks reopened two weeks ago, though restrictions on cash transactions remain in place to avert a run on the banks’ deposits. To prevent capital flight, a mass sell-off of holdings and a market crash, there is a cap on stock fluctuations and restrictions on local traders, though foreign investors will face no constraints when stock trading resumes. The reopening of Greece’s market comes as government officials and representatives of the country’s international creditors enter a second week of difficult negotiations on a multibillion-euro bailout, Greece’s third in five years. —Niki Kitsantonis

headline: Picky Eating in Children Linked to Anxiety, Depression and A.D.H.D.
abstract: In some children, finicky eating habits may be part of a more complicated psychological story.
lead_paragraph: For the last several months, my 3-year-old daughter Annika has been on a steady diet of waffles, yogurt sticks and milk. Before that, she ate mainly hot dogs and milk. And for many months before that, she ate almost nothing but fruit-and-yogurt squeezers and, you guessed it, milk. While I haven’t exactly been thrilled with her eating habits, I recognize that in life, and in parenting, we need to pick our battles. And the food battle is one I had chosen not to fight in full force. I had purposefully avoided putting too much pressure on Annika to eat a wider variety of foods because I thought that might backfire and make things worse. I also figured she would branch out eventually, as my older daughter had. But a new study, published in the journal Pediatrics, made me wonder if I should rethink my strategy.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 A.M. (TMC) HAPPY-GO-LUCKY (2008) The irrepressible optimism of a 30-year-old London schoolteacher (Sally Hawkins, above) grates on those whose days she’s intent on brightening up — among them, her driving instructor (Eddie Marsan), flamenco teacher (Karina Fernandez) and sister (Caroline Martin) — in this character study directed and written by Mike Leigh, which earned him an Oscar nomination for best original screenplay. Ms. Hawkins’s portrayal is “glorious,” a “gurgling, burbling stream of gasps, giggles and words,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Leigh has a documentarian’s eye for unadorned reality — his people and places look equally lived in — and his dialogue has the ebb and flow, the swells and eddies and logjams of ordinary conversation,” she added. “But the dramatist in Mr. Leigh is always hard at work, aligning his characters for maximum narrative effect and emotional pow.”

That’s Just My RBF,” about the struggles associated with having a face that, when at ease, seems to others angry, irritated or simply expressionless, inspired over 2,200 comments on nytimes.com/styles and on Facebook. Readers shared their own experiences with being told to smile, wondered about RBF’s cultural context and expressed frustration with the inherent sexism of such a term. Below are some of the highlights, edited for space.

headline: HSBC Profit Falls 4% in Second Quarter as Bank Retrenches

headline: Patter and Patois
abstract: Walter Mosley writes about his relationship to the literature of Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: I am what you might call a grandchild of Louisiana. My father was born there as were many of his friends and relatives. Most of my neighbors in Los ­Angeles came from there too — black rural folk who had traveled west through southern Texas on their migration to escape the South’s heavy hail of racial hatred. They came to California for the tattered shelter of mocking freedom that the Golden State had to offer people like them, poor people willing to work hard.

headline: Cleaning Up a Legacy of Pollution on an Alaskan Island
keywords: ['PCB (Polychlorinated Biphenyls)', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Water Pollution', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: On St. Lawrence Island, a former military listening post in the Bering Sea, native residents believe pollution has contributed to their poor health.
lead_paragraph: ST. LAWRENCE ISLAND, Alaska — America’s Far North cherishes its image of wild purity in a landscape so vast it can sometimes seem barely touched by people. But the roughly 600 military installations across Alaska — some dating from World War II, others built during the Cold War — tell a different story, in polluted sites that were never fully cleaned up, and in the related health problems that have lingered and festered.

headline: Stocks Plunge in Greece as Athens Exchange Reopens

headline: Foreign Language Apps for Traveling Abroad
abstract: Gone are the days when tourists wander around clutching guidebooks with an index of handy phrases. Today there are more convenient ways to facilitate communication.
lead_paragraph: You’re going on vacation to a place where you don’t know the language, and English isn’t widely spoken. Sure, you’ve learned how to say “hello” and “where’s the bathroom?,” but beyond that you’re clueless and your flight is tomorrow. What to do?

headline: Pregnancy Is the Best Time for Some Vaccines
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Whooping Cough', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Many women go through pregnancy unprotected by readily available vaccines that can prevent irreversible harm to the woman, the unborn baby or the very young infant.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 20, 1968, I was in Minnesota for a family wedding and got the flu; what I didn’t get, to my surprise, was my period. With a fever of 104 degrees, I was too sick to eat or even go to the bathroom unaided for 10 days. Returning to New York on Sunday night of New Year’s weekend, I was struggling to breathe and too weak to walk.

headline: Don’t Blame Medicaid for Rise in Health Care Spending

A recent analysis by The Pew Charitable Trusts revealed that it consumed 31 percent of state and local government revenue in 2013, nearly doubling from 1987.

lead_paragraph: HEALTH CARE DEALS RAISE DOUBTS FOR CONSUMERS | The recent frenzy of mergers among health insurers promised big savings, but not everyone is convinced that consumers will see that, Reed Abelson reports in The New York Times. The tie-up between Anthem and Cigna and the deal for Aetna to join its smaller rival Humana would create two behemoths. Along with UnitedHealthGroup, they would control nearly half of the American commercial health insurance market.

As Hervé Morin, a former French defense minister, recently warned, Europe — and France in particular — cannot afford to wait until the black flag of the Islamic State is hoisted above the presidential palace in Tunis.

headline: Cap and Trade and Polarization
abstract: Who’s responsible for the gap?
lead_paragraph: One of the most obvious facts about the U.S. political scene is also a fact most pundits refuse to acknowledge: the extreme polarization we now experience, the complete disappearance of any kind of political center, is not a two-sided phenomenon. Democrats haven’t moved drastically to the left — if anything they inched right for a couple of decades, and are only now shuffling slightly back toward a more robust liberalism. But Republicans have barreled off to the right.

Kering’s Sport & Lifestyle division?) — not to mention its love of all things celebrity — fashion has been extraordinarily slow to embrace female sports stars.

headline: No Sanity Clause

lead_paragraph: Just in case you had any illusions about the state of US governance, and the sanity of the party that now controls Congress, the estimable Stan Collender now tells us that there is a better-than-even chance of a government shutdown this fall. And the issue that will bring us to the brink? Republican demands that we defund Planned Parenthood.

headline: New York Regulator Moves to Suspend Promontory Financial
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The decision was detailed in a report that accused the consulting firm of helping to obscure some of the same bank misconduct it was supposed to unearth.
lead_paragraph: The Promontory Financial Group occupies a position of trust in the global financial system, acting as a consultant to big banks, foreign nations and the Vatican. Its influence has soared over the years, positioning it as a sort of shadow regulator that provides government authorities with a window into bank misconduct. And the firm’s political ties run deep, thanks to its founder and chief executive, Eugene A. Ludwig, a former top banking regulator and a law school friend of Bill Clinton.

headline: Katie Ledecky Breaks World Record, Almost by Accident

lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — Out of the water, Katie Ledecky does little to draw attention to herself. She dresses demurely, wears her hair in a relaxed bob and is quiet in a crowd, content to leave the performing to others. When she does talk, she speaks the way she writes: succinctly, with nary a run-on sentence.

headline: American Pharoah Steers Clear of Route of Past Triple Crown Winners
abstract: American Pharoah’s post-Belmont campaign hardly follows the pattern of past Triple Crown winners, who went on to win 92 races in 162 more starts. Pharoah may race two or three more times.
lead_paragraph: American Pharoah won the Haskell Invitational with ease Sunday. He was a 1-9 favorite and is the reigning Triple Crown winner, so few were surprised. He may race two or three more times at the most, then he will be retired. Few are surprised by that decision either.

Should he seek political asylum, he could become one of the most damaging defectors in the history of the People’s Republic.

headline: Baby Name Change Could Reduce Hospital Errors
abstract: A simple change in how the NICU names babies can significantly reduce medication errors.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 percent of neonatal intensive-care units, or NICUs, use temporary first names for patients — Babygirl Jackson or Babyboy Goldsmith, for example — a convention that may lead to errors in prescribing medicines. A new study has found that a simple change in this procedure can significantly reduce such errors.

headline: Review: ‘Le Nozze Di Figaro’ Gets an Update in Salzburg
abstract: Everything about the show exuded immediacy and naturalness at the Haus für Mozart.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — For a director, conductor and cast, it must be intense pressure to present a new production of Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro” amid the high expectations of the Salzburg Festival here in the composer’s hometown. But, if those involved in this summer’s new “Figaro” are feeling burdened, it did not come through during Sunday afternoon’s performance, the second of seven, at the intimate Haus für Mozart.

Year after year, it gets tougher to come up with new ways to dramatize the story.
