headline: The Challenges of Fighting Money Laundering
abstract: Criminals are always seeking ways to hide their profits, and recent cases highlight the difficulty of keeping up with their latest tactics.
lead_paragraph: The Watergate credo to “follow the money” is the reason for a number of laws that require banks, credit unions and money-transmission businesses to keep track of who their customers are and report suspicious transactions. These financial firms are the first line of defense against money laundering, and recent cases highlight just how difficult it is for the government to police the tidal waves of cash that wash through the banking system.

headline: Trend of New York Gun Violence Has Flattened Out, Police Statistics Show
abstract: Since early June, shootings have fallen, even as the number of homicides in the city remains 10 percent higher than last year’s historic low.

headline: 1965: Draft Call Is Biggest Since 1951
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'UNITED STATES', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson orders the highest draft since the Korean War, in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Defense Department, carrying out President Johnson’s military manpower demands, today ordered the highest draft quotas since the Korean war. The new figures were 27,400 for September, all for the Army, and 33,600 men for October, including 4,600 for the Navy. The original draft call for September was 17,000. The September and October quotas were the highest since 80,000 youths were called in March of 1951. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 4, 1965

headline: Auto Sales Jumped in July; G.M. and Fiat Chrysler Were Up 6%

headline: First Came Summer Camp Marriage, Then Came a More Mature Love
abstract: Ashwini Chawla and Sanam Wadhwani met two years ago at a religious and cultural camp. A tragedy soon followed, tethering them closely together.
lead_paragraph: They met when they were 17 and 19 years old, and a week later, they were married — in a play.

headline: Summery, Sweet-Smelling Hair Perfumes
abstract: Gardenia, white rose and more to freshen up this summer.
lead_paragraph: During the summer, it’s tempting to skip the shampoo and go an extra day (or two) without washing one’s hair. But to keep it smelling fresh, there’s hair perfume: small, portable bottles that protect and hydrate hair while serving up a dose of white rose or gardenia. Here, a mix of recent launches and classics.

headline: What Is Our Attention Really Worth?
abstract: Attention is a currency. We choose how to spend it, just like we spend our time and money. But unlike money, there’s no way to store attention for later use.
lead_paragraph: Pay attention!

headline: The Internet of Things and the Future of Farming
abstract: The Internet of Things presents daunting technical and policy challenges. But smarter farming, for example, shows its potential.
lead_paragraph: The Internet of Things — the vision of a world brimming with communicating sensors and digital smarts — occupies the peak of Gartner’s most recent “hype cycle.” And a report released two months ago by the McKinsey Global Institute laid out the potential multitrillion-dollar payoff from the emerging technology.

headline: Investment Consortium Buys Germany’s Tank & Rast
abstract: The group, led by the German insurer Allianz’s private equity arm, will pay about $3.8 billion, according to a person familiar with the discussions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A group of investors led by the private equity arm of German insurer Allianz agreed to acquire Autobahn Tank & Rast Holding, the German motorway service area operator, its owners said on Monday.

headline: Alpha Natural Resources, a Onetime Coal Giant, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coal', 'Mines and Mining']
abstract: Heavy debt and plummeting prices as power generators turn to natural gas and renewables forced the company into Chapter 11 protection.
lead_paragraph: Alpha Natural Resources, once a powerhouse of the American coal industry, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Monday so it may emerge from the grip of a $3 billion debt at a time when utilities are switching to natural gas and coal prices are plummeting.

headline: Theory on Lithium in Stars May Be Confirmed
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Lithium (Metal)', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Lithium has been found in material ejected by a nova, or a stellar explosion, for the first time. That may confirm the theory that lithium in young stars came from novae.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers believe that the metal lithium was created during the Big Bang 13.8 billion years ago. Yet old stars often have less lithium than might be expected, while young stars seem to have much more. Some scientists have speculated the source of extra lithium in young stars may be stellar explosions, or novae, expelling matter into space. Now lithium has been found in material ejected by the younger star Nova Centauri 2013, which may confirm the theory. The observation was made by telescopes at La Silla Observatory, the European Southern Observatory’s site in Chile, and at the Observatory of the Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile near Santiago.

headline: India Blocks 857 Pornography Websites, Defying Supreme Court Decision
abstract: Without warning, the government acted just weeks after the nation’s Supreme Court declined an activist’s request to block access to online pornography.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Without warning or explanation, the Indian government this weekend ordered Internet service providers to block access to 857 pornography websites that had been singled out by an anti-pornography activist.

headline: Dispense With the Jokes Now: Pez Candy Gets Its Own Film
abstract: The brick-shaped treats will be the subject of an animated tale.
lead_paragraph: In what could be viewed as a sign (but almost certainly isn’t) that the era of toy-themed movies is nearing its end, a Hollywood production company announced Monday that it would be making a film about Pez.

headline: Miscelanea NY Brings Mexico to Manhattan
abstract: Miscelanea NY does more than tacos; flavored pumpkin seeds; breakfast the Moroccan and Japanese way; cookies to make Vienna proud; and sleek ice-cream bowls.
lead_paragraph: Guillaume Guevara considered his options. A restaurant? New York had enough Mexican places. But a market selling chiles, Oaxaca cheese, masa and Mexican sweets may make a difference, he thought. There could be some takeout food, but definitely not more tacos. What was needed, he believed, were tortas (sandwiches), like egg and chorizo. His inventory also tempts with jams infused with tequila and mezcal; paletas (ice pops) from Fany Gerson; coffee; and less common Mexican items like sweet maguey syrup and Mayan clay (for cosmetic use). He also sells lime presses, cookbooks and personal-care products from Mexico. And if he suggests iced coffee with the rice-milk drink horchata, take him up on it, especially when the sidewalk is steaming: Miscelanea NY, 63 East Fourth Street (Bowery), 212-253-0277, miscelaneany.com.

headline: British Government to Begin Partial Sale of R.B.S. Stake
abstract: U.K. Financial Investments, which oversees the holdings, plans to sell a 5.2 percent stake in a private placement to institutional investors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government said on Monday that it would sell a 5.2 percent stake in Royal Bank of Scotland, its first sale since the bank received a huge bailout seven years ago.

headline: Soylent Announces New Version of Its Nutrition Drink
abstract: Soylent 2.0 uses soy protein and derives half of its fat energy from “farm-free algae sources.”
lead_paragraph: The makers of Soylent, the powdered drink that has developed a following in Silicon Valley as an easy meal replacement for busy workers, has created a follow-up version called Soylent 2.0.

headline: Collegiate Chorale, Under a New Name, Is Teaming Up With City Center
abstract: The Collegiate Chorale is changing its name to MasterVoices and is starting a new partnership with City Center.
lead_paragraph: The Collegiate Chorale, which was founded in 1941 by the conductor Robert Shaw, announced Monday that it was changing its name to MasterVoices and beginning a new partnership with City Center to give concert performances there of operas and operettas in English.

lead_paragraph: What’s going to generate headlines this week in international news? We’re experimenting with offering readers a tip sheet. Let us know if you find it useful or what you’d like to see here. Contact hanna.ingber@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general’s office said on Monday that it would investigate the death of a woman who was found dead in a holding cell in Mount Vernon after she was arrested on shoplifting charges and then fell ill.

headline: Wild Uganda Chimpanzees Using Clay as Food
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Clay', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Forests and Forestry']
abstract: Researchers studying the chimps living in the Budongo Forest says the apes are eating clay because of the destruction of local raffia palm trees.
lead_paragraph: Wild chimpanzees in Uganda have begun eating clay, which furnishes dietary minerals to them, a new study reports.

headline: The Promise and Limits of Obama’s ‘Clean Power Plan’ for Limiting Global Warming
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Assessing the strengths and limits of President Obama’s “Clean Power Plan” for blunting climate change.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, in a “Memo to America” and lots of details released to the press, President Obama set the stage for today’s release of the Environmental Protection Agency’s final “Clean Power Plan,” aimed at meeting the administration’s pledges to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

headline: After Killing of Cecil the Lion, Delta Joins Airline Ban on Game Trophies
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'Lions', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Poaching (Wildlife)']
abstract: The recent killing of a popular lion named Cecil has sparked outrage, but it has also brought to light the role airlines play in transporting trophy kills as cargo.
lead_paragraph: The recent killing of a popular lion named Cecil by an American dentist in Zimbabwe sparked considerable outrage on social media and elsewhere against safari hunting. The event has also brought to light the role that airlines play in transporting trophy kills as cargo, and may have contributed to changing airline policy.

headline: If You Were the Boss, Would You Raise the Minimum Salary to $70,000?
abstract: Dan Price drew wide praise and intense criticism for his plan to raise the minimum salary at his company to $70,000. How would you compensate your employees?
lead_paragraph: Three months ago, Dan Price, the chief executive of Gravity Payments, a credit card processing company, decided to raise the salary of his lowest paid workers to $70,000. Almost overnight, he represented a swashbuckling blow against income inequality. He also drew no small amount of criticism.

headline: A Baseball Habit Begins to Feel the Pinch
abstract: Smokeless tobacco, a staple of players for more than a century, will be banned from San Francisco’s AT&T Park at the beginning of next year, and more venues are likely to follow suit.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Most days he is at work at AT&T Park here, Giants pitcher Madison Bumgarner can be seen with a clump of smokeless tobacco lodged in his lower lip. Bumgarner, a World Series hero and the face of the team, grew up in small-town North Carolina, where, he said, nearly all men dipped. He has been doing it since he was in fifth grade.

headline: British Police to Review Sex Abuse Claims Against Ex-Premier Edward Heath
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: An independent agency will look into whether an inquiry was dropped when a subject threatened to go public with accusations that former Prime Minister Edward Heath had sexually abused children.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s independent police watchdog agency said on Monday that it would investigate an allegation that the police in Wiltshire had dropped a criminal investigation in the 1990s when the subject threatened to go public with accusations that the former Conservative prime minister Edward Heath had sexually abused children.

Holmes to death for carrying out a massacre inside a suburban movie theater in July 2012, rejecting defense arguments that his mental illness should remove the death penalty from consideration as a potential punishment.

headline: Do Israelis Still Care About Justice?

abstract: At least 73 people have died since Friday amid heavy rains in two states in the country’s east, disaster management officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 73 people have died in India since Friday amid flooding and a landslide linked to heavy rains in two states in the country’s east, disaster management officials said.

headline: Good Timing for Britain to Shed Its R.B.S. Stake
abstract: Although the British government faces a paper loss, it may be better to sell now than to hold on for a recovery in price that might never come.
lead_paragraph: Britain shouldn’t obsess about losing money on its Royal Bank of Scotland stake. George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, is about to get cracking on reducing the government’s 79 percent holding, which will mean a short-term loss on the 46 billion pounds handed over by taxpayers in 2008 and 2009. That hit needs to be put into perspective.

headline: Move to Fight Obama’s Climate Plan Started Early
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'States (US)', 'Attorneys General', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Coal', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A group of lawyers, lobbyists and political strategists started devising a strategy for dismantling President Obama’s climate change regulations before he had even put forth a draft proposal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the early months of 2014, a group of about 30 corporate lawyers, coal lobbyists and Republican political strategists began meeting regularly in the headquarters of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, often, according to some of the participants, in a conference room overlooking the White House. Their task was to start devising a legal strategy for dismantling the climate change regulations they feared were coming from President Obama.

lead_paragraph: The poster evoked a family law practice, or perhaps an Off Broadway act, announcing the gathering’s hosts inside the overstuffed Midtown office of New York’s senior senator.

headline: Puerto Rico Defaults on Bond Payment
abstract: The Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico did not make a $58 million bond payment, saying it lacked the funds to meet the amount due.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico defaulted on a $58 million bond payment on Monday, a risky move that seemed to intensify the pressure on creditors for broader debt renegotiation, but might also make future borrowing far more difficult.

headline: Effective Ovarian Cancer Treatment Is Underused, Study Finds
abstract: The treatment, known as IP, in which chemotherapy is pumped directly into the abdomen, could add 16 months or more to women’s lives, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, the National Cancer Institute took the rare step of issuing a “clinical announcement,” a special alert it holds in reserve for advances so important that they should change medical practice.

headline: Review: China Miéville’s ‘Three Moments of an Explosion’
abstract: The short stories in Mr. Miéville’s newest collection take place in a variety of strange worlds, including one in which icebergs fly.
lead_paragraph: Even when he is orbiting somewhere in a galaxy too far away for normal human comprehension, the genre-subverting English novelist China Miéville is dazzling. His latest collection of short stories, “Three Moments of an Explosion,” crowds virtuosity into every sentence.

headline: Wylie Dufresne Is Closing Alder
abstract: The East Village restaurant ends a two-and-a-half-year run in the East Village. Mr. Dufresne said he’s looking for a new home.
lead_paragraph: The innovative chef Wylie Dufresne will close his bistro, Alder, in the East Village, at the end of the month. The restaurant confirmed the news, which Mr. Dufresne announced in a message on Twitter that added, “The search for a new home begins.” He did not give a reason for the closing and has not returned calls.

headline: Dr. Forrest Bird, Inventor of Medical Respirators and Ventilators, Dies at 94
abstract: Dr. Bird, who built his first prototype from shortcake tins and a doorknob in 1953, developed four generations of widely used cardiopulmonary devices.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Forrest M. Bird, an eccentric aviator and inventor who studied high-altitude breathing problems of World War II pilots and later created medical devices that saved lives and aided thousands of people with respiratory ailments, died on Sunday at his home in Sagle, Idaho. He was 94.

headline: Expert Panel Withholds Support for Early Autism Screening
abstract: An expert panel has concluded that there is no evidence to support universal autism screening of young children, raising concern among autism advocates and experts who for years have been urging physicians to screen children as early as possible in order to begin early treatment.
lead_paragraph: For years experts have urged physicians to screen infants and toddlers for autism in order to begin treatment as early as possible. But now an influential panel of experts has concluded there is not enough evidence to recommend universal autism screening of young children.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear Evan Hansen,’ Teenage Angst Grows Complicated
abstract: A note found in a dead teenager’s pocket sets off unpredictable events in the sweet, sad and quite moving new musical making its premiere at Arena Stage in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The quirks of fate prove both kind and cruel in “Dear Evan Hansen,” a sweet, sad and quite moving new musical making its premiere here at Arena Stage. The title character, a friendless teenager crippled by the depression that only being a friendless teenager can bring, is caught up in the whiplash of web fame when a note he wrote finds its way into the hands of another troubled kid, with complicated consequences.

China is too repressive to hold the Games, detaining hundreds of lawyers just in the past month, rights campaigners said. On Friday, despite those complaints, the International Olympic Committee awarded the Games to Beijing.

headline: Fragile Burundi Casts a Wary Eye on Rwanda
abstract: As distrust deepens between the countries, Burundian officials say that Rwanda played a part in a coup attempt to stop the president from securing a third term.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Burundi and Rwanda can seem deceptively like conjoined twins. They share a common history, geography and language, and their populations are divided ethnically between Hutu and Tutsi. Both were devastated by some of the worst mass slaughter of the 20th century.

headline: Boston Symphony Extends Andris Nelsons’s Contract Through 2022
abstract: Mr. Nelsons, 36, will continue as music director, noting that he and the orchestra “speak the same language.”
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — The honeymoon was a success, and the flirtation with a would-be home wrecker from overseas ended without infidelity, so now they are renewing their vows: The Boston Symphony Orchestra  said on Monday that it had extended Andris Nelsons’s contract as its music director through 2022.

headline: Review: Carl Safina’s ‘Beyond Words’ Doesn’t Mince Any on Animal Abilities
abstract: Carl Safina, unafraid to challenge scientific orthodoxy, accepts as a given that animals are capable of thought and emotion.
lead_paragraph: Given the subtitle of Carl Safina’s fascinating and expansive new book, “Beyond Words: What Animals Think and Feel,” it’s no surprise that Dr. Safina frequently discusses animal cognition.

headline: Great Men (Mostly) Through History
abstract: Making composite portraits of national leaders — layering dozens of them, sometimes, into a single frame — one photographer explored the “aesthetic of power” and sameness.
lead_paragraph: Making composite portraits of national leaders — layering dozens of them, sometimes, into a single frame — one photographer explored the “aesthetic of power” and sameness.

headline: ‘Bobby Jones Gospel’ and Its Strongest Voice Prepare to Say Farewell
abstract: The BET gospel music series will have its 35th and final season premiere in October, signaling the end of an international platform for the genre.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some folks skipped church on Sunday in hopes of getting to BET’s headquarters here in time for the final taping of “Bobby Jones Gospel.” Many were turned away, though, as the studio’s chairs runneth over, filled with gospel stars who trace their careers back to their debuts on the show and retired network executives who did not want to miss the chance to say goodbye to a legend.

headline: Review: ‘The Dreamer Examines His Pillow’ Talks of Love, Lust and Lots More
abstract: This 90-minute intermissionless production of an early John Patrick Shanley work is really a play in three parts that centers on a young couple.
lead_paragraph: In its current revival by the Attic Theater Company, “The Dreamer Examines His Pillow,”an early John Patrick Shanley work, is an intermissionless 90 minutes, but it’s really a play in three parts. From the audience’s perspective this particular production’s three parts are: “Not buying it,” “Just got more interesting” and, “Ah, now it all makes sense.”

headline: Review: Nação Zumbi Returns to Central Park SummerStage
abstract: The show took the form of a 20-year anniversary for a concert the band had played on the same stage when Chico Science, then its leader, was still alive.
lead_paragraph: A great band can sound even better when propelled by a great thesis: an endlessly renewable idea big enough to encompass music, history, philosophy, politics and the daily grind.

headline: A Fencer Strives to Crack a Saber Ceiling
abstract: Daryl Homer, 25, ranked sixth in the world in saber fencing, is a favorite to become the first American man to win an Olympic gold medal in the sport.
lead_paragraph: Daryl Homer secured his spot in United States fencing history last month by becoming the first American man to claim a medal in saber fencing at the world championships, winning silver in Moscow. But for a broader scope of the legacy he has been building, look no further than his home fencing club in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: The Little Orchestra Society Limits Schedule and Aims for Younger Audience
abstract: The ensemble, whose average age of its audience is dropping, is planning only 16 performances next season, down from 28 last season.
lead_paragraph: The Little Orchestra Society is getting littler, at least for now.

headline: In Case You Missed It: July’s Top Real Estate Stories
abstract: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the most popular stories of the month.

headline: Yankees Pitching Prospect Luis Severino Draws Raves Before Debut Against Red Sox
abstract: Severino, 21, has a smooth, rhythmic delivery that produces late life on his fastball.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Dellin Betances was at the Yankees’ minor league complex in Tampa, Fla., at the end of the 2012 minor league season preparing to head to the instructional league, there were about 20 young pitching prospects working out.

headline: Toy Guns Can Be Dangerous, for Real
abstract: Fake guns can be hazardous, especially to the person holding them.
lead_paragraph: A toy gun is supposed to look like a toy — not a gun. In New York, it cannot be black, blue or silver. It should have bright neon colors in New York City, and a strip of orange around the barrel in the state. That’s the law. Yet, the office of New York’s Attorney General Eric Schneiderman found that retailers had sold more than 6,400 toy guns to New York families in the last three years that looked all too real.

headline: Vigilante Effort After a Child’s Death Underlines Stark Change in West Bank

abstract: The village of Duma had found a peaceful accommodation with its Jewish neighbors, but attitudes changed after the death of a Palestinian toddler.
lead_paragraph: DUMA, West Bank — Early one recent morning, a few residents of this sleepy hilltop hamlet heard that Jewish settlers were hurling rocks at a house. Almost instantly they started posting messages on Facebook, rousing neighbors — then somebody’s brother called a friend, who called his cousin, who called the Muslim preacher, who rushed to the mosque, flicked on a megaphone rigged to the minaret and shouted:

headline: Review: ‘Turandot’ and ‘Les Contes d’Hoffmann,’ Spectacle and Substance at Bregenz Festival
abstract: Puccini’s opera played at the festival’s floating stage while the Festspielhaus featured Stefan Herheim’s staging of Offenbach’s “Hoffmann.”
lead_paragraph: BREGENZ, Austria — Opera at its best has always been spectacle with a brain. And nowhere is that marriage of seriousness and showmanship pursued more openly than at the Bregenz Festival.

abstract: The two Lincoln Center Out of Doors performances highlighted dance and music from a broad range of immigrant cultures in New York City.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s hear it for Congress!”

headline: Garbage In, Garbage Out, Garbage Around
abstract: Rerouting the truck traffic for a garbage-transfer station in the Upper East Side was always the simpler, better idea.
lead_paragraph: O.K., so the compromise is small in the global scheme of things. It is not a two-state solution and it does not involve the sovereignty of tiny islands claimed by China and Japan. But it does loom hugely for citizens of the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where conflicts over land use can – and do – take on geopolitical proportions and urgency.

headline: Pimco May Face S.E.C. Action Over a Fund
abstract: The asset manager said it had received a Wells notice from the regulator over potential trading infractions concerning an exchange-traded fund in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A Pimco exchange-traded bond fund that once tracked the performance of a much larger fund formerly managed by the firm’s co-founder, William H. Gross, may have violated federal securities laws.

headline: Legionnaires’ Disease Death Toll in Bronx Rises to 7
abstract: New York City officials announced that the tally had climbed by three amid calls for tighter regulation of water-cooling towers.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx has claimed three more lives, bringing the death toll to seven, New York City officials said on Monday amid calls for tighter regulation of water-cooling towers, which are thought to be the origin of the illness.

headline: Planned Parenthood Is Defended as Senate Democrats Block Bill to End Funding
abstract: Democrats resisted backlash against the organization, set off by videos about fees for tissue from fetuses. Cecile Richards, the group’s president, said the videos proved that employees did nothing wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As president of Planned Parenthood, Cecile Richards tries to keep perspective while the group faces one of its biggest political crises. After all, she said on Monday, the founder, Margaret Sanger, was arrested 99 years ago for pamphleteering about birth control.

headline: Richard S. Schweiker, Former Senator and Reagan Confidant, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Schweiker, a Pennsylvania Republican, served for two decades in Congress and two more years in the White House in an era of assassinations, war and sweeping social changes.
lead_paragraph: Richard S. Schweiker, a former United States representative and senator from Pennsylvania who was the secretary of health and human services during the first term of President Ronald Reagan, died on Friday in Pomona, N.J. He was 89.

lead_paragraph: José Alvarrado saved for more than a decade to buy 3 Brothers Mini Market, a bodega at 169th Street and Audubon Avenue.

headline: Hitchhiking Robot, Safe in Several Countries, Meets Its End in Philadelphia
abstract: The social media-savvy robot had relied on the kindness of strangers to travel the world but was found battered and dismembered in an alley.
lead_paragraph: After an international adventure that included spending a week with a heavy metal band, cruising through the canals of Amsterdam and participating in a wave at a Boston Red Sox game, a hitchhiking robot met a brutal demise in a Philadelphia alley on Saturday. It was 1 year old.

headline: The Failed Attack on Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Senate Republicans’ latest ploy to choke off all federal funding to Planned Parenthood failed, but it shouldn’t have made it as far as it did.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans’ latest ploy to choke off all federal funding to Planned Parenthood failed, as expected, on Monday afternoon in a 53-46 procedural vote. The measure fell short of the 60 votes needed to move it forward.

headline: Trans-Pacific Partnership Session Ends With Heels Dug In

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tokyo was ready to extend major concessions on American truck tariffs but was blocked by Mexico, which wanted less competition for its own trucks in the United States market.

headline: Trial Opens for Charlotte Officer Who Fatally Shot Black Motorist Seeking Help
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The fatal shooting of Jonathan Ferrell in September 2013 occurred amid the beginning of the national debate over the deaths of young black men that followed the killing of Trayvon Martin in 2012.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A Charlotte police officer fired eight shots at the fallen body of an unarmed former college football player who had knocked on the door of a house in an unfamiliar neighborhood seeking help after a car crash, a prosecutor said in opening arguments Monday in the trial of Officer Randall Kerrick on voluntary manslaughter charges.

headline: Obama Administration Urges States to Cut Health Insurers’ Requests for Big Rate Increases
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: After finding that new customers were sicker than expected, some health plans have sought increases of 10 percent to 40 percent or more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hoping to avoid another political uproar over the Affordable Care Act, the Obama administration is trying to persuade states to cut back big rate increases requested by many health insurance companies for 2016.

headline: Suspect in Memphis Police Officer’s Death Turns Himself In
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Law enforcement authorities confirmed that Tremaine Wilbourn, wanted in the death of Officer Sean Bolton on Saturday, had been taken into custody and faced a first-degree murder charge.
lead_paragraph: An ex-convict wanted in Tennessee for the murder of a Memphis police officer turned himself in to the authorities on Monday, law enforcement officials said.

headline: United Nations Members Establish 15-Year Global Development Agenda
abstract: Its 193 member states have agreed on aims to eliminate poverty and hunger, protect the environment from climate change, achieve gender equality and raise living standards.
lead_paragraph: In what the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, described Monday as the organization’s “to-do” list for the next 15 years, its 193 member states have agreed on an agenda for global development that aims to eliminate poverty and hunger, protect the environment from climate change, achieve gender equality and raise living standards. The agreement, known as the  2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, was finalized over the weekend after negotiations that began a few years ago. It will be formally adopted at a United Nations summit meeting next month. The agenda supersedes and broadens the eight Millennium Development Goals set in 2000, which Mr. Ban has credited with helping to raise more than one billion people out of abject poverty.

headline: Kentucky Officer Handcuffs Third Grader
abstract: The video released by the A.C.L.U. shows a deputy sheriff in Kentucky handcuffing a third grader to a chair. An A.C.L.U. lawyer said the handcuffing was “traumatizing, and in this case illegal.”
lead_paragraph: The video released by the A.C.L.U. shows a deputy sheriff in Kentucky handcuffing a third grader to a chair. An A.C.L.U. lawyer said the handcuffing was “traumatizing, and in this case illegal.”

headline: A.C.L.U. Sues Over Handcuffing of Boy, 8, and Girl, 9, in Kentucky School
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Disabilities', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The federal lawsuit seeks to spotlight the use of handcuffs to restrain young children who act out in school.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American Civil Liberties Union, seeking to spotlight the use of handcuffs to restrain young children who act out in school, filed a federal lawsuit in Covington, Ky., on Monday alleging that a school resource officer there shackled an 8-year-old boy and a 9-year-old girl, both with disabilities, causing the children “pain, fear and emotional trauma.”

headline: A Climate Plan Businesses Can Like
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'United States Economy', 'Energy and Power', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Obama is sending a signal that low-carbon energy will be profitable.
lead_paragraph: WITH the release of President Obama’s Clean Power Plan, a flood of legal challenges will begin. Already, opponents have denounced the new rule limiting carbon pollution as unconstitutional. Behind the rattling sabers, however, there’s a quieter story worth noticing. Many big players in the electric power industry will gain more with the rule in place than if the courts strike it down.

headline: New Polls Show Donald Trump Widening His Lead and John Kasich Holding His Own
abstract: Less than 24 hours before the candidates’ deadline to qualify for Fox News’s debate, polls by Fox News poll and by WMUR show Mr. Trump with a statistically significant lead over the rest of the field and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio squeaking into the tenth and final spot.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours before the candidates’ deadline to qualify for Fox News’s debate, two polls released on Monday show Donald J. Trump with a statistically significant lead over the rest of the field and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio squeaking into the top ten.

headline: Securities Fraud Charges Bring Texas Attorney General, Ken Paxton, to County Jail
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'State Legislatures', 'Attorneys General', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Ken Paxton, who was elected in November, was booked in a case stemming from accusations that he misled investors and clients while doing securities work in the years before he became the state’s top lawyer.
lead_paragraph: McKINNEY, Tex. — Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general, was arrested on felony charges Monday and booked at the county jail in this Dallas suburb after a grand jury indicted him last week for securities fraud, the start of a criminal case that could complicate and even jeopardize his tenure as the state’s top lawyer.

headline: Syria: U.S. Sets New Sanctions
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control said seven commercial ships had been blocked by its action, cutting off a potential fuel source to Assad’s military.
lead_paragraph: The United States sought to broaden its economic pressure on Syria’s government on Monday, imposing sanctions on a far-flung network of seven overseas companies and four individuals for actions to evade American and European Union restrictions on fuel imports. The Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control, which oversees enforcement of American sanctions, said seven commercial ships owned or controlled by one of the newly penalized companies had been blocked by its action, cutting off a potential source of fuel to President Bashar al-Assad’s military. The affected companies operated in Syria, the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, Lebanon, Panama, St. Kitts and Nevis and the Marshall Islands, the Treasury said in a statement, asserting that “many of these entities are front companies that the government of Syria and its supporters have used in an attempt to evade U.S. and E.U. sanctions.” Any sanctioned individuals and entities risk seizure of assets under American jurisdiction, and are barred from commercial dealings with the United States.

headline: Vincent Marotta Sr., a Creator of Mr. Coffee, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Marotta, who once played football professionally and signed with an M.L.B. team, created a coffee maker that knocked the percolator from its perch.
lead_paragraph: Vincent Marotta Sr., who as a creator of the Mr. Coffee machine helped send the percolator the way of the one-horse shay, died on Saturday at his home in Pepper Pike, Ohio. He was 91.

headline: David Price Electrifies Toronto’s Fans With Debut for Blue Jays
abstract: Price, who has pitched in the World Series and in critical playoff games, said his Toronto debut was “the best atmosphere I’ve ever been in.”
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — When the Toronto Blue Jays acquired David Price from the Detroit Tigers last week, the objective was both to add his pitching excellence and to capitalize on his vast experience. Price has pitched in the World Series, critical playoff games and even a win-and-get-in 163rd game two years ago.

keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Terrorism']

headline: From the Cheap Seats at Mets Game, ESPN Misses the Action
abstract: The network’s announcers, seated in the bleachers, called the game as they would from the booth, but they could not see the field as they normally would have.
lead_paragraph: When ESPN brought its announcing crew to Citi Field on Sunday for the Mets-Nationals game, I was leery of what would be accomplished by planting all three announcers in the bleachers, far from the traditional broadcast booth. It was not a very illuminating spot from which to call a game that would, with the Mets’ victory, put them in a tie for first place with the Nationals.

headline: Shiri Appleby and Constance Zimmer on the ‘UnREAL’ Season Finale
abstract: “During pilot season, you get sent seven cop scripts, four medical shows. But this one was really unique.”
lead_paragraph: The first season of Lifetime’s “UnREAL”, a drama that takes place behind the scenes of a “Bachelor”-like show, has tackled bulimia, domestic violence, suicide, mental illness, blackmail and the grimy aspects of how reality television sausage gets made. But even with all that darkness, it still found a way to shock in its first season finale.

lead_paragraph: The New Jersey governor and Republican presidential candidate proposed increasing the retirement age by two years over the next quarter-century.

headline: A Refreshing Cocktail Recipe, Featuring Iceland’s Newest Export
abstract: The Up & Up’s Stone Crush features Brennivín, an aquavit recently made available in the United States.
lead_paragraph: “Ever since I had come back from London, I have always been looking for how I could get this stuff,” says barman Matt Piacentini. It’s a sentiment that has continuously informed choices for his bars, from Clyde Common in Downtown Portland to his latest venture, the Up & Up, on New York’s Macdougal Street. “This stuff” is Piacentini’s shorthand for the goods he found easily accessible back in Europe that he wants to bring stateside: everything from William Morris wallpapers and Italian amari to Scandinavian aquavit.

headline: One-Thing Shops: Herbs in Athens
abstract: Evangelia Koutsovoulou created Daphnis and Chloe, a store under the Acropolis, to source and celebrate her home country's thyme flowers, bay leaves and more.
lead_paragraph: Among a generation of young Greeks scattered around the more prosperous cities of Europe, Evangelia Koutsovoulou is an anomaly: an émigré who last year returned to Athens with opportunity on her mind. The sage- and mint-perfumed islands of her Mediterranean homeland are rich in herbs, unchanged and mostly uncultivated since ancient times with a world of unique flavors not found elsewhere, even in her adopted country of Italy. “Greek herbs were something very special but no one else had paid any attention to them,” says the former journalist, who opened her tiny headquarters below the Acropolis in the midst of the country’s economic crisis and created Daphnis and Chloe, a brand of wild-bred culinary herbs named after a second-century Greek tale of predestined love.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:40 A.M. (Starz) WHIPLASH (2014) Andrew (Miles Teller), an aspiring jazz drummer at a highly selective Manhattan music school, falls in thrall to Fletcher (J. K. Simmons, in an Oscar-winning portrayal), a charismatic and terrifying instructor whose teaching methods include browbeating, humiliation and cymbal throwing in this second feature from Damien Chazelle. And a blood bath, literal and figurative, ensues. “For all its dexterity and assurance, the movie has its share of false notes and rhythmic stumbles,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “A few plot twists test the limits of credibility. And there is something a little dispiriting — if sadly unsurprising — about the way Mr. Chazelle turns a historically African-American art form into the existential arena for a couple of white guys.” Still, he added, “the battle of master and disciple is exciting and terrifying to witness, and, at its best, the film can feel as wild and spontaneous, as risky and precise, as a live jam session.”

headline: Great Men (Mostly) Through History
abstract: Making composite portraits of national leaders — layering dozens of them, sometimes, into a single frame — one photographer explored the “aesthetic of power” and sameness.
lead_paragraph: In the 19th century, eminent smart guys like the Scottish author Thomas Carlyle popularized the Great Man theory, the idea that history was a shapeless wad of ground beef till a great man came along to make a sturdy hamburger of it. Or something like that. Carlyle had his contemporary critics, of course, but confronted with images from “Portraits of Power,” a fine art photo project by Alejandro Almaraz, he might have reconsidered his theory.

abstract: Outrageous comments by politicians were common in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — WE are currently enjoying a master class in the art of political stupidity. Donald J. Trump has been schooling us for some time, but the Iran nuclear deal has touched off a new race to the bottom. Mike Huckabee said the agreement with Iran would “take the Israelis and march them to the door of the oven.” Ted Cruz called the Obama administration “the world’s leading financier of radical Islamic terrorism.” Let’s not even get started on the Affordable Care Act, which Ben Carson once called “the worst thing that has happened in this nation since slavery.”

headline: Obama’s Flexible Fix to Climate Change
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'ACID RAIN', 'Environment', 'Coal', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president takes a successful 1990 approach to a 2015 environmental problem.
lead_paragraph: For many years, I used to spend at least part of the summer in the gorgeous Laurentides region of Quebec, an hour northwest of Montreal. By the mid-1980s, with each return trip, I could see a growing environmental threat to the area’s beauty: More and more trees were dying. When I asked people what was happening, the answer was simple: “pluie acide,” or acid rain, a form of pollution caused by sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides that were spewing from coal-fired power plants in America.

headline: Walker Percy’s Theory of Hurricanes
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms']
abstract: Percy believed that we feel good when we no longer feel uncertain about our role in the world; when everyone is focused, connected and engaged.
lead_paragraph: Walker Percy had a theory about hurricanes. “Though science taught that good environments were better than bad environments, it appeared to him that the opposite was the case,” he wrote of Will Barrett, the semi-autobiographical title character of his second novel, “The Last Gentleman.” “Take hurricanes, for example, certainly a bad environment if ever there was one. It was his impression that not just he but other people felt better in hurricanes.”

headline: ‘The Beautiful Bureaucrat,’ by Helen Phillips
abstract: This debut novel explores existential questions through the experiences of an administrative worker.
lead_paragraph: In the opening pages of Camus’s “The Stranger,” a nurse warns Meursault to keep a steady pace during his mother’s funeral procession: “If you go slowly,” she says, “you risk getting sunstroke. But if you go too fast, you work up a sweat and then catch a chill inside the church.” Meursault’s response conveys his overwhelming, and baffling, sense of imprisonment: “She was right. There was no way out.” It’s an illustrative moment of the paralysis — damned if I do, damned if I don’t — that characterizes so much of existential literature: Vladimir and Estragon, waiting for a God who never shows; the man from the country in the parable told by the priest in Kafka’s “The Trial,” inert, cursing his fate and praying to fleas, waiting for the doorkeeper to admit him into the Law; Gregor Samsa, trapped between identities, unable to leave his house or return to his human condition. This existential paralysis emerges, in part, from spiritual crisis: If God is dead, what is the individual’s role in an essentially meaningless universe? Are we pawns in the thrall of bureaucratic (Kafka) or totalitarian (Orwell) systems? Or are we, in fact, the ones with ultimate power; the arbiters — even unknowingly — of life and death?

Some handshakes, some smiles, a quick word between the writer and the manager, and a nice picture in the next day’s paper: It was the sort of thing that happened in small towns everywhere.

headline: What It’s Really Like to Be an Airline Pilot
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: Mark Vanhoenacker is a pilot for British Airways, and in his new book, “Skyfaring: A Journey With a Pilot,” he waxes poetic and passionate about his work.
lead_paragraph: Mark Vanhoenacker’s new book, “Skyfaring: A Journey With a Pilot” (Knopf), isn’t exactly a memoir. It’s a meditation on flying, on the physical act of soaring through the air in a giant metal tube, and on the foreign-to-most experiences of the pilot behind the yoke. “I am occasionally asked if I don’t find it boring, to be in the cockpit for so many hours,” he writes. “But I’ve never had the sense that there was any more enjoyable way to spend my working life, that below me existed some other kind of time for which I would trade my hours in the sky.”

headline: The Tough Love of ‘Austerity’
keywords: ['English Language', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: When we talk about the need for austerity in Greece, the word conveys not just an economic but a moral requirement — a lesson that must be taught.
lead_paragraph: Austerity, diet of our lives, girder of our loins. At the moment, the word brings to mind the continuing crisis in Greece and, by extension, the power of the Germans holding the purse strings. ‘‘Austerity’’ has become the catchall word for the cost-cutting a government enacts in order to balance its books: Cut pensions, cut the public payroll, cut social services — cut whatever and wherever. Shrink spending, shrink debt, shrink deficits. The idea is to inspire confidence and make the place more attractive to investors, who prefer a government that’s tough and lean to one that’s marbled and tender.

headline: The Misadventures of Issa Rae
abstract: Four years ago, the comedian’s YouTube series went viral. Why is she finding it so difficult to replicate that success on television?
lead_paragraph: Somewhere, during the elaborate chor­eography leading up to my initial meeting with Issa Rae, a miscommunication between her publicist and me led to my asking Rae how the filming of her pilot was going. Rae pressed her chin to her chest and rolled her eyes upward, making the universal face for: ‘‘Are you kidding me?’’ Actually, she explained, the show had no director attached, no pit crew, not even the slightest inkling of a cast. She was nowhere near filming. All she had was a finished script and a charged cellphone.

headline: Free Diver Natalia Molchanova Descends for Fun, Then Vanishes
abstract: On Sunday, Molchanova, regarded as the greatest free diver in history, attempted a recreational dive to a depth that was modest for her. She never resurfaced.
lead_paragraph: Natalia Molchanova, widely regarded as the greatest free diver in history, wore her favorite purple wet suit Sunday on a chartered boat off the coast of Formentera, an island near Ibiza. Only 1.5 millimeters thick, the wet suit was low buoyancy, designed specifically for divers like her who want to go deep on a single breath. It was a Molchanova, the brand she started with her son, Alexey Molchanov.

headline: ‘Act of God’ Costs, Region by Region

headline: 1915: Peace Mission Fails in Haiti
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S. peace mission fails in Haiti in 1915.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — A special cablegram to the Herald from Port-au-Prince says the mission of the Peace Committee has completely failed. The Cape army refused to fight. Governor Blot and his staff secretly fled during the night aboard a Haitian gunboat, while the population shouted ‘‘Vive Bobo.’’ The garrison of 1,500 was disarmed. Later the American warships Eagle and Nashville landed 250 sailors. Bobo’s army then tried to force the city gates despite the interdiction of the United States naval commanders. The Eagle then shelled the army. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 5, 1915

headline: 1965: Greek Lawmakers Vote
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Greek lawmakers take part in a vote of confidence in the government in 1965.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Parliament met for a showdown vote on the nation’s political crisis tonight [Aug. 4], with observers giving the three- week-old government only a slim chance of success. Shouts and interruptions rang out across the assembly as soon as debate got under way. A vote of confidence in the administration of Premier George Athanasiades-Novas was expected to be held early tomorrow morning. In the lobbies, the predominant opinion was that Mr. Athanasiades-Novas has little chance of mustering a majority of the 300 deputies. At least 143 deputies belonging to the Center Union party are pledged to support former Premier George Papandreou. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 5, 1965

Fabio Zaffagnini, an enterprising 39-year-old fan of the Foo Fighters in Cesena, in Northern Italy, had an idea. He organized 1,000 people to play the band’s upbeat anthem “Learn to Fly,” had professionals film it, posted the video to YouTube — and watched it go viral.

headline: A Creperie, Délice & Sarrasin, Opens
abstract: Bar Goto gives cocktails an Asian spin; wood-fired ovens at Macchina; Indian flavorings at Madison Square Tavern, and more.
lead_paragraph: Délice & Sarrasin Hunger for authentic French crepes drove Christophe Caron, a model, to open this creperie. Mr. Caron enlisted his mother, Yvette, a chef and former surgeon, and his father, Patrick, an engineer, in the project. Now for the French lesson: The word sarrasin means “buckwheat” and refers to the flour traditionally used for savory crepes, or galettes as they are called in France. (Sweet crepes are made with white flour.) And at this charming little cafe, both varieties are well balanced. None of the filling combinations, including smoked salmon with shrimp, or chocolate and banana, overburden the flavor of the delicate crepe. Pastries, coffee drinks, wine and cider are also served: 20 Christopher Street (Gay Street), 212-243-7200, delicesarrasin.com.

headline: Siebel Institute Seeks to Make the Smart Grid Smarter
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Research']
abstract: The new Siebel Energy Institute is backing research into the software needed to deliver the energy-saving promise of smart-grid technology.
lead_paragraph: Companies and governments are investing heavily to digitize much of the world’s power grid with sensors. The worldwide spending estimates range up to $2 trillion over the next decade for everything from so-called smart meters and thermostats in homes to sensors on transformers and power lines. But if power-curbing and cost-saving sense is to be made of all the data flowing from those sensors, something more is needed — intelligent software.

headline: Shire’s Merger Machine Stumbles on Baxalta Bid

Unlike the previous combination, Shire’s $30 billion lunge for Baxalta carries a fair slug of industrial logic, as well as tax benefits. Its shareholders, though, still need some persuading.

headline: A Dirt Road in Gaza, Devised by Hamas as a Message to Israel

Jakar comes from a slang Arabic term that suggests provocation, stubbornness, an effort to vex or annoy or irritate.

headline: Hair Protection From the Sun, One Spritz (or Pump) at a Time
abstract: A handful of new serums and oils promise to protect locks from sun damage.
lead_paragraph: In the summer, protecting one’s hair from the sun isn’t always a top priority, with so much attention and energy paid to safeguarding the skin. But as anyone who’s seen blond turn to brass knows, the sun can do long-lasting damage to one’s locks. Luckily, there are a handful of products on the market to protect against it: Last summer, the Stockholm-based brand Sachajuan launched a leave-in serum that protects the hair from ultraviolet rays; earlier this year, the French colorist Christophe Robin released a treatment (with SPF 6) infused with lavender and plant oils to strengthen it before sun exposure. Elsewhere, Phyto introduced five oils in a single bottle as an after-sun mist to renew hair fibers and Davines relaunched its SU line in a four-product range, all with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory benefits. Even the 58-year-old hair-care company René Furterer added three new products to its already-established sun protection line, Soleil. But our favorite of the bunch is a sun-specific hair-repair shampoo, formulated with jojoba wax, that prevents strands from dehydration.

headline: In Zimbabwe, We Don’t Cry for Lions
abstract: Do Americans who are upset about Cecil even realize how terrifying animals can be?
lead_paragraph: Winston-Salem, N.C. — MY mind was absorbed by the biochemistry of gene editing when the text messages and Facebook posts distracted me.

headline: On Island of Lesbos, a Microcosm of Greece’s Other Crisis: Migrants
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The number of refugees and migrants arriving on Lesbos and on other Greek islands has surged to a full-scale disaster, and only squalor awaits them.
lead_paragraph: LESBOS, Greece — The immigration center here, a cluster of prefabricated buildings surrounded by rows of chain-link and barbed-wire fences, was full again on a recent evening, leaving hundreds of families, some with infants, to find a place among the piles of garbage outside.

headline: What’s the Buzz About Wild Bees?

lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman strolls through a Northern California farm with UC Berkeley’s Claire Kremen as she explains why pollinators — especially wild bees — are essential for crops.

headline: ‘What’s the Buzz About Wild Bees?’
abstract: Farming landscapes that encourage diverse pollinators, like bees, birds and insects, can help produce food that is abundant and nutritious.

headline: Refugee Crisis on the Beach in Greece
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The foreign correspondent Suzanne Daley reports on the scene in Lesbos, Greece, where thousands of migrants have washed up on shores popular with vacationing tourists.
lead_paragraph: Refugee camps are always sad, desperate places. I saw a lot of them when I was covering southern Africa for four years. But most were in desolate, poor places, not vacation islands like Lesbos, Greece, where thousands of refugees have been arriving in small inflatable boats, as upscale tourists do their best to unwind.

lead_paragraph: With tomatoes, it’s all about waiting for the vigorous, sometimes-gnarly ones grown outdoors. Shun those impostors at the supermarket. Though there have been early outdoor cherry tomatoes to tease us, now we can really let loose.

headline: Zucchini Two Ways
abstract: A cheesy flan and a twist on traditional fried zucchini to make the most of summer’s most prolific vegetable.
lead_paragraph: If you have a vegetable garden, you know the drill. A zucchini plant is prolific. Yesterday’s tiny squash has grown to medium-size seemingly overnight. And there are always a few giants lurking, like big fish that got away. But, if I may say, there is nothing like an unblemished, shiny, just-picked zucchini, whatever the size (well, perhaps not those great, great big ones).

Joining the ranks at the corn stand and rummaging for the best ears (heavy and green, with fresh-looking husks and silk) is a summer ritual. The reward for waiting is blissfully sweet corn, the kind that induces a certain euphoria.

And then there’s the Julie Klausner career path: Aspire to the Jim Gaffigan career path and then parlay your underachievement into a small-screen series loosely inspired by your own life.

That’s when we had fresh vegetables; the rest of the year, they came neatly frozen in their little paper boxes, just right for a family of four.

headline: Katie Ledecky Sets Another Record, Then Returns to Pool

The first was a plate of pasta with pesto sauce, a mound of rice, a piece of bread and green beans. The second, roughly three hours later, consisted of another plate of pasta.

lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — She is a magnificent specimen: the hair big and honey blond, the clothes snug and revealing, the jewelry copious and gold. Meticulously manicured, stalking around in screaming-orange sandals with wedge heels that would maim a weaker woman, the aggrieved Adriana is pure Jersey girl — the stereotypical variety.

lead_paragraph: The number of new Ebola diagnoses in Sierra Leone and Guinea reached its lowest point in well over a year last week, according to the World Health Organization, with only one reported case in each country. There were no new cases in Liberia, the third nation most severely affected by the outbreak.

abstract: The company said it was offering unlimited leave for new mothers and fathers for one year after the birth or adoption of a child.

headline: Rise of SoundExchange Shows the Growth of Digital Radio Royalties

lead_paragraph: For a sense of how quickly digital radio outlets like Pandora and SiriusXM have become a major source of revenue for the music industry, look no further than their royalty payments.

headline: Oklahoma Acts to Limit Earthquake Risk at Oil and Gas Wells
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Earthquakes', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A roughly 40-mile-long stretch that includes some 23 wells has experienced a dramatic increase in earthquakes in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: Oklahoma regulators have told energy companies to sharply reduce underground wastewater disposal across an earthquake-prone stretch of the state, a move that ratchets up a so-far unsuccessful effort to reduce quakes related to oil and gas production.

lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee said Tuesday that they had reached a $21 million settlement with hundreds of victims of sexual abuse by clergy members, though the agreement is still subject to approval by a federal judge.

lead_paragraph: The super PAC backing Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, who was relegated to the second-tier debate panel on Thursday in Cleveland, will broadcast an ad on Fox News in Iowa during the main event.

headline: Puerto Rico Has Another Debt Worry on Horizon
abstract: The government said it stopped making contributions to a fund that would pay an additional $13 billion in bond debt.
lead_paragraph: While Puerto Rico’s first bond default in its history reverberated through the financial markets on Tuesday, another move by the cash-poor island may provide a clue to where the next trouble spot lies.

headline: Judge Rejects Settlement in American Express Case
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Citing “egregious conduct” in text messages and emails between two lawyers, a federal judge scrapped a proposed $75 million settlement between American Express and a group of retailers.
lead_paragraph: It sounded like an innocuous message: “Amex negotiation has gotten crazy,” Gary Friedman, representing merchants in a lawsuit against American Express, said in a text message to his friend and fellow lawyer Keila Ravelo two years ago. “Gmailed u the issue.”

headline: U.N. Chief Appeals for More Aid to Support Palestinian Refugees
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon beseeched donors on Tuesday to fill an emergency $100 million gap in funding for the agency that aids five million Palestinian refugees.
lead_paragraph: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations beseeched donors on Tuesday to fill an emergency $100 million gap in funding for the agency that aids five million Palestinian refugees in the Middle East. In a statement, Mr. Ban said the shortfall confronting the United Nations Relief and Works Agency was unprecedented and risked disrupting the education of a half-million children. Many United Nations agencies are under severe financial pressure because of emergency efforts to help people displaced by the conflicts in Syria, Iraq and Yemen.

headline: Iraq: Funding Shortfall Deprives Uprooted Iraqis of Health Services
abstract: The aid agencies, including the W.H.O., need $60.9 million to operate their health care centers in Iraq but have received only $5.1 million from donors.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a shortage of funds, international aid agencies have been forced to suspend 84 percent of their health programs in 10 Iraqi provinces, depriving almost three million people of basic medical care, World Health Organization officials said Tuesday. The aid agencies, including the W.H.O., need $60.9 million to operate their health care centers in Iraq but have received only $5.1 million from donors. More than 184 centers serving refugees and other people displaced by violence in Iraq have suspended their operations, the W.H.O. said. The centers were the only health care providers in many parts of Iraq. “This is a country ravaged by conflict,” said Dr. Syed Jaffar Hussain, the W.H.O. representative in Iraq. “Not only do we have innocent civilians being caught in the violence, with so many people fleeing the fighting and living in temporary housing, people are at much higher risk from communicable diseases. Unless additional funding is received, millions more will be deprived of health services they urgently need.” The W.H.O. said it was appealing to international donors and seeking alternative sources of funding.

headline: Catch a Back-to-School Spending Break With Sales-Tax Holidays
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: At least 17 states will temporarily exempt state sales tax (and, in some cases, local sales taxes) for shoppers buying school supplies, clothing and other school needs.
lead_paragraph: August is time for back-to-school shopping — and, in many states, that means so-called sales-tax holidays as well.

headline: Friends of Joe Biden Worry a Run for President Could Bruise His Legacy
abstract: Few seem eager to tell the vice president of their reservations concerning a possible run for the presidency, regarded as a deeply personal decision.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Later this month, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will escape for a family retreat to mourn his late son, Beau, but also to mull, as his dying son urged him to do, a campaign for president. Some of Mr. Biden’s friends and allies worry that he will decide it is a good idea.

headline: Luis Severino Carries Hopes of Yankees
abstract: The Yankees lost Michael Pineda to injury and added no pitchers in trades. But on Wednesday, they will unveil Severino, who will be the youngest pitcher to make a start in the majors this season.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees took the field on Tuesday with precisely 600 innings from their starting pitchers this season. Only one winning team in the major leagues, the Kansas City Royals, had fewer. This explains the Yankees’ seemingly daily habit of calling up a fresh bullpen arm from the minors.

headline: Group Plans to Renovate Long-Neglected Areas of Prospect Park
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Prospect Park Alliance, a nonprofit that supports and operates the park, plans to restore the Rose Garden and the Vale of Cashmere, little-known areas on its east side.
lead_paragraph: When the gleaming Lakeside skating complex opened in Prospect Park’s southeast corner in 2013, it quieted critics who had long said that the park’s east side, which faces grittier neighborhoods, was being neglected.

headline: M.L.B. Advanced Media Joins With N.H.L. in Unusual Intersport Deal
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Hockey, Ice', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Television']
abstract: Major League Baseball Advanced Media will pay the N.H.L. $100 million annually for the right to operate the N.H.L.’s website as well as the league’s television and streaming services.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual transaction between two major sports entities, Major League Baseball Advanced Media will pay the National Hockey League $100 million annually starting next year to operate the NHL.com website, and the NHL Network will also distribute out-of-market games online through NHL GameCenter Live and through television providers on NHL Center Ice.

headline: Another Exoneration in Brooklyn Brings Total Since Last Year to 14
abstract: On Tuesday, Joel Fowler, who was found guilty of murder in 2009, became the latest person to have a conviction overturned since Kenneth P. Thompson became the borough’s district attorney in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Joel Fowler wore his green, prison-issued clothes for the last time on Tuesday.

headline: Fruit at an Oasis
abstract: Patrick Berry comes up with some interesting alibis. Sorry, I mean clues.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — If you’ve been reading Wordplay for a while, you will know that I firmly believe that the themes in some of the crosswords published here are subliminal messages from the constructors or, if they’ve been doing this for many years, an occasional cry for help. Today, we have a call for help from Patrick Berry, who has apparently landed himself in prison.

headline: Kentucky: Sheriff Defends Officer Shown Handcuffing Child in Video
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The county sheriff in Covington on Tuesday defended a school resource officer who was shown on a video restraining an 8-year-old boy with handcuffs last year.
lead_paragraph: The county sheriff in Covington on Tuesday defended a school resource officer who was shown on a video restraining an 8-year-old boy with handcuffs last year, saying the officer had acted appropriately while responding to a request from school officials to “de-escalate and defuse a threat to others.” The handcuffing is the subject of a federal lawsuit filed Monday by the American Civil Liberties Union against the Kenton County sheriff’s office, Sheriff Charles L. Korzenborn and the resource officer, Deputy Kevin Sumner; a video shows the boy, who has attention hyperactivity deficit disorder and had been acting out in school, crying as Deputy Sumner holds his arms behind his back and places handcuffs on his biceps. In a statement, Sheriff Korzenborn said the deputy “did what he is sworn to do and in conformity with all constitutional and law enforcement standards.”

headline: New York City Task Force Targets Cheating by Teachers and Principals
abstract: After several reports of cheating by teachers and administrators in city schools came to light this summer, the education department announced it would create a task force to confront the issue.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Department of Education said on Tuesday that it would establish a task force to root out cheating by teachers and administrators in city schools, responding to recent episodes and allegations of grade inflation, forged test answers and the passing of students who rarely attended class.

headline: Seeking Comedy at City Hall, Louis C.K. Shadows Mayor de Blasio
abstract: The actor and comedian Louis C.K. is spending two days observing Mayor Bill de Blasio as research for an upcoming, unspecified project.

headline: A B.Y.O.B. Peking Duck Feast With Some of New York’s Top Sommeliers
abstract: Crispy canard and crisp rieslings convene.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, Chinatown blazed in a noontime swelter as some of the city’s top sommeliers filed into the Peking Duck House on Mott Street. Each had a thing or two tucked under his or her arm — bottles of wine from their personal collections. Michael Madrigale, Bar Boulud’s head sommelier, entered with a 2007 Albert Boxler Riesling Grand Cru Brand ($50). Ashley Santoro, the wine director at Narcissa, came with a 1974 Francesco Rinaldi & Figli Barolo from Piedmont, Italy (about $115 retail). Patrick Cappiello was waiting for the sommeliers — eight, in all — with a magnum of Savart Premier Cru L’Accomplie Brut Champagne ($80). As the wine director for Rebelle and Pearl & Ash, sister restaurants on Bowery, Cappiello convenes these impromptu lunches about once a month, whenever the time allows. There are only two rules: Bring an intriguing bottle of wine; and keep it to around $100 each.

Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin compared this “multitiered confection with a romantic spirit and an enchantingly pretty veneer” to a wedding cake, adding that it was “elegant, festive and very, very funny.”

Those three words attest to a hard-earned wisdom, of learning how to survive challenges big and small, ideological and practical, without getting caught in the middle or, worse, on the wrong side.

headline: My Question for the Republican Presidential Debate
keywords: ['Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I’d certainly pay a nickel for the candidates’ thoughts.
lead_paragraph: If I got to ask one question of the presidential aspirants at Thursday’s Fox Republican debate, it would be this: “As part of a 1982 transportation bill, President Ronald Reagan agreed to boost the then 4-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax to 9 cents, saying, ‘When we first built our highways, we paid for them with a gas tax,’ adding, ‘It was a fair concept then, and it is today.’ Do you believe Reagan was right then, and would you agree to raise the gasoline tax by 5 cents a gallon today so we can pay for our highway bill, which is now stalled in Congress over funding?”

keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: The promise of integration vs. the reality of segregation.
lead_paragraph: If its goal is to move up the ladder, where should a poor family live? Should federal dollars go toward affordable housing within high-poverty neighborhoods, or should subsidies be used to move residents of impoverished communities into more upscale – and more resistant — sections of cities and suburbs with better schools and job opportunities?

headline: The Voting Rights Act at 50
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: Today, there are no poll taxes or literacy tests, but the right to vote is more fragile than ever.
lead_paragraph: For the first 48 years of its existence, the Voting Rights Act — signed by President Lyndon Johnson 50 years ago this week — was one of the most popular and effective civil rights laws in American history. Centuries of slavery, segregation and officially sanctioned discrimination had kept African-Americans from having any real voice in the nation’s politics. Under the aggressive new law, black voter registration and turnout soared, as did the number of black elected officials.

headline: Who Will Fund the M.T.A.?
abstract: The state and the city should seize this moment to find more lasting ways to sustain and upgrade the system.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority has said that it needs $29.8 billion in capital spending over the next five years if the nation’s largest mass transit system — the network of trains, buses and subways that supports New York City and its suburbs and serves 15.2 million people — has any real hope of improvement. The question, as always, is where this money will come from.

headline: ‘Verbatim: The Ferguson Case’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Jury System']
abstract: This short video contrasts the re-enacted testimony of two key witnesses in the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: By now, most Americans have heard of Ferguson, Mo.: on Aug. 9, 2014, a white police officer, Darren Wilson, shot an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, on a street in that suburb of St. Louis. One year later, the word “Ferguson” has become indelibly linked to the charged conversation about racial justice in the United States. Like many Americans, I followed the case and ensuing protests, absorbing a barrage of commentary from news sources and my social networks. And yet as the months wore on, and the officer was not indicted, I realized that I (perhaps like many others), was never clear on the details: What exactly happened in Ferguson the day Mr. Brown was shot?

abstract: The neighborhood is undeniably crowded during rush hour, and around tourist hubs like the World Trade Center site, but quiet corners can be found.

headline: Gary Rivlin’s ‘Katrina: After the Flood’
abstract: A former Times reporter examines how New Orleans and its residents have fared in the years since Katrina.
lead_paragraph: New Orleanians have been hearing it for 10 years now: How’s New Orleans doing? Is it back? Is the Lower Ninth Ward . . . O.K.? The questioner takes the tentative, commiserating tone one might use to inquire about a friend’s infirm grandmother who, at last report, had been moved to hospice. The local, sighing, responds tersely: New Orleans is doing terrifically and terribly. It’s back but different and currently undergoing a furious transformation. Much of the Lower Ninth Ward is not O.K. But each of these answers requires a book-length footnote. If you really want to know how New Orleans is doing, you have to ask different questions.

headline: ‘We’re Still Here Ya Bastards,’ by Roberta Brandes Gratz
abstract: An urbanist tracks the post-Katrina road to recovery.
lead_paragraph: When I first lived in New Orleans, during the spring of 2005, the unfinished work of Reconstruction was much on my mind. An obelisk near the ­Mississippi River commemorates a revolt against the Reconstruction government led by former Confederate soldiers. Half a mile away, where Canal Street meets North Rampart, I’d wait at a bus stop among people going home post-shift — hotel chambermaids and kitchen workers in their black-and-white checkered pants — waiting to be carried away from the city’s hallucinatory core to the New Orleans that lay beyond, a city whose racialized inequality was so entrenched it masqueraded as the natural order of things. During a public forum on gentrification at the historic St. Augustine Church, people spoke of being under siege. A neighbor told me, “If you cut the ground here, it will bleed black.”

headline: The Kansas Experiment
abstract: My uncle Gene is a state legislator in Topeka. This year, he and his fellow Republicans tried to do something pretty drastic with the state budget. And I got to watch the whole thing.
lead_paragraph: When I think of my uncle Gene, I think of a man who, late into the night at a particularly boisterous family wedding, would flatten his palms against the dance floor, extend his body parallel to the ground and then begin to undulate his legs and torso in a move known as the worm. Or I think of how, even later that same evening, he would agitate for a midnight meal at a diner in west Wichita, Kan., called the Golden Bell. Or of how, in his more abstemious workaday life, he left the family business — a small bank based in Colwich, a town of about 1,000 people in south-central Kansas, where he grew up alongside my father and 11 other siblings — so that he could expand a chain of pizzerias, which grew to include 48 franchises in five states.

headline: Ungrounded
abstract: I lived in a house on stilts. When my father died, I felt myself swaying with no underpinning, no support.

Despite this minor celebrity, there were certain perils to living in a house that didn’t touch the ground, the foremost being its sway in a powerful storm.
