lead_paragraph: Every year, natural disasters cost the United States billions in insured losses. In 2014, the figure reached $25 billion. Which disasters are the most common, and what do they cost?

headline: Is It Wrong If a Friend Sells My Hand-Me-Downs?
abstract: The Ethicists debate whether it is a violation of generosity to profit from a friend’s giveaways.
lead_paragraph: I have two small children and am frequently divesting our household of toys, clothes and other child supplies. I sell the larger items, but I typically give the smaller items away to a neighborhood parent or leave them in a box in front of my house to be taken for free. A friend on my block recently indicated that she takes much of what we leave out, and I’ve since offered her first pick before leaving the remaining items outside. I was happy to do so, as she has two children a bit younger than mine, and I considered it a worthwhile gesture to share what we no longer need with her, despite the fact that she is of similar economic status and likely doesn’t need our castoffs. She recently held a stoop sale, and I recognized a very large number of the items that were formerly ours on display for sale. Am I wrong to see this as somehow inappropriate? I recognize that a gift means I’m not free to question what the receiver does with it, but this has changed the way I feel about her and the prospect of putting out other items in the future. Am I wrong to feel that she should have passed on these items to others? NAME WITHHELD, BROOKLYN

headline: Assessing Tom Brady’s Stock in the Fashion World
abstract: Amid the accusations of Deflategate, his image has been tarnished. But how much will it really matter?
lead_paragraph: If we accept as a given in the fashion/celebrity complex that public figures sell clothes (and cars and cookies) — that their carefully constructed image transfers itself to the stuff that surrounds them, along the way suggesting that if we get that stuff, too, we might be more like them — does it then follow that the obverse is true? That the tarnishing of public figures tarnishes that which is associated with them, too?

headline: A Mess of Clams
abstract: Steamed clams and melted butter define summer perfection.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘The hard-shell is the king of the clams,’’ a clam merchant named Archie M. Clock told the New Yorker writer Joseph Mitchell in 1939. They were sitting on Clock’s battered old sloop, the Jennie Tucker, out on the wind-ruffled waters of the Great South Bay, off Islip and Babylon, on Long Island. Mitchell was there to report on the harvest of the hard-shell littleneck and cherrystone clams that then dominated the shellfish sections of New York restaurant menus.

headline: What’s Left of the Voting Rights Act?
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination', 'State Legislatures', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A federal court case in North Carolina could tell us.
lead_paragraph: My cover story in the Aug. 2 magazine details the half-century-long arc of the Voting Rights Act, from its passage as a signal accomplishment of the civil rights movement to the ultimately successful campaign to eradicate its strongest provisions at the Supreme Court in 2013. During my reporting I became particularly interested in the federal court challenge to North Carolina’s sweeping new voting law, which showed how the Supreme Court’s decision gutting key provisions of the law had immediate consequences in some states.

headline: Barrel Bombs, Not ISIS, Are the Greatest Threat to Syrians
abstract: The Syrian military is committing extraordinary slaughter in civilian neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — As the self-proclaimed Islamic State, or ISIS, commits horrendous videotaped executions, it might seem to pose the greatest threat to Syrian civilians. In fact, that ignoble distinction belongs to the barrel bombs being dropped by the military of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad. The Islamic State has distracted us from this deadly reality.

headline: What You Get for… $2,000,000
abstract: Water views in Georgia, Connecticut and Minneapolis
lead_paragraph: Water views in Georgia, Connecticut and Minneapolis

lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, GA.

headline: Halsey, With ‘Badlands,’ Is Moving Fast to Share a Secret Language
abstract: A 20-year-old New Jersey singer and her label, Astralwerks, release her first full album on Aug. 28, which may bring her half a million Twitter followers, some of them fans since Halsey was 14, to tears.
lead_paragraph: It was one thing for Ashley Nicolette Frangipane, a kid from New Jersey, to have 14,000 friends on MySpace at age 14 and 16,000 subscribers on YouTube at 18. But it’s quite another for Halsey, Ms. Frangipane’s pop-star alter ego, to have taken that innate 21st-century talent for self-presentation — not to mention songwriting — from her bedroom to arena stages in a mere year since signing with a record label.

headline: A Five-Bedroom 1927 Townhouse in a Suburb of Brussels
abstract: The house, in Uccle, south of the city, is on the market for $3.2 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, in Uccle, south of the city, is on the market for $3.2 million.

abstract: Prices in the affluent Brussels suburb of Uccle have risen 20 percent since 2008.
lead_paragraph: A FIVE-BEDROOM TOWNHOUSE IN A SUBURB OF BRUSSELS

headline: Daily Report: E-Sports Continues to Reshape Gaming Landscape
abstract: The marketing push with Halo 5 is a reminder that we’ve entered a brave new world, one in which, when the first Halo arrived 14 years ago, was barely a figment of our imagination.
lead_paragraph: Video games used to be such a simple business. You bought a console (say, an Xbox), you bought a game at your local big-box retailer ($46 for Halo: Combat Evolved at Wal-Mart), and you went on your merry way — spending hundreds of hours glued to a TV screen, blasting away at the bad guys.

headline: Morning Agenda: Puerto Rico’s Next Debt Problem
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Hedge Funds', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mortgages', 'PUERTO RICO', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Neiman Marcus files for I.P.O. | Shire Rebuffed by Baxalta | A Sydney Exchange Woos Chinese Listings
lead_paragraph: PUERTO RICO’S NEXT DEBT PROBLEM | The Puerto Rican government quietly disclosed on Monday afternoon that it had stopped making contributions of $92 million a month into a fund used to make payments on $13 billion in bond debt, Mary Williams Walsh writes in DealBook. A small payment from the fund is due on Sept. 1 and unlike the bond payments that went into default on Monday, these are general obligation bonds. Puerto Rico had issued such bonds over the years to raise money for government projects, with a guarantee in the island’s constitution that the bonds would be paid.

headline: There is No Pro-Life Case For Planned Parenthood
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Sex Education']
abstract: Why a popular argument for funding the nation’s largest abortion purveyor doesn’t hold up.
lead_paragraph: I’m hoping to do something broader about the abortion issue in this space soon, given the prominence that the debate over Planned Parenthood funding has suddenly assumed. But for this week a word (well, a few words) on the argument in this Dana Milbank column, which was also basically the argument in this earlier Milbank column, which is also roughly the argument in this Ruth Marcus column, which is also the argument in this Damon Linker column, which is also a case that Slate’s Will Saletan has made repeatedly in the past, which … well, you get the idea. The claim they’re all making, in different ways, is that even though Planned Parenthood performs hundreds of thousands of abortions every year (while lobbying constantly against any restriction on the practice), to oppose channeling public dollars to its family planning operations is to be objectively pro-abortion, because those operations objectively prevent many more abortions still.

headline: ‘Right to Be Forgotten’ Online Could Spread
abstract: Some countries’ demands for the erasure of search engine results on privacy grounds could soon affect even information available in the United States.
lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, in a decision that stunned many American Internet companies, Europe’s highest court ruled that search engines were required to grant an unusual right — the “right to be forgotten.” Privacy advocates cheered the decision by the European Court of Justice, which seemed to offer citizens some recourse to what had become a growing menace of modern life: The Internet never forgets, and, in its robotic zeal to collect and organize every scrap of data about everyone, it was beginning to wreak havoc on personal privacy.

headline: Tim Blanks Joins the Industry Website The Business of Fashion
abstract: The online publication, which began as an enthusiast’s blog, brings on the noted fashion journalist Tim Blanks as it expands its runway coverage.
lead_paragraph: Fashion’s never-ending game of musical chairs, a nonstop roundelay of personnel moves, tends to confine itself to those who create, rather than observe, fashion. Designers shuffle; those who file into the stands season after season to see their shows, less so.

headline: Review: ‘Let’s Be Less Stupid,’ a Distracted Meditation on Absent-Mindedness
abstract: In her latest work, Patricia Marx sets out to uncover why her brain, clogged with too many bits of information, does not seem to work the way it once did.
lead_paragraph: When you need something short and funny to read, it helps to have a few old journalistic favorites on standby. Mine include Dave Barry’s seminal Miami Herald piece “Can New York Save Itself?” and a Guardian article from 2002 in which the writer, Tim Dowling, was forced by his editors to spend a night in a trench in his backyard.

headline: No, Giving More People Health Insurance Doesn’t Save Money
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Preventive Medicine']
abstract: The argument for the cost savings from universal health coverage makes some intuitive sense, but it’s not backed up by research.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, an estimated  nine million people became newly insured thanks to Obamacare.

headline: Floyd Mayweather’s Choice of Andre Berto Excites Few
abstract: Mayweather, 38, has chosen a less than inspiring opponent for what he says will be his farewell fight: Andre Berto, 31, who is 3-3 in his last six bouts.
lead_paragraph: Floyd Mayweather Jr. has named the final opponent in his storied career. But the general reaction to his announcement has been resigned disappointment.

headline: Report Finds Wide Diversity Gap Among 2014’s Top-Grossing Films
keywords: ['Movies', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Minorities', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: A researcher of the report, which looks at gender, race and ethnicity in the most popular films in the United States, says there is an “epidemic” of lack of diversity.
lead_paragraph: The numbers are stunning: From 2007 through 2014, women made up only 30.2 percent of all speaking or named characters in the 100 top-grossing fictional films released in the United States. That’s bad enough to repeat: For every 2.3 male characters who say “Dude,” there is just one woman saying, “Hello?!”

headline: 1890: Push for President to Resign
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Argentina’s president is pressured to resign in 1890.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AYRES, Aug. 5 — Having failed to obtain a single Opposition Minister, President Celman has offered the city all kinds of privileges, including practical autonomy. The populace, sullen and menacing, refuse everything except the President’s resignation. The officers of the regiments that recently fought on opposite sides have fraternized and declare that in future the troops will not fight against each other. The naval opposition officers have been quietly permitted to resume their commands in the fleet. The situation here is unprecedented and almost incredible. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 6, 1890

headline: Jeb Bush on Funding for Women’s Health
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, said on Tuesday that he would cut off federal funding for Planned Parenthood if elected to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, said on Tuesday that he would cut off federal funding for Planned Parenthood if elected to the White House.

abstract: Despaña Brand Foods, in Jackson Heights, Queens, ships its chorizo all over the world. On Saturdays, it sets out samples of sausage and cheese for customers.
lead_paragraph: Despaña Brand Foods, in Jackson Heights, Queens, ships its chorizo all over the world. On Saturdays, it sets out samples of sausage and cheese for customers.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The radical preacher Anjem Choudary, some of whose followers have joined the Islamic State, was charged by the British authorities on Wednesday with inciting support for the organization.

lead_paragraph: Photos of the designer Adi Gil in South Sinai.

headline: Staging Passion Play for 200 Years, Italians Become More Than Merely Players
abstract: More than half of the 1,300 residents of Sordevolo, a town in Piedmont, are involved in the production in one guise or another.
lead_paragraph: SORDEVOLO, Italy — The horses were skittish. The microphones occasionally went silent or screeched shrilly. Phones in the audience trilled a little too often.

headline: From a Spanish Shop in Queens, Chorizo That’s Out of This World
abstract: Despaña Brand Foods, in Jackson Heights, is crammed with goods from Spain, as well as its own sausage, which an astronaut once took on a mission to space.
lead_paragraph: It is true that there’s a SoHo branch of Despaña Brand Foods, a chic and airy boutique on Broome Street. But to get the full sense of Despaña, you have to visit the original outlet in Queens, where the chorizo has been made for four decades.

headline: Kids in the Kitchen: No-Knead Bread for All Ages
abstract: Crusty. Easy. Kid-Friendly. Give your child 24 hours, and he’ll give you bread fit for any meal.
lead_paragraph: Who wouldn’t want children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthy meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task? In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlode’s KJ Dell’Antonia and Cooking’s Margaux Laskey work toward that long term goal with their very differently aged families. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11 and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own. This week, both families tried simple bread-making.

headline: Summer in Iraq: Beneath the Heat and Abaya and a Flak Jacket Too
keywords: ['Air Conditioning', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Weather']
abstract: Anne Barnard recalls the punishing heat of an Iraqi summer and the reporting challenges that it has presented in the past.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD – It was August 2004 in Najaf, in southern Iraq. Off to the west past the edge of town, the desert shimmered like a sea. In the streets, mud brick and cinder block magnified the heat. I was too busy to check the temperature, but at midafternoon, it was likely heading toward 120 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Egypt’s President Leads Celebration of ‘New’ Suez Canal
abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi is promoting a new channel of the Suez Canal as if it is a historic victory. But economists say it is unlikely to significantly transform the passage.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An image of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt triumphantly piloting a ship full of smiling Egyptians appears Wednesday on the cover of the state-owned newspaper Al Akhbar al Youm to mark the successful excavation of what he has called a new Suez Canal. Really, it is a new channel, parallel to about a third of the existing canal, intended to reduce shipping bottlenecks.

headline: Turkey’s Push Into War Is Seen as Erdogan’s Political Strategy
abstract: Analysts say that by resuming military operations against the Kurds, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting the stage for snap elections so his party can regain control of Parliament.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Confronted with widespread protests two summers ago, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan ordered a harsh police crackdown and tarnished the demonstrators as traitors and spies. Faced with a corruption inquiry focused on his inner circle, he responded by purging the police and judiciary.

headline: Shanice Williams to Play Dorothy in NBC’s Live Version of ‘The Wiz’
abstract: Shanice Williams, 18, will have her first major role as Dorothy in NBC’s live broadcast of “The Wiz.”
lead_paragraph: Shanice Williams will have some big silver shoes to fill. NBC announced Wednesday that she will play the lead role of Dorothy, made famous by Diana Ross in a 1978 film, in the network’s live version of “The Wiz.” Following on the heels of NBC’s live “The Sound of Music” in 2013 and “Peter Pan” in 2014, “The Wiz” will air Dec. 3.

headline: Kerry Washington’s Colorful, All-Paisley Layers

headline: A New Action Camera, Born From a Cycling Crash

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2012, a Brazilian software engineer named Bruno Gregory and a friend went for a bicycle ride in the hills of the East Bay, where Mr. Gregory was living. With a GoPro camera on one of their bikes recording the ride, a car mowed into the two cyclists, sending them hurtling to the pavement.

headline: Spotify’s Content Chief Moves to Online Video Start-Up Pluto TV
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Ken Parks, Spotify’s chief content officer and one of its longest-serving executives, will become Pluto TV’s executive chairman in October.
lead_paragraph: Spotify is losing a top executive to Pluto TV, a start-up in the fragmented and competitive world of online video.

headline: 1965: U.S. Jobless Rate at New Low
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The unemployment rate in the United States drops to an eight-year low in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The unemployment rate dropped to an eight-year low in July and President Johnson pledged today that his administration would try to cut it further. The Labor Department announced that unemployment fell to 4.5 percent of the working force last month from 4.7 percent in June. It attributed the drop to the heavy hiring of teenagers, young men, and adult women. Employment jumped sharply to a record high of 74,854,000. There were 1.1 million more at work in July than in June and 2.4 million more than in July a year ago. Mr. Johnson said he was ‘‘extremely pleased.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 6, 1965

headline: James Lecesne of the Trevor Project, Inhabiting Lives and Saving Them
abstract: The actor and writer is appearing Off Broadway in his solo show “The Absolute Brightness of Leonard Pelkey.”
lead_paragraph: Late in the first episode of Caitlyn Jenner’s documentary series “I Am Cait,” Ms. Jenner visits the family of Kyler Prescott, a 14-year-old transgender boy who committed suicide in May. “It’s so hard for young people,” Ms. Jenner says. “They can’t see the future, and because of that they become extraordinarily desperate and suicide becomes an option. We have to do something about that.”

headline: A Real Adventure: Sorting Out All the F.K.T.s (Fastest Known Times)
abstract: Peter Bakwin’s website is the closest thing that trail running and speed hiking have to a record book, making him the endurance genre’s de facto commissioner.
lead_paragraph: When a man named Brett Maune completed California’s 223-mile John Muir Trail in record time in 2009, crushing the previous mark by many hours, he was surprised to be greeted mostly by online doubters.

headline: Blocking a PC’s Webcam
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cameras', 'Smartphones', 'Recording Equipment', 'Google Phone', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Computer Security']

lead_paragraph: Q. I never use the built-in webcam on my PC laptop. Is there a way to deactivate it in case I ever get infected with any malware that tries to use the camera?

headline: Guerrilla Girls, Going and Going …
abstract: Thirty years after the feminist activists began, the Guerrilla Girls are still going. Their identities remain a secret but their fight for equality in the art world still attracts legions of fans.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years after the feminist activists began, the Guerrilla Girls are still going. Their identities remain a secret but their fight for equality in the art world still attracts legions of fans.

headline: Cheryl Boone Isaacs Re-Elected President of Motion Picture Academy
abstract: Ms. Isaacs was elected to a third one-year term as president of the group that grants the annual Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Cheryl Boone Isaacs was elected to a third one-year term as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Tuesday, the Academy said. Academy presidents may serve up to four consecutive years under the group’s rules, and have typically been re-elected by its governors if they choose to return.

headline: Style, Substance, and The Donald
abstract: Who’s really being taken in?
lead_paragraph: Just about the entire political commentariat has been caught completely flatfooted by Donald Trump’s durable front-runner status; he was supposed to collapse after being nasty to St. John McCain, but nothing of the sort happened.

headline: The Guerrilla Girls, After 3 Decades, Still Rattling Art World Cages
abstract: The activist, feminist art collective began protesting inequality at New York museums in 1985. Now, their work appears in them.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve spent 30 years wearing a gorilla mask, as the women known by the aliases Frida Kahlo and Käthe Kollwitz have, certain behavior becomes second nature. So there were Kahlo and Kollwitz, two of the pseudonymous founding members of the Guerrilla Girls, the activist, feminist art collective, preening and posing at their 30th anniversary party and retrospective in May. They sipped prosecco through straws (their gorilla lips wouldn’t allow much more) at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side, while guests gazed at walls lined with the posters protesting elitism and bias that first shook the art world in the 1980s. “Do Women Have to Be Naked to Get Into the Met Museum?” one provocatively asked. The Guerrillas’ name tags identified them as pioneering dead female artists (like Alice Neel, the portraitist, or Zubeida Agha, the Pakistani modernist) whose legacies they hope to continue.

headline: S.E.C. Approves Rule on C.E.O. Pay Ratio
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Income Inequality', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

headline: A Virtual Reality Film Festival Becomes a Reality
abstract: The Kaleidoscope VR Film Festival will tour the country, showcasing the work of independent filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: Would you like to be in a movie? How about inside a movie? A new film festival focused solely on virtual reality projects will give audiences that opportunity. The inaugural Kaleidoscope VR Film Festival, announced by organizers on Wednesday, will go on a 10-city tour and will feature a variety of virtual reality films by independent filmmakers. It will start Aug. 22 in Portland, Ore., and move on to San Francisco and Los Angeles, among other cities. It comes to New York on Oct. 6.

headline: Liquefied Natural Gas Makes Qatar an Energy Giant
abstract: A rich natural gas field and a fleet of ships has turned Qatar, once a poor nation of fishers and pearl divers, into a major player in the global energy trade.
lead_paragraph: RAS LAFFAN, Qatar — The temperature hovered around 100 degrees on the jetty here, where a set of pipes were connected to a giant red-hulled ship. But the moisture in the air froze on the pipes and flaked off, creating snowlike flurries on the early summer evening.

keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Drownings', 'Rescues', 'Boats and Boating', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Rescuers saved 400 people, though 25 died when the boat overturned, and another hundred were feared to have drowned, Italian officials said.
lead_paragraph: ROME — An overcrowded fishing boat carrying migrants to Europe capsized on Wednesday, apparently after being approached by a rescue vessel a few miles off the coast of Libya. Rescuers saved 400 people, though 25 died when the boat overturned, and another hundred were feared to have drowned, Italian officials said.

headline: It’s Either Iran Nuclear Deal or ‘Some Form of War,’ Obama Warns
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: President Obama portrayed the coming vote in Congress on the deal as the most consequential foreign policy decision for lawmakers since the vote to authorize the invasion of Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama took on critics of the nuclear deal between Iran and six world powers in an aggressive speech on Wednesday, saying they were the same people who created the “drumbeat of war” and played on public fears to push the United States into the Iraq war more than a decade ago.

headline: Three Reasons to (Still) Visit Puerto Rico
abstract: We’ve asked travel experts for their thoughts on how Puerto Rico’s financial crisis will affect the island’s $7 billion tourism industry.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico faces a potentially crippling financial crisis that is drawing comparisons with Greece. We’ve asked travel experts to share their perspective on how the crisis will affect the island’s $7 billion tourism industry. So if you’re planning a trip to Puerto Rico, here are three things to keep in mind.

headline: 36 Hours in Provence
abstract: The Roman-era town of Arles and the medieval walled city of Avignon combine a dense mix of architectural beauty, world-class art and sun-soaked Provençal gastronomy.
lead_paragraph: Exploring Provence’s vast, rugged sprawl can be exhilarating — and daunting. From the salt marshes of the Camargue to storybook hilltop villages like Gordes to the lively Mediterranean city of Marseille, the famously picturesque French region offers an array of landscapes and experiences that could take months to uncover. Where to start? Arles and Avignon. Just 20 minutes apart by train, the Roman-era town of Arles and the medieval walled city of Avignon enfold a dense mix of architectural beauty, world-class art, sun-soaked Provençal gastronomy and Unesco World Heritage sites. Toss in ambitious new cultural spaces, a hint of urban cool and a high-speed rail link with Paris (about three hours away), and the result is a southern French smorgasbord that can be devoured in a weekend.

headline: Bank of America Starts to Pull Clients’ Money Out of a Paulson Fund
abstract: The move comes during a rocky year for the hedge fund billionaire John A. Paulson, who has bets on Greece and Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: John A. Paulson, the billionaire investor who rose to fame betting against the housing market bubble, is having a rocky 2015. And at least one major investor may have had enough.

headline: Revisiting Ferguson
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Monica Davey returns to the scene of last summer’s racial unrest.
lead_paragraph: The strangest thing about returning to write about Ferguson, Mo., almost a year after the death of Michael Brown, the black teenager who was fatally shot by a white police officer, was how ordinary the place looked.

headline: The Key Numbers in the California Wildfires
abstract: Dozens of fires have burned tens of thousands of acres of land in the state and prompted the evacuation of entire communities. Here are the latest statistics.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of wildfires have burned tens of thousands of acres in California and prompted the evacuation of entire communities. The fires are part of a regional phenomenon of severe drought and heat that has gripped the West.

headline: Pope Francis Urges Priests to Welcome Remarried Catholics
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Excommunication', 'Priests', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: In his first remarks to his general audience after a summer break, Francis reminded church leaders that divorced Catholics who remarry “are not at all excommunicated.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — In brief remarks on Wednesday, Pope Francis offered a comforting word for divorced Catholics and their children, urging priests to welcome and foster these families with “doors wide open.”

headline: Departing German Prosecutor Defends Treason Inquiry Against Bloggers
abstract: The prosecutor was forced to retire after it was revealed that he had been investigating two journalists who wrote about plans to increase digital surveillance.
lead_paragraph: MÜNSTER, Germany — Germany’s outgoing federal prosecutor defended his decision to open a treason inquiry against two journalists, saying on Wednesday that an independent assessment he had ordered supported the domestic intelligence agency’s claim that the journalists’ publication of an official document, on April 15, violated a state secret.

headline: Manslaughter Charges for Construction Managers After Queens Worker Dies in Pit Collapse
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Building (Construction)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, also announced the creation of a task force to help identify and prosecute corruption and fraud in the construction business.
lead_paragraph: With construction-related deaths and injuries on the rise, prosecutors announced on Wednesday that manslaughter and other charges were being brought against two construction managers and the companies they worked for in the April death of a worker at a Lower Manhattan building site.

headline: Eleanor Roosevelt Is Top Choice for the $10 Bill, Poll Finds
abstract: A Marist poll finds that about one in three women would pick Mrs. Roosevelt, with Harriet Tubman taking second place.

headline: New Poll Shows Mayor de Blasio’s Support Has Eroded
abstract: The Quinnipiac University survey showed that 44 percent of New York City voters approved of the mayor’s performance, with the same share disapproving.

headline: A New Throwback Joint From the Cabin Down Below’s Jesse Malin
abstract: Berlin, located on the underground level of a storied East Village watering hole, aims to recapture the neighborhood’s old spirit.
lead_paragraph: The East Village nightlife entrepreneur and musician Jesse Malin has a fondness for the neighborhood’s bygone, coarser days. Now, the area is filled with rising rents and Pilates studios, but the little empire of hip haunts Malin has helped to build below 14th Street — Black Market, the Bowery Electric, Niagara, Lovers of Today, Dream Baby and the Cabin Down Below, the intimate clubhouse-like bar just off Tompkins Square Park — pay homage to the neighborhood of 40 years ago. And Malin’s obsessive interest in creating auras of New York authenticity (or, at least, the closest approximation 2015 can offer) is likewise demonstrated in Berlin, the small club he opened last Tuesday on Avenue A.

headline: Adidas Acquires Runtastic, a Maker of Fitness Apps and Devices
abstract: The deal, which values Runtastic at $239 million, will help Adidas better compete with rivals like Under Armour and Nike in wearable technology.

headline: Estate of Man Exonerated in 1992 Murders Sues New York City and Police
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: Tiffany Wilson had just turned 6 when her brother Sharrif, 15, was arrested. He and another teenager were convicted of murdering the other teenager’s mother, 12-year-old sister and another girl. All of the victims had been stabbed then strangled with electrical cords.

headline: Following Netflix, Microsoft Sweetens Parental Leave Benefits

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft said on Wednesday that it would offer new parents an additional eight weeks of paid time off from their jobs at the company, in a significant boost to its parental leave benefits.

headline: Richard Matt, New York Prison Escapee, Was Intoxicated When He Died, Police Say
abstract: Mr. Matt had a blood-alcohol content of 0.18 percent at the time he was shot and killed by the authorities.
lead_paragraph: Richard W. Matt, the prison escapee who was shot and killed by a federal agent in June, had a blood alcohol content of 0.18 percent when he died, more than double the level that would make him legally intoxicated, the New York State Police said on Wednesday.

headline: California Fire, Aided by Drought, Defies Tactics to Defeat It
abstract: The blaze has easily overcome barriers meant to contain it, turning computer models of how it will burn into futile predictors, officials said.
lead_paragraph: LAKEPORT, Calif. — As firefighters on Wednesday embarked on their sixth day of battling the largest of the many wildfires that have flared across the state, fire officials said the Rocky Fire, which has grown to consume nearly 70,000 acres here in the northern reaches of wine country, was still nowhere near under control and may not be until perhaps Monday.

headline: Obama Takes On Opponents of the Iran Deal
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: The trenchant speech reveals how opponents of the nuclear agreement are still wrapped in the mind-set that led America into the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Wednesday made a powerful case for the strong and effective nuclear agreement with Iran. In a speech at American University, he directly rebutted critics like Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and rightly warned of the damage to global security if the Republican-led Congress rejects the agreement.

headline: Money, Lust and Kung Fu: Shaolin’s ‘C.E.O. Monk’ Is Under Fire
abstract: Much of China is transfixed by allegations that the abbot of the famed Shaolin Temple, now a commercial empire, is a swindler and serial philanderer.
lead_paragraph: DENGFENG, China — Incense drifting through ancient cedars. Saffron-robed monks, limbs a blur of movement, making quick work of imagined enemies. The boing of a giant bronze bell calling the faithful to prayer.

headline: Days of Selling Popular College Players’ Jerseys Seem Numbered
abstract: With several financial issues in college sports being litigated or debated, some colleges have stopped selling jerseys with popular players’ numbers on them.
lead_paragraph: Last year, any Ohio State fan could buy an officially licensed Buckeyes football jersey bearing No. 97. Though N.C.A.A. rules prohibit colleges from selling jerseys with players’ names on them, Ohio State fans understood what a scarlet jersey with a white 97 meant: a tribute to the star defensive end Joey Bosa, who wears the number when the Buckeyes play.

headline: The Proms, BBC’s Classical Music Festival, Is All the More Important as Austerity Looms
abstract: The event, this year spread over eight weeks and featuring 76 major concerts, should continue to be broadcast on the national classical station.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Classical music has been part of the British Broadcasting Corporation’s mission since its early years. In 1927, when the BBC’s first royal charter  dedicated it to “education and entertainment,” the corporation also took over the Henry Wood Promenade Concerts. That music festival, dating to 1895, has been under the BBC’s stewardship ever since, barring a brief wartime interlude.

headline: A Woman on the $10 or the $20 Bill?
abstract: It would be far better for a woman to replace Andrew Jackson than Alexander Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: A new poll out on Wednesday shows that 27 percent of Americans would like to see Eleanor Roosevelt on the $10 bill and about 17 percent want Harriet Tubman. Sacagawea came in third with 13 percent and Susan B. Anthony and Amelia Earhart each had 11 percent.

headline: Temporary Tattoos, Now for Grown-Ups, Too
abstract: Adults are impermanently inking up in style with help from companies like Tattly.
lead_paragraph: At a Friday night cocktail party early this year at the auction house Christie’s, some 400 prospective buyers in their 30s and 40s were checking out the old masterworks up for auction, including Caravaggio, a pair of Canalettos and a sketch by Rubens. But the art that drew the most fuss from the collectors was free: temporary tattoos that echoed the paintings for sale, including demons by a follower of Hieronymus Bosch and the monogram-like signature of Albrecht Dürer.

headline: A George Benjamin Exacting Storm in Opera Comes to Mostly Mozart
abstract: With his opera “Written on Skin,” George Benjamin, a master of restraint, delivers a punch in a velvet glove with devastating stealth.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one description that persistently attaches to the music of George Benjamin it’s “fastidious”: a word that doesn’t promise much for a career in opera, where grand, sweeping gestures tend to count for more than careful details. Opera is a rough-and-tumble business. Mr. Benjamin is, in the nicest way, exquisite.

headline: Donald Trump and Bill Clinton Chatted by Phone Before Trump Announced Candidacy
abstract: Shortly before he kicked off his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump had a cordial phone conversation with former President Bill Clinton, but Mrs. Clinton’s presidential ambitions apparently did not come up.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before Donald J. Trump kicked off his presidential campaign, he had a genial phone conversation with former President Bill Clinton, but the two apparently did not discuss the race itself or Hillary Rodham Clinton’s bid for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Hiroshima Atomic Bomb Survivors Pass Their Stories to a New Generation
abstract: In a Japanese project, volunteers called “denshosha” spend time with elderly survivors of the bombing, learning their stories to pass them along.
lead_paragraph: HIROSHIMA, Japan — Hiromi Hasai was being trained to make machine gun bullets when the flash from the atomic bomb that destroyed his city lit up the already bright morning sky. Just 14, he had been pulled from school a week before to help Japan’s failing war effort.

headline: Best Is Still to Come in Pearson Breakup
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Pearson values its stake in Penguin Random House at $1.7 billion. But waiting to sell that stake to the co-owner, Bertelsmann, could bring a better price.
lead_paragraph: The best chapter of Pearson’s breakup is yet to be written. Selling a 47 percent stake in the book publisher Penguin Random House to the co-owner Bertelsmann might generate twice as much as The Financial Times, which the British company sold to Japan’s Nikkei for 844 million pounds ($1.3 billion) last month. Pearson’s chief executive, John Fallon, can unshackle himself from the publisher of “Fifty Shades of Grey” as early as October, when a lockup ends. Yet it makes sense to wait.

headline: Texas ID Law Called Breach of Voting Rights Act
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Discrimination', 'Identification Devices', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The court ruling centers on a state requirement that would-be voters produce some specific forms of government-issued photo identification.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel ruled Wednesday that a strict voter identification law in Texas discriminated against blacks and Hispanics and violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965 — a decision that election experts called an important step toward defining the reach of the landmark law.

headline: Value of Iran Sanctions Relief Is Hard to Measure
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Even the Iranians do not seem to know how much money in impounded accounts overseas would be available to them.
lead_paragraph: A principal argument opponents raise against the nuclear agreement with Iran is that it would release at least $100 billion in impounded funds that Tehran could then use for attacks against the West and others. But exactly how much money the Iranians would actually receive and how they would use it, should the accord survive, remain difficult and unresolved questions.

headline: At Glimmerglass Festival, ‘The Magic Flute’ Is Among the Reimagined
abstract: In addition to Mozart’s “Flute,” this event’s 40th-anniversary repertory includes productions of “Cato in Utica,” “Candide” and “Macbeth.”
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — No, Vivaldi’s “Cato in Utica” is set not in Utica, N.Y., some 40 miles to the north of here, but in the ancient North African city of that name. Mozart’s “The Magic Flute,” on the other hand, is set in the woods virtually next door.

headline: Reddit Sets New Content Policy, Banning Some Racist Communities

lead_paragraph: Reddit, the popular community news site, formalized a new set of guidelines that aim to restrict some of the risqué and potentially offensive content posted to the site.

headline: Spain Says Banker’s Seized Picasso Will Head Back Home
abstract: Customs officials confiscated the painting, valued at nearly $30 million, after its owner’s yacht left Spain for French waters.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — To the Spanish authorities, Picasso’s 1906 “Head of a Young Woman” is a unique painting, the only example in Spain from a pivotal period in the artist’s life. Because of that status, the courts labeled it a “national treasure” that should not be sold outside the country.

headline: Tesla Motors Trims Delivery Outlook, Sending Stock Down
abstract: The maker of high-end electric cars reported more revenue and a smaller loss than analysts predicted, but said it expected production challenges.
lead_paragraph: Even as Tesla Motors painted a better-than-expected financial picture in announcing its second-quarter earnings on Wednesday, it warned of fewer car deliveries for the year, sending the stock tumbling.

headline: Review: Joshua Beamish Takes On Challenges Within Couples, in 4 Takes
abstract: The choreographer presented four works, including the highly involved ensemble piece “Surface Properties” and a sensual duet, “Stay.”
lead_paragraph: Do major ballet companies commission new works by committee, or does it just seem that way? Depending on the year, certain choreographers — lately Liam Scarlett and Justin Peck — are suddenly everywhere. But what about all the others plugging away? The Joyce Theater plays host to several in its two-week Ballet Festival, which began Tuesday with Joshua Beamish’s MOVE: the company.

headline: Review: ‘Swing That Music,’ Effortless Fun in a Tribute to Jazz Forerunners
abstract: Danny Bacher, with a lineup of seasoned traditional jazzmen, conflated the music of three Louises — Armstrong, Jordan and Prima — at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: The secret of serious fun is not to take it too seriously, especially if it involves playing jazz. That attitude is something that the easygoing singer and saxophonist Danny Bacher, who appeared with a small swing band at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening, knows in his bones. It is about making hot music but staying cool, about cutting up while maintaining effortless self-control, about having a blast with friends. And at his performance of “Swing That Music,” a homage to the era of jumpin’ jive with a dollop of Dixieland, Mr. Bacher conflated the music of three Louises — Armstrong, Jordan and Prima — in a concert revealing him to be a prodigiously talented musical preservationist.

headline: Los Angeles Agrees to Overhaul Jails to Care for Mentally Ill and Curb Abuse
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Police']
abstract: The settlement with the Justice Department comes after disclosures that guards routinely abused prisoners, including breaking bones and sexually humiliating them.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After disclosures of routine prisoner abuse by the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department — where jailers were found to break prisoners’ bones and sexually humiliate them — a settlement was announced Wednesday with the Justice Department in which the county will submit to sweeping reforms of its jail system, with the goals of improving the care of mentally ill inmates and curtailing abuse by deputies.

headline: Review: Vail International Dance Festival Celebrates Meter
abstract: New creations at this year’s festival included Dance Heginbotham’s “Easy Win,” Matthew Neenan’s “Show Me” and a touch of flamenco nuevo.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — Every August, the Vail International Dance Festival, high in the Rockies here, presents an impressive collection of world premieres: ballet, modern dance and other genres. While there’s no scenery (except the mountains), most performances are accompanied by live music. And most of the dancers and choreographers are well known — often from New York.

headline: Yahoo Tweaks Email to Make Search More Personal
abstract: The company is making small changes to sort email search results better, changes that it hopes to extend to its other services.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Searching email is generally an exercise in frustration.

headline: When Architecture Meets Pop Culture (Kanye West Included)
abstract: Oana Stanescu is making a name for herself in design circles for her ability to merge pop culture with utilitarian design (see: a swimming pool in the East River).
lead_paragraph: For a serious architect who has designed public housing in Dallas and a bridge in Slovenia, it may come as a surprise that Oana Stanescu’s best-known work is a 50-foot-high volcano that Kanye West ascended onstage during his grandiose Yeezus tour.

headline: Midcentury Chic at Loosie Rouge, in Williamsburg’s South Side
abstract: A hangout for neighborhood holdouts who want a spot away from the hipster crowds.
lead_paragraph: For longtime Williamsburg denizens, the area’s North Side now feels like a grim “Mad Max” wasteland patrolled by clean-cut conquistadors in hipster Halloween costumes. Seeking cooler climes, the neighborhood’s holdouts now huddle in a South Side oasis along Broadway, just south of the Williamsburg Bridge, where new spots like Loosie Rouge have cropped up around the stately century-old street.

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Fiat Chrysler Automobiles said on Wednesday that profits at its American subsidiary fell 3 percent in the second quarter, primarily because of a record civil penalty against the company for violating federal safety laws.

headline: The Accidental Historian of Drag Queens
abstract: The drag comic Linda Simpson took thousands of photos at clubs, pride parades and on the street during the ’80s and ’90s heyday of New York drag queens.
lead_paragraph: Long before “RuPaul’s Drag Race” made cross-dressing a televised form of mainstream entertainment, there was the drag boom of the 1980s and ’90s, when a burgeoning New York club scene was filled with drag performers who perfected the art form.

headline: Four Cool New(ish) Summer Surf Breaks
abstract: The waves await, at spots near (the Rockaways in New York) and far (Bundoran, Ireland).
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to own a quiver of boards or a vintage Volkswagen Westfalia to head out on an old-school surfari this season. A quick flight and a few phone calls to surf schools and hotels will put you on the best waves of your life. Listed here are the greatest quick hits for an endless summer.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Handbags and Purses']
abstract: At Moschino’s new boutique in SoHo, find an array of Looney Tunes items from Jeremy Scott. And Betsey Johnson is holding a yard sale in the Hamptons.
lead_paragraph: What’s up, Doc? This week, Moschino opens a New York boutique in SoHo. There you’ll find all manner of Looney Tunes-themed items from the designer Jeremy Scott’s fall collection, like a Bugs Bunny sweater dress ($895), a Tweety Bird bucket bag ($950) and a Daffy Duck iPhone 6 case ($75) to celebrate your inner child. At 73 Wooster Street.

headline: Bill Plympton Lends His Animation Skills to ‘Kahlil Gibran’s The Prophet’
abstract: A talk with the animator about his work on this collaborative project, as well as his own original work.
lead_paragraph: Since the late 1970s, Bill Plympton has been creating shorts and features that use hand-drawn animation to explore adult themes, like  relationships and sexuality. That was the case with his recent film “Cheatin’ ” which looked at difficulties in a relationship with a fever-dream kind of style. He has also collaborated with recording artists including Kanye West on music videos and has drawn some of the opening couch gags for “Simpsons” episodes. His contributions to anthology projects included a segment in the film “The ABCs of Death 2″ and “The Animation Show,” a compilation  put together by Don Hertzfeldt and Mike Judge.

headline: Fox, Topping Projections, Reports a Tough Quarter
abstract: Profits beat expectations, but were down nonetheless, as broadcasting trouble, lower movie revenue and higher sports costs cut into cable-affiliate growth.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Reporting its first quarterly results since Rupert Murdoch stepped aside as chief executive, 21st Century Fox revealed a mixed picture on Wednesday: Profits beat expectations, but were down nonetheless, as broadcasting trouble, lower movie revenue and higher sports costs cut into cable-affiliate growth.

headline: New Hampshire: A Vote Against Planned Parenthood
abstract: Officials on Wednesday voted against funding health centers operated by Planned Parenthood of Northern New England.
lead_paragraph: Officials  on Wednesday voted against funding  health centers operated by Planned Parenthood of Northern New England. New Hampshire’s Executive Council voted, 3 to 2, to reject contracts that would have provided the organization’s centers in the state with about $638,000 over two years, roughly one-third of the public funding for the centers, which is primarily federal.  Planned Parenthood, whose centers  provides reproductive health services that sometimes include abortion, has been under fire after an abortion opponent released undercover videos showing its officials discussing fees for fetal tissue donation. Lawmakers elsewhere have also called for funding cuts. On Monday, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana announced that his state would terminate its Medicaid contract with the organization. On Wednesday, the councilors in New Hampshire approved contracts for three other reproductive health service providers.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']

lead_paragraph: Another member of the brotherhood left the family just before game time on Wednesday. Daniel Nava, an outfielder on the Boston Red Sox’ 2013 championship team, was claimed on waivers by Tampa Bay. The Red Sox cut him last week, when he was hitting .152.

keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Income Inequality', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Wages and Salaries']

lead_paragraph: While chief executives generally prefer not to say how much more money they make than their typical employee, some have found it advantageous to do just that.

headline: Fox News Moderators Look for Ways to Keep 10 Candidates on Their Toes
abstract: Behind the scenes, the Fox News team has spent weeks discussing how to handle the challenges of the first Republican presidential primary debate.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Just over 24 hours before the first Republican primary debate here, more than a dozen Fox News executives and producers gathered Wednesday with their debate moderators — Bret Baier, Megyn Kelly and Chris Wallace — backstage at Quicken Loans Arena for a final run-through of logistics.

headline: High Diving, a Crowd-Pleasing Sport, Pursues an Olympic Platform
abstract: The 27-meter high diving world championships were contested in Kazan, Russia, in what the sport’s enthusiasts hoped would be a prelude to acceptance in the 2020 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — It makes no sense that the International Olympic Committee voted Beijing, a city devoid of snow, to be a Winter Games host but has resisted inviting high diving into the Summer Olympics. The men’s high diving event on Wednesday at the FINA world championships, won by Britain’s Gary Hunt, was more entertaining than puppy videos on YouTube.

headline: De Blasio, Facing Criticism, Is Taking On Homelessness With $22 Million Initiative
abstract: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has staked his administration on battling inequality, dealing with what seems to be a growing homelessness problem is as much about social reform as political survival.
lead_paragraph: The question has leapt from dinner parties to community boards to the nightly news, its implications echoing in the highest echelons of City Hall: Why are there so many homeless people in New York?

headline: Bronx Man’s Death From Legionnaires’ Disease Gives Family Cause to Worry
abstract: The family of Carmelo Quiles said they did not know how the man contracted the disease, and worried whether they, too, were at risk.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Quiles was a man of routine. He did not live with his wife anymore, but he rode two buses every day to see her. No later than 9 a.m., he would knock on the door of her brick house in the South Bronx and call her name through the window to let her know he had arrived for his daily visit.

headline: Bob Timmons, 91, a Demanding Coach Who Developed a Star Runner, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Timmons, whose most famous athlete was the Olympian and world-record holder Jim Ryun, enjoyed great success in more than two decades at the University of Kansas.
lead_paragraph: Bob Timmons, a former wartime Marine whose rugged brand of coaching helped Jim Ryun become America’s most celebrated mile runner of the 1960s, died on Tuesday in Lawrence, Kan. He was 91.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Visit Liberty University, a Rare Venue for a Democratic Campaign
abstract: Mr. Sanders will speak at the university founded by the Rev. Jerry Falwell, despite, the senator said, the “very different” views he and the conservative institution have.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will address a convocation next month at Liberty University, the evangelical school where the firebrand Senator Ted Cruz kicked off his own presidential campaign.

headline: High Emotion at Aurora Shooting Trial as Families Share Stories of Lives Cut Short
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Emotional testimony from family members of the victims of a 2012 shooting in a movie theater in Aurora, Colo., could sway jurors weighing the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — Through three months of testimony and deliberation, the 12 people killed inside a Colorado movie theater have existed as little more than names and faces, glimpsed mostly through their final actions before an armor-clad gunman walked in and started shooting one night in July 2012.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate headed into its August recess on Wednesday without voting on a cybersecurity bill, adding it to a contentious to-do list for September that includes a push to disapprove the Iran nuclear deal and a spending fight mired in abortion politics.

headline: Seeing Likely Nominee, Hillary Clinton Hits Jeb Bush Hard
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s aides, for the most part, believe Jeb Bush will win the Republican nomination, so she is jabbing at him on issues where they think he is vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has very noticeably and intensely trained her sights on a single rival candidate for president: Jeb Bush.

headline: Senate Report Cites I.R.S. Mismanagement in Targeting of Tea Party Groups
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Taxation']
abstract: A report released by the bipartisan panel said the Internal Revenue Service improperly targeted conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status but it did not suggest that any laws were broken.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Senate committee on Wednesday closed a two-year investigation with unanimous agreement that mismanagement at the Internal Revenue Service led it to improperly target conservative groups seeking tax-exempt status. But a report by the panel did not suggest that any laws were broken, and Republicans and Democrats were divided over whether White House politics was behind the problems.

headline: We Write to Taste Life Twice

lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Ah, cross-referenced clues. For some solvers, they are the bane of existence, while others just don’t care. I highly doubt that anyone loves them, because they have a tendency to interrupt a good solving flow.

headline: Luis Severino, in a Loss, Shows the Yankees What They’ve Gained

lead_paragraph: His preparations complete, Luis Severino left the bullpen and made his way across the outfield grass toward the first-base dugout. Soon, he would take the mound in a major league stadium for the first time. As he made that walk, he reflected on what the moment meant.

lead_paragraph: After decades of delay, federal workplace regulators on Thursday proposed a sharply lower limit for exposure to beryllium, a widely used industrial mineral, which is linked to a deadly lung disease.

lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Like many players in high school, Julian Howsare started on both sides of the ball, though for college he had to choose. The coaches at Clarion University projected him as a defensive end, so that was where he played, demoralizing quarterbacks with an array of speed rushes and spin moves.

headline: Marlins Erupt, With Six Runs in Final Inning, but the Mets Avert a Meltdown
abstract: Matt Harvey pitched seven innings of two-hit ball, and the visiting Mets held on after taking an 8-0 lead into the bottom of the ninth inning.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Mets entered the bottom of the ninth inning Wednesday with an 8-0 lead. Matt Harvey had just put in a sterling performance: six strikeouts, two hits and no runs in seven efficient innings. Their offense, powered by recent additions, had hammered the Marlins’ pitching for 12 hits. The Mets were an inning away from a day off, nine strikes from their second straight series sweep.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights
lead_paragraph: 6:25 P.M. (Flix) FLIRTING WITH DISASTER (1996) Mel Coplin (Ben Stiller), a worker at the American Museum of Natural History and a new father, goes in search of his biological parents with the help of Tina (Téa Leoni), an adoption agency employee, and encounters a succession of oddballs in this comedy from David O. Russell. Patricia Arquette (above right, with, from left, Josh Brolin, Ms. Leoni, Mr. Stiller and Richard Jenkins) plays Mel’s wife, who is just getting her sexual footing back after the birth of their son and doesn’t like Tina’s flirty ways. Mary Tyler Moore plays the mother who raised Mel. She nags a lot and likes to show off her body. “I want you to consider my age and ask yourself how I maintain this,” she declares, lifting her sweater. Writing in The Times, Janet Maslin called the film a “wonderfully mad odyssey of a movie,” adding that “thanks to this filmmaker’s fine comic acumen, the payoff is always there.” In “The Secret Life of Walter Mitty” (2013), at 8 on Cinemax, Mr. Stiller, who also directed this adaptation of the James Thurber short story, stars as Walter, a dutiful drone in the photography department of Life magazine, who finds himself in a caper beyond his wildest imagination when the negative for the publication’s final print edition goes missing. Kristen Wiig plays the crinkly-nosed co-worker on whom Walter has a crush; Adam Scott is the leader of the new tech-jerk bosses who have Walter’s job on the line; and Sean Penn is the mysterious photographer behind Walter’s travels to Iceland, Afghanistan and other stunning far-off places. “Though it is a celebration of modesty, there is also quite a lot of vanity in ‘The Secret Life of Walter Mitty,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. There is also a contradiction: “An ordinary fellow should not have to be quite so special to win our admiration.”

Muscles are abundant, clothing is not: glittery bathing suits, thong-like “performance suits” and the occasional pair of heels.

headline: Free Puerto Rico, America’s Colony
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Taxation', 'Puerto Ricans', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The island is broke because of an oppressive economic system.
lead_paragraph: PUERTO RICO has begun to default on its bond payments, for the first time since it became part of the United States, 117 years ago. If it fails to make interest payments on its $72 billion public debt, pension funds across the United States may be unable to meet their payment obligations. But if it were allowed to file for Chapter 9 bankruptcy protection, as cities and counties have done, every state will want that right.

headline: Making Life Harder for Pimps
abstract: Credit card companies have upended the business model of sex traffickers by eliminating a way they pay for advertising.
lead_paragraph: In the long struggle against sex trafficking, we finally have a breakthrough!

headline: Howard Schultz: America Deserves a Servant Leader
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: Both parties have failed us. Our next president must put others first.
lead_paragraph: FROM the earliest days of Starbucks, I’ve been captivated by the art of leadership. I was mentored over three decades by Warren G. Bennis, the eminent professor and scholar on leadership. I’ve gathered insights from peers, and I’ve drawn inspiration from our 300,000 employees. But nothing I’ve read or heard in the past few years has rivaled the power of the image I viewed on my cellphone a few years ago: Pope Francis, shortly after his election, kneeling and washing the feet of a dozen prisoners in Rome, one of them a young Muslim woman, in a pre-Easter ritual.

headline: Why the Voting Rights Act Is Once Again Under Threat
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Efforts to restrict the ballot are growing, North and South.
lead_paragraph: IN his opinion for the majority in the Supreme Court’s 2013 Shelby County decision, which struck down a major section of the Voting Rights Act, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. wrote that “history did not end in 1965.” But the sad truth is that voter-suppression efforts did not end, either.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Gap on Race and Juries
abstract: Blacks are still being excluded from juries at disproportionate rates, especially when the defendant is black and the crime victim is white.
lead_paragraph: There are so many troubling issues surrounding race and the criminal justice system these days that it is easy to forget a longstanding problem: the exclusion of African-Americans from juries. After all, it was nearly three decades ago that the Supreme Court took what was seen then as a major step toward solving that problem. In Batson v. Kentucky, decided in April 1986, the court ruled that prosecutors could be required to provide a race neutral explanation when their use of peremptory challenges to strike black potential jurors raised an inference of discrimination.

headline: A Long Time Coming, Sunlight on the Executive Pay Gap
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Executive Compensation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Income Inequality', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Stocks and Bonds']

lead_paragraph: After years of delay, the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a sensible final rule on Wednesday  that will force publicly traded companies to reveal how the pay of chief executives compares with that of typical employees.

headline: Greece’s Refugee Crisis and Europe’s Failure
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The European Commission should immediately allocate emergency funds to Greece for refugee services.
lead_paragraph: As if Greece didn’t have enough on its hands after its European creditors forced it to accept a damaging bailout deal last month, it is also trying to cope with more refugees crossing the Mediterranean to its shores than to any other country in Europe. It is unconscionable for Europe to expect Greece to shoulder this burden, yet that is exactly what is happening.

headline: State Department Cautions Americans Considering Travel to Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Travel Warnings', 'Americans Abroad', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a warning issued on Wednesday, the agency said the recent nuclear deal “does not alter the United States’ assessment of the risks of travel to Iran for U.S. citizens.”
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Obama administration hopes that the nuclear deal it negotiated with Iran may one day lead to broader cooperation. But the State Department has some cautionary words for Americans who think the reconciliation is already underway.

headline: Albino Sea Cucumbers, a Delicacy, Could Become a Lot Less Rare
abstract: Chinese researchers say they have found the gene that causes the albinism — thought in traditional medicine to hold special properties — and have been able to breed the white variety in mass quantities.
lead_paragraph: Sea cucumbers, sluglike creatures that hug the seafloor, have long been a prized delicacy at Chinese banquets, the mark of a special occasion. And no variety of sea cucumber is more valued, or costlier, than the exceedingly rare albino. Just a few years ago, five white sea cucumbers sold at auction in the city of Jinan for 160,000 renminbi, or nearly $26,000 at today’s exchange rate.

headline: A Brooklyn Rental for Sisters and Their Families
abstract: Two families, each in need of more space, rent a house together in Ditmas Park.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Lisbeth Kaiser and Alex Rappaport bought a condo with two bedrooms, two baths and almost 1,000 square feet on Fourth Avenue, the busy thoroughfare on the edge of lively Park Slope, Brooklyn. For $640,000, they got a terrace, a washer-dryer, a roof deck, a storage unit and even a parking spot.

headline: June’s Book Club Pick: ‘The Fifth Season,’ by N.K. ­Jemisin
abstract: In this novel, civilization faces destruction and the world itself is an enemy.
lead_paragraph: Fantasy novels often provide a degree of escapism: a good thing, for any reader who has something worth escaping. Too often, though, that escape comes through a fictional world that erases rather than solves the more complex problems of our own, reducing difficulty to the level of personal struggle and heroism, turning all obstacles to monsters we can see and touch and kill with a sword. But N.K. ­Jemisin’s intricate and extraordinary world-­building starts with oppression: Her universes begin by asking who is oppressing whom, what they are gaining, what they fear. Systems of power stalk her protagonists, often embodied as gods and primeval forces, so vast that resistance seems impossible even to contemplate. When escape comes in her novels, it is not a merely personal victory, or the restoration of a sketchy and soft-lit status quo. Her heroes achieve escape velocity, smashing through oppressive systems and leaving them behind like shed skins.

headline: Ursula K. Le Guin: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of the updated “Steering the Craft: A 21st-Century Guide to Sailing the Sea of Story,” avoids “fiction about dysfunctional urban middle-class people written in the present tense.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of the updated “Steering the Craft: A 21st-Century Guide to Sailing the Sea of Story,” avoids “fiction about dysfunctional urban middle-class people written in the present tense.”

headline: Cuban Youth See New U.S. Embassy, but Same Old Drab Life

lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Wedged between a construction site and the shells of once grand colonial homes, a basketball game was underway, the neighborhood pouring into the rubble-strewn street for some evening entertainment.

headline: The Tale of an Anxious Economic Recovery, Told by a Revived Textile Mill
keywords: ['Textiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: After closing during the recession, the 150-year-old Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota is back in business. But its workers are not resting easy.
lead_paragraph: Founded 150 years ago, the Faribault Woolen Mill in Minnesota survived the Great War and the Great Depression, not to mention World War II. But it almost did not make it through the Great Recession.

headline: As Coaches Come and Go, Arsène Wenger of Arsenal Just Keeps Going
abstract: Most Premier League managers have short tenures, but Wenger, 65, is entering his 20th season with the Gunners and continues to position them as contenders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is often said that no job in sports is less secure than that of an N.F.L. player. With no guaranteed contracts, incredible pressure for immediate results, a steady influx of new talent from college football and the constant threat of serious injury, it is hardly surprising that the average player’s career lasts about three years.

headline: Ice Cube Might Have Dinner With the President
keywords: ['Music', 'Movies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: An interview with the rapper about police brutality and the upcoming biopic of N.W.A.
lead_paragraph: In a trailer for ‘‘Straight Outta Compton,’’ the N.W.A. biopic that you co-produced, you say a lot of people don’t realize that your music was a form of nonviolent protest. Is that because the nonviolent part wasn’t very clear? I think it’s very clear. We put our frustrations on a record, and we were creative. We didn’t make a Molotov cocktail; we didn’t loot no buildings or burn ’em down or none of that. All we did was make music.

headline: Suez Canal Upgrade May Not Ease Egypt’s Economic Journey

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock’
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Writing and Writers', 'English Language']
abstract: How the poem by T.S. Eliot entered a 17-year-old’s head and never left.
lead_paragraph: My first hours with the spiky words of T.S. Eliot’s ‘‘The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock’’ are fixed in a precise location: the cluttered space of my teenage bedroom floor. It’s 1982. The light is low. The parquet tiles are coming unglued. Album covers — Talking Heads, David Bowie, the Clash — fan out around me, and an array of paperbacks sprawl among a week’s discarded clothes. I begin to read: ‘‘Let us go then, you and I,/When the evening is spread out against the sky/Like a patient etherized upon a table’’ — and, with a 17-year-old’s sense of imminent upheaval, feel the stirrings of a new language in me, connected to my own language but having passed through fire. I can’t say whether the voice the poem puts in my head as it extends its opening invitation is stiffly formal, smarmy or seductive. ‘‘Spread yourself out on the floor,’’ it seems to whisper, ‘‘and prepare to be turned inside-out.’’

headline: Out of the Woods
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Communes', 'Hippies']
abstract: After decades of semi-secrecy, a commune for L.G.B.T.Q. nonconformists has slowly begun to join the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, David Withers, a zoologist with the Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation, was digging for crayfish in some creek beds on the edge of DeKalb County, in an area that can plausibly be described as nowhere at all, when he spotted an unmarked road. He had never noticed it and decided to see where it led; after a short drive, he found himself amid a strange encampment. Withers stepped out of his truck and looked around. Cheerful, rickety houses sprouted from the ground like unclassified fungi, or something dreamed up by Lewis Carroll, but what appealed to him most was the barn; on the side, in large yellow letters, someone had written ‘‘Welcome Home.’’ Withers walked up to a shack that appeared to be inhabited and — overtaken by curiosity — he knocked. The woman who came out looked surprised. She told him that he was on a commune for gay, lesbian and transgender people and suggested politely that he leave. Later, Withers called his friend Neal Appelbaum, the openly gay director of the arts center in neighboring Cannon County, and told him about what he saw. Appelbaum explained that Withers had stumbled into Ida, a commune for queer vegetarians; the entire region was home to maybe a dozen rural planned communities for L.G.B.T.Q. people, a kind of sexually nonconforming Amish country. He also pointed out that the fading sign on the barn didn’t say ‘‘Welcome Home.’’ The last letter was not an ‘‘e’’ but an ‘‘o.’’

headline: 4 Palestinians Are Killed by Leftover Explosive in Gaza War’s Rubble
abstract: The explosion, which occurred as residents cleared debris from the conflict with Israel last summer, was the deadliest episode since the 50-day conflict, human rights officials said.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Four Palestinians from one extended family were killed and more than 40 others were wounded on Thursday after military ordnance exploded in Gaza as residents cleared the rubble of their homes a year after the war with Israel.

headline: Review: ‘The Gift,’ a Stalker Thriller That Isn’t What It Seems
abstract: Directed by Joel Edgerton, this movie about a prosperous couple and their ominous new acquaintance takes several turns even after abandoning its formulaic premise.
lead_paragraph: Even if “The Gift,” the Australian director Joel Edgerton’s creepy stalker thriller, didn’t make a dramatic U-turn at around the halfway point, it would still rank as a superior specimen. This movie doesn’t foam at the mouth like “Fatal Attraction.” No bunnies are boiled. But fish are poisoned, a family dog goes missing and the soundtrack is tricked out with the sudden jolts dear to the genre. Any revenge is more pitiable than cathartic.

headline: At Katmai National Park in Alaska, Bears Rule
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Camps and Camping', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Summer (Season)', 'Bears']
abstract: Katmai National Park is visited by thousands of bears near its campground every summer, so visitors must follow the rules.
lead_paragraph: Katmai National Park sprawls over four million acres in southern Alaska. So why does its only established campground allow for just 60 people per night — a limit that leads to an online booking fray every January? The answer is also one of the park’s main draws, and its primary claim to national fame: bears. Lots of them — about 2,200 at the National Park Service’s last count, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer. In theory, you can camp elsewhere in Katmai, but the campground has an electric fence and constant activity, making it an unlikely place to find a bear too close to your tent for sleeping comfort.

headline: 1965: Voting Rights Act Passed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act into law in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson today [Aug. 6] signed into law federal voting rights legislation which he said will ‘‘fuse and blend … the Negro story and the American story.’’ He said his administration will move immediately to enforce it in the Deep South. After his address, Mr. Johnson walked to the ornate ‘‘President’s Room’’ in the Senate, where 104 years ago Abraham Lincoln signed a law freeing slaves impressed into war service by the Confederacy. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 7, 1965

abstract: Ballet troupes around the country perform Mr. Neenan’s works. His “Sunset, o639 Hours” is coming to the Joyce Theater as part of its late-summer Ballet Festival.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A few weeks back, the lobby of the Wilma Theater here took on the aspect of a cheap Hawaiian resort. Polynesian music twanged from speakers. Everyone who entered was offered a paper-flower lei. This was not a visit from a hula troupe. This was a gala performance of the Wilma’s resident contemporary ballet company, BalletX. And yet the atmosphere made complete sense, if only in combination with a more incongruous fact: The ballet on the program was about a signal incident in the history of airmail.

headline: Making Every Vote Count
abstract: On the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act, two picture books pull children in to an earlier generation’s struggle.
lead_paragraph: The Voting Rights Act, which marks its 50th anniversary this week, was meant to end one of the quieter ways black people have been held back from equal participation in American life. If half a century later, new laws are still being passed intended to create arcane impediments to their voting, it’s still a landmark of the civil rights movement worth celebrating – and one that’s still vitally important to explain to children. Two new picture books do that through moving narratives of an older generation’s struggles.

abstract: The shooting, which took place Monday on the east side of Detroit, was the first such case that the Wayne County prosecutor could recall involving a person so young.
