headline: 1940: Ministers Ponder Actor’s Trip
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Westminster discusses Noel Coward’s trip to America in wartime.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Parliament today [Aug. 6] buckled down to discussing Noel Coward and Miss Gracie Fields and how they got away to America. Coward, actor and all-round entertainer, was the subject of a question put by a Conservative. On what mission, he asked, was Mr. Coward engaged by his majesty’s government? Harold Nicolson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Information, replied that Coward had gone with the approval of Prime Minister Winston Churchill. Another member said feeling was rising that ‘‘if a man has a certain amount of publicity value and money he can get out of this country when the country is going through a period of great stress and anxiety?’’ — New York Herald Tribune, August 7, 1940

Instead, Casini and her partner, Keiko Seya, release “editions” — of 12 to 15 items — every six months. “We wanted to do something that would be timeless, using the best materials — pieces that you can keep for a long time,” Casini says.

keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The company is investing not only money but also some of its corporate reputation on the belief that it can be a technological leader in improving health care.
lead_paragraph: IBM is adding medical images to the health data its Watson artificial-intelligence can mine to help doctors make diagnoses.

headline: Natalia Molchanova Was Teaching Divers When She Vanished, Son Says
abstract: An underwater search for Ms. Molchanova, who is presumed dead, was halted on Wednesday, and her son on Thursday provided new details about the incident.
lead_paragraph: The champion free diver Natalia Molchanova was giving private instruction to at least two inexperienced divers Sunday when she failed to surface from a dive, her son said Thursday.

headline: The Weitz Brothers Help Each Other Through Hollywood Hits and Misses
abstract: The siblings and prolific filmmakers, who made their names with “American Pie,” are still pals and collaborators.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The filmmaking brothers Paul and Chris Weitz, who have had their movie hits and misses since breaking through with the blockbuster 1999 teen sex comedy “American Pie,” had childhoods that resemble something out of a movie made by their friend Wes Anderson.

headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General, Kathleen Kane, Charged in Leak Case
abstract: In announcing the charges, the Montgomery County district attorney said Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane was accused of leaking information from a 2009 investigation.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor filed criminal charges on Thursday against Pennsylvania’s attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, in a convoluted tale of political maneuvering and retribution that threatens the career of an official who was seen until recently as one of her state’s rising stars.

headline: What’s That Bubble? A Dying Star’s Glowing Remains
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: A new picture of the Southern Owl Nebula was captured by the Very Large Telescope in Chile.
lead_paragraph: A new picture of the Southern Owl Nebula was captured by the Very Large Telescope in Chile.

headline: Viacom’s Weak Results Pile On More Bad News for TV Industry
abstract: Viacom shares were down as much as 22 percent as a startling slump in major media stocks continued on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: It is no more than a coincidence that Viacom announced weak earnings and suffered a sharp plunge in its stock on the same day that one of its biggest stars, Jon Stewart, exited the stage.

headline: Texas Watchdog Group Calls Another Political Titan to Account
abstract: Texans for Public Justice, criticized as a liberal attack machine, filed the complaints that led to the indictments of Tom DeLay, Rick Perry and Ken Paxton, the state attorney general.
lead_paragraph: McKINNEY, Tex. — When Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas was booked at the county jail here Monday on felony fraud charges, he joined some pretty high-powered company, including Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, and former Gov. Rick Perry, as powerful Texas officials indicted while in office over the last decade.

headline: Review: In ‘The Diary of a Teenage Girl,’ a Hormone Bomb Waiting to Explode
abstract: Bel Powley stars as a 15-year-old who candidly chronicles the passion, anxieties and adventures of adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Minnie Goetze, the 15-year-old heroine of “The Diary of a Teenage Girl,” is a would-be cartoonist who, despite her first name, is closer in lusty spirit and scratchy pen to Robert Crumb than to Walt Disney. When, partway through this gutsy, exhilarating movie, she draws her first cartoon, it’s of a bodacious female colossus striding across San Francisco. As this inky giant keeps on trucking, she evokes the 50-foot-woman of cult film fame, if one that has received a Crumb makeover, with thighs as mighty as giant sequoias and a bottom that rolls like a ship in a storm.

headline: What We Learned From German Prisons
abstract: Unlike in America, they reflect their country’s commitment to human dignity.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this summer, we led a delegation of people concerned about the United States criminal justice system to visit some prisons in Germany and observe their conditions. What we saw was astonishing.

headline: Russia Destroys Piles of Banned Western Food
abstract: Following an order by President Vladimir V. Putin, officials threw huge piles of pork, tomatoes, peaches and cheese into landfills and incinerators.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ramping up enforcement of a ban on European food imports, the Russian authorities on Thursday destroyed hundreds of tons of foodstuffs they said violated the proscription, instituted a year ago in retaliation for Western sanctions over Ukraine.

headline: Form for Drug Dealers to Snitch on Competitors Results in an Arrest
abstract: When a sheriff posted a flier on Facebook asking local drug dealers to snitch, there was skepticism. But then they caught a drug dealer.
lead_paragraph: When the sheriff in Franklin County, Ky., posted a flier on Facebook asking local drug dealers to snitch on their competition, the response was more than a little incredulous.

headline: Salesforce Ventures and Microsoft Join Informatica Buyout
abstract: The two companies, partners of the enterprise software maker, will take ownership stakes in the biggest leveraged buyout of the year.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Informatica closes its $5.3 billion sale to private equity on Thursday, the enterprise software maker will count two of its big technology partners as new investors as well.

headline: Hiplife, a Sound Imported From Ghana, Arrives on a New York Stage
abstract: A concert on Saturday featuring hiplife — a blend of hip-hop and upbeat indigenous soul music called highlife — is a milestone for a transnational experiment that began in Ghana two decades ago.
lead_paragraph: When Evans Appiah moved to the Bronx from Ghana at age 8, he was teased for his accent. As a way of fitting in, he learned to rap. By the time he got to Middle School 391 on Webster Avenue, his friends were calling him “Lighter” because he rapped so fast and furious in English that it sounded as if he were spitting fire.

headline: A Millennial’s Guide to Kissing
abstract: After a stranger on an international flight delivers the perfect kiss, a college student weighs the possibilities of romance.

headline: As China Reduces Local Spending, Cities Woo Private Investors
abstract: Hundreds of cities across China are turning to deep-pocketed private investors to help foot the bill for public infrastructure and services.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The wide new boulevards that cut across parts of Weifang in eastern China are largely free of traffic, a quiet reminder of the coastal city’s big ambitions.

headline: Charges Announced Against Kathleen Kane
abstract: Risa Vetri Ferman, the district attorney for Montgomery county, Pa., said on Thursday that the state’s attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, is being charged with leaking information to the media.
lead_paragraph: Risa Vetri Ferman, the district attorney for Montgomery county, Pa., said on Thursday that the state’s attorney general, Kathleen G. Kane, is being charged with leaking information to the media.

headline: Welcome, Small Pigs
abstract: The Prospect Park Zoo has added three adorable faces to its menagerie.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrating once again that the only things more appealing than charismatic megafauna are miniature charismatic megafauna, the Prospect Park Zoo has added three adorable faces to its menagerie.

headline: Facebook Joins the Live-Streaming Crowd With a Service for Celebrities
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Facebook has joined the live-stream scene with a video service that airs clips as they’re happening — but it’s only for famous people.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has joined the live-stream-video scene — but so far, it’s only for famous people.

headline: What Dad Should Do About the Brat Pack
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Text Messaging', 'Camps and Camping', 'Parties (Social)']
abstract: Plus: how to say yes after saying no; when the boss infringes on your down time; and standing up to a difficult cousin.
lead_paragraph: I am a 65-year-old man, vigorous and still working. I divorced 20 years ago when I came out as a gay man. After years of dating, I find myself in love with a man in his early 20s who loves me back. We have been dating for a couple of years. I do not support him financially; he is not in my will. But my three adult children, all married, find the age difference impossible to accept. I was their primary caretaker, and we have always been close. I don’t want a rift. How to proceed?

headline: California Burning: Photographer’s Notebook
abstract: Jim Wilson describes his experience photographing California’s latest wildfire.
lead_paragraph: The Rocky fire is the largest of several fires currently burning in California. It has consumed 68,000 acres, or an area of a little more than 106 square miles, forcing thousands of residents from their homes. It has burned 91 structures including 39 homes in a very rural area near Clearlake that encompasses parts of Lake, Yolo and Colusa Counties. Since the fire began last Wednesday, about 3,500 firefighters have battled it. As of 7 a.m. on Aug. 6, it was 40 percent contained and the cause of the blaze was unknown.

headline: For Vaccines Needed in an Epidemic, Timing Is Everything
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Ebola Virus', 'MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Waiting to develop a vaccine until an epidemic is raging means waiting too long for it to be proved safe and effective, say scientists who are proposing a global vaccine fund.
lead_paragraph: Last year, scientists launched a trial of an experimental vaccine against Ebola in Guinea. On Friday, they reported great news: The vaccine works well, providing remarkable protection just 10 days after injection.

headline: Fox Failed Statistics in Explaining Its G.O.P. Debate Decision
abstract: Did Rick Perry miss making the main Republican debate field because he was unpopular or because he was unlucky?
lead_paragraph: Will Rick Perry miss the main Republican debate Thursday night because he’s unpopular or because he’s unlucky? This turns out to be a far more difficult question that you might realize, and it’s one that apparently eludes the Fox News decision desk.

headline: Jemera Rone, Investigator Who Bared Human Rights Abuses, Dies at 71
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Ms. Rone left a legal career on Wall Street to focus on exposing and seeking justice for human rights violations in El Salvador and Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Jemera Rone, who abandoned a legal career on Wall Street in her 40s to focus instead on exposing and redressing human rights violations in El Salvador and Sudan, died on July 29 in Washington. She was 71.

headline: The Hosts Are Wild, So Keep Your Distance
keywords: ['Bears', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: About 2,200 bears reside at Katmai National Park in Alaska, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer.
lead_paragraph: About 2,200 bears reside at Katmai National Park in Alaska, with 60 or so regulars that hang around Brooks Camp every summer.

headline: Ledecky Gains Relay Gold; Lochte Wins 200 I.M.
abstract: Ryan Lochte, 31, become the first man to win the world championship in 200-meter individual medley four consecutive times, and Katie Ledecky led the U.S. to victory in the 4x200 freestyle relay.
lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — For four days at the world championships, Katie Ledecky hauled the weight of the United States’ sterling swimming reputation by herself. While New Zealand, Chile, Jamaica and Iceland put athletes in individual finals, the American team, which had won 182 gold medals in the previous 15 world championship meets, saw only Ledecky rise to the very top.

headline: The Speech That Defined the Fight for Voting Rights in Congress
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Law and Legislation', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: How President Lyndon B. Johnson saw one of the signature accomplishments of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago today, on Aug. 6, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, which effectively ended centuries of black disenfranchisement by banning barriers to minority voting like the poll tax and the poll test, as I detailed in the magazine’s Aug. 2 cover story. At the signing ceremony, Johnson called the Voting Rights Act “a triumph for freedom as huge as any victory that has ever been won on the battlefield.”

headline: Follow Debate Day Coverage on The Times’s Live Blog
abstract: Times reporters are posting on the Republican debates and the run up to the events on the live blog.
lead_paragraph: Times reporters are posting on the Republican debates and the runup to the events on the live blog.

headline: Does America Still Believe in Diplomacy?
abstract: As President Obama pushes for the Iran nuclear deal, he is making a bigger point that the country can’t have a foreign policy based just on military power.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has never seemed so sure-footed on foreign policy as now, when he is battling against determined opponents to persuade the American public and Congress on the merits of the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549 — 553
abstract: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549 — 553
lead_paragraph: Lively Morgue Tumblr 549 — 553

headline: King Coal, Long Besieged, Is Deposed by the Market
keywords: ['Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Bankruptcies', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: In a few short years, market forces have accomplished what environmentalists struggled to do for decades: curtail America’s coal consumption.
lead_paragraph: In April 2005, President George W. Bush hailed “clean coal” as a key to “greater energy independence,” pledging $2 billion in research funds that promised a new golden age for America’s most abundant energy resource.

headline: Rebuilding Around Tina Charles Puts Liberty in Playoff Hunt
abstract: The W.N.B.A.’s Liberty are in first place with a 13-6 record after finishing last season 15-19 and missing the playoffs. So what has changed?
lead_paragraph: A Liberty season that began with an off-court to-do over the hiring of Isiah Thomas as team president has turned into a great one on the basketball court. The Liberty sit on top of the W.N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference at 13-6. If the team maintains that .684 winning percentage over its final 15 games, it will finish with the best record in franchise history.

headline: Review: ‘Fantastic Four,’ the Reboot (Wanted or Not)
abstract: Directed by Josh Trank, this reframing of the Marvel Comics superhero group features Miles Teller, Kate Mara, Michael B. Jordan and Jamie Bell.
lead_paragraph: The opening scenes of “Fantastic Four” — 20th Century Fox’s reboot of its Marvel superhero franchise — take place in 2007, which happens to be the year that the second movie in the prerebooted franchise (“Rise of the Silver Surfer”) was released. Ben Grimm and Reed Richards (played as children by Evan Hannemann and Owen Judge, later by Jamie Bell and Miles Teller) don’t mention that fact, because if they did the cinematic universe would collapse on itself and all light would be extinguished from the cosmos. Also, the thoughtful people at Fox probably don’t want to remind anyone of those earlier movies.

headline: Soul-Searching in Israel After Bias Attacks on Gays and Arabs
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: After two attacks that underscored Israel’s conflict with the Palestinians and its internal struggle, there has been outrage, blame and backlash.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — On one edge of the Zion Square gathering, an Orthodox yeshiva student was in heated debate with a secular couple over the hierarchy of sin. On the other, young men wearing skullcaps rocked back and forth, reciting the evening prayer. In between, people sat cross-legged on the cobblestones amid an array of memorial candles and banners decrying violence, promoting love, demanding change.

headline: In South Sinai With One-third of Three as Four
abstract: The designer Adi Gil recently spent a week in the desert.
lead_paragraph: The Israel-born designer Adi Gil remembers family trips to South Sinai in the ’70s, before Egypt secured the area. Recently, she’s started spending time there again — though the present-day peninsula bears little resemblance to the crowded South Sinai from her childhood photo albums. Still, it remains “beautiful and surreal,” says Gil, one-third of the brand Three as Four. “It all depends on how you look at it — and who is looking at it. When it comes to the Middle East, sometimes I feel that the media likes to magnify the negative. We know there are issues in North Sinai. But next door there is beauty, and no one is talking about that.”

headline: Video Is Released From 2013 North Carolina Police Shooting of Jonathan Ferrell
abstract: The video was shown in the trial of the Charlotte officer who fatally shot a black motorist who had been seeking help in 2013 after an accident.
lead_paragraph: A police dashboard camera video from the shooting death of a black man in North Carolina in 2013 has been made public as part of the trial of the police officer accused of killing him.

headline: 18-Year-Old Sentenced to Five Years for Robbing Man, 84, She Met on Dating Site
abstract: Shaina Foster had pleaded guilty to one count of robbery, admitting that she and her twin sister tied up the man and took his cash and credit cards.
lead_paragraph: A teenager who with her twin sister robbed an octogenarian they met on an Internet dating site was sentenced on Thursday to five years in prison.

headline: In North Dakota, Boom, Bust and Oil
abstract: North Dakota’s northwest region, which has seen Native Americans, Lewis and Clark and settlers come and go, is home to the state’s latest oil boom.
lead_paragraph: On U.S. 2 in North Dakota, just west of the turnoff for Tioga, you will spot two little brown highway signs pointing left:

headline: Chenin Blanc Makes an Audacious U.S. Return
abstract: A former staple of Napa Valley, the wine is showing up again in California and New York.
lead_paragraph: After 20 years in which the repertoire of American winemakers seemed to have dwindled to a half-dozen grapes, endlessly repeated, the last decade has been one of intrepid exploration. Myriad grapes once deemed unworthy or too esoteric have been rediscovered and revived by winemakers seeking to make fresh, lively wines that are simply delicious to drink nightly, rather than ponderous wines aiming for trophies.

headline: Boom, Bust and Oil
abstract: On the byways of northwest North Dakota, a richly historic past meets the oil-fueled present.
lead_paragraph: On the byways of northwest North Dakota, a richly historic past meets the oil-fueled present.

headline: Review: ‘We Believe the Children,’ on Child Abuse Hysteria in the 1980s
abstract: Richard Beck examines the social and political climate that set the stage for the sensational child abuse cases and lurid investigations that gripped the United States in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: From 1987 to 1990, in the longest criminal trial in American history, prosecutors tried to prove that Virginia McMartin, who owned a preschool in Manhattan Beach, Calif., and other school employees, including her daughter and grandson, had raped or abused 13 children, taken pornographic pictures of them and forced them to watch the mutilation of animals.

headline: Macedonia Arrests 9 Suspected of Having Ties to ISIS
abstract: Nine people have been arrested and 27 others are being sought in a crackdown on citizens who have gone to fight in the Middle East or have recruited fighters.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Macedonian officials announced Thursday that nine people had been arrested and that 27 more were being sought in a crackdown on citizens who traveled to the Middle East to fight alongside the Islamic State group or who helped recruit fighters for it.

headline: In Chicago, Lincoln, Copernicus and Shakespeare Have Something to Say to You
abstract: A project in Chicago gives voices to public statues.
lead_paragraph: If a public sculpture in a large American city could talk, what would it say, besides complaining about pigeons and benign neglect? In Chicago, beginning Thursday, residents are finding out with the help of prominent writers and performers, as part of a program started by the British arts organization Sing London, and supported in Chicago by the Richard H. Driehaus Foundation.

headline: Humpty Dumpty Deal-Making
abstract: Should Mondelez be put back together again with Kraft? Or should spinoff VMware absorb its parent EMC? It’s fantasy season for all the Street’s men.
lead_paragraph: Some of the finest minds in finance seem to have missed the lesson of the nursery rhyme “Humpty Dumpty”: All the king’s horses and all the king’s men couldn’t put that character together again.

headline: Pakistan Army Helicopter Crashes, Killing 12
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The helicopter, carrying a medical team and supplies, had taken off from Rawalpindi and was headed to a flood-hit northern region.
lead_paragraph: PAKISTAN — At least 12 people aboard a Pakistani Army helicopter were killed Thursday in northwestern Pakistan, a military spokesman said. They included a team of army doctors, paramedics, two pilots and crew. Officials said they were trying to determine the cause of the crash and suspected weather conditions to be responsible. The helicopter, carrying medical supplies, took off from Rawalpindi and was headed toward Gilgit, which has been affected recently by floods.

headline: ‘Crucible’ Revival, With Whishaw and Okonedo, Sets Broadway Opening
abstract: Ivo van Hove will direct the production, which is scheduled to begin performances on February 29.
lead_paragraph: As the 100th anniversary of Arthur Miller’s birth approaches, Broadway is doubling down on two of his most produced plays this season.

headline: In Papua, Indonesia, a Visit to the Welcoming Dani People
abstract: A trek that ends up in a visit to the Dani people proves to be an enlightening experience as the villagers share their customs.
lead_paragraph: The thatched-roof homes of Wesagalep lay at cloud level, high above the Baliem Valley in Papua, the Indonesian side of the island of New Guinea. They are built on about six terraced levels of the mountain, with startling views of the valley and down to the rushing river below.

headline: With Deadline Deals, Blue Jays Load Up on Optimism
abstract: In deals for shortstop Troy Tulowitzki, pitcher David Price and others, the Jays acquired, almost overnight, the parts they thought they needed to end a 21-year playoff drought.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Paul Molitor rounded the bases just ahead of Joe Carter on that electrifying night of Oct. 23, 1993. He felt the roar that pulsated inside the Skydome when he scored the winning run on Carter’s homer, giving the Toronto Blue Jays their second consecutive World Series title.

headline: Creator and Fans Hit It Lucky With ‘Hamilton’
abstract: The hip-hop musical about the nation’s founding fathers is scheduled to open on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Three hours before the 5 p.m. Broadway opening night of his hip-hop musical “Hamilton,” Lin-Manuel Miranda paid emotional tribute to the biography, and the life, that inspired his work.

headline: A Home of One’s Own in Notting Hill
abstract: The West London district has a new set of townhouses turned hotel suites.
lead_paragraph: The West London district of Notting Hill famously attracts visitors to its pastel-colored rows of houses, sprawling Portobello Road Antiques Market and Europe’s biggest street festival — and yet has always, until now, lacked sumptuous places to stay. On the south side of the secluded Pembridge Gardens, just seconds from Notting Hill Gate station (and a mere 15-minute hop to the hubbub of Soho), a row of five stucco Victorian mansions have recently been transformed into what is now the Laslett hotel.

headline: New York Ordering Tests of Water-Cooling Towers Amid Legionnaires’ Outbreak
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York said building owners had two weeks to test and disinfect the towers, as the death toll from the disease rose to 10.
lead_paragraph: New York City buildings with water-cooling towers must assess and disinfect the units within the next two weeks under an order issued on Thursday by health officials in response to the outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx.

headline: Syrian Official’s Visit to Oman May Signal a Diplomatic Opening
abstract: In his first trip to Oman since the Syrian conflict began, the minister drew speculation that efforts to find ways to end the war have intensified.
lead_paragraph: Syria’s government sent a high-level delegation on Thursday to Oman, the Persian Gulf state that historically has helped broker negotiations in regional conflicts.

headline: Wait, He Plays for Them Now?
abstract: A look at the players who joined, left or switched Premier League teams over the summer.
lead_paragraph: While Arsène Wenger never seems to go anywhere — he will begin his 20th season at Arsenal on Sunday — a host of prominent players joined, left or switched Premier League teams over the summer. Among the more notable moves you will notice starting this weekend:

headline: Top Hillary Clinton Donor Comes Out Against Iran Deal
abstract: A top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed his opposition to the Obama administration’s agreement with Iran to curtail its nuclear program, calling it a “very bad deal.”
lead_paragraph: A top donor to Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed his opposition Thursday to the Obama administration’s agreement with Iran to curtail its nuclear program, calling it a “very bad deal.”

headline: For Mets Fans, First Is a Surprise. For Yankees Fans, It’s About Time.
abstract: Fan reaction to the unexpected success of the Yankees and the Mets this season would make for a fascinating study in expectations.
lead_paragraph: After three emotion-filled days with the Mets at Citi Field last weekend, I was looking forward to going to the Bronx this week and watching the first-place Yankees during a six-game homestand against Boston and Toronto.

headline: Living With Cancer: Alone and Ghosted
abstract: When cancer patients need help, they are often surprised to find that long-trusted friends have disappeared.
lead_paragraph: When my husband, incapacitated by knee surgery, was placed in a rehabilitation facility, I lost my caregiver. Don can no longer drive me to the cancer center or undertake the chores he used to do for both of us, and he must consider his own overriding physical problems, not mine. With the good luck of my relatively stable physical condition, I struggle to meet our basic needs. However, an unluckier member of my support group found herself in dire circumstances after her partner traveled overseas on a business trip.

headline: 1945 | Witnessing the A-Bomb, but Forbidden to File
abstract: David W. Dunlap tells the story of The Times’s coverage of the development and dropping of the atomic bomb, 70 years ago.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘The Gift’ (With Movie Trailer): Joel Edgerton Narrates a Scene
abstract: The director and actor discusses a sequence from his drama featuring Rebecca Hall and Jason Bateman.
lead_paragraph: For the “The Gift,” the actor Joel Edgerton goes behind the camera to direct a twist on the thriller genre, while also using some of its conventions. Jason Bateman and Rebecca Hall play Simon and Robin, a couple who have moved to a new town and are greeted and befriended by Gordo (Mr. Edgerton), an old classmate of Simon’s. The relationship the couple maintains with Gordo is uncomfortable at best.

abstract: An old canal gets a new channel.
lead_paragraph: An old canal gets a new channel.

headline: The Coolest Look This Season: All That Came Before
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Hats and Caps', 'Coats and Jackets']
abstract: From ’70s floral-print suits to ’40s-era net hats, from oversize shearlings to logo sweatshirts, the current, decade-spanning style of today alludes to the past.

headline: Reducing Skyscraper Sway
abstract: Mass dampers are added to slender skyscrapers to reduce their sway in high winds.
lead_paragraph: Mass dampers are added to slender skyscrapers to reduce their sway in high winds.

headline: An N.W.A. Biopic Heads Straight Into Mainstream
abstract: Like all too many other hip-hop films, “Straight Outta Compton” focuses on N.W.A’.s struggle to make it, not the success and the reckoning it brings.
lead_paragraph: N.W.A., the group that brought gangster rap to the mainstream, angering conservatives and the F.B.I. along the way, burned hot and fast. The core group as it’s remembered today — Dr. Dre, Ice Cube, Eazy-E, MC Ren, DJ Yella — was together for only about two years, and in total the group lasted for maybe five, from the late 1980s to early ’90s.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Aug. 7
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a projection on the Empire State Building, closing parishes and a wet walk with dry cleaning.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a projection on the Empire State Building, closing parishes and a wet walk with dry cleaning.

lead_paragraph: Elegant classics, a capsule collection from Nick Wooster, a minimalist bathing suit and more.

headline: Revisiting Ferguson and the Death of Michael Brown
abstract: Whitney Curtis returned to Ferguson, Mo., to see what has changed, and hasn’t, since police shot the teenager, setting off vigils and volatility.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Curtis returned to Ferguson, Mo., to see what has changed, and hasn’t, since police shot the teenager, setting off vigils and volatility.

headline: An Ecuadorean Horseman at Bemelmans Bar
abstract: Luis Serrano followed an unlikely path to his job as the longest-tenured bartender at a New York institution.
lead_paragraph: Luis Serrano grew up in Ecuador with a love for horses and the idea that he would become a veterinarian. He ended up wearing the crisp red jacket at Bemelmans Bar, the Carlyle hotel’s elegant drinking spot on the Upper East Side, where he is currently the longest-tenured bartender, having served drinks there for 22 years.

headline: Review: ‘Holden’ Explores the Distance That Killing Requires
abstract: Written and directed by Anisa George, this compelling, disturbing play at the New Ohio Theater examines the mindsets that can lead to violence.
lead_paragraph: “Holden,” a new play written and directed by Anisa George, occupies a claustrophobic realm: a one-room cabin into which four intense men are crammed, bounded by slowly growing walls of chopped firewood.

headline: Review: In ‘Sneaky Pete’ and ‘Casanova,’ a Fast Talker and a Smooth Talker
abstract: Two Amazon pilots going up on Friday both feature lead characters engaging in subterfuge.
lead_paragraph: Judging “Sneaky Pete,” which stars Giovanni Ribisi as a con man and recent ex-con hiding out in upstate New York, has a lot to do with context. As an Amazon pilot — it’s one of two, along with “Casanova,” going up on Friday — it looks kind of ordinary, surprisingly like a broadcast network drama. Semi-episodic, slightly procedural, light dusting of dark humor.

headline: Isabella Rossellini on Her Mother Ingrid Bergman’s Enduring Style
abstract: The actress reflects on what she learned from “Mama,” including the courage not to wear heels.
lead_paragraph: “This is how I look, take it or leave it,” said the Swedish film star Ingrid Bergman, perhaps the first natural actress of the Golden Era. (When the film producer David Selznick suggested a Hollywood makeover — change her name, pluck her eyebrows and fix her teeth — right before her debut in 1939, she refused.) This year, Bergman’s legacy will be honored in a centennial celebration opening at the Museum of Modern Art on her bittersweet birthday, Aug. 29, which is also the day she died at age 67 in 1982. The 14-film retrospective spans Bergman’s 50-year career, including her starring roles in “Casablanca” and Hitchcock’s “Notorious.”

headline: Why ‘Hamilton’ Has Heat
abstract: What’s the story behind a show that’s become a Broadway must-see with no marquee names, no special effects and almost no white actors? Erik Piepenburg explains, in six snapshots, why “Hamilton” has become such a big deal.
lead_paragraph: What’s the story behind a show that’s become a Broadway must-see with no marquee names, no special effects and almost no white actors? Erik Piepenburg explains, in six snapshots, why “Hamilton” has become such a big deal.

headline: Short Game
abstract: Whether they’re Boy Scout cargo-style or fashion-designer formal, nothing exposes a man to more judgment and ridicule than wearing shorts.
lead_paragraph: Whether they’re Boy Scout cargo-style or fashion-designer formal, nothing exposes a man to more judgment and ridicule than wearing shorts.

headline: Why Putting a Number to C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: A new rule requiring a company to give the ratio of the top executive’s pay to worker pay will produce an easily grasped and perhaps shocking number.
lead_paragraph: It is a confounding truth about outsize executive pay — all past attempts to rein it in have failed.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 9 to 15, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

abstract: James Draplin­‘s favorite things.
lead_paragraph: James Draplin­‘s favorite things.

headline: ‘By the Sea’ Trailer Is Released, Featuring Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie Pitt
abstract: A look at the teaser trailer for “By the Sea,” written and directed by Angelina Jolie Pitt
lead_paragraph: In the new Angelina Jolie Pitt film, there seems to be a lot less combat, but still plenty of suffering. After directing two tense movies set in wartime, Ms. Pitt has now written and directed the drama “By the Sea,” for which the teaser trailer was released today. She stars in it with her husband, Brad Pitt — their first on-screen pairing since “Mr. and Mrs. Smith” in 2007.

headline: The Jeter of Yankee Stadium Cameramen
abstract: To many fans at Yankee Stadium, Eric Capstick, 53, is as welcome a sight as a star player. His job is to shoot them in the stands for real-time display on the big screens.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Eric Capstick appeared in an upper deck of Yankee Stadium, camera on his shoulder, the fans began clamoring as if Derek Jeter had suddenly returned from retirement.

headline: A Design Guru’s Work Lair
abstract: A cluttered work space is a source of inspiration for James Draplin­, a graphic designer.
lead_paragraph: Aaron James Draplin

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Studies of Nepal Quake Raise Concern About Skyscrapers
abstract: Two scientific papers suggest that an earthquake similar to the one that struck Nepal in April, with relatively slow oscillations, could be especially dangerous to cities with taller buildings.
lead_paragraph: In April, as email alerts ricocheted with the news that a large earthquake had shaken Nepal near its capital, Kathmandu, experts somberly expected a toll comparable to the roughly 85,000 who died in 2005 when a smaller earthquake struck a more sparsely populated area in the Kashmir region.

headline: Review: ‘Ricki and the Flash’ Puts Meryl Streep Behind a Telecaster
abstract: Diablo Cody wrote and Jonathan Demme directed this film about a rocker who returns to mend a crisis in the family she abandoned.
lead_paragraph: “Ricki and the Flash,” a gentle-hearted baby boomer guilt-trip family drama directed by Jonathan Demme and written by Diablo Cody, is bookended by two musical performances from the rock ’n’ roll bar band that gives the movie its name. It would be a spoiler to say too much about the number that ends the movie, a Bruce Springsteen cover, but the opener, sung to a sparse, appreciative audience at a scruffy club in Tarzana, Calif., is a competent version of an old hit by Tom Petty. (If that name doesn’t ring a bell, go ask your dad.) Ricki, the lead singer, sporting a blue Telecaster, heavy eyeliner and half of Bo Derek’s haircut from “10” (ask your dad about that too), belts out the lyrics with perfect credibility, landing somewhere between Chrissie Hynde and Bonnie Raitt on the spectrum of available reference points.

headline: A Steve Jobs Opera Is Up Next for the Santa Fe Company
abstract: The Santa Fe Opera said its next commissioned work would be “The (R)evolution of Steve Jobs,” which will receive its first workshop in September in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Just don’t call it iOpera. The Santa Fe Opera has announced that its next commissioned work will be “The (R)evolution of Steve Jobs,” with music by Mason Bates, known for combining electronic sounds and traditional instruments, and a libretto by Mark Campbell.

headline: Review: ‘Cold Mountain,’ at Santa Fe Opera, Recounts a Separated Lover’s Arduous Journey
abstract: A modern “Odyssey,” this opera, based on Charles Frazier’s 1997 novel, is about a wounded Civil War soldier who escapes a Confederate hospital and walks nearly 300 miles home.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — It’s quite a ways from here to western North Carolina, where Charles Frazier set his 1997 novel, “Cold Mountain.” And it’s quite a different landscape out there, too.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Ricki and the Flash’
abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Ricki and the Flash.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Ricki and the Flash.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
abstract: France and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Brooks Brothers Discontinuing Black Fleece Collection
abstract: The line, which is designed by Thom Browne and is less traditional than the company’s other looks, will be dropped after the fall 2015 season.
lead_paragraph: Devotees of Black Fleece, Thom Browne’s collection for Brooks Brothers, should hurry to stores to stock up. Claudio Del Vecchio, the Brooks Brothers chief executive, confirmed in a phone interview on Thursday that the Black Fleece line will be discontinued following the fall 2015 season, though he did not rule out the option of reviving it, potentially without Mr. Browne, in the future.

headline: August 6, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from France, United States, Macedonia and El Salvador.
lead_paragraph: Photos from France, United States, Macedonia and El Salvador.

headline: This Week’s Movies | August 7, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Ricki and the Flash,” “Diary of a Teenage Girl” and “Fantastic Four.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Ricki and the Flash,” “Diary of a Teenage Girl” and “Fantastic Four.”

headline: Review: ‘Drawing Waves’ and ‘Borne Frieze,’ a Robin Rhode Twofer
abstract: This South African artist shows his signature participatory artwork in two shows, one at the Drawing Center, in SoHo, and one at Lehmann Maupin, in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: For the South African artist Robin Rhode, drawing is never enough. He draws on gallery walls, then throws his body against the images he’s made, or drags his hands through the fresh chalk or charcoal. He draws in public places, in choreographed acts or in improvised, highly physical exertions. Drawing is not a stand-alone artistic medium; it forms part of a constellation of techniques, from performance to photography and video, which in turn informs a larger cluster of concerns, from his own childhood to the politics of urban space.

headline: A Facebook for Watch Geeks
abstract: An entrepreneur turns to his techie roots to start a site for collectors of analog watches.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Rose, the Digg founder and Silicon Valley wunderkind, remembers the pushback he got in young-tech circles when he started wearing his late father’s Rolex a few years ago.

headline: At Givenchy in Paris, Toughness and Light
abstract: The Givenchy men’s store in Paris shows off its mix of haute history and sharp detailing.
lead_paragraph: The Givenchy men’s store in Paris shows off its mix of haute history and sharp detailing.

headline: 25 Years After Gardner Museum Heist, Video Raises Questions
abstract: Security footage from the night before the largest art heist in American history draws fresh attention to a rookie security guard.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In 1990, Richard Abath was a 23-year-old self-described hippie and guitarist for a rock band named Ukiah who, while moonlighting as a security guard, allowed two thieves posing as police officers to enter the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here.

headline: ‘How Cats Took Over the Internet’ at the Museum of the Moving Image
abstract: The exhibition, a cultural deconstruction of cats’ enduring popularity, takes a high-minded look at anthropomorphism and a low-brow wallow through cheesy trends and bad puns.
lead_paragraph: WHILE it’s not true that 15 percent of all Internet traffic is cat-related, as the Friskies cat food company asserted in 2013, it does make a convincing urban legend.

headline: Review: Paintings by George Stubbs Travel to the Met
abstract: Stubbs was dismissed as a minor painter of horses for 200 years. Now he’s recognized as one of the great artists of the 18th century.
lead_paragraph: New York should be grateful that the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is closed for renovations. As a result, eight canvases by the inimitable English painter George Stubbs, one of the great artists of the 18th century, have been lent to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Works by Stubbs are scarce in this town: The Met has one painting, and there’s a drawing at the Frick Collection. This makes “Paintings by George Stubbs From the Yale Center for British Art” a rare and thrilling treat.

headline: Elaine de Kooning and Andreas Gursky in Close-Up in the Hamptons
abstract: Visual art still has a lively presence in the area, as viewers can discover at two of the region’s pre-eminent destinations.
lead_paragraph: Decades before the East End in Long Island became a crowded mecca for summertime vacationers, the Hamptons and their neighboring villages were quiet, rural getaways for artists, from the American Impressionists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries to the Pop artists of the ’60s. Visual art still has a lively presence in the area, as viewers can discover at two of the region’s pre-eminent destinations.

headline: Heavy on Top
abstract: To keep skinny skyscrapers from swaying when high winds blow, giant counterweights are placed at the top. To get an idea of how much heft is required, consider the following equivalents.
lead_paragraph: To keep skinny skyscrapers from swaying when high winds blow, giant counterweights are placed at the top. To get an idea of how much heft is required, consider the following equivalents.

headline: Review: ‘Call Me Lucky,’ About the Comedian-Activist Barry Crimmins
abstract: Bobcat Goldthwait’s documentary about his mentor chronicles the work he has done not only as a comic but also to rid the Internet of child pornography.
lead_paragraph: “Call Me Lucky,” Bobcat Goldthwait’s documentary portrait of his professional mentor, the political comedian Barry Crimmins, is an earnest homage that also honors Mr. Crimmins’s crusade to drive child pornography off the Internet.

headline: Review: Mostly Mozart, Highlighted by Sol Gabetta’s Haunting Vocalise
abstract: Ms. Gabetta, in her Mostly Mozart debut, played in both the festival orchestra concert and the Little Night Music recital after the show.
lead_paragraph: It was a good night Wednesday for avid followers of the Mostly Mozart festival. The main event was the concert of the festival orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall, featuring the New York debut of the young German conductor Cornelius Meister and the Mostly Mozart debut of the Argentine cellist Sol Gabetta. It was preceded by a recital from the piano duo Anderson & Roe in the hall and followed by a Little Night Music recital in the Kaplan Penthouse, performed by Ms. Gabetta and the pianist Ilya Yakushev.

headline: Daily Show Fans on Jon Stewart’s Legacy
abstract: Fans of the Daily Show waiting for the taping of Jon Stewart’s final episode share their thoughts on the host’s 16 years, and the legacy he leaves.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the Daily Show waiting for the taping of Jon Stewart’s final episode share their thoughts on the host’s 16 years, and the legacy he leaves.

headline: As Egypt Unveils Its ‘New Suez Canal,’ Dissenters Make Voices Heard Online
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Online reaction to the celebration was divided between praise for President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi from his supporters and jeers from his critics.
lead_paragraph: As Egypt’s government congratulated itself on Thursday at the very grand opening of a new side channel to the Suez Canal, the reaction on social networks to the televised pageantry was divided between praise for President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi from his supporters and jeers from his critics.

headline: At Givenchy’s Men’s Shop in Paris, the Two Sides of Riccardo Tisci
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Joining the parade of men’s boutiques in the Marais, Givenchy shows off its mix of haute history and sharp detailing.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain, redoubtable logic to fishing where the fish are. Thus, the Marais — Paris’s gay mecca, the rough equivalent in demography (if not style) of New York’s Chelsea or West Hollywood in Los Angeles — has lately been filling with designer stores catering to the stylish men who fill its streets. Along the Rue des Archives are men’s boutiques from Gucci, Fendi, Moncler and, at No. 13, Givenchy.

headline: Review: In ‘Cop Car,’ a Joyride by 2 Runaway Boys Takes a Wrong Turn
abstract: Jon Watts’s film, in its self-consciousness and breezy, instrumental violence, ambitiously announces itself as the latest spawn of neo-exploitation artists like Quentin Tarantino.
lead_paragraph: When the 10-year-old heroes of “Cop Car” first see the cruiser in question, it’s parked unattended in a field, ready to be plucked like a daisy. Travis (James Freedson-Jackson) and Harrison (Hays Wellford) make a fine pair of pipsqueaks, and they’re on a great journey when they find the car, having run away from home that same day. They have no real reason or complaint or plans, just a single piece of beef jerky and a boy’s own sense of adventure.

A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.★ Ben Allison Quintet (Tuesday through Aug. 15) Mr. Allison is a resourceful bassist, bandleader and composer, and for this run he celebrates the great jazz guitarist Jim Hall, who died in 2013. He’ll have excellent personnel for the task: the guitarist Steve Cardenas, the trumpeter Jeremy Pelt, the pianist Frank Kimbrough and the drummer Rudy Royston. At 8:30 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, 212-581-3080, birdlandjazz.com. (Nate Chinen)

abstract: Men’s fashion designers trade in the baggy board shorts look for shorter, tailored swim trunks.

headline: Memories of Tanglewood on Its 75th Birthday
abstract: Founded in 1940, the Tanglewood Music Center has exposed young musicians to artistic and political debate, master classes, potluck dinners and beautiful summers in the Berkshires.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — The conductor Andris Nelsons was coaxing the students in the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra into a Mahlerian frenzy: crouching low during quiet passages, leaping at fortissimos, exhorting them to play with meaning and passion and fervor.

headline: Review: ‘Kahlil Gibran’s The Prophet’ Turns Essays Into a Family Movie
abstract: This animated film, based on a volume of poetic writings by that early-20th-century Lebanese writer, is determined to sanctify its subject.
lead_paragraph: The burning question during my freshman year in college was whether “The Prophet,” a slim volume of poetic essays by the early-20th-century Lebanese writer and artist Kahlil Gibran, was more spiritually profound than Captain Beefheart’s seminal album, “Trout Mask Replica.” I still haven’t decided.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Party’ Celebrates New York Club Culture
abstract: The writer Anthony Haden-Guest created this show about the gleeful debauchery of the club scene of the mid-70s to early ’90s.
lead_paragraph: ‘THE LAST PARTY’

abstract: This exhibition demonstrates Picasso-like inventiveness in the ceramics of the man known as the Mad Potter of Biloxi.
lead_paragraph: ‘GEORGE OHR POTTERY’

keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'Campaign Finance', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: At this early stage and with this many candidates, the key players are donors, party elites and the press.
lead_paragraph: There are four audiences for the G.O.P. debate Thursday night — voters, donors, party leaders, media members — and they are not equal in importance.

headline: Theodore Roosevelt on How You Kill a Lion
abstract: More than a century before a Minnesota dentist hunted Cecil the lion, Theodore Roosevelt set off on a yearlong safari in Africa, where he bagged his first lion.
lead_paragraph: 106 YEARS AGO

abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: Great Jazz on the Great Hill, and Club Fare in Harlem and the Village
abstract: The free annual concert returns to the Great Hill in Central Park with the King Solomon Hicks Blues Quintet, Ray Schinnery and Ebony Jo-Ann in the lineup; dancing is highly encouraged.
lead_paragraph: Jazz is as synonymous with New York City as the Empire State Building or the Statue of Liberty. On any given night, live jazz options abound for nearly all preferences and budgets.

headline: Review: ‘God Bless the Child’ Follows Neglected Siblings at Play
abstract: Robert Machoian and Rodrigo Ojeda-Beck’s drama creates a seemingly oblivious world of make-believe, goofing off and hanging out after a mother distressingly drives off.
lead_paragraph: Directed by Robert Machoian and Rodrigo Ojeda-Beck, “God Bless the Child” poignantly illustrates what busy, tired parents have told bored offspring for years: You have to make your own fun. This extraordinary movie immerses us in the playtime of five California siblings abandoned to their own devices.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 7-13
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: Captain Mary’s Story Hour

headline: The ‘Green Book’ Legacy, a Beacon for Black Travelers
abstract: Films and books are documenting the legacy of the “Negro Motorist Green Book,” which helped African-American travelers find lodging and restaurants during the Jim Crow era.
lead_paragraph: Starting in 1936, Victor Hugo Green, a letter carrier who lived in Manhattan, published the “Negro Motorist Green Book,” listing hotels, restaurants and other businesses where African-Americans would not only be welcome but also safe. The “Green Book” series rather diplomatically described Jim Crow-era experiences with racist business owners as “painful embarrassments suffered which ruined a vacation or business trip.”

headline: Antique Lacquered Furniture’s Odd Ingredients
abstract: Mangrove bark, corncobs, guava, poppy seeds, crushed insects and other elements in lacquer can help researchers determine where objects originated and traveled and how they should be conserved.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have detected some surprising ingredients in pieces of lacquered furniture that will soon go on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston and the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.

headline: Before Main Republican Debate, Bottom 7 Contenders Put On Brave Faces
abstract: The seven Republican presidential candidates bumped from Thursday’s main event sparred several hours earlier, with little energy, in an empty arena.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — They called it the undercard. The kiddie table. The happy hour debate.

headline: Buccaneers Offer Women a Modern N.F.L. Lesson Out of the ’50s
abstract: Tampa Bay unveiled an initiative that insulted the intelligence of female fans, suggesting, among other things, that they share Bucs-themed projects on Pinterest.
lead_paragraph: Well, this must be a relief for all the women out there who lose sleep during football season wondering, “What delicious snack can I whip up for this weekend’s N.F.L. games, and what is the appropriate (and possibly color-coordinated) handmade centerpiece to accompany it?”

headline: Review: ‘Homme Less’ Follows a Homeless Middle-Age Model-Photographer
abstract: A documentary shows a former model who hits the runway shows and parties late into the night, while storing his belongings in a Y.M.C.A. locker and sleeping on a roof.
lead_paragraph: Poignancy and pathos distinguish Thomas Wirthensohn’s polished documentary, “Homme Less,” a portrait of Mark Reay, a former model struggling as a photographer. The New Jersey-born Mr. Reay had a moment more than 20 years ago, posing for shoots in Europe. Now in his 50s, he entreats Marc Jacobs for work by leaving a photo of the designer at his office; talks women into posing for him on the street; and works as a day player on movie sets. But the title derives from Mr. Reay’s nightly shelter: an East Village rooftop, where he sleeps under a tarpaulin.

headline: Final Biker Is Sentenced in Assault on S.U.V. Driver
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: A judge said Robert Sims, who was given three years in prison, became part of an angry mob in the 2013 attack in Upper Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A state judge sentenced the last of the motorcyclists convicted of attacking a driver in Upper Manhattan to three and a half years in prison on Thursday after the defendant gave a tearful apology in court.

headline: The Washington Hostess Who Nurtured Warhol
abstract: A Warhol portrait will be among the works from Ina Ginsburg’s art collection up for auction
lead_paragraph: Ina Ginsburg, the Washington patron of the arts and fund-raiser who died in November at 98, befriended some of the most powerful politicians and celebrities of her era. Famously, in 1975, she held a dinner for Andy Warhol at her house in Washington, despite warnings from some of her friends.

headline: Review: ‘The Runner’ Stars Nicolas Cage as a Politician After an Oil Spill
abstract: Written and directed by Austin Stark, this movie follows a Louisiana congressman trying to clean up his life after the Deepwater Horizon catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: In “The Runner,” a political drama without much drama, Nicolas Cage plays a Louisiana congressman, Colin Pryce, whose personal choices — too much alcohol, an affinity for extramarital affairs — make him thoroughly unlikable and a walking cliché. It’s difficult to feel the sympathy for him that Austin Stark, who wrote and directed, wants us to feel.

headline: ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Scenes from the Broadway musical about the founding fathers.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Broadway musical about the founding fathers.

headline: Review: ‘Assassination,’ With Twists and Hired Guns in 1930s Seoul and Shanghai
abstract: This historical drama, written and directed by Choi Dong-hoon, is set mainly in the 1930s, when Korea was chafing under Japanese occupation.
lead_paragraph: ASSASSINATION

headline: Review: In ‘Sneakerheadz,’ an Obsession Over Something More Than Footwear
abstract: This fans-only documentary about sneaker enthusiasts draws connections among style, sports and popular culture.
lead_paragraph: Footwear enthusiasts left wanting by “The Rise of Sneaker Culture,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum this summer, can continue exploring that snug niche in “Sneakerheadz,” an unrelated, fans-only documentary.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Hamilton’
abstract: The cast of the Broadway musical performing the number “The Schuyler Sisters.”
lead_paragraph: The cast of the Broadway musical performing the number “The Schuyler Sisters.”

headline: Review: ‘Hamilton,’ Young Rebels Changing History and Theater
abstract: In its move to Broadway, the show about America’s founding fathers is proof that the musical is not only surviving but evolving in ways that should allow it to thrive.
lead_paragraph: Yes, it really is that good.

headline: Missouri Governor Calls for Improved Police Training
abstract: Three days before the anniversary of Michael Brown’s fatal shooting, Gov. Jay Nixon called for more education on “fair and impartial policing.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri called on Thursday for improved training for law enforcement officers in his state, including more education on “fair and impartial policing” and helping mentally ill residents.

headline: Ackman Bets on Mondelez Going on Sale
abstract: The emergence of Pershing Square Capital Management as a major investor in Mondelez highlights the widespread belief that opportunities for deals abound in the food sector.
lead_paragraph: By putting $5.5 billion into Mondelez International, a hedge fund billionaire is wagering that the company, which makes Oreos, Cadbury chocolates and Trident gum, could be prodded into selling itself.

headline: ‘On the Town’ to Close on Broadway
abstract: The show will close after the ballerina Misty Copeland makes her Broadway debut.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Award-nominated revival of the musical “On the Town” will end its Broadway run at the Lyric Theater on Sept. 6, the producers of the show announced on Thursday. The musical will go out with a big ballet bang: the ballerina Misty Copeland, who this summer became the first African-American woman to be named a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will make her Broadway debut in the show for two weeks beginning on Aug. 25, replacing Megan Fairchild, for 12 performances through Sept. 6.

headline: 200 Migrants Are Believed Drowned in Capsizing Off Libya
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Trafficking', 'Drownings', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Rescues']
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency says more than 2,100 people have died this summer as refugees head across the Mediterranean Sea to Europe.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — About 200 migrants are believed to have drowned off the coast of Libya when their boat capsized, the United Nations refugee agency said Thursday.

headline: The Never-Ending Lawsuit Against 2 Former A.I.G. Executives
abstract: A still-going suit brought by Eliot Spitzer against Maurice Greenberg and another executive in 2005 shows the effectiveness of certain tactics in prolonging proceedings.
lead_paragraph: Charles Dickens invented the interminable estate dispute Jarndyce v. Jarndyce for “Bleak House,” his 1853 novel. In real life, the Federal Trade Commission once took 16 years to force Carter’s Little Liver Pills to drop the word “Liver.” And antitrust regulators spent 13 years on a case against IBM before the Reagan administration dropped it abruptly.

headline: As Temperatures Rise in Phoenix, Hikers Embrace Heat on a Grueling Ascent
abstract: Summer heat keeps many indoors in Phoenix, but it can also be inviting for a hardy few who climb Piestewa Peak, one of the most difficult mountains to hike in the area.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Summer has a smothering presence here, with its punishing triple-digit temperatures that turn parked cars into ovens so hot one can bake cookies on the dashboard. (Yes, it happens.) It triggers a modified hibernation — it is heat that keeps people indoors.

headline: George Cole, 90, British TV Star, Dies; Played a Young Scrooge in ’51 Film
abstract: Mr. Cole, who was mentored by Alastair Sim, played a young Scrooge in 1951, then went on to gain fame for his role in “Minder,” an ITV series.
lead_paragraph: George Cole, a British actor who as the young Scrooge foreshadowed Alastair Sim’s aging, coldhearted moneylender in a celebrated film version of “A Christmas Carol,” and who later developed a following as British television’s favorite rogue, died on Wednesday in Reading, England. He was 90.

headline: Life or Death for Colorado Theater Gunman Now in Jurors’ Hands
abstract: After 15 weeks in court and testimony from more than 300 witnesses, lawyers in the trial of James E. Holmes rested their cases on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — After 15 weeks in court and testimony from more than 300 witnesses, lawyers in the trial of James E. Holmes rested their cases on Thursday. A jury will now decide whether to sentence him to death or to send him to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

headline: President Reflects on Voting Rights Act
abstract: At a White House event commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act, President Obama said there were still “too many ways in which people are discouraged from voting.”
lead_paragraph: At a White House event commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act, President Obama said there were still “too many ways in which people are discouraged from voting.”

headline: Obama Urges Restoring Voting Rights Provisions
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The president argued that court decisions and state statutes discouraging “certain kinds of folks” from voting were threatening to erode the fundamental promise of the 50-year-old law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama used the 50th anniversary of the Voting Rights Act on Thursday to urge Congress to restore key elements of the law, arguing that court decisions and state statutes that discourage “certain kinds of folks” from voting are threatening to erode the fundamental promise of the civil rights-era bulwark.

headline: A Troubled Jockey’s Full Legacy Is on Display
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Museums', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Chris Antley, who died in 2000 and is being inducted into the National Museum of Racing’s Hall of Fame on Friday, was known for his success on the track and his struggles off it.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Jowett Antley does not know what she will say about her late husband, Chris Antley, when she speaks at the National Museum of Racing’s Hall of Fame on Friday. She has been worried more about how her daughter will hold up when the father who died before she was born will be recognized as one of the greatest jockeys of all time.

headline: $25,000 Fine Proposed in Taxi Driver’s Snub of Black Family
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: A judge ruled that the driver, Baqir Raza, violated a section of city human rights law when he drove away from a black family to pick up two white women.
lead_paragraph: The taxi lurched away from the curb in Midtown Manhattan, leaving behind a black family of three who had flagged it down on their way to a birthday dinner 10 blocks away. The driver, Baqir Raza, told them he had to go off duty to use the bathroom, the family said, and then picked up two white women nearby and drove away.

headline: Connecticut to Require All 11th Graders to Take the SAT
abstract: The new rule will eliminate a statewide exam given last year, and comes amid complaints that public high school students have to take too many tests.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut announced on Thursday that all 11th graders in the state’s public schools would soon be required to take the SAT college admissions tests, replacing an existing statewide exam amid widespread concern that the nation’s students are tested too much.

abstract: Carlos Menem is suspected of conspiring to conceal what prosecutors have said was Syrian involvement in the suicide bomb attack, which killed 85 people.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina’s labyrinthine investigation into the suicide bombing of a Jewish community center here two decades ago began a new chapter on Thursday with the start of a trial in which Carlos Menem, a former president, is accused of trying to derail the case.

The latest installment in the series comes from Alice Waters —chef, author, restaurant owner and slow-food pioneer — who shares her picks exclusively with T.

headline: From an Unfussy New Orleans Cafe, a Summer Cobbler
abstract: The Southern pastry chef Kelly Fields shares a recipe from her new bakery.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2003, the Southern-born pastry chef Kelly Fields approached her boss, the beloved blue-eyed New Orleans chef and James Beard Award-winner John Besh, about opening a bakery. Then Hurricane Katrina hit, putting Fields’s plans on hold while the city picked itself back up again. At Besh’s urging, she traveled the world in the meantime, gathering culinary inspiration in Italy, Egypt and throughout the Middle East before settling back in New Orleans and holding the title of executive pastry chef at his culinary empire there. And finally this week, over a decade after she first conceived it, Fields opened the doors to Willa Jean, an unfussy corner bakery and cafe in the up-and-coming South Market District.

headline: Jon Stewart Signs Off From ‘Daily Show’ With Wit and Sincerity
abstract: After 16 years of presiding over the Comedy Central news-parody show, Mr. Stewart, 52, said goodbye on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: After 16 years of taking satirical aim at the hypocrisy of politics and the fatuousness of the news media, Jon Stewart said goodbye to “The Daily Show” on Thursday evening with a farewell broadcast that mixed wry parting shots with earnest displays of emotion and with a passionate speech urging his audience not to accept falsehoods and misinformation in their lives.

headline: Jon Stewart Cements His Legacy in ‘Daily Show’ Finale

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Edge) FROZEN (2013) Warm up your vocal cords: This Disney movie musical produced “Let It Go,” the Oscar-winning power anthem written by the married songwriters Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez. Chris Buck and Jennifer Lee directed this fable about Elsa, above (the voice of Idina Menzel), an ice princess cursed with a frigid touch, and Anna (Kristen Bell), her younger sister and best friend. When Anna falls for a prince (Santino Fontana), Elsa forbids them to marry, casting their Scandinavian kingdom into eternal winter with a wave of her hand. Horrified, she retreats to an ice palace, but sibling love sends Anna plowing through drifts and up glacial ridges in search of Elsa, confident that she can reverse the spell. “Allegorically, ‘Frozen’ lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like ‘Beauty and the Beast,’ but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this blockbuster, inspired by Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Snow Queen.”

headline: Missing the Warnings on Legionnaires’ Disease

Even more dismaying has been the city’s sluggishness in responding to early-warning signs of a potential health problem.

headline: From Trump on Down, the Republicans Can’t Be Serious

abstract: Donald Trump is fundamentally absurd, but so are his rivals, and that’s what their party requires.

Instead, however, Donald Trump leads the field by a wide margin. What happened?

headline: The Real Voter Fraud Is Texas’ ID Law
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A practically non-existent problem has become an excuse to discriminate against the poor, blacks and Latinos.

headline: Keeping Skyscrapers From Blowing in the Wind
