headline: Today in Politics: Debates Give Those Fighting for Traction a Chance to Gain a Footing
abstract: It was a night of two debates, but in a way, Thursday evening’s marathon in Cleveland felt like three events.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington. It has been only a few hours since 17 Republicans gathered in two debates in an effort to stand apart. As expected, the big names remained big, but a few lesser-known candidates found a way to rise above the crowded field, at least for a night.

headline: The 7.26.15 Issue
abstract: Readers react.
lead_paragraph: RE: CHRISTIANS

headline: What’s on This Week Around the World
abstract: A music festival gets underway in two cities in Japan, an exhibition in Pakistan showcases design from the region, and the BBC Proms bring major orchestras to London.
lead_paragraph: Berlin

headline: How to Project Power
abstract: Work on an expansive posture. Avoid overexplaining.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Keep your limbs away from your body,’’ says Deborah H Gruenfeld, a social psychologist who teaches at Stanford University. Some research shows that people posed in expansive postures feel more powerful, exhibit higher testosterone levels and have lower levels of the stress hormone cortisol — all characteristics of high-ranking social status. Make eye contact while you’re talking, but feel free to look away when others do. This is what scientists call having a high ‘‘look-speak to look-listen ratio,’’ which is common for dominant members of groups.

headline: ‘Written by Himself’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: There is so much to pay attention to in this poem: the rich and varied allusions; the use of repetition at the beginnings and endings of its sentences; the rhythm in the making and breaking of its pattern; and the idea of a personal mythology, a song of the self that, in its expansiveness, might stand for us all.

headline: He’s Got Legs
abstract: Nothing exposes a man to more judgment and ridicule than wearing shorts, whether they’re Boy Scout cargo-style or fashion-designer formal.
lead_paragraph: Up above the hems of a proper pair of trousers — above the ankle-­baring ends of high-­waters and clam-­diggers, above the shin-­skimming edges of pants named for the isle of Capri and for the gauchos of the Pampas — are the knees. Bared by shorts, they point us toward a few truths about social standards. Women’s legs are tangled in their own sex-­segregated history of social control and gender politics; shorts are, first off, short pants, and it was not so very long ago that women were told wearing pants of any length was prima facie evidence of moral turpitude. The man in shorts, meanwhile, occupies a space that is more subtly strange. Year after year, as surely as tender spring yields to scalding summer, a season of dress-­code controversies gives way to a running conversation about the unwritten rules of urban spaces, with arbiters of taste cringing at men’s legs in shorts as if wincing at a comedy of embarrassment.

headline: Starring Vermouth
abstract: The fortified wine — especially the fragrant Spanish variety — deserves more than a supporting role in cocktails.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, my brother asked me where I would like to spend my 40th birthday. I chose Spain, and he generously presented me with a plane ticket to Barcelona. I booked a sunny apartment with an abundance of colorful tiles. I got a ticket for an FC Barcelona match at Camp Nou. But in the weeks leading up to my birthday, my mother’s health declined precipitously. I couldn’t leave New York under the circumstances, and canceled the trip.

headline: Off the Road
abstract: It was just another truck, until the engine finally died.
lead_paragraph: I never thought I was a car guy until the day my little blue Toyota truck died. In fact, on some level, I had contempt for guys who cared too much about what they drove. Proof that I didn’t share their affliction, in my mind, was the fact that I had been driving the same beat-up base model Toyota pickup, with camper shell, for 23 years, ever since my father sold it to me for $4,000 in 1992.

headline: Yankees’ C. C. Sabathia Grows Older, Wiser and, at Least for a Night, Stronger
abstract: Sabathia, 35, had his best outing of the season Thursday against the Red Sox, throwing his fastball at 94 m.p.h., but his challenge now is to have success when he is not at his best.
lead_paragraph: In his first few years with the Yankees, when his fastball hummed as reliably as it did on Thursday against the Boston Red Sox, C. C. Sabathia made pitching sound so easy. All he did, he would say after starts, was pound the zone.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its ninth, and penultimate, week. To participate, post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on Aug. 14.
lead_paragraph: Our Summer Reading Contest is now in its ninth, and penultimate, week. To participate, post a comment here by 7 a.m. Eastern on Aug. 14 and answer the question “What interested you most in The Times this week?”

headline: Morning Agenda: Ackman’s Bet on Mondelez Sales
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'Food', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'NEW YORK CITY', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The Never-Ending Lawsuit | Why Disclosing C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change | Apollo’s Stake in American Realty
lead_paragraph: ACKMAN’S BET ON MONDELEZ SALES | By building up a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, William A. Ackman is wagering that Mondelez could be persuaded to sell itself, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. The investment that Mr. Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management has made also highlights the widespread belief that the food sector is ripe for consolidation.

headline: China Detains Lawyer Who Accused Police of Torture, His Wife Says
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Over the past month, more than 200 lawyers and members of their support staffs have been detained or questioned by the police, according to rights advocates.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese lawyer who defied the authorities by speaking publicly about being tortured in police custody and who had become a vocal critic of a continuing government crackdown on human rights lawyers has been detained by the police, his wife said on Friday.

headline: A Call to ‘Cry Out’ Against Cross Removals in China
abstract: Last week, the Catholic diocese of Wenzhou released a letter signed by its bishop and 26 priests on the government’s taking down of crosses at churches.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year and a half, the government of Zhejiang Province has forcibly removed hundreds of crosses from churches, part of a campaign by the local authorities to lower the profile of Christianity in a region where it has made deep inroads. The campaign has long met with protests by parishioners, but now it is also being denounced by government-approved Christian organizations. In early July, official Protestant and Catholic associations issued open letters questioning the campaign’s legality.

headline: Presidential Debate Fashions: Windows Into a Candidacy
abstract: Ever since Richard Nixon met John F. Kennedy on the small screen in 1960, there’s been little doubt that image and appearance can play a potentially significant role in swaying voter opinion.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night voters got their first look at the 10 current leading Republican candidates in comparison to one another — literally. Ever since Richard Nixon met John F. Kennedy on the small screen in 1960, there’s been little doubt that while it’s the substance of presidential debates that matters most, image and appearance can play a potentially significant role in swaying voter opinion (consciously or not). As a result, different schools of thoughts have developed on the best approach to the situation. The two most popular were on view last night, and like the candidates themselves, proved to have varying degrees of success.

headline: Donald Trump Says Again He Remains Open to Independent Run
abstract: Donald J. Trump said that he owed it to his supporters to keep open the possibility of running as an independent.
lead_paragraph: One of the more contentious moments of the first Republican presidential debate was when Donald J. Trump refused to rule out the possibility of a third party bid.

headline: Gao Yu, Jailed Chinese Journalist, Is Said to Be Receiving Good Medical Care
abstract: She was taken to a specialist civilian hospital outside the medical system run by the police for tests that revealed cardiovascular problems, her lawyers said.

headline: Suicide Blast Kills 8 in Afghanistan
abstract: The attacker detonated a deadly truck bomb near an army camp in the eastern part of the capital, Kabul, on Friday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The attacker detonated a deadly truck bomb near an army camp in the eastern part of the capital, Kabul, on Friday, officials said.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Ricki and the Flash,’ ‘Diary of a Teenage Girl’ and ‘Fantastic Four’
abstract: Times critics on “Ricki and the Flash,” “Diary of a Teenage Girl” and “Fantastic Four.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Ricki and the Flash,” “Diary of a Teenage Girl” and “Fantastic Four.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Mike Huckabee Adds Levity to Debate, and Signals More to Come
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate brought a bit of humor to last night’s debate and indicated that he might step up his role as the happy warrior.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee hinted that he might ramp up his happy warrior act as his presidential campaign moves forward.

headline: Verbatim: Hold Your Nose and Vote
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, commented on his party loyalty.
lead_paragraph: — Senator Lindsey Graham, promising on MSNBC to support whoever the Republican Party nominates for president.

headline: Review: ‘Compton,’ Dr. Dre’s First Album in 16 Years
abstract: Inspired by the N.W.A. biopic “Straight Outta Compton,” the album has an almost an open-door policy for collaborators.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Dre doesn’t surface often — since N.W.A. disbanded in the early 1990s, he’s released just two albums and supervised one compilation — but when he does, he exudes what feels like decades’ worth of tension.

headline: A Brooklyn Grocery’s Last Night
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman in Clinton Hill bought an odd selection of groceries, but her neighborhood store was closing, and she wanted to buy anything left.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: 1890: Electrical Execution Botched
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Americans express their indignation at execution by electric chair in 1890.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — From one end of the country to the other there is nothing but expressions of indignation and horror at the method of Kemmler’s execution and a demand from all classes that it should be the last scene of such horrors. Two curious points have been developed. It is supposed that 1,700 volts were applied to Kemmler, but twenty incandescent test lamps were by mistake left burning, consuming fifty volts each, leaving only 700 volts for the death of Kemmler, which was not enough to cause instant death.

headline: In Katie Ledecky’s Amazing Feats, Echoes of a Swimmer From the 1970s
abstract: Ledecky is going for a sweep of the distance freestyle events at the world championships. In 1975, Tim Shaw was similarly dominant.
lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — The 5-foot-11 teenage freestyler with the reserved personality and the swimming range of an albatross won every final at the world championships from the 200 meters through the 1,500, thrilling the crowds inside the stadium while gun-toting soldiers patrolled outside.

headline: The Republican Scrum Begins
abstract: In spite of Trump, a pretty good night for seriousness and the non-Jeb, non-Donald field.
lead_paragraph: My fantasy of the 2016 G.O.P. primary debate, regular readers may remember, involved a serious clash of ideas between Marco Rubio and Rand Paul, the two candidates who seemed — as of six months ago, at least — to be charting the most creative and interesting paths forward for a Republican Party that’s lost the popular vote in five of the last six presidential contests. My worst-case scenario, on the other hand, basically involved a replay of 2012 — an establishment candidate playing it as safe as possible while a group of would-be populists fought one another noisily but emptily for the chance to finish second.

headline: The Doorman’s Dilemma: What to Do With All Those Packages?
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building Service Employees', 'Doormen']
abstract: With the increased popularity of online shopping, New York co-ops, condos and rental buildings are being forced to reconsider their delivery policies.
lead_paragraph: As president of the board of his Midtown East co-op, Dennis Paget has reason to walk a little faster when a particular fellow resident comes into view. To do otherwise would mean enduring yet another stern lecture about the building’s supposedly dilatory parcel delivery service.

headline: ‘Kitchens of the Great Midwest,’ by J. Ryan Stradal
abstract: This debut novel centers on an outsize food prodigy.
lead_paragraph: “Larger than life” is usually a cliché, but in the case of Eva Thorvald — the 6-foot-2 mighty Aphrodite who strides through the pages of J. Ryan Stradal’s appealing first novel — the description is literally as well as metaphorically accurate. Born with a “once-in-a-generation palate,” Eva is a food prodigy. At 3½ months old, she destroys a vegetable stand in pursuit of a perfect heirloom tomato; at 10, she runs a cottage industry from her bedroom closet, growing chocolate habanero peppers so incendiary that her client, the city’s best Mexican restaurant, is forced to post a warning label on the menu; at 11, she earns extra cash from bar bets by consuming quantities of blistering chili and “Circle of Hell” chicken wings. Yet despite a life pockmarked by poverty and other adversities, Eva has an equally outsize heart. A warring mass of desires, talents and imperfections, she’s an attractively flawed, completely likable demigoddess.

headline: What Steve Jobs Taught Me About Being a Son and a Father
abstract: While mourning his mother, a new father thinks of a lesson he learned from Steve Jobs that he would like to teach his newborn son.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, right after my first son was born, I thought about the lessons I wanted to pass along to him that I had learned a little late in life. Among the morals I scribbled down in my mind one that stood out began with a story involving Steve Jobs and ended with the serving of my mother’s last meal.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Spicy Food, Running Shoes and Legionnaire’s Disease
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: ‘Folk City: New York and the American Folk Music Revival’
abstract: New York City’s folk revival in pictures and interviews.
lead_paragraph: How New York City and specifically Greenwich Village came to be at the epicenter of an American folk music revival between 1950 and 1965 is the subject of Stephen Petrus and Ronald D. Cohen’s “Folk City.” This handsome book, which includes rarely seen photographs, reminiscences of participants and a lively narrative, adds depth to an exhibition of the same name on view at the Museum of the City of New York until January.

headline: Why a Boring Jobs Report Is Great News for the Fed
abstract: There are no great mysteries for Janet Yellen and her colleagues to sort out, as the economy continues to improve at a slow but steady rate.
lead_paragraph: Here is how to think about the July jobs numbers that the government released Friday morning: Whatever you thought about the economy, or financial markets or the proper course of Federal Reserve policy at 8:29 a.m., just before the numbers were released, you have every reason to have also believed it at 8:31 a.m., just after.

headline: Hugh Thomas’s ‘World Without End: Spain, Philip II, and the First Global Empire’
abstract: King Philip II extends and consolidates his empire in the final volume of a trilogy that began with Columbus.
lead_paragraph: When did the modern age begin? There is no shortage of contenders — from the fall of Constantinople to Columbus’s arrival in the Americas to (my candidate) Vasco da Gama’s projection of European power into Asia. In “World Without End,” Hugh Thomas stakes a claim for one more: an obscure 1559 peace treaty between Philip II, the Hapsburg king of Spain, and Henry II, the Valois king of France, that concluded a decades-old struggle for control of Italy.

headline: Since Katrina
abstract: “The Katrina Decade: Images of an Altered City” collects photos by David G. Spielman.
lead_paragraph: Ten years after Hurricane Katrina’s historic devastation, we review several books this week about New Orleans. Over the course of that decade, David G. Spielman, a photographer in the Crescent City, has been recording the storm’s effects, collected in “The Katrina Decade: Images of an Altered City.”

headline: Runner Nick Symmonds Faces Ban Over Gear
keywords: ['Track and Field', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Uniforms', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment']
abstract: A top American 800-meter runner is involved in a dispute with track officials over a document that governs when athletes must wear team apparel instead of that from their own sponsors.
lead_paragraph: Nick Symmonds is a six-time outdoor national champion at 800 meters. He finished fifth at the 2012 London Olympics, in a personal best of 1 minute 42.95 seconds. And he has been named to the United States team for the world track and field championships this month in Beijing.

headline: Daily Report: A Peek at the Future of Artificial Intelligence and Human Relationships
abstract: This may not be the world of “Her,” and computers aren’t now doing the work of doctors. The trend lines, though, sure look pretty clear.
lead_paragraph: Two possible glimpses into the future arrived on Thursday, if you were looking for them.

headline: Priceless Violin Found After 35 Years
abstract: Roman Totenberg’s rare Stradivarius violin, stolen after a performance in 1980, was returned to the authorities this June.
lead_paragraph: Roman Totenberg’s rare Stradivarius violin, stolen after a performance in 1980, was returned to the authorities this June.

headline: Baby Dies After Fall From 4th-Floor Window in Queens, Police Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Falls', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: The authorities were investigating how the boy, not even a month old, tumbled to his death from an apartment in Richmond Hill.
lead_paragraph: Mazol Ilyayeva had just fed her baby before sunrise on Friday when she stepped out of her apartment in Queens to get some air. Then, she heard a thump.

headline: Digging for Trashed Pictures in Mac’s Photos App
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Tablet Computers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mac OS (Operating System)']
abstract: Recovering discarded photos before they are gone for good, and shutting down misbehaving applications.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: C.J. Box is known for his thrillers set in Wyoming, but in “Badlands,” No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list, he shifts his attention to North Dakota and the fracking boom.
lead_paragraph: Carbon Footprints: The thriller writer C.J. Box (whose initials stand for Charles James, dashing your hopes that his full name was Cracker Jack Box) is best known for his series of gritty mysteries about the Wyoming game warden Joe Pickett. But in “Badlands,” a stand-alone suspense thriller new at No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list, Box shifts his attention to North Dakota and the fracking boom; the book, set in the fictional oil town of Grimstad, N.D., is about a 12-year-old boy who witnesses a car accident on his paper route and makes off with the bundle of drugs and money he finds at the scene. As a child, Box had relatives who worked blue-collar jobs in the energy industry — “The house I grew up in didn’t have a single bookcase except mine,” he once told a website devoted to crime fiction — and in this novel he pokes some fun at journalists who reflexively condemn big oil. “They fly all the way here from the East Coast burning up jet fuel,” the town sheriff grouses at one point, “then rent cars and fill ’em with gasoline to drive all the way to Grimstad just so they can trot me out to say, ‘Oil is bad.’ I won’t play their game anymore.” Box has observed reporters up close: He used to be one. “My first job was working for a small Wyoming weekly newspaper,” he told the same website, The Rap Sheet, in 2010. “In retrospect, it was spectacular training in ‘the real world’ for what was to come. I learned so much, and met so many people in all walks of life. Much of what I’ve since written came from those days as a starving reporter.”

headline: ‘Sea Lovers: Selected Stories,’ by Valerie Martin
abstract: Many of the stories in Valerie Martin’s collection — which looks at artists, nature and transition — are set in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Among the many potent themes that weave in and out of the stories in “Sea Lovers” — the stark realities of the artist’s path; the proximity of death to life; the complexities of the relationship between humans and animals — are a number of seemingly ordinary yet revelatory ­images. For Valerie Martin’s characters, something as simple as drinking a glass of water can yield a moment of reflection and clarity.

headline: ‘All That Followed,’ by Gabriel Urza
abstract: In Gabriel Urza’s debut novel, characters’ memories are prompted by the Madrid train bombing of 2004.
lead_paragraph: Stories are shape-shifters in “All That Followed,” Gabriel Urza’s strange and ambitious debut novel. Set in Spain’s Basque Country, the book revolves around the assassination of Councilman José Antonio Torres, as recounted by three characters: Mariana, his dubiously grieving widow; the American teacher Joni Garrett, who came to Muriga in 1951 and wound up staying for his entire life; and Iker Abarzuza, serving time for murder in an island prison, where he listens to the cries of shorebirds and receives the occasional letter from Mariana.

headline: Opposing Iran Nuclear Deal, Chuck Schumer Rattles Democratic Firewall
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Schumer, a powerful voice, joins the resistance among Democrats concentrated in two heavily Jewish areas, Greater New York City and South Florida.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The decision by Senator Chuck Schumer of New York to oppose the Iran nuclear deal has rattled the Democratic bulwark around the accord, emboldened the deal’s opponents in both parties, and set off a wave of condemnation from liberals for the man who hopes to lead Senate Democrats in the next Congress.

headline: In a First, a Sudanese Migrant Nearly Crosses the English Channel on Foot
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The authorities arrested Abdul Rahman Haroun, who evaded 400 security cameras and walked about 30 miles underground, dodging trains traveling at up to 100 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For one African migrant, there was nothing left to lose.

headline: ‘Crooked Heart,’ by Lissa Evans
abstract: A young orphan and a widow run a charity scam amid the corruption of World War II London.
lead_paragraph: Show of hands: Was anybody here an odd-looking, precocious, misunderstood child? Oh. . . . Everybody? Maybe that’s why so many of the novels we love most, from Brontë’s “Jane Eyre” to Rowling’s Harry Potter series, feature some version of this small person. We are gutted not by Scout or Jem in “To Kill a Mockingbird,” but by Dill, the fatherless fantabulist; we may admire Sara Crewe when she’s a kind little heiress, but she’s truly a princess when she loses both her money and her dad. I’ll read anything that features an invisible, unloved child, an orphan either in reality or spirit, more resourceful than any wee one should have to be. Bonus points if the child finds ways to skirt the law. (I’m looking at you, Addie Pray.)

headline: ‘Joy: Poet, Seeker, and the Woman Who Captivated C.S. Lewis’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A biography of the woman who married C.S. Lewis.
lead_paragraph: Even if “Joy,” Abigail Santamaria’s life of C.S. Lewis’s wife, were a bad book, Lewis’s zealous admirers would read it, eager for another way to finger his shroud. Joy Davidman married Lewis, author of the beloved “Chronicles of Narnia,” at 41, and her late entrance into his bachelor existence is a cherished part of his legend. She soon died of bone cancer, but she had made him a husband and stepfather, adding an intimate touch to the genial but distant self-portrait that emerges from his grown-up books, tracts like “Mere Christianity.” Her death was also the subject of “A Grief Observed,” his classic book on mourning and how faith can survive it.

headline: The Economy Vanishes
abstract: About that Obama disaster ….
lead_paragraph: There was almost no discussion of the economy in last night’s debate, which is actually weird if you consider the Republican self-image. These guys portray themselves as high priests of growth, the people who know how to bring prosperity. And remember all the crowing about how Obama was presiding over the worst recovery ever?

headline: Robin Williams’s Underrated Roles Help Illustrate His Major Talents
abstract: In addition to his well-known roles in films like “Dead Poets Society,” the actor worked on a wide range of less-celebrated films, from “Popeye” to “World’s Greatest Dad.”
lead_paragraph: This summer brings in close proximity two sad milestones for fans of Robin Williams: July 21 would have been the 64th birthday of this inventive comedian and Academy Award-winning actor, and Aug. 11 is the one-year anniversary of his death. It is a bittersweet occasion to reflect on the range of work that Williams created, as he bounded from classically trained stage actor to stand-up comedian, and from a star of sitcoms to a leading man in movies. While a full consideration of Williams’s career would naturally gravitate toward his sympathetic serio-comic roles in films like “Good Morning Vietnam,” “Dead Poets Society” and “Good Will Hunting,” these performances overshadow other, more idiosyncratic but equally vivid efforts — some from a time when his on-screen persona hadn’t completely coalesced, and others he was able to sneak in once his fame was assured. Here are five of Williams’s less celebrated performances.

headline: Marco Rubio Clarifies His Position on Abortion
abstract: The Florida Republican’s abortion remark in the debate Thursday evening might have surprised some viewers.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio surprised some viewers on Thursday night when he said that he never supported exceptions that would allow for abortions if conception occurred from rape or incest.

headline: The Man Who Gave Air Force One Its Aura
abstract: Raymond Loewy, a pre-eminent commercial designer, told an aide to John F. Kennedy in 1962 that he could help transform the drab presidential jet.
lead_paragraph: Next time you see an image of Air Force One taking off, think Coca-Cola and Lucky Strike. The look of today’s presidential plane, emblazoned with “United States of America” on the blue-and-white fuselage, originated with a quiet collaboration between President John F. Kennedy and Raymond Loewy, who was perhaps the most accomplished commercial image and design expert of the post-World War II era.

headline: Donald Trump’s Remarks Feed Into Charges of Sexism
abstract: The businessman was angry over the anchors’ debate questions about his fitness to be president in the wake of disparaging remarks he has made about women,
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump kept his vow to remain unbeholden to political correctness after Thursday night’s debate, continuing to criticize the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly for asking him questions that were too tough while he was on stage.

headline: The Next G.O.P. Phenom
abstract: If recent history of Republican presidential campaigns continues, a couple of different candidates will have a few weeks or months to shine.

headline: A Product of Tunisia’s 1960s Resistance Continues to Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Fathi Ben Haj Yahia, a school director, former political prisoner and Marxist writer, laments that political theorists have failed to forge something new out of Tunisia’s 2011 uprising.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — WhenFathi Ben Haj Yahia seeks to explain Tunisia’s troubled transition since its revolution overthrew nearly 60 years of dictatorship four years ago, he offers a parable.

headline: She Answered His Ad for a Roommate, Moved In and Never Left
abstract: Kerry Ryan was 21 and had just arrived from Ireland when she replied to 43-year-old John Juback’s classified ad in The Village Voice. It has been 24 years since she came to check out the place.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Ryan needed a new place to live; her crazy Yugoslavian roommate had become unbearable. So, as people did in 1991 in New York City, she turned to the classified ads in The Village Voice.

headline: How to Approach the Generation Gap in the Workplace
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Age, Chronological', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Discrimination', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Readers share their advice about navigating the workplace in an era when millennials are hiring and managing older employees.
lead_paragraph: A generation gap is widening in the workplace. As baby boomers (ages 51 to 69 or so) express reluctance about retiring, so-called millennials (roughly ages 18 to 34) have become the single largest demographic in the American labor force. Because of this, more older workers have found themselves being hired and managed by people much younger than they are.

headline: Stuff We Liked: How Cats Took Over the Internet
abstract: A roundup of interesting items online includes a look at an obscure but important economist and a forecast of how driverless cars can end our parking problems.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Don Brown’s ‘Drowned City,’ and More
abstract: Property is not all that was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina, as these three books for young readers demonstrate.
lead_paragraph: Ten years have passed since Americans were glued to their televisions, watching the catastrophic results of Hurricane Katrina. Yet much of the drama happened after the storm pummeled New Orleans. For readers too young to remember, three new books revisit those troubled days and offer a clear view of that notorious storm’s impact.

headline: ‘The Little Brother,’ by Victoria Patterson
abstract: After their parents split, siblings pursue vastly different paths.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Patterson is a capable and ­canny writer, and she would have to be to take on the subject of her newest novel, “The Little Brother,” and produce so arresting and haunting an experience. To say the book is about a rape is true, but that’s only part of it — in many ways, the least interesting part. The real subject is the conditions that allow that rape to happen.

headline: A Missed Opportunity: G.O.P. Debate Avoids Family Policy Issues
abstract: Do any of the Republican candidates support policies that support working families? We don’t know, because they weren’t asked.
lead_paragraph: I watched the first 2016 Republican debate with four children, aged 14, 11, 9 and 9. That meant juggling pizza off the grill while juggling questions about immigration (“But why does it matter if they come here? We’re all on the same continent.”); foreign policy (We have enemies? Who? China?); and Donald Trump’s hair. It meant introducing my oldest son to Politifact and its Pants on Fire GIF and teaching my suddenly very worried youngest daughter (“America is under attack?”) about the concept of exaggerating for dramatic affect (“just like your sister does”).

headline: Lauren Fox’s ‘Days of Awe’
abstract: A woman faces sudden singlehood and the loss of a confidante.
lead_paragraph: What’s wonderful about reading a novelist’s books in back-to-back sequence is that you witness the writer grow not gradually, but seemingly overnight. In Lauren Fox’s first novel, “Still Life With Husband,” an unhappily married woman who works for a journal called Male Reproduction (complete with, yes, a boss named Dick) satisfies her seven-year itch with a hunky but sensitive writer she meets in a cafe. Fox furthers these themes with a more mature voice in her delightful “Friends Like Us” — a story of relationships made all kinds of confused when the protagonist’s best friend as an adult falls for her best friend from adolescence.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PANIC IN A SUITCASE, by Yelena Akhtiorskaya. (Riverhead, $16.) The boundaries between the Old and New Worlds blur in this debut novel, which follows a Ukrainian family adjusting to Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Spanning 15 years of their lives, the resulting story is, as Karolina Waclawiak wrote here, a “rewarding biography of displacement, where those left behind are often as disconnected as those who flee for an elusive better life elsewhere.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: LET ME TELL YOU: New Stories, Essays, and Other Writings, by Shirley Jackson. Edited by Laurence Jackson Hyman and Sarah Hyman DeWitt. (Random House, $30.) Insights into the vagaries of Jackson’s ruminant, generous mind.

headline: Men and Women Team Up and Face Off in New Mixed Relays
abstract: The world championships now include mixed relays, in which each country uses two men and two women in whatever order they choose. That can produce thrilling comebacks.
lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — The gun went off for the medley relay final at the swimming world championships, and it quickly seemed that Russia was in deep trouble. Its backstroker rapidly fell behind the other seven swimmers and, by the end of the leg, was more than seven seconds behind the leader and nearly six seconds behind the next slowest swimmer.

headline: After the Storm
abstract: Three new books about life in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: SHOTS ON THE BRIDGEPolice Violence and Cover-Up in the Wake of KatrinaBy Ronnie Greene240 pp. Beacon, $24.95.

headline: Most Railroads Won’t Meet Deadline for Safety Controls, Report Says
abstract: The Federal Railroad Administration said the majority of freight and passenger rail companies would not be able to install the technology known as positive train control by Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of freight railroads and passenger trains will not be able to meet a year-end deadline to install technology that prevents trains from exceeding speed limits and helps avoid collisions, the Federal Railroad Administration said Friday in a report to Congress.

headline: Navigating Tougher I.R.S. Rules for Family Partnerships
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The I.R.S. is expected to release restrictions on the partnerships, abused by some very wealthy families to avoid estate taxes, as soon as mid-September.
lead_paragraph: THE Internal Revenue Service is about to toughen the rules on a type of investment vehicle that has been abused by some very wealthy families to avoid millions of dollars in taxes.

headline: Readers on Cecil the Lion
abstract: Many readers drew a distinction between their revulsion toward the trophy hunting and the obvious need to protect human life in Zimbabwe.
lead_paragraph: The first time #CeciltheLion popped up on Twitter, I wondered, “Who would name a lion after Cecil John Rhodes?”, the colonial founder of Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe.

headline: Swiss Identify Remains of Japanese Climbers Missing for 45 Years
abstract: The two mountain climbers were caught in a snowstorm while preparing to climb the Matterhorn and buried under nearly a half-century of Alpine ice.
lead_paragraph: Two Japanese mountain climbers caught in a snowstorm and buried under nearly half a century of Alpine ice have been identified, the police in Switzerland announced this week.

headline: Political Scandal Consumes Malaysia at Time of Flight 370 Inquiry
abstract: Attention in the nation has been focused on an affair involving almost $700 million that mysteriously appeared in bank accounts belonging to Prime Minister Najib Razak.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was a breakthrough in one of the biggest mysteries in aviation history. When a wing part belonging to a Boeing 777 was found last week on the remote Indian Ocean island of Réunion, the world took notice, echoing the intense news media coverage that followed the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 on March 8, 2014.

headline: Busy September Looms for Obama, but First: Two Weeks of Golf
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Global Warming', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The president will face likely showdowns on Iran and the budget, not to mention high-profile visitors from Beijing and the Vatican, after a vacation on Martha’s Vineyard.
lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — President Obama slipped out of Washington on Friday afternoon for his annual Martha’s Vineyard vacation, just in time for the political spotlight to swing firmly away from the White House and toward the 2016 presidential campaign after the first Republican debate on Thursday night.

headline: 1940: Stewardess Says Man Hit Her
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An American Airlines stewardess was hit by a passenger in 1940.
lead_paragraph: A mysterious attack on a pretty twenty-two-year-old stewardess on a New York to Dallas, Tex., sleeper plane was being investigated yesterday by American Airlines officials. The girl swallowed a baggage compartment key after she was struck by an unidentified man thirty minutes before the plane landed at 11:40 p.m. Wednesday at Nashville, Tenn. The stewardess, Miss Rosemary Olive Griffith, who was taken to a hospital in Nashville after the plane landed, suffering from a bruised head and scratches on her legs and arms, told the story of the assault to C.R. Smith, president of the American Airlines, yesterday from her hospital bed. She was struck on the head just after entering the women’s lounge to get her bag, and fell to the floor unconscious after first swallowing the key which the intruder had demanded. — New York Herald Tribune, August 8, 1940

headline: Success or Excess: What’s Behind Manhattan’s New Residential Sales Record?
abstract: The average price for a residence was reported to have hit $1.7 million, proof that the real estate market has bounced back from the 2008 recession.
lead_paragraph: The average price for a residence was reported to have hit $1.7 million, proof that the real estate market has bounced back from the 2008 recession.

headline: Duck in Summertime, Spicy and Fruity
abstract: Fragrant with Chinese five-spice powder, the duck is topped with juicy blackberries
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to go to a restaurant to have duck for dinner. Many home cooks leave duck cooking to the professionals, but once you know the technique, cooking a large Muscovy duck breast is no more difficult than cooking a steak.

headline: Review: A Divisive ‘Fidelio’ Draws Boos at Salzburg
abstract: A Freudian version of the opera, directed by Claus Guth, sees it as a meditation on the prisons we create for ourselves.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — What’s a summer at the Salzburg Festival without at least one opera production that provokes vociferous booing on its opening night? That requisite rite took place here on Tuesday, at a new staging of Beethoven’s “Fidelio,” when the German director Claus Guth and his production team appeared during curtain calls at the Grosses Festspielhaus.

headline: Army Ranger School a Test for Women in Combat Roles
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Two officers may become the first women to graduate from Ranger School. For now, though, they are not allowed to try out for the Ranger regiment.
lead_paragraph: CAMP JAMES E. RUDDER, Fla. — Wearing a cap, sunglasses and a 75-pound rucksack and carrying a 17-pound machine gun, the young, buzz-cut Army officer quickly traversed a muddy river, pulling on a rope stretched between trees on either bank.

headline: SoulCycle: You Say ‘Cult.’ I Say ‘Loyal Customer Base.’
abstract: Investors should ask if SoulCycle has a unique factor that will get customers to keep paying more than its competitors charge.
lead_paragraph: When young, trendy companies prepare for initial public offerings, their financial statements often show rapid growth but little profit. Investors are expected to take a leap of faith and bet that today’s expanding popularity will lead to sustainable earnings down the road.

headline: Potash Corporation Again Approaches K&S About Takeover
abstract: The latest takeover offer was unchanged in its value, but included a more formal “business combination agreement,” K&S said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — K&S, the German potash and salt mining company that owns Morton Salt, said on Friday that the Potash Corporation had made another unsolicited takeover approach for the company.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Katrina: After the Flood’
abstract: This week, Gary Rivlin discusses “Katrina: After the Flood”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Joe Domanick talks about “Blue: The LAPD and the Battle to Redeem American Policing”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Gary Rivlin discusses “Katrina: After the Flood”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Joe Domanick talks about “Blue: The LAPD and the Battle to Redeem American Policing”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Long Shadow of Bill Gross
abstract: With assets under management and profit falling, Allianz’s Pimco arm is still reeling from its co-founder’s exit. But the German insurer can ride it out.
lead_paragraph: Pimco may not have emerged from the shadow of its larger-than-life co-founder Bill Gross, who left the world’s biggest bond fund abruptly in September 2014. But Allianz, its German owner, can take Pimco’s fall from grace in its stride. The company’s half-year results suggest its insurance division and a growing in-house asset manager are taking up the slack.

headline: Norwegian Youths Return to Camp on Utoya, the Site of a 2011 Massacre
abstract: Over 1,000 young activists tried to reclaim the summer retreat from the horrors of an attack by a right-wing extremist that killed 69 people.
lead_paragraph: UTOYA, Norway — With songs, volleyball games and defiant displays of summer languor, more than 1,000 Norwegian youths on Friday joined the secretary general of NATO and other dignitaries on the island of Utoya, reclaiming the bucolic summer retreat from the horrors of a 2011 attack by a right-wing extremist that killed 69 people.

lead_paragraph: This week, Gary Rivlin and Joe Domanick.

headline: Bad Decision by Senator Schumer
abstract: The New York senator is making a wrong-headed and irresponsible decision in declaring his opposition to the Iran nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: New York’s senior senator, Chuck Schumer, has cast his lot with Republican presidential candidates, other hardliners and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in declaring his opposition to the nuclear agreement that President Obama and five other world leaders negotiated with Iran. Given Mr. Schumer’s wrong-headed and irresponsible decision, Democrats may want to reconsider whether he is the best candidate to be their next leader in the Senate, a job he desperately wants.

abstract: Mr. Daniels, a creator of the melodrama, said there will be a spinoff that delves into the past of the flamboyant character Cookie.
lead_paragraph: “Empire” fans know Cookie Lyon is an outsize character. Now it appears that she’s become too big for one show to contain her.

lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

abstract: In this gently spiced vegetable dish, baby eggplant slices are first fried until golden, then braised with chickpeas, tomatoes and garam masala until soft, velvety and richly flavored.
lead_paragraph: In this gently spiced vegetable dish, baby eggplant slices are first fried until golden, then braised with chickpeas, tomatoes and garam masala until soft, velvety and richly flavored.

abstract: Frying is a little more work and mess, sure, but the crispy outside and custardy inside make for a worthwhile delicacy. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: To fry or not to fry?

headline: Trump Sells His Penthouse for $21.38 Million
abstract: Donald J. Trump sold a penthouse he owned at the Trump Park Avenue to the founder of the Fresh Market, a supermarket chain.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer and presidential hopeful, sold one of the two penthouses he owned at the Trump Park Avenue to the founder of the Fresh Market, a supermarket chain, for $21,383,250, a transaction that was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

abstract: Donald J. Trump sold his full-floor penthouse on the 24th floor of the Trump Park Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump sold his full-floor penthouse on the 24th floor of the Trump Park Avenue.

headline: China Philharmonic Orchestra to Play in Tehran
abstract: The orchestra will play two concerts, which have been in the works for some time, as part of a tour of the ancient Silk Road trade route.
lead_paragraph: As the world focuses on the accord to limit Iran’s nuclear capabilities that was reached last month, the China Philharmonic Orchestra, a major ensemble from one of the six nations that negotiated the deal, is planning to play two concerts in Tehran next week.

lead_paragraph: The Gregory Brothers present a musical mash-up video of the first Republican presidential debate of 2016.

abstract: The comedian’s recent successes have not prevented him from offering amused resignation about the state of the world.

headline: Psychologists Approve Ban on Role in National Security Interrogations
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Interrogations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The American Psychological Association voted overwhelmingly to approve a ban that would include noncoercive interrogations now conducted by the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The American Psychological Association on Friday overwhelmingly approved a new ban on any involvement by psychologists in national security interrogations conducted by the United States government, even noncoercive interrogations now conducted by the Obama administration.

headline: Colin Quinn Can Find the Dark Cloud in a Silver Lining
abstract: The comedian and actor doesn’t need any prompting when it comes to finding something to complain about.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Colin Quinn, it turns out, likes to bicker and complain. A lot.

headline: Capitalists, Arise: We Need to Deal With Income Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: If we don’t deal with income inequality, we’ll face intolerable taxes or social unrest.
lead_paragraph: I’M scared. The billionaire hedge funder Paul Tudor Jones is scared. My friend Ken Langone, a founder of the Home Depot, is scared. So are many other chief executives. Not of Al Qaeda, or the vicious Islamic State or some other evolving radical group from the Middle East, Africa or Asia. We are afraid where income inequality will lead.

headline: Britain, Consumed by Sex Scandals, Focuses on Inquiries
abstract: Since 2012, Britain has been consumed by scandals about sexual predations and child sexual abuse by elite politicians and entertainers dating back to the 1960s. Here are some of the most prominent among them.
lead_paragraph: Since 2012, Britain has been consumed by scandals about sexual predations and child sexual abuse by elite politicians and entertainers dating back to the 1960s. Here are some of the most prominent among them.

headline: In Britain, Edward Heath Case Intensifies Debate Over Validity of Sex Abuse Claims
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: After some notable previous revelations proved true, Britain is now taking each new case seriously and engaging in a systemic review.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Accusations of child sexual abuse against some prominent figures of Britain’s recent past have proved true. Allegations of similar wrongdoing by others, dating back decades, surface regularly now in the hothouse British press, as does talk of cover-ups by some of the nation’s most powerful institutions.

headline: ‘We Need Brain: Songify the G.O.P. Debate’
abstract: The Gregory Brothers present a musical mash-up video of the first Republican presidential debate of 2016.
lead_paragraph: As we hunkered down at Gregory Brothers headquarters in Brooklyn to songify the first debate of the 2016 election season, word broke that the Fox News team, inspired by their broadcast from Quicken Loans Arena, was considering using the Cleveland Cavaliers’ N.B.A. shot-clock buzzer to alert candidates that their allotted time was up. We were crestfallen when, at the first such transgression, we instead heard a polite “ding.” The Cavaliers’ claxon would have been perfect for a debate field so large it could have filled two basketball teams, qualifying in number if not by height.

headline: Shooting of Unarmed White Teenager, Zachary Hammond, Enters National Debate
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Mr. Hammond, 19, was shot by an officer in Seneca, S.C., but the episode initially escaped much of the national attention to race and police behavior.
lead_paragraph: Zachary Hammond, a white teenager, pulled up to a drive-through window last week at a Hardee’s restaurant in Seneca, S.C. A sting operation was underway, with police officers suspecting a possible drug deal.

headline: Another Secular Blogger in Bangladesh Is Killed
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Niladri Chaterjee, whose social media posts were often critical of Islam, became the fourth online activist for secularism in the country to be fatally attacked this year.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A group of men on Friday slit the throat of Niladri Chaterjee, an activist whose social media posts were often critical of Islam, in the fourth fatal attack this year against secular bloggers, the police said.

headline: Headstrong Filly Will Skip Undercard and Take on Colts in Hambletonian
abstract: Mission Brief is passing up the Hambetonian Oaks to try to become the first filly since 1996 to win Saturday’s main event, the most prestigious race for trotters.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Money was relatively low on the list of priorities when the owners of Mission Brief, a record-setting filly, decided to test her against males in the $1.2 million Hambletonian. They had loftier aims.

headline: Biweekly Mortgage Payment Problems
abstract: Promoted as a way to pay down a mortgage more quickly, some biweekly payment plans may promise borrowers more than they actually deliver.
lead_paragraph: Many lenders promote biweekly payment plans as a way to pay down mortgages more quickly. But the programs can sometimes be costly, and, as federal regulators recently found, may promise borrowers more than they actually deliver.

headline: Greta Gerwig, Illustrated
abstract: The actress sketches her responses to personal questions.
lead_paragraph: The actress sketches her responses to personal questions.

headline: Officials in Turf Fight Over Response to Legionnaires’ Outbreak in Bronx
abstract: New York officials jockeyed for position as the outbreak appeared to be ebbing.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx appeared to be ebbing on Friday, even as city and state officials jockeyed to show how they were responding to the airborne illness.

headline: Kerry Speaks on Human Rights in Vietnam
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech on Friday in Hanoi recognizing the 20th anniversary of the restoration of diplomatic ties between the United States and Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech on Friday in Hanoi recognizing the 20th anniversary of the restoration of diplomatic ties between the United States and Vietnam.

headline: Popcast: Drake’s Bully Pulpit
abstract: Jon Caramanica, Minya Oh and Rawiya Kameir discuss Drake and OVO Fest.
lead_paragraph: For the last five years, the annual OVO Fest in Toronto has been Drake’s hometown pulpit. Earlier this week, at its sixth annual installment, he turned it into a bully pulpit. After two weeks of squabbling with Meek Mill – over the ethics of ghostwriting, or maybe something deeper – Drake orchestrated an elaborate takedown that seemed to secure the victory that was already pretty plainly his.

abstract: Here’s where to eat, sleep and shop in San Francisco’s neighbor to the north.
lead_paragraph: Here’s where to eat, sleep and shop in San Francisco’s neighbor to the north.

headline: Eye Shape May Help Distinguish Predator From Prey
abstract: An analysis of 214 species suggests a link between pupil shape and an animal’s ecological niche as a hunter or an animal concerned about being hunted.
lead_paragraph: Why do the eyes of some animals, including goats, have horizontal-shaped pupils, while others, such as rattlesnakes and domestic cats, have vertical slits?

headline: 20 Years After Honeymoon, a Return Trip to Amsterdam
abstract: Returning to our honeymoon destination for a family vacation was a little less romantic, and certainly less trippy.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, I traveled with my husband, Wendell, on our honeymoon to Amsterdam, where we walked hand in hand along 17th-century canals, visited museums, ate an obscene amount of cheese, and then blew a big black hole into the middle of our trip by eating hash-laced space cakes.

headline: 6 Strategies to Extend Savings Without Working Longer
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Savings', 'Personal Finances', 'Mortgages', 'Social Security (US)', 'Home Equity Loans', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)']
abstract: Working into your mid-60s isn’t always an option, but planning ahead to maximize Social Security, reducing taxes and using a reverse mortgage can help stretch savings.
lead_paragraph: Karen Arndt, 60, has tinkered with several retirement calculators, and they all generate the same finger-wagging advice: Keep working, they seem to warn. You’re not even close.

headline: Female Visibility Matters
abstract: Narratives of police brutality often exclude women, but the scourge of racism doesn’t belong to a single gender.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I taught a social-justice workshop for African-American teenage girls from Chicago’s West Side. They all attend school in North Lawndale, one of the city’s most impoverished neighborhoods, and many of them have experienced hostile or violent interactions with the police. But because they are girls, not boys, they’ve told me, most people in their community do not take those interactions seriously.

headline: Republican Debate Draws 24 Million Viewers
abstract: The debate broke previous records for primary debates, and is the ninth-most viewed cable program ever, according to Nielsen. The top eight were college football games broadcast on ESPN.
lead_paragraph: Fox News’s telecast of Thursday night’s Republican debate drew a staggering 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated presidential primary debate ever and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.

headline: ‘I Am Cait’ Ratings Drop Nearly 50 Percent
abstract: After 3.9 million people watched the first episode of “I Am Cait,” the second episode drew 2.1 million.
lead_paragraph: Ratings for the second episode of “I Am Cait,” E!’s reality series about Caitlyn Jenner, fell almost by half from its July 26 premiere. The second show drew 2.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s live-plus-three-days data, which accounts for delayed viewing; 3.9 million total viewers watched the first episode of “I Am Cait” within three days of its first airing.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch to End On-Call Shifts for Workers
keywords: ['Working Hours', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The retailer had been one of 13 investigated by the New York State attorney general’s office over the practice of unpredictable scheduling and staffing.
lead_paragraph: Abercrombie & Fitch said on Friday that it would no longer require workers to be on call for shifts that may be canceled with little notice, after a regulator’s inquiry into the practice.

headline: Jets’ Dee Milliner Expected to Miss 6 to 8 Weeks With Wrist Injury
abstract: A week into training camp, four prominent Jets have already been hurt, the latest being Milliner, a cornerback who has been hampered by injuries throughout his brief N.F.L. career.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A week into training camp, the Jets have already endured injuries to four prominent players. The latest came Thursday, when cornerback Dee Milliner hurt a tendon in his right wrist.

headline: On the Campaign Trail With Hillary Clinton
abstract: Amy Chozick, a politics reporter, discusses pack reporting, campaign rallies and following Ms. Clinton over the years.
lead_paragraph: Amy Chozick, a politics reporter, has been covering Hillary Rodham Clinton for years. Some people have called her obsessed.

headline: Debate Was Highest-Rated Program Ever for Fox News
abstract: Fox News’s telecast of Thursday night’s Republican debate drew 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated program ever for Fox News and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.
lead_paragraph: Fox News’s telecast of Thursday night’s Republican debate drew 23.9 million viewers, making it the highest-rated program ever for Fox News and among the most-viewed events in cable TV history.

headline: Out on the Prairie
abstract: A group of six high school students from New York City won grants to visit the American Prairie Reserve in Montana, where they met bison and learned how to roast marshmallows.
lead_paragraph: A group of six high school students from New York City won grants to visit the American Prairie Reserve in Montana, where they met bison and learned how to roast marshmallows.

headline: New York High School Students Trade Skyscrapers for Big Sky
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: Six teenagers who had never been west of Chicago won grants to visit a reserve in Montana, where they met bison and learned how to roast marshmallows.
lead_paragraph: MALTA, Mont. — On a late July day 2,000 miles west of the Bronx, Vaughn Minott, a tall and soft-spoken aspiring biochemist who was born in Jamaica, bounced with five other New York teenagers in the bed of a 4X4 pickup through a Montana bison range as vast as the bright dome of sky above.

headline: Sparks Flew: Assessing the Republican Debate
abstract: Readers found it variously “a circus” and “illuminating.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Activist Hedge Fund Takes Significant Stake in American Express
abstract: Shares of the credit card company jumped after the news that ValueAct Capital Management, a prominent activist hedge fund, had made a major investment.
lead_paragraph: ValueAct Capital Management, a prominent activist hedge fund, has taken a significant stake in American Express, which is grappling with a number of recent challenges.

headline: Lessons of Yonkers From David Simon’s ‘Show Me a Hero’
abstract: A battle over affordable housing, race and class in Yonkers in the 1980s offers some lessons for battles being fought in New York City.
lead_paragraph: In the second hour of “Show Me a Hero,” David Simon’s long-awaited HBO miniseries about a crisis of race and class that erupted in Yonkers in the 1980s and reverberated for years, a crazed mob floods City Hall to denounce a plan, mandated by a federal court, to residentially desegregate the city. Yonkers is vertically divided by the Saw Mill River Parkway: The east side had traditionally been home to white middle-income earners, many of whom were Italian-American; the west side was poor, and black and Hispanic. In 1988, close to 98 percent of Yonkers’s public housing stock was located in the southwest section, which contained 81 percent of the city’s minority population.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Knife in the Ear Solved!
keywords: ['Carotid Arteries', 'Ears and Hearing', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Stroke', 'Weight Lifting']
abstract: Readers solve the mystery of a police officer with an earache and asymmetrical pupils.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 39-year-old man with an earache and asymmetrical pupils. More than 200 of you wrote in with your thoughts on his diagnosis, but only a handful got the two part answer completely right.

headline: Brazil’s Vice President Sees Influence Grow as Scandal Engulfs Dilma Rousseff
abstract: Vice President Michel Temer is likely to see his influence grow as President Dilma Rousseff faces calls for her impeachment over stunning claims of graft.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Few Brazilians gave much thought until recently to their vice president, a 74-year-old scholar of constitutional law with a bearing so formal that a political rival once compared him to “a butler from a horror movie.”

headline: 49ers Release Star Defender Aldon Smith, Adding to Their Recent Turmoil
abstract: The departure of the linebacker, who was arrested Thursday night and accused of drunken driving, hit-and-run and vandalism, continues an exodus since the team finished last season 8-8.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco 49ers released linebacker Aldon Smith on Friday after his arrest on accusations of hit and run, driving under the influence and vandalism, a move that continues the extraordinary foundering of an organization that reached the Super Bowl just three seasons ago.

headline: Factors Unrelated to Driving Can Affect Car Insurance

abstract: It’s not about real achievements.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith suggests that Reagan worship reflects a misunderstanding of how the economy works — that those who idolize Reagan believe in the Green Lantern theory of presidential power, that presidents can make stuff happen, in the economy and elsewhere, though sheer force of will.

keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The decision clears the way for Amarin to promote patient use of its drug Vascepa in a way that the F.D.A. declined to approve.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge said on Friday that the Food and Drug Administration could not prohibit the truthful promotion of a drug for unapproved uses because doing so would violate the protection of free speech.

keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Cotton', 'Drought', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Water', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: The crop, used in high-end clothing, has been hit hard by the drought, and farmers and officials are struggling to preserve the industry and the environment.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — Up and down the San Joaquin Valley, vast fields that once grew cotton lie fallow, remnants of a boom and bust fueled by a worldwide demand for premium T-shirts and linens.

headline: Life Sentence for James Holmes, Aurora Theater Gunman
keywords: ['Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The jury rejected the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage in a Colorado movie theater.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — In a decision that surprised many in this community, a jury sentenced James E. Holmes on Friday to life in prison with no chance of parole, rejecting the death penalty for the man who carried out a 2012 shooting rampage that killed 12 people in a Colorado movie theater.

headline: Court Says 4 Catholic Nonprofits Must Allow Workers Access to Contraception
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Freedom of Religion']

lead_paragraph: Four Roman Catholic nonprofits in New York must allow employees access to contraception, a federal appeals court panel ruled on Friday, reversing a decision by a lower court that allowed the organizations to get around a requirement in the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Linda Sarsour Is a Brooklyn Homegirl in a Hijab
abstract: Mixing street smarts, activism and her Muslim identity, Linda Sarsour has become a political force and is setting her sights on New York’s City Council.
lead_paragraph: Behind schedule as usual, Linda Sarsour rushed into the Times Square office of the civil rights group the Gathering for Justice last month, 40 minutes late for a meeting with its founder, Harry Belafonte. On the way in from Brooklyn, the Uber driver she had hired made a wrong turn and wound up in New Jersey. Now, wearing her head scarf and hungry from fasting for Ramadan, Ms. Sarsour scurried into an auditorium packed with some of the city’s most prominent social-justice warriors.

headline: A Republican Broadside on Immigrants
abstract: Latinos of America, the Republican presidential campaign has nothing good to offer you on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Latinos of America, there you have it. The Republican presidential campaign has nothing good to offer you on immigration.

headline: Jon Stewart, Patron Saint of Liberal Smugness
abstract: The beloved “Daily Show” host failed to help his viewers better understand conservatives — and themselves.
lead_paragraph: IT shows how gifted Jon Stewart is that his best moment happened on someone else’s show. He appeared in 2004 on “Crossfire,” a CNN yelling program, and asked the hosts to take seriously their responsibility to public understanding by having useful conversations instead of shouting matches.

headline: What I Love | John Miller

lead_paragraph: John Miller, a bass player who assembles musicians for theater productions, lives with his wife, Constance Barron, on the Upper West Side.

headline: For ‘Public Morals,’ Edward Burns Exhumes the ’60s From Manhattan Streets
abstract: Shot entirely in New York, the series, which begins on TNT on Aug. 25, is a cop-and-gangster tale set in the early 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Tourists walking in New York look up at the skyscrapers and blinding billboards. Locals look down to avoid stepping in gum or whatever. Edward Burns lately has been looking here, there and everywhere when he strolls the city: at stoops, windows, cornices, railings. He has been looking for the 1960s.

headline: The Best Paternity Leave Policies
abstract: Here’s our working list of the United States employers that offer at least 10 weeks of paid parental leave to new fathers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our working list of the United States employers that offer at least 10 weeks of paid parental leave to new fathers.

headline: Bringing Paternity Leave Into the Mainstream
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves', 'Parenting', 'Men and Boys', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Paid paternity leave offers broad benefits, but it won’t become common until prominent men use it and don’t pay a penalty for doing so.
lead_paragraph: This week, two companies joined in an unfolding race to provide ever more generous paid parental leave. Netflix said it planned to offer unlimited leave in the first year after a child’s arrival to many (though not all) of its employees, while Microsoft said it would substantially increase the paid leave that it will provide.

headline: A Musician on the Upper West Side
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: John Miller, a bass player, an actor and an orchestra assembler, lives in Manhattan with his wife, Constance Barron.
lead_paragraph: “I think every home should have an upright bass,” said John Miller, walking into his music room and nodding at the instrument in the corner. “It adds a certain je ne sais quoi. The shape of the bass, the contours, the gestalt of the bass only adds to a room.”

abstract: Bernie Sanders, after a phone call from the president, said he would support the nuclear deal with Iran on Friday, a day after another Jewish Democrat in the Senate, Chuck Schumer, said he would oppose it,
lead_paragraph: A day after Senator Chuck Schumer of New York announced his decision to vote against President Obama’s deal to curtail Iran’s nuclear program, he and the president each placed a call to Bernie Sanders.
