headline: Mostly Mozart’s Big Tent Embraces George Benjamin, Dai Fujikura and More
abstract: The Mostly Mozart festival this week features George Benjamin’s opera “Written on Skin” as well as performances of Bach, Beethoven and Mendelssohn.
lead_paragraph: The big news this week at Mostly Mozart is George Benjamin’s opera “Written on Skin,” to be performed Tuesday Thursday and Saturday. But there’s also plenty of interest elsewhere at the festival.

headline: Ebola Survivors Face Lingering Pain, Fatigue and Depression
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Joints (Body Part)', 'Blindness', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: About half the survivors seem to have chronic joint pain that is often severe enough to prevent them from working, an expert said.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola outbreak that started more than a year ago seems to be waning at last. But now, West Africa faces another difficulty: More than 13,000 people survived the virus, and many have lingering health problems, psychological troubles like depression and post-traumatic stress disorder, and worries about returning to work to feed themselves and what is left of their families.

headline: Drive East Festival Spins to a Bigger Stage at La MaMa
abstract: The South Asian festival, with more than 20 programs of Indian music and dance, moves into La MaMa’s largest performing space.
lead_paragraph: This year Drive East, the South Asian performing arts festival, has grown up or, rather, into La MaMa’s largest space, the Ellen Stewart Theater, where it will host more than 20 programs of Indian music and dance. Presented by the organization Navatman, performances include Archana Joglekar, an esteemed dancer and actress who specializes in Kathak, and Ashwini Ramaswamy, of Ragmala Dance Company, in a Bharatanatyam solo featuring music by an all-female orchestra.

headline: German TV Anchor Denounces Online Hate
abstract: In a commentary broadcast on public television in Germany, Anja Reschke, a journalist, blamed a recent spate of “hateful Internet tirades” for inciting real-world violence against foreigners.
lead_paragraph: In a commentary broadcast on public television in Germany, Anja Reschke, a journalist, blamed a recent spate of “hateful Internet tirades” for inciting real-world violence against foreigners.

headline: Van Halen and Mötley Crüe, Stylists of Hair Metal, Play Area Shows
abstract: The bands, on separate tours, epitomize two approaches to a genre.
lead_paragraph: Here was one thrilling route to whiplash in the 1980s: Mötley Crüe, “Too Fast for Love” (1981); Van Halen, “Diver Down” (1982); Mötley Crüe, “Shout at the Devil” (1983); Van Halen, “1984” (1984); Mötley Crüe, “Theatre of Pain” (1985); Van Halen, “5150” (1986); Mötley Crüe, “Girls, Girls, Girls” (1987); Van Halen, “OU812” (1988); Mötley Crüe, “Dr. Feelgood” (1989). It was a rich decade for headbanger decadence, toggling between Mötley Crüe’s devil-may-care Dionysian pop-metal and Van Halen’s howling blue-collar arena aerobics — competing approaches, both demanding copious amounts of hair spray.

headline: At Sea With Joseph Conrad
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Books and Literature', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: Learning about life, from the age of the great sailing ships.
lead_paragraph: THE tall ship Corwith Cramer stumbled into the Celtic Sea, engine roaring, 7,500 square feet of sail furled up mute. Its two masts ticked against the horizon like a metronome set to allegro. I joined a row of pallid sailors crouched at the leeward rail. Foam-lathered swell swung for my face, then reeled abruptly away. By the third time I threw up over the side, the “wine-dark sea” of Homer’s poetry just looked like the basin of a billion vomits.

headline: In ‘Shared Dining,’ a Table of Heroines at the Brooklyn Museum
abstract: The exhibition features table settings honoring people who have inspired Women of York, a collective of inmates at a Connecticut prison.
lead_paragraph: “The Dinner Party,” Judy Chicago’s sumptuous, vulva-themed table with places for 39 historical female figures (Susan B. Anthony to Mary Wollstonecraft), has been permanently set at the Brooklyn Museum since 2007. Through Sept. 13, it will be joined in the museum by another women’s table, inspired by Ms. Chicago’s but made under far different circumstances.

headline: On ‘Kevin From Work,’ an Office Romance Built for One
abstract: The new ABC Family sitcom, which has its premiere on Wednesday night, features Noah Reid as a lovelorn worker and Paige Spara as the object of his unspoken affection.
lead_paragraph: Kevin (Noah Reid), an earnest young office worker, finally gets to quit the worst job in history. Every bit of it stinks, except for the colleague with whom he has shared a cubicle wall for three years: Audrey (Paige Spara), perpetually backlit, her hair tousled by a magical breeze and the wings of the animated bluebirds that suddenly appear every time she is near. And like them, Kevin longs to be close to her. If only she didn’t have a lunk of a boyfriend — which is why Kevin has banished himself and his shredded heart to Italy, but not before pouring his passion into a love letter and mailing it. After all, he’s never going to see her again.

headline: T City Guides: Milan
abstract: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.
lead_paragraph: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

headline: ‘The Three Musketeers,’ the Richard Lester Treatment
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center screens the action-adventure movies that star Michael York, Oliver Reed, Faye Dunaway and Charlton Heston.
lead_paragraph: Countless directors have taken on Alexandre Dumas’s “The Three Musketeers,” but none have matched Richard Lester’s adaptation, so rambunctious it took “The Three Musketeers” (1973) and “The Four Musketeers” (1974) to contain it. The Film Society at Lincoln Center screens both Sunday and Tuesday. (Also on Sunday: Mr. Lester’s “The Return of the Musketeers,” from 1989.) The novel’s action and humor play to Mr. Lester’s gifts for the same, and working from George Macdonald Fraser’s script, the director attracted an unsurpassable cast, including Faye Dunaway as the lethal Milady de Winter; Christopher Lee as an eyepatched Rochefort; Raquel Welch as Constance; Michael York as D’Artagnan; Oliver Reed as Athos; and a peerless Charlton Heston as Cardinal Richelieu.

headline: How Mitchell J. Silver, New York City Parks Commissioner, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Silver works out at the gym, takes his camera to various parks to survey how the city’s public spaces are being used, and spends time with his family and on social media.
lead_paragraph: A lot of New Yorkers spend their weekends frolicking in the city’s 1,700 parks, but Mitchell J. Silver takes his visits more seriously than most. As the New York City parks commissioner, Mr. Silver picks a different borough every Sunday, packs his beloved camera and sets off to observe and document how a select few parks are being used and how they could be improved. A born-and-bred New Yorker, the 55-year-old urban planner recently returned to the city after serving for nearly a decade in North Carolina as the planning director for its capital city, Raleigh. Mr. Silver lives with his wife, Mary, 48, an administrator for the nonprofit Brooklyn Community Services, and his daughter, Rachel, 17, in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: New York Review of Books Fills a Niche by Reviving Forgotten Works
abstract: Founded in 1999, the publishing arm of The New York Review of Books has reissued everything from ancient Chinese poems to a never-released Chekhov story collection to the literary sleeper “Stoner.”
lead_paragraph: In 1882, the writer Anton Chekhov, just 22 and beginning his literary career, submitted a dozen short stories to Czar Alexander III’s censors, who discerned a subversive intent and promptly forbade publication of the collection, called “The Prank.” The satirical tales then languished in official archives for more than 130 years — until last week, when they were finally published, in English, by New York Review Books.

headline: Hillary Clinton Has Her Own Celebrity Moment After Debate
abstract: A photo of Mrs. Clinton with her reality star friends at a California fund-raiser appeared on Twitter just as the Republicans ended their debate.
lead_paragraph: Just as one reality television star upended the first debate of the Republican presidential race in Cleveland, another posed for a selfie with Hillary Rodham Clinton in Los Angeles.

headline: Frances Oldham Kelsey, Who Saved U.S. Babies From Thalidomide, Dies at 101
abstract: Dr. Kelsey became a 20th-century American heroine for sparing the United States from widespread birth deformities, and for inspiring laws that made drugs safer.
lead_paragraph: The sedative was Kevadon, and the application to market it in America reached the new medical officer at the Food and Drug Administration in September 1960. The drug had already been sold to pregnant women in Europe for morning sickness, and the application seemed routine, ready for the rubber stamp.

headline: Revenue Down Slightly at Sotheby’s, a House in Transition
abstract: The auction house attributed the diminished results to the timing of an art auction in London and a loss on a big purchase early in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s, the upscale auction house that appointed a new chief executive in March, reported weaker results on Friday than analysts had expected.

headline: The Great Victorian Weather Wars
abstract: What we think of as a modern controversy actually began in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: THE history of today’s climate change debate may have begun on Feb. 7, 1861. That day, an Irish physicist named John Tyndall, a professor of natural philosophy, delivered the annual Bakerian Lecture to the Royal Society in London.

headline: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Parasites
abstract: Watching them grow.
lead_paragraph: One of the pleasures I wasn’t expecting back when I discovered, to my surprise, that I liked a lot of indie music was that of following the progress of favorite bands. In general, when I become aware of them — often, I have to say, via Bob Boilen’s Tiny Desk concerts — they already have a following but are still playing to small venues and haven’t fully worked out their persona. Over time, however, they visibly develop.

headline: Common Yellowthroat Warbler: A Bandit in the Bramble
abstract: The male warbler sports a black, broad bandit’s mask, and male and female may be the most beautiful birds no one knows.
lead_paragraph: Though tiny, the common yellowthroat warbler is no church mouse. Unlike many of their beautiful warbler relatives, these birds shun the treetops for a life amid the tangled brambles and vines of wetland edges and dense thickets. Highly inquisitive — even aggressive while protecting a breeding territory — the birds are animated subjects for anyone with even a passing interest in bird-watching. A lengthy view of the three- to four-inch warbler is measured in seconds.

headline: The Hole in the Middle of the Jobs Report
abstract: Job growth without pay raises is a discouraging sign of slack in the job market.
lead_paragraph: The jobs report for July, released on Friday, showed steady if unspectacular job growth. The economy created 215,000 jobs, in line with average job creation so far this year.

headline: Mussolini Slept Here: Unearthing a Roman Villa’s Uneasy Past
abstract: At the Villa Torlonia in Rome, visitors can see Mussolini’s bunker, part of a compound whose restoration has exposed centuries of complex history.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Deep beneath the historic Villa Torlonia, where Benito Mussolini lived for nearly two decades, a wine cellar repurposed in 1941 as a bunker to protect the Fascist leader was recently opened to the public. Even in a city stratified with centuries of history, where archaeologists are digging up the remains of an ancient empire, the damp underground space is a telling sign of how deeply Italy’s relatively recent past can stay buried.

headline: The Clash of New York’s Irish and Italians, and the City’s First Black Firefighter
abstract: A book explores how the Irish and Italians assimilated from separate tracks and on occasion inevitably collided. Another book profiles Wesley Williams, who enlisted with the Fire Department in 1919.
lead_paragraph: “Among the most overlooked racial problems in the country,” the columnist Jimmy Breslin wrote in 1970, “is the division between Irish and Italians.”

abstract: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took us from Rand Paul’s campaign headquarters to the cockpit of a Boeing 747.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took us from Rand Paul’s campaign headquarters to the cockpit of a Boeing 747.

keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: After the shouting stopped and the spin died down, the candidates seemed to be much where they were before.
lead_paragraph: Thursday night’s Republican primary debate was watched by a record-shattering 24 million people, and some pundits lauded it as the “best, classiest debate ever.” But for all the fireworks, nothing seems to have changed.

headline: Review: Santa Fe Opera Offers ‘The Daughter of the Regiment,’ ‘Rigoletto’ and ‘Salome’
abstract: The Santa Fe Opera’s summer festival presents works by Donizetti, Verdi and Strauss, with varying results.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — The appeal of the Santa Fe Opera, with its history of presenting the most distinguished American summer festival of its kind, is obvious. Taking in the mountain vistas from the terraces before performances may alone be worth the price of admission, though perhaps not at a top rate of $300 on weekends.

headline: The Bobbed-Hair Bandit of Brooklyn
abstract: In 1924, New York was captivated by the story of two robbers, including a 20-year-old woman named Celia Cooney, who committed 10 armed robberies before they were caught and imprisoned.
lead_paragraph: Q. My stepdaughter, a hairdresser who is interested in old styles, was telling me about a young woman in the 1920s known as the Bobbed Hair Bandit. Can you tell me more?

headline: Photographs of Train Riders’ Idle Hands, on Way to Work
abstract: For a project called “Strangers in Common,” Alvaro Keding has discreetly captured images of New Yorkers on their commutes.
lead_paragraph: For a project called “Strangers in Common,” Alvaro Keding has discreetly captured images of New Yorkers on their commutes.

headline: A Photographer Puts Subway Riders’ Idle Hands to Work
abstract: For a project called “Strangers in Common,” the photographer Alvaro Keding has discreetly captured images of New Yorkers on their commutes.
lead_paragraph: A young man’s puffy coat on an overstuffed No. 4 train. The slick semi-oasis of an empty seat. The distressing warm patch of a vertical pole — which fellow traveler made it so, and what is his recent medical history? — tethering riders to their transit fate.

headline: Falling All Over Trump
abstract: Only the most attention-hungry candidates show up in the post-debate spin room, which explains why Donald Trump was there.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment at the Republican debate in Cleveland on Thursday night — actually, there were several moments, but this one in particular lingered, and lingers, as an illuminating episode. You’ll never guess who was in the middle of it: starts with T and ends with “rump.”

headline: Review: In ‘Pimm’s Mission,’ Seeking Clues to a Deadly Blast
abstract: Christopher Stetson Boal’s drama, at the 59E59 Theaters, toggles between an F.B.I. interrogation and flashbacks of a friendship.
lead_paragraph: “Pimm’s Mission” takes place on a Sunday afternoon in an empty bar across the street from the Manhattan headquarters of a Big Pharma company, Zincorp, where an explosion has just killed 15 people. F.B.I. agents are questioning Robert Pimm, a Brit who was outside the building when the blast went off, and is nursing a head injury.

headline: Colorado: Heavy Metals Spill Into River
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Mines and Mining', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Gold']
abstract: E.P.A. and contractor crews accidentally unleashed lead and arsenic from a Colorado mine into the Animas River.
lead_paragraph: Environmental officials are working to clean up one million gallons of wastewater containing heavy metals that spilled from an abandoned mine, turning an adjoining river a mustard yellow. The Environmental Protection Agency caused the spill on Wednesday while it was investigating a leak at the Gold King Mine. The wastewater flowed into Cement Creek, a tributary of the Animas River in southwestern Colorado, and snaked through the river toward New Mexico. E.P.A. officials said the wastewater included lead and arsenic, but said it was too early to know whether there was a health risk. The river was closed for recreational and other uses, but officials said water sources should be safe. “The orange color is alarming to people, but that is not an indication in any way of a health risk,” said Joan Card, an official with the E.P.A. Testing continues, she said.

headline: Vice Media Staff Latest to Choose Unionizing
abstract: The writers will join Writers Guild of America, East, the union that the websites Gawker and Salon recently chose for their unionization efforts.
lead_paragraph: Some staff members at Vice Media have voted to unionize, according to two people familiar with the matter, joining other digital media outlets that have recently moved to organize.

headline: Prince Plans to Make New Album a Tidal Exclusive
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Prince announced on Friday that he had signed an exclusive deal with the music-streaming service Tidal to release his new album, HITNRUN.
lead_paragraph: Prince announced on Friday that he had signed an exclusive deal with the music-streaming service Tidal to release his new album, HITNRUN. A longtime advocate for artists’ rights, Prince recently began removing his music from most streaming services. But he has left his music on Tidal, the subscription service owned by Jay Z and more than a dozen other artists (Prince is not thought to be among them). Last month, Prince released a new single, “Stare,” on Spotify, another streaming service.

headline: Her Son Was Safe Behind Bars, but Then He Came Home
abstract: Rosalyn Jackson’s son, Donnell Smith, 25, was gunned down near their Brooklyn apartment. He was released from prison less than five months ago.

headline: Judge Rules New York Teacher Exam Did Not Discriminate Against Minorities
abstract: Even though minorities tended to score poorly on the test, the exam evaluated the skills necessary to do the job, a federal judge said.

headline: Brazilian Implicated in FIFA Case Remains Free, Unlike Many Others

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Gleydson Carvalho’s radio program was on the air in the provincial beach city of Camocim when two gunmen burst into his studio. During a musical interval, they subdued the receptionist and told a technician to stay quiet. Then they did their work, unloading three rounds and killing Mr. Carvalho, a journalist known for crusading against political corruption.

headline: Remembering Hiroshima, and How It Changed the World

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: THE BATTLE OF THE FIVE ARMIES (2014) In Peter Jackson’s conclusion to the tale of Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman, above), the hobbit and his companions become mired in a war that threatens to destroy Middle-earth. Ian McKellen returns as Gandalf, who finds himself at the heart of the story after his imprisonment; Richard Armitage is Thorin Oakenshield, the headstrong leader with a lust for treasure; Evangeline Lilly is the elf Tauriel, who pursues a forbidden love; and Benedict Cumberbatch lends his voice to the dragon Smaug. “What this adaptation of ‘The Hobbit’ can’t avoid by its final installment is its predictability and hollow foundations,” Nicolas Rapold wrote in The New York Times. “It’s been said before, but Mr. Jackson himself is still haunted by the past.” He added: “It’s especially a shame since Mr. Jackson’s original knack for world building (not to mention the sense of humor in his early films) is often missing in the ever-proliferating superhero-franchise worlds that his own vastly successful endeavors no doubt helped encourage. Bilbo may fully learn a sense of friendship and duty, and have quite a story to tell, but somewhere along the way, Mr. Jackson loses much of the magic.”

abstract: The two franchises are experiencing a rebirth, with the Cubs holding the best road record in the National League and the Mets holding the second-best home record.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It was a let’s-play-two jewel of an evening at Wrigley Field, the shadows of summer long and sharp as the Cubs and the Giants gathered for a showdown.

headline: Andrew Zirm: An Astrophysicist With a Down-to-Earth Calling
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Andrew Zirm, 41, is a data scientist at Greenhouse Software, which sells a tool that allows companies to interview and analyze job applicants.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Zirm, 41, is a data scientist at Greenhouse Software in New York.

headline: Regulators Should Develop Rules to Protect Cars From Hackers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: With cars becoming computers on wheels, automakers need to adopt strong software technology systems.
lead_paragraph: The recent revelation that hackers have found ways to remotely take control of cars made by Fiat Chrysler and Tesla is alarming. This is a danger that most drivers had not even imagined. And it comes on the heels of the recalls of millions of cars for dangerous defects.

headline: Exposing Abuse on the Factory Farm
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Livestock', 'Factory Farming', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Law and Legislation', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: A federal judge rightly struck down Idaho’s “ag-gag” law for violating the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: While most Americans enjoy eating meat, it is hard to stomach the often sadistic treatment of factory-farmed cows, pigs and chickens.

headline: Is India Selling Out Its Tigers?
abstract: The Modi government is diluting environmental protections.

headline: Africa’s Scramble for Europe
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Population']
abstract: The Continent’s immigration-driven divisions are likely to worsen as its population stagnates and Africa’s explodes.
lead_paragraph: THIS summer, a striking, often tragic story has been playing itself out on the outskirts of Calais in France, at the entrance to the tunnel that connects the European mainland to Great Britain. Thousands of migrants, African and Middle Eastern, have been trying to sneak onto the trucks and trains that traverse the tunnel, cutting through wire fences and evading the police along the way. Ten have died, but enough have succeeded for many more to keep trying, while politicians on both sides of the Channel point fingers and a refugee camp outside Calais remains swollen with would-be subjects of Elizabeth II.

headline: Congress and Obama Are Too Timid on Marijuana Reform
keywords: ['Editorials', 'States (US)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Marijuana']
abstract: While the states move ahead on legalization, Washington drags its feet and complicates everyone’s lives pointlessly.
lead_paragraph: Even as support for ending marijuana prohibition is building around the country, Congress and the Obama administration remain far too timid about the need for change.

headline: Suicide on Campus
abstract: Responses to an Education Life article about pressure on students and the rising rate of suicide on college campuses.
lead_paragraph: Responses to an Education Life article about pressure on students and the rising rate of suicide on college campuses.

headline: Trump the Disrupter
abstract: Donald Trump is the gleefully offensive showman, even as a candidate.
lead_paragraph: Washington — I’VE been hesitant to start writing about Donald Trump.

headline: U.S.A., Land of Limitations?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'Poverty', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The biggest factor for success isn’t hard work but how our lives started.
lead_paragraph: YAMHILL, Ore. — We like to boast of America as the “land of opportunity,” and historically there is truth to that.

headline: A Prudent College Path
abstract: There’s a way to combine an intimate academic environment with a state school’s sweep and socioeconomic diversity. More students should consider it.
lead_paragraph: EVERY year the frenzy to get into highly selective colleges seems to intensify, and every year the news media finds and fawns over the rare students offered admission to all eight Ivy League schools. This year Ronald Nelson, from the Memphis area, was one of those who sopped up that adulation.

headline: Do the Amazon’s Last Isolated Tribes Have a Future?
abstract: Development can’t be halted, but it can happen humanely and intelligently.
lead_paragraph: HIS name is Shuri, but everyone calls him Epa, which means father in the indigenous Pano language family. His wizened face and bare, gnomish feet are familiar to the villagers who live along the Curanja River, which flows through some of the densest rain forest of Peru’s vast Amazon region.

headline: A Cheer and a Half for Cheap Commodities
keywords: ['Futures and Options Trading', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Commodities']
abstract: Consumers may welcome lower prices of products like gasoline, but the decline in global commodity markets could be a sign of trouble ahead.
lead_paragraph: Commodities markets have taken a beating this summer. Oil, coal, coffee, soybeans, copper, iron and nearly every other commodity has fallen sharply in price, upending currency markets and inflicting pain in large parts of the world economy.

headline: Afghan Forces Display Effectiveness in Fending Off Attacks
abstract: Officials noted that in none of the three bombings on Friday, scattered across Kabul, did the insurgents manage to breach their targets’ inner defenses.
lead_paragraph: Officials noted that in none of the three bombings on Friday, scattered across Kabul, did the insurgents manage to breach their targets’ inner defenses.

headline: What Do the Poor Need? Try Asking Them
abstract: A Houston anti-poverty program tries something radical: Ask people what they want, then give it to them.
lead_paragraph: FOR decades, policy makers have treated poverty as a sign of helplessness and ineptitude. The worse off the neighborhood — the higher the rate of poverty, crime, and juvenile delinquency — the less influence it would have over its future. Social service agencies conducted “needs assessments” rather than asking residents what would strengthen their community. Government agencies or private entrepreneurs then delivered brick-and-mortar solutions — a new school, medical clinic or housing.

headline: Congolese See No End to President’s Final Term
abstract: President Joseph Kabila is carving the country’s 11 provinces into 26, which many Congolese see as a ploy to delay the coming presidential election and allow Mr. Kabila to “slide” into a third term.
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — To take the political pulse of this sprawling, mineral-rich country, head to the busiest stretch of Lumumba Boulevard, one of the capital’s main roads. On weekdays, a large crowd gathers here to peer at the newspapers posted on an eight-foot-high wall and loudly trade opinions on the news of the day.

headline: Giants Can’t Give Big Hits for Now, and That Hurts, Some Players Say
abstract: Several players said they missed aspects of the old gladiator-style training camps because modern restrictions prevented them from honing their blocking and tackling techniques.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In 2011, a new N.F.L. labor agreement did away with a staple of summer pro football workouts since the 1950s. Gone was the punishing two-a-day practice regimen.

headline: What Selfie Sticks Really Tell Us About Ourselves
abstract: The insecurities of those addicted to getting “likes” on their selfies can only rise as facial recognition technologies improve.
lead_paragraph: CREMATED remains, xylophones and lawn chairs are not allowed in the Magic Kingdom, and now selfie sticks aren’t either. Disneyland banned the so-called narcisticks this summer following similar prohibitions at the Roman Colosseum, Palace of Versailles and Sydney Opera House. The cited reason was public safety concerns as well as basic propriety.

headline: Margrethe Vestager
abstract: The European commissioner for competition on sharing a book with her daughter, watching James Bond movies and knitting an elephant with a message.
lead_paragraph: Margrethe Vestager is a Danish politician who last year was appointed the European Union’s commissioner for competition and promptly took to task several powerful interests including Google, Russia’s gas behemoth Gazprom and European Union countries’ state-owned utilities.

headline: Key Events in the Hillary Clinton Email Controversy
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's email account has become a significant early chapter in her presidential run, and a new stroke in the portrait of the Democrats' leading candidate.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton's email account has become a significant early chapter in her presidential run, and a new stroke in the portrait of the Democrats' leading candidate.

headline: Hillary Clinton Emails Take Long Path to Controversy
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: The former secretary of state’s email account has become a significant early chapter in her run for the presidency and a new element of her evolving portrait.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Earlier this summer, the inspector general of the nation’s intelligence agencies contacted the longtime lawyer for Hillary and Bill Clinton with a pointed question. Classified information had been found in a small sample of 30,000 messages from the former secretary of state’s private email account. The inspector general, I. Charles McCullough III, wanted to know from the lawyer, David E. Kendall, where copies of the message collection might still be stored.

headline: Caregiving: A Burden So Heavy, Until It’s Gone
abstract: “Freedom,” it turns out, is just another word for no one left to lose.
lead_paragraph: “Marry an orphan,” my mother used to say, “and you can always come home for Christmas.” What she should have said was: “Marry an orphan, or you’ll have four parents to nurse through every torment life doles out on the long, long path to the grave.”

headline: Kazan, a Russian Cultural Hub, Finds It’s Good at Sports
abstract: Kazan has spent the decade since its 2005 millennium celebration reinventing itself as a Russian athletics capital, becoming a top host of world and European tournaments.
lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — In his first trip abroad, Michael Weiss visited a place he had a hard time locating on a map. Was Kazan a sports destination or an exclamation popularized by the television character Gomer Pyle?

headline: Mother Is Charged With Murder After Infant’s Fall From a Window in Queens
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Babies and Infants', 'Falls']
abstract: Rashida Chowdhury, 21, is accused of throwing the 3-week-old baby out of a fourth-floor apartment, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The mother of a 3-week-old boy who died after plummeting from a fourth-floor window in Queens was charged on Saturday with intentionally killing her child.

headline: A Minor League Home Run King Without Major Fanfare
abstract: Mike Hessman, 37, who now sits alone atop the career home run list for the affiliated minor leagues, is thankful to have had brief chances in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Hessman entered professional baseball, as a 15th-round draft choice in 1996, he fixed his mind on reaching an annual statistical benchmark.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Australian Brothers Cherish Their Reunion at P.G.A. Championship
abstract: In the P.G.A. Championship, Matt Jones, who has three top-10 finishes on the tour this year, will be joined by Brett Jones, a club pro in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The last time that Matt and Brett Jones played a competitive round in the same field was nearly a decade ago at the Jacob’s Creek Open Championship in Adelaide, Australia, a regular stop on the PGA Tour of Australasia. The event was “co-sanctioned” by the Nationwide Tour in the United States, meaning that those who finished in the money had a chance to move up to the PGA Tour.

headline: Scientists’ Letter to Obama on Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Twenty-nine of the nation’s top scientists wrote to President Obama on Saturday in support of the deal, which calls for Iran to curb its nuclear program and allow inspections in return for an end to sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine of the nation’s top scientists wrote to President Obama on Saturday in support of the deal, which calls for Iran to curb its nuclear program and allow inspections in return for an end to sanctions.

headline: Iris DeMent Returns, Via Russia
abstract: A songwriter and singer of country and gospel music is back with a new album.
lead_paragraph: Iris DeMent, a songwriter and singer of country and gospel music, emerged in the 1990s. And if you listened a lot to the New York City radio station WFUV back then, you could hear her voice every day, plaintive and joyous, lonely and quite unforgettable, singing tunes that felt brand new and many generations old.

headline: Manuel Contreras, Chilean Spy Chief Under Pinochet, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Gen. Contreras, Chile’s intelligence chief during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, was serving 526 years of multiple prison terms for human rights violations.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Gen. Manuel Contreras, Chile’s intelligence chief during the military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, died on Friday in the military hospital in Santiago while serving 526 years of multiple prison terms for human rights violations. He was 86.

headline: Ditching Honky-Tonk for Chic
abstract: Baron’s Cove in Sag Harbor was once a family motel and is now an upscale resort and restaurant.
lead_paragraph: It’s a sign of the times: Baron’s Cove, for many years a mainstay among local family motels, reopened this spring as an upscale resort and restaurant. The old space had grown a little honky-tonk over the years, and the results of the upgrade — overseen by the hotelier, Curtis Bashaw, and his designer sister, Colleen Bashaw — are ravishing.

headline: With Seventh Straight Win, Blue Jays Creep Closer to Yankees
abstract: David Price had struggled against the Yankees, but his seven scoreless innings and a grand slam allowed Toronto to cut its deficit in the American League East to two and a half games.
lead_paragraph: Taped to David Price’s locker was a self-written message on yellow notebook paper, pronouncing in all capital letters, “If You Don’t Like It, Pitch Better,” with the last two words underlined three times for emphasis.

headline: Restaurant Review: Charritos in Weehawken Is a Family Affair
abstract: At Charritos in Weehawken, several aunts and the boss’s mother help make this spot ideal for enjoying Oaxacan specialties.
lead_paragraph: One ideal place to be this summer is the slender terrace overlooking Manhattan at Charritos, a restaurant in Weehawken specializing in the colorful dishes of Oaxaca, a region in southern Mexico. For those unfamiliar with Oaxacan cuisine, it is known for chocolate-infused moles, which Charritos does serve, and grasshoppers, which it does not.

headline: Amid an Inquiry, Patrick Kane Cancels Stanley Cup Events
abstract: Kane, a right wing with the Chicago Blackhawks, kept a low profile in Buffalo, his hometown, rather than celebrate publicly with the Stanley Cup, as he had in the past.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Under increasing scrutiny as the subject of a criminal investigation, Patrick Kane, one of the N.H.L.’s highest-profile players, kept a low profile here in his hometown Saturday rather than celebrate publicly with the Stanley Cup, as he had in the past.

headline: Hanoi Through a Parisian Lens
abstract: Good Elephant in Chester, C.T., is the result of its owners’ long-marinating idea to merge French and Vietnamese cuisine.
lead_paragraph: The vision for Everett and Linda Reid’s new restaurant began, like so many dreams, over a meal in Paris. But it was not a traditional French cafe that sparked the couple’s imagination, during that visit more than 20 years ago. Rather, it was the City of Light’s most famous Vietnamese eatery, Tan Dinh, still a fixture on the Seventh Arrondissement’s Rue de Verneuil.

headline: Everything for a Summer Picnic at Westchester County Markets
abstract: If you have the blanket, the bucket and the bottle opener, stores in Katonah, North Salem and Bedford Hills can supply the rest.
lead_paragraph: August, in my book, is picnic month. As summer and mosquitoes wane, a simple meal spread over a checkered cloth among tall grasses and Queen Anne’s lace reminds us that we are part of the natural order of things.

headline: A Duo, in Jazz and in Love
abstract: Carla Bley and Steve Swallow, Hudson Valley jazz musicians, keep at it after decades of making music and a life together.
lead_paragraph: By her own account, Carla Bley was operating outside her comfort zone when at a ceremony honoring her and three other new National Endowment for the Arts jazz masters in April, she was obliged to deliver an acceptance speech to a packed house at Lincoln Center.

headline: Douglas LeVien, New York Detective Who Infiltrated the Mafia, Dies at 68
abstract: An expert on organized crime, Detective LeVien was a 20-year veteran of the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Douglas A. LeVien Jr., a former undercover police detective who in 1972 infiltrated the meeting ground used by New York’s five Mafia families, a landmark operation that produced scores of convictions, died on July 30 while vacationing in Saratoga, N.Y. He was 68.

headline: Documentary Explores Struggle of New Jersey’s Ramapough Tribe
abstract: A film looks at the Native Americans of northern New Jersey and separates their real story from the myths that have defined them for generations of outsiders in the state.
lead_paragraph: Corey Bobker was an accomplished 30-something adult when he took his first drive into the Ramapo Mountains in 2010. But the 12-year-old version of him still had knots in his stomach.

headline: Cecil’s Kin?
abstract: What a tour group saw.
lead_paragraph: What a tour group saw.

headline: Review: ‘The Cottage’ in Northport Is a Saucy Farce
abstract: The play by Sandy Rustin, set in 1923 England and inspired by Noël Coward and perhaps Oscar Wilde, continues through Sept. 6 at the John W. Engeman Theater.
lead_paragraph: “The Cottage,” a saucy farce about infidelity set in 1923 England, was written — contrary to any expectations that description might conjure — very recently by Sandy Rustin, a young American playwright who lives in Maplewood, N.J. Compounding its lack of British pedigree, the play was first produced at the Astoria Performing Arts Center in 2013 before spawning regional productions in Colorado, Massachusetts and Arizona. In 2014, the Astoria production enjoyed another run in the borough where it had its world premiere, this time at Queens Theater in the Park.

headline: 299 Connecticut Museums and One Special Child
abstract: A man’s quest to visit hundreds of Connecticut’s 600 museums also became a primer of sorts on living and traveling with a special-needs child.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Wood arrived at the Ukrainian Museum and Library of Stamford on a recent Sunday afternoon, in his head were the number 299 and a sense of uncertainty.

headline: Help Wanted
abstract: Melanie Miller walks us through a job search.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE —If a HELP WANTED ad ran for test crossword-puzzle solvers, what do you think it might say?

headline: Benton Becker, Ford Aide, Dies at 77; Negotiated Nixon Pardon
abstract: Mr. Becker pushed for an acknowledgment of guilt from Richard M. Nixon and sought to keep records out of the hands of the disgraced president after his resignation.
lead_paragraph: Benton L. Becker, who as President Gerald R. Ford’s personal emissary negotiated the pardon of Richard M. Nixon in 1974 and preserved his White House papers and tapes from what Mr. Becker predicted would have otherwise been “a hell of a bonfire in San Clemente,” where Nixon lived, died on Aug. 2 in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 77.

headline: India Warns TV Stations Over Criticism of Hanging
keywords: ['Television', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'News and News Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Three networks were accused of violating rules by showing interviews that criticized the execution of Yakub Memon for the 1993 Mumbai bombings.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s government on Friday accused three television networks of violating broadcasting regulations by showing interviews that criticized the execution of Yakub Memon, hanged last month for bombings that killed 257 people in Mumbai in 1993.

headline: Did Roger Stone Jump, or Was He Pushed From Donald Trump’s Campaign?
abstract: Both Donald Trump and political strategist Roger Stone agree they have parted ways. What they don’t agree on is when and how they did it.
lead_paragraph: Both Donald J. Trump and political strategist Roger Stone agree they have parted ways. What they don’t agree on is when and how they did it.

headline: On the Defensive, the S.E.C. Quietly Pursues High-Profile Cases
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Insider Trading', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission continues to adapt its regulatory role, pushing ahead with insider trading cases and one involving cybersecurity.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s chief regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, appears to some to be in need of a makeover.

headline: Poor E.U. Migrants Test Limits of Swedish Tolerance
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Romani People', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Attacks are on the rise, as the arrival of newcomers from within the European Union itself adds to the pressures from a rising tide of refugees.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — After begging through the night outside bars and nightclubs, Gheorghe Rancu, a homeless migrant from Romania, was asleep one morning this summer in a Stockholm park when he woke with a start and felt a sharp pain on his face.

headline: Medicare, Reversing Itself, Will Pay More for an Expensive New Cancer Drug
abstract: The Obama administration has decided that Medicare will pay for one of the newest, most expensive cancer medications, Blincyto, which costs about $178,000 and treats an aggressive form of leukemia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has decided that Medicare will pay for one of the newest, most expensive cancer medications, which costs about $178,000 for a standard course of treatment.

headline: 70 Years After Nagasaki Bombing, Atomic Debate Yields Little Consensus
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: On the anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima, The Times asked readers to debate Truman’s decision. As the Japanese commemorate the Nagasaki anniversary, we review that debate.
lead_paragraph: Did the United States have to drop the bomb?

headline: Daughter Honors Seau Onstage at a Celebration Under a Cloud
abstract: Sydney Seau paid tribute to her father, Junior, in an onstage interview after the showing of a video, but the Hall of Fame did not address the circumstances of his death.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ohio — At a dinner and ceremony Thursday night as part of the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction weekend, Sydney Seau received a standing ovation after Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, presented her with a gift honoring her father, Junior, one of the game’s most celebrated linebackers.

headline: A Year On, Ferguson Killing Is Recalled
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Twelve months after the death of Michael Brown touched off a national protest movement, demonstrators have returned to the streets of Ferguson for a series of commemorations.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — As demonstrators shouted, “Hands up, don’t shoot,” and marched toward West Florissant Avenue, the scene here on Saturday morning looked in many ways like a flashback to the protests that followed the police killing of Michael Brown a year ago.

headline: Man Dies After Being Shocked With a Taser by a Hartford Police Officer
abstract: The Connecticut State Police are investigating the death of a 26-year-old man after a call reporting a medical disturbance.
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut State Police are investigating the death of a man who was shocked with a Taser by a Hartford police officer after a call for medical assistance.

headline: Final Hearing for Reporter Held in Iran Is Scheduled for Monday
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'News and News Media', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The trial of Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post correspondent held in Tehran for over a year, “may now finally be nearing its end,” The Post’s executive editor said.
lead_paragraph: The final hearing in Iran’s espionage trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent whose yearlong incarceration has helped worsen tensions with the United States, has been scheduled for Monday, the newspaper’s executive editor and Mr. Rezaian’s brother said Saturday.

headline: Marco Rubio: Won’t Comment on Everything Donald Trump Says
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio praised Megyn Kelly, the Fox News debate moderator, but said he was not going to comment on Mr. Trump’s latest remarks.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio praised Megyn Kelly, the Fox News debate moderator who has come under fire from Donald J. Trump, but said he was not going to comment on Mr. Trump’s latest remarks.

headline: Tom Coughlin Finds Little New in a Talk With Jason Pierre-Paul
abstract: Coughlin said Pierre-Paul, whose right index finger was amputated, did not indicate when he planned to rejoin the team, but it did not sound as if it would be soon.
lead_paragraph: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin had a telephone conversation Friday afternoon with Jason Pierre-Paul, the Giants’ defensive end who has stayed away from the team’s training camp after a serious fireworks accident on the Fourth of July weekend. Coughlin said Pierre-Paul, whose right index finger was amputated, did not indicate when he planned to rejoin the team, but it did not sound as if it would be soon.

headline: Jeb Bush Gets Applause at Conservative Forum
abstract: Jeb Bush may not have converted every skeptic at the RedState Gathering, but he persuaded more than a few to give him a second look.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jeb Bush, who has fought the perception of conservatives that he is not one of them, journeyed into the lion’s den on Saturday. While he may not have converted every skeptic at the RedState Gathering, a conclave of anti-establishment Republicans, he persuaded more than a few to give him a second look.

headline: Jefferson-Jackson Dinner Will Be Renamed
abstract: The Iowa Democratic Party is changing the name of the annual event because Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson owned slaves.
lead_paragraph: An Iowa Democratic Party panel voted on Saturday to change the name of the popular Jefferson-Jackson dinner, joining several state parties in distancing itself from the legacies of the two former slave-owning presidents for whom the dinner is named.

headline: Measuring the Legacy of Ferguson: Readers Respond
abstract: Reflections on the legacy of the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer last year in Ferguson, Mo., that set off protest movements and sparked a nationwide conversation about race.
lead_paragraph: Reflections on the legacy of the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer last year in Ferguson, Mo., that set off protest movements and sparked a nationwide conversation about race.

headline: Officials Expand Efforts to End Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said the outbreak in the South Bronx, which has infected 108 people since last month, appears to be tapering off.
lead_paragraph: New York City and state officials continued to step up efforts on Saturday to thwart the spread of Legionnaires’ disease, even as an outbreak of the airborne illness in the South Bronx appeared to be waning.

headline: An Excerpt From Sydney Seau’s Speech
abstract: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But she was not allowed to give the speech. Here’s an excerpt from Sydney’s speech.
lead_paragraph: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But she was not allowed to give the speech. Here’s an excerpt from Sydney’s speech.

headline: The Hall of Fame Speech You Didn’t Hear
abstract: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But the Hall didn’t allow her to speak at the ceremony. Here’s what Sydney would have said.
lead_paragraph: Before his suicide, Junior Seau told his daughter to speak on his behalf if he entered the Hall of Fame. But the Hall didn’t allow her to speak at the ceremony. Here’s what Sydney would have said.

headline: The Hall of Fame Speech Junior Seau’s Daughter Couldn’t Give
abstract: The Pro Football Hall of Fame would not allow Junior Seau’s daughter to give a speech at his induction ceremony. Recorded in her hotel room in Canton, Ohio, here’s what Sydney would have said.
lead_paragraph: In his 20-year N.F.L. career, Junior Seau established himself as one of the game’s greatest linebackers. He committed suicide in 2012 at age 43 and was subsequently found to have had a degenerative brain condition linked to repeated hits to the head. Before his death, Seau told his daughter Sydney that she should speak on his behalf if he made it into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. But the Hall, citing a five-year-old policy of not letting others give full speeches for deceased inductees, did not allow Sydney to deliver her speech.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Struggles as Rays End Mets’ 7-Game Winning Streak
abstract: Syndergaard, who in his previous nine starts was 4-1 with a 1.80 E.R.A., uncharacteristically stumbled as the Mets fell to the Rays at Tropicana Field.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Amid the clang of cowbells, Noah Syndergaard stalked off the mound, his face buried in his glove and hanging toward the ground.

headline: A Moscow of Dancing Feet, Under an Iron Fist
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Culture (Arts)']
abstract: The Russian capital is looking ever more like an elegant European capital, but its political life is marching steadily in the opposite direction.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s capital city has worn many outfits since the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: Answers Sought in Police Shooting of Unarmed Christian Taylor
abstract: The police in Arlington, Tex., asked the F.B.I. to help investigate the shooting death of an unarmed black college student, Christian Taylor, who was killed by a police trainee early Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: The police in Arlington, Tex., asked the F.B.I. to help investigate the shooting death of an unarmed black college student who was killed by a police trainee early Friday morning inside a car dealership.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sunday, August 9, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 9, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not the end of the world; she didn’t give away the crown jewels. But this is not how things are supposed to be done.”

headline: Nicole Gill and Robert Ottaway Jr.: Grandma Knows Best. Both of Them.
abstract: The couple met because of the friendship between two of their grandmothers, who are winter residents of Vero Beach, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Marie Gill, a daughter of Patricia Dunsmore Gill and Robert L. Gill of Jackson, Wyo., was married there Saturday to Robert Flinn Ottaway Jr., a son of Anne Galvin Scruggs of Cashiers, N.C., and Mr. Ottaway of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Carl Beavers, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Frances Middleton, Michael Fields
abstract: The bride and groom met at Dartmouth. The bride’s father is an owner of the Philadelphia Phillies.
lead_paragraph: Frances Baird Middleton, a daughter of Leigh P. Middleton and John S. Middleton of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married Saturday to Michael David Fields, a son of Barbara Y. Fields and Bryan J. Fields of Atlanta, at the Winterthur Museum, Garden & Library in Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Dr. Eugene Bay, a Presbyterian minister, officiated, with Rabbi Philip Kranz assisting. The bride will take her husband’s name.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: ‘I Love to Watch You Play’ but Not Every Game
abstract: When did watching every game become an unspoken part of the modern parental contract?
lead_paragraph: I couldn’t help but be a little relieved when the thunder rolled in. Baseball was canceled, one of five games scheduled in a nine-day span. The weekday games are precisely at dinnertime, and I have two other children and a husband with a commute.

headline: Similarities Aside, Bernie Sanders Isn’t Rerunning Howard Dean’s 2004 Race
abstract: Both Democrats from Vermont caught a populist wave, but there are crucial differences between the men and between their eras.
lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — It was a summer Friday night in Iowa, and a high school auditorium here was overflowing, as more than 1,000 people, holding signs and collecting names, spilled out into the lobby and onto the sidewalk. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont strolled onstage — tieless, his white hair askew, his shoulders stooped — and stopped at the sight in front of him.

headline: Teacher Shortages Spur a Nationwide Hiring Scramble (Credentials Optional)
abstract: Just a few years after the recession caused widespread layoffs for teachers, school districts now find themselves with numerous job vacancies and few qualified candidates to choose from.
lead_paragraph: ROHNERT PARK, Calif. — In a stark about-face from just a few years ago, school districts have gone from handing out pink slips to scrambling to hire teachers.

headline: Do You Have Change for a Bowie? The Advent of Artisanal Cash
abstract: Alternative local currencies, some depicting pop stars instead of politicians, may be the last hurrah for cash.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Though paper money here typically bears the visage of Queen Elizabeth, the Brixton district of the city last month released a new 5-pound note designed by Jeremy Deller, an artist who won the prestigious Turner Prize in 2004. It features a fuzzy, psychedelic image of an androgynous face surrounded by rainbow clouds and coruscating, swirling etchings.

headline: More Cohesive Australian Team Shows a Harder Edge
abstract: Wallabies Coach Michael Cheika cautioned that a single victory over New Zealand’s powerful All Blacks should not be blown out of proportion.
lead_paragraph: Any notion that Australia would not be a serious threat at the Rugby World Cup was dispelled as the Wallabies underlined their credentials with a 27-19 victory over New Zealand in Sydney on Saturday night.

headline: 1890: Power Struggle in Guatemala
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'War and Revolution']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Conspiracies break out in all quarters in 1890 as President Barillas is said to be overthrown.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Despatches to the HERALD from Guatemala say that conspiracies are breaking out in all quarters. Senor Sobrol, Minister of Foreign Relations, suspected of being a traitor, is confined in the penitentiary and the imprisonment of other prominent men is expected.

headline: ‘True Detective’ Season 2, Unexplained
abstract: Fans of the HBO television show “True Detective” attempt to explain what the second season of the series is about.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the HBO television show “True Detective” attempt to explain what the second season of the series is about.

headline: African-American Stage Stars to Join Audra McDonald in ‘Shuffle Along’
abstract: Brian Stokes Mitchell, Billy Porter, Brandon Victor Dixon and Joshua Henry — with eight Tony nominations (including two victories) among them — have signed on to join Ms. McDonald, a six-time Tony winner, in “Shuffle Along, Or, The Making of the Musical Sensation of 1921 and All That Followed.”
lead_paragraph: Four of the American theater’s leading African-American singer-actors will join Audra McDonald next spring in a musical that seeks to reintroduce one of the first all-black shows on Broadway.

headline: Lollapuzzoola 8: On a Saturday in August
abstract: Oliver Roeder reports from the Lollapuzzoola 8 crossword tournament in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Lollapuzzoola Alert! We are thrilled to have Oliver Roeder of FiveThirtyEight.com as our guest blogger covering Lollapuzzoola 8, the most fun you can have with a sharp pencil on a Saturday in August. Warning: If you are playing the Home version of the game, you might want to avert your eyes until you submit your answers. We have taken precautions, using power tools and advanced chemistry, not to spoil any of the answers, but you never know what could spill out of Oliver’s mouth. That’s how much fun he had.

headline: Premier Haider al-Abadi, Facing Protests, Proposes Iraqi Government Overhaul
abstract: Mr. Abadi’s proposals could be a turning point in the dysfunctional politics of Iraq that have persisted since the American invasion in 2003.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Facing widespread protests against government corruption and poor services, as well as a crucial call for change from the country’s top Shiite cleric, Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi proposed on Sunday to radically reshape the dysfunctional political system of Iraq that has been entrenched since the American-led invasion in 2003.

headline: Email Requesting Another Date for Taking Sergeant’s Exam
abstract: Police Officer Akema Thompson sent an email to the Department of Citywide Administrative Services requesting other options for taking the test because Oct. 19, 2013 was the same day as her due date.
lead_paragraph: Police Officer Akema Thompson sent an email to the Department of Citywide Administrative Services requesting other options for taking the test because Oct. 19, 2013 was the same day as her due date.

headline: Email Details Make-Up Exam Date Guidelines
abstract: An officer giving birth or recovering from childbirth on the exam date is not among the instances in which an individual can reschedule taking the sergeant’s exam.
lead_paragraph: An officer giving birth or recovering from childbirth on the exam date is not among the instances in which an individual can reschedule taking the sergeant’s exam.

headline: Pregnant Officer Denied Chance to Take Sergeant’s Exam Fights Back
abstract: Officer Akema Thompson was recovering from childbirth on the day of the exam, but officials said her request for a makeup test was “not approvable.” The city settled her discrimination case last month.
lead_paragraph: Police Officer Akema Thompson felt the energy in the air the moment she walked into the Manhattan precinct station. And as soon as she stepped into the women’s locker room, she knew why.

headline: Shots Are Fired as Anniversary Is Marked in Ferguson
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: A day of peaceful protest commemorating the killing of Michael Brown by a police officer one year ago ended in gunfire late Sunday. A St. Louis County police officer was involved in the shooting, the department said.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — A day of peaceful protest commemorating the killing of Michael Brown, an unarmed black 18-year-old, by a white police officer one year ago ended in gunfire late Sunday as multiple shots rang out on West Florissant Avenue, the commercial district hit by rioting last summer.

headline: ‘Hannibal’ Recap: Did He Who Made the Lamb Make Thee?
abstract: This episode repeatedly returns to the well of “The Tyger,” a poem that speaks of a predatory and ferocious beauty.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 10: “And the Woman Clothed in Sun”

headline: Knitting History (Trivial)
abstract: All hail Egbert.
lead_paragraph: Via Brad DeLong, a great history of socks. But somehow it misses the economic geography story, where there once was a great hosiery center in Cohoes, near Albany, thanks to one Egbert Egberts, who invented the first power knitting frame. In England the comparable complex was in Nottingham.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (Travel) AMERICA. THE BEAUTIFUL. Robert Redford narrates this exploration of some of the country’s most breathtaking landscapes in advance of the National Park Service’s centennial celebration in 2016. The journey begins in California, as the pilots Chris Bolfing and John Heiney, above, hang glide through Yosemite; the arborist Chad Brey climbs 200 feet into the branches in Redwoods National Park; and the marine biologist Alana Osaki dives into kelp that can grow 90 feet tall in the Channel Islands. At 7:30, the series moves to Utah, where the adventurers Faith Dickey and Andy Lewis slack-line in Mineral Canyon, and Heidi Redd herds cattle in Indian Creek Canyon.

headline: Donald Trump Remains Defiant on News Programs Amid G.O.P. Backlash
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In phone interviews with four Sunday programs, Donald J. Trump suggested that he had been singled out for attacks by the hosts of Thursday’s Republican presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: A defiant Donald J. Trump suggested on Sunday that he had been singled out for attacks by the hosts of last week’s widely watched Republican presidential debate and again threatened a third-party White House bid if he was not treated “reasonably fairly” by party leaders.

headline: 1965: Friction Between Singapore and Malaysia Intensifies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Some predicted that the federation would be torn apart in 1965.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The bitter friction between Singapore’s government and the predominantly Malay federal government intensified during recent weeks and led to predictions that the federation would be torn apart by racial and political bitterness. But no one expected it to happen so soon, with so little warning.

headline: 29 Are Killed in Afghanistan as Bombing Targets Militia
abstract: At least 29 people were killed and 19 others wounded in the bombing in the northern Afghan province of Kunduz, Afghan officials said Sunday.
lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — At least 29 people were killed and 19 others wounded in a suicide bombing targeting a militia in the northern province of Kunduz, Afghan officials said Sunday.

headline: A Hive of Activity Atop the Barclays Center
abstract: Three acres of sedum plants added to the roof of the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last month briefly attracted a swarm of bees.
lead_paragraph: “We have a bee,” Ashley Cotton said, in a we-have-liftoff voice.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Precision Castparts
abstract: The deal, which could be worth more than $30 billion, would be the largest takeover in Mr. Buffett’s five-decade investing career at Berkshire.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett has long spoken about his “elephant gun,” the huge pile of cash at Berkshire Hathaway that is reserved for big deals, and his itchy trigger finger.

headline: Man Charged After 8 Members of Texas Family Are Found Dead
abstract: The victims, including five children, were discovered Saturday after the arrest of a man later identified as David Conley, 49, who was booked on multiple counts of capital murder on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Eight members of a Texas family, including six children, were shot to death over the weekend and the mother’s former domestic partner was arrested and charged with the murders on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: Change in Militant Tactics Puts Tunisians on Edge
abstract: Recent attacks have provoked a security crackdown that has Tunisians wondering if they can fight terrorism without giving up hard-won freedoms.
lead_paragraph: MONASTIR, Tunisia — A dozen police officers, one with an assault rifle across his knees, guard the presidential mausoleum in this seaside resort, easily outnumbering the foreign visitors on a recent morning.

headline: ‘Rocky Horror’ at Lincoln Center, With Headphones
abstract: Viewing of the 40-year-old cult film “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” continues to evolve, with a “silent” screening in Damrosch Park.
lead_paragraph: It is a cinematic ritual that unconventional film fans have shared in for nearly 40 years, but it has probably never been presented quite so unconventionally.

headline: After Sydney Seau, Football Hall of Fame Policy Will Be Tested Again
abstract: By giving Sydney Seau an abbreviated forum to speak on behalf of her father, the Pro Football Hall of Fame showed the folly of an exclusionary policy for dead inductees.
lead_paragraph: When Sydney Seau spoke briefly Saturday at the Pro Football Hall of Fame induction for her late father, Junior, she proved emphatically that the relatives of deceased inductees deserved to deliver full speeches at their enshrinement ceremonies. Who would have thought otherwise?

headline: Frank Gifford, Star for Giants and in the Broadcast Booth, Dies at 84
abstract: Gifford was a Hall of Fame running back and receiver who personified the Giants’ glory years of the late 1950s and early ’60s and then became a mainstay on television.
lead_paragraph: Frank Gifford, a gleaming hero of sports and television in an era when such things were possible, who moved seamlessly from stardom in the Giants’ offense to celebrity in the broadcast booth of “Monday Night Football,” died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84.

headline: ‘Fantastic Four’ Lacks Superpowers at Box Office
abstract: The big-budget flop from 20th Century Fox added to fears about superhero fatigue and called into question Hollywood’s willingness to hire novice directors for major films.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — 20th Century Fox’s big-budget “Fantastic Four” went down in flames at the weekend box office, adding to fears about superhero fatigue and calling into question Hollywood’s willingness to hire novice directors for major films.

headline: After Nokia Layoffs, Tech Workers in Finland Regroup and Refocus
abstract: Thousands of laid-off workers have started their own businesses or have been recruited by other tech companies lured to Finland by its surplus of talent.
lead_paragraph: Kimmo Kalliola knows the feeling that thousands of Finns have been dealing with over the last couple of years. He spent more than a decade working on geolocation positioning at Nokia, a highly technical job, but the Finnish tech giant hit hard times. In late 2012, Mr. Kalliola and 10,000 others at the company were laid off.

headline: As South Korean Villages Empty, More Primary Schools Face Closings
abstract: When Nogok Primary closes this spring, it will become one of thousands of schools in the country that have shuttered as industrialization and education draw people to cities.
lead_paragraph: NOGOK, South Korea — The post office pulled up stakes and moved away years ago. The police station is long gone. And so is the bank. Over the years, the residents of Nogok have watched almost every major institution disappear, victims of an exodus of young people that is emptying villages and towns across much of rural South Korea.

headline: Behold the Deep Bench
abstract: Feel the Jebmentum.
lead_paragraph: NBC has the first post-debate poll; it’s an online poll, but using a methodology that worked very well in the midterm elections. And it does not, it turns out, show the predicted Trump collapse and rise of the establishment candidates.

headline: Mets Lose Early Lead and Fall to Rays
abstract: Chris Archer shut down the Mets after some early trouble as Tampa Bay rallied to beat Bartolo Colon, 4-3.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — On his final pitch of Sunday’s game, Tampa Bay starter Chris Archer threw an 88-mile-an-hour slider to Wilmer Flores. Flores swung and missed. Archer, the Rays’ young All-Star pitcher, pumped his arms, let out a yell and strutted off the mound. He had allowed three runs and four hits while striking out 10 in six innings.

headline: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and 1MDB
abstract: The prime minister of Malaysia, Najib Razak, is mired in a scandal over billions of dollars that his critics say are missing from a sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad, known as 1MDB.
lead_paragraph: The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Najib Razak, is mired in a scandal over billions of dollars that his critics say are missing from a sovereign wealth fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad, known as 1MDB.

headline: Yankees Shut Out by Blue Jays for Second Day in Row
abstract: Toronto completed a three-game sweep in which the Yankees produced only a single run. The Yankees lead in the A.L. East is down to 1.5 games.
lead_paragraph: Of the three hits that Masahiro Tanaka allowed in six innings Sunday, two were home runs. The damage was minimal, but it supplied the Toronto Blue Jays with just enough offense to send the Yankees off winless in this important three-game series between teams jockeying for supremacy in the American League East.

headline: Abrons Announces Premieres for New Season
abstract: The arts center on the Lower East Side will also feature festivals devoted to dance, “queer arts” and elecroacoustic music.
lead_paragraph: Seven world-premiere theater pieces are in store for the coming season at Abrons Arts Center, the 100-year-old home to avant-garde theater and dance at the Henry Street Settlement.

headline: KCON
abstract: Scenes from the festival of K-Pop music.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the festival of K-Pop music.

headline: At Salzburg Festival, Musicians Tap Their Inner Mozarts and Schuberts
abstract: A stretched-out Schubert piece has been among the performances during this Austrian event’s full calendar.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — The six-week calendar of this summer’s Salzburg Festival is, as usual, packed. Among the offerings are seven staged opera productions (three of them new), and three operas in concert, as well as dozens of programs by the Vienna Philharmonic, nine guest orchestras, chamber groups, contemporary ensembles and more.

headline: Coca-Cola Funds Scientists Who Shift Blame for Obesity Away From Bad Diets
abstract: The company supports a new nonprofit, the Global Energy Balance Network, that promotes a “science-based” approach to weight control: Get more exercise and worry less about cutting calories.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola, the world’s largest producer of sugary beverages, is backing a new “science-based” solution to the obesity crisis: To maintain a healthy weight, get more exercise and worry less about cutting calories.

headline: It’s Not the First Time Donald Trump Has Flirted With a Third-Party Run
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2000', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Mr. Trump has thought about rage-against-the-machine runs as a minor party candidate before, and how serious he is about it for the 2016 presidential race is about to be tested.
lead_paragraph: Over nearly two decades, Donald J. Trump has given more than a little thought to a third-party presidential candidacy. How serious he is about it for 2016 is about to be tested.

headline: Review: In ‘Delirium’s Daughters,’ Dad Wrestles Daughters’ Suitors, One Dead
abstract: In this farce by Nicholas Korn, influenced by commedia dell’arte, a patriarch weighs the qualifications of three suitors courting his children; a fourth complicates matters.
lead_paragraph: Things turn complex and lovely when the ghost appears in “Delirium’s Daughters.” It’s not a real ghost. Giovio isn’t dead; he has cleverly faked his own demise so that everyone will think kindly of him, especially his girlfriend’s father, who has rejected him as a prospective son-in-law. So he visits the man in the middle of the night.

headline: Israel Continues Crackdown on Jewish Extremist Network in West Bank
abstract: The authorities ordered that two high-profile activists from the radical right, Meir Ettinger and Eviatar Slonim, be imprisoned without charge or trial.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli authorities on Sunday continued their crackdown against the young Jewish zealots believed to be associated with the Revolt, a shadowy network described by its members as an anarchistic vision of redemption.

headline: Review: Stately Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, a Brave Danish String Quartet
abstract: Edward Gardner conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall; the Danish String Quartet played the Kaplan Penthouse later the same night.
lead_paragraph: In recent summer seasons, Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, has successfully transformed the Mostly Mozart Festival. What was once a stodgy diet of Classical-era hits and occasional novelties has become a varied festival that includes a valuable platform for contemporary music. This week, for example, the festival presents the American stage premiere of George Benjamin’s acclaimed opera “Written on Skin,” with Alan Gilbert conducting the Mahler Chamber Orchestra, a major event.

headline: Review: Steven Osborne Is Joined by 2 Collaborators at Kaplan Penthouse
abstract: The pianist Steven Osborne twice played the Kaplan Penthouse, once with the violinist Alina Ibragimova and once with his wife, the clarinetist Jean Johnson.
lead_paragraph: One of the most attractive innovations of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center in recent decades has been A Little Night Music, a series of intimate concerts in a nightclub atmosphere (with free wine) at the Kaplan Penthouse. The 10 o’clock start typically allows patrons a leisurely stroll from the evening’s orchestral concert, where, as often as not, they will have heard some of the same performers.

keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Child Pornography', 'Gangs', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

headline: New York, Combating Worker Abuse, Requires Salon Owners to Secure Wage Bonds
keywords: ['Nails (Body Part)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Beauty Salons', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The rule is the latest in a series of reforms Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has introduced to address worker exploitation in nail salons.
lead_paragraph: For nearly six years, Silvia Gonzalez opened the doors of Romy’s Nails in Brooklyn at about 8:45 a.m. and left more than 12 hours later, six days a week. She performed manicures and pedicures with no lunch break, making $55 a day, or about $4.50 an hour. After Ms. Gonzalez had worked there four years, her pay increased to $80 a day, which was still below minimum wage. She recalled hearing her employer often proclaim to workers, many of whom were working illegally in the country, that no one could win against him in court.

headline: Another Sunday Dominated by Donald Trump
abstract: Virtually every other candidate who made an appearance on the Sunday morning news shows found themselves asked about Mr. Trump’s remarks during Thursday’s presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump may have found himself on the defensive this weekend for his remarks criticizing the moderators of Thursday’s Republican presidential debate. But even under attack, Mr. Trump seems to be dominating the Republican primary campaign.

headline: Review: In ‘A Moon for the Misbegotten,’ Audra McDonald Is Front and Center
abstract: This revival of Eugene O’Neill’s play centers on people who assume false roles that allow them to function in their daily lives.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — She may be wild-eyed, dusty and barefoot, and wearing a dress that looks like it doubles as a heavy-duty cleaning rag. But from the moment you set eyes on her at the beginning of the Williamstown Theater Festival’s production of Eugene O’Neill’s “A Moon for the Misbegotten,” you never for a second doubt the supreme, comforting competence of the rowdy farm gal named Josie Hogan.
