lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Russian dynamos Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev zipped into City Center for “Solo for Two,” a program intended to highlight an artistic partnership that was once personal as well as professional.

headline: Smile!
abstract: Smile along with C. W. Stewart.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Even on a Monday, there has to be a mental separation between the solving of a puzzle and the full understanding of the theme. That gap is where your brain takes all of the theme clues, digests them and then delivers that “Aha!” moment that we all know and love. The gap can’t be too short, because that would mean that the theme is too obvious, and that’s no fun. It can’t be too long, because then it wouldn’t be a Monday puzzle. It’s an art to get it just right.

headline: Scenes From Ferguson’s Protests
abstract: A year after the death of Michael Brown, protesters marched in Ferguson to mark the anniversary of the shooting of the black teenager by a white police officer.
lead_paragraph: A year after the death of Michael Brown, protesters marched in Ferguson to mark the anniversary of the shooting of the black teenager by a white police officer.

headline: Instagram Takes on Growing Role in the Art Market
abstract: How much the use of the online mobile app actually translates into sales is still up for debate.
lead_paragraph: Anyone in the art market who was not already paying attention to the social media platform Instagram had to sit up and take notice in April after the actor Pierce Brosnan visited the showroom of Phillips auction house in London. Mr. Brosnan snapped a selfie in front of a work he admired: the “Lockheed Lounge,” a space-age aluminum chaise longue by the industrial designer Marc Newson. Then he added the words “let the bidding commence,” and posted it to the 164,000 followers of his Instagram feed.

headline: Harper Lee and Truman Capote: A Collaboration in Mischief
abstract: The author Greg Neri has written a novel for middle-grade readers about the friendship that bound Harper Lee and Truman Capote.
lead_paragraph: One summer about 85 years ago in a small Alabama town, a scrappy tomboy named Nelle met her new next door neighbor, Tru, a bookish, dapper dresser with a high-pitched voice and a mischievous streak.

headline: Review: ‘On Writing,’ a Charles Bukowski Collection of Rants and Musings in Letters
abstract: This anthology of letters and drawings by the bellicosely opinionated author and poet, who would have turned 95 this month, was edited by Abel Debritto, a Bukowski biographer.
lead_paragraph: Charles Bukowski’s 95th birthday would have been this Sunday. And, inevitably, here comes “On Writing,” a selection of letters, and a scattering of drawings, by that prolific and bellicosely opinionated author, from 1945 to 1993. According to the news release from Ecco, the book is “the first in a series of at least three Bukowski anthologies.” Batten down the hatches, folks — as surely everyone must know by now, this wasn’t a man inclined to edit himself.

abstract: This week analysts expect modest results from four department stores, a quarterly earnings report from Alibaba and retails sales for July.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Labor will hold four days of public hearings this week to discuss its proposed rule that would require a broader group of financial professionals to put their clients’ interests ahead of their own when handling the clients’ retirement money. The hearings will be held from Monday through Thursday. The White House has estimated that the lack of consumer protection costs investors as much as $17 billion annually, or 1 percent of their assets, and perhaps more. But the rule has faced strong and well-funded opponents in the financial services industry. Those stakeholders, along with consumer advocates including AARP, will have the opportunity to make their arguments to regulators this week. —Tara Siegel Bernard

headline: Cuomo Says Hudson Tunnels Need Grants, Not Loans to States, From U.S.

lead_paragraph: Two weeks after the federal government’s top transportation official urged the governors of New York and New Jersey to meet with him about how to solve the problems plaguing rail service between their states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Sunday that such a meeting would be pointless unless federal officials offered grants, not loans, to finance new tunnels under the Hudson River.

headline: For a Villa Full of Artists, a French Chef Masters His Italian
abstract: Guillaume Rouxel left Le Dauphin in Paris to serve three-course dinners, six nights a week, at Villa Lena in Tuscany.
lead_paragraph: While many Parisians travel to Tuscany in August to enjoy their requisite monthlong holiday, chef Guillaume Rouxel, the former head chef at Inaki Aizpitarte’s smart 11th Arrondissement bistro Le Dauphin, has packed up his cooking knives and traveled to Italy to work. Rouxel has taken on a chef residency at the hip hotel and artist retreat Villa Lena, a sprawling 500-hectare estate perched high up in the hills, just a 50-minute drive from Pisa.

headline: A Sculptor’s Assistant Whose Canvas Is Cake
abstract: Georgia-Rose Fairman started baking two years ago in her London studio and makes desserts that are delicious, beautiful and a little gross.
lead_paragraph: Georgia-Rose Fairman makes desserts that are delicious, beautiful and a little gross: a miniature human figure fashioned after the bold, imperfect beauty of a Lucian Freud nude; a fruits de mer banquet commissioned by the French fashion label Carven. So convincing — and tasty — was the flower-festooned pig’s head that she made for the restaurant critic A. A. Gill’s 60th birthday party, that the chef Heston Blumenthal jokingly threatened to dismiss his own pastry chef. Fairman, an assistant to the sculptor Phyllida Barlow, started baking two years ago in her London studio, when she decided to make something for her boyfriend’s birthday. Rather than the usual chocolate gateau, she got ambitious, precision-carving blocks of marzipan-covered sponge cake before painting them with edible watercolors to create what looked exactly like a roast chicken complete with carrots, potatoes and peas. “It’s a weird cross between food and sculpture,” she says. “The main thing for me is that they look like still-life paintings.”

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 A.M. (Animal Planet) WORLD LION DAY In remembrance of Cecil (above), who was illegally killed last month in Zimbabwe, and others, Animal Planet presents some of its most memorable lion programming, starting with “Last Lion of Liuwa,” about the sole survivor of a massacre that destroyed the rest of the pride. The lineup continues with “Big Cat Diary,” which tracks lions, cheetahs and leopards roaming the Masai Mara National Reserve in Kenya, at 7; “Into the Lion’s Den,” which follows Dave Salmoni, a large-predator expert, into lion territory as he tries to prove that the creatures are more likely to accept people than attack them, at 10; “Into the Pride,” in which Mr. Salmoni works to save rogue lions from elimination, at noon; and “A Lion Called Christian,” about the story behind the Internet phenomenon depicting the emotional reunion between two men and their 300-pound captive lion a year after it was released into the wild, at 5 p.m. Nat Geo Wild also commemorates big-cat conservation from noon through 8 p.m.

headline: Returning to a Rebuilding Nepal
abstract: As soon as Kevin Bubriski learned of the earthquake that devastated Nepal, he knew he had to return to the land he has documented since 1975.
lead_paragraph: As soon as I heard the news of Nepal’s earthquake last April, I knew I had to get back there as soon as possible. Ever since I first arrived there as a Peace Corps volunteer in 1975, I have lived and traveled throughout the country, including in three of the districts devastated by the quakes. Now, deeply saddened and dismayed, I needed to continue documenting life after the devastating 7.8 magnitude quake.

headline: The Meeropol Brothers: Exonerate Our Mother, Ethel Rosenberg
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Capital Punishment', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: A newly released transcript shows she was prosecuted mainly for refusing to turn on her husband, Julius.
lead_paragraph: OUR parents, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, were executed on June 19, 1953, after being convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage. That was the formal legal charge, but in the public’s mind they were executed for providing our archenemy, the Soviet Union, with the ability to destroy our country with atomic bombs. Theirs was the most sensational case of the McCarthy period.

headline: Keep the Internet Free of Borders
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Inventions and Patents', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The government should not apply the same rules to data that it does to physical goods.
lead_paragraph: One of the great things about the Internet is that it does not have national borders. When a company in Tokyo sends a digital file to a company in New York, the data does not have to clear customs. But the outcome of  a federal appeals court case could hinder that free flow of information.

headline: The Pentagon’s Dangerous Views on the Wartime Press
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Defense Department’s new manual on the law of war could severely hinder the work of journalists covering armed conflicts.
lead_paragraph: The Defense Department earlier this summer released a comprehensive manual outlining its interpretation of the law of war. The 1,176-page document, the first of its kind, includes guidelines on the treatment of journalists covering armed conflicts that would make their work more dangerous, cumbersome and subject to censorship. Those should be repealed immediately.

headline: Failing Patients With Heart Failure
abstract: Doctors still aren’t very good at easing an end that can be very difficult.
lead_paragraph: HEART disease is the world’s No. 1 killer, despite advances in medical technology, as well as public health initiatives that have eased the burden of heart disease drastically. While one marvels at the progress, we often ignore how heart-disease patients die.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates and Obama’s Failure to Fail
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: Despite their overall condemnation of the Obama record, Republican candidates are oddly short on specifics.
lead_paragraph: What did the men who would be president talk about during last week’s prime-time Republican debate? Well, there were 19 references to God, while the economy rated only 10 mentions. Republicans in Congress have voted dozens of times to repeal all or part of Obamacare, but the candidates only named President Obama’s signature policy nine times over the course of two hours. And energy, another erstwhile G.O.P. favorite, came up only four times.

headline: California Is Proving That Health Reform Works
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In a double dose of good news, more of the state’s uninsured gained coverage and premiums have risen only modestly.
lead_paragraph: Californians got a double dose of good health care news late last month. The number of Californians who have trouble finding a doctor or paying their medical bills has sharply declined since the Affordable Care Act took effect. And premiums charged by private insurers have risen only modestly, contrary to warnings that insurers were likely to get double-digit premium increases.

headline: When Prostitution Is Nobody’s Business
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Online Dating', 'Privacy', 'Prostitution', 'Sex', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A moral expectation of privacy can change the meaning of an act, even and especially if that act is exchanging sex for money.
lead_paragraph: Moral and political philosophers distinguish among different forms of privacy: physical, informational and decisional. When it comes to sex, we tend to have a strong expectation that we’ll be granted all three.

headline: Inside Syria: Kurds Roll Back ISIS, but Alliances Are Strained
abstract: Even as Kurds are assisting in the campaign against the Islamic State in Syria, Turkey, a latecomer to the U.S.-led mission, is also bombarding Kurdish insurgent positions.
lead_paragraph: HASAKA, Syria — Green drapes were drawn against the sun, cloaking the room where members of a Syrian Kurdish militia huddled around walkie-talkies, assiduously taking down GPS coordinates.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The St. Louis County executive declared a state of emergency here on Monday as officials and activists sought to regain control of the volatile streets after plainclothes police officers shot and critically wounded an 18-year-old black man who they said was firing on them late the night before.

headline: Stampede in India Kills 10 Pilgrims Attending Hindu Festival

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian court could hand down a verdict in the trial of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent charged with espionage, within a week, his lawyer told reporters on Monday, as a fourth and possibly final hearing in the case was held in Tehran.

headline: Need a Taxi to the Airport? Options Expanding Beyond Uber
keywords: ['Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Mobile Applications', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: With new services like Bandwagon and Tripda, and others expanding, there are more ways than ever to hire a car or share a ride in many cities.
lead_paragraph: Hailing a taxi nowadays can feel downright old-fashioned. New ride-sharing alternatives — such as Via, Bandwagon, Tripda and RideWith — are springing up in major cities and at airports. At the same time, established car services like Uber and Lyft are continuing to expand to more corners of the world while adding bells and whistles like Starbucks rewards points, free beach bags and on-demand water taxis.

headline: ‘Body’ Report Cards Aren’t Influencing Arkansas Teenagers

lead_paragraph: It is one of the boldest and most controversial tactics in the battle against childhood obesity: A growing number of schools are monitoring their students’ weight and sending updates home, much like report cards.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Embarrassed by Coupons, but Learning How to Save to Splurge
abstract: My youngest child used to stand near other adults on line when the complaints began, as if he was with another, less-troublesome shopper.
lead_paragraph: My middle child unwraps the red wax wrapping and bites into a chunk of cheese. “That cost 9 cents,” I tell him. Unimpressed, he eats another. “It was supposed to cost almost 50 cents,” I explain. “It comes in a pack of five, which normally costs $2.49. This week the package cost $1.99, less my 55-cent coupon, taking it down to 89 cents, and that’s before a 50-cent rebate. Divide that by five cheeses and you just ate 18 cents,” My son looks at me as he unwraps another cheese circle. “You’re scary,” he says at last. “But the cheese is pretty good for 9 cents.”

headline: Not Vaccinating Children Is the Greater Risk
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Hepatitis', 'Mumps', 'Tetanus', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Whooping Cough']

headline: Today in Politics: Donald Trump’s Comments Follow Other Candidates on the Trail
abstract: Not only is Donald J. Trump not going away, but he also is ensuring that yet another week on the campaign trail will begin with questions that the rest of the Republican candidates are growing sick of.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington, where Congress is on recess, President Obama is on vacation, and the debate’s hurly-burly is done, the battle lost and won. Among those claiming victory is Donald J. Trump, whose subsequent online confrontation with the Fox News moderator Megyn Kelly was widely seen as sexist, and has prompted hand-wringing among the other candidates about what should be done with him.

headline: After Kabul Attack, Afghan Leader Points Finger at Pakistan for Failing to Stop Taliban
abstract: After a car bombing on Monday continued a wave of attacks, President Ashraf Ghani accused Pakistan of failing to prevent fighters from gatherings in its territory.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Under pressure after a wave of deadly bombings in the Afghan capital, President Ashraf Ghani on Monday accused Pakistan of turning a blind eye to mass gatherings of Taliban fighters in its territory, where such attacks are planned.

headline: Labels Like ‘Alternative Medicine’ Don’t Matter. The Science Does.
abstract: As long as you can prove that it works, it doesn’t matter what you call it.
lead_paragraph: The University of Toronto recently stirred up a bit of controversy by offering an uncritical class on “Alternative Medicine.” A variety of bloggers and journalists brought up many valid concerns about the curriculum, but there is a much larger problem: No one is sure how best to teach that subject.

headline: The Roanoke Island Colony: Lost, and Found?
abstract: Archaeological finds in North Carolina may provide clues to the fate of at least some of the Roanoke Island colonists who vanished in the late 1500s.
lead_paragraph: MERRY HILL, N.C. — Under a blistering sun, Nicholas M. Luccketti swatted at mosquitoes as he watched his archaeology team at work in a shallow pit on a hillside above the shimmering waters of Albemarle Sound. On a table in the shade, a pile of plastic bags filled with artifacts was growing. Fragments of earthenware and pottery. A mashed metal rivet. A piece of a hand-wrought nail.

headline: Attackers in Istanbul Open Fire Outside U.S. Consulate
abstract: The attack was one of several violent episodes across the country, which some attributed to an uptick in clashes between Turkish security forces and Kurdish militants.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Attackers opened fire outside the United States Consulate here on Monday morning, setting off a brief gun battle with the police as violence in Turkey continued to escalate nearly two weeks after the government began what it called a major counterterrorism effort, including increased cooperation with the United States in the fight against the Islamic State.

keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']

headline: Morning Agenda: S.E.C. Ready to Make a Splash
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'PUERTO RICO', 'Venture Capital']

lead_paragraph: S.E.C. READY TO MAKE A SPLASH | The Securities and Exchange Commission is pursuing high-profile cases while fending off criticism that it is not aggressive enough in forcing wrongdoers to admit liability, Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein report in DealBook. It is poised to file charges soon in an investigation that combines insider trading with cybersecurity, according to people briefed on the investigation, but not authorized to speak publicly. The case centers on whether overseas hackers broke into the networks of American companies to secure inside information about corporate deals, later passing on that information to traders.

headline: Pakistan, the Next Software Hub?
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Start-ups']
abstract: It’s becoming a destination for freelance programmers, software coders and app designers.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI — Pakistan isn’t usually considered one of the world’s information technology powerhouses; its share of global I.T. sales is only $2.8 billion, of which $1.6 billion represents tech and I.T. services and software exported abroad. This is a tiny percentage of the expected $3.2 trillion global market for 2015, and is dwarfed by India’s $100 billion worth of software exports per year.

headline: As Print Fades, Part 1: ‘Live Journalism’ at The Times
abstract: The first post in an occasional series about new ventures to support Times journalism as print revenue declines.
lead_paragraph: With its announcement last week that one million digital-only subscribers now pay for its journalism, The Times hit a major milestone, and one worth celebrating. Just a few years back, as various pay wall efforts were tried and put on the shelf, that eye-popping number was close to unimaginable.

headline: Environmental Agency Uncorks Its Own Toxic Water Spill at Colorado Mine
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Mines and Mining', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Rivers', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Residents of Durango, Colo., are fuming over an E.P.A. mistake that sent three million gallons of mine waste into the town’s cultural soul, the Animas River.
lead_paragraph: DURANGO, Colo. — The Animas River is the cultural soul of this patch of southwestern Colorado, a sort of moving Main Street that hosts multiple floating parades a year and is typically bustling with rafters and kayakers. Schoolchildren study the river. Sweethearts marry on its banks. Its former name, given by Spaniards, is el Río de las Ánimas, the River of Souls.

headline: Trash Talk and the Macroeconomic Divide
abstract: What happened to the Chicago School?
lead_paragraph: Paul Romer continues to maintain that Chicago’s inward turn, the rejection of all salt-water macroeconomics that left it so hapless in the face of the Great Recession, was a defensive reaction to the sarcasm of Robert Solow. Brad DeLong points out that Solow was, as it turns out, right. Beyond that, as Brad notes and Paul actually acknowledges, what was actually going on at MIT was nothing like the implacable opposition of Chicago fantasies.

headline: Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals to Acquire Therakos for $1.33 Billion
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mallinckrodt Pharmaceuticals, a maker of drugs and medical devices, said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Therakos from the American private equity firm Gores Group for about $1.33 billion.

headline: Why ‘Smart’ Objects May Be a Dumb Idea
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Our cars, fridges and even bank safes are connected to the Internet. It’s making us vulnerable in new and alarming ways.
lead_paragraph: A FRIDGE that puts milk on your shopping list when you run low. A safe that tallies the cash that is placed in it. A sniper rifle equipped with advanced computer technology for improved accuracy. A car that lets you stream music from the Internet.

headline: Algorithms and Bias: Q. and A. With Cynthia Dwork
abstract: Preventing discriminatory algorithms is an issue being taken up by computer scientists as well as policy makers, ethicists and legal experts.
lead_paragraph: Algorithms have become one of the most powerful arbiters in our lives. They make decisions about the news we read, the jobs we get, the people we meet, the schools we attend and the ads we see.

headline: 1915: German Intellectuals’ Manifesto
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A German manifesto gives reasons for invading France in 1915.
lead_paragraph: The German intellectuals, according to the ‘‘Figaro,’’ have just signed another egregious manifesto which bids fair to rival the notorious one they issued at the outset of the war in defence of the war. ‘‘Naturally,’’ says the manifesto, ‘‘we do not want to dominate the world, but we demand the possibility of extending our culture and our industrial and commercial power all over the earth. This is the firm determination of the German people. To this end we must remove the French menace and danger. We must modify our western frontier from Belfort to the coast. We must, if possible, conquer the French Channel coast in order to fortify ourselves against Great Britain.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 11, 1915

headline: Daily Report: How to Play the Valuation Gap Between Start-Ups and Public Tech Companies

lead_paragraph: One of the most notable trends in Silicon Valley over the last five years has been the emergence of a group of highly valued start-ups, all valued at more than $1 billion, and known as unicorns. Only a small set of deep-pocketed investor, typically venture capitalists and hedge funds and mutual funds, has been able to participate in the run-up in valuations of these companies.

headline: John Conway’s Wizard Puzzle
abstract: Try your hand at the devlishly tricky wizard problem by John Conway, one of the most brilliant living mathematicians.
lead_paragraph: This week we continue to acknowledge the whimsical brilliance of John Conway, the British mathematician featured in the newly-released biography by Siobhan Roberts (in case you missed it, see John Horton Conway, the Genius at Play). Our Conway challenge is a rather famous one in math circles, and was suggested by Laura Feiveson, an M.I.T.-trained economist. Dr. Feiveson warms us up with a rock and a hen before getting to the main event:

headline: When Mom Is Part of the Bachelorette Party Debauchery
abstract: More mothers are included in — and expecting to be invited to — their daughters’ pre-wedding celebrations.
lead_paragraph: Traveling to a resort city like Miami with a handful of girlfriends for a pre-wedding weekend of debauchery — with drinking, pricey dinners, high-end hotels and male strip clubs — is the norm these days for a bachelorette party.

headline: Setting Up a Budget Based on Your Values
abstract: A couple learns to align their spending with what is important to them by asking themselves a series of questions.
lead_paragraph: At a recent breakfast, a friend shared the process he and his wife use in place of traditional budgeting. It takes them less than 15 minutes a month, and after the first month, it’s already had a massive impact on the way they use money. Think of this as a little case study, one that shows exactly how easy it can be to align your spending with what you say is important to you.

headline: Milan’s Expo 2015 Finds Success, but With a Muddled Message
keywords: ['Food', 'Sustainable Living', "World's Fairs", 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows']
abstract: The culinary achievements of the eco-oriented Expo Milano 2015 are found hidden among prominent vendors like McDonald’s and Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: Milan — At the New York Crystal Palace Exhibition in 1853, the potato chip made its big debut. The Pan-American Exposition of 1901 in Buffalo introduced the X-ray machine.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
abstract: Barcelona’s busy, Bayern kicks off, and Chelsea battles Manchester City. The soccer editor Andrew Das tells you what to watch.
lead_paragraph: As you settle in for another week of soccer viewing in your comfiest chair, spare a moment to think about the soon-to-be-weary legs of the players at Barcelona, which will soon be the latest victim of the club’s success. The soccer editor Andrew Das tells you what to watch.

headline: 1940: Rush to Marry Ahead of Draft
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: American couples marry to avoid the military draft in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The effects of the Burke-Wadsworth bill for compulsory selective military training, which exempts married men, were noticeable yesterday at marriage license bureaus throughout New York. Records were established in the Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens offices, even though they were not open for the full day. At the Brooklyn bureau, on the second floor of Borough Hall, ten policemen were needed to keep a long line of applicants in order. Julius J. Brosen, chief clerk, said: ‘‘This is the biggest day we’ve had this year.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, August 11, 1940

headline: NBC Retains Rights to Premier League in Six-Year Deal
abstract: NBC, which has used English soccer to define its NBCSN cable network, made a deal worth about $1 billion, basically double the annual cost of NBC’s current contract.
lead_paragraph: Two years of success broadcasting England’s Premier League proved a basic truth to NBC Sports: It would have to pay a lot more to keep carrying the league’s games.

headline: Unpredictable Work Hours, Chaotic Life
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Child Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Minimum Wage', 'Paid Time Off', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Irregular and on-call scheduling increases workers’ stress and family conflicts, recent research shows.
lead_paragraph: The tyranny of erratic work schedules is obvious to employees who don’t know what their schedules will be tomorrow or have to call in to see if there is work. And the effects have been well documented in articles and oral histories. Increasingly, the anecdotal evidence is being confirmed by research.

headline: Cumberbatch Makes Plea to ‘Hamlet’ Fans
abstract: The actor Benedict Cumberbatch asked a group of fans in London not to film his performances of “Hamlet” on their mobile phones, as the red lights are distracting.
lead_paragraph: The actor Benedict Cumberbatch asked a group of fans in London not to film his performances of “Hamlet” on their mobile phones, as the red lights are distracting.

headline: A Searing First Encounter With David Lynch’s ‘Blue Velvet’
abstract: How I would love to see this dark masterpiece again, in that same state of unsullied expectation.
lead_paragraph: And then the young man picked up the severed ear and stared deeply into its ant-encrusted whorls.

headline: A Republican Agitator in the Senate Makes Friends Across the Aisle
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mike Lee, the junior senator from Utah who helped lead the government shutdown effort, has a reputation of defying party leaders as well as cooperating with Democrats on libertarian-leaning policy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As meetings among congressional colleagues go, the one last month in which Republican senators confronted Mike Lee, a freshman from Utah, was among the most contentious in years.

headline: 2 Sayreville Football Players Cleared of Serious Charges in Hazing Case
abstract: The players, both 17 at the time of the episode, had been charged with aggravated sexual contact and aggravated assault; they were found guilty of two disorderly persons charges.
lead_paragraph: Two of the high school football players charged in a 2014 hazing case in Sayreville, N.J., have been acquitted of all serious charges, their lawyers said on Monday.

headline: Witness Videos of Shootout in Istanbul
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Amateur videos show a gun battle between attackers and Turkish police outside the United States Consulate in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: Amateur videos show a gun battle between attackers and Turkish police outside the United States Consulate in Istanbul.

headline: Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush Pan Hillary Clinton’s Student Loan Plan
abstract: Republican candidates like Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush are likening Hillary Rodham Clinton’s proposals addressing America’s student loan debt crisis to a typical Democratic tax hike.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton is readying a $350 billion plan to address America’s student loan debt crisis, but to her Republican rivals the idea sounded like something familiar: a tax hike.

headline: You Will See the Doctor’s Fallibility Now
abstract: Physicians, too, can become confused in ways that lead to “never” events, as in they should never occur. How far should the system go to prevent them?
lead_paragraph: I was not present for the incident in radiology, but I heard all about it. The patient with the swollen ankle watched with increasing puzzlement as the technician prepared to X-ray his other foot.

headline: Nusra Front Announces Withdrawal From Front Line Against ISIS in Syria
abstract: The Nusra Front, the Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda, said it disagreed with plans by Turkey and the United States to clear the Islamic State from an area along the Turkish border.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — The Syrian affiliate of Al Qaeda has announced its withdrawal from front-line positions against the Islamic State extremist group in northern Syria, saying that it disagrees with plans by Turkey and the United States to clear the extremists from an area along the Turkish border.

headline: A Tanqueray Gin With a Past
keywords: ['Oysters', 'Food', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Gin (Liquor)', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Worcestershire Sauce']
abstract: A limited-edition spirit from Tom Nichol; Creemee, a soft-serve Vermont-style ice cream; Worcestershire sauce with a lager base; and more.
lead_paragraph: An unmistakable whiff of juniper rises from the glass holding the latest iteration of Tanqueray gin. Called Bloomsbury, the gin is named after the location of the company’s English distillery in the late 19th century. It is a limited-edition spirit that the company’s former distiller Tom Nichol based on a recipe created by Charles Waugh Tanqueray. Though it is in the bracing style of London dry gin, it also has spicy, licorice and floral notes. Sip it on the rocks with a subtle touch of lime, or let it loose in a gimlet or a southside: Tanqueray Bloomsbury gin, $33 at reservebar.com.

headline: Vu Tran’s ‘Dragonfish’
abstract: A cop searches for his ex-wife, a haunted Vietnamese immigrant, in the city’s sleazy depths.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to all protestations, America is a nation not of immigrants but of refugees. Trauma, displacement and fanatical hope have marked all new Americans from the occupants of the Mayflower through every subsequent group who came to these shores (or who were brought here by force). This is the unspoken and sometimes unacknowledged fear and fact of being American: These unkind ghosts of our pasts, these specters of previous selves and previous nations that will not be dismissed so easily, always attend our daily negotiations around identity. They cause a torment that can turn us violent, hateful and self-destructive, and the uneasy grace we win is in itself a remarkable thing. The longer our stay in the United States, the fainter the ghosts get, until they are not much more than a vague unsettled feeling that itself causes even more confusion. Novels by recently arrived Americans have tried to negotiate the struggle to fit into a new home that doesn’t always want them, and the nostalgia for all that has been lost. In this way new immigrant literature mimics its antecedents.

headline: Stylish Synthetics
abstract: Life in plastic? It’s fantastic.
lead_paragraph: Life in plastic? It’s fantastic.

headline: Climate Change Could Harm British Butterflies
abstract: Six species of butterflies in Britain will face local extinction by 2050 because of climate change, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: Six species of butterflies in Britain will face local extinction by 2050 because of climate change, a new study reports.

headline: Ivan Doig’s ‘Last Bus to Wisdom’
abstract: A plucky 11-year-old hits the road in Ivan Doig’s final novel.
lead_paragraph: By the time he died in April at age 75, Ivan Doig had created a body of work that helped shape our understanding of rural working-class life in the postwar American West. Raised by Montana ranchers in the 1940s and ’50s, Doig lived most of his adult years in Seattle but never really left Big Sky Country. From his early memoir, “This House of Sky,” to this final novel, “Last Bus to Wisdom,” Doig often gave Montana a leading role. Partly because of this emphasis, his work has been hit or miss for me. I’ve pounded the table in favor of some novels (once literally, as an award juror, for “Bucking the Sun”), and I’ve abandoned others halfway through, bored with the relentless Montanana.

headline: Landlord of ‘Three-Quarter’ Homes Faces Criminal Charges
keywords: ['Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords', 'Evictions', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The landlord, Yury Baumblit, is accused of illegal evictions in two counts filed last week. Housing advocates called the charges unusually forceful.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors have filed criminal charges against a notorious landlord of cramped flophouses in Brooklyn, taking what housing advocates described as unusually forceful action against an operator of so-called three-quarter homes.

headline: Preventing Suicide in America’s Jails
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Suicide has reached crisis proportions in local jails, where psychiatric care appears to be especially poor.
lead_paragraph: Suicide has long been a problem in the corrections system, where a considerable portion of inmates suffer from mental illness. But new federal data show that suicide has reached crisis proportions in local jails, where psychiatric care appears to be particularly poor. This situation is especially alarming, given that 12 million people — many with mental illnesses — will cycle through local jails this year.

headline: Truffles Travel Well for D’Artagnan
abstract: Despite a few flames, the purveyor of fine foods makes a successful move to a larger warehouse.
lead_paragraph: The move was just six miles. But the cargo — 63 truckloads of pâté, truffles, Wagyu beef and even whole pigs — required extraordinary attention, as well as refrigeration.

headline: If Mosquitoes Disappeared
abstract: It’s only natural that human beings, who do the itching and suffering from mosquito-borne diseases, want to imagine the insects gone.
lead_paragraph: It’s only natural that human beings, who do the itching and suffering from mosquito-borne diseases, want to imagine the insects gone.

headline: Donald Trump Reacts to Criticism by Staying on the Offensive
abstract: “She should really be apologizing to me, if you want to know the truth,” Donald J. Trump said on Monday, reiterating that he considered his treatment by the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly in last week’s debate to be unfair.
lead_paragraph: After a weekend of criticism about his contentious debate performance and verbal attacks on the Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly, Donald J. Trump showed no signs of backing down on Monday.

headline: Around the World in One Memoir
abstract: Geoffrey Kent’s book takes readers to Kenya, Antarctica and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Geoffrey Kent, the founder and CEO of the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent, is adding, coincidentally albeit poignantly, to the discussion about big-game hunting. The Kenya-raised Kent led his inaugural safari in 1962 under the slogan “hunt with a camera, not with a gun,” and expanded his program over the years, even attracting a post-Liz-Taylor-breakup Richard Burton. In “Safari: A Memoir of a Worldwide Travel Pioneer” ($35, Harper Collins), out tomorrow, Kent recounts these anecdotes and more from places as far-flung as the North Pole and the Galápagos Islands. “I wanted this book to inspire people to travel,” he says. “You can find out more about yourself and find out more about others.”

headline: Growing Vegetables in Space, NASA Astronauts Tweet Their Lunch
abstract: The local food movement has reached the final frontier.
lead_paragraph: The local food movement has now reached outer space.

headline: tk
abstract: tk
lead_paragraph: tk

headline: Frogs With a Venomous Head Butt
abstract: Researchers have discovered two species that deliver potent toxins through bony spines on their heads. One biologist had a personal encounter.
lead_paragraph: There are many poisonous frogs — eat the wrong frog legs at a Paris bistro, and you’re in trouble. Now researchers have discovered two venomous frogs that deliver potent toxins through bony spines on their heads.

headline: Body Found in Hudson Is That of Ian Jones, Tali Lennox’s Boyfriend
abstract: A passing boat rescued Ms. Lennox, the daughter of singer Annie Lennox, after the kayak she and her boyfriend, Ian Jones, were in capsized Saturday morning near Staatsburg, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The search for Ian Jones, the artist and model missing since a kayak accident on Saturday, ended on Tuesday with the confirmation that the body found in the Hudson River on Monday was that of Mr. Jones. The findings of an autopsy conducted by the Dutchess County Medical Examiner were consistent with drowning, and Mr. Jones’s death is considered to be an accidental drowning with no criminal charges expected, according to a statement by Capt. John Watterson of the Dutchess County sheriff’s office. Results of toxicology tests performed during the autopsy will not be known for several weeks.

headline: F.D.A.’s ‘Off-Label’ Drug Policy Leads to Free-Speech Fight
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A judge’s decision sets up a likely court battle to determine just how far the government can go to punish speech that is truthful.
lead_paragraph: It certainly seems odd that speaking the truth can violate the law. Yet the Food and Drug Administration takes the position that when it approves a drug for a particular treatment, the manufacturer of that drug cannot promote it for other uses even if those statements are true.

headline: Deadly Stampede at Indian Temple
abstract: Additional forces have been deployed to eastern Jharkhand State in India, after a stampede broke out at a local temple, leaving at least 10 people dead and more than 20 injured.
lead_paragraph: Additional forces have been deployed to eastern Jharkhand State in India, after a stampede broke out at a local temple, leaving at least 10 people dead and more than 20 injured.

headline: Jonathan Ollivier, Dancer Featured in Matthew Bourne’s Work, Dies in Crash
abstract: Jonathan Ollivier, who starred in works choreographed by Matthew Bourne, was killed when a car struck his motorcyle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jonathan Ollivier, a British dancer who played a starring role in Matthew Bourne’s work, died here on Sunday after a car struck his motorcycle. He was 38. Mr. Ollivier, who had been performing the leading role in Mr. Bourne’s “The Car Man” at Sadler’s Wells, was on his way to the theater, where he was set to appear that night in the company’s final performance of the season. The BBC reported that paramedics and an air ambulance tried to save Mr. Ollivier’s life but pronounced him dead at the scene shortly before midday. It also reported that the driver of the vehicle that collided with Mr. Ollivier had been arrested.

headline: Police in Bangladesh Kill 6 Suspected of Tiger Poaching in Shootout
abstract: The police described the raid on Sunday in the Sundarban mangrove forest as the beginning of a larger crackdown on poaching.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police in Bangladesh announced that they had killed six men suspected of tiger poaching during a shootout Sunday in the Sundarbans, a mangrove forest, in what they described as the beginning of a larger crackdown.

headline: When Dams Come Down, Salmon and Sand Can Prosper
abstract: The removal of a dam on the Elwha River in Washington has found a beneficiary other than fish: a beach.
lead_paragraph: When people urge the removal of dams they say are strangling rivers in the West, it’s usually fish they’re worried about. Studies of dam-removal projects show that migratory species like salmon respond quickly to improved conditions once a dam is removed.

headline: Armani/Silos
abstract: Scenes from inside the exhibition space (don’t call it a museum) in Milan.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from inside the exhibition space (don’t call it a museum) in Milan.

headline: Watts, 50 Years On, Stands in Contrast to Today’s Conflicts
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A symbol of racial tensions after riots broke out on Aug. 11, 1965, Watts, a neighborhood in Los Angeles, has made strides in relations between the police and the community. But it is no utopia.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Donny Joubert watched the boy round the corner of the housing project holding what looked like a handgun. The barrel was pointed at him and the two officers from the Los Angeles Police Department. The boy was 10 or 11 years old, Mr. Joubert figured, and had more gleam than anger in his eyes. Mr. Joubert, a community activist who grew up in the project, shouted and lunged for the gun.

headline: Armani’s Four-Story Wardrobe
abstract: The newly opened Armani/Silos is practically a temple to the prolific Italian designer.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — In a former Nestlé granary in the Zona Tortona of Milan, Giorgio Armani has opened a temple to Giorgio Armani. Armani/Silos, his new exhibition space (he prefers not to call it a museum) is stocked four floors high with his clothes, about 600 pieces in all.

headline: Judd Apatow and Trevor Noah Among New York Comedy Festival Performers

lead_paragraph: Judd Apatow,Trevor Noah, Margaret Cho and Sarah Silverman are among the performers taking part in this year’s New York Comedy Festival, which will run from Nov. 10 through Nov. 15.

headline: Republican Attack on Voting Rights

lead_paragraph: Editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal on what he says is a partisan effort to keep minorities from voting.

headline: The Donald and Decadence
abstract: How Trump’s sort of populist nationalism differs from the European variety.
lead_paragraph: I tried to avoid the coals-to-Newcastle phenomenon that is Trump coverage this weekend by writing my Sunday column on immigration politics in Europe instead, with a particular focus on how the widening population differential on either side of the Mediterranean, already roiling European politics, is likely to create a kind of sweeping “Eurafrican” interaction over the next fifty years, with truly unknowable results. It’s a big topic, a lot bigger even than the yugeness of Trump … but there are, yes, links between the two phenomena, which my old friend Reihan Salam teased out a bit for Slate last week:

headline: 2 Who Parachuted Off World Trade Center Tower Avoid Jail Time
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Parachutes and Parachute Jumping']
abstract: Andrew Rossig and James Brady were fined $2,000 each and ordered to perform hundreds of hours of community service for their September 2013 leap.
lead_paragraph: Two men who parachuted off 1 World Trade Center avoided jail time when they were sentenced on Monday, but a judge fined them $2,000 each and ordered them to perform hundreds of hours of community service.

headline: A Disco-Driven Track Inspired by a Near-Death Experience
abstract: The Greek pop singer Monika wrote “Secret in the Dark” after surviving a sailing accident.
lead_paragraph: The story of the Greek pop singer Monika’s upcoming album, “Secret in the Dark,” begins in 2012, when, fresh from a trip stateside, she found the courage to end a rotten relationship. “Everyone feels imprisoned at one point in their life. Coming to New York really let me breathe,” she says. “My first two releases were pretty much just ballads. I was known in Greece for my deep, emotional side.” (She’s picked up significant steam in her homeland for her Florence Welch-reminiscent vocals, appearing on a spate of magazine covers and headlining each of its major music festivals.)

headline: Drawings of Police Torture Seize China’s Attention
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Torture', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A man wrongly convicted in a shooting death hired an artist to depict scenes of the police tactics he said were used to force him to confess to a crime he did not commit.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The hand-drawn images are bizarre and disturbing. One shows a man locked in a cage while a police officer pours boiling water on his head. Another shows him suspended from the ceiling by handcuffs as an officer jabs his side with an electric baton.

headline: Astronauts Eat Lettuce Grown in Space
abstract: On Monday, astronauts aboard the International Space Station harvested and ate the first lettuce to have been grown in space.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, astronauts aboard the International Space Station harvested and ate the first lettuce to have been grown in space.

headline: Travel Diary
abstract: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden share images from India, the second stop in their three-week trip around the world.
lead_paragraph: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden share images from India, the second stop in their three-week trip around the world.

lead_paragraph: The arrival of the Opera House Hotel in the South Bronx two years ago was a turning point for a poor corner of New York City.

headline: 1947: Flying Saucers Land in The Times
abstract: The term “flying saucer” appeared in The Times years before the infamous Roswell incident. Mark Bulik looks at those first mentions.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Ferlinghetti on Nagasaki
abstract: The poet entered Nagasaki a few weeks after it was bombed, and the experience made him a lifetime pacifist.
lead_paragraph: The horror of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki blasts, 70 years ago this month, is receding in human memory. With distance comes the peril of ignorance and indifference.

headline: Buffett’s Diverse Deals
abstract: The businesses Warren Buffett likes to acquire are also leaders in their industry, have stable management, and reliably produce lots of cash. Here are Berkshire’s five biggest deals, which all fit the mold.
