headline: ‘Black Chronicles II’ Exhibition in Cambridge Set for September
abstract: The exhibition will show recently discovered photographs of black subjects in Britain from the late 1800s to early 1900s.
lead_paragraph: “Black Chronicles II,” an exhibition of photographs of black subjects in Britain in the late 1800s to early 1900s, will be shown to an American audience for the first time starting Sept. 2 at the new Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African American Art in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: De Blasio Gives Legionnaires’ Update
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announces that no one has gotten sick from Legionnaires’ disease since Aug. 3, called it “a promising sign” while saying the death toll from the outbreak had reached 12.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announces that no one has gotten sick from Legionnaires’ disease since Aug. 3, called it “a promising sign” while saying the death toll from the outbreak had reached 12.

headline: Review: Ayn Rand’s ‘Ideal’ Presents a Protagonist Familiar in Her Superiority
abstract: This novel, written in 1934 and not published until now, features one of Rand’s Nietzschean characters, a pessimist alienated from a world she regards with disdain.
lead_paragraph: The movie-star heroine of Ayn Rand’s “Ideal” is a legendary, enigmatic beauty named Kay Gonda, paid a fortune by Hollywood for her work and worshiped by the faceless multitudes. Her press agent writes: “Kay Gonda does not cook her own meals or knit her own underwear. She does not play golf, adopt babies, or endow hospitals for homeless horses. She is not kind to her dear old mother — she has no dear old mother. She is not just like you and me. She never was like you and me. She’s like nothing you rotters ever dreamt of.”

headline: U.S. Air Power and Kurdish Fighters Team Up to Inflict Losses on ISIS
abstract: But Turkey is nervous about the coordination between the United States and the Kurds, who are seeking autonomy in parts of Turkey and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: But Turkey is nervous about the coordination between the United States and the Kurds, who are seeking autonomy in parts of Turkey and elsewhere.

headline: Review: In ‘Kevin From Work,’ Caricatures Are the Rule
abstract: This ABC Family comedy centers on Noah Reid’s lead character, who admits having feelings for a colleague whom he mistakenly thought he would never work with again.
lead_paragraph: It’s O.K. to make a deliberately dumb comedy; some people like them. But when your deliberately dumb comedy is populated by dimwitted, sex-obsessed women and its premiere is broadcast days after Donald Trump’s incendiary comment about Megyn Kelly of Fox News, it suddenly seems not just dumb but also regressive.

headline: No Trick: ‘Penn & Teller’ a Broadway Hit
abstract: The magic show is earning more than most of the musicals and plays on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: In one of their onstage illusions, Penn & Teller make coins appear in a fishbowl and hand them to an audience member.

headline: Frances Stark
abstract: No subject is off-limits in her uncompromising oeuvre, from sex chats to work anxieties.
lead_paragraph: No subject is off-limits in her uncompromising oeuvre, from sex chats to work anxieties.

headline: Warren Buffett Bucks Trends With Precision Castparts Acquisition
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway is paying $37.2 billion for the aircraft components maker, even though shares of Precision Castparts have tumbled 40 percent since last summer.
lead_paragraph: It could be said that Berkshire Hathaway’s latest multibillion-dollar deal — its biggest ever — lacks precision. Berkshire, Warren Buffett’s industrial empire, is paying $37.2 billion, including debt, for the aircraft components maker Precision Castparts. The acquisition fits Mr. Buffett’s mold, but coincides with cyclical highs in plane orders, stock valuations, and mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Shake Shack Reports Higher Quarterly Sales and Profits
abstract: Revenues for the hamburger chain founded by the restaurateur Danny Meyer were up 74.7 percent to $48.5 million.
lead_paragraph: Shake Shack, one of the many upstart burger chains that are redefining the American fast-food hamburger, reported  quarterly  sales on Monday that surpassed Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: A Guide to Museums Dedicated to Fashion Designers
abstract: There are shrines to Saint Laurent, Ferragamo, Gucci, Valentino Balenciaga and Dior.
lead_paragraph: There are shrines to Saint Laurent, Ferragamo, Gucci, Valentino Balenciaga and Dior.

headline: New Jersey Man Charged With Plotting to Support ISIS
abstract: Nader Saadeh, 20, who lived in Rutherford, N.J., until he left the United States in May, was charged with conspiracy and seeking to provide material aid to a terrorist group.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man who prosecutors said tried to organize support for the Islamic State was arrested on Monday.

headline: Housing for Homeless Veterans Is Planned for Ex-Walter Reed Site
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: A deal being negotiated by the city of Washington and the Army may give the shuttered Walter Reed Army Medical Center a renewed purpose.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The hallways of the former Walter Reed Army Medical Center, which cared for generations of soldiers, have been quiet since the hospital closed in 2011 and merged with the nearby Bethesda Naval Hospital. But a deal being negotiated by the Army and the city of Washington might give the historic hospital a renewed purpose: housing veterans who might otherwise be homeless.

headline: Review: In ‘Unknown Soldier,’ a War Echoes Through Generations
abstract: Michael Friedman and Daniel Goldstein’s new chamber musical examines a family’s past.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — About 10 million soldiers never came home from World War I. Many who did left something behind on those battlefields — skin, bone, spirit. In Michael Friedman and Daniel Goldstein’s affecting new musical, “Unknown Soldier,” which just closed a brief run at the Williamstown Theater Festival, an amnesiac in military dress (Derek Klena) is found in 1918, wandering around Grand Central Terminal without identifying papers. (The story seems inspired by an actual case that captivated postwar France.)

headline: Google to Reorganize as Alphabet to Keep Its Lead as an Innovator
abstract: Under the new name, Alphabet, the company is signaling that it has essentially become a collection of disparate businesses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google was founded as a company that did Internet search. Over time, it has broadened into areas as varied as drones, pharmaceuticals and venture capital, none of which make much money, and some of which have spooked investors.

headline: Ferguson Anniversary Protesters Arrested
abstract: Police in St. Louis arrested dozens of protesters, including the scholar and author Cornel West, as they gathered outside a courthouse on the one-year anniversary of the death of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Police in St. Louis arrested dozens of protesters, including the scholar and author Cornel West, as they gathered outside a courthouse on the one-year anniversary of the death of Michael Brown.

headline: Donald Trump Makes Up With Roger Ailes of Fox News
abstract: Donald J. Trump said on Monday that Roger Ailes, the chairman and chief executive of Fox News, called him and assured him that the network would treat him fairly.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump appears to be ready to let bygones be bygones — with Roger Ailes.

headline: Dior’s Exquisite New Bracelet
abstract: In the hands of Victoire de Castellane, something hard looks soft, something inert looks alive.
lead_paragraph: The very idea of a cuff can seem constraining, but Victoire de Castellane, the iconoclastic designer of Dior Fine Jewelry since 1998, has spun an exquisitely supple one. De Castellane spent her childhood admiring the sumptuous plissés and chiffons of her grandmother’s evening gowns, and this bracelet, from the Soie Dior collection — a play on the French for silk as well as on the words “be Dior” — captures the fluidity of fabric falling in folds. Platinum, pink and yellow gold and five sorts of precious stones undulate like silken ribbons; threads of gems cinch and bunch, loosen and flow; and stitches of baguettes give way to dazzling purple and pink sapphires that unfurl from the cushion-cut Mozambique ruby centerpiece, which clasps the strands. In the hands of the fearlessly quirky de Castellane, who has in the past riffed extravagantly on themes from Disney to Bollywood, something hard looks soft, something inert looks alive — a cuff deep with pleats and creases, as delicate as a charm bracelet in motion.

headline: Plan to Redraw Internal Districts in Nepal Prompts Violent Protest
abstract: Two people were killed and six wounded in clashes with the police over a proposal linked to the drafting of a new constitution.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Protests broke out across Nepal on Monday after four major political parties signed an agreement to divide the country into six provinces, a significant but contentious step toward creating a new constitution.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
abstract: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 10, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from the United States, Portugal, Greece and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, Portugal, Greece and Nepal.

headline: India’s Enduring Creative Spirit
abstract: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden met the people behind some of the country’s greatest exports.
lead_paragraph: Richard Christiansen, the founder of Chandelier Creative and Vanessa Holden, former senior vice president of West Elm, document their three-week trip around the world searching for creative inspiration exclusively for T.

headline: Born to Make Photos
abstract: Harry Gruyaert’s father made film. He makes pictures. His credo: “I just physically jump into a situation and react to it, and see how things are working out.”
lead_paragraph: Harry Gruyaert’s father made film. He makes pictures. His credo: “I just physically jump into a situation and react to it, and see how things are working out.”

headline: Yodlee, a Hub for Financial Apps, Sells Itself to Envestnet
abstract: Yodlee, a public company for less than a year, will give Envestnet, a software provider, a new tool to market to financial advisers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last fall, Yodlee, an online hub for consumer financial apps, went public after 15 years as a private company.

headline: Guggenheim Partners Pays $20 Million to Settle S.E.C. Charges
abstract: The settlement covers a charge brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the firm failed to disclose a $50 million loan from a client to an executive.
lead_paragraph: The investment arm of Guggenheim Partners has agreed to pay $20 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to disclose a $50 million loan by a client to one of its senior executives.

headline: Haruki Murakami’s Virtual Desk Tour, Lenny’s Head Start and an Instagram That Marries Art and Eats
abstract: All the places you should be hanging out online this week.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Our nightly rundown will get you caught up on the day’s big stories.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: The Moon Passed in Front of the Earth. Why Wasn’t There an Eclipse?
abstract: NASA explains why an animated image of the Moon crossing over the Earth wasn’t just someone being creative with Photoshop.
lead_paragraph: NASA explains why an animated image of the Moon crossing over the Earth wasn’t just someone being creative with Photoshop.

headline: From Hemingway to Miles Teller, a Brief History of the Tough Celebrity Profile
abstract: An article on a rising actor is part of a long, if infrequent, tradition of throwing out the usual niceties of the celebrity profile genre.
lead_paragraph: One can imagine the gatekeepers of Hollywood emailing the September Esquire cover article about the actor Miles Teller to their clients with a cautionary warning: “This is what happens when you run your mouth to a reporter.”

headline: Vail International Dance Festival Sets Itself Apart With an Enchanting Lineup
abstract: This festival featured a plenitude of dance talent while also showcasing several young performers who are still on their way to the top.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — After Friday’s International Evening of Dance here, a California friend, visiting Colorado for a few days, texted me to say: “Can’t believe I just saw that lineup! Amazing ballerinas Sara Mearns, Yuan Yuan Tan, Isabella Boylston, Linda Celeste Sims, and Tiler Peck on the same stage in one night!”

headline: With ‘Kill the Lights,’ Luke Bryan Downshifts a Country Party
abstract: The country star’s fifth studio album is his most mature, and he’s no longer playing spring break raves. What a drag.
lead_paragraph: Luke Bryan turned 39 last month, and it’s safe to surmise that his hips are getting tired. For the last few years, he’s been playing a young man’s game — his brand of country music is dynamic, attitudinal, a little goofy. There are flickers of hip-hop in his phrasing; at his shows, he struts atop a tricked-out pickup truck. His most successful single is called “Country Girl (Shake It for Me).”

headline: Man Charged in Bitcoin Scheme Appears in New York Court
abstract: Anthony Murgio, who is thought to have information about a cyberattack on JPMorgan Chase, appeared in court on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Murgio, a Florida man who was charged last month by federal prosecutors in Manhattan with running an illegal bitcoin money exchange firm and is thought to have information about last summer’s hacking attack against JPMorgan Chase, seemed to be taking the unfolding criminal case against him in stride during a court appearance on Monday morning.

headline: Review: Tanglewood Orchestra Celebrating Its 75th
abstract: Andris Nelsons conducted the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra in Mahler’s two-part, 90-minute Symphony No. 8 on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — In the late 1930s, when the Boston Symphony Orchestra started playing concerts in the open-air environs of Tanglewood in the Berkshire Mountains of western Massachusetts, Serge Koussevitzky, the ensemble’s visionary music director at the time, thought that presenting symphonic programs in an idyllic setting was a valuable enterprise.

headline: Style at the Apollo
abstract: Men discussed their fashion choices before a show in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Men discussed their fashion choices before a show in Harlem.

headline: Black Activists Arrested in Ferguson Protests
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Two high-profile activists were among 56 people arrested during a civil disobedience protest.
lead_paragraph: Two activists widely known on Twitter were among 57 people arrested Monday during a protest at the federal courthouse in downtown St. Louis.

headline: Review: The Academy of Ancient Music Tackled Mendelssohn at Mostly Mozart Festival
abstract: This ensemble, a period-instrument band, was delicate and electric at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Was that really the Academy of Ancient Music, playing so roughly, almost raucously at times, in Mendelssohn’s “Scottish” Symphony on Sunday? Yes, it was, and it was thrilling.

headline: Review: Diane Coburn Bruning and Ashley Bouder Stretch the Rules of Classicism at the Joyce
abstract: Ms. Bruning’s Chamber Dance Project featured a string quartet and small-scale works while the Ashley Bouder Project offered works by Joshua Beamish, Adriana Pierce and Andrea Schermoly.
lead_paragraph: Diane Coburn Bruning, a choreographer based in Washington, has long been a proponent of stretching the definition of classicism in contemporary ballet. Ashley Bouder, the prodigious New York City Ballet principal, is just getting started on that path as the producer (with Phil Chan) of the Ashley Bouder Project. Both are part of the Joyce Theater’s Ballet Festival, which continues through Sunday.

headline: La MaMa Announces Season of Premieres and Reimagined Classics
abstract: La MaMa announces a broad season ranging from classical Greek drama to puppetry.
lead_paragraph: A production of Euripides’ “Medea,” performed by actors with disabilities, as well as the world premiere of the last work from Mabou Mines’s founder are part of the coming season at La MaMa.

headline: Rand Paul Compares Donald Trump to ‘the Emperor With No Clothes’
abstract: Lagging in the polls, Senator Rand Paul laid into Donald J. Trump, calling him “a bully” and an “empty suit,” and adding, “Somebody has to challenge him.”
lead_paragraph: Lagging in the polls, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky set aside his right to privacy agenda on Monday afternoon to take up another cause: derailing Donald J. Trump.

headline: Gus Mortson, Scrappy All-Star for Toronto N.H.L. Champions, Dies at 90
abstract: Mortson teamed with Jim Thomson in a Maple Leafs pairing that was among the league’s toughest.
lead_paragraph: Gus Mortson, a pugnacious All-Star defenseman who played on four Stanley Cup championship teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the late 1940s and early ’50s, died on Saturday in Timmins, Ontario. He was 90.

headline: Review: Bard Festival Salutes Carlos Chávez
abstract: The festival examines the life and times of Carlos Chávez, the central figure in 20th-century Mexican music.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — In an article in 1940 in The New York Times the Mexican composer Carlos Chávez wrote that “the folk-music of a country influences in one way or another, but always substantially, the individual creations of great ‘learned’ composers.” The degree to which Mr. Chávez (1899-1978) integrated native and local traditions into his own works was a major theme of the Bard Music Festival, which opened last weekend at Bard College here.

headline: ‘Descendants’ Soundtrack Tops a Chart of Descending Sales
abstract: The soundtrack for the Disney Channel movie “Descendants” is No. 1 on the album chart with sales of just 30,000.
lead_paragraph: The soundtrack to “Descendants,” Disney Channel’s latest television movie, tops the Billboard chart this week, the latest example of music from TV and the movies going to No. 1. But its sales were the lowest for any No. 1 in 24 years.

headline: Chinese Christians Resist Government Plan to Remove Crosses
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Crosses and Crucifixes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: China’s campaign has provoked sometimes spectacular protests, including church members who have climbed spires to shield crosses.
lead_paragraph: Resistance is growing among China’s expanding Christian community to a government campaign to remove crosses from churches in a wealthy coastal province.

headline: Police Group’s ‘Darren Wilson Day’ Is Condemned
abstract: On the anniversary of Michael Brown’s death, a police officers’ association in Columbia, Mo., called Mr. Wilson “innocent, but persecuted.”
lead_paragraph: A police officers’ group in Columbia, Mo., proclaimed “Darren Wilson Day” on Sunday, the one-year anniversary of the officer’s fatal shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: Verbatim: ‘I Thought It Would Be Fun’
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she attended Donald Trump’s wedding in 2005 because she happened to be in town anyway and because “it is always entertaining.”
lead_paragraph: — Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaking in Exeter, N.H., after being asked at a news conference why she attended Donald J. Trump’s wedding in 2005.

headline: Rory McIlroy Says He’s ‘100 Percent’ for P.G.A. Championship
abstract: McIlroy, who ruptured ankle ligaments while playing soccer on July 4, said he would tee off in a much-anticipated Thursday grouping with Jordan Spieth and Zach Johnson.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — After he arrived at Whistling Straits for practice rounds last week, Rory McIlroy said he expected to play in Thursday’s first round of the P.G.A. Championship, despite rupturing ankle ligaments while playing soccer with friends July 4.

headline: Billy Sherrill, Producer, Dies at 78; Promoted a ‘Countrypolitan’ Sound
abstract: Mr. Sherrill helped kick-start the career of Tammy Wynette, breathed new life into a declining George Jones and helped infuse country music with the spirit of 1960s pop.
lead_paragraph: Billy Sherrill, who as a songwriter, record producer and executive helped kick-start the career of Tammy Wynette, breathed new life into a declining George Jones and was an architect of the so-called countrypolitan sound, which applied the tenets of 1960s pop maximalism to country music, died on Aug. 4 at his home in Nashville. He was 78.

headline: Democrats Offer Ways to Make College Affordable
abstract: Young Americans buried by student loans want fresh thinking from presidential candidates on the crisis.
lead_paragraph: A college education is a basic requirement for many middle-class jobs, but it is increasingly harder to afford. That is why every presidential candidate needs to explain what he or she will do to make higher education attainable for more Americans without them having to take on crippling amounts of debt.

headline: Test Yourself: 6 Questions From a Third-Grade Reading Test
abstract: Read a passage from the third-grade reading test called “Secrets Are Hard to Keep” and answer the six questions that students were tested on.
lead_paragraph: Read a passage from the third-grade reading test called “Secrets Are Hard to Keep” and answer the six questions that students were tested on.

headline: New York State Test Questions Tricky for 3rd Graders, and Maybe Some Adults
abstract: Many questions and answers from this year’s third- through eighth-grade tests were publicly released to show parents the kind of work their children were expected to do.
lead_paragraph: The East African fable goes like this: A man frees a snake that is trapped between two rocks, and as a reward the snake gives him a charm that will allow him to hear what animals say, but only if the man keeps it a secret. The man betrays his new power by giggling at the things he hears, arousing his wife’s curiosity. He eventually tells her about the charm, and it stops working.

headline: Want a Real Old White House Memento? Warning: It Won’t Be Cheap
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Auctions', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A previously unknown piece of ornamental wood from the White House of Abraham Lincoln and John Quincy Adams is about to hit the auction market and could fetch $500,000.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Theodore Roosevelt hired an architecture firm to renovate the dark, cramped White House in 1902, much of the structural interior was thrown into piles of trash on the lawn outside: 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue had become a construction site. Wood, plaster, glass and even old curtains were strewn about, leaving the once stately grounds in a heap of “dirt and confusion,” as an article in The New York Times put it.

headline: The Big Five: Africa's Most Sought-After Trophy Animals
abstract: The Big Five animals hunted for sport, their conservation status according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Red List and the market rates that a trophy demands in South Africa, home to the biggest hunting industry on the continent.
lead_paragraph: The Big Five animals hunted for sport, their conservation status according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Red List and the market rates that a trophy demands in South Africa, home to the biggest hunting industry on the continent.

headline: Outcry for Cecil the Lion Could Undercut Conservation Efforts
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Lions', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Trophy hunting, which has been viewed under a harsh public spotlight since the killing of Cecil, a lion in Zimbabwe, is part of a complex economy that is an effective method of conservation, many wildlife experts contend.
lead_paragraph: OLIFANTSVLEI, South Africa — Before the two hunters from Texas had breakfast, Stewart Dorrington drove through his 12,000-acre game ranch. As the early-morning sun cast a soft glow on the landscape, turned a wintry pale brown, buffalo wandered in the tall grass and giraffes appeared in a cluster of trees.

headline: Delays for N.J. Transit Train Riders May Become ‘Norm,’ Amtrak Official Warns
abstract: The proposed Gateway project would create a new tunnel and allow for the projected doubling in the number of train commuters, Stephen Gardner told New Jersey legislators.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Train problems like those that stranded commuters several days last month may become “the norm,” an Amtrak executive told state legislators here on Monday, as aging tunnels increasingly require repairs, passenger demand grows and lawmakers cannot agree on how to pay for a new tunnel under the Hudson River to ease the burden.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Donald Trump’s ‘Outrageous’ Comments Are Part of a Republican Theme
abstract: “While what Donald Trump said about Megyn Kelly is outrageous; what the rest of the Republicans are saying about all women is also outrageous,” Ms. Clinton said after an event in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: EXETER, N.H. — Hillary Rodham Clinton had planned to spend her campaign stop at a high school here on Monday focusing mainly on her plan to make college more affordable. But, like most candidates for president, she also had to take questions about the latest headline-grabbing comments from Donald J. Trump.

headline: Separate Briefings, and Findings, on Legionnaires’ Disease Outbreak
abstract: In a communication breakdown later attributed to a missed voice mail message, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio appeared to present conflicting information at simultaneous events.
lead_paragraph: The outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx continued to show signs of waning on Monday. But the maneuvering between state and city officials seemed far from over.

headline: With Google as Alphabet, a Bid to Dream Big Beyond Search
abstract: From Google’s start, Larry Page has been afflicted with a desire for two competing corporate virtues: focus and expansiveness.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Shortly after its founding, Google posted a document on its site called “Ten things we know to be true,” an effort to distill its unusual corporate culture into a succinct list of prescriptions — the 10 commandments of Googliness. Among the most-quoted of Google’s big thoughts has been that corporations should “do one thing really, really well.” Google’s one thing, the document said, was obvious: “We do search.”

headline: Game Publisher’s Lawsuit Against Oculus Moves Forward
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Headphones and Headsets', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: A federal judge has refused to throw out a lawsuit filed by a games publisher accusing Oculus VR of stealing trade secrets and code in the creation of the Oculus virtual reality headset.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has refused to throw out a lawsuit filed by a games publisher accusing Oculus VR of stealing trade secrets and code in the creation of the Oculus virtual-reality headset.

headline: At Whistling Straits, Golfers Will Have to Go Against the Grains
abstract: P.G.A. Championship officials have said that, as in 2010, when Dustin Johnson was assessed a controversial penalty, the roughly 1,000 sand patches strewn about the property are again bunkers.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — The notorious Dustin Johnson bunker at Whistling Straits is gone. The rule that made the bunker famous five years ago remains.

headline: Primaries in Argentina Point to a Close Presidential Race
abstract: Daniel Scioli beat his main rival, Mauricio Macri, by eight points in an all-party primary, but it proved close enough to raise uncertainty over who would prevail in October.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The future of Argentine politics was fuzzy on Monday after an all-party presidential primary, billed as a measure of the nation’s desire for change, proved close enough to cast doubt on who would prevail in general elections.

headline: Arrested in Ferguson Last Year, 2 Reporters Are Charged
abstract: Arrested while covering the protests in Ferguson, Mo., in August 2014, reporters for the Washington Post and Huffington Post face trespassing charges.
lead_paragraph: Two reporters who were arrested while covering the protests in Ferguson, Mo., last August, were charged with trespassing and interfering with a police officer, their outlets said on Monday.

headline: Sundar Pichai Will Lead Google With Users in Mind
abstract: The newly appointed chief executive owes his new job to his success in making Google products easier to use and thus more popular.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The technology industry is partial to dramatic, sometimes blustery, often larger-than-life top executives. Sundar Pichai will have to work hard to be ranked among that colorful crew. He sent news of his ascension to the top slot at Google — he is just the third person to officially run the search company — on Twitter, very obliquely.

headline: Marin Cilic Struggles to Get Back Into Zone After U.S. Open Success
abstract: As the No. 14 seed last year, Cilic claimed his first Grand Slam title. But since then, he has been bothered by a shoulder injury and has yet to reach the final of any tournament.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After two hours of intense practice in the lingering afternoon heat here last week at the Citi Open, Marin Cilic finished with a series of sprints. From one baseline to the other, he went faster when fading away would have made more sense.

headline: Lawrence Lessig to Explore a Run for President as a Democrat
abstract: Mr. Lessig, the Harvard professor and democratic theorist, said he would explore a protest bid for the Democratic nomination if he can raise $1 million in small donations by Labor Day, and would tie his campaign to the issue of empowering small donors in politics.
lead_paragraph: Some people land gyrocopters on the lawn at the Capitol to protest big money in politics. Lawrence Lessig, the Harvard professor and democratic theorist, is thinking of running for president.

headline: David Nobbs, Novelist and Creator of Reginald Perrin, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Nobbs, a British novelist and comedy writer, was best known for “The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin,” the dark BBC sitcom of the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: David Nobbs, a British novelist and comedy writer best known for “The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin,” the dark BBC sitcom of the 1970s that won an ardent following on both sides of the Atlantic, died on Saturday in Harrogate, England. He was 80.

headline: A French Couple’s Love for the American West Ends in Tragedy
abstract: David and Ornella Steiner were found dead in a New Mexico desert last week. Their 9-year-old son survived, likely because they sacrificed water to save him.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The family from France was so enthralled by their last visit to the American West that they started planning another almost immediately. On Facebook, they posted pictures of the vast blue skies, the rugged ocher canyons and the endless strips of asphalt that had captivated them.

headline: Alphabet Wordplay, a Hooli ‘Easter Egg’ and More on Google’s Name Change
abstract: With wordplay and references to the Google parody from the HBO series “Silicon Valley,” the company formerly known as Google Inc. captured the imagination and curiosity of the Internet with its reorganization on Monday.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Google announced that it was changing the name of the company to Alphabet, creating a structure that would encompass multiple parts. The search engine division will be separate from some of the more futuristic parts of the company, such as an anti-aging biotech firm and the lab that builds self-driving cars.

headline: Stock Buybacks Draw Scrutiny From Politicians
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Hillary Clinton and others are asking whether there’s a need for greater regulation of stock buybacks, on which companies have spent $7 trillion since 2004.
lead_paragraph: Should corporate stock buybacks be regulated? Or made illegal?

headline: Review: ‘Cymbeline’ Unspools Its Many Plot Twists at the Delacorte Theater
abstract: This Shakespeare in the Park production stars Lily Rabe and Hamish Linklater as a couple torn apart and then reunited.
lead_paragraph: Not one but two gilt prosceniums currently adorn the normally proscenium-free Delacorte Theater in Central Park, where the Public Theater is presenting “Cymbeline,” Shakespeare’s weird and wonder-filled late romance, as its second offering of the free summer season. Piled around the outer proscenium are crates, boxes and odd bits of statuary, vaguely suggesting that we are in a disused theater of some advanced age, filled with odd props.

headline: Messy Sandwich Filler
abstract: Jay Kaskel and Daniel Kantor are making me hungry.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — If you are at all suggestible and you happen to be on a diet, you might want to skip this puzzle. There be calories galore ahead.

headline: Mets Top Rockies as Michael Cuddyer Comes Off D.L., and Sits
abstract: While Cuddyer was out with a knee injury, the Mets acquired three veterans, and a top prospect earned their trust. So Cuddyer, even while earning $8.5 million this year, could become a bench player.
lead_paragraph: Michael Cuddyer arrived at work Monday as an active member of the Mets for the first time in about two and a half weeks, and found that his old position had been effectively filled. In that time, the Mets had acquired three veteran position players, the top prospect Michael Conforto had earned their trust, and they had propelled themselves into the playoff race.

headline: Megyn Kelly Says She Won’t Be Cowed by Donald Trump
abstract: “This is a tough business,” the Fox News host told viewers, brushing off the candidate’s comments, “and it’s time now to move forward.”
lead_paragraph: Megyn Kelly opened her Fox News program on Monday night by addressing the uproar over Donald J. Trump’s personal attacks on her, her first comments since he made a remark that many interpreted as a reference to her menstrual cycle.

headline: David Wright Looks Good in First Rehab Start
abstract: Wright, wearing his Mets helmet while playing in a game for the first time since April 14, went 1 for 3 with a walk as the designated hitter for Class A St. Lucie.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Standing in the St. Lucie Mets’ clubhouse on Monday night, with a large pack of ice pressed against his lower back, David Wright kept glancing at a television. It was showing the Mets’ game against the Colorado Rockies at Citi Field, and the Mets were leading, 4-2.

headline: China Devalues Its Currency as Worries Rise About Economic Slowdown
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The move appeared to be a response to signs that the economy was slowing too fast for comfort and could raise tensions with trading partners like the United States.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As China contends with an economic slowdown and a stock market slump, the authorities on Tuesday sharply devalued the country’s currency, the renminbi, a move that could raise geopolitical tensions and weigh on growth elsewhere.

headline: Stephen Colbert’s Plans for His New Show, and a Prayer for Trump
abstract: Stephen Colbert, the new host of “The Late Show” on CBS, says he’s eager to get back onstage and jokingly shared his hopes regarding Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Stephen Colbert discussed his plans for his new late-night show for the first time Monday — as well as his restlessness about being off the air and the challenges of breaking from the satirical character he’s played for years.

headline: Big Game Hunting Is Also Big Business for Wealthy Few
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: The killing of Cecil the lion has shed a spotlight on safari hunts, an elite pursuit with a price tag of tens of thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: An American dentist’s recent killing of a lion named Cecil in Zimbabwe sparked public outrage, but it largely obscured the fact that big game hunting is also a big business in which animals are regularly pursued.

headline: All Emails Were Provided, Hillary Clinton Says in Statement
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said that she had given the State Department all of the work-related emails that were on the personal account she used while she was secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton said in a statement filed under oath in federal court on Monday that she had provided to the State Department all of the work-related emails that were on the personal email account she used exclusively while she was secretary of state.

headline: Back in Black
abstract: This season, there’s more than one way to wear a smoky eye.
lead_paragraph: This season, there’s more than one way to wear a smoky eye.

headline: Square-Toed Heels With Broad Appeal
abstract: The new daytime shoe isn't overtly sexy, but it is sharp enough to bring order to a midcalf skirt, cropped pants or even a flared mini.

headline: Lizzy Caplan’s Long, Embroidered Valentino Skirt
abstract: The actress wore a chic skirt and crop top last night.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Lizzy Caplan

headline: A Summery Sashimi Salad and Chrysanthemum Cocktail From New Jersey
abstract: Elements shares recipes for seasonal, local dishes from its opening night menu.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, the New Jersey chef Scott Anderson opened the doors to Princeton’s Mistral Bar, the spirituous neighbor of his year-old Witherspoon Street bistro Mistral. Inside, university professors and foodie types congregate for effervescent cocktails fizzy with homegrown kombuchas and irreverent bar snacks like beef tendon chicharrones dappled with marrow creme. And this evening, in a hidden corner of Mistral Bar, a newly installed elevator will deliver diners to a relocated Elements, the acclaimed haute seasonal restaurant Anderson and co-owner Steve Distler had operated on nearby Bayard Lane since 2008.

headline: In Japan, History Has No Place
abstract: Despite its reverence for tradition, Japan has an ambivalent — and unsentimental — relationship with its Modernist architecture. Why preparing for the future sometimes means destroying the past.
lead_paragraph: Despite its reverence for tradition, Japan has an ambivalent — and unsentimental — relationship with its Modernist architecture. Why preparing for the future sometimes means destroying the past.

headline: High Tech Hope for Repelling Mosquitoes
abstract: Kid-safe bands with plant oils, chemically treated clothes and bug spray offer some protection, but a new patch may finally confound this nemesis.
lead_paragraph: In Alaska, where I grew up, mosquitoes outnumber people some 24 million to one. That makes it a great place to test the very latest in mosquito shields.

headline: Word of the Day | bantering
abstract: This word has appeared in 18 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: bantering • \ˈban-tə-riN\ • adjective

headline: Japan Restarts Reactor, Lifting 2-Year Ban Prompted by Fukushima Accident
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)']
abstract: The reactor at the Sendai Nuclear Power Plant, in Kagoshima prefecture, is the first to return to service.

headline: What’s On TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:05 P.M. (Encore) BUTCH CASSIDY AND THE SUNDANCE KID (1969) Does it get any prettier than this? Robert Redford and Paul Newman (above right, with Mr. Redford) star as the famous Wild West outlaws on the lam (destination: Bolivia), with Katharine Ross as the woman who sets their hearts aflutter. The soundtrack to their lives: Burt Bacharach’s Oscar-winning score, featuring “Raindrops Keep Fallin’ on My Head,” which won for best original song, written with Hal David. Much of the movie “is very funny in a strictly contemporary way — the last exuberant word on movies about the men of the mythic American West who have outlived their day,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. And while there are “some bothersome technical things about the movie (the camera is all zoom, zoom, zoom),” he added, “the overall production is very handsome, and the performances fine, especially Newman, Redford and Miss Ross, who must be broadly funny and straight, almost simultaneously. They succeed even if the movie does not.”

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Plan for Affordable Housing
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Land Use Policies', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Zoning', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: With a new rezoning plan, Mayor Bill de Blasio hopes to spur the creation of permanent affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has unveiled another part of his ambitious plan to save New York City — a proposal to use land-use regulations to spur the creation of large amounts of permanently affordable housing. He wants to use a tactic called mandatory inclusionary zoning  in which as neighborhoods or specific parcels are rezoned, developers who want to build there would have to set aside at least 25 to 30 percent of new apartments for people of low and moderate incomes. They could not opt out, and the affordability would be permanent.

headline: Why Group Therapy Worked
abstract: One-on-one treatment was fascinating. But I needed to change.
lead_paragraph: I first entered individual therapy in the late 1980s, in Manhattan. Once a week for six years I strolled happily northward up Columbus Avenue from my apartment to my therapist’s office in the West 90s. Our sessions were a high point of my week. And why not? I got 50 minutes of undivided attention from a smart, empathetic professional, there to help me find out who I was and to address the old malaise that brought me to her door. “Narcissistic injury,” I learned to call it.

abstract: This short documentary chronicles the ordeal of three mountain climbers attempting one of the most elusive first ascents in the Himalayas.
lead_paragraph: The mission of professional mountain climbers is almost impossibly difficult by design: Their very livelihood is based on achieving the unprecedented. Their expeditions are complicated, exhausting, often life-threatening. Risk is the fuel that keeps them going.

abstract: In what ways has Ferguson changed for the better, according to the article? In what ways has the city stayed the same?

headline: ‘The Hairdresser of Harare,’ by Tendai Huchu
abstract: The trials of daily life in Zimbabwe.
lead_paragraph: Warning of the dangers of what she calls “the single story” about any given place or people, the Nigerian novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie says that it “creates stereotypes, and the problem with stereotypes is not that they are untrue, but that they are incomplete.” Too often in the United States, we have created a single narrative about foreign countries, particularly African countries: They’re impoverished and war-torn and beset by disease or, more benignly, simply teeming with exotic animals.

headline: ‘In the Language of Miracles,’ by Rajia Hassib
abstract: An Egyptian immigrant family struggles in their suburban community after their son kills a neighbor’s daughter.
lead_paragraph: What happens to a family when one of its members perpetrates an unspeakable act of violence? How do you grieve for a loved one who has committed both murder and suicide? How does the local community react? What if the family in question is Muslim? Is that a game changer? Are you wondering if Islamic ideology, extremists and terrorists are at the heart of this story? You are not alone.

headline: A Remade Medellín, Colombia, Shows Off Its Style
abstract: Nowhere is this city’s shift from drug capital to forward-looking metropolis more apparent than the chic El Poblado neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The Colombian city of Medellín has gone through a drastic transformation from drug capital to forward-looking metropolis. This is especially true of the chic El Poblado neighborhood, where the streets are crowded with designer boutiques, cafes and restaurants with ample outdoor seating — because, well, there’s no reason to sit inside. Locals are extremely proud of the neighborhood’s progress in bringing global style to Colombia while maintaining local flair. The city’s perennially comfortable weather and luscious natural habitat have a decided influence on the way people dress, from airy fabrics to colorful prints. “The way people dress in this part of Colombia is all about layers,” said Amelia Ochoa, who was recently spotted in the neighborhood. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Welcome to Liberland, the World’s Newest Country (Maybe)
abstract: Travels with Vit Jedlicka, the would-be founding father of a libertarian paradise.
lead_paragraph: Along the western bank of the Danube, more or less halfway between Zagreb and Belgrade, there rests in historic obscurity a three-square-mile teardrop of no man’s land. It is an artifact of a border dispute of long standing, and neither Serbia nor Croatia expresses a desire to rule over this unprepossessing Gibraltar-size property. The land, marshy and prone to seasonal inundation, is choked with unregulated scrub, with here and there the lone tongue of a poplar or the gentle shag of a willow. The only road is a rutted single-lane dirt track, the only existing dwelling a flimsy hunting hovel, its provenance unknown.

headline: How ‘Rock Star’ Became a Business Buzzword
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'English Language', 'Music', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Rock Music']
abstract: Like most things that were once cool because they positioned themselves against the mainstream, the rebel musician has been thoroughly co-opted.
lead_paragraph: Once, a long time ago, a rock star was a free-spirited, convention-flouting artist/rebel/hero/Dionysian fertility god who fronted a world-famous band, sold millions of records and headlined stadium concerts where people were trampled in frenzies of cultlike fervor. Someone who smashed guitars, trashed hotel rooms, developed Byzantine drug problems and tried to mask evidence of his infidelity with the strategically applied scent of breakfast burritos. Despite what his ‘‘Behind the Music’’ episode would invariably reveal, a ‘‘rock star’’ — or the Platonic ideal of a rock star — was not just a powder keg of charisma and unresolved childhood issues, but a revolutionary driven by a need to assert the primacy of the self in an increasingly alienating commercial world.

headline: 1890: Sky Streaked With Meteors
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A meteor shower lights up the sky over Paris in 1890.
lead_paragraph: A rain of meteors that streaked the sky with hundreds of fiery trails kept thousands of Parisians on the rooftops last night. It was a strange and fascinating sight. The absence of moonlight lent greater brilliancy to the huge bodies as they flashed through the starry sky and vanished. Many persons had provided themselves with telescopes after reading that the August shower of the Perseid group could be seen, but no lens, however powerful, could add to the silent grandeur of what could be seen with the naked eye. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 12, 1890

abstract: The revelation is significant as the first from Dutch investigators to link physical evidence with a specific type of missile system, a Russian-made Buk surface-to-air system.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Prosecutors in the Netherlands revealed on Tuesday that they had found what could be pieces of a Russian-made surface-to-air missile system in eastern Ukraine, in the area of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

headline: Dreams of a Hip, High-Tech Sacramento Hinge on Kings’ New Home Court
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Basketball', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Golden 1 Center is the nexus for renovation and new construction that many hope will turn the capital’s downtown into a hot spot.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — When it opens for the Sacramento Kings’ first home basketball game, the Golden 1 Center — which will have the capacity to hold 17,500 fans and is designed with online graphic and social media interfaces — will be more than the newest and most technologically advanced arena in the National Basketball Association.

headline: Moments Before Texas Dealership Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: In this edited video released on Monday, Christian Taylor, an unarmed football player from Arlington, Tex., is seen in the moments before he was shot dead by a police officer at a car dealership.
lead_paragraph: In this edited video released on Monday, Christian Taylor, an unarmed football player from Arlington, Tex., is seen in the moments before he was shot dead by a police officer at a car dealership.

headline: Neighborhood Car Service Companies Adopt Their Own Apps to Fend Off Uber
abstract: After years of proud independence, some companies are joining forces, powered by an app, to create a car service network in hopes of fighting expanding ride-hailing companies.
lead_paragraph: The chatty, frenetic dispatch hubs of neighborhood car services are getting quieter.

headline: With Roll of the Dice, Buddy Baker Got Lone Daytona 500 Win
abstract: The racecar driver, who died Monday at 74, won the Daytona 500 on his 18th attempt after taking on less gas than usual to save a few seconds during his final pit stop.
lead_paragraph: Buddy Baker, the folksy storyteller of Nascar broadcasts, was known as the Gentle Giant. But during his racing career he was famed for his daring, notably in his only win in the Daytona 500.

headline: Why Did China Devalue Its Currency? Two Big Reasons
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The nation wanted to keep its economy on an even keel, but it is also looking to assert more leadership in the global economy.
lead_paragraph: HERE are two things that China’s government wants very badly: first, for its economy to remain on an even keel, keeping growth and employment high. Second, for its currency, the renminbi, to become globally pre-eminent, helping promote the country’s diplomatic goals and solidifying the country’s centrality to the global economy.

headline: Alphabet? Google Might Get Some Letters
abstract: Alphabet is Google’s new entity that will house its search and other units, but other businesses — including a BMW subsidiary — have already staked a claim on the name.
lead_paragraph: One can only assume that before Larry Page and Sergey Brin chose Alphabet as the name for their new holding company, they Googled it.

headline: Struggling to Stay Connected When a Spouse Deploys
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Marriages', 'Parenting', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: How did we go from long talks, fingers intertwined, to miles apart and discussing appliances?
lead_paragraph: Six minutes. We had my husband on the phone for six minutes. Long enough for our 4-year-old to tell him about the pet caterpillar she adopted and for our 3-year-old to answer a few questions about swim lessons. Before it was my turn, it was time for him to go. Slightly defeated, I heard myself pouting, “I didn’t even get to talk to you!” He offered a rushed, albeit sincere apology, and just as quickly, he was gone.

headline: Clinton Details Plan for Student Loans
abstract: At an event in Exeter, N.H., on Monday, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton outlined her vision for making college more affordable.
lead_paragraph: At an event in Exeter, N.H., on Monday, Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton outlined her vision for making college more affordable.

headline: Réunion, Once a Surfer’s Paradise, Finds Only Sharks in Its Waters
abstract: At least 18 people have been attacked since 2011, and seven have been killed. The government responded with a controversial ban on nearly all surfing and swimming.
lead_paragraph: ST.-LEU, Réunion — “To see the perfect wave and not be able to surf,” Nicolas Dantec said, shaking his head. “It is too difficult.”

headline: Jeb Bush Says Hillary Clinton ‘Stood By’ as Iraq Descended Into Violence
abstract: Jeb Bush will deliver a foreign policy speech on Tuesday, when he is expected to say Hillary Rodham Clinton “stood by” as secretary of state when the situation in Iraq deteriorated, creating the conditions that led to the rise of ISIS.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jeb Bush is planning to issue a full-throttle attack Tuesday night on the Obama administration’s handling of Iraq and terrorism issues, asserting that Hillary Rodham Clinton “stood by” as secretary of state when the situation in Iraq deteriorated, creating the conditions that led to the rise of the Islamic State as the Obama administration reduced its troop level in Iraq.

headline: Building the Next New York Times Recommendation Engine
abstract: Alexander Spangher discusses recent work that’s been done to revamp our article recommendation algorithm.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times publishes over 300 articles, blog posts and interactive stories a day.

headline: Beckham Defends Daughter’s Pacifier, Stirring Parenting Debate
abstract: David Beckham, the global soccer star, defended his 4-year-old’s use of a pacifier after a photo led to parental criticism.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Mail, a British tabloid, published a photograph over the weekend of David Beckham’s 4-year-old daughter, Harper, with a pacifier in her mouth in an article questioning whether it was appropriate for a child to still be using one at that age.

headline: Michael Brown Protesters Block I-70
abstract: The police arrested dozens of people on Monday after protesters blocked a highway in Missouri during demonstrations organized to remember Michael Brown’s death at the hands of an officer a year ago.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested dozens of people on Monday after protesters blocked a highway in Missouri during demonstrations organized to remember Michael Brown’s death at the hands of an officer a year ago.

headline: Australia’s Leader Details Climate Goals
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia outlined his country’s plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions between 26 and 28 percent from 2005 levels by 2030.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia outlined his country’s plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions between 26 and 28 percent from 2005 levels by 2030.

headline: Iraqi Parliament Backs Overhaul of Government
abstract: The elimination of several high-level positions and sectarian quotas in political appointments is meant to transform Iraq’s corrupt political system, but it could further alienate Sunnis.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s Parliament unanimously passed measures on Tuesday that are meant to transform the country’s corrupt political system. Yet by eliminating several high-level positions and doing away with sectarian quotas in political appointments, the measures risk further alienating the country’s Sunni minority while the government is struggling to defeat the Sunni militants of the Islamic State.

headline: Additional Charges in Insider Trading Scheme
abstract: A federal grand jury in Brooklyn charged four people with using stolen news releases to profit on information before it was made public.
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury in Brooklyn charged four people with using stolen news releases to profit on information before it was made public.

headline: In a Shift, Rite Aid to Accept Apple and Google Mobile Payments
abstract: The pharmacy chain is the latest retailer to accept the mobile payments, which involve little more than waving a phone to conduct a transaction.
lead_paragraph: Rite Aid, the nationwide pharmacy and retail chain, announced on Tuesday it would accept smartphone payments from Apple and Google, two of the largest players in mobile wallet technology, beginning this weekend.

headline: She May Be Small, but Kaci Lickteig (the Pixie Ninja) Is a Giant in Ultrarunning
abstract: Lickteig has defied her geography (the flat plains of the Midwest) and her background (she barely ran as a teenager) to emerge as one of the country’s top female ultramarathoners.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Kaci Lickteig, in her creative efforts to mimic various mountain ranges that are not native to Nebraska, does some of her most important training here on a nondescript stretch of road that she calls Pacific Hill.

headline: Tea and Trumpism
abstract: Revolt of the angry, affluent white guys.
lead_paragraph: Memo to pollsters: while I’m having as much fun as everyone else watching the unsinkable Donald defy predictions of his assured collapse, what I really want to see at this point is a profile of his supporters. What characteristics predispose someone to like this guy, as opposed to accepting the establishment candidates?

lead_paragraph: A brasserie fit for Bruce Wayne in Midtown.

headline: Donald Trump Gets Mixed News in New Iowa Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s remained the favorite in Iowa, according to a new Suffolk University poll, but the survey also showed less confidence from potential Republican caucusgoers in his ability to be president.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s erratic debate performance last week did not undo his standing as the favorite in Iowa, according to a poll released Tuesday from Suffolk University, but it did damage the confidence that potential Republican caucusgoers have in his ability to be president.

headline: Restaurant Review: Chevalier in Midtown
abstract: The new French restaurant in Midtown where luxury comes with a Baccarat heritage.
lead_paragraph: “What’s the matter?” my dinner companion asked one night at Chevalier, the luxurious new French restaurant in Midtown at the base of the Baccarat Hotel & Residences New York. “You look like you just saw a ghost.”

headline: Martha Graham Dance Company Will Revisit Classics for 90th Anniversary
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company will celebrate its 90th-anniversary season in April at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: The Martha Graham Dance Company will celebrate its 90th-anniversary season next year by dancing some of Graham’s most celebrated works, including “Appalachian Spring,” as well as new choreography by Marie Chouinard, Mats Ek, and Pontus Lidberg, the company said Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: TKTK

headline: Marco Rubio, Amid Soaring Moments, Sticks to Steady Course
abstract: He has often raised expectations before retreating into the background for stretches during his presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida earned glowing praise and predictions about how formidable a contender he would be when he announced his run for the White House in April. Then he disappeared on a two-month fund-raising trip.

headline: Data on Use of Force by Police Across U.S. Proves Almost Useless
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: In a Justice Department survey, some departments said they did not know how many times their officers had used force, and some simply refused to say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Justice Department surveyed police departments nationwide in 2013, officials included for the first time a series of questions about how often officers used force.

headline: 1940: British Fight Off 400 Raiders
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain fights off a Nazi attack on its coast in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Out of a cloud-checked Sabbath sky over the English Channel, 400 Nazi warplanes struck yesterday at the British south coast naval bases of Portland and Weymouth, at balloon defense on the southeast coast in Kent and at a convoy. Two hundred German craft attacked Portland and Weymouth at one time. At 11:30 p.m., the Air Ministry said reports received up to 9 p.m. showed that sixty enemy planes had been shot down, five of them by anti-aircraft fire. The Ministry also raised the total of British losses from its first report of nineteen fighter planes lost to twenty-six, but said the pilots of two were saved. — New York Herald Tribune, August 12, 1940

headline: Workers Stage Strike at National Gallery in London
abstract: A dispute over privatization of some services leads to a strike at the National Gallery in London, which says it will remain open.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Around 200 staff members at the National Gallery here went on an indefinite strike Tuesday in a dispute over the gallery’s plans to privatize some of its services.

headline: S.E.C. Complaint in Hacker-Insider Trading Case
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that defendants made trades based on illegally obtained information and reaped over $100 million in unlawful profits.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission said that defendants made trades based on illegally obtained information and reaped over $100 million in unlawful profits.

headline: NBC ‘Nightly News’ Holds Lead in Fight for Viewers
abstract: The network’s evening news broadcast, drew an average of 7.8 million total nightly viewers during the week of Aug. 3, more than ABC’s “World News Tonight” and CBS’s “Evening News.”
lead_paragraph: Six months after Brian Williams was suspended without pay from his position as the anchor of NBC’s “Nightly News” show, the broadcast has held its lead in the fierce battle for viewers.

headline: Grilled Halloumi for a Light Summer Meal
abstract: Making a dish of this grilled or fried cheese and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Halloumi is a firm, white, brined cheese traditionally made from a mixture of goat’s and sheep’s milk. (Though today, cow’s milk is often used.) Like other low-fat cheeses, it is perfect for grilling. It sears and colors quickly when it hits the hot grill. The interior softens, but the cheese doesn’t melt; it just warms up invitingly.

headline: From Underarm Hair to Summer Turtlenecks, Styles Trends Are Hot
abstract: The Monocle Meter gets a workout from stories some saw as disgusting, but many readers talked about.
lead_paragraph: At the end of last year, I published a list of what I would like to see happen at The Times in 2015. Because I was having a little fun with the listicle format, which seems to require an odd, preferably prime, number in its title, I called it “17 Hopes and Dreams for The Times in the New Year.”

headline: Seth Meyers Decides to Take a Seat to Deliver His ‘Late Night’ Monologue
abstract: Mr. Meyers is the first of his broadcast network peers to dispense with the stand-up comedy monologue, substituting instead a format that more closely resembles “Weekend Update” on “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: When audience members at Monday’s broadcast of “Late Night” finished applauding and took their seats, the host Seth Meyers did something unusual: He sat down, too.

headline: Geno Smith Is Sucker-Punched in the Latest Bizarre Blow to the Jets
abstract: Jets Coach Todd Bowles said Smith, the team’s starting quarterback, was punched in the locker room by linebacker Ikemefuna Enemkpali. Smith will need surgery on a broken jaw.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It had been nearly two weeks since absurdity befell the Jets, an epoch in their tormented history.

headline: China’s Currency Dilemma
abstract: If China doesn’t allow the market to set the exchange rates for the renminbi, it can’t expect it to be considered a global currency.
lead_paragraph: China’s decision to devalue its currency, the renminbi, by 2 percent against the dollar on Tuesday is intended to give its slowing economy a boost. But the decision is likely to be seen by lawmakers in the United States and elsewhere as currency manipulation to increase Chinese exports at the expense of producers in other countries.

headline: Palestinian Prisoner’s Case Tests Israeli Force-Feeding Law
abstract: Mohammad Allan, who is on a hunger strike to protest his indefinite incarceration, could become the first Palestinian prisoner forced to stay alive under the law.
lead_paragraph: ASHKELON, Israel — The first Palestinian prisoner who could be forced to stay alive under a new Israeli law lies shackled to a hospital bed, vomiting bile and blood after 57 days of drinking only water to protest his indefinite incarceration without charges.

headline: Competitiveness and Class Warfare
abstract: Who won the competition among nations? The one percent.
lead_paragraph: For reasons not entirely clear to me, recently I found myself thinking about Lester Thurow’s Head to Head: The Coming Economic Battle Among Japan, Europe, and America. For those too young, or who don’t remember, Thurow’s book was a monster best-seller in the early 1990s; it resonated with many people who feared that America was losing its economic edge, that Japan was an unstoppable juggernaut, and so on. And it also played into the general notion of global economics as a struggle for competitive advantage, which is a perennial popular favorite.

headline: Leaf Bar and Lounge Joins the Asian Rush in Flushing
abstract: A rooftop enclave notable for its inventive drinks at One Fulton Square; whole-animal cooking in Bedford-Stuyvesant; and changes at Aldea and Kappo Masa.
lead_paragraph: Leaf Bar and Lounge Flushing, Queens, is already chockablock with Asian restaurants and bars, but this new rooftop enclave is notable for its inventive drinks, like a chrysanthemum old-fashioned. Leaf Bar and Lounge, which opens Wednesday, is on top of a Hyatt hotel at One Fulton Square. It is the latest in the growing collection of Asian restaurants in this new multistory complex. The bar offers a menu of small plates like pork-belly buns, yellowtail collar, dumplings and popcorn chicken. The chef is Henry Lin, a Taiwan native. Already open at One Fulton Square are the Coop, a bar and restaurant specializing in Korean fried chicken; Good Harvest, a branch of a big hot-pot chain in China; Rong Restaurant, for Chinese regional cuisine; and Iki, a Japanese restaurant with a variety of dishes and wagashi sweets: One Fulton Square, 39-16 Prince Street, (Roosevelt Avenue), Flushing, Queens, onefultonsquareflushing.com.

headline: The Latest Snapchat Update, Explained
abstract: Snapchat released its newest update for Android and iPhone. Here’s a review of the new features. Find us on Snapchat, username: thenytimes

abstract: Our top winner is Kelly, who wrote about San Francisco-New York food wars, but we also crown 13 excellent Runners-Up and 12 Honorable Mentions. Scroll down to see if your name made our list.
lead_paragraph: Every week, a rotating group of judges helps choose our Summer Reading Contest winner, runners-up and honorable mentions. A few of the judges, however, have now been on the panel all seven weeks, and they agree that this week’s crop of essays was, overall, the strongest yet.

headline: Amnesty International Votes for Policy Calling for Decriminalization of Prostitution
abstract: Delegates from Amnesty International voted to support a policy that will allow the group to lobby governments to repeal most laws that forbid the sale and purchase of sex.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After days of emotional debates and intense lobbying, delegates from Amnesty International voted on Tuesday to support a policy that calls for decriminalization of the sex trade, including prostitution, payment for sex and brothel ownership.

lead_paragraph: With one punch, Ikemefuna Enemkpali transformed himself from a little known third-string linebacker into a figure of infamy for the Jets.

keywords: ['Prison Escapes', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: In letters to the authorities and interviews, inmates at the Clinton Correctional Facility who were housed near the escapees tell of being abused by guards while a frantic search for the pair was underway in June.
lead_paragraph: Night had fallen at the Clinton Correctional Facility in far northern New York when the prison guards came for Patrick Alexander. They handcuffed him and took him into a broom closet for questioning. Then, Mr. Alexander said in an interview last week, the beatings began.

headline: Showtime To Produce Series Based on Patti Smith’s ‘Just Kids’
abstract: John Logan, the executive producer of “Penny Dreadful,” will co-write the series with Ms. Smith.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Showtime announced Tuesday that it had acquired the rights to Patti Smith’s memoir, “Just Kids” and would adapt it into a limited TV series.

headline: Why Misleading Americans About Climate Change Is Dangerous
abstract: Many Republicans claim the science on climate change is murky, but in fact the scientific consensus is clear — and making people aware of that fact matters.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Pope and some conservatives call for action on climate change, it remains common among Republican politicians to claim that the science on the issue is murky or inconclusive. The latest to take this position is Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.

headline: Labour Party, Leaning Left, Looks to Outsider Jeremy Corbyn
abstract: Mr. Corbyn, who has disobeyed party instructions on how to vote more than 500 times since 1997, is considered the favorite to be its new leader.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “A working-class hero,” John Lennon wrote in 1970, “is something to be.”

headline: Ted Cruz Gets a Boost in Mississippi From a Tea Party Stalwart
abstract: State Senator Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party favorite whose popularity has alarmed Republican leaders, helped draw supporters to campaign stops by Senator Ted Cruz in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: OLIVE BRANCH, Miss. – Perched on a barstool at Sweetpea’s Table here was a Tea Party favorite whose political rise alarmed the Republican leadership last year. And pacing the stage in front of him and delivering a rousing speech was Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Swing House Seat in New Hampshire May Have Another Rematch
abstract: New Hampshire’s First Congressional District, one of the few genuine swing districts left in the country, has recently bounced back and forth between the same two candidates, and they are gearing up to face each other again.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire’s First Congressional District is one of the nation’s dwindling number of genuine swing districts — and, in recent elections, it has bounced back and forth between the same two candidates, with the incumbent losing each time.

headline: Colorado Governor Visits Polluted River
abstract: Governor John Hickenlooper of Colorado announced that the Animas River is beginning to improve after an accidental spill of toxic wastewater by Environmental Protection Agency workers.
lead_paragraph: Governor John Hickenlooper of Colorado announced that the Animas River is beginning to improve after an accidental spill of toxic wastewater by Environmental Protection Agency workers.

headline: Tracy Morgan Crash Largely Result of Truck Driver’s Fatigue, Regulators Say
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue']
abstract: Federal investigators also faulted unused seatbelts and the actions of emergency workers in the 2014 crash on the New Jersey Turnpike that injured Mr. Morgan and killed the comedian James McNair.
lead_paragraph: Federal transportation regulators on Tuesday cited a Walmart truck driver’s fatigue as the chief cause of a crash last year that killed the comedian James McNair and critically injured Tracy Morgan, a star of the television series “30 Rock.”

headline: You’ll Love What We’re Doing With the Place
abstract: Improvements are coming to the New York Times Crossword experience.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Human nature loves a routine, but sometimes change is necessary. Change can bring vast improvements to how you get your crossword puzzle, from keeping track of streaks and statistics to easily accessing the more than 8,000 crossword puzzles in our Archive. You’ve given us your feedback and we listened.

headline: Tech Breakups Show Bigger Is Not Necessarily Better
abstract: The trouble is that with fresh cash in hand or the slate wiped clean from an old deal, there is almost always a wide-eyed desire for a new one.
lead_paragraph: Symantec is revealing the truth about tech mergers and acquisitions. Offloading its data storage and recovery business Veritas for $8 billion to the buyout firm Carlyle and GIC of Singapore ends a decade-long disaster of a deal. Like Hewlett-Packard, Microsoft and others, Symantec discovered that it can be harder to buy than to build. The resulting carve-ups and write-downs, though, have a tendency to perpetuate the problem.

headline: Kickstarter Campaign Aims to Fund ‘Kids’ Documentary
abstract: Two actors from the 1990s film “Kids” hope to raise at least $81,000 by Sept. 10 to help pay for a documentary about the movie.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Some of Larry Clark’s “Kids” became stars. Others committed suicide or died of drug overdoses. A couple more, 20 years later, are still trying to make sense of a movie, a place, a time and themselves.

headline: Liftoff
abstract: Flight time: 10 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Flight time: 10 seconds.
