keywords: ['Psychics and Psychic Phenomena', 'Fortune Telling', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Jury System']
abstract: A fortuneteller convicted in 2013 of swindling two women out of tens of thousands of dollars had appealed in part based on a possible mishandling of the notes.
lead_paragraph: A mystery over two jury notes sent during a 2013 larceny trial of a Manhattan psychic has been resolved, dampening the hopes of the psychic, who has appealed her conviction.

headline: Buying Car Insurance for Teenagers Can Be a Balancing Act
abstract: While keeping a teenage driver on a family policy can increase premiums significantly, there are ways to reduce the cost.
lead_paragraph: Adding a teenager to a family’s auto insurance policy is a sure way to raise the premiums, but it’s usually less expensive than buying a separate policy, according to new research.

headline: Philosophers Jürgen Habermas and Charles Taylor to Share $1.5 Million Prize
abstract: The John W. Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity, recognizing work in disciplines not covered by the Nobel prizes, is awarded by the Library of Congress.
lead_paragraph: The German philosopher Jürgen Habermas and the Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor will share this year’s $1.5 million John W. Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity. The prize, inaugurated in 2003 and awarded by the Library of Congress, is intended to recognize work in disciplines not covered by the Nobel prizes.

headline: Review: Clarice Lispector’s ‘The Complete Stories’ Sees Life With Existential Dread
abstract: This 84-story collection, edited by Benjamin Moser, is of a piece with Lispector’s nine novels, and makes clear that she also had a mastery of short fiction.
lead_paragraph: On the very first page of the Brazilian writer Clarice Lispector’s “The Complete Stories,” she signals that hers was never an ordinary sensibility, but one capable of perceiving anxiety and menace in even the most routine phenomena. The story in question was her debut as a writer, published in 1940 when she was just 19. Called “The Triumph,” it begins with a woman awakening to a “bright stain of sunlight” that leaves her motionless in bed, “crucified by lassitude.”

headline: Review: Archana Joglekar Presents a Dazzling Solo at Drive East
abstract: A celebration of classical Indian music and movement began its weeklong run at La MaMa with a program of Kathak dance.
lead_paragraph: In the last couple of years, the Drive East festival, a celebration of classical Indian music and dance, has packed the small First Floor Theater at La MaMa. Opening night of the third edition, on Monday, seemed more sparsely attended than usual, perhaps because there were more seats to fill. This year’s festival has moved to the cavernous Ellen Stewart Theater, and the Kathak dancer Archana Joglekar, in a vibrant solo program, made the extra space work to her advantage.

headline: In El Salvador, Gangs Hold on to Power
abstract: Murder rates have soared as the government has struggled to rein in criminal organizations.
lead_paragraph: Murder rates have soared as the government has struggled to rein in criminal organizations.

headline: El Salvador Cracks Down on Crime, but Gangs Remain Unbowed
abstract: Murder rates have soared as the government has struggled to rein in powerful criminal organizations.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — Seven bus drivers are killed in four days. A morgue worker slowly counts 224 stab wounds on a murder victim. Police officers post memorials to slain comrades and photographs of “eliminated” suspects on Facebook.

headline: New York City’s Responsible Banking Act Is Unconstitutional, a Judge Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The 2012 law intends for an advisory panel to oversee large banks’ practices on foreclosures and loans to small businesses.
lead_paragraph: A law passed by New York City three years ago that required banks to make public their efforts to be socially responsible, particularly in low-income neighborhoods, is unconstitutional, according to a federal court ruling.

headline: Birdland Club to Open a Theater Next Spring
abstract: The Birdland Theater will occupy the lower level of the club on West 44th Street.
lead_paragraph: The Birdland jazz club announced that the Birdland Theater, a 100-seat space that will occupy the lower level of the club at 315 West 44th Street in Manhattan, would open in the spring. The programming will include cabaret, jazz, dance, burlesque and comedy.

headline: Are Times Readers Smarter Than a 3rd Grader?
abstract: A sample question from the Common Core exam that New York students take stumped some Times editors.
lead_paragraph: You might remember the reading passage about an anthropomorphic pineapple that appeared on New York State’s eighth-grade tests a few years ago. Some of the accompanying questions were so confusing that the state decided not to count the answers in students’ scores.

headline: Kodak’s First Digital Moment
abstract: In the mid-1970s a young engineer invented the digital photographic process. Some of his bosses were not impressed. His employer? Eastman Kodak.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1970s a young engineer invented the digital photographic process. Some of his bosses were not impressed. His employer? Eastman Kodak.

headline: Review: ‘How to Smell a Rose,’ Ricky Leacock at His French Farmhouse
abstract: The filmmakers Les Blank and Gina Leibrecht make a documentary about Mr. Leacock, and ask about documentary films.
lead_paragraph: Through its subject and its maker, “How to Smell a Rose” puts us in the vibrant presence of documentary history. Ricky Leacock — the film’s twinkly man of the hour — helped pioneer the documentary approach called direct cinema in the 1960s, using portable cameras and synchronized sound to record everyone from John F. Kennedy to a mother of quintuplets. But in his nine decades on earth, Mr. Leacock also apprenticed with Robert J. Flaherty, director of the silent classic documentary “Nanook of the North”; shot combat photography in World War II; taught rising filmmakers at M.I.T.; and embraced shooting on video.

headline: Plaxico Burress’s Game-Winning Super Bowl Catch
abstract: Arlo White calls Plaxico Burress’s touchdown catch that won Super Bowl XLII for the Giants against the Patriots.
lead_paragraph: Arlo White calls Plaxico Burress’s touchdown catch that won Super Bowl XLII for the Giants against the Patriots.

lead_paragraph: Arlo White calls the David Tyree’s catch that helped the Giants win Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Curiae Veteres Sanctuary in Rome Attracts the Curious
abstract: The discovery of sanctuary remnants during a dig on the Palatine Hill has caused academics and others to wonder what else might be found.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Archaeologists working on the Palatine Hill here this summer excavated parts of sixth-century B.C. foundations connected to a sanctuary of a cult that ancient sources trace back to Romulus, Rome’s mythic founder — a rare find from such an early period.

headline: Facts & Figures: Change Could Keep Thousands of Kansans From Voting
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The proposal would cancel the voter registration applications of over 30,000 Kansans if they can’t provide proof of citizenship in 90 days.
lead_paragraph: A proposal by Secretary of State Kris Kobach of Kansas could cancel the voter registration applications of over 30,000 Kansans who haven’t yet provided proof of citizenship. Under current regulations, they have until Election Day to do so — the new proposal would void their applications if they don’t provide the necessary documents within 90 days.

headline: Review: UP’s ‘Ties That Bind’
abstract: This show centers on a detective who takes her brother’s children into her own family after he goes to prison.
lead_paragraph: Many have tried, but when it comes to making television that is both family- and faith-friendly, few have produced anything other than unwatchable mush. The UP network, though, has shown signs of being the exception, and its first original scripted series, which begins on Wednesday night, is another respectable offering.

abstract: Herman Cornejo and Isabella Boylston, principals of American Ballet Theater, made their debuts as Apollo and Calliope in “Apollo,” one of five Balanchine works at this festival on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — The Vail festival spoils dancegoers. We start to feel that every theater should be surrounded by pine-clad mountains and approached by a path featuring a rushing river (and at least one hummingbird).

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As President Xi Jinping of China prepares for a state visit to Washington next month to smooth over troubled relations, his government has just turned the spotlight back on a recurring issue: the value of his country’s currency.

headline: Is the New Google More Like Berkshire Hathaway, General Electric or AT&T?
abstract: The restructuring could fund world-changing research, but only so long as the underlying business remains a cash cow.
lead_paragraph: Google’s decision to restructure is the strongest signal yet that it intends to be a 21st-century innovator, a bold creator of new products, not simply a harvester of profits from its lucrative search engine business.

headline: A Conversation With John C. Tashjian
abstract: Mr. Tashjian is a principal of Centurion Real Estate Partners, which develops, acquires and manages residential and office buildings, mainly in New York and Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Tashjian, 45, is a founder and principal of Centurion Real Estate Partners, a New York-based company that develops, acquires and manages commercial property. Centurion’s most recent project is River & Warren, a condominium conversion it is developing in partnership with Five Mile Capital Partners.

abstract: A student-faculty team at M.I.T. publishes a design for an “affordable, robust, compact” fusion power plant.
lead_paragraph: It’s a sure bet that the best known “arc reactor” in the world is the glowing energy source in the chest of Tony Stark, the inventor with a superhero complex at the heart of the “Iron Man” film franchise.

headline: A Milestone in Africa: No Polio Cases in a Year
abstract: Health experts are quietly celebrating, while remaining on guard for a possible resurgence of a formerly widespread disease.
lead_paragraph: It has been one full year since polio was detected anywhere in Africa, a significant milestone in global health that has left health experts around the world quietly celebrating.

headline: Moments Before Ferguson Shooting
abstract: St. Louis County investigators posted a surveillance video on Tuesday that they say shows Tyrone Harris pulling out a handgun. The man, wearing a white shirt, appears near the end of the video.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: General Electric announced on Tuesday that it would sell its Healthcare Financial Services business to Capital One for about $9 billion, continuing a campaign to refocus its business.
lead_paragraph: General Electric continued its campaign to shrink its huge finance arm, announcing on Tuesday that it will sell its health care lending business to Capital One for about $9 billion.

headline: ‘King Lear With Sheep.’ Yes, Sheep.
abstract: An adaption of “King Lear” in London stars one man and nine sheep.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A new adaptation of “King Lear,” will open at the Courtyard Theater here on Wednesday.

headline: Arlington, Tex., Officer Is Fired in Fatal Shooting of Christian Taylor
abstract: Officer Brad Miller was dismissed after what was described as a series of troubling decisions that led to the death of Mr. Taylor, an unarmed black 19-year-old.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — A white rookie police officer who shot and killed an unarmed black college football player after the youth had broken into a car dealership in this Dallas suburb was fired on Tuesday for “inappropriate judgment” in his handling of the situation, officials said.

headline: Showtime Reveals ‘Twin Peaks’ Details
abstract: The new series will debut in 2016 or 2017.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Showtime’s revival of “Twin Peaks” is back on track  after a dispute over the show’s budget this spring between the network and the co-creator of the series, David Lynch, led to uncertainty over its return.

headline: How Hackers Made $1 Million by Stealing One News Release
abstract: A scheme to hack into news wire services to steal confidential corporate information required patience and persistence, if not crude tactics. Here’s a case study, on Panera Bread.
lead_paragraph: A scheme, announced by federal authorities on Tuesday, to hack into three news wire services to steal copies of corporate news releases went on for years, and required a good deal of patience and persistence. For a while, it seemed to pay off.

headline: One Year Later, ‘Bouncy Bridge’ in Brooklyn Remains Closed
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The closing of the Squibb Park Bridge last Aug. 11 was supposed to be temporary. Several deadlines for its reopening have come and gone, and now park officials refuse to give a new target date.
lead_paragraph: After missing a number of reopening dates, the so-called bouncy bridge of Brooklyn Heights reached a dubious milestone on Tuesday: It has now been closed for repairs for exactly one year.

headline: John Riggi, Who Led New Jersey Crime Family, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Riggi was chief of the DeCavalcante family, New Jersey’s only indigenous mob group, but not, as some said, an inspiration for “The Sopranos.”
lead_paragraph: John Riggi, a convicted New Jersey labor racketeer who was often mistakenly cited as an inspiration for the acclaimed HBO series “The Sopranos,” died on Aug. 3 at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 90.

headline: Google Goal in Restructuring as Alphabet: Autonomy
abstract: The Internet giant has been short on details about how its reconfiguration as the entity Alphabet will work. But a look at Nest Labs may provide some clues.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For a glimpse of how Larry Page might envision the way a newly restructured Google will work, take a look at Nest Labs, the company’s Internet-connected thermostat business.

headline: Newlyweds Are Accused of Planning to Join ISIS
abstract: The couple were on their way to the airport in Columbus, Miss., on Saturday when they were arrested by F.B.I. agents after unwittingly making travel plans with undercover federal agents on social media.
lead_paragraph: A newlywed Mississippi couple who were arrested on the way to the airport for a trip to Syria to join the Islamic State were ordered held without bail on Tuesday.

headline: Serena Williams Recovers After Another Middling Start
abstract: As she has done seven times this Grand Slam season, Williams played a listless first set, falling behind the 26th-ranked Flavia Pennetta of Italy before rallying in a persistent wind for a 2-6, 6-3, 6-0 second-round victory at the Rogers Cup.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Given its beginning, Serena Williams’s hardcourt season may well look like the clay and grass-court campaigns that preceded it. And her march toward a calendar-year Grand Slam will most likely require stepping into potholes along the way.

headline: Global Selling Shows Concerns About China’s Weakness
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Currency', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: After China devalued its currency, the price of oil plunged and stock markets fell, reflecting worry that the country’s leaders would be unable to bolster the economy.
lead_paragraph: After China shocked investors on Tuesday by devaluing the country’s currency, a wave of selling swept the globe. The price of oil plunged, the currencies of other countries tumbled and stock markets skidded on every continent.

headline: Ann McGovern, Author, Is Dead at 85; She Made ‘Stone Soup’ a School Staple
abstract: Ms. McGovern, who worked at Little Golden Books and Scholastic, broke into children’s literature by writing about Roy Rogers after overhearing an editor wishing someone would write one.
lead_paragraph: Ann McGovern, a prolific author for children whose work ranged over women’s history, adaptations of folk tales and her own exploits as a globe-trotting adventurer, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 85.

headline: Donald Trump Defines His Style: Deal-Making Flexibility
abstract: The Republican candidate, dogged by criticisms of his debate performance and his past comments about women, was still ahead in polling on Tuesday as he sought to redirect the campaign conversation in televised appearances.
lead_paragraph: BIRCH RUN, Mich. — Donald J. Trump’s plan to combat the Islamic State? “We go in, we knock the hell out of ’em, we take the oil,” he told Fox News on Tuesday.

headline: New Diplomacy Seen on U.S.-Russian Efforts to End Syrian Civil War
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Envoys, including from Middle Eastern powers, have been meeting recently to try to head off a Syrian collapse that could strengthen the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With President Bashar al-Assad of Syria facing battlefield setbacks, diplomats from Russia, the United States and several Middle Eastern powers are engaged in a burst of diplomatic activity, trying to head off a deeper collapse of the country that could further strengthen the militant group Islamic State.

headline: Schumer Says Corporation Should Oversee Hudson Tunnels Project
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, seeking an end to the standoff over financing, proposed creating a nonprofit to assemble the billions of dollars needed to build the new tunnels.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, seeking an end to the standoff over financing new Hudson River rail tunnels, proposed on Tuesday creating a nonprofit corporation to oversee the project and to assemble the billions of dollars needed to build new tunnels.

headline: Any Sexual Abuse by Guards May Violate Inmates’ Rights, Court Says
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Any malicious sexual contact by prison guards against prisoners may be a constitutional violation, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, noting how society’s standards of decency have evolved.
lead_paragraph: Any malicious sexual contact by prison guards against inmates may amount to a constitutional violation, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, noting how standards of decency have changed in the past two decades.

headline: Head of Group Opposing Iran Accord Quits Post, Saying He Backs Deal
abstract: When the bipartisan advocacy group United Against Nuclear Iran decided last week to mobilize opposition against the nuclear deal with Tehran, Gary Samore knew he could no longer serve as its president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the bipartisan advocacy group United Against Nuclear Iran decided last week to mobilize opposition against the nuclear deal with Tehran, Gary Samore knew he could no longer serve as its president.

headline: E.P.A. Treating Toxic Water From Abandoned Colorado Mine After Accident
abstract: Emergency declarations in Colorado, New Mexico and the Navajo Nation as the Animas and San Juan Rivers remain restricted.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Nearly a week after the Environmental Protection Agency accidentally breached a store of chemical-laced water from an abandoned mine in southwest Colorado, toxic water continues to spill at a rate of 500 to 700 gallons a minute, E.P.A. officials said Tuesday.

headline: Puerto Rico to Issue $750 Million in Revenue Bonds for Construction
abstract: The announcement comes less than a month before a working group is scheduled to reveal plans for restructuring of Puerto Rico’s debt
lead_paragraph: Eight days after it defaulted on bond payments for the first time, the government of Puerto Rico said on Tuesday that it planned to issue $750 million more in bonds for an array of construction and maintenance projects.

headline: Hillary Clinton Directs Aides to Give Email Server and Thumb Drive to the Justice Department
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The inspector general for the intelligence community told members of Congress that two of the former secretary of state’s emails among the 40 he has reviewed held “top secret” information.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton has directed her aides to give the Justice Department an email server that housed the personal account that she used exclusively while secretary of state, along with a thumb drive that contained copies of the emails, her presidential campaign said on Tuesday.

headline: Jeb Bush Blames Hillary Clinton and Obama for Iraq’s Decline
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a blistering attack, Mr. Bush said the early withdrawal of American troops set the stage for the chaos now sweeping the region.
lead_paragraph: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The war in Iraq, which dominated American presidential politics in 2004 and 2008, has returned as an issue in 2016. This time, the argument is not over whether the United States should have gone to war, but rather how the Obama administration sought to end it.

headline: Handling of Donald Trump Puts Fox News on the Spot
abstract: If there is a war between Donald Trump and Fox News, it is an unconventional one. It is not mutually assured destruction; it is mutually beneficial combat.
lead_paragraph: It started with Megyn Kelly’s interrogation of Donald J. Trump at Thursday night’s debate on Fox News. Mr. Trump wasted no time responding, in less than presidential terms. The network’s chief executive, Roger E. Ailes, intervened, placating Mr. Trump while also defending his star anchor, Ms. Kelly.

headline: An Aging Nomad, Jose Reyes Longs for a Team in the Hunt
abstract: Now with his fourth team in five seasons, Reyes is facing the Mets, his first club and the one that now has exactly what he wants: a shot at the postseason.
lead_paragraph: It was around midnight, and Jose Reyes was sleeping in his Toronto home when his wife received a call from a Toronto Blue Jays trainer summoning him to the ballpark. Reyes had spent the off day mostly hanging around the house. At 32, he needed ample rest and recovery.

headline: In Former Hummer Plant in Indiana, Mercedes Turns Out S.U.V.s for China
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Automobiles', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: An old plant has become an example of how a modest-size Rust Belt manufacturer can find its niche in an increasingly global automotive industry.
lead_paragraph: MISHAWAKA, Ind. — The steady comeback of the American auto industry has brought new life to underused factories, as carmakers across the country add shifts of workers to meet growing demand for new vehicles.

headline: Police Officer With U.N. Force in Central African Republic Is Accused of Rape
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: An officer has been accused of raping a 12-year-old girl in the capital, Bangui, during a nighttime house-to-house search, according to Amnesty International.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In the latest allegation of child sexual abuse by peacekeepers in the Central African Republic, a United Nations police officer is accused of raping a 12-year-old girl in the capital, Bangui, during a nighttime house-to-house search, according to Amnesty International.

headline: Questions of Focus Hover Over Tiger Woods
abstract: As Woods prepares for his 18th P.G.A. Championship, business and philanthropic interests competing for his attention may be distracting him from his effort to regain standing among golf’s elite players.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Tiger Woods’s new, and first, sports bar and restaurant opened Monday night in Jupiter, Fla. About 18 hours later, Woods was on the practice range at Whistling Straits, preparing for his 18th P.G.A. Championship.

headline: Straight Outta History, the Rage That Makes Movies
keywords: ['Movies', 'Music', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Universal Pictures has been taking the stars of “Straight Outta Compton” into urban neighborhoods to discuss the movie in the days before its opening.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Universal Pictures took on one of its more delicate challenges on Tuesday: making sure that the studio’s film “Straight Outta Compton” heals more wounds than it reopens.

headline: Review: In ‘John,’ Pondering Life’s Mysteries From Gettysburg
abstract: The membrane between life and death seems strangely permeable in the Signature Theater’s production of Annie Baker’s appealingly odd drama.
lead_paragraph: If chintz could speak, I’m sure it would sound like Georgia Engel, whose girlish purr must be the most comforting voice possessed by man or woman. The comparison springs to mind because Ms. Engel is presiding over a virtual museum of chintz — and cute tchotchkes, and stuffed animals, and dainty figurines — in the new Annie Baker play, “John,” which opened on Tuesday night at the Signature Center.

headline: Glaxo Closes Plant After Legionnaires’ Bacterium Is Found
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline temporarily shut the plant, one of three buildings at its site in Zebulon, N.C., after the bacterium was found in a cooling tower.
lead_paragraph: GlaxoSmithKline temporarily shut down a major pharmaceutical manufacturing plant in North Carolina on Tuesday after the bacterium that causes Legionnaires’ disease was discovered in a cooling tower.

headline: Looking Within
abstract: Tom McCoy offers us a meditative puzzle.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When there are starred clues in a puzzle, I immediately scan the list to see if there is a revealer that will help me guess the theme. It’s not always successful, but occasionally it pays off. Today was not one of those days, but that’s on me: I forgot that Tom McCoy tends to see things through a mathematical lens.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Takes Step in Test of Knee
abstract: Taking part in a light, noncontact workout with U.S.A. Basketball, was a small but noteworthy step for Anthony, who has not played basketball since February, when he underwent surgery to repair a damaged tendon in his left knee.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony took part in a light, noncontact workout on Tuesday in Las Vegas, where U.S.A. Basketball convened a three-day training camp this week involving more than 30 N.B.A. players. It was a small but noteworthy step for Anthony, 31, who has not played basketball since February, when he underwent surgery to repair a damaged tendon in his left knee.

headline: Matt Harvey Proves Stellar in Shutout as Mets Defeat the Rockies
abstract: Harvey extended his scoreless streak to 15 innings in the 4-0 victory at Citi Field. He allowed only four base runners, including three on infield singles.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, with about eight weeks remaining in the season, the Mets sent their season-ticket holders directions for buying tickets for potential postseason games at Citi Field. As part of the package, the Mets were selling hypothetical seats to the World Series — and it was not a cruel joke.

headline: Donald Trump Lashes Out at Bush
abstract: While speaking at a campaign event in Michigan Tuesday, the Republican presidential candidate called Jeb Bush’s comments on women’s health issues a “disaster.”
lead_paragraph: While speaking at a campaign event in Michigan Tuesday, the Republican presidential candidate called Jeb Bush’s comments on women’s health issues a “disaster.”

headline: Rikers Inmate Has Legionnaires’ Disease; Officials Find No Link to Outbreak
abstract: The 63-year-old inmate was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and, as a precaution, the cooling towers and shower heads at the jail complex were being cleaned and disinfected.
lead_paragraph: A Rikers Island inmate has Legionnaires’ disease, New York City officials said on Tuesday, quickly adding that it was unlikely the case was connected to an outbreak in the South Bronx that has killed 12 people since early July.

headline: Arlington Police Chief Addresses Media
abstract: Will D. Johnson, the Arlington, Tex., police chief, said the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager at a Dallas-area car dealership had been fired.
lead_paragraph: Will D. Johnson, the Arlington, Tex., police chief, said the officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager at a Dallas-area car dealership had been fired.

headline: China Weakens Its Currency Further
abstract: The nation’s central bank set the official rate 1.6 percent lower than the previous day, jolting markets and raising concerns about the economy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China weakened its currency, the renminbi, for a second straight day on Wednesday, jolting markets across Asia and raising concerns about the path of the giant economy.

headline: Own a Piece of Le Corbusier’s Tree
abstract: A felled giant Paulownia has been turned into a series of collectible objects by the Spanish designer Jaime Hayon.
lead_paragraph: At Le Corbusier’s Villa Le Lac near Geneva — one of the architect’s first projects, which he designed for his parents in 1924 — a felled giant Paulownia tree has been turned into a series of collectible objects by the Spanish designer Jaime Hayon. In partnership with the Italian furniture manufacturer Cassina, Hayon has fashioned birds, birdhouses and swing-shaped shelves from the wood of the ancient tree, whose branches once created a canopy over the property’s waterfront terrace.

headline: A New Tuscan Spa in a Centuries-Old Granary
abstract: In a partnership with Santa Maria Novella, the idyllic Hotel Monteverdi offers an extensive menu of treatments.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in the Siena region of central Tuscany, the idyllic Hotel Monteverdi has opened a heavenly new spa in partnership with Santa Maria Novella, the cult skin-care and fragrance label (and one of the most storied apothecaries in the world). Housed in a centuries-old granary, the space offers an extensive menu of treatments including olive- and grapeseed-oil massages and outdoor mineral baths overlooking the rolling countryside.

headline: The Art of the Sculpturally Unfinished Updo
abstract: On the fall runways, hair was elaborate but undone — like your grandmother’s hair, only crazier.
lead_paragraph: On the fall runways, hair was elaborate but undone — like your grandmother’s hair, only crazier.

headline: Camilla Guinness and the Importance of Not Being Earnest
abstract: From troll dolls to the queen, the interior designer blends Old World elegance and British charm.
lead_paragraph: From troll dolls to the queen, the interior designer blends Old World elegance and British charm.

headline: Number of Uninsured Has Declined by 15 Million Since 2013, Administration Says
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The number of people without health insurance dropped by 15.8 million, or one-third, since 2013, as major provisions of the Affordable Care Act took effect, the administration said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The number of people without health insurance continues to decline and has dropped by 15.8 million, or one-third, since 2013, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day | pigment
abstract: This word has appeared in 104 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: pigment • \ˈpig-mənt\ • noun and verb

headline: ‘The Girl on the Train’ Chugs Past 3 Million in Sales
abstract: Sales continue on track for “The Girl on the Train” by Paula Hawkins.
lead_paragraph: When Riverhead Books acquired a thriller from an unknown British novelist last year, it seemed like a bit of a gamble. Foreign suspense novels don’t always resonate with American readers, and the author, Paula Hawkins, was new to writing crime fiction. But the book had a lot going for it, mainly a mesmerizing plot fueled by three unreliable narrators, and Riverhead planned a healthy first print run of 40,000 copies.

headline: Yankees’ Loss in 16th Shrinks Their Lead to Half a Game
abstract: The loss was especially crushing as the Yankees’ squandered a hard-earned lead in the 10th inning when closer Andrew Miller, who had converted his first 24 save opportunities of the season, faltered.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — After last weekend, when simply pushing a runner across home plate seemed like such a monumental task for the Yankees, the sight of much-maligned Stephen Drew hitting a home run that ended a 31-inning scoreless streak inspired a sigh of relief Tuesday night.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) KEVIN FROM WORK Kevin (Noah Reid), an earnest young office worker, finally gets to quit the worst job in history. Every bit of it stinks, except for the colleague with whom he has shared a cubicle wall for three years: Audrey (Paige Spara), perpetually backlit, her hair tousled by a magical breeze and the wings of the animated bluebirds that suddenly appear every time she is near. And like them, Kevin longs to be close to her. If only she didn’t have a lunk of a boyfriend — which is why Kevin has banished himself and his shredded heart to Italy, but not before pouring his passion into a love letter and mailing it. After all, he’s never going to see her again, right? With a whisper of “(500) Days of Summer” in its DNA — those bluebirds again, and a younger sister (Jordan Hinson) to inflict pain — “Kevin From Work” heralds the return of the single-camera comedy to ABC Family. It also packs a secret weapon in Amy Sedaris, as Kevin’s monster of a boss.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 12, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “It’s something we don’t tolerate; it’s something we can’t stand. And you don’t walk up to another man and punch him in the face.”

abstract: Test your knowledge of financial matters by playing our crossword.

headline: Kodak’s First Digital Moment
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Cameras', 'Innovation', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Photography', 'Television Sets and Media Devices']
abstract: In the mid-1970s a young engineer invented the digital photographic process. Some of his bosses were not impressed. His employer? Eastman Kodak.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world where photography is a slow process that is impossible to master without years of study or apprenticeship. A world without iPhones or Instagram, where one company reigned supreme. Such a world existed in 1973, when Steven Sasson, a young engineer, went to work for Eastman Kodak.

headline: Keep the Tax on High-End Health Plans
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Taxation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Instead of an outright repeal, the “Cadillac tax” should be adjusted by Congress to eliminate inequities.
lead_paragraph: Congress is under pressure to repeal an impending tax on the so-called Cadillac health plans offered by many employers. Scores of legislators from each party have endorsed separate bills to repeal it, and candidates for office, pressed by lobbyists from labor unions, business groups and insurers, may join the call for repeal. The tax should probably be adjusted by Congress to eliminate inequities, but outright repeal would be a mistake that would undermine the viability of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: President Obama’s Letter to the Editor
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A letter from the president in response to Jim Rutenberg’s article about the 50-year campaign to roll back the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: For the cover story of our Aug. 2 issue, Jim Rutenberg wrote about efforts over the last 50 years to dismantle the protections in the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the landmark piece of legislation that cleared barriers between black voters and the ballot. The story surveyed a broad sweep of history and characters, from United States Chief Justice John Roberts to ordinary citizens like 94-year-old Rosanell Eaton, a plaintiff in the current North Carolina case arguing to repeal voting restrictions enacted in 2013. The magazine received an unusual volume of responses to this article, most notably from President Barack Obama.

abstract: The issue’s political polarization has a surprisingly short history.

But on a cool evening in May, the main auditorium of the Abbey, the national theater of Ireland, was filled with enthusiasts of W. B. Yeats who had gathered for a contemporary dance performance inspired in part by his poem “Sailing to Byzantium.” The venue was particularly apt: Yeats co-founded the theater in 1904.

headline: How Do I Handle the Towel Saga Next Door?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Domestic Service', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Summer (Season)']
abstract: The Ethicists consider how to respond to the dramatic aftermath of a neighborhood pool party.
lead_paragraph: On Easter Sunday, we always have an egg hunt for our neighbors and the children of our Hispanic housekeeper and yard man. This past Easter, our next-door neighbor invited the kids to swim in their pool afterward. In July, a full three months later, we received an email from our neighbor stating: ‘‘Would you mind reminding your housekeeper that they have a large portion of my swimming towels, I was terribly short this weekend. Hope you had a great Fourth of July.’’ This was the first we heard of missing towels. We did not want our housekeeper to think that we or our neighbor thought the children had taken towels that did not belong to them, so we made the decision to purchase 12 towels and give them to our neighbor. We wrapped them up and left them with a note — ‘‘A little surprise for your generosity.’’ A week later, we found the box of towels with a note back at our door — ‘‘I cannot accept these towels and cannot keep them because it is morally as wrong for me to take your towels as it was for your housekeeper’s children to keep my towels.’’ We do not think the children were morally wrong in intent; they simply did what kids do when getting out of the pool — dry off and then wrap in a towel before piling into cars to go home. Had we known about the towels, we would have collected them at the time, but three months after the fact changes how we think the towels should be regarded. The cost of the towels is not really an issue for us or our neighbors. Should we have tried to retrieve the towels from several families before buying new ones? We are almost certain that our housekeeper was not even aware the children were given towels, as she was at our house the entire swim time cleaning up from the meal. Our effort to replace the towels was meant to defuse the situation, not continue into a towel saga. NAME WITHHELD

headline: The Pleasure of a Steak at Home
abstract: It’s easier and cheaper than you might think to play grill master for one night.
lead_paragraph: After staring at the bill for a ridiculously overpriced and not very good rib-eye at a famous steakhouse in Chicago — replete with a sauce so banal it may as well have been ketchup, and served with attitude, too — I remembered I could do better at home. I went to my local butcher (which in my neighborhood just happens to be called the Local Butcher Shop) and paid $60 for a glorious, two-inch thick, fat-laden rib-eye. The plan was to blow the minds of three guests with a piece of meat so good it needed no sauce — and then pair it with sauces that were irresistible on their own.

headline: 1915: Cotton Seen as Key to Peace
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Scientists say declaring cotton contraband would stop the war in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ‘‘If cotton had been declared contraband, the war would have been over last March.’’ Sir Charles Macara and Sir William Ramsay repeated that statement (which they have made before) at the meeting over which Sir Charles presided last night in Queen’s Hall. ‘‘If we stop cotton,’’ Sir William declared, emphatically, ‘‘then we stop this war.’’ (Applause.) ‘‘Cotton is the only substance which the Germans cannot furnish themselves with for ammunition,’’ said Sir William. Wood, hemp, straw, anything that contained wood fibre, was available to make nitric cellulose, but none of these fibres had the ballistic power of cotton. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 13, 1915
