headline: Haruki Murakami’s ‘Wind/Pinball’
abstract: Two novels reveal Haruki Murakami’s early interest in pop culture and slippery temporal realms.
lead_paragraph: More than anyone, Haruki Murakami invented 21st-century fiction, which says as much about the 21st century as it does about Murakami. He is the novelist of our mash-up epoch and the subversive who, by intent or not, lit the fuse to whatever “canon” of the previous century anybody still takes seriously. Unless some aging secret master clandestinely labors away at the center of the Tokyo labyrinth, Murakami is the first major Japanese author born in the radioactive white light of the modern age that commenced in the zero-years of 1945, with nuclear decimation by the United States, and, even more traumatically, 1946, with the emperor’s admission to the Japanese public that he wasn’t divine.

headline: ‘A Manual for Cleaning Women,’ by Lucia Berlin
abstract: Lucia Berlin’s unadorned stories feature hard-pressed women and figures on the fringe.
lead_paragraph: Some short story writers — ­Chekhov, Alice Munro, William Trevor — sidle up and tap you gently on the shoulder: Come, they murmur, sit down, listen to what I have to say. Lucia Berlin spins you around, knocks you down and grinds your face into the dirt. You will listen to me if I have to force you, her stories growl. But why would you make me do that, darlin’?

headline: The Peronist Roots of Pope Francis’ Politics
abstract: Francis’ identification with the poor derives from very distinctively Argentine forms of populism.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — “I wish to join my voice to yours in calling for land, lodging and labor for all our brothers and sisters. I said it and I repeat it: These are sacred rights. It is important, it is well worth fighting for them.” The combative-sounding message of Pope Francis last month on his South American tour resonated deeply in a region where poverty continues to be the most pressing concern.

headline: Six Years After Murder, Guinea-Bissau Autocrat Makes a Posthumous Comeback
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: In a move unthinkable not long ago, Parliament has voted to erect a statue of João Bernardo Vieira, a tempestuous leader whose killing is unsolved.
lead_paragraph: BISSAU, Guinea-Bissau — A mystery has hung over this sweltering West African capital for six years, but not because no one could solve it. Many people have an answer, though they will not say so in public: Who killed Nino?

headline: Greece Rounds Up Migrants on Kos, Locking Them in Stadium Overnight
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A Doctors Without Borders spokeswoman said about 1,000 refugees on the island of Kos had been locked inside the stadium for 24 hours and had no food and very little water.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — About a thousand refugees have been locked in a stadium on the Greek island of Kos overnight without food and with very little water, as Greek authorities struggle to contain the rising tide of migrants from war-torn countries, a spokeswoman for Doctors Without Borders said Wednesday.

headline: 1965: Johnson on U.S. Vietnam Role
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson says the U.S. is present “to help” in Vietnam in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson said today that the United States would not be making sacrifices in South Vietnam ‘‘if its help were not wanted and requested.’’ Mr. Johnson’s remarks, at the swearing in of Henry Cabot Lodge as U.S. ambassador to South Vietnam, were significant in light of reports that Mr. Lodge had told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee July 27 that the United States would keep its forces in South Vietnam even if the Saigon government asked them to leave. Spokesmen insisted yesterday that these reports were inaccurate. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 13, 1965

headline: Pro-Choice Questions, Pro-Life Answers
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Poverty', 'Sex Education', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A response (the first of two) to Katha Pollitt’s questions for the pro-life movement.
lead_paragraph: Last week I turned a little bit intemperate in arguing about abortion with members of the conflicted center-left. Now I’m going to try to be a little calmer in pursuing a conversation with the not-at-all-conflicted pro-abortion left, by answering some of the questions that Katha Pollitt posed to her pro-life opponents last fall. I wanted to write a response at the time (she wrote up some of the answers she did receive here), but it slipped by the wayside; now that we’re in the throes of the ongoing Planned Parenthood controversy, it seems like an appropriate time to take her challenge up. So here are the first four of Pollitt’s (meaty) questions, in italics, with my (prolix) responses following; I’ll try to handle the remaining five by this time next week.

headline: Why Turkey Is Fighting the Kurds Who Are Fighting ISIS
abstract: While the United States has long sought Turkey’s help in fighting ISIS, getting its help has revealed a tangle of diverging interests in the region.
lead_paragraph: While the United States has long sought Turkey’s help in fighting ISIS, getting its help has revealed a tangle of diverging interests in the region.

headline: Jon Watts, Director of ‘Cop Car,’ Rocketing to Hollywood From a Viral Video
abstract: To hear Mr. Watts talk about his film career, you might think much of it happened by chance. Up next: the latest “Spider-Man” reboot.
lead_paragraph: To hear the director Jon Watts talk about his film career, you might think much of it happened by chance. His first feature came about because of a prank video that went viral. His second feature, the new thriller “Cop Car,” was based on a recurring dream and written for fun, but the script drew interest from Kevin Bacon, who stars as the not-so-kind Sheriff Kretzer. And now, Mr. Watts, at 34, has already been tapped for a superhero franchise, the latest “Spider-Man” reboot.

headline: New Releases From Nicholas Payton, Robyn & La Bagatelle Magique and Others
abstract: Other new releases include the guitarist Brad Allen Williams’s debut album and the eclectic free downloads available at Adult Swim.
lead_paragraph: Robyn & La Bagatelle Magique

headline: 20% of New York State Students Opted Out of Standardized Tests This Year
abstract: Just 31 percent of third through eighth graders passed state reading tests and 38 percent passed math, both slight improvements from last year.
lead_paragraph: More than 200,000 third through eighth graders sat out New York’s standardized tests this year, education officials said on Wednesday, in a sign of increasing resistance to testing as more states make them harder to pass.

headline: ‘Évocateur’ on CNN Revisits the Bullying and Bluster of Morton Downey Jr.
abstract: Mr. Downey’s syndicated talk show in the 1980s didn’t last long, but others soon picked up the banner and continue to carry it today.
lead_paragraph: Between what went on in the first Republican presidential debate and what goes on daily on social media, it sometimes seems that browbeating, not baseball, is America’s pastime. Morton Downey Jr. certainly didn’t invent public nastiness. For verification, see the campaign posters from presidential contests of a century or a century and a half ago. But his nationally syndicated talk show in the 1980s gave bullying and bluster a new prominence. “The Morton Downey Jr. Show” didn’t last long, but others soon picked up the banner and continue to carry it today.

headline: Jets Are a Franchise as Broken as Their Quarterback’s Jaw
abstract: Before the Jets had even played a game, people were again asking, why do bizarre things always happen to this franchise?
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A dejected Calvin Pace stood outside the Jets’ training complex on Tuesday evening, valiantly trying to make sense of how another black cloud had suddenly appeared over the team.

headline: Battery Dance Festival Offers World and Harbor Views
abstract: The Polish Dance Theater will make its American debut with Takako Matsuda’s “Thousand Colors” and “It’s Already Dusk.”
lead_paragraph: The Battery Dance Festival, which runs from Aug. 15-21, offers a panoramic view of world dance on an outdoor stage with panoramic views of New York harbor. On Monday night the Polish Dance Theater makes its American debut with Takako Matsuda’s “Thousand Colors” and “It’s Already Dusk,” in which Ewa Wycichowska, the company’s director, depicts a symbolic contest between life and death. (It’s inspired by Ingmar Bergman; death, on stilts, looms above everyone.) Enzo Celli and Elisabetta Minutoli’s “Zònton,” for Mr. Celli’s Rome-based VIVO Ballet, takes its title from an ancient Greek word for “living.” Although Kate Thomas’s Ballet Neo is a New York group, her “Fellini’s Dream” evokes the sentimental and grotesque Italy imagined by the film director Federico Fellini. It’s all free, views included. (6:30 p.m., Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park, Battery City, 212-219-3910)

headline: When Online Loan Applications Lead to Unauthorized Bank Account Debits
abstract: Federal regulators charged two data brokers with illegally selling consumers’ loan applications to nonlenders that used the sensitive financial information to commit fraud.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of cash-strapped Americans who filled out applications for payday loans on sites with names like paymeloans.com instead found their financial details had been used to make unauthorized debits or credit card charges, according to an investigation by federal regulators.

headline: The Afropunk Festival in Brooklyn Explores All the Angles
abstract: The annual outdoor festival of alternative black music in Brooklyn is an evolving argument against category.
lead_paragraph: Afropunk, the annual outdoor festival of alternative black music, is an evolving argument against category. This year’s edition, on Aug. 22 and 23 in Brooklyn, includes varying takes on the long and wide R&B tradition from Kelis, SZA and Ms. Lauryn Hill; progressive-pop virtuosity from the bassist Thundercat; enigmatic rapping from Danny Brown; metallic and noisy heaviness from Suicidal Tendencies and Death Grips; futuristic folk from Raury; traditional or mainstream blues and rock from Gary Clark Jr. and Lenny Kravitz.

headline: George Benjamin Reimagines the Pied Piper in ‘Into the Little Hill’
abstract: This darkly inventive chamber opera features the soprano Hila Plitmann and the mezzo Susan Bickley taking on a host of characters.
lead_paragraph: George Benjamin’s brilliant opera “Written on Skin” was rightly heralded as the highlight of this summer’s Mostly Mozart Festival. If you weren’t able to snag a ticket, try Sunday’s performance of Mr. Benjamin’s “Into the Little Hill.” This 40-minute chamber opera is a darkly inventive reimagining of the tale of the Pied Piper of Hamelin as a political allegory, with a text by Martin Crimp, the poet behind the astonishingly original libretto to “Written on Skin.” The soprano Hila Plitmann and the mezzo Susan Bickley take on a host of characters, and many of the 15 musicians from the International Contemporary Ensemble multitask, too — watch for unusual instruments including bass flute, cimbalom, banjo and basset-horns.

headline: Met Opens Asian Art Exhibitions Featuring Dynasties’ Silk and Gold
abstract: One exhibit features three rare pieces from the Tang dynasty, a Song dynasty tapestry scroll cover and Yuan dynasty examples of cloth woven with gold thread.
lead_paragraph: The 100th anniversary celebration of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Asian Art department continues this month with the opening of exhibitions on Chinese lacquer and textiles.

headline: Bigger Is Brighter at the Museum of the Moving Image
abstract: This week alone includes “Lawrence of Arabia” and the greatest New York musical, “West Side Story.”
lead_paragraph: Table the tablet, shut down the smartphone. From outdoor movies to Imax blockbusters, summer seems built for living large. In that seasonal spirit, the Museum of the Moving Image’s intermittent series “See It Big!” has scheduled a program through Aug. 30 of features shot using 70-millimeter film for images that are brighter and sound that is richer than 35 millimeter can hope to provide. This week alone includes David Lean’s classic “Lawrence of Arabia” and the greatest New York musical, Jerome Robbins and Robert Wise’s “West Side Story.”

headline: A.R. Gurney’s ‘Love & Money’: Wealth, a Widow and Complications
abstract: The playwright’s new work at the Signature Theater examines the late-in-life introspection of a wealthy widow determined to give away all her worldly possessions.
lead_paragraph: The playwright A. R. Gurney may have mused about retirement in the past, but he isn’t going anywhere. In his mid-80s, Mr. Gurney, the longtime chronicler of the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant experience, seems to have a play opening every week. Last season brought a revival of “Love Letters” on Broadway and two productions at the Signature Theater. A revival of his popular comedy “Sylvia” comes to Broadway in September. And his new “Love & Money,” now in previews for an Aug. 24 opening at the Signature, examines the late-in-life introspection of a wealthy widow named Cornelia Cunningham (played by Maureen Anderman) determined to give away all her worldly possessions. The plan of Ms. Cunningham, who is white, hits a snag when an African-American man (Gabriel Brown) arrives at her home saying that he is the child of her dead daughter, putting into question issues of inheritance. (Pershing Square Signature Theater, 212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org.)

headline: Uggie, Co-Star of ‘The Artist,’ Dies at 13
abstract: The Jack Russell terrier was a red-carpet favorite.
lead_paragraph: Uggie, the plucky Jack Russell whose co-starring performance in “The Artist” (2011) earned him the Palm Dog and Golden Collar awards, died in Los Angeles on Friday after a battle with a prostate cancer. He was 13.

headline: Want to Shop for a Surprise? Try a Subscription Box
abstract: The business is precarious, with thin margins on low-cost supplies, but the interest, in items from makeup to animal treats to fantasy fiction, is growing.
lead_paragraph: Need a monthly delivery of doomsday prepping supplies? How about treats for your pet rabbit, or only-available-in-Japan snacks like Umashi Oasi Cheetos?

headline: Through the Keyholes, Reporting on Prisons
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prison Escapes', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Reporter Michael Schwirtz explains how he and Michael Winerip explain how they report stories about life behind bars.
lead_paragraph: Mike Winerip and I have been reporting on New York jails and prisons for more than a year. Doing so is like looking through a keyhole: It is very difficult to get reliable information about what is going on inside a corrections facility.

headline: Sam Elliott, a Leading Man Again at 71, No Cowboy Hat Required
abstract: Mr. Elliott has spent close to 50 years as America’s screen cowboy. But now he finds himself in demand in different kinds of roles.
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, Calif. — Not too long ago, the actor Sam Elliott, who has spent much of his 46-year career alternately fighting and embracing habitual typecasting as America’s cowboy, was referred to as a “male ingénue.”

headline: The Quay Twins: Spinning Magic From Marginalia
abstract: Identical twins Stephen and Timothy Quay muse about their imaginative process.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, identical twins Stephen and Timothy Quay have gradually coaxed life from a baffling combination of everyday objects and handcrafted puppets and sets.

headline: Donald Trump Takes On China After Devaluation
keywords: ['Currency', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Donald J. Trump criticized China on Tuesday for its recent currency devaluations, saying “it’s a disgrace” how detrimentally it affects United States businesses and competition in the world economic market.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump announced his run for president in June, much of the focus was on his explosive comments about Mexican immigrants. But he also had another target: China, which he mentioned at least a dozen times, saying, “They’re killing us” economically and that “China comes over and they dump all their stuff” on American markets.

headline: Janet Baker’s Voice, a Singular Instrument, Lingers Like No Other
abstract: A lover of dance tells why he’ll always remember the infinite variety of a mezzo-soprano’s 1970s opera performances.
lead_paragraph: Dance was not the first love of my life among the arts. Growing up in the English countryside, I lived for hours on end in books and beside the gramophone; the first performing art to obsess me was opera. When I first attended opera, at 17, it immediately proved addictive.

headline: For ‘Mistress America,’ Noah Baumbach and Greta Gerwig Serve Screwball With a Whiff of Menace
abstract: Noah Baumbach and Greta Gerwig talk about some of the films that helped inspire their latest collaboration, “Mistress America.”
lead_paragraph: Both of Noah Baumbach’s parents reviewed movies when he was growing up in Brooklyn — his father, Jonathan Baumbach, for Partisan Review, and his mother, Georgia Brown, for The Village Voice. So it may not be a surprise that Mr. Baumbach, 45, became a writer-director whose films often pay homage to screen influences like Woody Allen and Hal Ashby.

headline: International Money Mania
abstract: Big symbolism, small consequences.
lead_paragraph: China is claiming that it’s not devaluing the renminbi to gain competitive advantage, it’s adding flexibility to prepare for the yuan as an international reserve currency, becoming part of the basket in the IMF’s SDRs and all that. That’s highly implausible as a story about what’s happening right now; but it may be true that China’s urge to loosen capital controls is driven in part by its global-currency ambitions.

headline: Paying for College: Election Edition
keywords: ['Income', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Student Loans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Marco Rubio supports linking student loan repayments to borrowers’ incomes — but that’s not a solution to high college costs.
lead_paragraph: The Editorial Board recently pointed out that the Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders have announced plans to make college more affordable, while the only rumbling from the Republican camp so far is Senator Marco Rubio’s support for linking loan repayments to borrowers’ incomes.

headline: Hailee Steinfeld’s Tough, Perforated Leather Skirt
abstract: The actress attended a screening last night in a playful Miu Miu look.
lead_paragraph: The Star: Hailee Steinfeld

headline: F.D.A. Warns Company Over Kardashian Instagram Marketing
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said that Kim Kardashian West’s promotion of a morning-sickness product did not mention the drug’s risks.
lead_paragraph: “OMG. Have you heard about this?”

headline: Excerpt: ‘Show Me a Hero’
abstract: Oscar Isaac stars as an embattled Yonkers politician in the HBO mini-series.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Isaac stars as an embattled Yonkers politician in the HBO mini-series.

headline: David Simon and Cory Booker on ‘Show Me a Hero’ and the Future of Cities
abstract: Mr. Simon, the creator of HBO’s “Show Me a Hero,” about the court-ordered desegregation of Yonkers, and Senator Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, discuss the mini-series, housing, race and urban policy.
lead_paragraph: When the elevator door at the housing project opens onto two men seemingly dealing drugs, a young mother, loaded down with groceries, wordlessly opts to lead her small children lugging backpacks up the decrepit stairs. Across town, an all-white mob fumes before an all-white city council, which eggs it on. Later, a man spits on the mayor, who defies the angry crowd.

headline: U.N. Official Resigns Amid Accusations of Sex Abuse by Peacekeepers
abstract: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, said his head of mission in the Central African Republic, Babacar Gaye, had resigned “at my request.”
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In an exceptional move, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Wednesday ousted his top official in the Central African Republic after repeated accusations that peacekeepers there committed what Mr. Ban called “terrible crimes of sexual violence” against civilians, including children.

headline: Devaluation Hints at China’s Rising Distress Over Economy
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: China allowed the renminbi to weaken significantly for a third consecutive day, its biggest plunge in decades, increasing concerns that the sluggish economy is even worse off and that the government is panicking.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Whenever China’s economy swooned in recent downturns, its currency never buckled. It held steady, or strengthened, even as China’s neighbors or trading partners scrambled to cut the value of their own currencies to deal with the fallout.

headline: Filling a Reservoir With ‘Shade Balls’
abstract: A municipal district in California has been filling its reservoirs with thousands of black balls in an effort to reduce evaporation and deter birds.
lead_paragraph: A municipal district in California has been filling its reservoirs with thousands of black balls in an effort to reduce evaporation and deter birds.

headline: Bayreuth Festival, the House That Wagner Built, Stays on Course but Changes
abstract: Founded by Richard Wagner and begun in 1876, the festival to this day is directed by his descendants and solely devoted to his work.
lead_paragraph: BAYREUTH, Germany — Audience members headed to the Bayreuth Festival weren’t happy. The train route from Nuremberg, the principal way to reach this small town in northern Bavaria, was suspended because of construction. They would have to take a bus instead. It would be slow. It would be uncomfortable.

headline: New York Hospitals Group Requests Ban on TV Filming
abstract: The request was prompted by anger over the story of a widow on the Upper East Side who was watching “NY Med,” a real-life medical series, in 2012 when she recognized her husband.
lead_paragraph: The association that represents nearly all major New York City hospitals has asked its members not to allow patients to be filmed for entertainment purposes without their consent, joining a chorus of disapproval of a practice that patients’ families have said breached their privacy during their most vulnerable moments.

headline: Teatro Colón in Buenos Aires Aims to Reclaim Glory Days with a New Direction
abstract: While the company has had its share of bumps, it remains a fount of talent and is taking on more contemporary fare under a new director.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The Teatro Colón, a stately Belle Époque building, presides over the Avenida 9 de Julio here like a grande dame, elegant and imposing. The century-old building fills a city block, rising four stories and extending three stories below ground, with studios and workshops beneath the avenue and the Plaza del Vaticano. It is one of this city’s most important landmarks, a reminder of a more prosperous era, when artists like Toscanini, Caruso and the Ballets Russes routinely performed there.

headline: New School Technology for Class and the Quad
abstract: New devices include some to help students with note-taking, navigating a laptop and data storage. But first, there’s a way to dispose of old gadgets.
lead_paragraph: It is almost time for teachers and students to head back to campus, and many of them will arrive with the newest technology in things like headphones and storage devices. Here are some notable gadgets that will enhance your back-to-school experience:

headline: Spielberg-Coens Drama ‘Bridge of Spies’ Gets New York Film Festival Premiere
abstract: The rest of the main slate was also announced and includes Cannes prizewinners “Carol” and “The Assassin.”
lead_paragraph: “Bridge of Spies,” the Steven Spielberg-Coen brothers Cold War drama, will get its world premiere at the New York Film Festival, organizers announced Wednesday as they released details of a diverse main slate featuring movies from Asia, Europe and North America.

headline: Guggenheim, With Eye on Asian Art, Hires Two New Curators
abstract: The Guggenheim Museum’s new curators will focus on exhibitions of work by artists from mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.
lead_paragraph: The Guggenheim Museum, which has delved more deeply into Asian art than any other American museum in recent years, announced Wednesday that it had hired two curators to focus on exhibitions that will feature the work of artists born in mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau.

headline: A Less Defiant Germany Seems Prepared to Clear a Path for a Third Greek Bailout
abstract: While a political obstacle course still lies ahead, officials in Berlin and Brussels are speaking of a markedly improved negotiating climate.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany softened its resistance to a third bailout package for Greece on Wednesday, raising the chances that a draft plan could be approved in time for the country to make a crucial debt payment next week.

headline: Facial Recognition Software Moves From Overseas Wars to Local Police
keywords: ['Police', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Computer Vision', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Face']
abstract: Dozens of police departments have begun using facial recognition technology to pursue conventional criminal suspects like drug dealers and prostitutes.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Facial recognition software, which American military and intelligence agencies used for years in Iraq and Afghanistan to identify potential terrorists, is being eagerly adopted by dozens of police departments around the country to pursue drug dealers, prostitutes and other conventional criminal suspects. But because it is being used with few guidelines and with little oversight or public disclosure, it is raising questions of privacy and concerns about potential misuse.

headline: Fury 325
abstract: Fury 325 at Carowinds is the newest addition to the giga coaster family, and is the tallest of the group. It traverses the North Carolina-South Carolina state line.
lead_paragraph: Fury 325 at Carowinds is the newest addition to the giga coaster family, and is the tallest of the group. It traverses the North Carolina-South Carolina state line.

headline: Tianjin, a Port in China, Is Rocked by Explosions That Killed Dozens
abstract: At least 44 died and hundreds were reported injured in the blasts, which caused a huge fireball in the city, about 90 miles east of Beijing.
lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — Thunderous, fiery explosions at a warehouse containing hazardous goods traumatized this northeast port city late Wednesday, killing at least 44 people, injuring at least 400, shattering glass on scores of high-rise buildings and causing other extensive damage.

headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General, Kathleen Kane, Denies Charges
abstract: Ms. Kane defended herself against charges including perjury, saying she did not conspire to leak information from a grand jury investigation.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane defended herself against criminal charges on Wednesday, saying she was the victim of retaliation against her own investigation into pornographic emails that were exchanged between some officials in the previous state administration.

headline: Pope Urges Work-Life Balance
abstract: Pope Francis, during his weekly general address at the Vatican, urged his followers not to become “slaves to work.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, during his weekly general address at the Vatican, urged his followers not to become “slaves to work.”

headline: 36 Hours in Berlin
abstract: Berlin bursts with a creative spirit that is on full display in cutting-edge restaurants, performance spots and art, both on and off the street.
lead_paragraph: Berlin bursts with a creative spirit that is on full display in cutting-edge restaurants, performance spots and art, both on and off the street.

headline: SunGard Sale Has a Bright Side for Owners
abstract: Although the private equity firms that own SunGard are selling it for less than what they paid, they can expect a modest return on their investment.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, it would appear that the $9.1 billion sale, including debt, of the financial software maker SunGard to Fidelity National Information Services would be a disappointment to the private equity firms that paid nearly $11 billion for Sungard.

headline: 36 Hours in Berlin
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Summertime highlights, when Berliners head outdoors, include a boat tour, riverside restaurants and evenings enjoying the view from a rooftop playground.
lead_paragraph: There are few cities in the world that transform themselves as profoundly from season to season as Berlin. The purgatorial winter, with its lightless days and frigid nights, gives way to four months of balmy intoxication. Cafe and gallery culture spills out into graffitied alleyways; the parks fill with techno D.J.s, nudists and picnicking families; and young people arrive by the planeload from Brooklyn, Copenhagen and East London to take part in an open-air night-life scene that is equal parts “Paris Is Burning” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” But even as the hype of the last decade has made the city a magnet for tourists, Berlin remains a place for the strange and libertine, where the radical left still nips at the heels of neoliberalism, where snapping photos in public is often more taboo than smoking a joint, and where people seldom ask what it is you “do.”

headline: Review: In ‘Up Here,’ Boy (and All His Inner Demons and Angels) Meets Girl
abstract: This original musical from the married team of Robert Lopez and Kristen Anderson-Lopez, who won an Oscar for their song “Let It Go,” is making its premiere at La Jolla Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Calif. — Geek meets girl. Geek’s neuroses drive him batty. Geek loses girl.

headline: Pajamas: From the Sheets to the Streets
abstract: This season, try a silky, structured pantsuit.
lead_paragraph: This season, try a silky, structured pantsuit.

headline: An Unusual Octopus Gets a Second Look
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: The larger Pacific striped octopus has an unusual way of mating, and hunts with a “slow bounce” style.
lead_paragraph: The larger Pacific striped octopus has an unusual way of mating, and hunts with a “slow bounce” style.

headline: App Smart | Start-Up 101
abstract: Manage projects for your new start-up from anywhere with organization apps that help tie all the loose ends together.
lead_paragraph: Manage projects for your new start-up from anywhere with organization apps that help tie all the loose ends together.

headline: Video Feature: Inexpensive Apps for Entrepreneurs and Start-Ups
abstract: These digital tools — many of which are free — can improve efficiency by helping your team perform a variety of functions, like filing expense reports, designing logos and enacting ideas.
lead_paragraph: WHEN you’re starting a company, speed and efficiency are priorities. Luckily, there are plenty of apps for your smartphone or tablet that can help people collaborate and make quicker decisions.

headline: Vertical Video on the Small Screen? Not a Crime
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Smartphones', 'Tablet Computers', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: There are strong opinions about whether to shoot video vertically or horizontally. Holding your phone the “wrong way” provokes both professional and amateur photographers.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Vincent Bova and Damien Eckhardt-Jacobi, two puppeteers who host a YouTube series called Glove and Boots, created a public service announcement to warn viewers about what they considered a modern scourge: People keep shooting videos while holding their phones vertically.

headline: In California, Millions of ‘Shade Balls’ Combat a Nagging Drought
abstract: Ninety-six million little balls in the Los Angeles Reservoir will help block sunlight and UV rays that promote algae growth, helping to keep drinking water safe.
lead_paragraph: Facing a long-term water crisis, officials concerned with preserving a reservoir in Los Angeles hatched a plan: They would combat four years of drought with 96 million plastic balls.

headline: Pennsylvania Attorney General on Charges
abstract: Kathleen G. Kane, Pennsylvania’s attorney general, denied all charges against her on Wednesday, saying that the accusations came out of an incomplete investigation into pornographic emails.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen G. Kane, Pennsylvania’s attorney general, denied all charges against her on Wednesday, saying that the accusations came out of an incomplete investigation into pornographic emails.

headline: Carly Fiorina Emerges as a G.O.P. Weapon Against ‘War on Women’ Charge
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After months of attacking Hillary Rodham Clinton, the former  Hewlett-Packard executive began to gain traction as debate viewers saw her as singularly qualified to take on Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: This week, Donald J. Trump said that listening to Carly Fiorina, the only woman competing for the Republican presidential nomination, gave him “a massive headache.”

headline: Alibaba’s Slump May Test Investors’ Good Will
abstract: Investors haven’t much challenged the founder of the Chinese e-commerce group. Its latest earnings report may change that.
lead_paragraph: The golden-child status of the Chinese e-commerce group Alibaba hangs by a thread.

headline: Judge Prods N.F.L. at Hearing on Tom Brady’s Suspension
abstract: A federal judge in Manhattan questioned lawyers from both sides for about an hour, but spent a lot of time poking at the N.F.L.’s case.
lead_paragraph: After seven months of accusations, recriminations and bluster, the N.F.L. and New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady faced off in federal court before a skeptical judge who grilled both sides about Brady’s four-game suspension for his role in the deflation of footballs used in a playoff game.

headline: Where to Watch the Perseid Meteor Shower in the New York Area
abstract: Fair weather and a new moon may make this year’s Perseid meteor shower the most spectacular since at least 2008.
lead_paragraph: A harmonic convergence of cosmic dust, lunar phase and fair weather on Wednesday is shaping up to make the Perseid meteor shower this year the most spectacular since at least 2008.

headline: Texas Officer Who Killed Unarmed Man Made Mistakes, Police Experts Say
abstract: Officer Brad Miller violated several principles of modern-day policing before he fatally shot an unarmed black college student, according to law enforcement veterans.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When Officer Brad Miller, a trainee in the Arlington Police Department, walked through the shattered glass in an automobile showroom here in pursuit of a suspected burglar, he had already violated several basic principles of modern-day policing, according to law enforcement veterans: Wait for backup, establish a perimeter, have a plan.

headline: Tianjin Blast Caught on Video
abstract: Cellphone video captured the moment an explosion tore through a warehouse in China’s northeast port city of Tianjin late Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Cellphone video captured the moment an explosion tore through a warehouse in China’s northeast port city of Tianjin late Wednesday.

headline: Siri, Tell Me a Joke. No, a Funny One.
abstract: Though aiming for chatbots with a personality and a comedic voice, most developers have offered up only an array of cheesy jokes.
lead_paragraph: When Siri, the voice-activated assistant, debuted on the iPhone in 2011, it had a number of hidden jokes that Apple executives were unaware of.

headline: Time Is Running Out on Part of Assange Sex Assault Investigation
abstract: Swedish officials said that three of the four claims against Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, may never be investigated, but one, of rape, could continue for a further five years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Time is running out for Swedish prosecutors investigating accusations of sexual assault against Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, who has been holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London since he walked into the building in 2012 and requested asylum.

headline: Pistol Packing in the Kansas Statehouse
abstract: New laws allow visitors to carry concealed loaded handguns into the building.
lead_paragraph: The citizens’ right to bear arms in Kansas is now flourishing at the very heart of government — the Statehouse in Topeka. New laissez faire laws championed by the gun lobby allow visitors to routinely carry concealed loaded handguns into the building, and they no longer need a state permit and safety training to do so.

headline: NBCUniversal Invests $200 Million in Vox Media
abstract: The media giant and digital upstart intend to blur the lines between their two worlds and collaborate on programming, advertising and technology.
lead_paragraph: Vox Media, a publishing house for the digital age, has landed a $200 million strategic investment from the entertainment group NBCUniversal, forming a partnership between the new and old media companies to collaborate on programming, advertising and technology.

headline: The Appeal of a Romper
abstract: Snapping on a playsuit in the heat of a New York City summer.
lead_paragraph: Snapping on a playsuit in the heat of a New York City summer.

headline: Bipartisan Group of Ex-Senators to Run Ads Against Iran Deal
abstract: Norm Coleman, Joseph I. Lieberman, Evan Bayh and Saxby Chambliss have founded a group that is spending $6.2 million to runs ads in nine states against President Obama’s nuclear agreement with Iran.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of former senators and veterans is unveiling a multimillion advertising campaign aimed at derailing President Obama’s nuclear agreement with Iran.

headline: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Has Cancer
abstract: In a statement, Mr. Carter said that recent liver surgery revealed cancer that had spread to several parts of his body.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Former President Jimmy Carter announced on Wednesday that he had been given a diagnosis of a spreading cancer that was detected by recent liver surgery.

headline: Scandals in Brazil Prompt Fears of a Return to Turmoil
abstract: Some Brazilians are calling for the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff amid corruption scandals. And the sense of political uncertainty ranks among the country’s worst since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The president is battling calls for her impeachment. The speaker of Brazil’s lower house is grappling with accusations that he pocketed a $5 million bribe. The former treasurer of the governing Workers Party is in jail.

headline: Teasing Out Ai Weiwei’s Endgame, After China Lifts a Travel Ban
abstract: Mr. Ai has said things to German news media that have horrified his fans, who saw him as a voice of resistance to tyranny.
lead_paragraph: Read in Chinese | 点击查看本文中文版

headline: No Comment Necessary: Clinton Campaign Asks for Student-Debt Emojis
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Student Loans']
abstract: The response has not been positive.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s official Twitter account asked followers on Wednesday to share their feelings about student loan debt — but the specifics of the request were a little surprising:

headline: Sandra Lee Is Released From Hospital After Surgery for Infection
abstract: Ms. Lee, a television host and longtime companion of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, underwent an operation several months after she had a double mastectomy for breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: Sandra Lee, the television host and longtime companion of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, was released from the hospital on Wednesday, her spokeswoman said, after undergoing surgery meant to address a lingering infection, several months after she had a double mastectomy for breast cancer.

headline: The Perils of Ever-Changing Work Schedules Extend to Children’s Well-Being
keywords: ['Working Hours', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Children and Childhood', 'Law and Legislation', 'Parenting']
abstract: Research suggests that as a result of parents’ problematic schedules, children’s language and problem-solving skills may suffer and they may be more likely to smoke and drink as they grow older.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Abercrombie & Fitch announced last week that it would stop requiring workers to be on call for shifts that could be canceled with little notice, making it the latest retailer to pull back from such scheduling practices.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Visits Syria for Talks With Assad
abstract: The Iranian minister arrived in Damascus to discuss the civil war in Syria with President Bashar al-Assad while rebel shelling and government strikes killed more than 30 people nearby.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The foreign minister of Iran arrived in Damascus, Syria, on Wednesday to discuss the civil war in Syria with President Bashar al-Assad, while rebel shelling and government airstrikes killed more than 30 people nearby.

headline: Review: Grace Potter Stretches Her Sound on ‘Midnight,’ Her Debut Solo Album
abstract: Ms. Potter, the frontwoman of Grace Potter and the Nocturnals for over a decade, shows she is a pop-rock eclectic, pinballing between styles and letting her voice fill in the outlines.
lead_paragraph: GRACE POTTER

headline: What Taylor Swift Can Teach You About Rompers
abstract: In summer, the grown-up version of a playsuit provides convenience, comfort and modesty.
lead_paragraph: As with any style traditionally worn by babies — pigtails, overalls, pinafores — a romper carries the risk of making an adult look as if she recently escaped from her playpen.

headline: Review: Terri Lyne Carrington’s ‘Mosaic Project’ Sequel
abstract: Subtitled “Love and Soul,” Terri Lyne Carrington’s latest album features a starry lineup of women singing romantic R&B.
lead_paragraph: TERRI LYNE CARRINGTON

headline: Review: Ashwini Ramaswamy Goes Solo at the Drive East Festival
abstract: Ms. Ramaswamy, from the Ragamala Dance Company of Minneapolis, performed works honoring Indian gods at La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: Dancers are like anyone else: Sometimes they get the urge to leave the nest. Ashwini Ramaswamy, a soloist with the much-admired Ragamala Dance Company, struck out on her own on Tuesday night at Drive East, the excellent festival of Indian music and dance playing through Sunday at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa.

headline: Conservatives Need to Redefine Themselves as More Caring, John Kasich Says
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: During a campaign trip to New Hampshire, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio said that conservatives should not be shy about saying that “we care about people who are down and out and we want to give them a chance to succeed.”
lead_paragraph: DERRY, N.H. – It was the last question at Gov. John R. Kasich’s town-hall-style meeting here on Wednesday, and it also was perhaps the bluntest.

headline: Review: Enrique Vila-Matas Plots His Own Awakening in ‘The Illogic of Kassel’
abstract: In this semi-fictional book by Mr. Vila-Matas, an invitation to act as an installation piece at an exhibition in Germany begins a journey of revelations.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a 60-something Spanish writer with several substantial international prizes under your belt. You’re prone to feeling anxiety and dread come nightfall, and famously decline invitations that keep you out late. But, one day, you receive an invitation to act as an installation piece at Documenta, the quinquennial contemporary-art exhibition in Kassel, Germany. You think, What would a writer like me do in a place like that?

headline: The ‘Shopping List’ of Rogue Traders
abstract: A group of men, who were recently indicted, would sometimes submit “shopping lists” to hackers with the names of the companies whose press releases they wanted to obtain illegally from news services like BusinessWire and PR Newswire. This is one of those lists.
lead_paragraph: A group of men, who were recently indicted, would sometimes submit “shopping lists” to hackers with the names of the companies whose press releases they wanted to obtain illegally from news services like BusinessWire and PR Newswire. This is one of those lists.

headline: Fashion’s Favorite Yoga Trainers Tell You What and What Not to Wear to Class
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Yoga', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Plus: A line of rubber-soled shoes made of neoprene that dries in the sun in just 10 minutes; a new e-commerce site with the goal to make gold and gold-plated jewelry affordable and a pop-up store with walls painted by the Instagram phenomenon @drawbertson.
lead_paragraph: Plus: A line of rubber-soled shoes made of neoprene that dries in the sun in just 10 minutes; a new e-commerce site with the goal to make gold and gold-plated jewelry affordable and a pop-up store with walls painted by the Instagram phenomenon @drawbertson.

headline: Trump Weighs In on China
abstract: Speaking at a campaign event in Michigan, the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump criticized the Chinese government for devaluing its currency, calling the move a “disgrace.”
lead_paragraph: Speaking at a campaign event in Michigan, the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump criticized the Chinese government for devaluing its currency, calling the move a “disgrace.”

headline: 7 La Guardia Cab Dispatchers Accused of Taking Bribes From Drivers
abstract: The dispatchers showed up at the airport for what they thought would be a training session, but were instead arrested and charged with taking payoffs to let cabdrivers cut long lines to pick up fares.
lead_paragraph: It might feel like forever, standing in line outside an airport terminal, luggage in tow, waiting for a taxi. But when cabdrivers obey the rules, it is likely that they have waited just as long, if not longer — idling in a lot, awaiting the go-ahead from a dispatcher.

headline: Tom Brady Sketch Artist, Panned Online, Apologizes
abstract: Jane Rosenberg, a New York City artist, apologized to Tom Brady for a courtroom sketch that was widely mocked online.
lead_paragraph: “This courtroom sketch of Tom Brady will haunt your dreams,” Fusion declared.

headline: Review: In ‘Written on Skin,’ George Benjamin Creates an Unusual Love Triangle
abstract: This opera, adapted from a 13th-century tale, has hooks beyond the music.
lead_paragraph: In the first scene of the British composer George Benjamin’s extraordinary opera “Written on Skin,” a group of modern-day angels bustle about in an upstairs room on a two-tiered set. It could be a kind of laboratory, or maybe the fitting room of a celestial opera house. That’s the way it looks in this haunting production by the director Katie Mitchell, which opened a three-performance run at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday, receiving an enormous ovation. The production comes from the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France, where the opera had its premiere in 2012. In an ambitious venture, the Mostly Mozart festival is presenting the American stage premiere at Lincoln Center.

headline: N.S.A. Used Phone Records Program to Seek Iran Operatives
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Terrorism', 'Cellular Telephones', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: A document obtained by The New York Times also showed that AT&T and Sprint were involved in the bulk domestic phone records program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency has used its bulk domestic phone records program to search for operatives from the government of Iran and “associated terrorist organizations” — not just Al Qaeda and its allies — according to a document obtained by The New York Times.

headline: N.S.A. Inspector General’s Reports About Bulk Phone Records Program Are Released
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has provided these reports by the National Security Agency’s inspector general about the once-secret bulk phone records program. The release includes an unredacted letter showing the full name of an order from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court about the program, which usually is redacted. It lists phone company names and discloses that the program can be used to search for operatives of the government of Iran and associated terrorist groups, not just Al Qaeda and its allies.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by The New York Times, the Justice Department has provided these reports by the National Security Agency’s inspector general about the once-secret bulk phone records program. The release includes an unredacted letter showing the full name of an order from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court about the program, which usually is redacted. It lists phone company names and discloses that the program can be used to search for operatives of the government of Iran and associated terrorist groups, not just Al Qaeda and its allies.

headline: How Olivia Kim Is Teaching Nordstrom to Think Small
abstract: With Space, Nordstrom prepares to challenge independent boutiques on their own terms.
lead_paragraph: The woman coaxing the $13 billion fashion retailer to think small has a “Babes in Toyland” squeak, intermittently bleach-blond hair and the letters S-I-C-K tattooed across her knuckles.

abstract: Greece and More — Photos of the Day
lead_paragraph: Greece and More — Photos of the Day

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘Sunset, o639 Hours’ by BalletX at the Joyce Theater
abstract: Matthew Neenan’s two-act ballet, about a 1938 airmail flight and its crash, with scenes set in Auckland, New Zealand, and in Pago Pago.
lead_paragraph: A plane crash may seem like unusual fodder for a story ballet, though the longer you spend with Matthew Neenan’s “Sunset, o639 Hours,” the more related ballet and aviation appear to be: twin forms of flight and propulsion through space. This two-act work for Philadelphia’s terrific BalletX, presented as part of the Joyce Theater’s Ballet Festival on Tuesday, revolves around the American pilot Edwin Musick, who in 1938 manned the first airmail flight from New Zealand to Hawaii. The Samoan Clipper, as his aircraft was known, went down on its return trip, just off the Samoan coast.

headline: The Slave Quarters at Joseph Lloyd Manor
abstract: Joseph McGill, founder of the Slave Dwelling Project, is sleeping in former slave quarters on Long Island, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Joseph McGill, founder of the Slave Dwelling Project, is sleeping in former slave quarters on Long Island, N.Y.

headline: Slavery at Sylvester Manor
abstract: Joseph McGill, founder of the Slave Dwelling Project, is sleeping in former slave quarters on Long Island, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Joseph McGill, founder of the Slave Dwelling Project, is sleeping in former slave quarters on Long Island, N.Y.

headline: Confronting Slavery at Long Island’s Oldest Estates
abstract: Joseph McGill has slept in more than 70 slave dwellings in 14 states. Now he’s coming to New York.
lead_paragraph: Joseph McGill first unrolled bedding in a former slave cabin in 1999. He was participating in a documentary about Civil War re-enactors and the controversy over the Confederate battle flag, and the producers asked Mr. McGill — an African-American museum professional from South Carolina who dresses in the Union blue — if he could add some spice to a scene being filmed at a plantation near Charleston.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know.

headline: Opponents of Iran Deal Try to Reach Young Voters on Snapchat
abstract: An effort to engage young people in the debate over the nuclear accord with Iran stimulated a lot of discussion, not all of it on-message.
lead_paragraph: Speaking in favor of the international arms control agreement with Iran last week in Washington, President Obama warned that opponents of the deal would flood the airwaves with “tens of millions of dollars in advertising,” ahead of a congressional vote in September. He failed, however, to advise citizens who want to tune out the debate entirely to avoid not just their televisions but also Snapchat, the social messaging service popular with teenagers.

headline: Rex Ryan and Bills Sign Ikemefuna Enemkpali
abstract: A day after punching Jets quarterback Geno Smith in the face, Enemkpali found a new home with a former Jets coach.
lead_paragraph: A day after punching Jets quarterback Geno Smith in the face, Ikemefuna Enemkpali found a new home — with the former Jets coach Rex Ryan.

headline: Review: Matthias Goerne Captures the Mood at the Mostly Mozart Festival
abstract: Mr. Goerne had a dark and heavy tone that matched Bach’s solo Cantata No. 82, one of the pieces he performed on Tuesday at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: What was notable about the concert of the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra on Tuesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall, apart from its excellence, was that the program was mostly Mozart, or at least more than half. Jane Moss, as artistic director of the festival since 1992, continues to take it in so many new and stimulating directions that Mozart can sometimes seem like an endangered species there.

headline: Review: Mario Diaz de Leon Plays Selections From ‘The Soul Is the Arena’
abstract: Mr. Diaz de Leon performed selections from his new album and others, at the Stone in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: A handful of listeners sat in almost total darkness at the late show at the Stone on Tuesday evening, as the composer Mario Diaz de Leon used a laptop to perform electronic works he described as his “most extreme music,” written while an undergraduate at Oberlin.

headline: HAY Mini Market Comes to New York
abstract: Here are some items that are sold at the store.
lead_paragraph: Here are some items that are sold at the store.

headline: August 12, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Greece, India, South Korea and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, India, South Korea and India.

headline: HAY Mini Market Hits New York
abstract: The Danish furniture company HAY has had success in Paris, London, Tokyo and Milan. Now New York gets a shot at the good stuff.
lead_paragraph: The Danish furniture company HAY has a loyal following in Europe but is virtually unknown in the United States. Think of it as the COS of couches: a brand that style insiders shop when they travel abroad and show off to their friends back home. What’s usually brought back from Copenhagen or Oslo is carry-on-size accessories, like HAY’s colorful trays, decorative textiles and stationery.

headline: U.S. Appeals Ruling That A.I.G. Bailout Terms Were Too Harsh
abstract: The Obama administration’s appeal is a rejection of a June ruling that the federal government overstepped its bounds in taking ownership control of the insurance company in the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: In a move that starts a new chapter in the battle over the bailout of the American International Group during the financial crisis, the Justice Department formally appealed a court ruling on Wednesday that said the government’s terms for saving the company had been too harsh.

headline: After Colorado Waste Spill, E.P.A. Halts Field Investigations
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency is seeking an independent review of a spill on Aug. 5 that released more than three million gallons of toxic waste.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — After a contractor for the Environmental Protection Agency accidentally caused a mine to burst during a field investigation — releasing more than three million gallons of toxic waste — the agency’s top official said Wednesday that she had halted all similar investigations until further notice.

headline: Ticks: Summer’s Unwanted Guests
abstract: Thorough checks of spouses, children and friends for the tiny pathogen-carrying freeloaders are now a necessary part of summer rituals.
lead_paragraph: At a recent dinner party in Greenwich, Conn., Topic A was not stock futures or boarding school, but something decidedly less tony: ticks.

headline: Common Core Test Results
abstract: The New York State Education Department released the results of the Common Core English and math tests for students in third through eighth grades.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Education Department released the results of the Common Core English and math tests for students in third through eighth grades.

headline: Gloria Allred Challenges Cosby Lawyer to Debate as 3 More Women Surface with Accusations
abstract: Ms. Allred, a lawyer who now represents 21 women who have leveled sexual allegations against Mr. Cosby, introduced three new accusers at a news conference Wednesday in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The lawyer Gloria Allred introduced three women with new accusations against Bill Cosby on Wednesday at a news conference here and challenged a lawyer for Mr. Cosby, Monique Pressley, to debate the raft of sexual allegations leveled by dozens of women against the entertainer.

headline: Capitalists, Arise!: Q. & A. With Peter Georgescu
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Income Inequality', 'Income Tax', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Corporations', 'Small Business', 'Outsourcing']
abstract: The author of a Sunday Review article arguing that capitalists must address rising income inequality responds to reader comments.
lead_paragraph: In a Sunday Review article last weekend, “Capitalists, Arise!,” Peter Georgescu, the chairman emeritus of Young & Rubicam, argued that if we don’t deal with income inequality, we’ll face intolerable taxes or social unrest. Readers rose up, posting more than a thousand comments on Facebook and The Times’s site challenging and applauding his ideas. Here, Mr. Georgescu addresses a few of their comments.

headline: How Are Those Walleye Biting? On Minnesota Lake, They’re Not
abstract: Only a few days into August, summer on Mille Lacs Lake seemed to be over after a state agency banned walleye fishing, saying the annual quota had already been exceeded.
lead_paragraph: GARRISON, Minn. — Along the rocky shore of Mille Lacs Lake on a recent morning, flat-bottomed fishing boats were idle in their docks. No customers wandered into a bait shop selling night crawlers, minnows and jumbo leeches. The restaurant at Twin Pines Resort was hushed and nearly empty, despite the postcard-perfect views of the vast, sparkling lake it offers from the patio.

headline: Cuba: Reliving Memories of Communism
abstract: When Yana Paskova visited Cuba, her eyes — and heart — were attuned to details that summoned her childhood in Communist Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: When Yana Paskova visited Cuba, her eyes — and heart — were attuned to details that summoned her childhood in Communist Bulgaria.

headline: New N.B.A. Schedule Gives Players More Breaks
abstract: More days off between games have been built in, and the number of games on back-to-back days have been reduced.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. released its 2015-16 schedule on Wednesday, trumpeting an effort to make the season more physically forgiving for players by building in more days off between games.

headline: Money Ills Raise Doubts on Plan to Take SFX Entertainment Private
abstract: A falling stock price, growing losses and several moves by SFX this year have rattled some in the music industry and worried analysts.
lead_paragraph: SFX Entertainment brought dance music to Wall Street, but lately the party — at least when it comes to the company’s stock price — has been a bit of a downer.

headline: Blue Bell Is Shipping Ice Cream Again After a Listeria Outbreak
keywords: ['Listeria Monocytogenes', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Blue Bell Creameries reopens its plant in Sylacauga, Ala., and lines up deliveries to some of its big supermarket customers.
lead_paragraph: Back in April, employees at H-E-B’s grocery stores were scrambling to pull Blue Bell ice cream from their shelves. Come September, they may be rushing to put it back.

headline: The Marines Who Took Down the American Flag in Havana
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: Three men who lowered the flag at the American Embassy in 1961 will be there on Friday to raise it again.
lead_paragraph: Around noon on Jan. 4, 1961, after spending hours feeding mounds of government documents into an incinerator, three American Marines assigned to the embassy guard force in Havana turned their attention to a solemn task: lowering the American flag.

headline: 22-Year Term for Nigerian Who Joined Al Qaeda and Then Denounced It
abstract: A federal judge in Brooklyn said Lawal Babafemi’s recent denunciations of terrorism helped him in receiving less time than guidelines called for.
lead_paragraph: From one perspective, Lawal Babafemi was a propagandist for Al Qaeda who traversed several countries to join in jihad, and was plotting to carry out an important mission when he was arrested in 2011.

headline: Ted Cruz Looks South
abstract: On a road trip full of sweet tea, biscuits and gravy, the Republican presidential hopeful tried hard to prove his bonafides in Dixie.
lead_paragraph: On a road trip full of sweet tea, biscuits and gravy, the Republican presidential hopeful tried hard to prove his bonafides in Dixie.

headline: Evoking Donald Trump, Ted Cruz Grabs for the Limelight During Southern Tour
abstract: In a zigzagging bus tour, Senator Ted Cruz flattered his audience with tributes to Southern culture and to the region’s growing political importance.
lead_paragraph: FRANKLIN, Tenn. — The sweet tea was mostly gone, the homemade coffee cakes picked over by the more than 2,000 who showed up here to hear Senator Ted Cruz deliver a blistering indictment of the direction the country is headed in and of the man who is now leading it.

headline: Prosecutors Ask to Deny Bail to 5 Accused in Insider Trading Ring
abstract: Given their strong ties to Ukraine, a country with which the United States has no extradition treaty, the five men are flight risks, the Brooklyn prosecutors maintained.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have asked the courts to refuse bail to all five men arrested in connection with a scheme that enabled securities traders to benefit from confidential corporate information in news releases stolen by hackers in Ukraine before the documents were made public.

headline: Yankees Surrender Division Lead as Their Offense Continues to Sputter
abstract: The team has scored only nine runs in the last 71 innings, losing six of the last seven games and all of its once-comfortable American League East lead.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Buried in the detritus of 16 innings of baseball on Tuesday night, an extraordinary event occurred: Brett Gardner tried to steal a base.

headline: U.S. Says Iranian Military Figure’s Visit to Russia Violates U.N. Ban
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, the head of Iran’s paramilitary Quds force, has been subject to a travel ban since 2007. The visit may provide fuel to opponents of a nuclear agreement with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department said Wednesday that a recent visit to Moscow by the head of Iran’s paramilitary Quds force had violated a United Nations travel ban that has been imposed because of concerns about Tehran’s nuclear and ballistic missile programs.

headline: The Growing Strength of New York’s “Opt Out” Movement
abstract: An analysis of where students are opting out of New York’s standardized tests.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of where students are opting out of New York’s standardized tests.

headline: Donors Descend on Schumer and Others in Debate on Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Campaign Finance', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The passions of big contributors — and their ability to change a candidate’s fortunes — are a keenly felt undercurrent to the debate over the fate of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before Senator Chuck Schumer’s decision to oppose the Iran nuclear accord, John Shapiro, a New York financier and a leader of the American Jewish Committee, had his ear, plying him with reasons to oppose it.

headline: Nigeria: Boko Haram Is Said to Have a New Leader
abstract: The leader of Boko Haram has been wounded and replaced, the president of Chad said in a state radio broadcast Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Boko Haram, the Islamist militant group that has traumatized Nigeria and expanded its attacks in three neighboring countries, has been wounded and replaced, the president of Chad said in a state radio broadcast Wednesday. President Idriss Déby, whose forces have been collaborating with their counterparts in Nigeria, Cameroon and Niger to battle Boko Haram, said its leader, Abubakar Shekau, had ceded control to another militant identified as Mahamoud Daoud. Mr. Déby did not elaborate on the source of this information, which could not be confirmed independently. But he asserted that Boko Haram’s capabilities had been crushed by the four-country military campaign against the group and that it would be finished as a fighting force by year’s end.

headline: Ivo Karlovic, King of Aces, Closes In on a Record
abstract: Karlovic has the most devastating serve in tennis, a point that was demonstrated Tuesday night when he reached a plateau that only Goran Ivanisevic had surpassed.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — When Ivo Karlovic was a lanky teenager, his daily routine took him to the Salata tennis club in Zagreb, Croatia, where he would fire hundreds of serves into an empty court.

headline: Former Met Museum Official to Lead Roosevelt House
abstract: Harold Holzer, a Lincoln scholar and former government official who recently retired from the museum, will take over the Roosevelt House Public Policy Institute at Hunter College.
lead_paragraph: The question for Harold Holzer — former government official, former Metropolitan Museum of Art official — was: Aren’t you about to follow in the footsteps of men like, oh, maybe, Ulysses S. Grant?

headline: News Corp. Planning to Sell Off Money-Losing Education Unit
abstract: Amplify, the education division of Rupert Murdoch’s company, is in an “advanced stage of negotiations” with a potential buyer.
lead_paragraph: Amplify, a much-heralded push by News Corporation into digital education, led by Joel Klein, a former New York City schools chancellor, is nearing an inglorious end.

headline: Back in Play at P.G.A. Championship, Rory McIlroy Sees Jordan Spieth Testing His Reign
abstract: The world’s No. 1 golfer is returning to defend his title in the P.G.A. Championship after recovering from torn ligaments in his ankle.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Poor Rory McIlroy. He misses two tournaments that he won last year, including the British Open, and people are talking about his No. 1 reign in the past tense. It is as if McIlroy is the established star being upstaged by the ingénue in a Theater on the Greens production titled “All About Spieth.”

headline: Scott Walker Approves Public Funding of Basketball Arena
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Basketball', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The decision to spend $250 million on a new home for the Milwaukee Bucks exposes Gov. Scott Walker, who is running for president as a fiscal conservative, to charges of corporate welfare.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin approved $250 million in public financing for a new arena for the Milwaukee Bucks basketball team on Wednesday, a deal exposing him to charges of corporate welfare as he seeks the Republican nomination as a fiscal conservative.

headline: J. Wallace LaPrade, New York F.B.I. Chief in ’70s, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. LaPrade was fired as head of the New York bureau after being threatened with prosecution for refusing to cooperate with an investigation of illegal F.B.I. break-ins.
lead_paragraph: J. Wallace LaPrade, who oversaw the safe return of several celebrity kidnapping victims and was later fired as the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s New York chief, accused of not being forthcoming about the bureau’s role in illegally investigating radical groups in the 1970s, died on July 31 in Lexington, Va. He was 89.

headline: Fred Otnes, Illustrator and Collage Artist, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Otnes, known for images he made for magazines, movie posters and postage stamps, embraced abstraction well before most other commercial illustrators.
lead_paragraph: Fred Otnes, a prominent illustrator, painter and collage artist who embraced abstraction well before most commercial illustrators did, died on July 28 in Westport, Conn. He was 89.

headline: Review: In ‘Steve: A Docu-Musical,’ Colin Summers Honors an Online Mystery Lyricist
abstract: Mr. Summers’s one-man show details his online correspondence with the title’s inspiration: a man, possibly Australian, who submitted lyrics to him over seven years.
lead_paragraph: “Everything I’m about to tell you is true,” Colin Summers says, and he dings a little yellow bell as his tale begins. But truth is an elusive thing when we know someone only online; we fill the giant gaps with guesswork, trying to discern what’s real.

headline: P.G.A. Events Still Set for Trump Courses
abstract: Since pulling a tournament from a Trump property in the immediate aftermath of remarks that Donald Trump made about Mexican immigrants, the P.G.A. of America has not pulled any more major events at other Trump courses.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — In response to inflammatory remarks that Donald Trump made about Mexican immigrants two months ago, the P.G.A. of America became the first golf organization to pull a tournament from a Trump property, announcing that the Grand Slam of Golf would not be played this fall at Trump National Golf Club near Los Angeles.

headline: DNA Is Said to Solve a Mystery of Warren Harding’s Love Life

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She was denounced as a “degenerate” and a “pervert,” accused of lying for money and shamed for waging a “diabolical” campaign of falsehoods against the president’s family that tore away at his legacy.

headline: Police Abuse Is a Form of Terror
abstract: It inspires a sense of outrage that the people charged with protecting your life could become a threat to it.
lead_paragraph: Writing about the wave of deadly encounters — many caught on video — between unarmed black people and police officers often draws a particular criticism from a particular subset of readers.

headline: A New Role for Lagares as the Mets Keep Rolling
abstract: Juan Lagares is playing with an injured right elbow, and he is essentially set to be replaced in center field by Yoenis Cespedes for the last two months of the season.
lead_paragraph: The other day in the Mets’ clubhouse, Juan Lagares and Ruben Tejada were joking and chatting with Yoenis Cespedes. They listened to him with reverence, the way some of the team’s young pitchers gather and listen to Bartolo Colon’s stories, the way a son might listen to his father.

headline: California: Grand Juries Are Barred From Deciding Cases Involving Police
abstract: The state has banned the use of grand juries to determine whether to prosecute a law enforcement officer in the death of a member of the public.
lead_paragraph: The state has banned the use of grand juries to determine whether to prosecute a law enforcement officer in the death of a member of the public. The law, which Gov. Jerry Brown signed on Tuesday, comes a year after the death of Michael Brown by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., sparked nationwide protests. A grand jury in Missouri did not indict the officer, Darren Wilson. Experts said that the use of grand juries in criminal cases already was relatively rare in California. But now prosecutors will no longer have the option of sending difficult cases to grand juries: they will have to decide whether to indict police officers. Because grand jury testimony is often held in secret, Holly Mitchell, the author of the law, said that the change would increase trust in police officers and transparency in government.

headline: Meat Without Meat, Courtesy of Herbivorous Butcher
abstract: Kale and Aubry Walch started the line of small-batch meat alternatives last year.
lead_paragraph: Kale and Aubry Walch launched the Herbivorous Butcher, a line of small-batch meat alternatives, last year, after recognizing a demand for vegan food that doesn’t taste like vegan food. When the brother-sister duo from Minneapolis, Minn., first brought their locally sourced, protein-rich products — smoky BBQ ribs, maple-glazed bacon, spicy chorizo, all made from creative blends of wheat gluten, beans and flavorings — to the local farmer’s market, they caused a small sensation. “One person said, ‘I’m a food scientist, and I swear I can taste fat marbling in that sausage,’ ” recalls Aubry. After appearing at a series of pop-ups across the Midwest, they’re now opening a brick-and-mortar location in their hometown. Says the aptly named Kale, “Our goal is to fool people into saving the planet.”

headline: From the Right, a New Slur for G.O.P. Candidates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Minorities', 'Social Media']
abstract: A word catches fire on social media among disaffected Republicans, called racist by some, who feel their candidates lean too far left.
lead_paragraph: As Republican presidential candidates offered careful answers to questions about education, immigration and foreign policy at last week’s debate, streams of tweets panned their responses as too soft or disingenuous. Senator Marco Rubio is beholden to corporate interests, one said. Former Gov. Jeb Bush is weak on immigration, crowed another. Many of them were adorned with a cryptic hashtag bearing a new word: “cuckservative.”

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:20 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE INVISIBLE WOMAN (2013) A young actress (Felicity Jones, above with John Kavanagh) becomes the clandestine lover of Charles Dickens (Ralph Fiennes) in this recounting of Dickens’s longtime affair with Nelly Ternan, who was 18 to his 45 when they met. Mr. Fiennes also directed the film, which was written by Abi Morgan (“The Iron Lady,” “Shame”). “You may become impatient with the leisurely pace of ‘The Invisible Woman’ and its occasional narrative vagueness, but its open spaces leave room for some of the strongest acting of any contemporary film,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, adding, “Ms. Jones gives a performance of extraordinary subtlety and delicacy.” And Mr. Fiennes “gives his warmest, most full-bodied screen performance as Dickens, an irresistibly charismatic, tirelessly energetic celebrity who was the life of every party he attended.”

headline: Conservatives in Myanmar Force Out Leader of Ruling Party
abstract: The party’s leadership did not explain the underlying reasons for the change, but the ouster appeared to be part of a struggle for power.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The head of Myanmar’s governing party has been removed from his post in what one aide described as a “coup,” the most visible sign yet of splintering within the country’s military elite and the resurgence of conservative forces that dominated under decades of military rule.

headline: Cuba: Reliving Memories of Communism
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Photography']
abstract: When Yana Paskova visited Cuba, her eyes — and heart — were attuned to details that summoned her childhood in Communist Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans who visit Cuba recall having a time machine moment: their grandfather’s Chevy, showgirls at the Tropicana, or the absent reach of email. My version of time travel included a Lada and a red scarf — two symbols of my childhood in Bulgaria, a Communist nation that turned to democracy after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.

headline: Review: In ‘Straight Outta Compton,’ Upstarts Who Became the Establishment
abstract: This film, about the rise of N.W.A., tracks a fistful of upstarts who helped introduce gangster rap to an alternately freaked out and receptive world.
lead_paragraph: “Straight Outta Compton,” an exultant rap-to-riches story about the group N.W.A., opens with a blast of action-film braggadocio. It’s night sometime in 1986, and the group’s future headliner and fly in the ointment, Eazy-E (Jason Mitchell), is taking care of shady business. With the camera dogging his steps so closely that you half expect him to shout “Heel,” he hotfoots it into a cramped, bleak house that has been prepped for maximum horror-film suggestiveness, with lighting as dark as a dungeon, a Welcome Wagon of tough-guy scowls and a she-devil who’s soon holding a shotgun next to a bare leg, her gat and her gam each loaded and lethal.
