headline: Rescuing Wildlife Is Futile, and Necessary
abstract: Saving wild animals — even just one — can be a way of pushing back against the harm that humans cause to the natural world.
lead_paragraph: In a plastic dishpan on Judith Wakelam’s kitchen table, six huge, dark eyes gaze up at me from a huddle of pale-fringed faces and dusty black feathers, bladelike wings projecting outward at a variety of unlikely angles. These are baby common swifts, insectivorous birds so exquisitely aerial that they eat, sleep and mate on the wing and spend the first two or three years of their lives migrating between Europe and Africa in continuous flight.

headline: Tyra Banks Isn’t Running a Democracy Here
abstract: The television personality on hosting “America’s Next Top Model” for more than 10 years.
lead_paragraph: You’ve been hosting ‘‘America’s Next Top Model’’ for more than a decade. It gives you a unique vantage point on how reality television has influenced the people who consume it. How are the young people who audition for the show today different from those of 10 years ago? In terms of the audition process, people sometimes come in and are like, ‘‘I’m gonna be the weird one!’’ or ‘‘I’m gonna be the overly sexual one!’’ They’ve grown up with reality television and know that producers are looking for strong archetypes. I’d like to think that we can see through that.

headline: A Night in Brooklyn Criminal Court
abstract: The difference between Rikers and freedom can be a couple of hundred dollars.
lead_paragraph: The difference between Rikers and freedom can be a couple of hundred dollars.

headline: Personal (Search) History
abstract: Making art from the trail of digital information we leave behind online.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon, riding the bus in downtown Montreal, Madelyne Beckles swiped open her phone to browse the web. She caught sight of her most recent mobile searches — ‘‘Snooki diet,’’ ‘‘Miley Cyrus’ sex tape,’’ ‘‘Bruno Mars songs’’ — and found this collection to be absurd but unexpectedly poignant: an unvarnished glimpse into the meanderings of her mind. Beckles, a 23-year-old visual artist whose work explores her relationship to technology, took a screen grab and shared the image on Instagram. This became the genesis of her newest project, called Herstory: Every so often, Beckles pulls up her mobile search history and saves it with a screen shot. In one image, ‘‘Labiaplasty’’ is listed right above ‘‘Bethenny Frankel Instagram.’’ In another, ‘‘Dirty martini’’ appears a few searches before ‘‘Who owns the Mona Lisa.’’ (To preserve the integrity of the project, she says she deletes only items with typos.) Some of the images appeared in a recent art book called ‘‘Babe’’; the rest will appear, in the form of large poster-size prints, as part of a show in a Toronto gallery called Autumn later this month.

headline: Bounce, Launch, Splash! The Joy of the Diving Board
keywords: ['Swimming Pools', 'Diving and Divers', 'Diving (Sports Event)', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Diving boards began disappearing from New York City’s public pools in the 1970s amid safety concerns. Now only three remain in regular use, calling to the adventurous.
lead_paragraph: Warren Davis, 18, had trekked over from Avenue D for this moment, and he made the most of it. After a preliminary bounce on the diving board at the pool at the Tony Dapolito Recreation Center, he took three steps, paused and started his signature move, a lofty dive with a midflight spin that ended with his slicing effortlessly into the water.

headline: The Bail Trap
abstract: Every year, thousands of innocent people are sent to jail only because they can’t afford to post bail, putting them at risk of losing their jobs, custody of their children — even their lives.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Nov. 20 last year, Tyrone Tomlin sat in the cage of one of the Brooklyn criminal courthouse’s interview rooms, a bare white cinder-block cell about the size of an office cubicle. Hardly visible through the heavy steel screen in front of him was Alison Stocking, the public defender who had just been assigned to his case. Tomlin, exhausted and frustrated, was trying to explain how he came to be arrested the afternoon before. It wasn’t entirely clear to Tomlin himself. Still in his work clothes, his boots encrusted with concrete dust, he recounted what had happened.

abstract: Smoke continued rising from buildings on Thursday after explosions ripped through a warehouse in Tianjin, a port city in northeast China, killing at least 50.

headline: Bomb Claimed by ISIS Kills Dozens in Baghdad
abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the blast in the Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City, which came just after dawn as shoppers were stocking up for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A devastating truck bomb struck a food market early Thursday morning in the teeming Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City, killing about 60 people and wounding more than 100 others, according to security officials.

keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu did not directly advise visiting Republican members of Congress how to vote on the Iran nuclear deal, the leader of the delegation told reporters on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu did not directly advise visiting Republican members of Congress how to vote on the Iran nuclear deal, the leader of the delegation told reporters on Thursday. The head of a Democratic Congressional group that visited Israel last week had said the same thing to journalists.

headline: Violent Backlash Against Migrants in Germany as Asylum-Seekers Pour In
keywords: ['Romani People', 'Discrimination', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: In the first half of this year alone, as more than 179,000 people applied for asylum, Germany’s Interior Ministry recorded 202 attacks on housing for them.
lead_paragraph: FREITAL, Germany — Even as Germany has been trying to accommodate a swelling stream of newcomers, the most anywhere in Europe, it is also experiencing a persistent pattern of violence against migrants, raising concerns about escalating far-right opposition.

headline: The Plight of Refugees, the Shame of the World
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Children are resilient when given a chance. It’s a shame how few are.
lead_paragraph: The world is facing the biggest refugee crisis since World War II, a staggering 60 million people displaced from their homes, four million from Syria alone. World leaders have abdicated their responsibility for this unlucky population, around half of whom are children.

headline: Stop Stealing From Strippers
keywords: ['Strip Clubs and Strippers', 'Women and Girls', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Workplace Environment', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: In every strip club I’ve worked in, it’s the same: We’re exploited.
lead_paragraph: TODAY I am a two for one. This is how it works: the first lap dance is free. The second one is 20 bucks. “Tenner Tuesday” is a weekly special, offering a bargain for customers on an otherwise sluggish day where I work, the only strip club for miles.

headline: Is Hillary Clinton Really in Danger of Losing the Primary?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Elections (US)']
abstract: Her favorability ratings are way down, but her position remains very strong. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders is said to be surging, Joe Biden is considering jumping in the race, and Hillary Rodham Clinton’s unfavorable ratings are the worst they’ve been in her 23-plus years in national politics — worse than they were in 2007 or 2008.

headline: Daily Report: Alibaba Disappoints Amid a Slowdown in China
abstract: The economic slowdown in China could make it hard for the e-commerce giant to meet the lofty expectations of investors.
lead_paragraph: For a while, Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant, looked as if it was making a retail push into the United States and, just maybe, could directly compete with Amazon.com. But in June, after just a year, Alibaba sold the online marketplace 11 Main as well as three other small companies it had acquired to compete for American customers.

headline: Brazil’s Vigilante Lynchings
abstract: In cities, some Brazilians resort to mob violence against criminal suspects, blaming weak policing and courts.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Last month, a man was beaten to death by a mob after being accused of trying to rob a bar in São Luís do Maranhão, in northern Brazil. The man, Cleidenilson Pereira da Silva, was stripped naked by the crowd, tied to a pole, kicked, punched and hit with stones and bottles. He died at the scene.

headline: Blast at Baghdad Market Kills About 60
abstract: A witness described a deadly truck bombing that struck a market in the neighborhood of Sadr City in the Iraqi capital early Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: A witness described a deadly truck bombing that struck a market in the neighborhood of Sadr City in the Iraqi capital early Thursday morning.

headline: 1940: Britain May Lift Blockade
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain considered allowing the delivery of American aid in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In spite of the chill with which London has greeted reports of Herbert Hoover’s latest appeal to the warring nations of Europe to permit food from America to be distributed to the 27,000,000 civilians in Norway, Belgium, Holland and Poland, an American source here said today that limited relief might be expected in the not too distant future. Earlier reports of Mr. Hoover’s statement were taken to indicate that Britain was, in effect, being asked to raise her blockade to allow American foodstuffs to get through to peoples recently taken under the German wing. — New York Herald Tribune, August 14, 1940

headline: Getting Rowdy: Keith Ape and Real Rap in Korea
abstract: Home-grown or appropriating American elements, hip-hop is emerging in a music scene dominated by glossy K-pop.
lead_paragraph: By the time the South Korean rapper Keith Ape made it to the nightclub S.O.B.’s in April for his first New York show, just three months had passed since the release of “It G Ma,” his breakout single.

headline: China 2015 Is Not China 2010
abstract: The yuan story has moved on, even if The Donald hasn’t.
lead_paragraph: If there is a central policy theme to Donald Trump’s candidacy other than immigration — actually, there isn’t, but there are some particular things he bellows about — it’s China-bashing. The unifying principle is probably xenophobia; but anyway, China’s currency moves are about to become a US political issue. And pretty soon, I expect, people will point out that some liberals also used to complain about Chinese currency manipulation.

headline: Devastation in Tianjin, China
abstract: The death toll in the port city has hit 50 after two overnight explosions, which burned countless cars, shattered windows for blocks and injured hundreds of people.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in the port city has hit 50 after two overnight explosions, which burned countless cars, shattered windows for blocks and injured hundreds of people.

headline: Doctors Fail to Address Patients’ Spiritual Needs
abstract: Studies have documented the importance of religion and spirituality to many patients, but doctors can feel unprepared to discuss the topic.
lead_paragraph: My patient, a woman in her 20s with cancer, was doing poorly on chemotherapy. The disease had spread throughout her body. We were doing everything we could to help her, but didn’t know how long she would live – probably only a few months, at most. Her mother came regularly to visit, and sat by her side. Around their necks, they both wore gold crosses on tiny gold chains. Taped on the wall, near the foot of her bed, was a greeting card with a picture of Jesus, in a red cloak with pointy gold beams radiating from his head.

headline: Using a Chat Tool to Cover the Republican Debate
abstract: Times Insider talked with two editors who were closely involved in live blogging the first G.O.P. debate using a chat tool called Slack.
lead_paragraph: Last week, The Times’s political team experimented with live-blogging the first Republican debate by using the increasingly popular chat tool, Slack. Times Insider talked to Paul Volpe, editor in the Washington bureau, and Marc Lavallee, editor of Interactive News, about how it went, using, of course — a Slack chat room!

headline: Winning in the N.F.L. Preseason Could Be a Bad Sign
abstract: A strong preseason performance in the N.F.L. not only does not predict a good season, it could actually be a sign of a bad one.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. preseason games, which began in earnest on Thursday night, are regularly derided as meaningless. A tedious method to sort out the future backups from the soon-to-be-cut. A chance for top players to be injured. A cash grab with high-priced tickets, food and parking for an inferior product.

lead_paragraph: Germanic undergarments have their own brand of sex appeal.

headline: Kentucky Clerk Defies Court on Marriage Licenses for Gay Couples

lead_paragraph: MOREHEAD, Ky. — Nearly two months after the Supreme Court declared a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, a county clerk’s office here — in defiance of a federal court order — turned away several gay couples seeking marriage licenses on Thursday, taking a stand that has infuriated gay rights advocates but buoyed Christian conservatives who insist their religious freedoms are being violated.

Kasich of Ohio unabashedly promotes his expansion of Medicaid under Obamacare, shows little appetite for relitigating culture-war battles like same-sex marriage and offers not much more than a shrug when asked about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s turning over her email server to the F.B.I.

headline: A Breakup and a Makeup, Without You
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Dogs', 'Lawns', 'Air Conditioning', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Friendship']
abstract: Plus: answering questions on leaving your puppy at home; discussing potential lawn accidents with neighbors; and adjusting the temperature at the office.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I were best friends with another couple. They were an integral part of our lives, and I’d like to think we were important to them, too. Sadly, they broke up. We did our best to keep in touch separately, but we drifted apart and “happy birthday” texts became the extent of our relationship. Recently, we saw on Facebook that they are back together and engaged. Should we approach them? We are very disappointed that they have not gotten in touch with us.

lead_paragraph: After the Legislature rejected a move to give the New York State Education Department enhanced powers over the troubled East Ramapo school system in Rockland County, the department is taking a more modest step: It has appointed three experts to study the district’s operations and offer recommendations to the school board and the Board of Regents, the agency said on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s two largest political parties ended talks on Thursday without agreeing to form a coalition government, setting the stage for likely new elections and threatening further political instability.

headline: Reaching Back

headline: Letters: ‘The Conservative Heart’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Arthur C. Brooks’s “The Conservative Heart,” Shirley Jackson’s “Let Me Tell You” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Show Me a Hero’ Focuses on a Mayor in the Maelstrom of Desegregation
abstract: David Simon’s new HBO series tells the true story of Nick Wasicsko, a 1980s Yonkers mayor caught up in a battle to change public housing.
lead_paragraph: You can see why the tale of Nick Wasicsko and the decades-long battle to desegregate Yonkers, in which he played a short but crucial role, would appeal to David Simon. Like Baltimore in “The Wire” and New Orleans in “Treme,” Yonkers symbolizes the tortured metamorphosis of the post-industrial American city. And in Wasicsko, elected mayor at 28 and caught in a vortex of racism and fear, it would seem to have a classic tragic hero: an impetuous young man who grows into leadership, is cast out and doesn’t live to see the full fruit of the seeds he planted.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | Man From U.N.C.L.E.
abstract: Guy Ritchie narrates a sequence from “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.”
lead_paragraph: Guy Ritchie narrates a sequence from “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.”

headline: How a Kitten Eased My Partner’s Depression
abstract: With a partner battling depression and her own mental state teetering toward perpetual grumpiness, a woman takes it upon herself to introduce a new member into the family.
lead_paragraph: When his depression was at its worst, my partner, Joe, would wake up in the morning engulfed in a fog so palpable that its presence would sometimes startle me awake, as if I had smelled something burning.

headline: Pouilly-Fuissés With an Identity Crisis
abstract: The wine panel recently sampled 20 bottles from the 2013 vintage.
lead_paragraph: The Mâconnais, a tranquil, hilly, picturesque region near the southern end of Burgundy, just to the north of Beaujolais, has long been a source for inexpensive white wines. Like almost all white Burgundies, they are made of chardonnay. And, as has been true all over the wine-producing world, the last 20 years have been incredibly exciting because of the tremendous rise in quality from the Mâconnais.

headline: A World War and Clashing Architecture Foil a German Arts District
abstract: The Kulturforum has long foiled urban planners and frustrated Berliners, but many hope that will change when a new home for modern art is built there.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Twenty-five years after German reunification, the capital is still trying to fill the lingering gaps in its urban fabric as it vies to be considered alongside Paris and Rome as one of Europe’s pre-eminent cultural centers.

headline: HBO, Brought to You by ‘Sesame Street’
abstract: Over the years, “Sesame Street” has parodied a number of popular HBO series. If you could, what show would you parody?
lead_paragraph: Starting this fall, new episodes of the children’s television series “Sesame Street” will appear exclusively on the cable network HBO and its streaming outlets. After nine months, the episodes will be available free on PBS, the show’s longtime home.

headline: The Man From U.N.C.L.E. (With Movie Trailer): Guy Ritchie Narrates a Scene
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from the film featuring Henry Cavill, Armie Hammer and Alicia Vikander.
lead_paragraph: The 1960s television spy series “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.” gets a big screen update from the director Guy Ritchie. Henry Cavill and Armie Hammer take the lead roles of Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin, CIA and KGB agents forced to join forces, with an assist from Alicia Vikander. This early scene pits the two against each another in a divided Berlin. In an interview, Mr. Ritchie spoke about the sequence and ideas for the movie. Following are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Review: ‘The Man From U.N.C.L.E.’ Resurrects a Glossy, Action-Packed ’60s
abstract: Guy Ritchie’s big-screen rendering of the 1960s television series tries hard not to be a museum piece, partly with a slick, agitated style.
lead_paragraph: Guy Ritchie makes the kind of enjoyably disreputable movies that are fun to watch until they’re not. He’s a talented flimflam artist and, for the industry, I imagine, a useful one because of how he glosses up schlocky, sketchy projects (his “Sherlock Holmes” movies and other hyperkinetic baubles), making them seem as if there’s more to their slick surfaces than naked commercialism, agency fees and facile pleasure. It works for him (he keeps getting hired), and sometimes also for us. Pleasure is, after all, rarely overrated, including in the often mind-bludgeoning arena of franchise cinema, and there’s a lot to be said for watching beautiful people doing very silly stuff on screen.

headline: Families of Virginia Tech Massacre Victims Start Program to Improve Campus Safety
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The program, announced by survivors and families, aims to help colleges and universities ask the hard questions about how they handle campus hazards.
lead_paragraph: Eight years after the Virginia Tech massacre, survivors and families announced a program on Thursday intended to make colleges and universities safer, hoping it will serve as a legacy for the 32 people killed.

abstract: Peru’s Ministry of Culture is using drones to survey the country’s archeological sites as part of conservation efforts.
lead_paragraph: Peru’s Ministry of Culture is using drones to survey the country’s archeological sites as part of conservation efforts.

headline: Connecticut Death Penalty Law Is Unconstitutional, Court Rules
abstract: The ruling, which says the law is “cruel and unusual,” blocks the execution of the 11 inmates currently on death row.
lead_paragraph: Casting the death penalty as an outdated tool of justice at odds with today’s societal values, Connecticut’s highest court on Thursday spared the lives of 11 men on death row by ruling that capital punishment violated the State Constitution.

headline: Exploring the Dolomites in Italy
abstract: In summer, hiking trails through forests and flower-filled meadows beckon, and enticing meals are never far away.
lead_paragraph: In summer, hiking trails through forests and flower-filled meadows beckon, and enticing meals are never far away.

headline: Adam Johnson’s ‘Fortune Smiles’
abstract: A collection of gleefully bleak stories from the author of ‘The Orphan Master’s Son.’
lead_paragraph: Late one night not long ago, when I was losing an ugly bout with insomnia and everyone in my family was snoring in syncopated swing, I read a story in Harper’s Magazine that made me wake my husband up and insist that he read it, no, read it right now. The story is from the point of view of a very sick woman, the wife of a writer, and it speaks about family love and grief and jealousy and guilt and rage and illness with a power that took my breath away. That story, “Interesting Facts,” has now been published with five others, all of them so long they could almost be called novellas, in a new collection titled “Fortune Smiles.” Its author is Adam Johnson, who won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize for his novel about North Korea, “The Orphan Master’s Son.”

headline: Lindsey Vonn Fractures Ankle While Training
abstract: Vonn, who holds the record for most World Cup ski racing victories by a woman, sustained the injury while training in New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn crashed while training on Coronet Peak in New Zealand on Thursday and sustained an ankle fracture that forced her to fly back to the United States for treatment, the United States Ski Team said. Vonn first announced the injury on her social media accounts.

headline: For ‘Mercury Fur’ Writer Philip Ridley, a Macabre Vision Takes Many Forms
abstract: Mr. Ridley, whose controversial play, “Mercury Fur,” opens this week Off Broadway, follows his art across many forms: photography, film and children’s novels among them.
lead_paragraph: When Philip Ridley was a child he suffered from severe asthma. When he wasn’t in the hospital, he was often kept at home. Alone in his bedroom, in a tower block in London’s East End, he would draw pictures and write stories, make up poems and sing songs. He would disappear into a world of his own making.

headline: 1965: Dr. King to Appeal for Peace
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Martin Luther King Jr. said he would send a letter to North Vietnam in 1965.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The Rev Martin Luther King Jr. will appeal personally to North Vietnamese President Ho Chi Minh to carry the war in Vietnam to the conference table, he said last night. The Negro integration leader said he would send a letter to the North Vietnamese leader as well as to those of South Vietnam, Russia and the United States. Dr. King told his Southern Christian Leadership Conference convention that each side must end the ‘‘cycle of mistrust, violence and war.’’ Dr. King suggested that the United States seriously consider halting its bombings. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 14, 1965

headline: After Ferguson, California Orders Police Shooting Cases Into Open Court
abstract: California has become the first state to ban the use of a grand jury when a police officer kills a civilian.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous year of nationwide protest, California has become the first state to ban the use of grand juries to decide whether a police officer should face criminal charges in using deadly force against civilians. Criticism of the secret grand jury process has become a flash point in a series of civilian deaths at the hands of police that began with the shooting of Michael Brown, a black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., last summer.

lead_paragraph: Sir Kensington’s, a small but growing company in the condiments business, has received a $8.5 million from some individual investors and Verlinvest, the family-owned private equity group that is snapping up stakes in some of America’s most popular new food companies.

headline: P.G.A. Championship 2015: Dustin Johnson Is Calm Before Storming to the Top
abstract: Johnson, who has won nine times on the PGA Tour but has yet to win a major, was relaxed en route to a six-under-par 66 and a one-shot lead after the first round.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Dustin Johnson started his first round of the 2015 P.G.A. Championship on the 10th hole, a short, downhill 361-yard par 4. Most players in the field Thursday used irons off the tee, strategically positioning themselves on a serpentine fairway so they could be aggressive with their second shots.

headline: Narcotic Drugs Can Be Coaxed From Yeast
keywords: ['Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Yeast', 'Poppies', 'Opium', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Researchers reported that they had added DNA to yeast that enabled it to produce enzymes that turn sugar into pain killers.
lead_paragraph: In a widely expected advance that has opened a fierce debate about “home-brewed heroin,” scientists at Stanford have created strains of yeast that can produce narcotic drugs.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Need help finding something to do? The Times arts team has you covered.
lead_paragraph: Looking for something fun to do?

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Redefine Japan and Its Military Has Echoes of Family History
abstract: Mr. Abe, who wants the military to take on limited combat roles, sees himself in the mold of his grandfather, who helped redefine cooperation with America.
lead_paragraph: In a famous photograph from his childhood, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is seen perched on the knee of his smiling grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, the influential postwar prime minister. There is no sign of the turmoil just outside the family home, where thousands were protesting Mr. Kishi’s plan to extend Japan’s military alliance with the United States.

headline: El Niño May Bring Record Heat, and Rain for California
abstract: This year’s Pacific weather pattern could be the most powerful on record and could bring enormous amounts of rain to drought-stricken California.
lead_paragraph: This year’s El Niño weather pattern could be the most powerful on record, federal forecasters said, while warning that the effects of the weather system are never certain.

headline: Japan’s Apologies for World War II
abstract: Here is a look at major statements on Japan’s war legacy by monarchs and senior officials since its defeat in 1945.
lead_paragraph: Here is a look at major statements on Japan’s war legacy by monarchs and senior officials since its defeat in 1945.

headline: Donald Trump Is Officially Off ‘The Celebrity Apprentice’
abstract: “The Celebrity Apprentice” will return to NBC’s lineup at some point in the 2016-17 television season, but Donald J. Trump will not.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The Celebrity Apprentice” will return to NBC’s lineup at some point in the 2016-17 television season, but Donald J. Trump will not.

headline: Age-Defying Athletes
abstract: In masters track and field, athletes 35 and older compete in various divisions. At the World Masters Championships in France, competitors in the top age groups provided many of the highlights.
lead_paragraph: In masters track and field, athletes 35 and older compete in various divisions. At the World Masters Championships in France, competitors in the top age groups provided many of the highlights.

headline: Mets Overcome Shaky Start and Complete Sweep of Rockies
abstract: Noah Syndergaard allowed two first-inning home runs but the Mets backed him with nine extra-base hits to extend their winning streak to four games.
lead_paragraph: Noah Syndergaard gritted his teeth and punched his glove, watching a solo home run sail over Yoenis Cespedes’s head in center field. Five pitches later, there was another home run to left. It was only the first inning, and the unimpressive Colorado Rockies were the opponent, but, still, Syndergaard looked vulnerable.

headline: Venezuela Releases Two Prominent Government Critics From Prison
abstract: The releases of Raúl Baduel and Daniel Ceballos come as the government works to weaken opposition ahead of legislative elections set for December.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela released two prominent government critics from prison this week, including a former defense minister who had been a confidant of President Hugo Chávez.

headline: Donald Trump Video Juxtaposes Obama Playing Golf With ISIS Violence
abstract: Donald J. Trump has released an ad on Instagram that shows images of President Obama playing golf and the Clintons dancing against “Jihadi John” and a burning Humvee, all with the caption: “Not under my watch.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump may be new to politics, but he has already demonstrated a mastery of the dark art of creating haunting campaign videos packed with imagery of violence and war.

headline: Works Sighted: Iranian Life Under Sanctions
abstract: As a vote on the nuclear deal approaches, an Iranian writer offers a look at what sanctions have meant to her family and her country.
lead_paragraph: As a vote on the nuclear deal that would lift sanctions against Iran approaches in Congress, Pedestrian, an Iranian writer, offers a look at what those sanctions mean to Iranians’ day-to-day lives. Via Vox:

headline: U.N. Faces Scrutiny Over Unpaid Intern Who Slept in a Tent in Geneva
abstract: The intern who said he could not afford housing in Geneva has called on unpaid interns around the world to unite, and the world body to live up to its own ideals.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials are facing pressure to revisit their unpaid internship policy after an intern who had been living in a tent near Lake Geneva resigned and called for “interns all over the world” to unite in a fight for their rights.

headline: The Roller Rink Origins of N.W.A.
abstract: The history of Skateland U.S.A., the venue that launched the iconic rap group.
lead_paragraph: Craig Schweisinger opened the doors to Skateland U.S.A. on Saturday, Nov. 16, 1984. High schoolers mingled with gangbangers and roller skaters who took their choreography seriously. A sign reading NO CAPS — NO COLORS greeted attendees at the door.

headline: 'Everyone Just Stood Around in Horror': Readers React to Moms at Bachelorette Parties
abstract: Readers discuss inter-generational partying, helicopter parenting and ageism.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss inter-generational partying, helicopter parenting and ageism.

headline: States With High Gun Ownership See More Officers Killed
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'States (US)']
abstract: Researchers have found that police officers in states with the lowest gun ownership rates are less likely to be murdered on the job.
lead_paragraph: The higher the rate of gun ownership in a state, the higher the likelihood of a law enforcement officer being killed, a new study has found.

headline: For Lenovo, Cost-Cutting Is Not Enough to Stem Losses
abstract: The tech company’s goal of breaking even in its mobile business will depend on demand, and a shrinking PC market will also affect its turnaround plan.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo’s turnaround will take more than cost-cutting. The PC and smartphone maker will slash $1.35 billion from annual expenses after earnings fell 51 percent in the second quarter. Revamping may halt losses at the Motorola handset unit that Lenovo bought last year. But any return to growth depends on a demand pickup.

headline: The High Price of Rejecting the Iran Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Critics of the nuclear agreement think we can revert to sanctions. But doing so would be an economic disaster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Iran nuclear deal offers a long-term solution to one of the most urgent threats of our time. Without this deal, Iran, the world’s leading state sponsor of terrorism, would be less than 90 days away from having enough fissile material to make a nuclear bomb. This deal greatly reduces the threat of Iran’s nuclear program, making Iran’s breakout time four times as long, securing unprecedented access to ensure that we will know if Iran cheats and giving us the leverage to hold it to its commitments.

headline: John A. Nerud, Hall of Fame Thoroughbred Trainer, Dies at 102
abstract: Nerud saddled more than 1,000 winners, including 27 in stakes races, and named his greatest horse, Dr. Fager, after the neurosurgeon who saved his life.
lead_paragraph: John A. Nerud, a Hall of Fame trainer of thoroughbreds who named his greatest horse, Dr. Fager, after the Boston neurosurgeon who saved his life, died on Thursday at his home in Old Brookville, N.Y. He was 102.

headline: Google Unveils New Chrome Operating System for Business Customers
abstract: Google and Dell show off the next version of Chromebooks. They look nice, but what really matters is changes in the back end to get older applications online.
lead_paragraph: Google figured out something important: You can sell businesses the future, but they’ll show up with lots of the past.

headline: Review: ‘One & Two’ Exposes Dangers of Trying to Control Teenagers
abstract: Andrew Droz Palermo wants his movie to be a parable, a supernatural tale involving normal tensions of adolescence and the need for independence.
lead_paragraph: In “One & Two,” an isolated family of four is about to go nuclear. Dad (Grant Bowler) runs a very tight ship on a very tidy homestead in a rural paradise, walled off from the outside world and apparently lacking any technology more recent than kerosene lamps. Mom (Elizabeth Reaser) pretty much goes along, except to try to soothe her husband when he rages about their teenagers, Zac (Timothée Chalamet) and Eva (Kiernan Shipka). They have powers, you see, that must be shunned.

headline: On View
abstract: Auto Body’s sixth art exhibition of the season, “Scapes,” opened this past Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Auto Body’s sixth art exhibition of the season, “Scapes,” opened this past Saturday.

headline: Review: In ‘Return to Sender,’ Rosamund Pike Connects With Her Attacker
abstract: A rapist’s victim visits him in prison, raising the question of whether she’s interested in his rehabilitation or something else.
lead_paragraph: For most of the way, “Return to Sender” merges creepy and sexy to good effect, thanks to a close-to-the-vest performance by Rosamund Pike, the missing wife of “Gone Girl.” The story works an old and distasteful trope — the rape victim who falls for the attacker — but the treatment is restrained rather than salacious.

headline: China’s Renminbi Devaluation May Initiate New Phase in Global Currency War
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'Interest Rates', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Some analysts say the currency tensions could worsen some of the entrenched problems in the global economy. China’s move also poses a dilemma for the Fed as it considers raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: For years, China looked like the principled noncombatant. As other countries, seeking to secure an economic advantage, let the value of their currencies slide on international markets, China held firm on the value of its money.

headline: Review: ‘Rosenwald,’ on a Philanthropist Who Created Schools for Blacks in the Jim Crow South
abstract: Aviva Kempner’s documentary offers a stirring portrait of a Sears executive whose Rosenwald Fund dispensed fellowships to black artists and academics including W. E. B. Du Bois and James Baldwin.
lead_paragraph: In the first half of the 20th century, Julius Rosenwald was not only a leading businessman — the chairman of Sears, Roebuck & Company, one of the country’s wealthiest men — but a leading philanthropist and civil rights advocate as well. With challenge grants, he spurred the building of Y.M.C.A.s that would accept blacks as residents; his Rosenwald Fund dispensed fellowships for a who’s who of black artists and academics, from W. E. B. Du Bois to James Baldwin.

headline: Copy of Postal Service Audit Shows Extent of Mail Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Experts said the unredacted audit was the first acknowledgment of how the Postal Service’s surveillance program for national security investigations is used.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In what experts say is the first acknowledgment of how the United States Postal Service’s mail surveillance program for national security investigations is used, the service’s internal watchdog found that inspectors failed to follow key safeguards in the gathering and handling of classified information.

headline: Why You Can’t Get There From La Guardia
abstract: Allowing longer-range flights at the airport would benefit travelers and enhance competition.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is reconsidering a longstanding rule that limits flights in and out of La Guardia Airport in Queens to a 1,500-mile radius. The authority should repeal the anachronistic policy, which was introduced decades ago to force airlines and travelers to use Kennedy Airport.

headline: Second Stage Adds ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ To Spring Season
abstract: The musical, with music and lyrics by Benj Pasek and Justin Paul, will be staged Off Broadway, though its commercial producer didn’t rule out further life on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: A new musical about suicide, social media and a group of angsty high school students will be presented at Second Stage Theater next spring after a production at Arena Stage in Washington received strong reviews.

headline: Emery LeCrone’s Intimate (and Often Emotional) Dance
abstract: This week, the company founded by the choreographer makes its New York debut.
lead_paragraph: “You haven’t said anything yet,” the choreographer Emery LeCrone tells the dancers Shane Ohmer and Izabela Szylinska in rehearsal. They face each other, each with a hand on the other’s shoulder, and move closer. LeCrone pauses. “Now you have the conversation.” It’s the intensity of this movement — a silent yet intimate exchange between the dancers — that is emblematic of LeCrone’s choreographic style. While working within the classical vocabulary, LeCrone incorporates pedestrian movements — touching hands, hugging — that are strikingly tender. The steps look like ballet, but they’re less formal, more rugged and athletic — and her dancers are certainly not afraid of the floor. “When you go to a big theater and watch 20 dancers on a huge stage, it can feel very distant,” says LeCrone. “But ballet doesn’t have to be that way. It can be more approachable and emotional, less stark and refined.”

headline: Review: In ‘Air,’ Norman Reedus and Djimon Hounsou Keep Hope, and Themselves, Alive
abstract: In this sci-fi film set in an underground missile silo, the actions of two men could decide the fate of civilization.
lead_paragraph: “We can’t just decide who lives and who dies!” one character says in “Air.”

headline: Review: In ‘Big Sky,’ Starring Bella Thorne, Mortal Fears Collide
abstract: Ms. Thorne plays a teenager with a dread of open spaces who must surmount her terror to save her mother and herself.
lead_paragraph: The actress Bella Thorne (“The Duff”; MTV’s “Scream”) dips her toes into grown-up desert noir with “Big Sky,” a lean exercise that leaves her over her head. Ms. Thorne plays Hazel, a teenager with acute agoraphobia and obsessive-compulsive disorder. Her lonely, mildly disheveled mother, Dee (Kyra Sedgwick), is accompanying her to a treatment center when the van carrying Hazel, Dee and four others is violently ambushed in a sandy wasteland. (The film was shot in New Mexico.) Their assailants are kidnappers (Aaron Tveit and Frank Grillo) who believe they have killed all the passengers save their quarry (Jodi Lynn Thomas), whom they stick in a car trunk. But Dee, though shot, is still alive, and Hazel, who has witnessed the carnage from a concealed spot, must surmount her fears to seek help in the wilderness.

headline: Review: ‘Fort Tilden,’ a Comic Odyssey to the Beach
abstract: Two self-centered young women from New York embark on a picaresque bike ride and encounter all sorts of complications.
lead_paragraph: Take the potty-mouthed, woman-centric millennial sensibility of HBO’s “Girls,” turn down the drama and turn up the comic amorality, and you have “Fort Tilden,” the highly amusing debut feature from Sarah-Violet Bliss and Charles Rogers. Rarely has a movie so humorously illustrated the meaning of “frenemy.”

headline: Mike Huckabee Offers 6 Percent Economic Growth, and Food Tips, at Iowa State Fair
abstract: Mike Huckabee mixed the serious with the jovial at the Iowa State Fair on Thursday, promising economic growth of 6 percent if elected president, but beginning a speech with a culinary tip.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – As the first of more than a dozen presidential candidates to drop by the Iowa State Fair, Mike Huckabee mixed the serious with the jovial on Thursday, promising economic growth of 6 percent if elected president, but beginning a speech with a culinary tip.

headline: Review: ‘Ten Thousand Saints,’ a Coming of Age in the East Village, Circa 1980s
abstract: A troubled Vermont teenager is sent to live with his estranged father in New York and finds himself there during a defining cultural moment.
lead_paragraph: If you are one of those people who romanticize the East Village in New York when it was at its grungiest, “Ten Thousand Saints” might be the movie of your dreams. Even if you’re not, it’s still a very fine film, full of quietly impressive performances and young characters who register as authentic.

headline: Viewfinder
abstract: Portraits by Delphine Diaw Diallo.
lead_paragraph: Portraits by Delphine Diaw Diallo.

headline: Message Believed to Be From Qaeda Leader Pledges Support for Taliban
abstract: The voice of Ayman al-Zawahri, who has not had any confirmed audio or video communications since September, was identified in a message acknowledging the Taliban’s new leader.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, broke nearly a year of radio silence on Thursday to pledge allegiance to the new leader of the Taliban, but his audio message made no mention of the Taliban’s two-year delay in acknowledging that their former leader was dead.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘Tango Negro’ Explores the Roots of a Dance and Musical Genre
abstract: The director Dom Pedro sets a breezy tone in this documentary, which theorizes that this Latin American art form has a deep connection with Africa.
lead_paragraph: An interesting idea is overexplained in the documentary “Tango Negro: The African Roots of Tango.” Here, theories that are worth voicing are apparently worth repeating, and beats that sound catchy are sure to be replayed many times.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Sarasota Ballet, With Ashton as the Beating Heart of a Triple Bill
abstract: It’s no surprise that Ashton choreography forms the centerpiece of the troupe’s Jacob’s Pillow debut.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — There is just one place I visit in America that seems a true dance-only haven: Jacob’s Pillow. People don’t come here to see theater or attend concerts, but hundreds drive every day to this secluded spot to attend performances of dance, dance, dance. Their interest in an extremely wide range of work makes the atmosphere one of singularly generous appreciation.

headline: In China, Single Women Live by Their Own Rules
abstract: Single women past a certain age are called “leftover women,” though some are pushing back against such traditional Chinese strictures.
lead_paragraph: Single women past a certain age are called “leftover women,” though some are pushing back against such traditional Chinese strictures.

headline: Review: In Sophie Hannah’s ‘Woman With a Secret,’ Mysteries Multiply
abstract: The ninth book of psychological suspense featuring Detective Constable Simon Waterhouse and his wife is as intricate as Ms. Hannah’s readers have come to expect.
lead_paragraph: If anyone in Sophie Hannah’s latest book deserves to die, it’s Damon Blundy, a repellent British tabloid columnist who cannot write a sentence without making an enemy. And while his murder is annoyingly nasty — he is bound and gagged, a knife taped across his mouth — an intriguing clue lingers on the wall behind him, daubed in lurid red paint resembling blood: “HE IS NO LESS DEAD.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 14-20
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: In ‘People Places Things,’ Jemaine Clement Navigates Life as a Newly Single Dad
abstract: In Jim Strouse’s comedy, Mr. Clement plays a graphic artist, teacher and father who must start over after his wife betrays him.
lead_paragraph: The fleeting pleasures of “People Places Things,” Jim Strouse’s winsome trifle of a comedy, derive almost entirely from the charm of its star, Jemaine Clement, the New Zealand-born actor best known in America as one-half of the musical comedy duo Flight of the Conchords.

headline: On Long Island, an Artists’ Collective Takes Shape
abstract: In the sleepy surf town of Bellport, eight young creatives have launched an interdisciplinary space in a vacant auto body shop.
lead_paragraph: The common good may seem like an elusive political ideal — or a naive one. But for a group of eight young creatives on Long Island, banding together to form a collective to promote the arts has revitalized a small, sleepy surf town. Auto Body, as both the crew and its community space are known, formed last summer when sisters Georgia and Claire Read (whose father, Howard, founded the blue-chip gallery Cheim & Read) and their photographer friend Johnny Knapp “pushed our way,” as Claire puts it, into a vacant auto body shop (hence the name) in Bellport, N.Y. “The space came first, in a way,” she explains. “We knew it had been vacant for years and years, and we wanted to exhibit art and design and hold events, create a space for everyone in the village, bring a creative energy to Main Street, because it was lacking before.”

abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Women Who Surf, New Yorkers Who Sand-Sculpt
abstract: The NYC Women’s Surf Film Festival opens Saturday night at the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, and Coney Island will host an annual sand-sculpture contest on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, women who surf will step into the spotlight in Far Rockaway, Queens.

lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Finding the Other, Cheaper Side of Bali
abstract: Avoiding the tourist crowd meant heading away from southern Bali’s two tourist epicenters.
lead_paragraph: It was about five miles from the Kudesa Homestay guesthouse in Kemenuh village to the Gianyar Night Market, on the Indonesian island of Bali. So I asked my host, Mangku, whether I could make it on the bike he had available for rent. No problem, he said, he knew people who do it all the time.

abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Samsung Unveils Two New Smartphones
abstract: Company executives discussed the addition of two Galaxy phones, the Note 5 and S6 Edge Plus.
lead_paragraph: Company executives discussed the addition of two Galaxy phones, the Note 5 and S6 Edge Plus.

headline: Review: ‘Meru’ Follows an Expedition Up Shark’s Fin Peak in the Himalayas
abstract: This film about mountain climbers pokes at the psychology of extremity, zeroing in on push-the-limits personalities for whom calculating risk is a way of life.
lead_paragraph: To dedicated mountaineers, an unconquered — and believed unconquerable — peak is an irresistible, insistent taunt on their to-do lists. “Meru” is the story of one such peak, the notorious Shark’s Fin atop Mount Meru in India and the pea beneath the mattress of the climber Conrad Anker.

abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: Photos from China, Greece, India and Taiwan.
