headline: Love for Jimmy Carter in Plains, Ga., Where He Stands Tall
abstract: The former president who is ailing is their “Mr. Jimmy,” who teaches Sunday school regularly and is well known at a local diner.
lead_paragraph: PLAINS, Ga. — Here, just beyond the welcome signs with the presidential seal, people still call him “Mr. Jimmy.”

headline: Review: Galactic, Paying Tribute to New Orleans and Its Sounds
abstract: The band pushes the funk envelope with the help of Leo Nocentelli of the Meters.
lead_paragraph: For its encore at Brooklyn Bowl on Wednesday night, Galactic dug into “Africa,” a flag-waving funk classic recorded by the Meters just over 40 years ago. That song choice suggested a genuflection; an acknowledgment of influence, if not a pledge of allegiance.

headline: Review: ‘We Come as Friends’ Explores Potential Exploitation of South Sudan
abstract: Hubert Sauper’s documentary blends striking visuals with a pointed argument that outside investors seeking profits played a big role in the region’s independence movement.
lead_paragraph: In “Darwin’s Nightmare” (2005), a searing Oscar-nominated documentary about economic exploitation in Tanzania, the director Hubert Sauper found a perfect microcosm for colonialism in the invasive Nile perch. The fish was artificially introduced into Lake Victoria in the 1950s and ’60s, ate all the other fish and then was exported as food for Europe and Japan. In the meantime, Tanzania suffered from a famine, and as the film repeatedly sought to demonstrate, the planes arriving to pick up the fish sometimes brought in weapons for use in the continent’s civil wars.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 14-20
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: International Contemporary Circus Festival

headline: NBC Extends Jimmy Fallon’s ‘Tonight Show’ Contract Into 2021
abstract: The network extended its commitment to the popular host just weeks before Stephen Colbert takes over “The Late Show” on CBS.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A few weeks before NBC faces a new challenge in late night, the network is doubling down on Jimmy Fallon as the host of the “Tonight” show.

headline: Review: In ‘Prince,’ a Restless Teenager’s Risky Bid for Acceptance
abstract: Set in an urban Dutch housing project, Sam de Jong’s film depicts a boy seeking to win the respect of an attractive girl and the ne’er-do-wells who make his life miserable.
lead_paragraph: For a boy of a certain age and income, the most potent instrument of seduction may well be a pair of ultramarine Zanotti shoes. They can carry him toward his dreams of joining the royal family of the streets, conquering the thugs who torment him and winning the heart of Laura (Sigrid ten Napel), the fairest of the girls at the Dutch housing project where he and his posse dwell.

headline: Study Links Polluted Air in China to 1.6 Million Deaths a Year
abstract: A research group’s findings may complicate the Chinese government’s efforts to clean up the capital city of Beijing ahead of the 2022 Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Outdoor air pollution contributes to the deaths of an estimated 1.6 million people in China every year, or about 4,400 people a day, according to a newly released scientific paper.

headline: Take a Ride on a SeaGlass Carousel
abstract: A carousel designed as an underwater garden teeming with fish is opening in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A carousel designed as an underwater garden teeming with fish is opening in Lower Manhattan.

headline: New York’s New Carousel Puts You in a Whirling School of Mechanized Fish
abstract: The $16 million SeaGlass carousel brings 30 spinning, color-changing fish to Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: COME with me to the Battery, to the tip of Manhattan, where the sea meets the city, where the sea once was, where the sea may be again someday.

headline: Christie’s to Sell Collection of Arthur and Anita Kahn Beginning This Fall
abstract: The collection features 400 objects, with a total value estimated at over $50 million, including 80 works by the American sculptor Alexander Calder.
lead_paragraph: There was a Calder sculpture on a tabletop, a Calder on a bookcase, and a Calder mobile hung from the ceiling.

headline: Even in the New Alphabet, Google Keeps Its Capital G
abstract: Google’s name is a protected trademark, and the company has fought to keep it from becoming generic, as brands like thermos, cellophane and others have.
lead_paragraph: G is for Google, as the company’s chief executive, Larry Page, put it this week in a blog post introducing Alphabet, Google’s new corporate name.

headline: Review: In ‘The Great Man,’ Friendship and Politics in a War Zone
abstract: In this Sarah Leonor drama, two French soldiers’ lives change after a near-death experience in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: A pocket-size pleasure, the French movie “The Great Man” opens with a fairy-tale flourish as a child narrator winds up the once-upon-a-time. The movie then takes a break in a war zone, where a monster with glowing eyes briefly sends it into fantasy and a wounded soldier yanks it back to terra firma. Not long after, swells of emotion seep in like low-rolling fog and suddenly you are watching a drama about real people wrestling with life blow by blow.

headline: Photos That Celebrate — and Challenge — Feminine Ideals
abstract: The photographer Delphine Diaw Diallo’s “Highness” series originated as a collaboration with the hairstylist Joanne Petit Frere.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Delphine Diaw Diallo’s “Highness” series originated a few years ago as a collaboration with the hairstylist Joanne Petit Frere, who creates fantastical, sculptural styles with real hair. Frere asked Diallo, a graduate of the Academie Charpentier of Visual Arts in Paris, to photograph her work, and the two started working together on a series of increasingly revealing portraits. Diallo, who was born to a Senegalese father and a French mother in Paris, was attracted to the idea of women recreating themselves — and wanted to challenge traditional notions of femininity and eminence. “What kind of queen can I create?” she says. “How can I redefine what highness means to a woman’s experience?” To her, the true “highnesses” are warriors.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 16 to 22, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Robert Seydel: The Eye in Matter’ Looks at an Artist’s Traces
abstract: Mr. Seydel was more curator than artist, and his notebooks, collages and drawings show a variety of influences.
lead_paragraph: Robert Seydel is growing on me. This artist, who rarely exhibited during his lifetime, but worked as a curator and taught photography and film at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., died at 50 in 2011. He left behind an odd body of work — mostly notebooks, little collages and drawings — that are now on view in “Robert Seydel: The Eye in Matter” at the Queens Museum.

headline: With $350 Billion Plan, Hillary Clinton Prods Rivals on Student Debt
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s ambitious plan to reduce debt in higher education has put pressure on her campaign opponents to propose their own solutions to an intractable problem.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton unveiled her plan this week to make higher education more affordable, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida promptly dismissed it as “Obamacare for college.” Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, asserted that she would burden taxpayers by throwing more federal money at the problem.

headline: Review: Bada Shanren, Chinese Art Superstar, Takes a Bow at the Freer
abstract: Before closing for 18 months for a building overhaul, the Freer Gallery of Art is giving the Chinese master a solo exhibition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Beginning in January, the Freer Gallery of Art here will go dark for a year and a half while its 1923 building gets an overhaul. Some museums might take a shutdown as an opportunity to send its collection on the road, to generate institutional advertising and earn rental fees. But the Freer doesn’t have that option.

headline: Dan Flavin’s ‘Icon’ Constructions on Display in Bridgehampton
abstract: The Dan Flavin Art Institute is showing five of the artist’s “icons”: boxlike constructions that marked a transition between his early paintings and drawings and his more famous fluorescent art.
lead_paragraph: Dan Flavin’s early works have come home again.

headline: Review: In ‘A Rare Earth Magnet’ at Derek Eller, a Focus on Repurposed Materials
abstract: The exhibition concentrates on artists drawn to found materials, recycled objects and strong color, with robust, often tactile results.
lead_paragraph: ‘A RARE EARTH MAGNET’

headline: Review: In ‘The Architectural Impulse,’ Art Aspires
abstract: Art objects are made in an architectural spirit at the Cristin Tierney Gallery.
lead_paragraph: ‘THE ARCHITECTURAL IMPULSE’

headline: For Fitz Henry Lane and Other 19th-Century Painters, Catalogues Raisonnés Go Digital
abstract: Efforts are underway to create comprehensive databases of the artists’ body of works.
lead_paragraph: New technology and fresh perspectives are jumpstarting efforts to assemble exhaustive lists of works by 19th-century American painters, sometimes in progress for decades. Next month a consortium of museums interested in the Massachusetts maritime painter Fitz Henry Lane (1804-65) will introduce a website, fitzhenrylaneonline.org, documenting about 320 paintings, drawings and prints at various institutions. Much of the material is being drawn from the Cape Ann Museum, in Mr. Lane’s hometown, Gloucester, Mass., and images on the website will be linked to infrared paint analyses, biographies of Mr. Lane’s clients, newspaper ads for his suppliers, maps of harbors where he sketched and portraits of owners of the ships moored there.

headline: Mastodons Remembered at Staten Island Show
abstract: The Staten Island Museum is showing its collection of mastodon fossils at an exhibition this fall.
lead_paragraph: Mastodons, while tramping around what is now New York, shed teeth and tusks, and dinosaurs, wandering along riverfronts in Massachusetts, left footprints in mud that hardened into sandstone. Remnants of these prehistoric creatures and artifacts from the Americans who discovered them are heading to museum galleries in the region.

headline: Review: The Writer Raymond Roussel and His Legacy, at Galerie Buchholz
abstract: The influential Frenchman (1877-1933) was praised by the likes of Marcel Duchamp, Michel Foucault, Max Ernst, Joseph Cornell and the poet John Ashbery.
lead_paragraph: RAYMOND ROUSSEL

headline: Review: Cy Gavin Employs Unusual Canvas Ingredients in ‘Overture’
abstract: Mr. Gavin incorporates a host of materials into his paintings, including, in “Portrait of My Father” (2015), his father’s cremated remains.
lead_paragraph: CY GAVIN

headline: Review: ‘Mistress America,’ a Noah Baumbach Comedy on Getting By in a Backbiting World
abstract: This smart, fast-paced film, advertised as a screwball comedy, subverts this most buoyant of genres with a steady undertow of anxiety, dread and anger.
lead_paragraph: Noah Baumbach’s “Mistress America” advertises itself as a screwball comedy. But this smart, fast-paced film is not really the zany, lighter-than-air divertissement that the term usually conjures. There are scattered sharp one-liners, but not enough to infuse the movie with a sustained bonhomie. It’s fair to say that “Mistress America” revises and subverts this most buoyant of genres with a steady undertow of anxiety, dread and anger.

headline: Review: In ‘Tom at the Farm,’ Psychosexual Games Down at the Farm
abstract: Xavier Dolan directs and stars in this film about a bereaved lover who discovers that his boyfriend’s family had no idea that he had a gay companion.
lead_paragraph: “Tom at the Farm,” the fourth film from the 26-year-old French Canadian wunderkind Xavier Dolan, is a teasing exercise in unfettered narcissism that sticks its out tongue out and goes, “Nyah, nyah, nyah” as if it were a 5-year-old running wild on a sugar high. I should add that the movie, completed in 2013 and just now being released, is wildly entertaining, sexy and beautifully shot in the Canadian heartland.

headline: One Year Later, Fringe Festival Shows Measure Their Success
abstract: Playwrights and producers discuss whether having been in the 2014 New York International Fringe Festival was worth all the time, effort and money.
lead_paragraph: A Fringe festival can be a real boon for theatergoers, offering the chance to binge on a variety of new plays, musicals and other performances. Best of all, in most cases you can gluttonously feed your theater addiction without spending a ton of money: Tickets for shows at the forthcoming New York International Fringe Festival, for example, are just $18.

headline: 10 Shows to Watch for at This Year’s New York Fringe Festival
abstract: “Elaine Stritch: Still Here,” “Exact Change” and “Naked Hamilton” are among the shows in this year’s FringeNYC, which opens on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Will participants in the 2015 New York International Fringe Festival be glad they performed, once this year’s frenzy is over? First they need audiences. Using methods mostly instinctual, editors and writers for The New York Times put their heads together for a list of 10 shows they’re anticipating among the 200 productions. (Dates, times and sites are at fringenyc.org.)

headline: ‘Outsider Art’ Under One Roof at Katonah Museum of Art
abstract: An exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art featuring five self-taught artists who were once on the fringes.
lead_paragraph: In the almost 70 years since the term was first coined, “outsider art” — a somewhat dismissive designation for the work of self-taught artists — has been steadily finding its way inside the mainstream art world. These days, it is no longer unusual to see pieces by artists with no formal training displayed in even the most prestigious venues; just the past two years have seen such works included in exhibitions mounted by the Venice Biennale, the Museum of Modern Art, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum, among others.

headline: Tiger Woods Blames His Putting After a Disappointing 75
abstract: Woods will have to rally significantly to match his best finish at a major this season, which was a tie for 17th at the Masters.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Tiger Woods’s first-round score at the P.G.A. Championship on Thursday was a disappointing three-over-par 75. But in a measure of how far Woods has fallen, it was his second-best result in the opening round of a major championship this year.

headline: Missing Historical Marker Resurrects Debate Over Photographer’s Birthplace
abstract: A marker honoring Mathew B. Brady, the Civil War photographer, will be replaced, but evidence suggests he may have been born in Ireland, not Johnsburg, N.Y., where he grew up.
lead_paragraph: JOHNSBURG, N.Y. — Publicity surrounding the mysterious disappearance, last August, of a sign commemorating a famed Civil War photographer, Mathew B. Brady, has generated more than enough money for its replacement.

headline: Theater Listings for Aug. 14-20
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Review of ‘Misalliance’ at the Shakespeare Theater in Madison
abstract: “Misalliance,” by George Bernard Shaw, takes on big social issues within a zany comedy.
lead_paragraph: The setting for “Misalliance,” which depicts an elegant conservatory in a baronial country house in England, may briefly mislead some theatergoers into expecting a genteel comedy. But its ever-devilish author, George Bernard Shaw, packs plenty of craziness into this 1909 play, now receiving a very smart revival by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.

headline: Review of ‘La Cage aux Folles’ at Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam
abstract: “La Cage aux Folles” may be campy, but it succeeds because it celebrates that most traditional of values: love.
lead_paragraph: Just what makes the campy musical “La Cage aux Folles” work so well? (As it does, delightfully, in the production now deep into a run at the Goodspeed Opera House.) I was moved to ponder that question after overhearing a couple of intermission conversations, both of which used this phrase:

headline: Goldman Expands Retail Banking by Taking On GE Capital’s Deposits
abstract: The Wall Street bank is acquiring $16 billion in customer deposits from GE Capital Bank, which General Electric is shedding to focus on its industrial business.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs is broadening its effort to offer banking services to people with a wider array of incomes than it has traditionally served.

headline: Restaurant Review: Regulars Say R.S.V.P. Does Everything Wrong, Except for the Food
abstract: The West Cornwall restaurant produces authentic, freshly prepared French bistro cuisine so good that diners don’t seem to mind that it has no website, takes no credit cards and has no menu.
lead_paragraph: R.S.V.P., in West Cornwall, offers one of the most unusual dining experiences in the Northeast. So unusual, in fact, that some of the restaurant’s regular customers have accused it of doing everything wrong. Everything, that is, except for the food.

headline: Restaurant Review: At Picnic on the Square in Ridgewood, Balancing Rich and Light
abstract: The author of “The Preppy Cookbook,” who learned to cook by reading Julia Child’s books, has opened a new restaurant in New Jersey for the luncheon crowd.
lead_paragraph: When Christine E. Nunn, the executive chef and co-owner of Picnic on the Square in Ridgewood, was 16 years old, her boyfriend made fun of her for burning a pot of Campbell’s soup and told her she didn’t know how to cook.

headline: Review: Lilly’s in White Plains Finds Room for Chandeliers and Sundaes
abstract: Lilly’s has Victorian décor and a menu that is clean and simple — with a playful twist.
lead_paragraph: Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains can be something of a scene, with restaurants competing for wandering singles with thumping music and standard pub fare. When I first entered Lilly’s, which opened in April, I feared I had found another example of the trend. Pop music was blasting and, despite the airy, attractive space, I braced myself for an uncomfortable meal with little conversation because no one could hear anyone speak.

headline: A Reading of “Later in the Garden” by Sandra Lim
abstract: The poet reads her verse on Adam and Eve.
lead_paragraph: The poet reads her verse on Adam and Eve.

headline: Review: A Classically Italian Menu at Restaurant Joanina in Huntington
abstract: A family deli business evolved into Restaurant Joanina, complete with a wine shop next door.
lead_paragraph: Was this downtown Huntington or a town in Tuscany? I counted nine restaurants with outdoor seating within a one-block radius. One of the most appealing spots was Restaurant Joanina. While most of the competition had sidewalk seating in front of a noisy street, Joanina faced a parking lot (a slight improvement) and its tables were separated from that lot by planters overflowing with flowers.

headline: Colorado: Water Near Mine at Pre-Spill Toxicity
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The water just below a Colorado mine that poured three million gallons of toxic waste into nearby waterways has returned to pre-spill levels of toxicity, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The water just below a Colorado mine that poured three million gallons of toxic waste into nearby waterways has returned to pre-spill levels of toxicity, officials said Thursday. The Environmental Protection Agency is still analyzing water farther along the spill’s path — in New Mexico, the Navajo Nation and Utah. Officials in Utah said waste from the mine had probably reached Lake Powell, a major water storage facility for the region. E.P.A. officials have said they will have to monitor the spill’s path for years to understand its full effect. The Gold King Mine, near Silverton, burst on Aug. 5 while workers contracted by the E.P.A. were conducting a field investigation of the mine, which had leaked for years. The agency has said it was responsible for the spill. Levels of metals including arsenic and lead jumped in local waterways as the contamination flowed down the Animas River and into the San Juan, angering many who use these rivers for drinking, irrigation and recreational activities. Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and the Navajo Nation declared states of emergency. The rivers remained closed Thursday.

headline: Bangladeshi Women, Isolated in New York City, Need More Support, Advocates Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Bangladeshi-Americans', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: The death of a baby whose mother is accused of throwing him from a window has gripped the social service providers trying to address mental health problems of Bangladeshis.
lead_paragraph: A 3-week-old baby ended up dead in the courtyard of an apartment building in Queens. The police arrested the mother, Rashida Chowdhury, a 21-year-old Bangladeshi immigrant, on charges of second-degree murder. They said she confessed to throwing the baby out the bathroom window of her fourth-floor apartment because she thought the child was possessed by an evil spirit.

headline: Former Editor of Time Inc. to Lead Yahoo Magazines
abstract: Martha Nelson, a former editor in chief of Time Inc., will join Yahoo as its global editor in chief, overseeing its portfolio of digital magazines.
lead_paragraph: Martha Nelson, a former editor in chief of Time Inc., will join Yahoo as its global editor in chief, the company said Thursday, overseeing its portfolio of digital magazines. Ms. Nelson, the founding editor of InStyle and a former editor of People magazine, had taken the top editorial job at Time Inc. in 2013. But she left later that year in a shake-up that eliminated her position and had editors of the company’s 21 magazines reporting to the business side. She will be based in New York when she starts her new job next week, Yahoo said, and will focus on developing Yahoo’s 13 domestic digital magazines and 30 international magazines.

headline: Tom Brady Unexpectedly Starts for Patriots
abstract: A day after the N.F.L. and New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady faced off in federal court, Brady started in the Patriots’ first preseason game.
lead_paragraph: A day after the N.F.L. and Tom Brady faced off in federal court over his suspension for his role in the deflation of footballs used in last season’s A.F.C. championship game, he started in the New England Patriots’ preseason opener Thursday against the Green Bay Packers.

headline: New York Council Passes Bill Aimed at Limiting Future Legionnaires’ Outbreaks
abstract: Under the legislation, building owners must conduct quarterly inspections of cooling towers, which have been pinpointed as the source of the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: With New York City’s largest ever outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease apparently waning, the City Council passed a bill on Thursday intended to thwart future spread of the illness.

headline: Biff Liff, Broadway Manager and Powerhouse Agent, Dies at 96
abstract: After making his mark backstage on shows like “My Fair Lady,” Mr. Liff became an agent whose clients included Julie Andrews, Angela Lansbury and Chita Rivera.
lead_paragraph: When “My Fair Lady” opened on Broadway in 1956, there was Alan Jay Lerner’s book, and there was Biff Liff’s book. Mr. Liff’s book, the log he kept as the production stage manager, swelled to several volumes over the show’s long run, and the entries were not just about each performance.

headline: Washington State Faces $100,000-a-Day Fine Until Schools Plan Is Reached
abstract: The state’s highest court “encouraged” Gov. Jay Inslee to call the Legislature into a special session to find a way to close the gap in spending between rich and poor schools.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Washington State’s highest court, which has threatened, cajoled and pleaded with the state Legislature and governor for years to close the gap in spending between rich and poor schools, said on Thursday that it had finally lost its patience. In a unanimous decision, the nine-member Supreme Court imposed a fine of $100,000 a day on the state until a plan to reduce the gap was accepted, and in a written order “encouraged” Gov. Jay Inslee to call the Legislature into a special session.

headline: Freddie Mac Yields
abstract: Average for some Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. securities.
lead_paragraph: Average for some Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. securities.

headline: In Good Times or Bad, Brazil Banks Profit
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Government Bonds', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With sky-high interest rates for consumers and businesses, favorable government policies and limited competition, Brazil’s banks do well, even when the broader economy is faltering.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Political parties whose symbol is a red star tend to be unfavorable for bankers, but Brazil’s ruling party has been a lucrative exception.

headline: In Latin America, Quiet Diplomacy Bears Fruit
abstract: The United States is being more pragmatic in its approach in Latin America, and it’s paying off.
lead_paragraph: Nearly seven years ago, President Evo Morales of Bolivia expelled the American ambassador, denouncing him for “conspiring against democracy and seeking the division of Bolivia.” Months later, Mr. Morales’s government kicked the Drug Enforcement Administration out of La Paz, in a rebuke of Washington’s approach to counternarcotics in the region. In 2013, Bolivia ejected the American government’s international aid agency, which Mr. Morales accused of working secretly to destabilize his government.

headline: U.S. and Turkey Face Questions in Anti-ISIS Effort
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Two weeks after the United States and Turkey announced the plan, it is unclear which forces will fight the jihadists and what support they will receive.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — The United States and Turkey have taken preliminary steps to carry out a plan to push the extremists of the Islamic State from the last strip of Syrian territory along the Turkish border controlled by the jihadist group.

headline: Joe Biden Wades Further Into 2016 Bid
abstract: As Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. vacations in South Carolina, he and those who support him are moving to put the pieces into place for a possible candidacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is vacationing on Kiawah Island off South Carolina’s coast, riding bikes and walking the beaches with his family. But on Wednesday night, he called one of his most outspoken political supporters and wrestled with the question looming over his future: Should he run for president?

headline: Breakdown at BP Refinery Strains Midwest Gas Prices
abstract: Since a breakdown at BP’s refinery in Whiting, Ind., the wholesale price of gas has climbed 50 to 80 cents a gallon in a broad region of the country.
lead_paragraph: A breakdown at a BP refinery outside Chicago is sending jolts across the energy markets of the Midwest and Canada, pushing up gasoline prices even as oil prices over all reached a six-year low.

headline: The End of Prison Days, the Start of Something New
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Rudolph Norris, 58, is out of prison and trying to piece together a new life after his sentence for drug offenses was commuted by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph Norris, 58, is out of prison and trying to piece together a new life after his sentence for drug offenses was commuted by President Obama.

headline: They Look to the Sky
abstract: People gathered in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan on Wednesday for an unobstructed view of the Perseid meteor shower.
lead_paragraph: People gathered in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan on Wednesday for an unobstructed view of the Perseid meteor shower, an annual occurrence during which burning specks of cosmic dust race zoom through the heavens at 36 miles per second. The meteor activity is expected to drop sharply after this weekend.

headline: Stores Suffer From a Shift of Behavior in Buyers
abstract: As Americans prioritize spending their money on experiences, not objects, department stores and other retailers are struggling with sales.
lead_paragraph: As Americans spend more money on doing things, not buying things, department stores are losing out.

headline: The Yen, Won and Renminbi: A Triangular Guide to the East Asian Currency Wars
abstract: These charts show the relative currency strength of East Asia’s three largest economies over the last 15 years.
lead_paragraph: These charts show the relative currency strength of East Asia’s three largest economies over the last 15 years.

headline: A Secretive Path to Raising U.S. Flag in Cuba
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The story of America’s reconciliation with Cuba is one of near misses, crossed wires and unexpected challenges that could have changed the course of history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before the United States and Cuba could seal a historic diplomatic rapprochement brokered in 18 months of secret talks, they first had to hide a pregnancy.

headline: Marco Rubio Frustrates Those Taking a Zero-Abortion Stand
abstract: In 2013, Marco Rubio co-sponsored legislation that would have banned abortions more than 20 weeks into a pregnancy. The bill, which ultimately failed, did grant exceptions in cases of rape or incest.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida surprised some Democrats and moderate Republicans last week when he said during the Republican presidential debate that he opposed abortion even in cases where rape or incest were involved: He had previously backed legislation allowing those exceptions. Though many abortion opponents applauded the bill, some groups were frustrated with Mr. Rubio for what they saw as compromised values.

headline: Rory McIlroy Returns, and Is Tested Immediately
abstract: Rory McIlroy, who missed the British Open after injuring his left ankle, played the opening round of the P.G.A. Championship with the rising star Jordan Spieth, and both confronted a difficult course in Whistling Straits.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — The next great rivalry in golf broke slowly out of the gates Thursday, which just shows the folly of treating golfers as if they are heavyweight boxers or world champion sprinters. Rory McIlroy and Jordan Spieth may have shared a tee time in the first round of the 97th P.G.A. Championship, but they were not each other’s main adversary.

headline: Story’s Opening
abstract: Natan Last and the J.A.S.A. class offer us a great entry into the weekend.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — The Jewish Association Serving the Aging, or J.A.S.A. as it’s popularly known, provides services for people age 55 and up in new York City, and one of the classes taught there is the fine art of crossword puzzle construction. The class has been taught by a variety of familiar constructor names, including Ian Livengood, Finn Vigeland and now Natan Last and, if the puzzle passes muster, it is published in The New York Times. If you live in New York City and would like to join the constructing class, the Fall 2015 catalog can be downloaded here.

headline: Before Texas Killing, Officer Took Unusual Path to Police Work
abstract: James Bradley Miller, the police officer who was fired after the shooting death of a black man during a burglary, was a hairdresser who was searching for a path to success.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Officer James Bradley Miller was not a typical rookie in the Police Department here. At 49, he was six years older than the chief. He discovered law enforcement relatively late in life, after struggling for decades in an array of jobs and careers.

headline: Egypt: 2 Groups Handled Hostage, Croatia Says
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'International Relations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A Croatian expatriate worker believed to have been beheaded by the Islamic State’s Egyptian affiliate was initially abducted by a different group that demanded a ransom.
lead_paragraph: A Croatian expatriate worker believed to have been beheaded by the Islamic State’s Egyptian affiliate was initially abducted by a different group that demanded a ransom, Croatia’s foreign minister said Thursday. The worker, Tomislav Salopek, 30, was kidnapped on July 22 on the outskirts of Cairo, and on Wednesday, the affiliate, Sinai Province, released a picture of what it claimed was Mr. Salopek’s body. Foreign Minister Vesna Pusic said it was “very likely” that “two separate organizations” were involved in Mr. Salopek’s abduction, “one which kidnapped and the other which presented itself as ISIS, Sinai Province.” Sinai Province released a video of Mr. Salopek on Aug. 5, in which he conveyed the militants’ threat to kill him if Muslim women were not released from Egyptian jails. Ms. Pusic said that Egypt and Croatia had not yet been able to confirm Mr. Salopek’s death.

headline: Smelly Visit to New York’s Sewer System Ends With 3 Men Under Arrest
abstract: The authorities suspect that the men were looking for lost valuable items.
lead_paragraph: The sewer system of New York — the more than 7,500 miles of it — exists to move the slush left behind in a city of millions. Still, for a branch of infrastructure, it has done a remarkable job of inspiring the public’s imagination into believing it is so much more.

headline: Man Killed in a Shooting in Brooklyn
abstract: A shooting on Thursday night in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn left one man dead and two others hospitalized in stable condition, the police said.
lead_paragraph: One man was killed and two more were injured in a shooting in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the police said.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick’s First Start for Jets Is Brief, but He’s Happy
abstract: Fitzpatrick, the new starting quarterback, played one series, completing 2 of 3 passes for 12 yards in leading the Jets on a 41-yard dive that culminated in a 34-yard field goal by Nick Folk.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Jets did something normal on Thursday: They played a football game without incident or swirling drama. Alas, they opened the preseason in underwhelming fashion, losing by 23-3 to the Lions at Ford Field.

headline: Obama Is Set to Discuss Rights Issues With China
abstract: A top State Department official said Thursday that human rights would feature prominently in talks next month between President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top State Department official said Thursday that there was a “growing sense of alarm in the United States about human rights developments in China,” vowing that the issue would feature prominently in summit talks between President Xi Jinping of China and President Obama in Washington next month.

headline: New York Schools With Many Opting Out of Tests May Be Penalized
abstract: The state and federal education departments had warned that districts with high refusal rates risked losing funds. But it is far from certain such action will be taken.
lead_paragraph: A drastic increase this year in the number of students sitting out New York’s standardized exams has created another kind of test, one for state and federal education officials who must decide whether to punish school districts with low participation rates.

headline: Fresh Face Arrives, and Yankees’ Bats Awake From a Slumber
abstract: The call up of Greg Bird, a prized prospect, was an acknowledgment that Mark Teixeira, 35, and Alex Rodriguez, 40, sorely need a break.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In the movie “Major League,” the first baseman for the Cleveland Indians, a character named Pedro Cerrano, makes offerings to Jobu, his voodoo totem, to drive the fear out of his bats. A cup of rum is the preferred sacrament, though sacrificing a chicken is also a consideration.

headline: The Illustrated Interview: Greta Gerwig
abstract: The new film "Mistress America," out this month, was co-written by the actress and the director Noah Baumbach.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, notables from the worlds of fashion, art, design and entertainment sketch their responses to a brief questionnaire.

headline: Imagining Life After Eden
abstract: The poet Sandra Lim and the artist Lionel Estève consider life for Adam and Eve after the fall, as a banal reality begins to crystallize.
lead_paragraph: For T’s ongoing series, the poet Sandra Lim and the artist Lionel Estève consider life for Adam and Eve after the fall, as a banal reality begins to crystallize.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Michael Stipe
abstract: The former R.E.M. frontman shares the titles he’d bring with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Michael Stipe, the artist and former frontman of the band R.E.M., who shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | bombastic
abstract: This word has appeared in 127 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: bombastic • \bäm-ˈbas-tik\ • adjective

headline: Indonesia Frees 2 Educators After Court Overturns Sex Abuse Convictions
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The two men, one Canadian and one Indonesian, were convicted in April of sexually assaulting kindergartners, charges their school said had been fabricated.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Two educators at a prestigious international school in Indonesia were freed from prison on Friday after an appeals court overturned their convictions and 10-year prison sentences on charges of sexually assaulting kindergartners, in a case that the school said was fabricated and that led to international concern about the competence of the country’s judicial system.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:15 A.M. (Cinemax) SWEENEY TODD: THE DEMON BARBER OF FLEET STREET (2007) Johnny Depp, his skin pale and his eyes odd, stars as the vengeful barber (and earned a best actor Oscar nomination) in Tim Burton’s film of the Stephen Sondheim-Hugh Wheeler musical. Helena Bonham Carter is Mrs. Lovett, the pie maker who disposes of Sweeney’s victims. And Alan Rickman is the malevolent judge who had Sweeney transported to Australia, stole his wife (Laura Michelle Kelly) and now has guardianship of his teenage daughter. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film “as dark and terrifying as any motion picture in recent memory, not excluding the bloody installments in the ‘Saw’ franchise,” adding, “It is also something close to a masterpiece, a work of extreme — I am tempted to say evil — genius.” In “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” (2005), Mr. Burton’s sugar-rush adaptation of the Roald Dahl book, at 8 p.m. on ABC Family, Mr. Depp portrays an oddly sinister candy maker, and Freddie Highmore is a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldn’t? Despite burdening Willy Wonka with a psychological back story, “there is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonka’s world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad,” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. “The real lesson of ‘Charlie and the Chocolate Factory’ is — or should be — that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.”

headline: How to Brush a Gorilla’s Teeth
abstract: Introduce the toothbrush slowly. Don’t force the process.
lead_paragraph: Even 400-pound silverbacks will fear a toothbrush. ‘‘You have to desensitize them,’’ says Jodi Carrigan, the lead keeper of primates at Zoo Atlanta, which is home to the largest collection of gorillas in North America. At first, place the toothbrush at a safe distance, somewhere out of reach but visible. Every day, inch it closer until you can hold the brush in your hand while you teach the gorilla to open its mouth. To do this, reward it with grapes, slices of apple, popcorn or juice (Crystal Light is an ape favorite). The first time an animal completes the desired behavior, ‘‘jackpot’’ it, offering 10 grapes instead of one. ‘‘Then they’re like, ‘Oh, whatever I just did I should do it again,’ ’’ Carrigan says.

headline: ‘More Than Once’

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Uzbek
abstract: Because you never know when you might be on a plane to Tashkent.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the federal government paid me a large sum — a year of graduate-school tuition, plus a stipend — to study Uzbek at the University of Chicago. Uzbek is among the least commonly taught of the so-called Less Commonly Taught Languages, or L.C.T.L.s. So uncommonly is it taught, in fact, that without federal largess it would hardly be taught at all. Because I happened to speak decent Turkish, a cousin of Uzbek, and because I spent a week in Uzbekistan when I was 22, and because life is nothing if not a sequence of odd choices vaguely considered, for two years I sat in a room with two other students and produced some extremely literal translations.

headline: Ramiro Gomez’s Domestic Disturbances
abstract: The subversive young Mexican-American artist paints homages to the Angelenos whom wealthy homeowners — and the art world — often fail to see.
lead_paragraph: I first noticed the work of the young Los Angeles artist Ramiro Gomez across a series of recent art fairs, on account of those Hockneys of his: that is, paintings that were dead ringers for Hockneys — same scale, same colors, same composition — except that something was always just slightly off. Take Gomez’s large-scale version of Hockney’s iconic ‘‘American Collectors’’ double portrait, for example, which Gomez’s Los Angeles dealer, Charlie James, exhibited at the most recent Expo Chicago. It looks almost exactly like the original portrait of the couple in question, clenched in a grim rictus amid the sculptures in their backyard garden, except that Gomez replaced the two collector protagonists with a pair of dark-skinned gardeners of the sort who regularly do the actual tending of such gardens. Into another Hockney, of one of those nondescript West Los Angeles apartment buildings with its wide front lawn, Gomez slotted a groundskeeper, rake extended. That was the genius of the whole series: how in much the same way that, back in the ’60s, the English transplant Hockney first opened our eyes to so much that we had previously overlooked in Los Angeles, rendering all sorts of things visible to us as if for the first time (those boxy apartment buildings, the distinctive street signs, the moderne furniture, that light), so Gomez seemed to be allowing us, indeed forcing us, to notice the very groundskeepers and housemaids and pool cleaners who make that look, the look of Los Angeles, possible, rendering visible a whole world of people, our fellow humans, who often go unseen (and who, for that matter, because they are sometimes ‘‘illegal,’’ often strive not to be seen).

headline: Taliban Present Gentler Face but Wield Iron Fist in Afghan District

headline: Morning Agenda: A New Global Currency War
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Private Equity', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Taxation', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: Brazil Banks Boom in Good Times and Bad | Goldman Expands Retail Banking | Google Gets More Time
lead_paragraph: A NEW GLOBAL CURRENCY WAR | China held firm on the value of its money for years, as other countries tried to secure an economic advantage by letting the value of their currencies slide on international markets. Some analysts see its jump into the fray as a new phase in a long-raging global currency war, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The plunge paused on Friday, but the renminbi was still down 4.4 percent against the dollar this week, a huge drop for China and the steepest drop since the country’s modern exchange system was set up, Neil Gough reports in The New York Times. The move could leave the United States exposed and undermine efforts to pull the world economy out of the doldrums.

abstract: For decades, presidential candidates have gone through the ritual of visiting the Iowa State Fair to mingle with potential caucus voters.
lead_paragraph: For decades, presidential candidates have gone through the ritual of visiting the Iowa State Fair to mingle with potential caucus voters.

headline: Where to Find Symbols on Tablets
abstract: Locate copyright, trademark and other symbols on Android and iOS tablets; and find how much free space is available on a Windows 7 drive.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Women and Movies, and Interactive History
abstract: Web gems of the week include how an economist approaches pregnancy and what’s happening with bicycle fatalities.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: 1915: Roumania Readies for Attack
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Romania set to oppose an Austro-German attack on Serbia in 1915.
lead_paragraph: Events are moving in the Balkans and there are indications that the attitude of Roumania will not remain in doubt much longer. According to the Bucarest correspondent of the ‘‘Secolo,’’ the intervention of Roumania on the side of the Entente Powers is certain.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Remarks on War Anniversary
abstract: The Japanese prime minister delivered a statement on the 70th anniversary of the announcement of the country’s surrender in World War II, expressing “profound grief” at the loss of life.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese prime minister delivered a statement on the 70th anniversary of the announcement of the country’s surrender in World War II, expressing “profound grief” at the loss of life.

headline: Ameer Abdullah Draws Praise in His Detroit Lions Debut
abstract: The running game has not been a strength of the Lions for years, but the second-round draft pick out of Nebraska may change that.
lead_paragraph: The first full slate of preseason games brought a surprise appearance from the recent litigant Tom Brady and a touchdown for Johnny Manziel. But the name that created the most excitement seemed to be Ameer Abdullah of the Detroit Lions.

headline: Elaine Wynn Eyes the Bigger Picture in Los Angeles
abstract: Five years after her divorce, the billionaire is establishing her own reputation as an arts patron and collector.
lead_paragraph: At the Los Angeles County Museum of Art on an unusually humid day last month, the museum’s director, Michael Govan, was consulting the new co-chairwoman of his board of trustees about another sticky situation — of the public relations variety.

headline: Effective Altruism: Where Charity and Rationality Meet
abstract: Applying economic concepts to philanthropy encourages donors to consider factors like opportunity cost and unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: You are lucky enough to have some money to give away: It could be $100 or $1 million. Whether you are prepared to make a small donation or a big one, you would like to accomplish something good with it.

headline: Singapore’s History Put to Song
abstract: "The LKY Musical" tells the story of the early years of Lee Kuan Yew, from the Japanese occupation of Singapore to the country's independence.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — When two Singaporean businessmen began pitching the idea for a contemporary opera about Singapore’s founding father to local theater companies about three years ago, they met with no shortage of skepticism.

headline: Doubt Starts Chipping Away at the Market’s Mind-Set
abstract: In this aging bull market, investors are showing signs of a sea change in their attitudes.
lead_paragraph: In the stock market, until recently, just about any news was good news.

headline: Seeking Privacy for Prince George, Royal Family Asks Photographers to Keep Their Distance
abstract: In a letter that aimed to create a boundary for the prince’s private life, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge described dangerous tactics used by those seeking photographs.
lead_paragraph: In a letter issued from Kensington Palace on Friday, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge expressed concern that members of the news media were going to increasing extremes to photograph their 2-year-old son, Prince George.

headline: Florida Legislators Deny Gerrymandering as They Slouch Back to the Drawing Board
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Maps', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The state’s Republican-dominated Legislature was forced back into a special session this week to make a third attempt at drawing congressional boundaries.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, 63 percent of Florida voters approved a “Fair Districts” amendment to the state constitution designed to end the partisan dirty pool that is as old as Congress itself — the gerrymandering of congressional boundaries to favor one party over the other. Patrick Henry tried it first in Virginia in 1788, having lines drawn to block James Madison from a congressional seat, but Madison prevailed before the voters.

headline: 1940: France Gets a 2nd Guillotine
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The unoccupied zone in France gets its own guillotine executioner in 1940.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — The partition of France into two zones, occupied and unoccupied, has had the unfortunate consequence of depriving the French government of the services of the official executioner, known as ‘‘Monsieur Paris,’’ who is in Paris. So the civil authorities have had to call on ‘‘Monsieur Algeria,’’ who in civilian life goes by the name of Henri Roch, to behead criminals guilty of capital offenses. ‘‘Monsieur Algeria’’ has arrived in Nimes from North Africa with three assistants and a guillotine. There he will discharge the duties of his gruesome office until the French government is permitted by the Germans to return to Paris. — New York Herald Tribune, August 15, 1940

headline: British Trader Charged in ‘Flash Crash’ Released After Bail Reduction
abstract: A judge in London reduced bail for Navinder Singh Sarao, who has been in custody since April and is fighting extradition to the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Navinder Singh Sarao, the British futures trader charged by United States authorities with contributing to a sudden plunge in American stock markets five years ago, was assigned a reduced bail at a court hearing on Friday, allowing him to be released from custody.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Straight Outta Compton,’ ‘Mistress America’ and ‘The Man From U.N.C.L.E.’
abstract: Times critics on “Straight Outta Compton,” “Mistress America” and “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Straight Outta Compton,” “Mistress America” and “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: An Ode to Diving Boards
abstract: Remember the summertime thrill of leaping off a diving board? Since the 1970s it has gotten harder to find in New York, as diving boards have steadily disappeared from the city’s pools.
lead_paragraph: Remember the summertime thrill of leaping off a diving board? Since the 1970s it has gotten harder to find in New York, as diving boards have steadily disappeared from the city’s pools.

headline: Readers Share Back-to-School Tips for Incoming Freshmen
abstract: The transition to college can be rocky. New York Times readers submitted advice on how to adjust and get the most out of the experience.
lead_paragraph: Freshman year can be a challenge. Between choosing the right classes, meeting new people and navigating tricky roommate relationships, there’s plenty of room for error.

headline: First Draft Focus: It’s Heigh-Ho, Come to the (Iowa) Fair!
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'State and County Fairs']
abstract: Can presidential candidates fit in with the locals at the ultimate down-home event, the Iowa State Fair, in the state with the first nominating contest? Knowing what to eat is part of the challenge.
lead_paragraph: Every presidential election cycle, candidates face a big test at the Iowa State Fair: Can they fit in with the locals at the ultimate down-home event in the state with the first nominating contest? Knowing what to eat is part of the challenge: corn dogs, fried butter, and apple pie on a stick are just some of the cholesterol-filled favorites.

headline: ‘Eileen,’ by Ottessa Moshfegh
abstract: In this debut novel, a crime sets a woman’s life on an entirely new course.
lead_paragraph: “I looked like a girl you’d expect to see on a city bus,” begins “Eileen,” Ottessa Moshfegh’s seductive novel, “reading some clothbound book from the library about plants or geography, perhaps wearing a net over my light brown hair.” This is the eponymous Eileen, and we quickly learn that any assumptions we might make about her from her appearance would be dead wrong. “I didn’t really read books about flowers or home economics,” she tells us a few pages later. “I liked books about awful things — murder, illness, death.”

headline: Why We Need Fetal Tissue Research
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Research']
abstract: Fetal tissue is not only being used in potentially life-saving medical research, it has already saved countless lives.
lead_paragraph: Hidden-camera videos showing Planned Parenthood staffers discussing fetal tissue donations have led not just to efforts to defund the organization, but to calls for an end to the use of fetal tissue in research. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the law and bioethics professor R. Alta Charo explains why these calls are misguided.

headline: The 19th Century in Fiction
abstract: New books by Jeffrey Lent, Clifford Jackman, Shannon Burke, Tom LeClair and Cormac James.
lead_paragraph: A SLANT OF LIGHTBy Jeffrey Lent357 pp. Bloomsbury, $27.

headline: ‘Make Your Home Among Strangers,’ by Jennine Capó Crucet
abstract: A homecoming coincides with a Cuban boy’s rescue at sea.
lead_paragraph: Elián González, the 6-year-old boy at the heated center of the international custody battle that tore apart Miami and the Cuban-American community in 2000, has resurfaced in the news. Fifteen years after the predawn raid by American agents that led to his return to his father in Cuba, he has announced that he would like to visit the United States again. With the thaw in relations between the two countries, the times are vastly different. But as we are expansively reminded in “Make Your Home Among Strangers,” Jennine Capó Crucet’s heartfelt first novel about a Cuban-American family entangled in a fictionalized account of the González affair, no amount of change erases the past. With history onboard, Crucet shows us how journeys between cultures are almost impossible to navigate and family relationships are bound to dump us in choppy waters.

headline: ‘The Pope’s Daughter,’ by Dario Fo
abstract: In his first novel, the playwright Dario Fo depicts a Lucrezia Borgia who belies the rumors.
lead_paragraph: Last year, at the venerable age of 88, the Italian comic Dario Fo took on a new creative challenge. The veteran of more than 60 years as an actor, painter, director, stage designer and playwright (as well as the recipient of the 1997 Nobel Prize in Literature), he had in recent years begun to deliver delightful public lectures on artists — Giotto, Leonardo, Raphael, Caravaggio, Picasso — and architecture, including the Romanesque cathedral of Modena. But up to 2014, he had never written a novel. That changed with “The Pope’s Daughter,” now translated into English, although needless to say for this wild man of the theater, the word “novel” is not quite enough to encompass his lightly fictional labor of love for, of all people, Lucrezia Borgia. “The Pope’s Daughter” is also a picture book, illustrated with some of Fo’s own colorful paintings, most based on Renaissance originals. It has since become a full-blown theatrical script. (Meanwhile, Fo has finished a second illustrated novel, inspired by an 18th-century Danish prince, Christian VII.)

headline: ‘The Marriage of Opposites,’ by Alice Hoffman
abstract: A novel inspired by the painter Camille Pissarro’s parents.
lead_paragraph: For a period of her young life, Virginia Woolf wrote while standing at an elevated desk poised near her sister Vanessa’s easel. The writing table’s curious height enabled Virginia to peer at the world from the same viewpoint as her artist sister, to witness all at once the world itself, the world transcribed in ink and the world brushed onto a canvas. Later, when Woolf created the character of the painter Lily Briscoe in “To the Lighthouse,” she knew the mix of delicacy and passion that collide to create a great work, and she was schooled in the fine craft of transforming daubs of paint into strings of words.

headline: Mystery of ‘Baby Doe’ Troubles Massachusetts Investigators
abstract: After a little girl’s remains were found eight weeks ago on a Boston Harbor shoreline, the police still have few clues about who she is and how she died.
lead_paragraph: For nearly eight weeks, investigators in Massachusetts have been struggling to solve a mystery: the identity of a little girl whose remains were found on a Boston Harbor shoreline.

headline: ‘Brief Loves That Live Forever’ and ‘A Woman Loved,’ by Andrei Makine
abstract: Two novels set in Soviet Russia exalt everyday joys and imagine Catherine the Great’s yearnings.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in a Soviet orphanage, the narrator of Andrei Makine’s memoiristic novel “Brief Loves That Live Forever” recalls being completely in thrall to the idea of a “dazzlingly white city” where everything would be abundant and free, and people would help themselves only to as much as they needed. The harsh realities of daily life under Communism being what they are, disillusionment sets in quickly. Even so, the novel’s dreamy and impressionistic linked episodes, which take the narrator from his boyhood under Brezhnev to his adulthood, offer up this essential truth: Fleeting moments of beauty and love are to be treasured above all else. Carved out of even the most dreary and oppressive circumstances, they’re the sum of a life, a means of triumphing over brutality, a more powerful form of resistance than “dissident whisperings.”

headline: Jeff Bartsch’s ‘Two Across’
abstract: A crossword creator and con man eludes the woman who loves him, until he realizes his error.
lead_paragraph: Right before college-age Vera Baxter disappears from Stanley Owens’s life for the second time, she wakes up in the middle of the night, wondering whether she should leave him. “Maybe,” she thinks, “it was better to make important decisions in the misty neverland of a tired mind, when she might be closer to her real desires, than using all the well-rested but suspect might of logic.” It’s one of many moments in Jeff Bartsch’s new novel, “Two Across,” where we’re reminded that brainpower can be vastly overrated, especially in matters of the heart.

headline: ‘The Dust That Falls From Dreams,’ by Louis de Bernières
abstract: Louis de Bernières’s historical novel follows a wealthy British family through the tumultuous first decades of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Enviously noting the insatiable public appetite for television dramas like “Downton Abbey,” writers often lament the prospects for their historical novels, which have faint hopes of attracting anything resembling such sizable audiences. Not Louis de Bernières, who charges straight at them with “The Dust That Falls From Dreams,” a sprawling story about the members of a wealthy English family and the neighbors, friends and servants who constellate around them at their grand house in London during the first few decades of the 20th century.

headline: ‘Sophie and the Sibyl,’ by Patricia Duncker
abstract: A novelist imagines an incident that inspired George Eliot’s “Daniel Deronda.”
lead_paragraph: In 1863, George Eliot received the largest advance that had yet been offered for a novel; the £7,000 paid for “Romola” were well-earned. Her previous books had captured a zeitgeist. They received rave reviews, sold enviably well and were even quoted in debates in Parliament. Her stories were much talked about, but Eliot’s authorship and life were also subjects of gossip and speculation; writing under a pen name, the journalist and translator Marian Evans was also scandalously cohabiting with a married man. Evans was a social pariah, but Eliot was now a success.

headline: ‘The Dressmaker,’ by Rosalie Ham
abstract: A native daughter’s return to a town of oddballs leads to fashion makeovers, and revenge.
lead_paragraph: Rosalie Ham’s novel “The Dressmaker” was published in Australia in 2000 and later this year will be presented as a movie starring Kate Winslet. What’s surprising is that a film version took so long to appear. From the moment the book opens, with a long shot of “wheat-yellow plains” around the “dark blot” of a hill in the small country town of Dungatar, we sense that we’re on our way to quirky-indie-movie land; and once the camera closes in on the “tumbling brown house” of Mad ­Molly, “leaning provocatively on the grassy curve,” it’s clear we’re visiting a small 1950s town not of history but as imagined by Tim Burton: the gothic, polarized world of “Edward Scissorhands.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Voices in the Ocean,” Susan Casey’s look at dolphin intelligence, is new at No. 13 on the hardcover nonfiction list.
lead_paragraph: The Dolphin Whisperer: One of the more entertaining figures in “Voices in the Ocean,” Susan Casey’s look at dolphin intelligence — new at No. 13 on the hardcover nonfiction list — is the neurophysiologist John C. Lilly, who before his death in 2001 did as much as anyone to promote the image of dolphins as a nearly alien superspecies that might speak English someday. In the 1960s, Lilly’s unfettered enthusiasm caught on big with a certain segment of the public, but his fellow scientists were less enthralled: As Casey notes, the trade reviews of his 1961 book, “Man and Dolphin,” were scathing. “Scientifically unsound and naïve,” Natural History fumed, judging the book a perfect example of “how not to do scientific research.” The biologist E.O. Wilson called it “borderline irresponsible,” and a Navy researcher snarked: “I find Dr. Lilly’s work very interesting. I like Dr. Seuss, too.” Not that the reviews hurt the book’s prospects: “Man and Dolphin” hit the New York Times best-seller list at No. 15. But Lilly’s reputation as a scientist never quite recovered. “Lilly is so fascinating because he’s so polarizing,” Casey told “Fresh Air” this month. “He was pretty freewheeling about the things he did and the things he said.” Or, as she clarifies in “Voices in the Ocean,”  “The real damage occurred when Lilly began a run of experiments that involved LSD and interspecies sex.”

headline: Mom, I Know You’re Doing that ‘Gift of Failure’ Thing, But Could You Please Just Not?
abstract: Jessica Lahey literally wrote the book about letting kids fail. But sometimes her kids want her to step in, not back.
lead_paragraph: In an earlier post, Six Things Parents Need to Send Kids Back to School (That We Can’t Buy), I mentioned that I needed time to read, because books like “The Gift of Failure” by Jessica Lahey are inspiring me to push my children, not toward conventional school and other successes, but toward the kind of independence that leads them to find their own way.

headline: ‘In Another Country,’ by David Constantine
abstract: Thirty years’ worth of stories, often about eccentric people, from a British master.
lead_paragraph: More than a century ago, in England during the late-Victorian and Edwardian eras, the god Pan made something of a comeback. In “The Wind in the Willows,” the Mole and the Water Rat encountered him piping at the gates of dawn. E.M. Forster located him in the Italian countryside in “The Story of a Panic,” and presiding over a secluded English pond in “A Room With a View.” Arthur Machen’s brilliant novella “The Great God Pan” emphasized the orgiastic horror as well as the freedom associated with the deity. And Peter Pan himself, that eminent Edwardian, recalled the god both in his name and in his occasional habit of blowing on the panpipes.

headline: Yes, Succotash Has a Luxurious Side
abstract: Leave memories of the school cafeteria behind: With the addition of lobster, succotash becomes a deluxe main dish.
lead_paragraph: Succotash, that savory mélange of corn and beans, is a noble dish with a long history. We have 17th-century Native Americans to thank for it; they introduced the stew to the struggling colonial immigrants. Composed of ingredients unknown in Europe at the time, it gradually became a standard meal in the settlers’ kitchens.

headline: Fumbling in the Dark
abstract: In Michael Koryta’s “Last Words,” an investigator for a death row defense firm takes on a cold case.
lead_paragraph: There are authors who keep writing the same book, over and over. Michael Koryta is not one of those authors. An inventive storyteller who’s also a skilled stylist, he’s constantly experimenting, which explains why his private eye novel LAST WORDS (Little, Brown, $26) doesn’t read like one. Mark Novak conducts investigative work for a team of Florida defense lawyers who take on pro bono cases for clients on death row. But he’s been unraveling for more than a year, ever since his wife, who worked for the same firm, was murdered. With his job hanging by a thread, Mark is given the mercy assignment of investigating a cold case in Garrison, Ind., noteworthy because Ridley Barnes, the man who has asked for help, was never charged but has been condemned by the whole town.

headline: José Mourinho Says Chelsea Doctor Won’t Be on Bench This Week, but May Return
abstract: The doctor, Eva Carneiro, had enraged Mourinho by running onto the field to treat an injured Chelsea player in the late stages of an opening-day game.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Manager José Mourinho pivoted on Friday under persistent criticism of his demotion of the club’s team doctor this week, confirming that the doctor would miss Sunday’s match against Manchester City but leaving open the possibility of her return to the bench.

headline: How California Is Winning the Drought
abstract: The state’s scorching summer of 2015 is showing us that we know what to do when it comes to conserving water — we just have to do it.
lead_paragraph: FOR California, there hasn’t ever been a summer quite like the summer of 2015. The state and its 39 million residents are about to enter the fifth year of a drought. It has been the driest four-year period in California history — and the hottest, too.

headline: Iowa Democratic Leader: Complaints on Debate Timing Have a Point
abstract: The chairwoman of the Iowa Democratic Party appeared to acknowledge this week that complaints about the party’s compressed presidential debate calendar from lower-polling candidates are understandable.
lead_paragraph: The chairwoman of the Iowa Democratic Party appeared to acknowledge this week that complaints about the party’s compressed presidential debate calendar from candidates trailing in the polls are understandable.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE MAGICIAN’S LAND, by Lev Grossman. (Plume, $16.) At the outset of Grossman’s novel, a satisfying end to his Magicians trilogy, Quentin Coldwater has been exiled from Fillory, the enchanted land he once helped rule, and dismissed from his teaching post at Brakebills College, where he first learned magic. Charting Quentin’s growth as both a magician and a man, the book “considers complex questions about identity and selfhood as profound as they are entertaining,” our reviewer, Edan Lepucki, wrote.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: KATRINA: After the Flood, by Gary Rivlin. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) A former Times reporter examines the personalities and process behind New Orleans’s reconstruction, including the often corrupt horse trading of the early days.

headline: Greek Parliament Approves Bailout Deal
abstract: Greek lawmakers spoke on Friday after its parliament approved the country’s third bailout in a vote relying on opposition party support.
lead_paragraph: Greek lawmakers spoke on Friday after its parliament approved the country’s third bailout in a vote relying on opposition party support.

lead_paragraph: The season’s ubiquitous staple is a sartorial blank canvas.

abstract: Tiina Loite, a Times editor, recalls her first and only visit to Shea Stadium to see the Beatles 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: “The Beatles, those four engaging Englishmen, whose rock ’n’ roll singing and long hair have stirred strong emotions in youngsters, proved yesterday that their mere presence in town can create more commotion along the Avenue of the Americas than the months of subway construction,” read the lead of a Times article about the group’s arrival in New York City.

headline: With an Eye to Impact, Investing Through a ‘Gender Lens’
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Women and Girls', 'Philanthropy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Finances', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Investment strategies that seek to promote the advancement of women are gaining currency with investors who want their money to do more than multiply.
lead_paragraph: ELLEN REMMER had wanted to align her investments with her values for years, seeking to put her money into stocks and bonds that would have an impact beyond the returns. For her, this meant investing in organizations that either improved the lot of women and girls or helped the environment.

lead_paragraph: This week, Vu Tran discusses his debut novel, “Dragonfish”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Ruth Franklin talks about Lucia Berlin’s stories; listeners share what they’ve been reading; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Downside of Labor Mobility
abstract: Death spirals in Portugal and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The theory of optimum currency areas is one of those old-fashioned pieces of macroeconomics — like IS-LM, the concept of the liquidity trap, and the theory of secular stagnation — that has turned out to be extremely relevant and useful to the world since 2008. So this is a version of Mark Thoma’s dictum that new economic thinking involves reading old books (or in this case articles). Still, we do learn some new things. And what we’ve learned lately, I’d argue, is that labor mobility — which was supposed to be good, and a prerequisite for currency union — is actually much more problematic than we knew.

headline: A Scotsman’s Mission Ends in a Fishing Bay Restored
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Environment', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: It took Howard Wood years to persuade the government to establish the first no-fishing zone in Scotland, but the result has won him international recognition.
lead_paragraph: HOLY ISLE, Scotland — HOWARD WOOD, round-faced and jolly, was happily counting the lobsters being pulled, measured and tagged out of the coastal waters he has worked for years to protect. One weighed close to four pounds, its huge right claw dwarfing its left, which was growing back after what must have been quite a battle.

headline: Low Oil Prices Pose Threat to Texas Fracking Bonanza
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The technology that unlocked the oil in shale fields produced a boom to Karnes County, Tex., but the economy there is cooling fast.
lead_paragraph: KARNES CITY, Tex. — No place in Texas produces more oil than Karnes County, but suddenly the roaring economy here is cooling fast, chilled by the plunging price of crude.

headline: State of Emergency in Ferguson Is Lifted as Protests Ease
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: After nights of limited protests and no arrests, the St. Louis County executive rescinded a declaration issued earlier in the week because of “criminal unrest.”
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis County executive, in a formal indication that tensions in Ferguson, Mo., had eased since an outbreak of gunfire on Sunday night, rescinded on Friday the emergency declaration that he had issued because of “criminal unrest.”

headline: Related C.E.O. Sells Co-op for $30 Million
abstract: A Fifth Avenue apartment owned by Jeff T. Blau, the chief executive of the Related Companies, one of the city’s largest private developers, was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: Jeff T. Blau, the chief executive of the Related Companies, one of the city’s largest private developers, sold the co-op he had bought more than seven years ago in an exclusive Rosario Candela-designed apartment house on Fifth Avenue to an unidentified buyer for $30,000,000 in the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: The Listener
abstract: Remembering the blues scholar Don Kent.
lead_paragraph: Don Kent, the blues scholar and founder of more than one obscure yet influential record label, died last week of cancer at the age of 71. For anyone who knew the man or cared at all about prewar American music, the loss is palpable. Last year, when I was working on “The Ballad of Geeshie and Elvie” — a story about recovering the identities and lives of two lost singers from that early period — Kent proved the most illuminating and generous of sources. He was, to borrow a Barry Hannah line, “a hell of a sweet genius guy.”

headline: The Closing of the Canadian Mind

lead_paragraph: THE prime minister of Canada, Stephen Harper, has called an election for Oct. 19, but he doesn’t want anyone to talk about it.

headline: The Junk Politics of 2015
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The candidates are offering us nothing but empty calories.
lead_paragraph: When you eat a bowl of Simply Granola in the morning, you may think you’re making a healthy start to the day, courtesy of Quaker Oats. But you’re taking in the amount of sugar in almost four Oreo cookies.

headline: Oliver Sacks: Sabbath
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Religion and Belief', 'Philosophy']
abstract: The seventh day of the week, the seventh day of life.
lead_paragraph: MY mother and her 17 brothers and sisters had an Orthodox upbringing — all photographs of their father show him wearing a yarmulke, and I was told that he woke up if it fell off during the night. My father, too, came from an Orthodox background. Both my parents were very conscious of the Fourth Commandment (“Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy”), and the Sabbath (Shabbos, as we called it in our Litvak way) was entirely different from the rest of the week. No work was allowed, no driving, no use of the telephone; it was forbidden to switch on a light or a stove. Being physicians, my parents made exceptions. They could not take the phone off the hook or completely avoid driving; they had to be available, if necessary, to see patients, or operate, or deliver babies.

headline: Popcast: ‘Straight Outta Compton’
abstract: A discussion on N.W.A. and the release of “Straight Outta Compton.”
lead_paragraph: The N.W.A. biopic “Straight Outta Compton” arrives in theaters Friday. In some ways, it’s the final symbol of the success N.W.A. had in redefining hip-hop, and over time, the shape of American pop culture. That’s true in terms of music, and also in terms of politics: the tales N.W.A. specialized in ended up being the stories that would define the news cycle, both in its era and for decades to come.

headline: Arab Bank Reaches Settlement in Suit Accusing It of Financing Terrorism
abstract: The deal, made with hundreds of American plaintiffs, comes after a jury in Brooklyn found the bank liable for dealings with the group Hamas; the court was to decide on damages starting Monday.

headline: A New Vodka Distillery That Subsidizes Artists
abstract: The new brand Material will divert boozy profit margins back to creatives via thrice-annual grants.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s a flute of champagne above the High Line or a can of medium-cold beer in Bushwick, beverages play an essential role in the social ritual of art consumption. Plenty of brands have cashed in on this association, commissioning elaborate bottle labels and other decorative schemes from artists — often with the effect of watering down their profiles. Enter a new vodka distillery called Material, expressly founded on flipping the script and diverting boozy profit margins back to makers.

headline: President Obama’s Eleventh-Hour Conservation Efforts
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Law and Legislation', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: The president has been making more use of his power to designate national monuments. Here are two more he should consider.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before leaving town for the summer, Congress approved – and President Obama happily signed into law – three bills that, taken together, will preserve as permanent wilderness roughly 275,000 acres of spectacular mountain terrain in Idaho known as  Boulder-White Clouds.  This was a rare moment for a Congress that has been far more interested in  party infighting than environmental stewardship, and a tribute to the perseverance of one person, Congressman Mike Simpson, Republican of Idaho, who spent years engaging with local officials, ranchers,  hunters, tribes, off-road vehicle enthusiasts and other stakeholders.
