headline: How Jesse Eisenberg Makes Cup of Noodles a Weapon in ‘American Ultra’
abstract: The film’s director and stunt coordinator explain how they transformed Mr. Eisenberg’s character from a stoner into a lethal C.I.A. agent.
lead_paragraph: Weed is not the only thing that is smoked in the violent action-comedy “American Ultra,” due Friday. Jesse Eisenberg plays Mike Howell, a stoner who works at a convenience store and who has, without his knowledge, been programmed by the C.I.A. to be a lethal sleeper agent. His dormant killer instincts are activated in the middle of a government operation, letting Mike transform whatever items he has at hand into weapons. An early scene, from which this frame is taken, shows Mike’s skills when, in a 10-second burst of action, he takes down two men sent to kill him by using a cup of noodles, a spoon and the gun they pull on him. It’s a quick but energetic scene that will probably shock the viewer as much as it does the character. Here is a closer look at that scene with commentary from the film’s director, Nima Nourizadeh, and its stunt coordinator, Robert Alonzo.

headline: At Iowa’s State Fair, Candidates Brave Cholesterol and Hecklers

And there are 18 presidential candidates in a bipartisan stampede to the Iowa State Fair — bringing their stump speeches, of course, but more important, aiming to prove their common touch in the ultimate venue for retail campaigning.

headline: How John Hatfield, Executive Director of Socrates Sculpture Park, Spends His Sundays
abstract: John Hatfield, the executive director of Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens, has made a pre-emptive strike on empty-nest syndrome: He and his wife got a puppy.
lead_paragraph: As the executive director of Socrates Sculpture Park, a public art space in Long Island City, Queens, John Hatfield keeps an eye on the weather: The clearer the skies and the warmer the temperature, the busier he is. “Late spring, summer, early fall — we have so many events,” Mr. Hatfield said. The schedule often keeps him away from his family’s TriBeCa apartment, so on Sundays, Mr. Hatfield, 51, focuses on spending time at home — taking in art with his wife, Amy Wolf, 57, an art dealer; catching up with their son, Otis, 18; and caring for the family’s new puppy, Babs Kramer.

headline: From the Vault of the Museum of Sex: Macaura’s Pulsocon
abstract: Invented in the 19th century by Dr. Gerald Macaura, who turned out not to be a doctor, the Pulsocon was one of the many early vibrators prescribed to women as cure-alls for ailments like the always-vague “hysteria.”
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, the Museum of Sex, at 233 Fifth Avenue (an address, appropriately enough, near the former site of an early-20th-century red-light district known to vice enthusiasts as the Tenderloin), has been educating, by way of titillating, age-appropriate tourists and locals alike. While those who visit for a bit of blushing will no doubt find an array of X-rated artifacts capable of getting the job done, the true lessons to be learned from the one act with which every culture is consumed are many. And, oftentimes, a little gross.

Pivoting often suggests a last-ditch attempt to salvage a failing start-up. But sometimes, the strategy can turn a business that’s simply chugging along into one with more staying power.

keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'News and News Media', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The experts’ statement came as a verdict was expected any day in the case of Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been held since July 2014.
lead_paragraph: United Nations human rights experts added their voices Friday to the pressure on Iran to release the Washington Post’s Tehran reporter, Jason Rezaian, calling his year-old imprisonment and closed trial a violation of international law and press freedom.

headline: Revised Program Will Reduce Student Loan Repayments
abstract: The plan has been called Repaye and is based on the “pay as you earn” repayment program, which became available to some borrowers nearly three years ago.
lead_paragraph: MORE student loan borrowers are expected to gain access this year to a repayment plan that cuts monthly debt payments to a small share of their income.

abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads from Jenna Wortham, Mike Isaac and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Jennifer Granholm, ex-Michigan Governor, Takes On New Role Supporting Hillary Clinton
abstract: Jennifer M. Granholm, the former Michigan governor, will leave the big-money “super PAC” supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton’s candidacy and take a role with another outside group backing Mrs. Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer M. Granholm, the former governor of Michigan, will leave the big-money “super PAC” supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy and take a role with another outside group backing Mrs. Clinton.

headline: A Bustling Beach Market
abstract: At Red Horse Market, famous patrons are outshined by the hand-made mozzarella.
lead_paragraph: At Red Horse Market, famous patrons are outshined by the hand-made mozzarella.

headline: Mo Rocca Finds Calm in the Kitchen in ‘My Grandmother’s Ravioli’
abstract: Mo Rocca’s Cooking Channel show travels the country in search of fabulous family recipes and finds fabulous family members, too.
lead_paragraph: It’s a frenetic time on the culinary TV front. On Wednesday, the Food Network rolled out “Camp Cutthroat,” a “Cutthroat Kitchen” spinoff competition show advertised with the tagline “This time, we’re playing with campfire.” On Thursday, Destination America’s “BBQ Pit Wars” reached the finale of a grueling season of cross-country grilling. Next Tuesday, the Season 2 premiere of the amusing truTV show “Hack My Life” has a segment on cooking lasagna in a dishwasher.

headline: 1896 | ‘Without Fear or Favor’
abstract: David W. Dunlap looks back at The Times’s mission, as laid of out the publisher Adolph S. Ochs on April 18, 1896.
lead_paragraph: Political madness has surely gripped the nation when a Fox News journalist publicly embraces a 119-year-old guiding principle of The New York Times, as Megyn Kelly did this week by vowing — Donald Trump’s taunts notwithstanding — to “continue doing my job without fear or favor.”

headline: Mozzarella for Big Cheeses at an East Hampton Market
abstract: Bustling with productivity, the Red Horse Market attracts celebrities like Martha Stewart, Alec Baldwin and the Kardashians, and its patrons are a devoted lot.
lead_paragraph: Unlike other East Hampton haunts treasured by affluent summer people for their beachy, low-key vibe, Red Horse Market bustles with productivity. The produce is arranged like a Flemish still life, women in equestrian garb demand to know the provenance of the grass in the grass-fed beef, and the Kardashian sisters once fought on camera in this small shop. Its patrons are a devoted lot.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Cuba and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from Cuba, China, Japan and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Cuba, China, Japan and Greece.

headline: Mylan’s Bid to Buy Perrigo Is Complicated by Opposing Declarations
abstract: I.S.S., an influential advisory firm, recommends that investors vote down the drug maker’s pursuit, but a hedge fund with a stake in Mylan supports the merger.
lead_paragraph: Mylan appeared on Friday morning to hit a significant hurdle in its quest to buy a fellow drug maker, Perrigo, when an influential advisory firm recommended that investors vote down the pursuit.

headline: Quenching a Thirst for Tacos in the Rockaways
abstract: The beachy peninsula in Queens seemed headed toward a taco-less summer. But Tacoway Beach has opened on the premises of the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, attracting a drinking crowd.
lead_paragraph: It looked at one point that the Rockaways, the beachy peninsula in southern Queens, home to firefighters, midlevel Wall Street guys and armies of sun-seeking Brooklyn hipsters, was headed toward a taco-less summer. Late in March, the news slipped out that Andrew Field and David Selig, the co-owners of Rockaway Taco, had parted ways over business plans and that their ramshackle joint on Beach 96th Street would not return this season. But then, Mr. Selig decided to take a food-truck version of Rockaway Taco across the country, and Mr. Field made plans to move his own new venture, Tacoway Beach, onto the premises of the Rockaway Beach Surf Club on Beach 87th Street. Showing no sign of the hostilities, Tacoway Beach was booming recently, filled with a ruddy, beer-drinking crowd that included two newlywed (or newlywed-ish) couples.

headline: Aug. 14, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photographs from Cuba, China, Japan and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Cuba, China, Japan and Greece.

headline: Review: From La Otra Orilla, Flamenco Without Flounces at Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: The Montreal company gave the world premiere of “Moi & Les Autres” at Jacob Pillow’s Doris Duke Theater.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — For about 10 fairly good minutes of “Moi & Les Autres,” the four performers of La Otra Orilla (The Other Coast) share the stage in equal measure and at close quarters: the dancer Myriam Allard, the guitarist Caroline Planté, the percussionist Miguel Medina and the vocalist Hedi Graja. Flamenco rhythms and sonorities pour forth.

headline: Orbitz Offers Vacation Packages by App
abstract: Users can purchase combined flight and hotel packages on Orbitz’s mobile application.
lead_paragraph: Reflecting a major shift in travel planning, Orbitz.com, the web-based travel company, now offers vacation packages in its mobile application. With a few taps, users can purchase combined flight and hotel packages on the app and view their total savings before they complete any sale.

lead_paragraph: On Mr. Cunningham’s Evening Hours page this week, a weekend of vintage dancing that took place at Nahant, Mass.

headline: Evening Hours | Period Pieces
abstract: On Mr. Cunningham’s Evening Hours page this week, a weekend of vintage dancing that took place at Nahant, Mass
lead_paragraph: A weekend of vintage dancing took place at Nahant, Mass. The three-day event, which benefited the Nahant Historical Society, was originally created 25 years ago as a Viennese dance by Katy and Ben Bishop at the urging of Ms. Bishop’s mother, the Viennese-born Olli Heil. RoAnn Costin lent her family’s 1867 seaside home for the gala and the Edwardian tea dance. Most guests wore period clothes for the dance at the Costin house, which has a ballroom and billiards room.

headline: Efforts to Preserve Henry Varnum Poor’s House and Its History Have Stalled
abstract: Town officials from Ramapo, which purchased the house seven years ago, say they plan to fix the house, but do not have the money to address its myriad problems.
lead_paragraph: CLARKSTOWN, N.Y. — The rambling stone cottage here where the artist Henry Varnum Poor created his ceramics and his paintings and other artworks now held at major museums around the country is called Crow House, perhaps because of the birds that circled overhead when Poor designed and built it, by hand, nearly 100 years ago.

headline: You Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Paul Kalkbrenner, a Techno Star, Rises From Berlin’s Clubs
abstract: A giant of electronic dance music tries to broaden his appeal without making too many concessions.
lead_paragraph: The German techno producer Paul Kalkbrenner is not just a famous musician in his home country — he’s also a movie star (“Berlin Calling,” 2008) and a folk hero, having taken his minimal electronic compositions from the Berlin underground to a performance last year for a half-million people at the 25th anniversary of the Berlin Wall’s crumbling.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Review: ‘Mother of the Maid,’ a Lesson on Raising a Teenage Saint
abstract: Jane Anderson’s new play, a Shakespeare & Company production in Lenox, Mass., is about the headaches of rearing a truly gifted child: Joan of Arc.
lead_paragraph: LENOX, Mass. — Teenage saints — and yes, religious history records the existence of such improbable phenomena — are apparently not so unlike other teenagers. They’re moody, rebellious, impulsive and prone to intense crushes on glamorous, inaccessible idols. They also love, loathe and are deeply embarrassed by their parents, who spend sleepless nights fretting over their wayward and baffling progeny.

headline: A South Bronx Graffiti Walkabout
abstract: For the first @nytimes Instameet, a group of photographers descended upon Hunts Point to see bold murals and hidden gems.
lead_paragraph: For the first @nytimes Instameet, a group of photographers descended upon Hunts Point to see bold murals and hidden gems.

headline: U.S.-Led Air Campaign Is Linked to Civilian Deaths in Syria
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The episode revived accusations that the United States and its allies are not careful enough about who is killed by airstrikes on militant groups.
lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — An airstrike by the American-led military coalition in northern Syria this week killed eight civilians, including two women and five children, according to neighbors and relatives of the dead.

headline: Mail Theft, With a Milk Carton and Some Glue
abstract: Investigators accuse a man of stealing money orders from the mail, switching the payees and finding unwitting accomplices online to help him obtain the cash.
lead_paragraph: The young man approached a mailbox on a dark corner in the Bronx. It was a Tuesday in November 2013, almost 4 a.m. He carried two tools: a milk crate and a crushed milk carton on a string. The carton was very sticky, covered in glue from rattraps.

lead_paragraph: Beware the tomato that masquerades as a true Italian.

headline: Internet Hoax on Downing of Malaysian Jet Spreads in Russia
abstract: In audio posted online this week by a Russian newspaper, a man identified as an American reporter working for the C.I.A. speaks in a British accent.
lead_paragraph: In the immediate aftermath of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over rebel-held, eastern Ukraine last year, Ukraine’s intelligence agency released what it said was audio from intercepted phone calls between separatist leaders and Russian military intelligence officers, in which the militants appeared to acknowledge shooting down a civilian plane by mistake.

headline: Yankees to Honor Alex Rodriguez’s 3,000th Hit With a Ceremony in September
abstract: The once frigid relationship between Rodriguez and the team has thawed, the latest example coming when the Yankees said they would honor him before their Sept. 13 home game.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The once frigid relationship between Alex Rodriguez and the Yankees has turned downright cuddly. The latest example came Friday when the team announced it would celebrate Rodriguez reaching the 3,000-hit plateau by holding a day in his honor at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Abandoned Cars Are a New York Memory
abstract: Abandoned cars were a fixture on the New York landscape from the ’60s to the early ’90s. A look back in The New York Times photo archive shows a city all but gone from memory.
lead_paragraph: Abandoned cars were a fixture on the New York landscape from the ’60s to the early ’90s. A look back in The New York Times photo archive shows a city all but gone from memory.

headline: Volkswagen and Mazda Recall Over 600,000 Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The recall comes several years after the automakers changed parts on new vehicles to fix the possible loss of steering or failure of airbags, according to documents filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen and Mazda are recalling about 613,000 vehicles, several years after the automakers changed parts on new vehicles to fix the possible loss of steering or failure of airbags, according to documents filed with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The automakers decided on a recall after the federal regulators opened investigations this year. The automakers said they were not aware of any accidents or injuries related to the problems. Volkswagen’s recall covers about 420,000 vehicles because the driver’s-side airbag may not deploy properly in a crash. They are the 2010-13 Eos and Jetta, the 2011-14 Golf GTI, the 2010-14 Passat and Tiguan and the 2010-14 CC. Mazda is recalling 2007-14 CX-9 family vans in some states because rust on a front suspension part could cause the loss of steering.

headline: Man Is Released After 34 Years in Prison; Murder Conviction Is Thrown Out
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: The authorities relied on jailhouse informants to link Lewis Fogle to the rape and murder of a 15-year-old, but new DNA evidence has emerged.
lead_paragraph: A man who served 34 years in prison for the rape and murder of a teenager in Pennsylvania has been freed after new DNA analysis led a judge to vacate his murder conviction.

headline: Brazil: Police Suspected in Killings of 18
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Authorities in São Paulo said Friday that they were investigating whether police officers were involved in a series of execution-style killings.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in São Paulo said Friday that they were investigating whether police officers were involved in a series of execution-style killings that left at least 18 people dead. The shootings were carried out by gunmen wearing balaclavas during a span of about three hours on Thursday night in the metropolitan area of São Paulo, Brazil’s largest city, according to video images captured on security cameras and witness accounts. “When we get to the suspects, whether they are police or not, we’ll act quickly to detain them,” Alexandre de Moraes, the top security official in São Paulo State, told reporters. He said investigators were examining whether the killings were reprisals for the recent shooting deaths of two police officers. The killings added to concern among human rights groups over a spate of similar episodes in Brazil that have left dozens dead in other cities, including Manaus and Belém. Police officers killed at least 2,212 people in Brazil in 2013, though the actual number of such killings around the country is thought to be much higher because some states do not report them.

headline: Richard S. Ross, Johns Hopkins Dean and Watergate Walk-On, Dies at 91
abstract: Dr. Ross pushed for broader education for prospective doctors and earlier helped assess Richard M. Nixon’s health during the Watergate investigation.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard S. Ross, an innovative cardiologist and medical school dean who encouraged prospective doctors to pursue broader undergraduate education, and who earlier had the distinction of examining Richard M. Nixon during the Watergate investigation, died on Tuesday at his home in Baltimore. He was 91.

headline: Hedge Funds Shed Shares in Alibaba and Baidu in Second Quarter
abstract: As China’s stock market plummeted, large money managers sold substantial amounts of their stock in the two Chinese technology giants, both of whose shares are down sharply.
lead_paragraph: As China’s stock market took a free fall earlier this summer, big money managers looked to sell shares of two of the largest Chinese tech companies listed in the United States — Alibaba and Baidu — during the second quarter.

headline: ISIS Is Suspected of a Chemical Attack Against Kurds in Syria
abstract: If verified, the use of chemical agents could increase pressure on the Obama administration to intervene in the war more forcefully.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State is suspected of using chemical agents — said by some American officials to be mustard gas — in an attack on Kurdish fighters in northern Syria two weeks ago, United States officials said Friday.

headline: Betting on a Smooth Ride, Investors Flock to Tesla
abstract: The company seems to embody many of a typical Wall Street investor’s desires: disruptive technology, larger-than-life founders and dazzling growth projections.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors has seemingly defied the law of financial gravity on Wall Street ever since the company began proving that electric cars could be sporty, powerful and trendy — not just green.

headline: Connecticut Death Penalty Ruling Stirs Painful Memories of 3 Grisly Killings
abstract: In a suburban town near New Haven, the decision brought back painful memories of a crime that began as a home invasion robbery and ended with the deaths of three members of the Petit family in 2007.
lead_paragraph: CHESHIRE, Conn. — Celine Bonilla was only 11 when she looked out her first-floor window and saw police officers pinning a man down on her front lawn. It was 2007, and that man and an accomplice had just killed two of her friends and their mother, dousing them with gasoline and burning them alive in their home in what became known as one of the grisliest crimes in Connecticut history.

headline: In Familiar Fashion, Giants Stumble in Preseason Opener
abstract: The offense wasn’t great. Neither was the defense. But injuries to the Giants’ youthful secondary are the biggest cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — After an off-season of strategic renovations designed to restore their proud franchise, the Giants opened the preseason in a familiar bumbling manner on Friday.

headline: Most Health Insurance Co-ops Are Losing Money, Federal Audit Finds
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: Most of the insurance co-ops created under the Affordable Care Act enrolled fewer people than they had predicted, according to the inspector general at the health department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most federal insurance cooperatives created under the Affordable Care Act are losing money and could have difficulty repaying millions of dollars in federal loans, an internal government audit has found, prompting the Obama administration to step up supervision of the carriers.

headline: Edward Thomas, Policing Pioneer Who Wore a Burden Stoically, Dies at 95
abstract: The first African-American to build a career with the Houston Police Department could not walk through the front door when he reported for work in 1948. Now Police Headquarters is named for him.
lead_paragraph: When Edward Thomas joined the Houston Police Department in 1948, he could not report for work through the front door.

headline: Jordan Spieth Is an Approachable Star on the Course
abstract: When Spieth plays, fans of both genders and every age group stalk the fairways, calling his name as if they know him like a neighbor.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Walking up a stone stairway halfway through his round on Friday, Jordan Spieth lifted his head to see his father, Shawn, waiting in his path.

headline: ISIS Held Kayla Mueller, U.S. Aid Worker, as Sex Slave Before Fatal Airstrike
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Details of Ms. Mueller’s captivity, including her repeated rape by the leader of the Islamic State, were pieced together by American officials.
lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Somewhere in territory controlled by the Islamic State, Kayla Mueller, an American aid worker, was chained in a room with other female captives. The leader of the Islamic State, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, would regularly enter and lead Ms. Mueller away, her parents say.

headline: Many Sailors Are Not Put Off by Rio de Janeiro’s Polluted Waters
abstract: The Aquece Rio International Sailing Regatta will give top sailors a chance to test Guanabara Bay’s winds and currents, and also any possible health effects from water pollution.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Putting aside concerns over health risks to athletes, about 339 sailors from 52 countries will begin racing here Saturday on the picturesque and polluted Guanabara Bay in the second official test race ahead of next year’s Summer Olympics.

headline: Donald Trump Called to Jury Duty in Manhattan
abstract: Mr. Trump has been summoned to serve in State Supreme Court, and he will report on Monday, an executive with his company said.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, whose bid for the Republican presidential nomination has shaken up the race, will participate in a more common civic activity next week: jury duty.

headline: The Affluent Ante Up for the Presidency
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: A small pool of the richest Americans is making presidential candidates in both parties increasingly dependent on special-interest money.
lead_paragraph: When the Republican candidates for president expounded on what they would do for ordinary Americans in their debate this month, they neglected to mention that more than half the money underpinning their campaigns has been coming from just 130 big-spending families and the businesses they run. These families are determined to influence the election with six- and seven-figure checks.

headline: Opting Out of Standardized Tests Isn’t the Answer
abstract: An ill-conceived boycott could damage educational reform and undermine the Common Core standards.
lead_paragraph: An alarming 200,000, or 20 percent, of the students in grades three through eight in New York State public schools this year refused to take the state’s standardized tests in reading and math that are supposed to measure progress in meeting national academic standards.

headline: Hillary Clinton Jokes About Emails at Fund-Raiser
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton joked on Friday night about the controversy surrounding her email account at the Annual Wing Ding Dinner in Clear Lake, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: — Hillary Rodham Clinton at the Annual Wing Ding Dinner in Clear Lake, Iowa, a Democratic fund-raising event.

headline: Brooklyn Man Accused of Supporting ISIS Pleads Guilty
abstract: Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev, 25, who admitted to plotting to provide material to the Islamic State terrorist group, could face up to 15 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man accused this year of trying to join the Islamic State pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiring to provide material support to the terrorist organization.

headline: Redemption as a Mark of Public Service
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The former politician Oliver Koppell and his so-called bottle bill are forever united.
lead_paragraph: After 33 years in public office in Albany and New York City, Oliver Koppell is finally admitting to himself that the one achievement likely to be featured in his obituary is a humble state law known as the bottle bill. This was a 1982 measure that introduced 5-cent redemptions on empty beverage cans and bottles. It thereby created an unintended subculture of midnight garbage gleaners — down-and-out citizens who quietly pick bottles and cans from curbside refuse collections and cash them in for sustenance.

headline: New Monitoring Program Aims to Keep Youths Out of Rikers Island
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney’s office plans to launch a pilot program in September that will use the GPS in smartphones to track defendants awaiting trial, which may help prevent them from being sent to Rikers Island.
lead_paragraph: Youths accused of felonies will be tracked and monitored with smartphones and electronic bracelets instead of awaiting trial in jail under a new program created by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.

headline: Hiroshi Iwata Ties a Record, Then Takes a Star Turn
abstract: Iwata of Japan posted a 63 on Friday, tying the lowest score for a men’s major.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — After signing his scorecard on Friday, Hiroshi Iwata started walking toward the clubhouse. He looked surprised when he was redirected to the media center. Iwata, who is making his first major start in the United States, did not draw much notice during his opening five-over-par 77, but in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship he came tantalizingly close to making history.

headline: Let Older Americans Keep Working
keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Age, Chronological', 'Retirement', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: Social Security pushes people to take early retirement. It’s perverse.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — EVERY day, 10,000 baby boomers — Americans born from 1946 to 1964 — leave the work force. Most of them have not saved enough for retirement; at least one-fifth have basically no retirement savings. Our economy has a shortage of skilled workers.

headline: The Painful Lessons of the Yonkers Housing Crisis
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Affordable Housing', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Can we finally deliver on the promise of a 30-year-old desegregation battle?
lead_paragraph: “IS that what all the trouble was about? Just that?” a young actor asked me, sweeping her hand toward a row of cream-shingled townhouses on a leafy residential street in Yonkers.

headline: Bank of America Stiffs Shareholders
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: For a while, bank officials accepted a binding resolution forced upon them. Then the board acted on its own, until the shareholders revolted.
lead_paragraph: The year 2009 was rough for the Bank of America and its chairman and chief executive, Ken Lewis. On Jan. 1, the bank closed its $50 billion purchase of Merrill Lynch, a deal Lewis had hastily negotiated the previous September, as the financial world appeared close to collapse.

headline: Iconoclast Stiflers
abstract: Jeff Chen’s childhood penchant for trouble gets him out of a tight constructing corner.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ironically, the very entry that Jeff Chen found hard to fill at 20 Down was one of the last entries that went in for me, and that was only because I am so used to using “click”-type ballpoint pens. I can’t remember the last time I used a pen with a cap, but that’s on me. I might have been more likely to be the back-of-the-head recipient of a flying PEN CAP in school, not that I’m bitter, Mr. Chen. But thanks for being “that guy.”

headline: Test-Refusal Movement’s Success Hampers Analysis of New York State Exam Results
abstract: With 20 percent opting out this year, some statisticians say it is hard to determine whether students improved over all from last year.
lead_paragraph: With 20 percent of eligible students sitting out the New York state standardized tests this year, even some central organizers of the “opt out” movement were surprised at their own success.

headline: Disney Announces Its Coming Slate of Animated Films at D23 Expo

lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — John Lasseter, the Walt Disney Company’s top animation executive, jogged onto a stage at a sprawling Disney fan convention here on Friday and started throwing red meat to the masses.

abstract: The annual Wing Ding Dinner here delivered on its name Friday night as four Democratic presidential candidates tried to excite a crowd of Iowa voters by attacking their Republican counterparts.
lead_paragraph: CLEAR LAKE, Iowa — The annual Wing Ding Dinner here delivered on its name Friday night, with no shortage of thrown elbows and plenty of baked ones, as four Democratic presidential candidates tried to excite a crowd of Iowa voters by attacking their Republican counterparts.

headline: Raised to Be Respectful, Ikemefuna Enemkpali Lets a Dispute Get the Better of Him
abstract: The former Jets linebacker Ikemefuna Enemkpali was embarrassed when Geno Smith failed to attend Enemkpali’s Texas football camp. The perceived slight simmered until it exploded.
lead_paragraph: His parents expected him to work hard, show respect and always be a man of his word, and Ikemefuna Enemkpali tried to uphold their teachings, partly rooted in their Nigerian upbringing, as he rose from high school football star to budding linebacker with the Jets.

headline: Community Seeks Answers After Officers Shoot Trenton Boy
abstract: Residents and civic leaders are upset that they cannot get answers to their questions about the shooting and the investigation.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — It was the start of a violent weekend in this capital city of 85,000.

headline: Carlos Beltran Propels Yankees Past Blue Jays
abstract: Beltran’s pinch-hit three-run home run in the eighth inning gave the Yankees a win over the Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — If, at age 38, Carlos Beltran is not the player he once was, he does not think of himself as anything other than an everyday player. He sticks to the same routine before each game, 25 or so batting practice cuts from each side of the plate, just enough to keep his swing finely tuned but not so many as to wear himself out.

headline: Mets Face a Truer Measuring Stick in the Pirates, and Fall Short
abstract: Despite a stubborn effort, the Mets lost a tense 10-inning game to open the series against Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: At a news conference Friday afternoon, hours before the Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates were to begin a three-game series at Citi Field, Mets Manager Terry Collins was asked to characterize what was at stake. He made no effort to mask or minimize the significance of the weekend.

headline: Showtime’s Spotlight Shifts at South Bend
abstract: Showtime has started production on a 12-week series about the Notre Dame football team.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE THEORY OF EVERYTHING (2014) Eddie Redmayne won an Oscar for his portrayal of the British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, who, as a graduate student at Cambridge intent on fathoming the origins of the universe and locating the beginning of time, learned he had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Felicity Jones, who earned a nomination, plays his first wife, Jane Hawking, whose memoir, “Traveling to Infinity: My Life With Stephen,” is the main source for James Marsh’s portrait of a marriage. “Mr. Redmayne, hunched into a wheelchair, the muscles of his face spread into what looks like a permanent smile, must communicate his character’s feelings almost entirely with his eyes, which are remarkably expressive, conveying Stephen’s mischievous wit as well as his intelligence,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this best picture nominee. “But it is in showing the application of that intelligence that ‘The Theory of Everything’ tumbles into a black hole of biopic banality.” The film’s historical and scientific lapses have been enumerated, but “taking liberties with facts is a prerogative of storytelling,” he said. The greater failing is that Mr. Marsh seems “unable to capture the spirit and energy of scientific inquiry.”

headline: South Korean Leader Marks Anniversary of War’s End With Warnings to North Korea

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea on Saturday urged North Korea to stop what she called military provocations on the border, hours after the North threatened to attack loudspeakers that the South has begun using to blast propaganda messages into North Korea.

headline: In China, Single Women Live by Their Own Rules

lead_paragraph: Single women past a certain age are called “leftover women,” though some are pushing back against such traditional Chinese strictures.

headline: How Video Killed the Family Vacation
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Memory', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Cameras', 'Photography']
abstract: A camera doesn’t have to spoil the summer vacation, but make sure you limit the amount of recording time.
lead_paragraph: Like most parents, I imagine, I keep a running list of things I’ve done well and things I’ve flubbed. Help our children get lots of sleep? Check. Play fun, stimulating games at dinner? Score. Have peaceful, stress-free mornings when everyone goes into the day uplifted and on time? Hardly. Produce handsome scrapbooks with carefully captioned memories? Not a one. (We do have a few boxes labeled “keepsakes.”)

headline: G.O.P. Is Vague on Using Power Abroad
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Finding any consensus on how the Republican candidates would exercise American power differently from President Obama, much less define an alternative foreign policy, gets a bit messy.
lead_paragraph: If the diverse group of candidates competing for the Republican presidential nomination agree on one thing when describing how they would engage with the world if they made it to the White House, it is this: If only the United States were stronger, and more feared, the country would not feel threatened by the Islamic State, manipulated by Iran or challenged by a rising China.

No matter how ragged his game, Tiger Woods, like any headliner worth his marquee billing, can still command a crowd of everyday fans.

headline: Red Cross Offers Workshops in International Law to Hamas
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Red Cross developed its program in conjunction with Islamic scholars. So far this year, it has conducted six sessions for a total of 210 fighters from Hamas’s Izzedine al-Qassam Brigades and two other Gaza armed groups
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — A new training regimen for fighters in Hamas’s armed wing employs slide presentations and a whiteboard rather than Kalashnikov rifles and grenades. The young men wear polo shirts instead of fatigues and black masks. They do not chant anti-Israel slogans, but discuss how the Geneva Conventions governing armed conflict dovetail with Islamic principles.

So tantalizingly close is Europe, the beach is a favorite launching point for the “harragas,” as illegal migrants are known here.

headline: Mom Plans, God Laughs
keywords: ['Summer (Season)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Camps and Camping', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Summer is what happens when you’re busy making other arrangements.
lead_paragraph: EVERY May, I start fantasizing about lazy, long days at the pool. I order a sundress from Athleta and picture myself wearing it while carrying a cheerful melamine platter of snacks and lemonade to my sweaty trio of children in the backyard. In June, I get a pedicure, bring the beach towels up from the basement, and compose a list of day trips we’ll embark on as soon as school gets out. This summer, my dream itinerary featured a spectrum of activities, ranging from rafting and boogie boarding to visiting a science museum and an aquarium. I imagined my family picking blueberries outside a tiny house in the Berkshires.

headline: The Frontier Chocolatier

Countries will have to decide whether to sink, remove or repurpose them.

headline: The V.A.’s Woman Problem
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Women and Girls', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: There are more female veterans than ever before, but they are not getting all of the health care they need.
lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 11, 2001, Desma Brooks was a single mother in her mid-20s who served part-time in the Indiana Army National Guard. Watching the attack on TV, she wondered if she might be called up. She had three kids, so maybe she would be assigned to some kind of support role on the home front. Instead, she served two yearlong deployments, the first to Afghanistan, the second to Iraq. During the second, while driving a military vehicle that was guarding a supply convoy, she hit a roadside bomb. Ms. Brooks returned home with a mild case of traumatic brain injury and a serious case of post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: EnChroma’s Accidental Spectacles Find Niche Among the Colorblind
abstract: An inventor of lenses invented to aid surgeons found that they could also help the colorblind, leading him to start a company that sells glasses.

headline: No Matter How Terry Collins Orders It, Mets’ Offense Is Producing
abstract: Mets Manager Terry Collins has used 100 lineups this season, and three new players have given him more room to maneuver.
lead_paragraph: The trade was met with little fanfare at the time, but on July 24, when the Mets acquired Juan Uribe and Kelly Johnson from the Atlanta Braves, Manager Terry Collins was given two versatile players for a team that had been mostly devoid of offense. But perhaps more important to the way Collins tends to run his team, it allowed him to start tinkering with the lineup in hope of finding the combination that worked best.

headline: When You’re in Charge, Your Whisper May Feel Like a Shout
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Voice and Speech', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Those in positions of authority can be oblivious to the outsize impact that seemingly innocuous statements and behavior can have on others.
lead_paragraph: “Gail, I need to talk with you about something this afternoon. Can you come by my office at 3 p.m.?” I didn’t think much about my seemingly innocuous words, spoken to one of my department’s doctoral students one morning back when I was an assistant professor.

headline: A Last Splash of Summer
abstract: Photographs of the water slide in Foley Square on the last day of Summer Streets.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of the water slide in Foley Square on the last day of Summer Streets.

headline: A Fashion Trailblazer’s Stylish Leap From Touch to Touch Screen
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'E-Commerce', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Social Media']
abstract: In a business that relies on personal interaction with people and clothes, MatchesFashion.com, a high-end retailer in Britain, is making the jump to e-commerce.
lead_paragraph: In a small house in South London, five executives of the high-end fashion retailer MatchesFashion.com sat around an oval conference table, discussing a coming event. From outside, the house looked like any sweet two-story London cottage, with a cobblestone courtyard and small balcony, but inside, it was all white and open plan — more Silicon Valley than Staffordshire.

headline: Puzzling Through My Fiction
abstract: What I learned about writing from doing crossword puzzles.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, crossword puzzles were — along with watching Ken Burns movies and eating lox — among the unfathomable pleasures of grown-ups. My grandmother would sit in her den for hours, the puzzle in her lap, looking blankly around the room as if she had just read a piece of news whose enormity she could scarcely comprehend. Other adults would periodically drift by to offer their condolences (“A nine-letter religious figure, hmm…”) and I would stare from the rug in disbelieving boredom.

headline: Now With the Mets, It’s All Come Into Focus for Tyler Clippard
abstract: When the Mets acquired the reliever days before the trade deadline last month, one of his first orders of business was getting a new pair of glasses, with frames colored Mets blue.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Clippard cannot remember the exact moment when he decided to see the eye doctor. He might have been standing on a mound in Columbus, Ohio, squinting at the sign in the shadows between the catcher’s legs. That happened often during the summer of 2008. Clippard also squinted when he was in the clubhouse, or looking at the television. His teammates teased him endlessly.

headline: After Protests for Racial Justice, Activists Ask: What Next?

headline: The Greek Debt Deal’s Missing Piece
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The latest bailout agreement between Greece and its European creditors will go forward without cash from one crucial lender: the International Monetary Fund.

headline: California Town, United by Drought, Is Split Over New Water Park
keywords: ['Drought', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Swimming Pools', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: Dublin officials say a $44 million water park won’t use much water, but some say any water is too much, given the restrictions brought on by the drought.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Calif. — On a typical hard-hat tour of a major municipal construction project, city officials extol the venture’s expansiveness and rave about how many citizens will benefit. But this city has taken a different approach to a nearly $44 million recreational complex underway: Officials boast how small it is and how few people are expected to use it.

headline: Yankees Resist Toll of Dog Days, Rebuilding Division Lead Over Toronto
abstract: The Yankees won their second in a row over the Blue Jays as Carlos Beltran and Mark Teixeira each hit solo home runs while Masahiro Tanaka delivered a masterful performance on the mound.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — These can be the miserable days of a baseball season, with the finish line still not quite in sight and the daily grind taking its toll on the body and the mind. They are called the dog days for a reason.

headline: Hillary Clinton Fires Back Against Jeb Bush on Rise of ISIS
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton said that Jeb Bush, in criticizing the Obama administration’s withdrawal of troops from Iraq, had failed to mention his brother’s pledge to withdraw forces by the end of 2011.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – Hillary Rodham Clinton hit back at Jeb Bush on Saturday over his accusation that the Obama administration’s handling of the withdrawal of 10,000 troops in Iraq had facilitated the rise of the Islamic State now sweeping violently through Syria and Iraq.

headline: As N.F.L. Prepares for Longer Extra Points, C.F.L. Offers a Preview

lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Boris Bede, the rookie kicker of the Montreal Alouettes in the Canadian Football League, made league history on June 25 when he launched the first rule-mandated 32-yard extra point.

lead_paragraph: The scene is a hauntingly familiar one: A white police officer stalks an unarmed black man in a dark alley and slams the man’s head into the open door of his patrol car.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Since the late 1990s, some 28,000 North Koreans have fled to South Korea.

lead_paragraph: Jerome G. Miller, who inspired a revolution in America’s juvenile justice system by virtually emptying Massachusetts’s reformatories in the early 1970s, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Woodstock, Va. He was 83.

headline: Susan Newhouse, Who Guided Fresh Air Fund, Dies at 80
abstract: Mrs. Newhouse was the longtime chairwoman of the Fresh Air Fund, which pays for poor children from New York City to go summer camp upstate or to stay with host families in rural and suburban areas.
lead_paragraph: Susan Newhouse, the longtime chairwoman of the Fresh Air Fund, among other philanthropic endeavors, and a fixture of New York high society, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80.

headline: Technical Problem Suspends Flights Along East Coast
abstract: An automation problem at the Federal Aviation Administration’s air traffic control center in Leesburg, Va., affected flights into and out of New York and Washington area airports.
lead_paragraph: A technical glitch at an air traffic control center in Northern Virginia disrupted flights along the East Coast for hours on Saturday, causing far-reaching delays and cancellations, federal regulators and airlines said.

headline: Bernard d’Espagnat, 93, Physicist, Dies; Sought Implications of Quantum Theory
abstract: Dr. d’Espagnat was one of a handful of scientists in the 1960s and ’70s who urged their colleagues to look into the deeper meaning of quantum mechanics.
lead_paragraph: Bernard d’Espagnat, a French physicist and philosopher whose writings explored the philosophical implications of the paradoxical laws that govern the subatomic realm, died on Aug. 1 in Paris. He was 93.

headline: Obama Power Foursome Hits Links Before Vernon Jordan Soiree
abstract: President Obama had some putting success on the first hole as he and his high-profile partners squeezed in a round of golf before a party for Vernon Jordan, a towering political and civil rights figure turning 80.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s golf habit on Martha’s Vineyard is so frequent that locals shrug it off. But there was nothing routine about his Saturday foursome, which included former President Bill Clinton, the civil rights activist Vernon E. Jordan Jr. and Ron Kirk, America’s former trade representative.

headline: Wolves, Resurgent and Protected, Vex Swedish Farmers
keywords: ['Wolves', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: With a wolf population that is resurgent and now protected, Sweden has a conflict that pits farmers and hunters against environmentalists and European officials, who object to culling the animals.
lead_paragraph: OLMHULT, Sweden — Electric fences surround his sheep, two large dogs stand guard and a neighbor monitors the adjacent forest from a security camera.

headline: 40 Migrants Found Dead in Sea Rescue
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: At least 40 migrants died on an overcrowded smuggling boat north of Libya, and about 320 others aboard were saved by the Italian Navy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The crew of an Italian Navy ship that responded to a distress call on Saturday morning from a boat carrying hundreds of migrants discovered the bodies of more than 20 people piled on top of one another in the boat’s hold, Italian officials said. It was another ghastly reminder of the perils faced by migrants crossing the Mediterranean in overcrowded and unsafe vessels.

headline: Disney Bulks Up Theme Parks, as Universal Gains Ground
abstract: After Disney’s aggressive overseas investment — which gave Universal an opening in the United States — Disney announced expensive plans for “Star Wars”-themed expansions at its California and Florida resorts.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The empire is striking back.

headline: Clinton and Trump at the Iowa State Fair
abstract: The presidential candidates Donald J. Trump and Hillary Rodham Clinton speak at the Iowa State Fair.
lead_paragraph: The presidential candidates Donald J. Trump and Hillary Rodham Clinton speak at the Iowa State Fair.

headline: Excess in Iowa: 90°, a Butter Cow and Rides on Donald Trump’s Helicopter
abstract: Presidential candidates flocked to the Iowa State Fair in Des Moines to connect with supporters while partaking in fare like corn dogs and deep-fried nachos.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Iowa — Hillary Rodham Clinton denounced Jeb Bush and discussed the rise of the Islamic State. Bernie Sanders held forth on Social Security. But at the Iowa State Fair, where a life-size butter cow rules and fairgoers devour stick-impaled delicacies, it is the candidacy of Donald J. Trump that perhaps best captures the air of raucous excess.

headline: Jason Day Leads a P.G.A. Championship Round Filled With Zany Shots
abstract: Day was 15 under par for the tournament on Saturday, but dogged contenders were nipping at his heels.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — No sequence exemplified the madcap, can-you-top-this personality of the third round at the P.G.A. Championship as perfectly as Matt Jones’s shot from the blue carpet of a hospitality tent.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.

headline: A 6-Under Round for Phil Mickelson Bolsters His Presidents Cup Bid
abstract: Mickelson’s first subpar round of the week moved him into a tie for 24th place at the P.G.A. Championship, a jump of 37 spots.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Phil Mickelson has never depended on the kindness of Team USA captains, and he does not intend to start now. That is why his six-under 66 in the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday mattered. Mickelson’s first subpar round of the week not only catapulted him up the leaderboard into a tie for 24th from 61st, but also gave him hope that the payoff for all his hard work would come in time for him to make the United States team for the Presidents Cup in South Korea in October.

headline: Three Killed and Eight Injured in Crash on Taconic State Parkway
abstract: A sport utility vehicle careered over an embankment separating the northbound and southbound lanes and went into oncoming traffic, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed in a four-car collision on the Taconic State Parkway in Westchester County on Saturday when a sport utility vehicle careered over an embankment separating the northbound and southbound lanes and went into oncoming traffic, the police said.

headline: Jordan Spieth Studies a Legend and Chases a Nearly Grand Finale
abstract: Spieth developed his game in the image of Ben Hogan, who is considered the consummate golfer. With a win at the P.G.A. Championship, Spieth would become the third player, after Hogan and Tiger Woods, to win three majors in the same calendar year.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — As he approached his teenage years, Jordan Spieth decided to give up baseball and get serious about golf. Around that time, he entered a junior event in his native Texas that was named after Ben Hogan.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Income Inequality', 'Poverty', 'Homeless Persons', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Income']

headline: Julian Bond, Charismatic Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Bond was also a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a former chairman of the N.A.A.C.P.
lead_paragraph: Julian Bond, a charismatic figure of the 1960s civil rights movement, a lightning rod of the anti-Vietnam War campaign and a lifelong champion of equal rights, notably as chairman of the N.A.A.C.P., died on Saturday night in Fort Walton Beach, Fla. He was 75.

headline: If She Can Make It There (Europe) She’ll Make It Anywhere (College). Right?
abstract: It may sound as though I was so cool with my daughter’s backpacking trip that I dropped her off with a hug and a wave. I wasn’t, but maybe I should have been.
lead_paragraph: In a matter of days, I’ll send my oldest to college 1,700 miles away from home. I may not be totally ready for that, but I know without a doubt that she is.

headline: Amid Perilous Mediterranean Crossings, Migrants Find a Relatively Easy Path to Greece
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Smuggling']
abstract: Compared with other routes for refugees crossing the Mediterranean, the journey from Bodrum to Kos is remarkably organized and unfettered.
lead_paragraph: BODRUM, Turkey — As darkness falls and the last of the shorefront cafes in Bodrum clear their tables for the night, dozens of migrants pour out of a waiting bus. In the gloam, they charge for the sea, dragging a large rubber dinghy.

headline: Exclusion of Blacks From Juries Raises Renewed Scrutiny
abstract: A study in Louisiana has found that prosecutors used peremptory challenges three times as often to strike black potential jurors as others during the last decade.
lead_paragraph: SHREVEPORT, La. — Here are some reasons prosecutors have offered for excluding blacks from juries: They were young or old, single or divorced, religious or not, failed to make eye contact, lived in a poor part of town, had served in the military, had a hyphenated last name, displayed bad posture, were sullen, disrespectful or talkative, had long hair, wore a beard.

headline: Hamid Gul, 78, Dies; Backed Militants in Leading Pakistan Spy Agency
abstract: Mr. Gul, a three-star general, was deeply involved in the country’s policy toward neighboring Afghanistan during the Soviet withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Hamid Gul, an influential and contentious three-star general who served as the head of Inter-Services Intelligence, Pakistan’s spy agency, from 1987 to 1989 and was deeply involved in the country’s policy toward neighboring Afghanistan when Soviet troops were withdrawing, died on Saturday in Muree, a hill station near Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan. He was 78.

headline: Provincial Minister in Pakistan Is Killed in Suicide Bombing
abstract: Shuja Khanzada, the home minister of Punjab Province, was killed along with at least 10 others in a bomb attack during a political meeting.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A senior provincial minister in Pakistan who was at the forefront of the country’s fight against militants and banned sectarian groups was killed in a suicide bomb attack on Sunday, officials said. At least 10 other people were also said to have been killed in the bombing, and several were reported wounded.

headline: Indonesian Plane Carrying 54 Is Declared Missing in Papua
abstract: The commercial airliner was carrying 54 people when it vanished on Sunday amid bad weather in the eastern region of Papua, an official said.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Rescue teams were searching Monday for the wreckage of an Indonesian commercial aircraft carrying 54 people that was believed to have crashed on Sunday amid inclement weather in the eastern region of Papua.

headline: 1915: M. Venizelos Scores Triumph in Greek Chamber Election
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Greek Chamber elects a new president in 1915.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek Chamber met at Athens yesterday for the first time after the elections, and M. Zavitsanos, the Venizelist candidate, was elected President of the Chamber by a clear majority of 58 votes. The Chamber was opened with the customary ceremonial. M. Venizelos will be summoned by King Constantine to-morrow. So soon as he has made known his programme, the King will give him his decision.

headline: Champion of Gardens in New York Savors a Lush Victory Lap
abstract: Betsy Pinover Schiff, a photographer who has long believed in adding more plant life to New York’s streetscape, says the city is becoming so green that she hardly recognizes some blocks.
