abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) SHOW ME A HERO Nick Wasicsko (Oscar Isaac, above, with Carla Quevedo), a young Yonkers mayor, tries to get the city to abide by a federal judge’s desegregation order, despite savage opposition — and destroys his future in the process — in David Simon’s mini-series, based on a nonfiction book by Lisa Belkin, a former reporter for The New York Times. The cast includes Alfred Molina as a machine politician, Bob Balaban as the judge, and Terry Kinney, Clarke Peters and Catherine Keener. “What Mr. Simon and his ‘Wire’ collaborator William F. Zorzi have written, and Paul Haggis (‘Crash’) has directed, is many things: meticulously and cleverly assembled, wonderfully coherent, often moving and funny, painstaking in its evocation of a midsize, tired city in the late 1980s and early ’90s,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “In its later episodes, as the first black and Latino residents move into their new homes in formerly all-white neighborhoods of east Yonkers, it has a real (if modest) emotional punch. But, ultimately, it’s a show to be admired, not loved.”

headline: ‘Hannibal’ Recap: Caught Between Two Gods
abstract: We finally see what it looks like when Hannibal turns vengeful.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 11: “…And the Beast from the Sea”

headline: One Dead in Crash of Small Plane on Long Island
abstract: Debris from the accident scattered across the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road, disrupting commuter service, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and another was injured on Sunday when a small plane crashed on Long Island, leaving debris scattered across the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road near Hicksville and disrupting commuter service throughout the day, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Straight Outta Compton’ Tops Box Office
abstract: The N.W.A. biopic, backed by a sophisticated marketing campaign, touched a cultural nerve over the weekend, taking in $56.1 million at the domestic box office, an astounding total for an R-rated drama.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The N.W.A. biopic “Straight Outta Compton,” backed by a sophisticated marketing campaign, touched a cultural nerve over the weekend, taking in $56.1 million at the domestic box office, an astounding total for an R-rated drama.

headline: Scenes From the Iowa State Fair
abstract: Iowans meet and greet the presidential candidates, eat hot dogs and get helicopter rides in Des Moines.
lead_paragraph: Iowans meet and greet the presidential candidates, eat hot dogs and get helicopter rides in Des Moines.

headline: 1965: U.S. Drops Effort to make Russia Pay UN Debts
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The United States permits the U.N. General Assembly to resume operations without a confrontation over Soviet voting rights in 1965.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — The United States today said it would bow to the will of the majority and permit the UN General Assembly to resume normal operations without a confrontation over Soviet voting rights. U.S. Ambassador Arthur J. Goldberg, in his first UN speech, told the 33-nation Committee on Peace-Keeping Operations that the United States had regretfully concluded, ‘‘on ample evidence, that at this stage in the history of the United Nations, the General Assembly is not prepared to carry out the relevant provisions of the Charter in the context of the present situation.

headline: Obama Administration Warns Beijing About Covert Agents Operating in U.S.
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Fugitives', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The Obama administration has warned Beijing about the presence of Chinese government agents operating secretly in the United States to pressure prominent expatriates to return home immediately, according to American officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has delivered a warning to Beijing about the presence of Chinese government agents operating secretly in the United States to pressure prominent expatriates — some wanted in China on charges of corruption — to return home immediately, according to American officials.

headline: Donald Trump Releases Plan to Combat Illegal Immigration
abstract: A position paper that appeared on Donald J. Trump’s website centered on three principles: a wall on the Mexican border, law enforcement and economic improvement.
lead_paragraph: After staking his early campaign on caustic and contentious remarks about undocumented immigrants, Donald J. Trump on Sunday outlined his plan to fix the country’s immigration system and deal with people who are in the country illegally.

headline: Yankees Fall to Blue Jays, Tightening A.L. East Race Again
abstract: The game, like the first two in the series, turned on the finest of margins, with a fly ball that Carlos Beltran lost in the sun paving the way for Toronto’s three-run third inning.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman walked out on a ledge near the top of CN Tower late Saturday afternoon, tethered only by a harness, which was stronger than his nerves.

headline: Review: Lars Vogt Presents Late-Career Beethoven and Schubert at Mostly Mozart
abstract: Mr. Vogt interpreted these composers and Cristian Macelaru conducted in a concert on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: The word “muscular” often came to mind while listening to the German pianist Lars Vogt perform Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 4 at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening. Mr. Vogt balanced a powerful touch that stopped just short of harsh in forte passages, particularly in the piano’s upper register, with a limpid delicacy, control and poise that proved striking in intimate sections.

headline: Review: Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance, a Showcase of Dizzying Movement
abstract: This performance, part of the Battery Dance Festival in Lower Manhattan, included five genres of Indian dance from around that country.
lead_paragraph: Now that the weeklong Battery Dance Festival — an August perennial — has settled on a stage in Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park, it has the best backdrop in New York. The audience sees, behind the dancers, the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. Sailboats, cruise boats and yachts pass. Airplanes pass silently above. The drawback is that audience members, at 6:30 p.m., have the early-evening sun in their eyes. Baseball caps or dark sunglasses are advised.

headline: An Ex-Player at the Center of the N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Dispute
abstract: The name of Shawn Wooden, a former Dolphin and an important advocate of the deal, will most likely be invoked again Monday, when a dozen objections are expected to be filed in court.
lead_paragraph: MIRAMAR, Fla. — During his nine years in the N.F.L., Shawn Wooden was a steady, if unspectacular, presence on the field. Selected in the sixth round of the 1996 draft by the Miami Dolphins, he never made it to the Super Bowl, and in all likelihood, he will never be elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

headline: Review: Emery LeCrone Dance and Amy Seiwert’s Imagery Balance Elements
abstract: Emery LeCrone Dance and the San Francisco troupe Amy Seiwert’s Imagery closed out this two-week event at the Joyce that largely highlighted female choreographers.
lead_paragraph: It’s not news that female choreographers are underrepresented within major ballet companies. Take the coming season at New York City Ballet, which includes 58 works, among them seven new commissions, and not one by a woman. In the midst of this landscape, the emphasis on female choreographers at the Joyce Theater’s recent Ballet Festival — where four out of the six engagements were produced and/or choreographed by women — was probably not incidental, an effort to counter that imbalance. And it made for a nice change of pace.

headline: New Dr. Dre Album Serves as a Test for Apple Music
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: “Compton: A Soundtrack” had 25 million streams worldwide in its first week on Apple’s new service, but is expected to open in second place in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Apple introduced its new streaming service, Apple Music, at the end of June, one of the big questions hanging over it was whether it could compete with outlets like Spotify to deliver blockbuster results for big new albums.

headline: Review: Lynn Nottage’s ‘Sweat’ Examines Lives Unraveling by Industry’s Demise
abstract: Lynn Nottage’s new drama, produced at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, examines two generations of factory workers and the decline of industry in the United States.
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ore. — “Sweat,” the title of Lynn Nottage’s scorching new play, refers to the hard labor that its characters have put in for decades, only to find their modest livelihoods threatened by the evaporation of manufacturing jobs in America. But members of the audience may find themselves getting a little moist with anxiety as this extraordinarily moving drama hurtles toward its conclusion with the awful inevitability of Greek tragedy.

headline: On China’s Economy
abstract: Is it time to panic?
lead_paragraph: Is it time to panic?

headline: Janelle Monáe, and Other Wondaland Artists, Step Back in Time at the Highline Ballroom
abstract: A collection of the label’s artists, featured on the compilation “Wondaland Presents: The Eephus,” made a statement of aesthetic protest as well a political protest.
lead_paragraph: Janelle Monáe is on her third, maybe fourth life, a striking fact given that she’s been an avowed futurist from the very start. For almost a decade, she’s been treating R&B and funk as technologies badly in need of updating, planning for their cyborg future and waiting for everyone else to catch up.

headline: Lucia Berlin’s Roving, Rowdy Life Is Reflected in a Book of Her Stories
abstract: “A Manual for Cleaning Women” collects 43 stories by Ms. Berlin, who died a little over a decade ago and whose darkly wry work has remained unknown to many.
lead_paragraph: “In order to write about life, first you must live it.” That’s often attributed to Hemingway, and he would have applauded Lucia Berlin, who made fiction from her life and had a surplus of raw material. Born in Alaska in 1936 to a father who was a mining engineer, Ms. Berlin lived all over the American West and in Chile, New York City and Mexico. She survived childhood abuse and adult alcoholism, an addiction that sent her, in her words, to “jails, hospitals, psych wards.” She hung out with poets and musicians (marrying two jazz players). By her early 30s, she had been divorced three times and had four sons. She worked as a house cleaner, a substitute teacher and a hospital clerk. She put much of her roving, rowdy life onto the page in vivid stories that garnered the respect of a modest audience and now could be on the verge of making her posthumously famous.

headline: Review: In Susan Barker’s ‘The Incarnations,’ Lives of Despair (Past and Present) in China
abstract: Ms. Barker’s betrayal-filled third novel is a 1,500-year gallop through the history of an unruly nation whose only constant, it seems, has been an inability to come to grips with its past.
lead_paragraph: Trying to spruce up its public image before the 2008 Summer Olympics, China embarked on a program of enforced self-improvement in which citizens were meant to change their ways on the spot. No more spitting; no more queue-jumping. No more risible translation of signs, either: In one fell swoop, the Dongda Anus Hospital, a much-photographed Beijing tourist attraction, became the Dongda Proctology Hospital.

headline: Catch Charlie Barnett and Other Rising Stand-Up Stars Who Never Hit the Top
abstract: A very informal survey asking comedians for their favorite comics who never received their due yields a host of underrated names.
lead_paragraph: I was walking through Central Park last year when I came across a comic on a bench selling jokes for a dollar. After I bought a punch line, we started talking comedy. “My dream,” he said, “is to be like Charlie Barnett.”

headline: Marc Quinn’s ‘The Toxic Sublime’ Shows a Provocateur and Social Observer
abstract: Marc Quinn’s art has always been daring, and his latest London exhibition is an example of how that audacity has taken different forms throughout his career.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Marc Quinn led the way through his East London studio late last month, past a marble sculpture of a fetus, a photorealist painting of raw meat and a bronze statue of Kate Moss in a yoga position.

headline: Review: ‘Detectorists’ on BBC and Acorntv Hope to Unearth a Fortune
abstract: Toby Jones and Mackenzie Crook play eccentrics hoping metal detectors will lead them to buried treasure.
lead_paragraph: “Detectorists,” a 2014 BBC sitcom, is part of a long tradition of British comedies about daft eccentrics. But instead of going in the direction of noisy farce, it’s dreamy and steeped in melancholy, with a hint of the charm of the Ealing films and the great Scottish comedies of Bill Forsyth.

headline: Bits of Textspeak
abstract: Andrea Carla Michaels celebrates a milestone, and her puzzle makes us smile.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — There is nothing better than completing a task that makes you smile. It’s even better when you get a reminder from the task at hand to smile or, better yet, laugh. And on a Monday, yet.

headline: A Concert Honoring Abe Lebewohl
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A participant in a klezmer concert for Abe Lebewohl, the slain owner of the Second Avenue Deli, noted the irony of his park’s being on Peter Stuyvesant’s old farm.
lead_paragraph: Metropolitan Diary:

headline: With High-Profile Help, Obama Plots Life After Presidency
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s preparations for an estimated $1 billion effort, including a library and global foundation, are showing the same fierce discipline he displayed in winning office.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The dinner in the private upstairs dining room of the White House went so late that Reid Hoffman, the LinkedIn billionaire, finally suggested around midnight that President Obama might like to go to bed.

headline: Ambiguity Shrouds the Case of a Missing Israeli of Ethiopian Descent
abstract: Almost a year after the disappearance of 29-year-old Avera Mengistu, his family remains mostly in the dark about his whereabouts or condition.
lead_paragraph: ASHKELON, Israel — In the grainy security camera footage, Avera Mengistu walks along the beach on the Israeli side of the border, marked by a wall and netting. Then, suddenly, he appears on the other side, in Gaza.

headline: Merkel Seeks to Head Off Opposition to Greek Bailout
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel said she expected the I.M.F. to participate in the new bailout as Germany’s Parliament prepared to vote on the package this week.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Sunday that she expected the International Monetary Fund to take part in the new bailout for Greece, as she sought to head off opposition to the aid package in the German Parliament.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 17
keywords: ['Municipal Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Collision of 2 Small Planes Near a San Diego Airport Kills 4
abstract: A single-engine Cessna 12 and a twin-engine Sabreliner that were flying to Brown Field Municipal Airport broke into pieces, leaving no survivors, an official said.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed on Sunday when two small airplanes collided in flight near an airport in San Diego, according to the authorities.

headline: Jason Day Wins P.G.A. Championship in a Record-Shattering Breakthrough
abstract: After many disappointments, Day, a 27-year-old Australian, captured his first major title, finishing at 20 under par and holding off Jordan Spieth at Whistling Straits.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — After a 314-yard drive on the par-5 16th hole at Whistling Straits, Jason Day had a decision to make. Ahead by three strokes in his bid to win his first major championship, Day could lay up with his next shot, which was the smart but conservative move, or go for the green as if he had nothing to lose.

headline: Bobby Parnell and Mets Stumble as Pirates Complete Sweep
abstract: Parnell, a Mets reliever, took the loss in two of the Mets’ three defeats by the Pirates.
lead_paragraph: The Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates, one of the best teams in baseball, were tied, 1-1, at Citi Field on Sunday when Pirates pinch-hitter Michael Morse hit a comebacker to the mound in the seventh inning. The Pirates had a runner on first with no outs. It was a routine play, the kind winning teams execute with ease.

headline: After Delicate Negotiations, U.S. Says It Will Pull Patriot Missiles From Turkey
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The decision came as the risk of Syrian Army missile attacks seemed to have eased and as concerns about Iran and North Korea demanded that the antimissile systems be made available for other missions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States said Sunday that it would withdraw two Patriot missile-defense batteries from southern Turkey this fall, a sign that the Pentagon believes the risk of Syrian Army missile attacks has eased since the Patriots were deployed in 2013. Officials said the antimissile systems would be needed elsewhere to defend against threats from Iran and North Korea.

headline: Racial Wealth Gap Persists Despite Degree, Study Says
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Income Inequality', 'Student Loans', 'Discrimination', 'Research', 'Minorities', 'Asian-Americans']
abstract: New research shakes the long-held belief that higher education clears a path to financial equality for blacks and Hispanics, and contends that the problem is deeply rooted and persistent.
lead_paragraph: Even with tuition shooting up, the payoff from a college degree remains strong, lifting lifelong earnings and protecting many graduates like a Teflon coating against the worst effects of economic downturns.

headline: Q. and A.: Qiu Xiaolong on His Novel ‘Shanghai Redemption’
abstract: In Qiu Xiaolong’s new novel, “Shanghai Redemption,” Inspector Chen Cao finds himself once again enmeshed in political struggles partly influenced by the real-life downfall of Bo Xilai, the party chief of Chongqing.
lead_paragraph: In Qiu Xiaolong’s new novel, “Shanghai Redemption,” Inspector Chen Cao of the Shanghai police finds himself once again enmeshed in elite political struggles inside the Chinese Communist Party, but it is now harder than ever for him to navigate the conflicts. This latest installment in the Inspector Chen series was published in March in France, and an English-language edition is set for release in the United States in September. In an interview, Mr. Qiu, a Shanghai native who now lives in St. Louis, discussed how the 2012 downfall of Bo Xilai, the ambitious party chief of Chongqing and Politburo member, influenced the novel. Mr. Bo’s purge from the party and criminal trial on corruption charges were precipitated by the flight of his former police chief, Wang Lijun, to the United States Consulate in Chengdu, where Mr. Wang told American officials that Mr. Bo’s wife, Gu Kailai, had killed a British businessman with poison.

headline: ‘The Mindy Project’ Is Revived on Hulu; CBS News Makes News
abstract: Highlights from the final week of the Television Critics Association media tour include a move for the former Fox program to a streaming service, and a move to put journalists “on the ground” at political conventions.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The two-plus weeks of the Television Critics Association’s media tour, which wrapped up late last week, gives networks, cable channels and streaming services an opportunity to preview coming shows and to tackle questions about the uncertain future of television.

headline: Finding Their Rhythm After Improvising
abstract: A jazz musician wanted someone who could tolerate his unpredictable schedule, and a dancer wanted someone who would not waste her time.
lead_paragraph: Mike McGinnis thought she must be a pumped-up arts investor when he saw her in the audience. He was playing woodwinds at a promotional event for “Fine and Dandy,” a musical he arranged. And there, amid a sea of “old white rich guys,” was a woman in a red sleeveless dress, with spiky hair and undeniably pronounced biceps.

headline: Rivalry Is Renewed for Soccer Final in West Bank as Restrictions Are Eased
abstract: A soccer club from Gaza was allowed to enter the West Bank for the Palestine Cup final, the first time the competition between the best teams from Gaza and the West Bank had been played in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: HEBRON, West Bank — As a member of the Palestinian national soccer team, Alaa Attiyah has traveled the world, playing in more than 20 countries, including Nepal, China, Iran and Norway.

headline: Without Release of Video, Police Shooting of White Driver Gets Less Publicity
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Supporters of Zachary Hammond, a 19-year-old who was killed last month by the Seneca, S.C., police, say he would have received more attention had he been black. But race was only one factor.
lead_paragraph: To Zachary Hammond’s supporters, the shooting death of the 19-year-old man was yet another example of questionable police behavior that has shaken communities around the country.

headline: Protests Across Brazil Raise Pressure on President Dilma Rousseff
abstract: Though protests seemed to lack the urgency of earlier demonstrations, tens of thousands returned to the streets of cities across Brazil to express their displeasure with President Dilma Rousseff.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Tens of thousands of protesters returned to the streets of cities across Brazil on Sunday to express their ire against President Dilma Rousseff, reflecting a low ebb for her as she grapples with a colossal bribery scandal and a declining economy.

headline: Order to Clean Towers Strains Crews Amid Legionnaires’ Outbreak in Bronx
abstract: The health department has ordered every building in New York City with a cooling tower to evaluate and disinfect it, prompting frustration and confusion.
lead_paragraph: When the bacteria that cause Legionnaires’ disease were discovered last week in a cooling tower above a South Bronx deli, New York City officials decided the cleanup could not wait.

headline: En Garde Arts To Produce Theater Festival
abstract: En Garde Arts brings a festival, Big Outdoor Site Specific Stuff, to Hudson River Park in October.
lead_paragraph: The theater company En Garde Arts will celebrate 30 years of immersive theater with a new festival called BOSSS (“Big Outdoor Site Specific Stuff”), coming to New York Oct. 2 to 4. The festival will present 11 new works by emerging artists, including Barbara Cassidy and Sam Alper.

headline: Colorado Spill Heightens Debate Over Future of Old Mines
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Mines and Mining', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Superfund', 'Environment']
abstract: The accident at the Gold King Mine also served as a reminder, some critics say, that the toxic demise could be repeated at any of thousands of abandoned mines around the country.
lead_paragraph: SILVERTON, Colo. — When the mine here opened in the early 1890s amid a frenzy of frontier gold exploration, its founders gave it a lofty name: the Gold King, reflecting their great hopes for finding riches in its depths. Over the next decade, the Gold King went on to become one of the most productive mines in Colorado’s San Juan County, with three shifts of men working 24 hours a day in its dark corridors.

headline: Comeback Hopes Dim for Mahinda Rajapaksa, Sri Lanka’s Ex-President
abstract: Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was voted out of office in January, is trying to become prime minister, but opponents are determined to bury his political hopes once and for all.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — At his final campaign rally on Friday, former President Mahinda Rajapaksa did his best to project supreme confidence that he would be swept back into power when Sri Lankans elect a new Parliament on Monday. “Let’s unite and win for the sake of our motherland,” he told thousands of supporters, his voice deepening into a thunderous growl.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Team, Recently Crowned Champion, Visits a Football Palace
abstract: In Pittsburgh, a city known for its football legends and a football fanaticism that bridges generations, it was a day for a different kind of football.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — From the looks of the traffic around Heinz Field on Sunday afternoon, it seemed like a typical game day.

headline: Japan Says Its Economy Contracted in Second Quarter
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Recession and Depression', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: The size of the contraction was roughly in line with the expectations of private-sector economists, but the slowdown is nonetheless a setback for the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Burdened by weaker consumer spending and exports, Japan’s economy contracted in the second quarter, government data showed on Monday, the first such setback since a short but painful recession last year.

headline: Air Traffic Control Problem Delays Hundreds of U.S. Flights
abstract: A tracking service reported delays continued into Sunday, the day after a problem at an air traffic control center in Virginia was fixed.
lead_paragraph: A technical problem at an air traffic control center near Washington caused hundreds of flight delays and cancellations at airports on the East Coast over the weekend, federal air safety regulators said.

headline: In the End, Jordan Spieth Is Resilient, but Also Resigned
abstract: Winning two major championships before his 22nd birthday had made anything seem possible. Spieth wanted, perhaps expected, more.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — On the par-5 11th hole in the final round of the 2015 P.G.A. Championship, Jordan Spieth walked to his tee shot thinking he might be approaching a pivotal moment in his quest to win three major championships in one year.

headline: Where Clicks Reign, Audience Is King
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As more readers move toward online social networks, and as publishers desperately seek scale to bring in revenue, many have deplored a race toward repetitive journalism.
lead_paragraph: Early last month, a lion known as Cecil was killed by a hunter near Hwange National Park in Zimbabwe.

headline: Relative of Morgan Freeman Is Stabbed to Death in Manhattan
abstract: E’Dena Hines, 33, who had a role in one of Mr. Freeman’s recent movies, was found in the street outside her Washington Heights apartment, the police said.
lead_paragraph: An actress related by marriage to Morgan Freeman died on Sunday after she was found with multiple stab wounds in the street outside her Washington Heights apartment, the police said.

headline: For Mets, an Inferior Record, and an Enviable Position
abstract: The Pirates stayed hot, completing the first season sweep of the Mets in their history, but the Mets’ path to the playoffs is clearer.
lead_paragraph: You could not blame the Pittsburgh Pirates if they flew home Sunday night cursing their geography. The Pirates had completed the first season sweep of the Mets in their history, yet if the playoffs began now, Pittsburgh would host a wild-card game while the Mets would advance directly to a best-of-five series. Frustrating?

headline: Luis Severino Is as Hard to Read as His Fastball Is to Hit
abstract: On Sunday, Severino once again delivered a performance beyond his years, with an easy demeanor and a casual confidence.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Somewhere beneath the easy demeanor and the casual confidence he carries to the pitcher’s mound, there must be a Luis Severino with sweaty palms, knocking knees and jittery nerves.

headline: In St. Francis’ Hometown, a New Kind of Pilgrim
abstract: New Age retreats that offer yoga, meditation and spa treatments are cropping up in Assisi, Italy, a spot popular with Catholic pilgrims for centuries.
lead_paragraph: ASSISI, Italy — For centuries, pilgrims have trekked to Assisi to walk the same steep and narrow lanes on which a rag-cloaked radical monk named Francis preached an antimaterialistic message 800 years ago, rocking the medieval Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Retailer Earnings, Fed Minutes and Greek Debt
abstract: This week, some of the nation's biggest retailers report earnings, the Federal Reserve will publish an account of its July meeting, and Greece must make a critical repayment.
lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s biggest retailers report earnings this week, including Walmart and Home Depot, which announce second-quarter results on Tuesday, and Target, whose announcement is on Wednesday. Walmart has invested heavily in its stores, as well as in its online business and work force, as part of a bid to overcome a prolonged decline in sales and market share. Still, analysts do not expect big results soon. On the other hand, Home Depot, the home improvement retailer, has been riding a recovery in the housing market to sales gains, and analysts expect it to book a solid quarter. Also reporting this week are TJX on Tuesday; Staples, Lowe’s and American Eagle Outfitters on Wednesday; and Foot Locker on Friday. —Hiroko Tabuchi

headline: ‘Masters of Sex’ Recap: Do You Believe in the Romance That Is Bill and Virginia?
abstract: The main characters seem to have changed — in a not-so believable way.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 6: “Two Scents”

headline: Protesters Gather in Rio de Janeiro
abstract: Thousands took to the streets to join a day of anti-government protests all over Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Thousands took to the streets to join a day of anti-government protests all over Brazil.

headline: National Sawdust Announces Inaugural Season Lineup
abstract: The inaugural season of National Sawdust will include Nico Muhly, John Zorn and Alicia Hall Moran.
lead_paragraph: National Sawdust, a brand new music center in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, led by the composer Paola Prestini, announced its inaugural season of programming on Monday. The opening night concert on Oct. 1 will include appearances by Nico Muhly, Theo Bleckmann, and Bryce Dessner.

headline: Chloë Grace Moretz’s Snake-Themed Gucci Look

headline: A Countryside Outpost That Preserves the Vintage Charm of Sweden
abstract: Kagan, in the small town of Hörby, is a throwback to the country's rustic, eccentric history.
lead_paragraph: In the mossy birch forests of Sweden’s rural south, raspberries and currants sprout wild from the bramble; near the sea, vacationers fill the modest plank-wood houses that dot the countryside. The old timber-frame cottages, some with their original thatched roofs intact, are by and large painted a warm brick Falu red, a color that seems designed to accentuate the greens of Scandinavian nature.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) TASHI AND THE MONK (2015) In 2006, Lobsang Phuntsok, a Buddhist monk who trained under the Dalai Lama, felt called to leave his life as a spiritual teacher in the United States and return to his homeland with the mission of rescuing unwanted children. This documentary, directed by Andrew Hinton and Johnny Burke, follows Mr. Phuntsok into the foothills of the Indian Himalayas, where he has created a community called Jhamtse Gatsal (translation: “the garden of love and compassion”) that offers a home and education to 85 children who have been orphaned or abandoned — among them Tashi, above, a 5-year-old girl with an alcoholic father who, at the time of filming, was the newest and youngest resident, and perhaps the most challenging.

headline: Mario Vargas Llosa’s ‘Notes on the Death of Culture’
abstract: A Nobel laureate weighs in on the diffusion of culture and the loss of common referents.
lead_paragraph: I call it the newspaper problem: About a decade ago I wrote an essay on contemporary poetry for a newspaper that will remain nameless, and had the occasion to quote a line by “Eliot.” The editor sent back many changes, the most telling of which was that the quotation was now attributed to “the English poet T.S. Eliot.” Vaguely piqued, I asked what the editor was trying to clarify: Was he afraid readers wouldn’t realize the quotation came from a poem? Or was he afraid readers might confuse the Eliot who wrote it with, say, George Eliot, the pseudonymous author of “Middlemarch”? Anyway, I noted that the English qualifier was misleading: Though T.S. Eliot had taken British citizenship, he had been born in America. The editor, then, sent on another suggestion: “the American-born English poet T.S. Eliot.” I, having lost all the patience I had as a 24-year-old, replied by modifying that tag to: “the American-born, British-­citizen English-language poet, essayist, dramatist, teacher, publisher and bank teller Thomas Stearns Eliot (1888-1965),” after which the editor finally got the point and canceled the assignment.

headline: ‘NeuroTribes,’ by Steve Silberman
abstract: A science journalist’s reading of medical history suggests that the “autism pandemic” is an optical illusion.
lead_paragraph: The history of science is studded with stories of simultaneous discovery, in which two imaginative souls (or more!) turn out to have been digging tunnels to the same unspoiled destination. The most fabled example is calculus, developed independently in two different countries by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz, but the list stretches back centuries and unfurls right into the present. One can add to it sunspots, evolution, platinum, chloroform . . . and now autism, as the science journalist Steve Silberman informs us, identified separately by Leo Kanner and Hans Asperger. The crucial difference is that Kanner had the fortune to publish his work in Baltimore, while Asperger had the misfortune to publish his in Nazi-controlled Vienna, and this accident of geopolitics lies at the tragic core of Silberman’s ambitious, meticulous and largehearted (if occasionally long-winded) history, “NeuroTribes: The Legacy of Autism and the Future of ­Neurodiversity.”

headline: An Expat in Berlin for 36 Hours
abstract: A writer who appears on the “36 Hours” Travel Channel series talks about why expatriates are streaming into Berlin.
lead_paragraph: While I was backpacking alone through Europe in 2006, people kept telling me to check out Berlin. Though I originally had no intention of moving here, I was immediately enamored of the city: its energy; its fascinating, devastating history; the freedom it seemed to offer.

headline: Ask Well: Washing Off the Pesticides
abstract: A reader asks whether washing fruits and vegetables does the trick in eliminating your exposure.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: John Lansing Named as New Chief of Broadcasting Board of Governors
abstract: Mr. Lansing replaces Andrew Lack as head of the agency that oversees United States government-supported, civilian international news media such as Voice of America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Lansing, a retired cable television executive, was named Monday as the new chief executive of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, the agency that oversees United States government-supported, civilian international news media such as Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.

headline: N.L.R.B. Rejects Northwestern Football Players’ Union Bid
abstract: The ruling was a victory for the college sports establishment and reaffirmed one of the N.C.A.A.’s core principles: that college athletes are primarily students.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board on Monday dismissed a petition by Northwestern football players who were seeking to unionize, effectively denying their claim that they are university employees and should be allowed to collectively bargain. In a unanimous decision that was a clear victory for the college sports establishment, the five-member board declined to exert its jurisdiction in the case and preserved, for now, one of the N.C.A.A.’s core principles: that college athletes are primarily students.

headline: Naoki Inaba’s Area Maze Puzzle
abstract: Can you crack Japan’s latest puzzle sensation?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge is an original suggested by Naoki Inaba, and is the second in a series by this ingenuous and remarkably prolific Japanese puzzle designer. (In case you missed it, check out Predator and Prey.) This week we take on Menseki Meiro, or “Area Maze,” referring to the labyrinthine process involved in finding the target — the area of a rectangle. Area Maze is already a hit in Japan. Will it have the same addictive potential in the United States as it does in Japan? Let’s give it a try. Here’s Mr. Inaba presenting five challenges in ascending difficulty:

headline: Gearing Up for Turner Prize, Art Exhibition Will Roam Scotland
abstract: A traveling exhibition will feature work by Scottish winners of the Turner Prize and nominees.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A roving art exhibition featuring work by Scottish Turner Prize winners and nominees will go on the road this fall in the lead-up to the Dec. 7 announcement of this year’s award winner in Glasgow.

headline: Where to Eat and Shop at the Barlow in Sebastopol
abstract: A fire pit, bocce courts and public lawns invite visitors to linger at a development called the Barlow in Sonoma County.

headline: Marijuana: Uncertain Medicine
abstract: Marijuana’s effects can vary from person to person, and scientists are not quite sure what to make of the common distinction users and growers make between cannabis sativa and cannabis indica.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana’s effects can vary from person to person, and scientists are not quite sure what to make of the common distinction users and growers make between cannabis sativa and cannabis indica.

headline: The Beatles Awaken a New Sensation
abstract: A night of music in 1964 taught me the joy of collective experience and the power of mass seduction.
lead_paragraph: I think I had my first orgasm at a Beatles concert — then again, how would I have known? When you’re preteen, prepubescent and pretty much pre-everything, “I Want to Hold Your Hand” seems the height of erotic ambition. And that was especially true in 1964, before the sexual revolution and the Internet made that kind of ignorance unimaginable.

headline: Stay Focused on Your Own Spending, Not the Other Person’s
abstract: Your goal is to pay attention to your own budget, not that your friend just bought a new car. How others spend has nothing to do with your financial health.
lead_paragraph: The CrossFit Park City gym is right across the parking lot from my office. I used to love going there early in the morning to get my daily dose of intensity and to spend time with other people dedicated to the same thing. But a few years ago, I made a mistake. Instead of staying focused on my goals, I got a little too focused on beating other people, and I injured my shoulder.

headline: Accomable: Lessons From an Inspiring Start-Up
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Disabilities', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: Srin Madipalli and Martyn Sibley, like many entrepreneurs, got the idea for their start-up from their everyday experience, seeing a problem to solve.

lead_paragraph: What’s the best way to connect with our readers? Meet them face-to-face.

headline: Tracy Morgan to Host ‘Saturday Night Live’ in First Performance Since Accident
abstract: He will appear on October 17.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after he was critically injured in an automobile accident, Tracy Morgan will return to host “Saturday Night Live” in his first announced performance since the accident. NBC said on Monday that Mr. Morgan, an alumnus of “Saturday Night Live” and the comedy series “30 Rock,” is scheduled to host “S.N.L.” on Oct. 17 in one of its first new episodes of the fall season. He has been recovering since he was injured in a crash on the New Jersey Turnpike in June 2014, when a luxury van he was riding in was struck from behind by a Walmart tractor-trailer. Mr. Morgan said in an interview on NBC’s “Today” show in June that he hoped to return to comedy when he was able, adding, “When I’m there, you’ll know it. I’ll get back to making you laugh. I promise you.”

headline: Russia Burns Dutch Flowers Amid Netherlands’ Inquiry Into Malaysia Airlines Crash
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A Russian crackdown on Dutch flower imports is seen by some as a response to an investigation into the shooting down of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In recent years, trade relations between Russia and the Netherlands have at times blossomed and at times wilted. This summer they went up in smoke.

headline: Lobbying Fight Over Iran Nuclear Deal Centers on Democrats
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The efforts represent a gritty summertime fight unusual in the annals of foreign policy debates with major implications for President Obama’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From his rented vacation home on Martha’s Vineyard with sweeping views of the Atlantic Ocean, President Obama has been making phone calls to Democratic members of Congress, trying to rally support for the nuclear deal with Iran that faces a vote next month.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch This Week
abstract: That music you hear when you close your eyes is this season’s first true stirrings of the Champions League anthem. The final playoff rounds begin this week, and Andrew Das tells you what to watch.

lead_paragraph: New Jersey Transit riders faced another morning of difficult delays on Monday after a car caught fire inside the Lincoln Tunnel and a train stalled in one of the Hudson River rail tunnels.

headline: 2015 Fantasy Football: Running Back Preview and Rankings
abstract: No matter which running back you think is No. 1, owners drafting in the top six positions would be wise to target one to build their team around.
lead_paragraph: Any fantasy football owner with the No. 1 overall draft pick this season will not have an easy decision, as there is no clear consensus on which player is the safest choice, though based on average draft position, at least most drafters agree that the selection should be a running back.

headline: Chris Christie Assails Donald Trump’s Immigration Plan
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said that walling off the entire southern border with Mexico “doesn’t make any sense,” adding that more patrol agents with better training are needed to improve security.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s immigration plan has been panned by many Democrats as an extreme measure, but some of his Republican rivals also have their doubts.

headline: 1915: U.S. Angered by German Plots
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The United States is furious at German conspirators in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — According to the New York correspondent of the ‘‘Daily Express,’’ the revelations concerning the great German plot in the United States have caused a nation-wide sensation, and the Government is considering whether formal action can be taken against the conspirators. The New York ‘‘World’’ to-day prints a memorandum on a project to obtain possession of all the liquid chlorine in America in order to prevent its exportation to the Allies for the manufacture of asphyxiating gases. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 18, 1915

headline: Facing Money Gap, Hillary Clinton Slowly Warms to ‘Super PAC’ Gifts
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign, with a focus on campaign finance reform, has seemed reluctant to change its tactics even as Republicans draw big donations.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton recently spent four days straight scurrying across the Western United States, mingling for hours at a time with hundreds of Democratic donors from the Rockies to Portland, Ore., from Southern California to the southern tip of Texas, and everywhere seeking the maximum primary campaign contribution allowed by law: $2,700.

headline: Scott Walker Is Heckled in Iowa State Fair Appearance
abstract: Speaking on the Soapbox at the Iowa State Fair, a perch that has drawn candidates of both parties since the fair opened last week, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin was the first to face a significant chorus of opposition.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – They sported Wisconsin cheese hats but the impression that Gov. Scott Walker had brought a home-state cheering section was demolished when catcalls began as soon as he started speaking Monday morning.

headline: A Mouthwash Rinse May Predict Throat Cancer Recurrence
keywords: ['Head and Neck Cancer', 'Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Men and Boys', 'Mouthwash', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases']
abstract: A rinse may be able to predict the recurrence of a kind of throat cancer that is rapidly increasing in heterosexual men, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: A simple mouthwash rinse may be able to predict the dangerous recurrence of a kind of throat cancer that is rapidly increasing in heterosexual men, according to a new study.

headline: Paul Smith’s College Will Get $20 Million, if It Changes Its Name
abstract: The philanthropist Joan Weill has pledged a gift that the college president says is crucial, but the board must agree to change the Adirondack institution’s name to include hers.
lead_paragraph: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y. — To administrators of the financially troubled college here, Joan Weill’s appearance on campus more than 20 years ago may have seemed like the arrival of a fairy godmother.

lead_paragraph: Two men arrange to meet at a cafe by whistling across a valley about 765 yards wide in Kuşköy, Turkey.

headline: David Denson, Gay Minor Leaguer, Has Power but Faces Long Odds
abstract: The 20-year-old slugger, the first openly gay player affiliated with Major League Baseball, struggled with a Class A Brewers affiliate, yet he has shown flashes.
lead_paragraph: Stepping into the batter’s box at Marlins Park in Miami three years ago, David Denson, 17, looked as if he might have a future in the big leagues when he mashed a 515-foot drive off the scoreboard in a home run competition, breaking the distance record by 12 feet.

headline: Sorry I’m Late Again, Boss…
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Commuting', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Railroads', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: With chaotic commuting delays on Monday morning, New Jersey travelers took to Twitter to air their feelings on NJ Transit and Governor Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: Anybody trying to cross the Hudson River by tunnel between New Jersey and New York on Monday morning probably had to rely on a reserve of patience, good humor and an understanding boss.

headline: Hacking Case Raises Question on Securities Fraud
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Insider Trading']
abstract: Stealing corporate information from computers to make trades certainly looks like insider trading, but it can depend on court jurisdiction.
lead_paragraph: The elaborate scheme described by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, which involved breaking into computer servers to obtain confidential information about impending corporate announcements, certainly looks like a classic case of insider trading. The defendants are accused of making millions of dollars in profits by using information to trade profitably.

headline: Batches of Root Beer Generate a Noticeable Buzz
abstract: Root beer with alcohol in stores; cups made of sugar; a pantry for Amy’s Bread; a new sriracha; new flavors of ice cream; a tandoori steakhouse.
lead_paragraph: Hard root beer is flying off the shelves. Not Your Father’s Root Beer, an ale fermented with spices, made by Small Town Brewery in Wauconda, Ill., landed in New York and elsewhere late last month. The taste, like soda fountain root beer with less sweetness, does not hide the gentle kick from 5.9 percent alcohol. Coney Island Brewing, which opened recently, also has a hard root beer. It is 5.8 percent alcohol and a tad sweeter and fizzier than the competition. The flavor is less earthy with more vanilla and coffee in the flavor notes. Coney Island’s main backer is Boston Beer, the parent company of Sam Adams. The root beer is being made at a Boston Beer plant, not in Brooklyn. Now you can turn that root beer float into a nightcap: Not Your Father’s Root Beer, $10.99 for a six-pack at Fairway markets; Coney Island Hard Root Beer, $2.50 a bottle at Malt & Mold, maltandmold.com.

headline: Ayatollah Khamenei Says Talk of U.S. Influences in Iran Is ‘Hollow Fantasy’
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei warned that Iran would remain vigilant in guarding against influences from the United States, a message at odds with other officials.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s highest leader lashed out at the United States on Monday, saying talk that American influences would pour into the country on a wave of positive feelings over the nuclear deal is nothing more than a “hollow fantasy.”

headline: A Woman’s Tweed
abstract: The traditional men’s wear fabric has been nipped and tucked to new feminine proportions.
lead_paragraph: The traditional men’s wear fabric has been nipped and tucked to new feminine proportions.

headline: In Tianjin Blasts, a Heavy Toll for Unsuspecting Firefighters
abstract: At least 39 firefighters were among the 114 people killed by the cataclysmic explosions in the Chinese port city of Tianjin.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The young firefighters, their thin frames puffed up by insulated coveralls, some of them barely old enough to shave, rushed to the scene of a modest warehouse blaze in the port city of Tianjin on Wednesday night with little idea of the danger that awaited them.

headline: South Sudan’s President Lets Deadline for Signing a Peace Deal Pass
abstract: Despite the threat of international sanctions after a deadline on Monday, Salva Kiir did not sign the accord aimed at ending fighting in a devastating civil war.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Bucking the threat of international sanctions, the president of South Sudan, Salva Kiir, refused to sign a peace deal to halt the nation’s civil war on Monday, the deadline for a final accord mediated by African leaders.

headline: Whistled Form of Turkish Is One of a Kind
abstract: Unlike all other spoken languages, a whistled form of Turkish requires that speakers rely as heavily on the right side of their brain as on the left.
lead_paragraph: Unlike all other spoken languages, a whistled form of Turkish requires that speakers rely as heavily on the right side of their brain as on the left.

headline: What Would You Pay for This Meal?

lead_paragraph: How often have you bought something you felt wasn’t worth the money?

lead_paragraph: Katherine Kelly Sorensen and Patrick Daniel Hebert were married Saturday at the Castle Hill Inn in Newport, R.I. Matan Ariel, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the Church of Spiritual Humanism for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Breast-Feeding’s Heart Benefits
abstract: A new study found that breast-feeding may reduce a woman’s risk for cardiovascular disease later in life.
lead_paragraph: Breast-feeding has many benefits. Now a new study found it may reduce a woman’s risk for cardiovascular disease later in life.

headline: Citigroup to Pay $180 Million Over Collapsed Hedge Funds
abstract: The settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission comes more than seven years after the two hedge funds collapsed, saddling investors with billions of dollars in losses.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup has agreed to pay $180 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that the bank concealed problems at two of its now-defunct hedge funds, while taking in additional investments in the months before the financial crisis.

headline: A Chinese Drought Weather Report Written on Cave Walls
abstract: The inscriptions inside Dayu Cave in the Qinling Mountains describe the effects of seven droughts between 1520 and 1920.
lead_paragraph: Writings on the walls of a cave in China record the effects of droughts over the last 500 years, researchers have found.

headline: Neighbors Surprised by New York Attack
abstract: Residents of the Washington Heights area of New York responded with shock to the stabbing death of E’Dena Hines, the granddaughter of the actor Morgan Freeman’s former wife.
lead_paragraph: Residents of the Washington Heights area of New York responded with shock to the stabbing death of E’Dena Hines, the granddaughter of the actor Morgan Freeman’s former wife.

headline: U.S. Budgets Cash to Treat Heroin Abuse in Northeast
keywords: ['Heroin', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Office of National Drug Control Policy announced it will spend $2.5 million to hire coordinators across 15 states to focus on the treatment, rather than the punishment, of addicts.
lead_paragraph: CHILMARK, Mass. — Faced with a surge in heroin abuse in recent years, especially in the Northeast, the White House on Monday announced a program aimed at improving the government’s response to the drug across 15 states in that region.

headline: Summer Vacation: Goodbye Restaurants, Hello Kitchen
abstract: With a week off from his nightly restaurant routine, the critic Pete Wells gets to call his own shots, finding his own kitchen rhythm along the way.
lead_paragraph: There are people who plan their vacations around restaurant reservations that have to be secured months in advance. I am not one of them. When I need to get away from it all, competing for a table is one of the main things I’m getting away from. That, and meals longer than a filibuster, and hearing that “Chef” would like me to eat this particular taste in one bite while rubbing my stomach and patting my head.

headline: The Butterfly, the Ant and the Oregano
abstract: The discovery of a hostile but symbiotic three-way relationship has led to the Large Blue butterfly’s comeback in Britain.
lead_paragraph: It may be hard to imagine a ménage à trois, satisfactory to all parties, in which one member tries to dislodge another with a toxic gas and a third eats the offspring of the other two. But such an arrangement exists, and one of its members may even be sitting quietly in your kitchen’s spice rack.

headline: 1940: Electroshock Therapy
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Electroshock Therapy']
abstract: A new method of treating mental disorders was reported on July 6, 1940, by The New York Times, which chronicled its initial uses, decline and return.
lead_paragraph: “Insanity Treated By Electric Shock” read the headline of an article published on July 6, 1940, in The New York Times. The article described “a new method, introduced in Italy, of treating certain types of mental disorders by sending an electric shock through the brain.”

headline: Egypt Widens Government Power With New Anti-Terrorism Law
keywords: ['Immunity from Prosecution', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'News and News Media', 'Terrorism', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi issued the new law on Sunday to combat a wave of militant attacks, but critics say it merely protects repressive practices already in use.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt has issued a counterterrorism law that gives state security officers wider immunity from prosecution, expands the government’s surveillance powers and penalizes journalists for contradicting official accounts of militant attacks.

headline: Warren Braren, 82, Dies; Urged Ban on Broadcast Tobacco Ads
abstract: Testifying before Congress, Mr. Braren, a reformed smoker, blew the whistle on broadcasters’ lax self-regulation on tobacco advertising.
lead_paragraph: Warren Braren, a reformed smoker who helped trigger a congressional ban on tobacco advertising on television and radio in 1970 by blowing the whistle on broadcasters’ lax self-regulation, died on Thursday at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 82.

headline: Palestinian Man Fatally Shot in Confrontation With Israeli Police
abstract: The man, identified by the police as Mohammad Abu Amsha, 26, was the third Palestinian to try to stab Israelis in the West Bank since Saturday.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Palestinian man wearing jeans, a black shirt and sneakers approached two heavily armed Israeli police officers at a West Bank checkpoint in Nablus on Monday, claiming he was sick and needed medical assistance. It was a ruse, according to an Israeli police spokeswoman, who said the man tried to stab the border officers before they shot him dead.

headline: Daily Coffee May Boost Colon Cancer Survival
abstract: Colon cancer patients who were heavy coffee drinkers had a far lower risk of dying or having their cancer return than those who did not drink coffee.
lead_paragraph: Colon cancer patients who were heavy coffee drinkers had a far lower risk of dying or having their cancer return than those who did not drink coffee, with significant benefits starting at two to three cups a day, a new study found. Patients who drank four cups of caffeinated coffee or more a day had half the rate of recurrence or death than noncoffee drinkers.

headline: Luke Bryan Tops Dr. Dre in Album Sales
abstract: Dr. Dre’s first album in 16 years lands at No. 2, with Luke Bryan’s “Kill the Lights” taking the top spot on Billboard’s album chart.
lead_paragraph: On the music charts this week, the country star Luke Bryan beat Dr. Dre for the No. 1 album, as expected, while OMI’s “Cheerleader” returns as the top single.

headline: Police Officers Are Killed at a Checkpoint in Afghanistan’s South
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Officials said the attack, in which the assailant used his cousin to gain access before poisoning and shooting the officers, was the third of its kind in Helmand Province in less than two weeks.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — At least five Afghan police officers were poisoned and then shot to death in the southern province of Helmand late on Sunday, according to Afghan officials, who said the attack was the third of its kind in the province in less than two weeks.

lead_paragraph: It was a big week at the box office for the founding fathers and a pair of magicians, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group for theater owners and producers.

headline: Jury Duty for Donald Trump: ‘Amazing,’ ‘Really Good’ and Done in a Day
abstract: Mr. Trump took a break from his campaign for president to fulfill a more basic civic obligation on Monday, and brought his superlatives along.
lead_paragraph: The prospective juror emerged from his stretch limousine at 9:07 a.m. He spoke briefly to the waiting media horde, walked a gantlet of photographers and climbed the steps of State Supreme Court in Lower Manhattan.

headline: As Winning Majors Gets Tougher, Losing Them Is Easier to Stomach
abstract: At the P.G.A. Championship, Jason Day broke through with his first win in a major, but top golfers such as Sergio Garcia and Lee Westwood remain without a major title.
lead_paragraph: HAVEN, Wis. — Can we agree that it has never been harder to win a major in men’s professional golf? Consider the case of Justin Rose, who produced 72-hole scores of 14 under par at the Masters and the P.G.A. Championship only to lose by a combined 10 strokes. In golf’s four showcase events, Rose was 34 under, the fourth-lowest cumulative total in history.

headline: Off the Coast of Iran, a High-Stakes Version of Spy Versus Spy

abstract: As American naval ships roam the waters along Iran’s coastline, Iranian fighter jets patrol the skies watching them in what sometimes seems like a high-risk game.
lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — The commander of the Navy’s Fifth Fleet was in his office on the afternoon of July 25 when he got the phone call: An Iranian Navy frigate in the Gulf of Aden had approached a ship where an American military helicopter had just landed.

headline: Petco Files for an I.P.O.
abstract: Going public will give its private equity owners, including TPG Capital and Leonard Green, an avenue to sell nearly a decade after buying the company.
lead_paragraph: Only months after one of the country’s big retailers of dog food and catnip went private, another is planning a return to the public markets.

headline: Hamptons Night at the Apollo
abstract: Christina Aguilera, Jamie Foxx, Jimmy Fallon, Smokey Robinson and others perform at Ron Perelman’s fund-raiser for the Apollo.
lead_paragraph: It has become of one of the Hamptons’ most glamorous galas: Ron Perelman hosted a Saturday night gala for the Apollo Theater at his East Hampton estate. Performers included Jamie Foxx and Jimmy Fallon, who, it turns out, does an uncanny impression of Mick Jagger. See the photos.

headline: Lifetime Commits to ‘Unauthorized’ Movie Franchise
abstract: The Lifetime network hopes to replicate the success of its “The Unauthorized Saved by the Bell Story” with similar movies.
lead_paragraph: Critics panned it. Fans skewered it. Ratings were middling. But in the end it didn’t really matter what anyone thought about Lifetime’s “The Unauthorized Saved by the Bell Story” when it ran over Labor Day weekend last year. It did the job.

headline: A Double Dose of Divine, and Other Reports From the Fringe Festival
abstract: The New York International Fringe Festival, now in full swing, features glimmers of talent and skill amid the amateurism and malfunctioning air-conditioners.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, I stood in a basement space in the East Village, holding hands with a man who was attempting to regurgitate a bean, possibly cannellini. The bean, he promised, would have a number on it that matched a slip of paper I’d chosen from a plastic bag. The man was red-faced, groaning and coughing and retching. (I’m still not sure why he had to hold my hand.) Finally, he ejected the numbered bean from an unlikely orifice. Everyone applauded.

headline: Review: In ‘Unity (1918),’ a Town Blindsided by Spanish Influenza
abstract: With flashes of humor, Kevin Kerr’s play evokes the horrors of a 1918 pandemic that gave people no time to mourn.
lead_paragraph: So much for genteel images of the 1918 Spanish flu. Kevin Kerr’s “Unity (1918)” can make any “Upstairs Downstairs” fan forget the tasteful expiration of James Bellamy’s febrile young wife in a grand bedroom at Eaton Place. “Unity,” having its United States premiere at the Gene Frankel Theater, is much more like a horror story. The flu killed an estimated 50 million people worldwide in less than two years. (AIDS has killed around 39 million, but over 34 years.)

headline: Review: ‘The Last Love Song,’ a Biography of Joan Didion
abstract: The Didion who emerges here is a frail, angst-ridden outsider and a shrewd Hollywood and New York insider, a vulnerable witness to history and a hardheaded survivor.
lead_paragraph: Loss, nostalgia for a vanished past and “the unspeakable peril of the everyday” represented by “swimming pools, high-tension wires, lye under the sink, aspirin in the medicine cabinet” — these are the themes that have animated Joan Didion’s work, since “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” established her as one of America’s most distinctive and acute literary voices almost five decades ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Head Over Heels,’ Jukebox Musical Meets Elizabethan Romance
abstract: At the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, Jeff Whitty’s merry new work combines a 16th-century poetic tale with the music of the Go-Go’s.
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ore. — One ancient and venerable theatrical genre, the jukebox musical, is merrily mashed up with another, the Elizabethan romance, in “Head Over Heels,” having its premiere at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival here. In this funny and frolicsome concoction, the back catalog of the Go-Go’s, the new wave girl group that made a splash in ye olde 1980s, is wedded to a book by Jeff Whitty (“Avenue Q”) that pays winking homage to Sir Philip Sidney’s prose poem “The Arcadia,” from way back in the late 16th century.

headline: Review: George Benjamin, at Mostly Mozart, Shows Depth as a Conductor
abstract: Mr. Benjamin led the International Contemporary Ensemble in a performance featuring the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Last week, during a discussion onstage after the opening-night performance of George Benjamin’s haunting opera “Written on Skin,” Mr. Benjamin, who has conducted the piece many times, lavished praise on the textured, exciting performance Alan Gilbert had just led.

headline: ‘This Looks Like a National Strategy’
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: An interview with the journalist Ari Berman, author of “Give Us the Ballot."
lead_paragraph: On the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Voting Rights Act earlier this month, Ari Berman, a contributing writer for The Nation, published “Give Us the Ballot,” a book about the decades-long political battle over minority voting rights that followed the act’s passage, which I also wrote about recently in the magazine. I caught up with Berman to discuss his book, the voting rights fights of the past and those that are to come.

abstract: It was not clear if sanctions imposed after the annexation of Crimea played a role in the reported removal of Vladimir I. Yakunin as director of Russian Railways.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir I. Yakunin, the director of Russia’s national railway company and a longtime associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, has reportedly been ousted in one of the most significant shake-ups in domestic politics since the Russian economy slipped into recession last year.

headline: Major Flaws Found in Inquiry That Led to Suspension of Public-School Therapist
abstract: The New York City Department of Investigation has rebuked a report submitted by the Department of Education that also recommended the firing of the therapist, Debra Fisher.
lead_paragraph: For sheer bureaucratic folly, it would be hard to top the suspension last year of a devoted occupational therapist in the public school system who showed children in wheelchairs how to get places.

headline: Why Amazon May Take a Page From Walmart’s Labor Playbook
abstract: The perception of Amazon as a difficult place to work could force the online retailer to initiate reforms, as Walmart has done with its own billion-dollar program.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s latest results were so superb that they catapulted the online retailer’s market value beyond that of Walmart Stores for the first time. Now, the $250 billion goliath led by Jeff Bezos finds itself in another spot that its bricks-and-mortar rival will more happily cede: defending labor practices.

headline: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s ‘Between the World and Me’
abstract: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s new book is written in the form of a letter to his son, who is trying to make sense of blatant racial injustice and come to grips with his place in the world.
lead_paragraph: For the past several years, I’ve greeted Ta-Nehisi Coates’s essays and blog posts for The Atlantic with nothing short of gratitude. As an African-American, he makes me proud. There is no other way to put it. I do not always agree with him, but it hardly matters. In a media world populated with pundits, so-called experts and public intellectuals driven by ego and familiar agendas, Coates’s voice stands nearly alone — a black man raised in the streets of Baltimore who narrowly escaped the violence that lurked around every corner and dodged the clutches of the prisons and jails that were built for him, and who now speaks unpopular, unconventional and sometimes even radical truths in his own voice, unfiltered. He is invariably humble, yet subtly defiant. And people listen.

headline: Hacking of Tax Returns More Extensive Than First Reported, I.R.S. Says
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service said the returns of more than 300,000 people were affected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service said Monday that hackers had gained access to the tax returns of more than 300,000 people, a far higher number than the agency had reported previously.

headline: As Scott Walker Struggles in Iowa, His Campaign Reaches Out to a Strategist
abstract: A consultant to Scott Walker’s presidential campaign telephoned a Georgia-based Republican strategist last week to sound him out about working for Mr. Walker, a sign Mr. Walker is considering staff changes as his campaign is being eclipsed by Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: A consultant to Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin’s presidential campaign telephoned a Georgia-based Republican strategist last week to sound him out about working for Mr. Walker, a sign that he is considering staff changes at a moment when his campaign has been eclipsed by Donald J. Trump.

lead_paragraph: Wrapping up a three-day visit to Syria on Monday, the new emergency relief coordinator of the United Nations, Stephen O’Brien, told reporters he was “absolutely horrified by the total disregard for civilian life by all parties in this conflict.”

lead_paragraph: John C. Malone is taking home shopping over the top.

abstract: Robert Steven Kaplan was head of investment banking at Goldman before leaving to teach at Harvard. He succeeds Richard Fisher. who left in March.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas on Monday chose for its new president Robert Steven Kaplan, a former Goldman Sachs executive.

headline: Iraq: Monitoring Group to Investigate Possible Chemical Weapons Use by ISIS
abstract: The group responsible for monitoring adherence to the global ban on chemical weapons said that it had contacted Iraq over reports of the possible use of such munitions there.
lead_paragraph: The group responsible for monitoring adherence to the global ban on chemical weapons said Monday that it had contacted Iraq over reports of the possible use of such munitions there. A statement by the group, the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, based in The Hague, came a few days after United States officials said Islamic State militants appeared to have used such munitions, possibly mustard gas, on Kurdish fighters in Iraq. If confirmed, it would be the first known use of the weapons by the Islamic State, which occupies parts of Syria and Iraq. The monitoring group called such reports “a matter of serious concern,” and its director, Ahmet Uzumcu, said it would “examine any substantive reports it receives including pertinent information that might be shared” by other signers of the chemical weapons ban, which appeared to be a reference to both Iraq and Syria. Iraq, where hundreds of old, corroded mustard artillery shells remained after the 2003 American invasion, signed the chemical weapons ban in 2009. Syria joined in 2013 after having promised to destroy its chemical stockpile, although the monitoring organization said this year that chlorine bombs had been used in the Syrian conflict. On Aug. 7, the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution authorizing an inquiry into who was responsible for the chlorine attacks.

headline: Starter’s Injury Tempers Yankees’ Extra-Inning Win Over Twins
abstract: Bryan Mitchell was hit in the face with a line drive off the bat of Eduardo Nunez, who, in an odd twist, handed the Yankees a victory when he mishandled a bases-loaded grounder in the 10th.
lead_paragraph: In a frightening scene at Yankee Stadium on Monday night, Yankees starter Bryan Mitchell was hit in the face with a line drive off the bat of Eduardo Nunez, a right-handed hitter for the Minnesota Twins, in the second inning of an 8-7, 10-inning Yankees victory. In 2013, when Nunez was an infielder with the Yankees and on a rehab assignment with Class A Tampa, he and Mitchell were teammates for three games.

headline: Shell Wins Final Permission for Arctic Oil and Gas Drilling
abstract: The Obama administration issued a final permit for Shell to start drilling for oil and gas in the Chukchi Sea off Alaska’s northwest coast.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Monday issued a final permit for Shell to start drilling for oil and gas in the Arctic Ocean. The Interior Department gave conditional approval in May for the company’s long-delayed application to drill in the untouched waters of the Chukchi Sea off Alaska’s northwest coast. In July, the administration issued a permit that would allow Shell to start drilling at the top of the seabed but would not allow the drill to penetrate into the oil reserves until Shell had quick access to a “capping stack,” which is used to shut down wells in case of emergency spills. The ship carrying that capping stack arrived at the drilling site last week. Environmentalists have criticized Mr. Obama for moving forward with the drilling.

lead_paragraph: Bob Johnston, who produced a string of classic albums in the 1960s and ’70s including Bob Dylan’s “Highway 61 Revisited” and “Blonde on Blonde” and Johnny Cash’s “At Folsom Prison,” died on Friday in Gallatin, Tenn. He was 83.

headline: Union Ruling Underlines N.C.A.A.’s Evolution
abstract: In effect, the college sports establishment has so far been able to head off fundamental alterations to its model in part by allowing incremental changes.
lead_paragraph: Among the more notable features of Monday’s landmark decision by the National Labor Relations Board declining to recognize Northwestern football players’ unionization efforts was the time it took to make it. A petition was filed in January 2014. An N.L.R.B. regional director recognized its legitimacy in March 2014, prompting an appeal to the federal board. But before Monday, it had been more than a year since anything appeared on the case’s docket.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To one Twitter user who experienced his first California earthquake on Monday, the 4.0 temblor was “tiny,” and “Disneyland had better rides.” Another post from the Bay Area derided earthquakes as “just God’s push notifications.” Several other people posted notices saying that the biggest disturbance by the overnight quake had been to their pets’ behavior.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:20 A.M. (Encore) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients, leaving her with little more than her pearls, Chanel jacket, Hermès bag and Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads and starts to see light at the end of her dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is “brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allen’s “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point.’ ”

headline: Of Camera Work and Fine Art
abstract: In Camera Work, Alfred Stieglitz sought to promote photography as fine art. To this day, some collectors have gone as far as to mount individual gravures from the fabled publication.
lead_paragraph: “The hand camera has come to stay — its importance is acknowledged,” Alfred Stieglitz begrudgingly declared at the end of an 1897 essay about Eastman Kodak’s campaign “You Press the Button, We Do the Rest.” For Stieglitz, this meant that “Every Tom, Dick and Harry could, without trouble, learn how to get something or other on a sensitive plate, and this is what the public wanted — no work and lots of fun.”

headline: California’s Saint, and a Church’s Sins
abstract: Pope Francis will canonize the Rev. Junipero Serro next month. But to Native Americans, that story has a dark side.
lead_paragraph: On his trip to the United States next month, Pope Francis is going to canonize the Rev. Junipero Serra, the great Spanish missionary of 18th-century California. As fourth graders from Chico to Chula Vista have been taught for generations, Father Serra founded the first of the 21 Catholic missions that stretch along the coast like rosary beads. He laid the foundation of California as we know it: the tile-and-adobe wonderland of vineyards, citrus, olives, wheat and cattle.

headline: What Your Vacation Says About You
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Paid Time Off', 'Happiness', 'Research']
abstract: Introverts like the mountains, while extroverts like the beach. And Europeans? They just like vacation. Work on, Americans.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY-THREE years ago, my wife and I were having an argument about how to celebrate our first anniversary. Money was tight, and we had to choose between taking a beach vacation or buying a couch, which we did not have. Being a Spaniard, she naturally advocated for the beach. As a thrifty American, I argued for the couch because it was permanent. In the end, we compromised — we went to the beach.
