headline: A Tobacco Tax to Save Lives
abstract: We should learn from the Swedes’ approach to nicotine.
lead_paragraph: A smokeless tobacco product called snus, which a user puts between his gums and his upper lip, has a long history in Sweden. At the start of the last century, it was the most common way Swedes ingested nicotine. By the early 1950s, however, sales of snus had been overtaken by cigarettes, a trend that continued for two decades.

headline: President Obama’s Department of Injustice
abstract: Despite individual acts of clemency, the Obama administration’s record on unfair imprisonment is terrible.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — LAST month, President Obama used his clemency power to reduce the sentences of 46 federal prisoners locked up on drug-related charges. But for the last six years, his administration has worked repeatedly behind the scenes to ensure that tens of thousands of poor people — disproportionately minorities — languish in federal prison on sentences declared by the courts, and even the president himself, to be illegal and unjustifiable.

headline: I Am Republican, Hear Me Roar
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: On foreign policy, the Republican presidential candidates offer little more than bombast.
lead_paragraph: To hear most of the Republican candidates tell it, all an American president has to do is talk tough, make demands, send more troops overseas, pour billions more dollars into the Pentagon and the world will fall in line. The notion they’re peddling boils down to this: President Obama is weak, I am strong and America will be great again when I am in the White House.

headline: The Idealist Versus the Therapist
abstract: When romanticism meets realism, which prevails?
lead_paragraph: I was giving a lecture in New York not all that long ago. I was talking about ideals. The audience was made up of therapists and therapists in training at the eminent William Alanson White Institute on the Upper West Side. After the talk was over, I was asked a remarkable question. Certainly it was the best-posed question that I have ever gotten at a talk.

lead_paragraph: For James Sewell, diving for scallops on the ocean floor off Maine’s jagged coastline transcends making a living – it’s what keeps him alive.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Even as tensions rise on other fronts, North and South Korea have reached agreement on at least one subject, officials said Tuesday: a raise for North Korean workers.

headline: $8.8 Billion Acquisition of Australian Port and Railroad Operator

headline: Why New Orleans’s Black Residents Are Still Underwater After Katrina
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Mortgages']
abstract: One black-owned bank helped build the city’s African-American middle class — until the hurricane destroyed much more than their homes.
lead_paragraph: ‘Bring a map of New Orleans.’’ That was all that Alden J. McDonald Jr., president and chief executive of Liberty Bank and Trust Company, said when I first asked to meet him. It was the summer of 2005, less than two weeks after the city’s flood-protection system failed to keep out the storm surge created by Hurricane Katrina, and I was reporting in Louisiana for this newspaper. The Gulf of Mexico was sitting in the lobby of his New Orleans headquarters. The flood had destroyed Liberty’s mainframe computer; a good many of the bank’s most essential documents — deeds for houses, titles for cars — were ruined as well. Six of Liberty’s eight branches were flooded and a seventh had been battered by looters. The bank’s central operations had to be moved to a branch office in Baton Rouge, 70 miles away.

headline: The Unwelcome Return of ‘Illegals’
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'English Language', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Using the term to describe undocumented immigrants implies that they are less than human and undeserving of fair treatment.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, the political strategist Frank Luntz issued a proclamation about the language of immigration. ‘‘Always refer to people crossing the border illegally as ‘illegal immigrants’ — NOT as ‘illegals,’ ’’ Luntz instructed fellow conservatives. ‘‘Illegals’’ sounds harsh and spiky. As with ‘‘fatties’’ in high school, or ‘‘thugs,’’ it’s a way to write off a group and justify its mistreatment. Luntz says his research showed that ‘‘if you used the word ‘illegals,’ you didn’t get a chance to say anything else — Latino audiences would turn you off.’’ Republicans have long respected Luntz’s messaging skills: This is the man who helped them write the Contract With America and pioneer the phrase ‘‘death tax.’’ Yet G.O.P. candidates for president have repeatedly ignored his warning.

headline: ‘Most Likely to Succeed,’ by Tony Wagner and Ted Dintersmith
abstract: A vision of education for an entrepreneurial America.
lead_paragraph: Here, then, is yet another book about success. This time it’s not grit that helps children succeed. Nor is it having a Tiger Mom or letting children walk home alone or allowing them to skin their knees or teaching them Arabic or Mandarin. It’s not about supporting their spiritual development or eliminating the gluten in their diets or teaching them about white privilege or the importance of team sports. No, this new tract aimed at the heart of parental anxiety — “Most Likely to Succeed: Preparing Our Kids for the Innovation Era,” by Tony Wagner and Ted Dintersmith — argues that the only way to ensure any kind of future security for our children is to totally upend the education system and rethink what school is for.

headline: ‘The Gift of Failure,’ by Jessica Lahey
abstract: A middle-school teacher blows the whistle on overparenting.
lead_paragraph: When I was learning to drive, my mother sat in the passenger seat pressing her foot on an imaginary brake, gripping the door handle for dear life. She couldn’t do it for me; she could only watch. It wasn’t pretty, but I did learn.

headline: ‘The Two-State Delusion,’ by Padraig O’Malley
abstract: Can Israeli and Palestinian states coexist?
lead_paragraph: Padraig O’Malley’s “The Two-State ­Delusion” is an impressive and frustrating book. It’s impressive because ­O’Malley, a professor at the University of Massachusetts at Boston who has written ­extensively on South Africa and Northern Ireland, has done a tremendous amount of research about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. He’s not only delved deeply into its literature; he’s also interviewed dozens of participants on both sides. The result is a book so packed with information that it will reward even the reader so dedicated that she consumes the Israel-Palestine stories buried on Page A17 of The Times.

headline: 1890: Finding a Substitute for War
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Portuguese use spitting bowls to represent Englishmen in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The Portuguese have discovered a substitute for war, which is both cheaper and more feasible than arbitration. Portugal has recently quarreled with England, but it was impolite for her to declare war against such a powerful adversary. The Portuguese therefore relieve their minds by the use of ‘‘spittoons,’’ made to represent pompous and plethoric Englishmen. Germany might demand the settlement of her next dispute with Russia under penalty of furnishing every German home with a receptacle for sauerkraut made in the image of a moujik. Thus would the horrors and expenses of war be avoided, while at the same time the overburdened hearts of nations relieved. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 19, 1890

headline: Drone Footage of Tianjin Blast Aftermath
abstract: Footage released by firefighters shows aerial images of a warehouse in Tianjin, China, the site of huge explosions on Aug. 12.
lead_paragraph: Footage released by firefighters shows aerial images of a warehouse in Tianjin, China, the site of huge explosions on Aug. 12.

headline: Skyscraper That Would Soar Over Sutton Place Runs Into Neighborhood Opposition
abstract: Residents near the site of a planned tower on the East Side have formed an alliance to try to stop the project, a sign that some New Yorkers are exhausted by the relentless pace of construction.
lead_paragraph: Herndon Werth met with several lawyers last week in a restaurant around the corner from his home of over 40 years, on a sleepy stretch of 58th Street near luxurious Sutton Place on the East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Films With Political Themes Among Those Added to Toronto Lineup
abstract: “Our Brand Is Crisis,” directed by David Gordon Green, and “Truth,” directed by James Vanderbilt, are added to the roster.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Toronto International Film Festival sharpened its political edge, as a pair of issues-oriented films joined another 22 additions to its September lineup of galas and special presentations.

headline: Was Portrayal of Amazon’s Brutal Workplace on Target?
abstract: A tough article about the retailing giant brought varied reactions and thousands of comments.
lead_paragraph: Soon after The Times’s massive takeout on the culture of Amazon’s workplace (“Where overachievers go to feel bad about themselves.”), an Amazon employee, Nick Ciubotariu, wrote a long, passionate response in disagreement.

headline: Fear of Toxic Air and Distrust of Government Follow Tianjin Blasts
keywords: ['Explosions (Accidental)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Air Pollution', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The government has insisted that it ensured the safety of the city’s air, but after rain on Tuesday, the streets began to foam.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Within minutes of the immense chemical explosions that sent apocalyptic fireballs into the night sky over Tianjin, Zhou Haisen, 23, was making arrangements to leave town. He was terrified that poisonous gases would reach his apartment six miles from the scene, and his fears were swiftly reinforced by posts on Chinese social media. So he and his parents fled to his grandmother’s house an hour’s drive away.

headline: 1965: Rift Over Vietnam Denied
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson dispels a rift between him and Eisenhower in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson moved to dispel suggestions of a rift between him and former President Eisenhower over policy in Vietnam. The chief executive abruptly sent an envoy to the Eisenhower farm at Gettysburg, Pa., by helicopter to discuss ‘‘UN matters.’’ However, the surprise announcement came after a strong statement by the presidential press secretary that Mr. Johnson sees ‘‘no division’’ between himself and Gen. Eisenhower on Vietnam. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 19, 1965

headline: Videos Show Bangkok Bombing
abstract: A compilation of surveillance and witness videos shows the frantic moments before and after Monday’s bombing at a religious shrine in Bangkok.
lead_paragraph: A compilation of surveillance and witness videos shows the frantic moments before and after Monday’s bombing at a religious shrine in Bangkok.

headline: Smashed Cucumber Salad Takes Manhattan
abstract: The smashing technique seems to be everywhere nowadays.
lead_paragraph: The difference between a sliced cucumber salad and a smashed cucumber salad reveals itself on first bite.

headline: NBCUniversal to Invest $200 Million in BuzzFeed
abstract: The deal, which values BuzzFeed at about $1.5 billion, includes plans for the new and old media companies to work together on television, movies, the Olympics and partnerships with marketers.
lead_paragraph: BuzzFeed, the digital media hub known for its shareable lists and a relatively recent push into more ambitious journalism, has landed a $200 million strategic investment from the entertainment conglomerate NBCUniversal, the two companies confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Poll Finds Most Back Healthy School Meals
keywords: ['Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Education (K-12)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Law and Legislation', 'Food']
abstract: According to the poll, released by the W.K. Kellogg Foundation, 86 percent of Americans support the standards required by a 2010 law, including providing more fruits and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of Americans support providing schoolchildren with healthy meals that consist of more fruits and vegetables and fewer foods high in calories and sodium, according to a national poll released on Tuesday by the W. K. Kellogg Foundation.

headline: How Artists Are Making a (Better) Living in the Internet Age
abstract: Six creatives in the Los Angeles area are supporting themselves with professions that would have been impossible 15 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Six creatives in the Los Angeles area are supporting themselves with professions that would have been impossible 15 years ago.

headline: Beatles’ First Recording Contract Up for Auction
abstract: The Beatles’ first recording contract, signed in Germany in 1961, is up for auction in September.
lead_paragraph: The Beatles’ first recording contract, signed in Hamburg, Germany, in 1961, is being sold by Heritage Auctions next month. The six-page contract led to the recording of the single “My Bonnie” with the singer Tony Sheridan, and landed the Beatles about $80. The contract is now expected to be sold for $150,000.

headline: Elections Seem Likely in Turkey as ISIS Threat Rises
abstract: Talks aimed at forming a coalition government ended, and an Islamic State video called on Muslims to revolt against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prospects for a period of instability in Turkey increased on Tuesday after attempts by the dominant party to form a new coalition government officially ended in failure.

lead_paragraph: Female workers and leaders shared colorful tales of bias and pay inequity in response to an op-ed urging transparent salary information in private workplaces.

abstract: Our top winner is MatthewPRHSLions2015, who wrote about the outrage directed at Cecil the lion’s killer. We also selected seven excellent Runners-Up and eight Honorable Mentions.
lead_paragraph: We’ve learned from running this contest over many years that as summer winds down, the competition heats up — evidenced in Week 8 by 828 entries.

headline: Oiji
abstract: Korean for the small-plate set in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Korean for the small-plate set in the East Village.

headline: Restaurant Review: Oiji in the East Village
abstract: Oiji in the East Village updates and translates Korean cuisine, adjusting traditional recipes for the small-plates era, while aiming for a little French-style nuance.
lead_paragraph: I’ll get to the heftier items on Oiji’s menu. I’ll praise the pine-smoked mackerel that a mackerel-conscious friend and I have been emailing each other about for a month now. I’ll reminisce about the bowl of buttered rice and stewed beef that seemed boring at first and then not boring at all. I’ll try to explain what makes the bubble-cluster of crust on the fried chicken so good. All in due time, all in due time.

lead_paragraph: DHAKA — The authorities in Bangladesh have arrested three men in connection with the brutal killings of secular bloggers, an official said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: It came to me, as most things do nowadays, while staring at my phone.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a letter published in The Times of London, prominent theater figures and other artists expressed concern that the National Youth Theater had been pressured to cancel a new play, “Homegrown,” about young Islamic State recruits.

lead_paragraph: For the last year, Google’s work force has increasingly been under attack from a herd of unicorns.

headline: A Roving Manhattan Pool Party Eases the Summer Heat

lead_paragraph: On sweltering summer days, the mind wanders masochistically to the beaches of the Hamptons, or the private pools tucked behind exclusive addresses. The Downtown Pool Club offers a refreshing option, with a roving Manhattan pool party, three times a week.

headline: Familiar Talk on Women, From an Unfamiliar Trump

lead_paragraph: The outspoken scion of the New York real estate developer Fred C. Trump stood on stage in Washington one day in 1992 and told a mostly female crowd of law enforcement agents to lighten up when it came to sexual harassment.

lead_paragraph: A girls softball team accused of intentionally losing at the Little League World Series was eliminated on Tuesday after being ordered to play a special play-in game.

headline: Will the Pentagon Change Its Manual on the Law of War?
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Defense Department is right to be concerned about criticism of its guidelines for journalists.
lead_paragraph: A senior lawyer at the Defense Department said last week that criticism about a section on the role and treatment of journalists in the Pentagon’s new Law of War manual, is “something of major concern.”  And well it should be.

headline: Cruise to New Guinea Is Offered
abstract: The highlight is meeting the people of Papua, West Papua and Papua New Guinea.
lead_paragraph: Lindblad Expeditions-National Geographic is offering a cruise to New Guinea, which it calls one of the least explored places. The 20-day trip aboard the National Geographic Orion, which can accommodate 102 passengers, departs Sept. 22 from Brisbane, Australia. The tour includes forays into largely inaccessible terrain where art, tribal life, biology and history intersect. The highlight is learning about the cultures of West Papua, Papua and Papua New Guinea and meeting Asmat, above, and Trobriand islanders.

headline: E.P.A. Announces New Rules to Cut Methane Emissions
keywords: ['Methane', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday proposed the first federal regulations requiring the nation’s oil and gas industry to cut emissions of methane as part of an expanding and increasingly aggressive effort to combat climate change.

headline: ISIS Lures 3 Teenage Girls: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Katrin Bennhold provides a close-up look at the reporting she did on a front-page story about three Londoners who left their childhood homes for Syria.
lead_paragraph: A foreign correspondent based in London, Katrin Bennhold has written about everything from the migrant crisis in Calais and Scotland’s independence movement to trigger-happy fox snipers. She has a front-page article in Tuesday’s paper about three well-educated teenage girls who left their childhood home in Bethnal Green in East London for Syria, where they joined forces with ISIS. She talked with Times Insider about her reporting.

headline: German Art Historian to Direct Uffizi Gallery in Italy
abstract: Eike Schmidt, currently at the Minneapolis Institute of Art, was appointed as the director of the Florentine institution, and is one of seven foreigners tapped to head some of Italy’s most storied galleries, including the Borghese Gallery here, the Gallerie dell’Accademia in Venice, and the Brera gallery in Milan.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A German art historian will run the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, Italy’s culture minister said Tuesday, announcing the appointment of the directors of the country’s top 20 museums, selected after an international competition.

headline: Chicken in a Time of Figs

lead_paragraph: When ripe figs are as plentiful as they are now, I use them in savory dishes, not just sweet ones. I like figs quickly grilled or seared, and sometimes I cook my figs long enough to render them a bit jammy. It takes only a few minutes for this to happen.

lead_paragraph: In a new video from the Islamic State, an unidentified fighter calls for people in Turkey to fight President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and conquer Istanbul.

headline: The Quiet Demise of the Army’s Plan to Understand Afghanistan and Iraq
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: In the heyday of counterinsurgency, the United States military’s Human Terrain Teams were a bold idea. In the drone-war era, they became an anachronism.
lead_paragraph: One dreary winter day in 2010, I joined a Georgia National Guard unit on a routine patrol in Zormat, a ragged mountain town in eastern Afghanistan, not far from the Pakistani border. With us were two American civilians in military uniforms who worked for a United States Army social-science program called the Human Terrain System. The Army had begun developing the program as an experiment in 2006; it expanded quickly as the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan foundered and American policy makers cast about for novel approaches. The idea was to send teams of social scientists, including anthropologists, to gather ethnographic, sociocultural and economic information and advise front-line soldiers on a range of delicate topics, from the mechanics of forging tribal alliances to how to respond to local offers of hospitality.

headline: Robert Menendez Says He’ll Vote Against Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat, said the agreement did not go far enough to limit Tehran’s potential to pursue a weapons program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, said Tuesday that he would vote against the nuclear accord with Iran, contending the agreement did not go far enough to limit Tehran’s potential to pursue a weapons program.

headline: Louis C.K. Defends Bill de Blasio on the Radio. Maybe.
abstract: A man who called into Brian Lehrer’s talk show on WNYC on Tuesday sounded familiar to many listeners, who thought he could have been the popular comedian.
lead_paragraph: Amid a bumpy summer, Mayor Bill de Blasio has said that “everyday New Yorkers” understand the good work his administration is doing.

headline: Technology to Keep Swimmers Safe
abstract: Tech companies are wading into the swim safety market, offering inflatable wristbands and smartphone monitors that can help prevent drowning accidents.
lead_paragraph: On a hot summer afternoon in July, my friend’s 8-year-old son Cody nearly drowned in a backyard swimming pool. There were two moms supervising and only one other family in the water. It was quiet and calm, and those watching him thought he was just trying to see how long he could hold his breath. When they realized it wasn’t a game and pulled him out, he was unconscious and his lips were blue. Both moms started CPR and the child was coughing up blood by the time the paramedics arrived less than 10 minutes later.

headline: Promontory Financial Settles With New York Regulator

lead_paragraph: When New York State’s financial regulator challenged the independence of a top Wall Street consultant, the Promontory Financial Group, the firm threatened to sue, vowing to “litigate the matter and defend our firm against this regulatory overreach.”

headline: Driven | 2016 Nissan Maxima
abstract: The Maxima distances itself from its sibling the Altima with a crafted interior and a look all its own.
lead_paragraph: The Maxima distances itself from its sibling the Altima with a crafted interior and a look all its own.

headline: Video Review: New Maxima Gives Nissan Fans a Reason to Trade Up
abstract: Maxima’s attitude is a reminder of Generation 3, the one first marketed as a four-door sports car. The new model is now a bit longer and lower.
lead_paragraph: NISSAN has offered few reasons for buyers to step up from a loaded Altima to the Maxima the last few years. Many of the same features and much of the same performance and design panache in the Maxima could be had with its less expensive sibling. There was no 2015 Maxima, and what 2014 models remained were sold to loyalists (and there are many) — until the 2016 models arrived this summer.

headline: Review: Aimard Plays George Benjamin’s ‘Shadowlines,’ Uniting Prelude and Canon

headline: N.F.L.’s Case Against Tom Brady Is Returning to Courtroom as Talks Stall

headline: A Jams Revival (in Spirit)
abstract: For a project in a new hotel, Jonathan Waxman is featuring holdovers from the 1980s menu from the restaurant on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Jams The California-style restaurant Jams, a trailblazer in New York when it opened on East 79th Street in 1984, remained part of Jonathan Waxman’s persona long after it closed. Now, for a restaurant project in a new hotel, Mr. Waxman is reviving Jams in spirit, though not in detail. It is an airy space done in stone and wood, and more rustic than the original, with simpler table settings and dishtowel napkins. Some of the 100 seats are at a long bar, and an open kitchen anchors the rear of the space. Along with grilled chicken with tarragon butter; and red pepper latkes with smoked salmon, corn and California caviar — which are holdovers from the 1980s — Jams will serve brightly accented dishes like rigatoni with crab meat and chile as well as swordfish with grilled pineapple salsa. “It’s my food, less Italian than Barbuto, but still what I like to cook,” Mr. Waxman said. Barbuto is his West Village restaurant, and its pastry chef Heather Miller is making the desserts at Jams, too. Melvyn Master, the wine expert who was Mr. Waxman’s partner and the “m’ in the name (Jams stands for Jonathan and Melvyn) is providing some of his wines to the new restaurant: 1 Hotel Central Park, 1414 Avenue of the Americas (58th Street), 212-703-2007.

headline: Gabon’s President Offers Some of His Wealth ‘to the People’
abstract: The move by Ali Ben Bongo, one of Africa’s wealthiest leaders, was heralded by his circle but met with skepticism from critics who pointed out the legal and political pressure he faces.
lead_paragraph: COURBEVOIE, France — One of Africa’s wealthiest presidents said this week that he was giving up at least some of his holdings “to the people of Gabon,” a declaration heralded by his inner circle but quickly met with skepticism by critics who pointed out the legal and political pressure the leader, Ali Ben Bongo, is facing over the vast riches acquired by his family.

headline: Review: ‘A Manual for Cleaning Women,’ Lucia Berlin’s Soul-Baring Stories
abstract: Deep shafts of sunlight penetrate these messily alluring and yet casually droll stories of struggling mothers, blue-collar jobs and desperate addictions.
lead_paragraph: There’s a fine crude moment in “A Manual for Cleaning Women,” an overdue collection of stories by Lucia Berlin (1936-2004), when one of her narrators, a nurse, pauses to consider the nature of clear colostomy bags.

headline: In Israel, a Focus on Chinese Tourists

lead_paragraph: The Israeli government, still reeling from a drop-off in visitors following last summer’s war with Gaza, is betting on China to jump-start the nation’s flagging tourism industry.

headline: A Deluge of Comments From Readers With an Opinion About Amazon

headline: American Ballet Theater to Debut Ratmansky Work Next Spring
abstract: For its spring 2016 season, American Ballet Theater offers a slightly bolder lineup, with more of a focus on its artist in residence, Alexei Ratmansky.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater’s spring 2016 season, from May 9 to July 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House, is to include one world premiere and one American premiere, the company announced on Tuesday. As usual, the lineup includes seven full-length ballets and two triple bills. The full-lengths are “Le Corsaire,” “La Fille Mal Gardée,” “The Golden Cockerel,” “Romeo and Juliet,” “The Sleeping Beauty,” “Swan Lake” and “Sylvia.” The two triple bills will be “The Shostakovich Trilogy” (which can be considered a full-length ballet, though not narrative) and another trio yet to be announced.

headline: BB&T Is New Deal-Making Powerhouse in Banking

abstract: BB&T’s $1.8 billion acquisition of National Penn is its fourth deal in a year. The longer that other banks stay on the sidelines, the more it will look as if they fear rejection.

headline: German Vote on Bailout Carries Risks for Merkel
abstract: Despite a rebellion in Parliament, the German chancellor is expected to win approval of the 86-billion-euro bailout package for Greece in a Wednesday vote.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Faced with a revolt among her own deputies over approval of a new 86-billion-euro bailout for Greece, Chancellor Angela Merkel and her government on Tuesday met with lawmakers to try to contain the political damage from the conservative rebellion.

headline: Kansas City Art Institute Receives $25 Million Donation
abstract: The gift to the Kansas City Art Institute is one of the largest ever to an American art school.
lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Art Institute in Missouri, which has trained or employed artists including Thomas Hart Benton, Robert Rauschenberg and Nick Cave and is celebrating its 130th anniversary, announced Tuesday that it had received a donation of $25 million, one of the largest gifts ever to an American art school.

abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, a Democratic presidential candidate, appeared at a town hall event in Las Vegas on Tuesday and criticized Republican candidates for what she found was a lack of substance.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, a Democratic presidential candidate, appeared at a town hall event in Las Vegas on Tuesday and criticized Republican candidates for what she found was a lack of substance.

headline: Pivotal Software Gets a New Leader and Announces Strong Cloud Revenue
abstract: Paul Maritz is stepping aside as chief executive of Pivotal Software. Pivotal, the cloud-computing spinoff of EMC, also announced strong growth in cloud subscriptions.
lead_paragraph: Pivotal Software announced on Tuesday that it had a new leader and that bookings for its cloud computing software is now a $100 million-a-year business, double the size of a year ago.

headline: Supporters of College Athletes’ Unions Look Past Setback
abstract: Advocates for college athletes are seeking new ways to influence policy after their bid to unionize football players at Northwestern was defeated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a cold January morning more than a year and a half ago when Kain Colter and the activist Ramogi Huma called a news conference at a downtown Chicago hotel to announce their intention to form the first college sports union.

headline: Review: ‘Grey Gardens’ Is Revived in Its Real Setting, the Hamptons
abstract: This musical about two relatives of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis is playing in Sag Harbor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: SAG HARBOR, N.Y. — Here in the manicured Hamptons, where affluence parades in the summer months, “Grey Gardens” counts as a local story: the Camelot relatives — Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis’s elderly aunt and middle-aged cousin — whose spectacularly mangy living conditions, in their wreck of an East Hampton mansion, grabbed headlines in the 1970s. The neighbors, naturally, had complained.

headline: Meal-Delivery Start-Ups Take Aim at Your Dinner
abstract: Gobble, Blue Apron, Marley Spoon, HelloFresh, Plated and others offer shortcuts for home-cooked meals. But is it still cooking?
lead_paragraph: Baking a cake has evolved over the years. When my grandmother learned to bake, she had to buy all the ingredients at the store, including flour, eggs, butter and sugar, and bake the cake from scratch.

lead_paragraph: BALDWIN, N.Y. — The recent letter from the Federal Emergency Management Agency about his flood insurance claim should have come as good news to William T. Lynch, who is now on his third apartment rental since his 1920s cottage here was gutted by Hurricane Sandy nearly three years ago.

abstract: The White House has hired its first openly transgender staff member, officials said Tuesday, adding a longtime advocate for transgender rights to the office of presidential personnel.
lead_paragraph: CHILMARK, Mass. — The White House has hired its first openly transgender staff member, officials said Tuesday, adding a longtime advocate for transgender rights to the office of presidential personnel.

lead_paragraph: Israeli-Norwegian relations have hardly been a flash point in the troubled history of the Middle East. But a programming decision last week by a film festival in Oslo to reject a film simply for its Israeli-ness may have opened a new chapter in the boycott movement against Israel.

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The lawyer for a white Charlotte police officer charged with voluntary manslaughter concluded his defense on Tuesday by shifting accusations onto the black former college football player who died in the 2013 shooting, portraying the unarmed victim as a would-be burglar who dared the police to kill him.

lead_paragraph: The romantic comedy “Slow Learners” opens with Jeff (Adam Pally from “The Mindy Project”) enduring his latest first date to go south: “You’re just soft and doughy,” she explains helpfully. “You’re sort of like an old baby.”

headline: ‘Hedwig and the Angry Inch’ Sets Broadway Closing Date
abstract: The musical will have played for more than 500 performances when it closes on Sept. 13.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to put that wig back on the shelf: “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” is closing on Broadway.

headline: The Education of a Gardener
abstract: In one of England’s greatest flower gardens, an Italian formalist learns to appreciate the subtleties of seasons.
lead_paragraph: In one of England’s greatest flower gardens, an Italian formalist learns to appreciate the subtleties of seasons.

headline: Review: ‘Beltracchi: The Art of Forgery’ Tells How a Swindler Fooled the World
abstract: This film documents how Wolfgang Beltracchi became rich by mimicking the work of notable artists for decades until the authorities closed in.
lead_paragraph: In the documentary “Beltracchi: The Art of Forgery,” the German forger Wolfgang Beltracchi — who was sentenced in 2011 to six years in prison but released this year — professes to be able to paint anything. The art historian Henry Keazor gives him names. Leonardo? “Of course. He’s not difficult,” Mr. Beltracchi replies. When Mr. Keazor notes that the forger has the potential to deceive even scholars like him, Mr. Beltracchi replies, “If you write a catalog of works, bring it to me first.” This is ostensibly to make sure that undiscovered fakes are not accidentally included.

headline: Rape Case Puts Focus on Culture of Elite St. Paul’s School
abstract: Prosecutors said in opening statements that the Concord, N.H., school was also a place of secret rites and sexual conquest where young girls were put at risk.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — Owen Labrie, a senior at the St. Paul’s School, made up a list of potential girls for his “senior salute” — a school ritual in which older students proposition younger ones for as much intimacy as they can get away with: a kiss, touching, or more.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Addyi, a Libido Pill for Women
abstract: The drug has faced criticism from those who say the F.D.A. was pressured. But advocates say the move was long overdue, given the options available to men.
lead_paragraph: The first prescription drug to enhance women’s sexual drive won regulatory approval on Tuesday, clinching a victory for a lobbying campaign that had accused the Food and Drug Administration of gender bias for ignoring the sexual needs of women.

headline: Ohio State’s Quarterback Plan Still Unclear Months After National Title
abstract: Cardale Jones, who went from third-stringer to starting quarterback as Ohio State won the national championship, finds himself in a duel with J. T. Barrett, a Heisman Trophy contender last season.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Cardale Jones has a flair for embracing his newfound fame, and anyplace he goes is a stage. His latest performance came at Ohio State’s media day over the weekend, when Jones, the quarterback who went from third-stringer to starter as the Buckeyes won the national championship last season, sat down at a table with his 9-month-old daughter, Chloe, on his lap to conduct his interviews.

headline: U.S. Investigates Airbag Rupture in a Volkswagen
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Volkswagen had been one of the few carmakers unaffected by exploding airbags. But on June 7, a driver reported the rupture of Takata airbag in a 2015 Volkswagen Tiguan.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen has been one of the few global automakers unaffected by rupturing airbags made by Takata that are linked to at least eight deaths and more than 100 injuries.

headline: Libya Asks Arab League Countries to Help Battle Islamic State
abstract: An appeal that risks new regional entanglements in what is already at least a three-way conflict among the Islamic State and two rival Libyan factions.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Islamic State militants who control the Libyan city of Surt are resorting to mass beheadings, public crucifixions and other stark displays of brutality as they seek to crush an insurrection, the foreign minister of Libya’s internationally recognized government said Tuesday at a meeting of Arab diplomats here.

headline: Howard Brody, an Expert in the Physics of Tennis, Dies at 83
abstract: Professor Brody began his professional life as a particle physicist before a chance encounter in the 1970s caused him to train his eye on tennis.
lead_paragraph: Howard Brody, the world’s foremost physicist of tennis, who explored what happens when the stoppable force known as a ball meets the movable object called a racket, died on Aug. 11 in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 83.

headline: Ex-Officers in Georgia Charged in Death Linked to Taser
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Stun Guns', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Two former policemen in East Point, Ga., each face seven counts in the 2014 death of Gregory L. Towns Jr., 24.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Two former police officers in East Point, Ga., have been charged with felony murder in connection with the 2014 death of a man who was repeatedly shocked with Taser devices while he was handcuffed.

headline: Russian Pagans Continue Ancient Traditions
abstract: Over the past four years, Tatiana Plotnikova has photographed Russian Pagans who follow their ancestors’ traditions in the Mari El Republic.
lead_paragraph: Over the past four years, Tatiana Plotnikova has photographed Russian Pagans who follow their ancestors’ traditions in the Mari El Republic.

headline: W.H.O. Calls ‘Vaccine Hesitancy’ an Increasing Concern Globally
abstract: The organization called the problem “a growing challenge for countries seeking to close the immunization gap.”
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization warned Tuesday of what it called the growing problem of “vaccine hesitancy,” when people delay or refuse vaccines for themselves or their children. In a statement on its website, the organization called the problem “a growing challenge for countries seeking to close the immunization gap.” Globally, the organization said, one in five children still do not receive routine lifesaving immunizations, and 1.5 million children die each year of diseases that could have been thwarted by vaccines.

headline: Bullpen Wobbles in Victory After Parnell Heads to D.L.
abstract: The team said Parnell had right shoulder tendinitis, but Terry Collins suggested the move was made so that Parnell could tweak his mechanics out of the spotlight of a playoff race.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — After Bobby Parnell was booed off the mound Sunday during an embarrassing Mets loss, his manager, Terry Collins, approached him about taking a break. Parnell was obviously still feeling the effects of Tommy John surgery. He might not feel pain, Collins told him, but it was natural for him to need time to regain his touch.

headline: Hillary Clinton Turns to Nevada as a General Election Litmus Test
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Nevada, with its mix of rural and urban areas, a diverse population and lingering economic problems, is viewed as a good early-state indicator.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — On Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton declared this city — with its flashy strip of casinos, rows of middle-class subdivisions and one of the highest unemployment rates in the nation — the perfect place to pitch her campaign message.

headline: New Mexico: Officers to Be Tried for Man’s Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A judge ordered an Albuquerque police officer and a retired detective to stand trial for the 2014 killing of a homeless man who they had accused of illegally camping.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Tuesday ordered an Albuquerque police officer and a retired detective to stand trial for the killing of a homeless man, James Boyd, last year during a long confrontation that started when the police accused Mr. Boyd of illegally camping on the foothills of the Sandia Mountains. The officer, Dominique Perez, and the retired detective, Keith Sandy, will face second-degree murder and manslaughter charges. A video of the shooting, captured by an officer’s lapel camera, set off protests in Albuquerque over the use of force by city police officers, who had fired at civilians at least 37 times in four years. These and other use-of-force incidents were the basis of a scathing report by the Justice Department, which entered into an agreement with the city last October to improve officers’ training, among other changes.

headline: Making Tires From a Desert Shrub Found in the U.S.
abstract: In seeking a domestic source for natural rubber, Cooper Tire and Rubber Company has created a way to make tires with rubber from the guayule plant, which thrives in the Southwest.
lead_paragraph: For years, tire industry executives, as well as government officials and scientists, have sought a domestic source for natural rubber to escape the price fluctuations of imports and, more recently, to avoid petroleum, which is used to make synthetic rubber.

headline: Disagreeing With President, Hillary Clinton Says She Opposes Drilling in Arctic Ocean
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: “The Arctic is a unique treasure,” Mrs. Clinton wrote in a signed Twitter post. “Given what we know now, it’s not worth the risk of drilling.”
lead_paragraph: In a rare disagreement with President Obama, Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday came out against drilling for oil and gas in the Arctic Ocean, one day after the White House granted approval for exploration off the coast of Alaska.

headline: Yankees’ Bryan Mitchell Lands on 7-Day Disabled List
abstract: The pitcher threw his hands up in self-defense, but the ball that struck him was hit with such force that it broke his nose and gave him a concussion.
lead_paragraph: A couple of dozen members of the hard-bitten, not-easily-impressed news media gathered Tuesday around Bryan Mitchell, who was hit in the face by a line drive the night before, when someone asked him about his cap, which the ball ticked off before striking his nose.

headline: South Sudan: U.S. Threatens Sanctions Over Rejection of Pact
abstract: The White House chastised President Salva Kiir of South Sudan on Tuesday for refusing to sign a peace agreement to halt that nation’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: The White House chastised President Salva Kiir of South Sudan on Tuesday for refusing to sign a peace agreement to halt that nation’s civil war, and it threatened to pursue sanctions against “those who undermine the peace process.” Susan E. Rice, the national security adviser, said in a statement that “there must be consequences for those who continue to stand in the way of peace” and that the United States had begun consultations at the United Nations and with regional partners to initiate action in the Security Council. This summer, President Obama met with the region’s leaders during a trip to Africa and urged them to seek an end to the fighting. The leaders agreed to seek sanctions if the warring parties refused to sign a peace deal by Monday. At the deadline, Mr. Kiir declined to sign, saying in a Twitter message: “If it is signed today and then tomorrow we go back to war, then what have we achieved?”

headline: Amazon’s Social Rift
abstract: The recent New York Times article about Amazon inspired an unprecedented online conversation about workplace stress. Here are a few of the thousands of comments posted across the web.
lead_paragraph: The recent New York Times article about Amazon inspired an unprecedented online conversation about workplace stress. Here are a few of the thousands of comments posted across the web.

headline: One Palestinian’s Refusal to Eat Puts Israel in a Bind

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A single Palestinian prisoner’s determination to starve himself to death unless he is freed is flummoxing Israel’s legal, medical, political and security systems.

headline: Times Square’s Topless Women Should Be Regulated, Mayor Says
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said that he sees the women in Times Square covered in little but body paint not as creative artists, but as hustlers.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Tuesday that he sees the women parading around Times Square covered in little but body paint not as creative artists, but as pushy panhandlers whose efforts to separate tourists from their money should be regulated.

headline: Using Technology to Close a Mortgage, and Relieve Stress
abstract: Some lenders are automating the mortgage process with e-closings, and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau says that could make things simpler for borrowers.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has purchased a home knows how stressful the closing of a mortgage loan can be.

headline: For Hillary Clinton, Another Grilling About Emails
abstract: In a testy exchange with Ed Henry of Fox News, Hillary Rodham Clinton defended her handling of the server that hosted the personal email account she exclusively used as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev. — In a testy exchange with Ed Henry of Fox News on Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton defended her handling of the server that hosted the personal email account she exclusively used as secretary of state and reiterated that she did not receive any emails that were marked as classified.

headline: After Swift Exit, Kyrgios Proves Reserved in Loss
abstract: Kyrgios said he might benefit from having more time to regroup before the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: MASON, Ohio — Days after making a remark to an opponent in Montreal that was picked up by on-court microphones and resulted in a $10,000 fine, Nick Kyrgios received a mixed reaction upon his arrival at his opening-round match at the Western & Southern Open.

headline: Video of Man Restrained by San Francisco Police Causes Stir
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Prostheses']
abstract: The video, which was taken on Aug. 4, shows police officers roughly restraining a black man with a prosthetic leg, pinning him to the ground and at points kneeling on the prosthesis.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A video that apparently shows police officers roughly restraining a black man with a prosthetic leg has caused a stir since it was posted to a popular online commentary magazine.

headline: Melva Bucksbaum, Art Collector and Curator, Dies at 82
abstract: One of the country’s leading collectors, Ms. Bucksbaum was a Whitney trustee and established the Bucksbaum Award, which grants an artist $100,000 and an invitation to exhibit at the museum.
lead_paragraph: Melva Bucksbaum, who transformed her childhood passion for collecting dolls and glass animals into a career as one of America’s leading art collectors, curators and patrons, died on Sunday at her home in Aspen, Colo. She was 82.

headline: Health Proposals by Walker and Rubio Are Less Concerned About the Poor
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Both Republican presidential candidates would replace Obamacare by giving individuals tax credits they could use to shop for plans.
lead_paragraph: Obamacare gives federal money to poor people to help them get health insurance. Scott Walker, Wisconsin’s governor, has a replacement plan. It would give federal money to old people instead.

headline: Tony Gleaton’s Defiantly Vivid Photographs
abstract: Tony Gleaton turned his back on a career in New York fashion and embarked on an itinerant artistic quest.
lead_paragraph: Tony Gleaton turned his back on a career in New York fashion and embarked on an itinerant artistic quest.

headline: Tony Gleaton, 67, Dies, Leaving Legacy in Pictures of Africans in the Americas
abstract: Mr. Gleaton traveled light, by bus, without assistants, complex equipment or luxury lodgings, to document the lives of black cowboys and create images of the African diaspora in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: Tony Gleaton, a photographer who turned his back on a career in New York fashion and embarked on an itinerant artistic quest, documenting the lives of black cowboys and creating images of the African diaspora in Latin America, died on Friday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 67.

headline: Leader at Washington National Cathedral Steps Down
abstract: The Very Rev. Gary Hall says he wants to give a younger dean time to gain trust to guide Washington National Cathedral through the financial and demographic challenges ahead.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Very Rev. Gary Hall, the dean of Washington National Cathedral, announced on Tuesday that he would step down at year’s end to make way for a younger leader who can help guide the century-old Episcopal church as it tries to overcome financial and demographic challenges.

headline: After Friction, Renewed Zen for de Blasio
abstract: Since weathering poor approval ratings and attacks on a range of issues, Mayor Bill de Blasio has adopted a subtle shift in tone, perhaps heeding the worries of advisers.
lead_paragraph: He was the mayor of populist messages, pledging to crack down on toplessness in Times Square, a recent pet cause of the New York City tabloids, whose campaigns he typically ignores.

headline: Review: ‘Informed Consent’ Tests the Ethics of Genetic Research
abstract: This play at the Duke on 42nd Street is about an anthropologist whose deeply personal reasons for pursuing her work lead her into questionable moral territory.
lead_paragraph: In “Informed Consent,” a thoughtful and engrossing play by Deborah Zoe Laufer, a research scientist specializing in genetic diseases finds herself embroiled in controversy when her fierce dedication to her work, and her deeply personal reasons for pursuing it, lead her into murky ethical waters.

headline: Similar to a Cor Anglais
abstract: Stay hydrated with this puzzle by Timothy Polin.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes a crossword puzzle theme can take you out of the act of routinely inserting letters into squares, and evoke pleasant memories of experiences past. [Uh oh. Proustian flashback ahead. Everyone buckle your seat belts. — Ed.]

headline: Another Red Sox Shake-Up as Dave Dombrowski Is Hired
abstract: In the latest seismic shake-up for the franchise, Boston hired Dombrowski as president of baseball operations, and Ben Cherington declined to stay on as general manager.
lead_paragraph: Say this for the Boston Red Sox: When a season turns sour, they do not stand still. As they lurch to the finish of a third wretched season in the last four years, the Red Sox on Tuesday hired Dave Dombrowski as president of baseball operations. It was only the latest seismic shake-up for the franchise.

headline: Scott Walker to Increase Attacks on Washington
abstract: Facing popular candidates who have never held office, Gov. Scott Walker looks to distinguish himself from the other politicians running by attacking Washington.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin suggested to donors on Monday that he was pivoting to a message more directly attacking Washington to fend off a growing threat to his campaign from candidates who have never held elected office, such as Donald J. Trump.

headline: Charges Brought Against 14-Year-Old Who Was Shot by Officers in Trenton
abstract: The teenager, identified by his lawyer as Radazz Hearns, was accused in Juvenile Court of gun possession and aggravated assault.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in New Jersey filed charges on Tuesday against a 14-year-old Trenton boy who was shot by law enforcement officers as he ran from them.

headline: Admiral Says ‘No Reason’ to Bar Women From SEALs
abstract: The Navy is on track to open up its storied SEAL teams to women, a top admiral said in an interview with a military-focused publication.
lead_paragraph: The Navy is on track to open up its storied SEAL teams to women, a top admiral said in an interview with a military-focused publication, the latest sign of a movement to widen access to roles long forbidden to women across all branches of the military.

headline: Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez Ends Drought With a Pivotal Grand Slam
abstract: The Twins led by 4-1 before Rodriguez hit a grand slam in the seventh inning. The Yankees tacked on three more runs in the eighth.
lead_paragraph: When Alex Rodriguez arrived at home plate Tuesday night with the bases loaded in the seventh inning and the Yankees trailing the Minnesota Twins by three runs, chants of “Let’s Go A-Rod” seemed like wishful thinking.

headline: Bud Yorkin, Writer and Producer of ‘All in the Family,’ Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Yorkin and his partner, Norman Lear, followed “All in the Family” with hits including “The Jeffersons,” “Sanford and Son” and “Maude.”
lead_paragraph: Bud Yorkin, who broke into television as a repairman and less than a decade later teamed with the producer Norman Lear to create pioneering, provocative and singularly successful satirical series including “All in the Family,” died on Tuesday at his home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 89.

headline: An Oasis in a Changing South Bronx
abstract: Mott Haven is rapidly developing, and Charlies Bar & Kitchen offers an alternative to catching the train to Manhattan for a special drink.
lead_paragraph: Mott Haven is rapidly developing, and Charlies Bar & Kitchen offers an alternative to catching the train to Manhattan for a special drink.

headline: Charlies Bar & Kitchen Is a Pioneering Dining Option in a Poor Bronx Neighborhood
abstract: Mott Haven, in the nation’s poorest congressional district, is rapidly developing, and a restaurant in a former piano factory built in 1886 is an example.
lead_paragraph: For most of its recent past, Mott Haven was known as a South Bronx industrial stretch, dotted with auto parts shops and vacant buildings. It had the woeful distinction in the last census of being in the poorest congressional district in the country. But longtime residents, and newcomers who venture across the nearby Third Avenue Bridge, see a neighborhood in full transformation, and many of them are drawn to a local watering hole with the sleek look of Lower Manhattan and the casual feel of the Bronx.

headline: Berlin-Style Tiki on the River Spree, Home to a New Artist’s Enclave
abstract: Chef Gordon W. shares a recipe for his smoke-roasted, red sweet pepper naan pizza with tandoori salmon.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, east of Berlin’s city center on the banks of the River Spree, and despite the August heat, an invite-only crowd of local and international creative types arrived just before sunset, by land and by water, to enjoy the latest in a series of “Jackie O” outdoor parties. Their host, the Berlin-based developer Christian Rosche, is known for bringing together interesting artists, collectors, investors, DJs, chefs and scenesters to help cultivate an active, creative community in Berlin. As Rosche says, for him, it’s all about “catalyzing magic moments, where people are so happy and grateful to come together, be themselves and share their talents, and truly connect.”

headline: The Romantic Drama of the Victorian Era
abstract: This season, the emphasis is on black, with lace and organza that simultaneously veil the body and reveal it.

abstract: This word has appeared in three New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: habituate • \hə-ˈbi-chə-ˌwat\ • verb

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FX) PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: THE CURSE OF THE BLACK PEARL (2003) Johnny Depp portrays Capt. Jack Sparrow, the grooviest swashbuckler on the bounding main, in this swaggering action adventure. And why shouldn’t he swagger, since he reportedly turned to Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones for inspiration? Orlando Bloom (above right, with Mr. Depp) is the blacksmith Will Turner, Sparrow’s unlikely ally. Keira Knightley is the damsel in distress and the love of Will’s life. The film, directed by Gore Verbinski, “raises one of the most overlooked and important cinematic questions of our time: Can a movie maintain the dramatic integrity of a theme park ride?,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “In this case the answer is — sure.”

headline: For My Father, Resurrecting the Ancient Rituals
abstract: My family is so assimilated that I had to research Chinese burial traditions online, but our heritage is passed down in other ways.
lead_paragraph: Even after the Parkinson’s diagnosis, my father seemed invincible. When a truck sideswiped his car, flipping it over, he hung upside down by his seat belt, his glasses on and intact. He’d taken a taxi home from the hospital, rather than calling my mother for a ride and upsetting her. And he’d survived falls, cracked one kneecap, and then the other, bruised his face, and healed each time. Iron bones, to match an iron will.

headline: Amityville, N.Y., Laced With Canals
abstract: Amityville has a variety of home options, from spacious Victorians to smaller ranches and updated bungalows.
lead_paragraph: After Sage and Eric Meyer were married in 2009, they stepped up their saving for a house. They were renting in Amity Harbor, N.Y., bordering the village of Amityville; avid swimmers and boaters, they knew they wanted to buy on the water. The couple also wanted to live near Amityville Memorial High School, where Ms. Meyer was an English teacher.

headline: Rebecca Stead’s ‘Goodbye Stranger’
abstract: A seventh grader who survived a near-fatal accident faces evolving friendships and new pitfalls in Rebecca Stead’s novel.
lead_paragraph: It’s really no wonder 12-year-olds appear frequently not only in novels written for children but also in those written for adults. Taken together, the characters of some classic literature might give the appearance of a middle-school class trip — with the likes of Carson McCullers, William Golding and Vladimir Nabokov in charge, making use of the power of being 12, which is essentially the power of the threshold. If you write a book about characters of this age, you get to document that fleeting moment of change from childhood to not-childhood, when the only person looking out for you might well be you. McCullers’s brilliant 1946 novel “The Member of the Wedding” used a spiky, soulful 12-year-old girl, Frankie Addams, as a vessel for ideas about, among other things, aloneness — both the day-to-day kind and the mortality kind. Frankie’s yearning to be part of something bigger consumes her. As she describes her brother and his bride, “They are the we of me.”

headline: ‘A Window Opens,’ by Elisabeth Egan
abstract: A bibliophile’s new full-time job disrupts her cherished work-life equilibrium.
lead_paragraph: Early on in Elisabeth Egan’s debut novel, “A Window Opens,” the narrator and main character, Alice Pearse — part-time magazine editor, full-time wife and mother of three children under the age of 12 — self-consciously invokes that familiar cultural catchphrase, “work-life balance,” admitting she’s “the tiniest bit smug” about her own equilibrium. “I wasn’t part of the high-powered commuter set and I wasn’t a PTA insider,” Alice says, “but I got to dip into both worlds.” Think of it as the Chekhov’s gun of chick-lit: If, in ­Chapter 2, a character appreciates her tidily arranged life, you can bet she’s on the verge of losing her sanctimonious footing.

headline: ‘The Prize,’ by Dale Russakoff
abstract: What happened when two politicians and a tech billionaire set out to reform a city’s schools.
lead_paragraph: In America, education was long seen as the great equalizer, but that has become mostly myth. So, over the past decade, there has been a vigorous effort to fortify and rebuild our schools, and in this there is a recognition that we have failed our children, especially those living in poverty, those for whom education could — and should — be transformational. From Chicago to New Orleans, school reform has been engineered by the well heeled and well connected — from hedge fund managers to corporate heads to directors of foundations — who believe that with the right kind of teachers and pedagogy, and with a ­business-like administration, schooling can trump the daily burdens and indignities of growing up poor. “No excuses” has become the rallying cry of the reformers.

lead_paragraph: The great philosopher Homer Simpson once memorably described alcohol as “the cause of and solution to all of life’s problems.” Internet advertising is a bit like that — the funder of and terrible nuisance baked into everything you do online.

headline: Myanmar’s Many Funks and Flavors
abstract: Learning to make tohu thoke, a Burmese tamarind-shallot ‘‘tofu’’ salad.
lead_paragraph: All I’ve ever known about Myanmar has been from the news: democracy advocates silenced with bullets; opposition politicians imprisoned by the government; soldiers opening a new campaign to oppress ethnic minorities. But in June, eating noodles with lemongrass broth at a rented high-school cafeteria in Queens, I finally got to see Myanmar as something else: a homeland, a people. Myo Moe, a photographer who grew up in Yangon, when its name was Rangoon, when the country was still Burma, invited me to the Moegyo Burmese Food Fair, a fund-raiser for Burmese orphans. ‘‘Here, our community is very tight,’’ she said. ‘‘We come from different backgrounds, but the food connects us — it’s how we’re related to each other. We can’t get it in any store, so when we have our food, we don’t even care about our backgrounds anymore.’’ It was a lovely, hopeful thing to hear about people who come from a place in the midst of a 60-year ethnic conflict.

headline: The New Making It

headline: The Creative Apocalypse That Wasn’t
keywords: ['Culture (Arts)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Movies', 'Art', 'Music', 'Books and Literature', 'Television', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: In the digital economy, it was supposed to be impossible to make money by making art. Instead, creative careers are thriving — but in complicated and unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: On July 11, 2000, in one of the more unlikely moments in the history of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Orrin Hatch handed the microphone to Metallica’s drummer, Lars Ulrich, to hear his thoughts on art in the age of digital reproduction. Ulrich’s primary concern was a new online service called Napster, which had debuted a little more than a year before. As Ulrich explained in his statement, the band began investigating Napster after unreleased versions of one of their songs began playing on radio stations around the country. They discovered that their entire catalog of music was available there for free.

headline: Shadows in São Paulo
abstract: Obsessed with an image of four men on a rooftop in Brazil, the author went on a quest to find its origins.
lead_paragraph: Are they gangsters? Are they bankers? There are certain photographs that seem to have been pulled out of the world of dreams. ‘‘Men on a Rooftop,’’ by the Swiss photographer René Burri (1933–2014), is one such picture. The photograph, taken in São Paulo in 1960, shows four men on a rooftop, seen from the vantage point of an even higher building. Far below them, stark in black and white, are tram lines and cars, and tiny pedestrians so perfectly matched with their long shadows that they look like miniaturized sculptures by Giacometti.

headline: How Texas Could Set National Template for Limiting Abortion Access
keywords: ['ABORTION', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'States (US)']
abstract: Its restrictions will be reviewed by the Supreme Court and are being copied by other states.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to defund Planned Parenthood and calls for tighter abortion laws at the Republican presidential debate have moved abortion rights back into the national spotlight. But the real fight is at the state level. The next big Supreme Court case involving abortion is expected to come from Texas [Update: The Supreme Court is hearing the case], where a 2013 law led to the closing of many clinics and inspired abortion opponents around the country to propose similar restrictions.

headline: Handling a Racist Remark in the Workplace
abstract: The ethicists consider how an employee should respond after learning that colleagues praised an anti-Semitic text.
lead_paragraph: I represent a real-estate developer in Florida. Recently an employee of one of the developer’s commercial tenants confided to me that he overheard an administrator at his company tell another employee that she had just read a book called ‘‘The Protocols of the Elders of Zion’’ and thought it contained excellent points. The person with whom she was speaking, a department manager, responded that it was a great book and that it must be legitimate because it was endorsed by Henry Ford. I’m uncomfortable that this type of conversation might reflect a negative aspect of our tenant’s company culture. I’m tempted to raise this with the general counsel of the company, with whom I negotiated the lease — but for what purpose? I can’t betray the confidence, so what am I trying to accomplish? I can’t get over that employees working in a respected chain could really accept any premise in that anti-Semitic rant. I thought the reach of the book was limited to uneducated neo-Nazis, but these are educated people in positions of authority. Something just feels wrong here, and I would appreciate some guidance on where to go with this. NAME WITHHELD

headline: 1915: German Corruption Fund Bared

The Washington correspondent of the ‘‘Morning Post’’ quotes the Herald as stating that Germany has raised $20,000,000 in the United States since March. Five thousand dollars, the Herald says, was spent in promoting the Bryanite meeting held in New York, a couple of months ago, and $100,000 in getting up the so-called ‘‘peace conference’’ meeting in Chicago. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 20, 1915
