abstract: Is gender flux a trend with legs or just a passing fancy?
lead_paragraph: Is gender flux a trend with legs or just a passing fancy?

headline: Jared Fogle, Ex-Subway Pitchman, to Plead Guilty to Child Sex and Pornography Charges
abstract: Mr. Fogle is expected to admit to paying for sex with minors and distributing explicit images. He will pay $1.4 million to 14 victims and faces prison time.
lead_paragraph: Jared Fogle, the former pitchman for Subway sandwich restaurants, notified a federal court on Wednesday that he would plead guilty to sex acts with minors and distribution of child pornography.

headline: How Not To Be Read (Trivial)
abstract: Amazing that people still do this.
lead_paragraph: A public service announcement for those who want a hearing: if you send me an email with an attached letter, which says “Please read attached letter” without any indication of what it’s about, you should know what will (or actually won’t) happen. Life is short, and if you can’t be bothered to take the time to say more, I can’t be bothered to open an attachment.

headline: In Israel, Huckabee Criticizes Iran Deal
abstract: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, said during a news conference in Jerusalem on Wednesday that Iran intends “to bring death to America.”
lead_paragraph: Mike Huckabee, the Republican presidential candidate, said during a news conference in Jerusalem on Wednesday that Iran intends “to bring death to America.”

headline: Thai Police Seek ‘Foreign Man’ in Bombing of Bangkok Shrine
abstract: They released a sketch of a man with features they characterized as Caucasian, Arab or mixed race and said they believed he had two accomplices.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The Thai authorities on Wednesday issued an arrest warrant describing the person sought in the bombing of a Bangkok shrine this week as a “foreign man,” and said they believed that he had at least two accomplices.

headline: Trump and the Charisma Premium
abstract: The superficial but important reason why having Trump on stage might actually hurt Jeb.
lead_paragraph: Having used my Sunday column to double down on one 2016 prediction — that Hillary’s still a mortal lock to be the Democratic nominee — let me use this post to quickly hedge a more recent bet: Namely, that the rise of Donald Trump might be a much-needed gift to Jeb Bush’s struggling “frontrunner” campaign. I offered various arguments three weeks ago for why this might be so, and most of them might yet be vindicated once we leave the preliminary phase of the campaign, Jeb starts spending ad dollars in earnest, the establishment field gets winnowed and voters get serious about the nominating process. But here’s one passage from my column that I want to revisit, because I’m not sure the first debate was kind to it:

headline: Police: More Suspects in Bangkok Bombing
abstract: Thailand’s national police chief said on Wednesday that there is likely more than one person involved in the fatal explosion at a Bangkok shrine on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s national police chief said on Wednesday that there is likely more than one person involved in the fatal explosion at a Bangkok shrine on Monday.

headline: Uber Raises $100 Million From Tata of India
abstract: The strategic partnership is meant to help Uber expand its business in India, one of the world’s biggest markets.
lead_paragraph: Uber has picked up another strategic investor.

headline: Pension-cutters and Privatizers, Oh My
abstract: More ideas plutocrats love but voters hate.
lead_paragraph: I wrote Monday about the strange phenomenon of Republicans lining up to propose cuts to Social Security, a deeply unpopular policy that is, however, also a really bad idea. How unpopular? Lee Drutman has the data: only 6 percent of American voters support Social Security cuts, while a majority want it increased. I argued that this apparent act of political self-destructiveness probably reflected an attempt to curry favor with wealthy donors, who are very much at odds with the general public on this issue:

headline: Bombs at 3 Churches in Las Cruces, New Mexico, Confound the Authorities
abstract: Detonations at two churches this month, and an unexploded device at a third, caused no injuries. As for motives and suspects, the hunt continues.
lead_paragraph: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — Two homemade bombs exploded early this month during busy Sunday services at Roman Catholic and Baptist churches here, while a third, undetonated explosive was discovered on Friday near a leaking sprinkler valve at a Presbyterian church, fueling unease in this placid city in southern New Mexico, the second largest in the state.

headline: Alongside a Doctor’s Care, a Dose of Traditional Healing
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Indigenous People', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: An effort to make the Chilean public health system more inclusive has taken an unusual turn, as non-indigenous patients increasingly look beyond Western medicine.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The first thing Manuel Lincovil does is take a look at the urine. A machi, or spiritual leader and healer of the indigenous Mapuche people, he watches the liquid settle as he shakes the glass jar, learning of his patient’s experiences, ailments and sorrows.

headline: Cécile McLorin Salvant, With Refined Power, Performs at the Jazz Standard
abstract: This singer, who has grown more expressive in her vocals and more beguiling in handling an audience, will be joined by the Aaron Diehl Trio as she previews a new album.
lead_paragraph: When Cécile McLorin Salvant released her sanguine debut album, “Woman Child” (Mack Avenue), she represented something new in jazz singing, even in those moments (and they were many) when newness seemed to be the furthest thing from her mind. That was two years ago, and she has only strengthened her art since, growing more expressive with her vocal gift and more beguiling in her handling of an audience.

headline: A Dance-Theater Work Explores the Life of Pearl S. Buck
abstract: “Pearl” is an ambitious program that blends East and West in telling the story of this Nobel- and Pulitzer Prize-winning writer.
lead_paragraph: Come fall, you can expect an avalanche of biopics jockeying for awards consideration; Hollywood loves dramatic life stories. Dance, on the other hand, has never been particularly interested in biographical narrative. So “Pearl,” an ambitious dance-theater work exploring the life of the Nobel- and Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Pearl S. Buck, is a rare breed in both form and content. Buck was born in West Virginia and spent decades in China. She was a prolific writer (best known for the 1931 novel “The Good Earth”), an adoption advocate and a feminist — an intriguing muse for a dance spectacle.

headline: From Holding a Clipboard to Carrying a Franchise’s Hopes
abstract: Last season, only half of the 32 N.F.L. teams used the same starting quarterback in all 16 regular-season games. And the teams with quarterback problems often seem to have them year after year.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. teams are completing their depth charts, but for the most part, they know who will be the starting quarterback, the most important slot.

headline: A Pianist Returns to Le Poisson Rouge, and LoftOpera Heads to Brooklyn
abstract: Taka Kigawa’s program at Le Poisson Rouge will include both books of Debussy’s “Images”; the LoftOpera’s mezzo-soprano Rebecca Ringle and the baritone Joel Herold will perform at the Muse.
lead_paragraph: Playing with suavity and nuance, Taka Kigawa took the stage at Le Poisson Rouge last August with a daunting program: all of Pierre Boulez’s works for piano solo. On Aug. 24, Mr. Kigawa returns to the same space with pieces in the Boulez orbit, by one of his great precursors and by two who’ve been influenced by him. The concert includes both books of Debussy’s “Images” alongside Marco Stroppa’s “Traiettoria ... deviata” for piano and live electronics and Tristan Murail’s “Territoires de l’oubli.” (7:30 p.m., lepoissonrouge.com.)

headline: The Imperfect Wim Wenders: Touring Films by the German Director
abstract: The IFC Center will host a retrospective of his films, including “Wings of Desire,” “Paris, Texas” and “Alice in the Cities.”
lead_paragraph: The German director Wim Wenders has a pile of awards from Cannes and other festivals as well as three Oscar nominations, but American moviegoers who stick to blockbusters probably remain unfamiliar with him. Perhaps a touring retrospective organized by Janus Films that begins a monthlong run on Aug. 28 at the IFC Center will serve as a small corrective. It features 12 of his films, including early works and some of his better-known movies from the 1980s. Among those is the haunting “Wings of Desire,” a fantasy about angels who eavesdrop on and sometimes comfort inhabitants of Berlin.

headline: ‘On the Town’ Is Pulling Up Anchor Soon
abstract: New York won’t be quite the same helluva town after Sept. 6, when this happy revival closes. Misty Copeland, the reigning It girl of American ballet, joins the cast Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: New York won’t be quite the same helluva town after Sept. 6.

headline: In TNT’s ‘Public Morals,’ Ed Burns Is on the Vice Beat in ’60s New York
abstract: Mr. Burns, who created this police drama, plays Terry Muldoon, a New York police officer trawling the city’s underbelly with the public morals division.
lead_paragraph: Prostitution, gambling, after-hours clubs, gay bars — you name it, residents crave it. And everything is against the law in the 1960s. But who wants to make arrests for crimes that aren’t really hurting anyone? Not Terry Muldoon, an officer with the New York Police Department’s public morals division. “So, then, what exactly do we do here?” asks Jimmy Shea, the handsome newcomer. “We do what has been done for the last hundred years: We manage it for the city,” Muldoon says. “Think of us as the landlords, and if you want to be in business, you got to pay your rent. Do you understand what I am telling you?” Shea does. “Now I’m only going to ask you this this one time,” Muldoon says. “Are you in?”

headline: Target Reports Stronger Earnings After Cost Cuts and Job Losses
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Company Reports', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Target bucked industry trends and beat Wall Street estimates after cutting jobs and closing stores.
lead_paragraph: In a season dotted with notable earnings misses among retailers, Target bucked the industry trends by reporting strong earnings on Wednesday, its bottom line lifted by brisk sales of apparel and home goods as well as intensive cost-cutting.

headline: Pimp C in a Journalist’s Back Pages
abstract: The Houston rapper Pimp C, who died in 2007, is now the subject of a biography — and a vivid memory for a New York Times journalist.
lead_paragraph: I can tell you about the moment I heard Pimp C was dead — Dec. 4, 2007; at work in my office at Vibe; nervously refreshing TMZ, which had broken the news; feeling nauseous. The room hummed with the white noise that takes over when you no longer register what’s happening around you. Minutes later, a colleague knocked on my door, disrupting the quiet, and we looked at each other wordlessly, our jaws quivering but holding firm. My boss came by to ask if I was all right. I wasn’t.

headline: Destroyer Takes Another Sharp Turn Toward the Fringe
abstract: In “Poison Season,” Dan Bejar of Destroyer rekindles his favorite inspirations after stretching into new territory with “Kaputt” in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Dan Bejar is proudly, defiantly out of touch.

headline: Spinning Heartache Into Humor: Tig Notaro on Cancer, Her HBO Special and Going Topless
abstract: Ms. Notaro, with her first hourlong comedy special, “Boyish Girl Interrupted,” on HBO, is having one of the best years of her life three years after having one of her worst.
lead_paragraph: Next time you have a terrible year, feel free to call it a Tig Year. Because the comedian Tig Notaro’s 2012 was one for the ages.

headline: In Jerusalem, Mike Huckabee Calls West Bank Part of Israel
abstract: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas, visiting Jerusalem and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, said Wednesday that the entire occupied West Bank was part of Israel, leaving no room for a Palestinian state there.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM – Staking out the most extreme position on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in the crowded field of Republican candidates – one to the right of even Israel’s conservative government – former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas said Wednesday that the entire occupied West Bank was part of Israel, leaving no room for a Palestinian state there.

headline: Watch Your Language
abstract: In a new picture book, a young bird discovers the strange power of curse words, thanks to his father.
lead_paragraph: “But why is it a bad word?” That’s a question parents reliably face as a former toddler enters the world of bigger kids, where a curse word can fly into the room like some confused baby bat, thrilling the kids and rattling the grownups. Curses are one of the great mysteries of human society, a testament to the weird and wonderful power of language. Hearing a small child cuss can be extremely funny but also, I suspect even for the most “relaxed” and mellow parent, unsettling.

headline: Assemble: Making Things Happen
abstract: For this renegade architecture collective, what goes on in and around a space is just as important as the space itself.
lead_paragraph: For this renegade architecture collective, what goes on in and around a space is just as important as the space itself.

headline: Obama to Visit New Orleans for Hurricane Katrina Anniversary
abstract: Mr. Obama will use the 10th anniversary of the disaster to tout his administration’s efforts to restore the economy and infrastructure of the region, according to the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will travel to New Orleans next week for the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, one of the costliest disasters in United States history.

headline: What I Learned From a Disgraced Art Show on Harlem
abstract: An art critic remembers “Harlem on My Mind,” a 1969 show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art widely viewed within black cultural circles as an insult.
lead_paragraph: Some first-time art encounters are life-changers, and you know it instantly. They zap you, cast a spell, send you back out with your eyes and mind rewired. Other encounters are just as deep, but don’t seem to be, because you’re not ready for them. You don’t know what you’re looking at, though some day you will, and you’ll wish you could be back there again, equipped with all you’ve learned. “Harlem on My Mind” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was that kind of show for me.

headline: 1965: Okinawa Visit Prompts Riot
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Japan’s prime minister is met with leftist protesters during a visit to Okinawa in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NAHA, Okinawa — Nightlong leftist demonstrations tore this Pacific Island capital today and forced visiting Japanese Prime Minister Eisaku Sato to take refuge in a U.S. military camp. Mr. Sato came to emphasize Japanese ties with the Ryukyu Islands. Two thousand rioters fought with sticks and bottles against club-wielding, steel-helmeted police. Police said 17 demonstrators, mostly students and unionists, were hurt. The leftist mobs oppose Mr. Sato’s support of U.S. Vietnam policy, and his lukewarm position on reversion of Okinawa and the Ryukyu islands to Japan. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 20, 1965

headline: Hillary Clinton Asks to Have Donors Pay for Food and Drinks at Her Fund-Raisers
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign wants to have donors foot the bill for those appetizers and gin-and-tonics -– not to mention valet parking — at some fund-raisers, and also follow Federal Election Commission finance rules.
lead_paragraph: All those pigs-in-a-blanket can get pricey.

headline: Hard Climb Awaits Sebastian Coe, New President of I.A.A.F.
abstract: Sebastian Coe was elected president of the International Association of Atlhetics Federations on Wednesday in Beijing and set out his ambitions, including an assault on doping.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If Sebastian Coe thinks beating Steve Ovett to the finish line or running a successful London Olympics was tough, he is now about to embark on something that looks a great deal more daunting.

headline: Watch Live: Trevor Noah on Race and Identity
abstract: Trevor Noah shares his perspectives on race and identity with John Eligon, a New York Times reporter, and an audience of students.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Noah shares his perspectives on race and identity with John Eligon, a New York Times reporter, and an audience of students.

headline: Gun Laws Associated With Lower Suicide Rates
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Medicine and Health', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: A new study found that four gun laws are associated with lower rates of firearm suicide and lower overall rates of suicide as well.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that four gun laws are significantly associated with lower rates of firearm suicide.

headline: The Big Picture on the Mini-Movie in ‘Sinister 2’ and Others
abstract: In horror films like “Sinister 2” and dramedies like “Me and Earl and the Dying Girl,” films-within-films are coming into their own.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in an alternate universe, a multiplex is playing a curious slate of motion pictures: “The Dogwalker,” “Habeas Corpus,” “Mant!” and “Camp Bloodbath.” If you don’t recognize any of these titles, there’s a good reason: All of them are imaginary films that pop up in actual movies. We catch a glimpse of these fake flicks when characters watch them in “Trainwreck,” “The Player,” “Matinee” and “The Final Girls.”

headline: Carly Rae Jepsen Moves on From ‘Call Me Maybe’
abstract: Joe Coscarelli and Jon Caramanica discuss Ms. Jepsen’s new album on this week’s Popcast.
lead_paragraph: Joe Coscarelli and Jon Caramanica discuss Ms. Jepsen’s new album on this week’s Popcast.

headline: Mexican Worker in Trump Hotel Criticizes Donald Trump’s Views, on Video
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Ricardo Aca, 24, who works at the Koi SoHo restaurant, a tenant of the Trump SoHo hotel, spoke out against the presidential candidate’s comments on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Ricardo Aca knew he could be fired. But he wanted the camera to roll anyway.

headline: In Clintons’ Town, a Call to Move a Prom Over Donald Trump’s Politics
abstract: In the heart of Clinton-land, another one of Donald J. Trump’s business interests is under pressure because of his remarks about Mexican immigrants: his Westchester County golf club in New York that hosts high school proms.
lead_paragraph: First there was Univision and the beauty queens, then NBC, then the top chefs. Now, in the heart of Clintonland, another one of Donald J. Trump’s business interests is under pressure because of his remarks about Mexican immigrants: his Westchester County golf club, which hosts high school proms.

headline: David Ortiz Not an Easy Choice for the Hall of Fame
abstract: Ortiz has three major strikes against him, each of which has been enough for voters to exclude other players in the past.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz has often seemed like a giant among men. His larger-than-life personality, his reputation for significant home runs, his three World Series rings with Boston (after more than 80 years of Red Sox futility) and his nickname (Big Papi) have made him an integral part of baseball’s narrative over the last 13 seasons.

headline: Kasich Discusses His Record on Education
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a presidential candidate, attended a Republican summit meeting on education in New Hampshire on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a presidential candidate, attended a Republican summit meeting on education in New Hampshire on Wednesday.

headline: Mike Huckabee Misses the Point of Black Lives Matter
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In saying “all lives matter,” he ignores the fact that the lives of African Americans have come under special and deadly threat.
lead_paragraph: When dominant racial, ethnic or religious groups are challenged by minorities who still suffer from discrimination, intolerance, hatred and violence, those dominant groups sometimes respond by saying that everyone’s rights should be respected and that it breeds division to single out the treatment of specific groups.

headline: Verbatim: John Kasich Takes On Teachers’ Attitudes
abstract: “If I were, not president, but if I were king in America, I would abolish all teachers’ lounges where they sit together and worry how woe is us.” — John Kasich, at an education forum in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a Republican presidential candidate, discussing fear-mongering done by teachers’ unions at an education forum in New Hampshire.

headline: No Suspension of Arguments as Tom Brady Case Becomes a Test of Wills
abstract: The standoff between the N.F.L. and the Patriots quarterback deepened as the league and the players’ union made oral arguments in federal court.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brady appeared to get the upper hand in his seven-month dispute with the N.F.L. on Wednesday when a judge peppered a lawyer for the league with questions at a hearing.

headline: Jared Fogle’s Guilty Plea
abstract: Mr. Fogle, who is best known as a Subway spokesman, pleaded guilty to “distributing and receiving visual depictions of minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct.”
lead_paragraph: Mr. Fogle, who is best known as a Subway spokesman, pleaded guilty to “distributing and receiving visual depictions of minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct.”

headline: George Pataki, in Presidential Bid, Fights to Jog Voters’ Memories
abstract: Mr. Pataki, one of the 17 Republican contenders, spends a lot of time reminding people that he used to be governor of New York.
lead_paragraph: WINDHAM, N.H. — As former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York strolled through the luncheon for seniors, bending his 6-foot-5 frame downward to make small talk over a soundtrack of square-dance music, he earned a rare smile of recognition. A retired high school teacher, Raymond Harmacinski, began to praise Mr. Pataki’s record when a note of uncertainty crept into his voice.

headline: Making the New East Village Old Again in ‘Ten Thousand Saints’
abstract: The directors Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini discuss how they made the East Village look vintage in their new film.
lead_paragraph: The East Village ain’t what it used to be. It’s a lament heard from many New Yorkers who knew the neighborhood in the 1980s, before gentrification replaced abandoned storefronts and artists’ squats with luxury condos and banks.

headline: Robert Menendez Offers Unrealistic Plan for Iran
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His proposal calls for new negotiations, new demands and, effectively, a pre-endorsement for war.
lead_paragraph: It was disappointing, although not unexpected, that Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has declared his opposition to the Iran nuclear deal. He has been skeptical, bordering on hostile, from the start.

headline: La Monte Young Is Still Patiently Working on a Glacial Scale
abstract: The composer prepares the latest version of Trio for Strings.
lead_paragraph: “The question is, who decides what music should be?” the composer La Monte Young asked during a recent interview. “What is music, and why is it music, and how did music start?” Sitting in his cluttered loft in TriBeCa, Mr. Young had just been ruminating on the creation myths of Indian music, and continued on to briefly address marches, bagpipes and Dizzy Gillespie before arriving at the conclusion to this circuitous historical trajectory: his own Trio for Strings, from 1958.

headline: China’s Carbon Dioxide Emissions May Have Been Overstated by More Than 10%
abstract: A study finds that the low quality of coal in China, containing less carbon, and its inefficient use means less carbon dioxide was emitted than previously estimated.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Scientists may have been overestimating China’s emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas driving global warming, by more than 10 percent, because of inaccurate assumptions about the country’s coal-burning, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline: Chromebooks Gaining on iPads in School Sector
abstract: Last year, about 3.9 million Chromebooks were shipped in the education sector, an increase in unit sales of more than 310 percent compared with the previous year, IDC said.
lead_paragraph: As school districts across the country increasingly invest in technology for their students, the volume of personal computers in the classroom is surging.

headline: Wall Street Journal Criticizes Iranian Reports on Its Reporter
abstract: The Journal said reports in Iran accusing the newspaper and a correspondent, Farnaz Fassihi, of conspiring against the government were false and scurrilous.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday criticized what it described as false Iranian state media reports that accused the newspaper and one of its veteran correspondents of conspiring against Iran’s government.

headline: Jeb Bush Uses Caution on Dicey Subject of School Standards
abstract: “If people don’t like Common Core, fine,” former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida said at an education policy forum in Londonderry, N.H. “Just make sure your standards are much higher than they were before.”
lead_paragraph: Common Core is Jeb Bush’s Achilles’ heel when it comes to courting many conservatives, and on Wednesday the former Florida governor treaded carefully over the subject.

headline: How to Style Fall’s Victorian Look for 21st-Century Girls
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: If high-neck collars and loads of ruffles and black lace smack of period drama, consider that the Old World look is easily styled for this fall. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: If high-neck collars and loads of ruffles and black lace smack of period drama, consider that the Old World look is easily styled for this fall. Here’s how.

headline: Pastis Plans to Open in Gansevoort Market in 2017
abstract: Keith McNally says his crowd-pleasing brasserie-style restaurant will have a new “look, menu and style of food.”
lead_paragraph: Keith McNally’s crowd-pleasing brasserie-style restaurant Pastis, which anchored the meatpacking district from 1999 and closed last year because of building construction, has found a new home in the Gansevoort Market, a collection of stands selling foods that opened about a year ago at 52 Gansevoort Street, near the new Whitney Museum.

headline: Trump in a Box
abstract: What’s in a name?
lead_paragraph: As pundits are discovering to their horror, there’s probably more to the Trump phenomenon than mere celebrity. The fact is that the central planks of modern conservatism — slashing taxes on the rich and benefits for the public at large — are deeply unpopular. Republicans have won elections only by wrapping these policies in other stuff; it’s about cutting benefits for welfare queens and “strapping young bucks” (that’s a Reaganism, in case you’re wondering) buying T-bone steaks with food stamps. And this in turn means that there is a sort of empty box in U.S. politics waiting to be filled.

headline: Low-Income Housing Goals Set for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
abstract: The Federal Housing Finance Agency clarified rules for determining affordability and put in place clearer procedures in establishing housing goals.
lead_paragraph: The federal agency that regulates the mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac on Wednesday set goals for the next two years to nudge them to provide mortgages to more low-income borrowers and to landlords who offer low rents to poor people.

headline: Bill de Blasio Addresses ‘Outrageous’ Remarks by Donald Trump
abstract: In a clash of political foils, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York took direct aim at Donald J. Trump, accusing the developer of “trying to undermine fundamental constitutional rights.”
lead_paragraph: Oil and water, meet de Blasio and Trump.

headline: Fed Minutes Show Caution in Discussion on Rates
abstract: Officials at the Federal Reserve’s July policy meeting wanted to see more evidence of economic health before raising rates, an official account shows.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials are struggling to get comfortable with the persistent sluggishness of price inflation as they move toward raising interest rates later this year.

headline: Soaring Along With the World’s Tallest Roller Coasters
abstract: Mekado Murphy has a passion for roller coasters that he has turned in to a beat. He describes the reporting that goes in to covering the tallest rides.
lead_paragraph: I have been intrigued by roller coasters since riding the Mini Mine Train at Six Flags Over Texas as a child. What started out as a fear turned into a discovery and then a passion. These days, I regularly seek out the tallest, fastest and most innovative thrills at parks around the country.

headline: Crash in Southern New Jersey Kills Boy, 2, and Injures 3 Others
abstract: A car struck a young woman and some children who were on a walk in Southampton Township, east of Philadelphia; she and two others were in critical condition.
lead_paragraph: A car struck a young woman and a group of children on a road in southern New Jersey this week, killing a 2-year-old boy riding in a red wagon, the New Jersey State Police said.

headline: Health Officials Investigating Second Plague Case in California
abstract: The disease that once devastated Europe is now rare in humans, but two recent visitors to Yosemite National Park have contracted it.
lead_paragraph: For the second time this summer, health officials in California are investigating a case of plague that a camper most likely contracted while visiting Yosemite National Park.

headline: Germany Announces Plan to Cope with Migrant Influx
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The country expects up to 800,000 asylum seekers or refugees this year, and its interior minister said that “it is also time for European solutions.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany expects as many as 800,000 asylum seekers or refugees this year, four times the number who came last year, Interior Minister Thomas de Maizière said on Wednesday in announcing new actions to cope with the biggest influx since the aftermath of World War II.

headline: App Smart | Golf Like a Pro
abstract: Apps can improve your golf game, from helping you understand the rules of the game to factoring the wind into a swing.
lead_paragraph: Apps can improve your golf game, from helping you understand the rules of the game to factoring the wind into a swing.

headline: Video Feature: Golfing Apps That Improve Play From Tee to Green
abstract: A review of four golfing apps that can turn your smartphone (or watch) into a virtual caddie, scorecard and rule book, helping everyone from duffers to scratch players get more out of the game.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S a conversation topic for you and your golfing buddies as you kick back at the 19th hole on a summer’s evening and look back over your day on the course: all the apps that can help with your golfing game.

headline: Conquering Android’s Stagefright Bug
abstract: How to protect from a vulnerability by which Android devices could be compromised by malicious code. Also, figuring out the iOS step counter.
lead_paragraph: Conquering

headline: The Alternatives: Designers Subverting Fashion’s Status Quo
abstract: As high fashion becomes an increasingly commercial business, a group of rebellious young designers has emerged, challenging the unwritten codes of design, from gender stereotypes to what’s even considered clothing.
lead_paragraph: As high fashion becomes an increasingly commercial business, a group of rebellious young designers has emerged, challenging the unwritten codes of design, from gender stereotypes to what’s even considered clothing.

headline: Elisabeth Egan’s ‘A Window Opens’ Has Echoes of Her Amazon Odyssey
abstract: Ms. Egan’s book, due out Tuesday, centers on a magazine editor whose life is upended when she takes a fast-paced job at a company much like Amazon.
lead_paragraph: “I’m an oversharer,” Elisabeth Egan said before an interview had even begun.

headline: 36 Hours in Burlington
abstract: Burlington has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the state’s spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen.
lead_paragraph: Burlington has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the state’s spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen.

headline: Social Security Benefits in Limbo for Some Same-Sex Couples
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: Those whose spouses died before the Supreme Court made two crucial marriage-equality rulings are fighting for retroactive recognition of their unions.
lead_paragraph: Same-sex couples may have won marriage equality, but some gay and lesbian individuals have been left wondering if their unions are still less than equal in the eyes of the government.

headline: 36 Hours in Burlington, Vermont
abstract: The state’s largest city is a great place to walk — or bike or hike or sail. And then sample the locovore fare.
lead_paragraph: Burlington, home of the University of Vermont and the birthplace of Phish, Ben and Jerry’s and Seventh Generation, has long embodied the earthy progressivism and can-do independence that define the state’s spirit. Lately that ethos has taken on a sophisticated sheen, as chefs apply Vermont’s longtime obsession with local ingredients in exciting new directions. There are still plenty of Birkenstocks about; they’re just parked under tables spread with confit duck poutine, braised leek crepes and crisp, complex Vermont craft brews like Alchemist’s Heady Topper, a beer of near-mythic reputation among hops aficionados.

headline: In Girl’s Account, Rite at St. Paul’s Boarding School Turned Into Rape
abstract: The second day of testimony in the trial of Owen Labrie, who has pleaded not guilty, brought out both excruciating detail and intense emotion from the girl said to have been sexually assaulted.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — The 16-year-old girl sat on the witness stand, her hair pulled back. She tried to speak steadily as she told a jury about the night when a ritual at St. Paul’s — an elite boarding school here — turned into what she described as a shocking sexual assault.

headline: Louis Stokes, Congressman From Ohio and Champion of the Poor, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Stokes, a Democrat, served in the House for 30 years, and led a special investigation into the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
lead_paragraph: Louis Stokes, who as the first African-American congressman from Ohio helped focus federal attention on the nation’s poor and led a special House investigation into the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Tuesday at his home in a Cleveland suburb. He was 90.

headline: In Bribery Law, a New Tool to Scrutinize Wall Street
keywords: ['Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Internships']
abstract: The S.E.C. and Justice Department are using the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act aggressively to police practices that many might consider standard for financial firms trying to win business.
lead_paragraph: If you want to succeed on Wall Street, you have to build relationships. So firms will do almost anything to please clients, catering to their wishes in the hope of winning the next underwriting assignment or new assets to manage.

headline: First Draft Focus: Striking Up the Band in New Hampshire
abstract: The Marching Lancers from Londonderry High School opened an education policy forum in Londonderry, N.H.

headline: Time Warner Promotes Priya Dogra to Deals Chief
abstract: She will lead the company’s global deal activity as its new senior vice president of mergers and acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner announced Wednesday that it had elevated Priya Dogra to lead the media conglomerate’s global deal activity as its new senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Scott Walker on His Education Reforms
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin defended his education reforms at a Republican education summit meeting in Londonderry, N.H.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin defended his education reforms at a Republican education summit meeting in Londonderry, N.H.

headline: 2007 Case Against Kenyan Leader Is Under Scrutiny
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: An effort to prosecute Uhuru Kenyatta, the Kenyan president, at the International Criminal Court over deadly postelection violence in 2007 collapsed last year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The failed case against President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya moved into the spotlight again on Wednesday when judges demanded a fresh inquiry into whether the Nairobi government obstructed access to crucial evidence against him.

headline: Jared Fogle Guilty in Child Sex Charges
abstract: Mr. Fogle, the former pitchman for Subway sandwich restaurants, pleaded guilty to sex acts with minors and to distributing child pornography.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Fogle, the former pitchman for Subway sandwich restaurants, pleaded guilty to sex acts with minors and to distributing child pornography.

headline: Food Matters
abstract: Lunch with the Four Horsemen’s family and friends.
lead_paragraph: Lunch with the Four Horsemen’s family and friends.

headline: London Theater Journal: Maximally Minimal
abstract: Ben Brantley reviews “Three Days in the Country” and “Operation Crucible.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Even fictional holidays, it seems, are subject to shrinkage in these days of austerity measures and arts cuts, subjects much on the minds of pundits (and taxpayers and theatergoers) here. On my first night in London this summer, I found myself spending only “Three Days in the Country,” as opposed to the usual full month, at the National Theater.

headline: Kids in the Kitchen: Broiled Fish With Chermoula
abstract: Chermoula: a huge success. Salmon for the child who doesn’t like it anymore? Less so.
lead_paragraph: The master plan? Raising children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthy meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task. In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlode’s KJ Dell’Antonia and Cooking’s Margaux Laskey move their very differently aged families toward that goal. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11- and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own.

headline: Bobby Jindal on Louisiana Schools
abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana appeared at a Republican education summit to discuss reforms to the school systems in New Orleans and throughout the state.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana appeared at a Republican education summit to discuss reforms to the school systems in New Orleans and throughout the state.

headline: Glencore Tripped Up by Faith in Rational Markets
abstract: Earnings have disappointed as copper and coal have tumbled. And looking forward, both rivals’ behavior and Chinese demand remain unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: Glencore’s shtick has long been that it is the master of the commodity markets. It knows when to take risks, it can shift supply to where it’s most wanted and it tweaks its own mines to maximise profit. Or at least it can do all that when everyone else behaves rationally. That thinking has come unstuck, and the British-Swiss commodities trader’s earnings have gone with it. They halved in the first six months of 2015.

headline: How Trump Might Help Reform Conservatives
abstract: Why the Donald’s rise need not spell doom for Republican policy reform.
lead_paragraph: We haven’t been talking very much about intra-conservative policy debates since the G.O.P. primary campaign, and especially the Trump boom, began in earnest. Over at Bloomberg Politics, Peter Gosselin has a piece up quoting some members of my own “reform conservative” tribe expressing dismay at this, and particularly at the way that Trump is killing off serious policy arguments and turning the G.O.P. primary into an exercise in substance-free showmanship. “To one degree or another,” Gosselin writes, “virtually everyone in [the reformocon] circle of mostly 30-something conservatives interviewed in recent days expressed apprehension that the Republican contest could degenerate into the negative, policy-light brawl of four years ago, something party officials and policy advocates had sought to avoid.”

headline: ‘Simpsons’ Memorabilia to Be Auctioned From Sam Simon Collection
abstract: Sotheby’s is selling fine art and memorabilia from the collection of one of the most important creative forces behind the Simpsons, Sam Simon, who died in March.
lead_paragraph: This fall ardent fans of “The Simpsons” can buy a Simpsons pinball machine at Sotheby’s. (Bart’s voice will berate you, “Hey, man, I’m an underachiever, too.” Homer’s taunts: “Don’t you know how to use the flippers?”)

headline: With an Eye on Fintech, Andreessen Horowitz Adds a New General Partner
abstract: Andreessen Horowitz is adding a new general partner, Alex Rampell. He will focus on the fast-growing field of financial technology start-ups.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of Andreessen Horowitz believe that experience is the best teacher. So the best venture capitalists are ones with first-hand experience founding companies, people who have “been through the war,” as Marc Andreessen puts it.

headline: Yankees’ Greg Bird Steps In for a Slugger and Breaks Into a Trot, Twice
abstract: Filling in for the injured Mark Teixeira, Bird had two two-run blasts, the first homers of his career, helping the Yankees sweep the Twins.
lead_paragraph: When Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman made inquiries into acquiring a starting pitcher before the July 31 trading deadline, he told his counterparts on other teams that three prospects were off-limits: pitcher Luis Severino, outfielder Aaron Judge and first baseman Greg Bird.

headline: Tattoos on and off the Runway
abstract: Twelve models and their tattoos.
lead_paragraph: Twelve models and their tattoos.

headline: Opening Statements in N.H. Rape Case
abstract: Lawyers for the prosecution and the defense made their opening statements in the trial of Owen Labrie, a graduate of the St. Paul’s School who is accused of raping a freshman girl.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the prosecution and the defense made their opening statements in the trial of Owen Labrie, a graduate of the St. Paul’s School who is accused of raping a freshman girl.

headline: A Variety Show for the Apollo in the Hamptons
abstract: From fashion icons to political powerhouses, a fund-raiser hosted by Ronald O. Perelman gathered an eclectic philanthropic crowd.
lead_paragraph: Captains of industry arrived in Maseratis and Porsches. The East Hampton lawn was filled with artworks by Robert Indiana, Anish Kapoor and Richard Serra. And celebrities like Christina Aguilera, Jamie Foxx and Jimmy Fallon were there not only as guests, but also as performers.

headline: Rare Sand Kittens Born in Israeli Zoo
abstract: A sand cat at the Ramat Gan Safari Park became pregnant after a mate was brought in from Sweden. The cats were previously considered extinct in Israel.
lead_paragraph: A sand cat at the Ramat Gan Safari Park became pregnant after a mate was brought in from Sweden. The cats were previously considered extinct in Israel.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Thailand, North Korea and Elsewhere
abstract: France, Bulgaria, Thailand and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: France, Bulgaria, Thailand and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Vintage Looks at Morphew Offer Fresh Take on Fashion
abstract: Morphew’s high-end collection of classic styles serves as inspiration for designers and collectors.
lead_paragraph: “We’re every designer’s dirtiest secret,” said Jason Lyon, while sitting on a leather ottoman in the Midtown Manhattan showroom of Morphew, a vintage clothing archive for which he is a co-owner.

headline: August 19, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photographs from Thailand, North Korea, South Korea and France.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Thailand, North Korea, South Korea and France.

headline: Treasure Discovered From 1715 Shipwreck
abstract: A treasure-hunting crew found $4.5 million worth of gold coins off Florida’s coast in July. The site is known as the resting place of a fleet of Spanish ships that sank in a hurricane 300 years ago.
lead_paragraph: A treasure-hunting crew found $4.5 million worth of gold coins off Florida’s coast in July. The site is known as the resting place of a fleet of Spanish ships that sank in a hurricane 300 years ago.

headline: A Hawaii Food Festival Goes Local
abstract: The fifth annual Hawaii Food & Wine festival begins on Aug. 29, and will feature the cooking of more than 100 chefs.
lead_paragraph: The fifth annual Hawaii Food & Wine Festival runs from Aug. 29 to Sept. 13 on the islands of Hawaii, Maui and Oahu.

headline: Two-Headed Calf Born in Peru
abstract: The rare calf was born in northern Peru on Tuesday at Edward Villegas Rubio’s stable in the country’s Cajamarca region.
lead_paragraph: The rare calf was born in northern Peru on Tuesday at Edward Villegas Rubio’s stable in the country’s Cajamarca region.

headline: An Itsy Bitsy Teenie Bikini? This Year. Maybe Not.
abstract: Sales of one-piece swimsuits are up, helped by the mega-celebrity trifecta of Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Rihanna, who have all worn one-pieces lately.
lead_paragraph: It was almost a decade ago that Nora Ephron famously instructed “anyone young” to go put on a bikini and not take it off until age 34.

headline: Baby Boomers Ready to Sell Businesses to the Next Generation
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Baby Boomers', 'Minorities', 'Women and Girls', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: As older owners choose the improved economy as a climate in which to sell, the buyers are putting a more diverse face on small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Dan Bizzarro and Bill Jordan were still in college when they went to work at the Bimac Corporation, a castings manufacturer in Dayton, Ohio. After graduation, they joined full time as manufacturing and engineering executives. And eventually they teamed with a third employee to buy the business.

headline: Panti Bliss, the Accidental Activist of Ireland
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transvestism', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Panti Bliss, Ireland’s queen of drag, becomes an accidental national hero in the fight for equal rights for gays.
lead_paragraph: How does a once-conservative Catholic country embrace not only equal rights for gays, but an outspoken H.I.V.-positive drag queen as a national icon?

headline: Ballet Life, Unfiltered and Uploaded to Instagram
abstract: Dancers, so accustomed to speaking with their bodies, are using social media to speak with a lens on their terms.
lead_paragraph: Deformed toenails, eating disorders and backstabbing jealousy — that’s a quick survey of ballet stereotypes. But with Instagram, dancers have found a way to break through the tulle and tiaras by presenting backstage life on their terms.

headline: Home is Where the Work Takes Him
abstract: The Pioneer Works art space in Brooklyn has Gabriel Florenz tied up for the moment.

headline: Justice Dept. Presses Civil Rights Agenda in Local Courts
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Discrimination', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'Attorneys General', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)']
abstract: The government has waded into cases involving legal aid, transgender students, juvenile prisoners and people who take videos of police officers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Burlington, Wash., was a small city fighting what seemed like a local lawsuit. Three poor people said that their public lawyers were too overworked to adequately represent them in municipal court cases. The dispute went mostly unnoticed for two years, until the Obama administration became involved.

headline: Ex-Executive Pleads Guilty in Toxic Spill in West Virginia
abstract: Gary Southern, the former president of Freedom Industries, whose chemical spill last year tainted the drinking water of more than 300,000 people, admitted to environmental crimes.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The former president of a company whose toxic chemical spill contaminated the drinking water of more than 300,000 people last year pleaded guilty Wednesday to environmental crimes.

headline: Review: The Battery Dance Festival Evokes Courtship Rituals Amid Flying Hats
abstract: Sankofa Danzafro, from Colombia, and Pajarillo Pinta’o Dance Company performed on Tuesday at Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Battery Park City.
lead_paragraph: The Battery Dance Festival, presented by the Battery Dance Company in Lower Manhattan for 34 years, has become known for its international roster. This year artists from India, Norway and Poland are among those appearing along the Hudson River — routinely backed by stunning, if blinding, sunsets — at Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park in Battery Park City.

headline: Review: At Mostly Mozart, Joshua Bell Plays a Rejiggered Bach Novelty
abstract: In addition to Julian Milone’s version of a rearranged Bach chaconne, this program included Mozart and Schumann.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly, classical artists are realizing that audiences appreciate hearing performers speak about a piece they are about to play. Of course, the performer had better be personable and have something helpful to say.

headline: Review: ‘Everybody Rise,’ Stephanie Clifford’s Debut Novel, Features That Old-Money Scent
abstract: The well-off heroine of this book wants to join what she considers the most elite social circle in New York.
lead_paragraph: At an Ivy League varsity team dinner in a college dining hall, I was once chastised by a teammate for not passing the pepper along with the salt. The rule was familiar to me, but the insistence on it in these raucous surroundings surprised me. Oh, but that was just the point, said my Miss Manners; in her circle these rules mattered always and everywhere. Having nothing to do with actual courtesy or consideration, a ritual like this one was, it seemed to me, part of a code by which people were meant to recognize one another as belonging.

headline: Chris Christie on a Teaching Revolution
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared at a Republican education summit meeting on Wednesday and said that if there were to be a revolution in teaching, the revolutionaries should be better armed.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appeared at a Republican education summit meeting on Wednesday and said that if there were to be a revolution in teaching, the revolutionaries should be better armed.

headline: A Hoarder’s Tale of Redemption
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Orderliness and Clutter', 'Hoarding', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Barry Yourgrau, a writer, performer and hoarder who collected bits and pieces from his travels around the world, turns himself into a project and cleans up his act (and apartment).
lead_paragraph: Barry Yourgrau collects shopping bags and stationery from grand hotels, cocktail napkins and coasters from European cafes and more esoteric souvenirs like sponge shoe polishers, a calendar put out by Italian policemen, a tissue paper Day of the Dead banner tucked inside a Mexican newspaper, soccer club scarves. His girlfriend, Anya von Bremzen, is a food writer who travels half the year for her work and Mr. Yourgrau, a fiction writer and performer, accompanies her on all her trips, so he’s been able to feed his collection with a constant stream of new treasures.

headline: Martin O’Malley Calls Hillary Clinton Email Issue a ‘Huge Distraction’
abstract: Martin O’Malley on Wednesday said that the constant questions about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use was a distraction for the entire Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Standing in front of a hotel emblazoned with Donald J. Trump’s name in Las Vegas, Martin O’Malley on Wednesday said that the constant questions about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use was a distraction for the entire Democratic Party.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Narrator on His Role and His Emmy Nomination
abstract: Mr. Mendez, who as the Latin lover narrator received the show’s sole Emmy nomination, talks about his voice-over career.
lead_paragraph: When nominations for this year’s Emmy Awards were announced in late July, CW’s “Jane the Virgin,” one of the most warmly received shows of the 2014-15 TV season, was nearly absent. Despite raves for its star Gina Rodriguez and expectations that it would vie for best comedy, the freshman series was the recipient of only a single nomination.

headline: Beyoncé Is Seen but Not Heard
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Celebrities', 'Social Media', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The curious case of the silent celebrity: Beyoncé last tweeted two years ago, and hasn’t given an interview in over a year.
lead_paragraph: The biggest Vogue of the year, the vaunted September issue (832 pages, four pounds, three ounces), is now on the stands. On its cover is arguably the biggest star of the moment, Beyoncé.

headline: The Artists Behind the Exhibitions
abstract: The Contemporary Arts Center and the New Orleans Museum of Art put on shows tied to Hurricane Katrina, 10 years after the storm.
lead_paragraph: The Contemporary Arts Center and the New Orleans Museum of Art put on shows tied to Hurricane Katrina, 10 years after the storm.

headline: Ten Years After Katrina, New Orleans Museums Reckon With Recovery
abstract: Three art exhibitions in New Orleans recall the catastrophe, and assess the city’s present.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — How well do you remember the last days of August 10 years ago? Asked that question, a 23-year-old New Orleanian writes of seeing a dead alligator on the highway, having nowhere to sleep and crying every night. This anonymous recollection, printed neatly on a card, is part of a growing number pinned to the basement walls of the Ogden Museum of Southern Art here.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
abstract: Intermix will host a fall denim event, where shoppers can enjoy free tailoring; Bird goes to final clearance on Thursday and more.
lead_paragraph: Saturday from noon to 4 p.m., Intermix will host a fall denim event. Shoppers can enjoy free tailoring and the help of an Intermix stylist to pick the perfect pair of on-trend jeans, like very ’70s J Brand velvet kick flares ($298) and Frame high-waist denim trousers ($250). At 125 Fifth Avenue.

headline: Uber Missed Criminal Records of Drivers, Prosecutors Assert
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: District attorneys in Los Angeles and San Francisco say drivers for the ride-hailing service have included some convicted of murder or sex offenses.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For more than a year, regulators in various cities have questioned whether Uber, the ride-hailing service, vets its drivers for criminal backgrounds as carefully as traditional taxi companies.

headline: In Fashion, Gender Lines Are Blurring
abstract: Unisex looks are gaining traction and a measure of cool they have not had since the ’60s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Each time Kimberly Wesson sheds her customary trousers and button-front shirt to put on a flowery dress, she suspects something is off.

headline: Review: Liberty Ellman Releases ‘Radiate’
abstract: The album is the first by the guitarist and sideman to Henry Threadgill in nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: LIBERTY ELLMAN

headline: Review: Royal Headache Releases Its Second Album
abstract: In “High,” this Australian band reflects experience and outrage.
lead_paragraph: ROYAL HEADACHE

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Call Carly Rae Jepsen a Pop Star With Depth (Maybe)
abstract: The album “Emotion” builds off her calling-card hit, “Call Me Maybe,” trying to establish her bona fides in thinking-person’s pop.
lead_paragraph: The year is 2015, yet surly clouds of shame still hover over those fortunate enough to have had one spectacular pop hit. How many streaming services must die before these blessed artists understand that their one calling-card hit is a wonder not to escape, but to embrace?

headline: The Instagram Archive of Celebrity Summers
abstract: Famous folk have been documenting their summertime escapades on the social platform.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities and fashion folk have been having a grand old summer this year. For those who don’t keep up by turning to the usual methods — tabloids, gossip websites and blogs — there’s Instagram, where many well-known users post personal photos from their adventures in locales near and far.

headline: On Instagram, the Summer You’re Not Having
abstract: The fear of missing out, which has spawned the #FOMO hashtag, seems to have grown more pronounced in the summertime as celebrity groups escape and document their fun on social platforms.
lead_paragraph: And how has your summer been so far?

headline: Russia Sentences Estonian to 15 Years in Disputed Spy Case
abstract: The conviction of a security officer, which was denounced by Estonia and Western nations, reflects tensions between Russia and its Baltic neighbors.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian court convicted an Estonian security police officer of espionage on Wednesday and sentenced him to 15 years of hard labor in a case highlighting tensions between Russia and its Baltic neighbors, which have escalated along with the conflict in Ukraine.

headline: Eli Manning Disputes Report That He Wants to Be N.F.L.’s Highest-Paid Player
abstract: Manning, who is in the last year of his current Giants contract, with a base salary of $17 million, said that neither he nor his agent had made such a demand.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In a rare display of annoyance, Eli Manning on Wednesday disputed a report that he wanted to be the N.F.L.’s highest-paid player. Manning, who is negotiating a new contract with the Giants, said that neither he nor his agent had made such a demand.

headline: Researchers Link Longer Work Hours and Stroke Risk
abstract: An analysis of data on more than 600,000 people is the largest study thus far of the relationship between working hours and cardiovascular health.
lead_paragraph: People who work 55 hours or more per week have a 33 percent greater risk of stroke and a 13 percent greater risk of coronary heart disease than those working standard hours, researchers reported on Wednesday in the Lancet.

headline: Cornel West: The Fire of a New Generation
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Young protesters in Ferguson and beyond are rekindling the spirit of W.E.B. DuBois and the civil rights struggles of the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: This is the 15th in a series of interviews on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s discussion is with Cornel West, one of the most prominent and provocative intellectuals in public life. He is a professor of philosophy and Christian practice at Union Theological Seminary and professor emeritus at Princeton University. He is the author and editor of more than 30 books, including “Black Prophetic Fire” and “The Radical King.” — George Yancy

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Grandma’
abstract: Paul Weitz narrates a sequence from his film “Grandma,” featuring Lily Tomlin and Sam Elliott.
lead_paragraph: Paul Weitz narrates a sequence from his film “Grandma,” featuring Lily Tomlin and Sam Elliott.

headline: Paul Weitz Narrates a Scene From ‘Grandma’
abstract: Paul Weitz discusses a sequence from “Grandma” with Lily Tomlin and Sam Elliott.
lead_paragraph: A woman visits an old flame to ask for a favor, and a fire burns. That’s the crux of this scene from “Grandma,” written and directed by Paul Weitz and featuring Lily Tomlin.

headline: Review: In ‘Grandma,’ Lily Tomlin Energizes an Intergenerational Road Trip
abstract: Paul Weitz’s new film, centering on a feminist poet in her 70s and her granddaughter, is a comedy of conflict and solidarity.
lead_paragraph: In need of cash — we’ll get to why in a minute — Elle Reid, a poet and sometime professor in her 70s, decides to sell some precious old books. She figures that even though they’re a bit worse for wear, her first editions of Betty Friedan and Simone de Beauvoir should fetch a few hundred dollars at the local feminist bookstore-cafe. Her outrage when she’s grudgingly offered a lot less than that compounds her dismay at her teenage granddaughter’s cluelessness about the authors of “The Feminine Mystique” and “The Second Sex.” What’s wrong with the world these days?

headline: The Icelandic Composer Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Searching for Beauty Amid Brokenness
abstract: “Clockworking,” by Nordic Affect, and “In the Light of Air,” by the International Contemporary Ensemble, tackle a barrage of extended techniques.
lead_paragraph: Listening to a recent album of Icelandic music from the chamber ensemble Nordic Affect is a bit like driving across the country from which its composers hail: The terrain changes radically every few minutes, but a sense of the uncanny unifies the landscape. “Clockworking,” released last month on the Sono Luminus label, forms an absorbing and persuasively performed snapshot of Icelandic composition today. The album brims with compellingly quizzical sounds, from Thuridur Jonsdottir’s “INNI” — in which electronic samples of a babbling baby accompany a shimmering Baroque violin — to Hafdis Bjarnadottir’s “From Beacon to Beacon,” which draws on recordings made at lighthouses to create twitchy grooves.

headline: Russia’s Pitch to Vacationers: Crimea Is for Patriots
abstract: A tourist tidal wave has not materialized after Russia annexed the Black Sea peninsula from Ukraine last year, prompting Western sanctions.
lead_paragraph: SAKI, Crimea — Tamara Tsetlayana stood on a narrow stretch of gray beach, rinsing off a thick layer of the black, ostensibly therapeutic mud that has drawn visitors to the salty lake here for more than a century.

headline: Lebanese Police Beat ‘You Stink’ Activists in Beirut
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Media', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Protesters in Lebanon call their government’s failure to arrange for trash collection just the most obvious sign of a dysfunctional administration.
lead_paragraph: Simmering tensions between protesters and the authorities over Lebanon’s continuing trash crisis erupted into violence on Wednesday as the police used force on demonstrators rallying outside the seat of government in Beirut.

headline: Early Prison Release Delayed for Oscar Pistorius
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: The minister, Michael Masutha, said the decision to release Mr. Pistorius on Friday to serve the rest of his term under house arrest was premature.
lead_paragraph: South Africa’s justice minister on Wednesday intervened to delay the early release of Oscar Pistorius, the imprisoned Olympic athlete convicted of killing his girlfriend — 48 hours before he was scheduled to begin serving the rest of his five-year term under house arrest.

headline: Oil Companies Sit on Hands at Auction for Leases
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Auctions']
abstract: The low turnout at the Gulf of Mexico auction was the clearest sign yet that the fortunes of oil companies are skidding so fast that they now must reduce plans for production well into the future.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With oil prices collapsing and companies in retrenchment, a federal auction in the Gulf of Mexico on Wednesday attracted the lowest interest from producers since 1986.

headline: British Study Says Electronic Cigarettes Curb Smoking Risks
abstract: The study concluded that electronic cigarettes lowered the health risks associated with smoking by 95 percent, compared with traditional cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: British health officials on Wednesday reported the results of a government-funded study concluding that the use of electronic cigarettes can reduce the health risks of smoking by 95 percent and may also help smokers quit the habit.

headline: Arkansas Governor Wants to Keep Medicaid Expansion, but With Changes
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Gov. Asa Hutchinson told an advisory group that he favored keeping the expansion, but only if the federal government allowed changes that seemed intended to appeal to conservative legislators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas on Wednesday told an advisory group weighing the future of the state’s alternative Medicaid expansion that he favored keeping it — but only if the federal government allowed changes that seemed intended to appeal to conservative legislators who continue to oppose the program.

headline: Rude Boy Style Can’t Fail
abstract: A recent book and exhibit showcase the suave street style of rude boy style, which transcends mere fashion to embrace a fierce sense of self-worth.
lead_paragraph: A recent book and exhibit showcase the suave street style of rude boy style, which transcends mere fashion to embrace a fierce sense of self-worth.

headline: Jets Sign Matt Flynn, Adding Experience to Backups at Quarterback
abstract: Geno Smith is nursing a metal plate in his jaw, and the rookies Bryce Petty and Jake Heaps do not appear to be N.F.L. ready.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Concerned about the inexperience of their backup options at quarterback, the Jets signed the veteran Matt Flynn on Wednesday.

headline: Syria: Typhoid Threatens Refugees
keywords: ['Typhoid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Palestinians', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: U.N. medical teams had confirmed six typhoid cases on Tuesday among Palestinians in the Yalda district, and five more cases on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A typhoid outbreak is threatening displaced Palestinian residents from the Yarmouk refugee camp outside Damascus, Syria, the United Nations reported Wednesday. Christopher Gunness, a spokesman for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, said that medical teams had confirmed six typhoid cases on Tuesday among Palestinians in the Yalda district near Yarmouk, and that five more cases had been confirmed on Wednesday. “We fear this is the tip of the iceberg,” Mr. Gunness said. The agency has been unable to gain access to Yarmouk since March 28, just before Islamic State militants seized control of part of it, but has been able to help some residents who have fled.

headline: What’s On TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:50 A.M. (Starz) MR. TURNER (2014) A growling, sputtering Timothy Spall, above, stars as J. M. W. Turner (1775-1851), the man the Victorian critic John Ruskin called “the greatest painter of all time.” Mike Leigh’s biographical masterpiece juxtaposes the vexing genius of Turner’s later years and his ramshackle personal life. Turner the painter divined luminously stormy seascapes and placid river scenes that inspired the praise of critics and the envy of colleagues — until his work fell out of fashion. Turner the man lived with his father (Paul Jesson), copulated with his longtime housekeeper (Dorothy Atkinson) and ignored his daughters by his semi-estranged wife (Ruth Sheen) while keeping company with a kindhearted widow (Marion Bailey) whose last name he adopts. “ ‘Mr. Turner’ is a mighty work of critical imagination, a loving, unsentimental portrait of a rare creative soul,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this Oscar nominee in cinematography, costume and production design, and original score. “But even as it celebrates a glorious painter and illuminates the sources of his pictures with startling clarity and insight, the movie patiently and thoroughly demolishes more than a century’s worth of mythology about what art is and how artists work.” He added, “It might be risking Ruskinesque folly to take ‘Mr. Turner’ as a self-portrait of its director, but Turner shares with Mr. Leigh an ability to travel the circuit between the sublime and the ordinary, to bring into view aspects of reality that had been somehow invisible in plain sight.”

headline: Rude Boy Style Can’t Fail
abstract: A recent book and exhibit showcase the suave street style of rude boy style, which transcends mere fashion to embrace a fierce sense of self-worth.
lead_paragraph: At the heyday of colonial conquest, Charles Baudelaire, the French poet and lover of the Haitian-born artist Jeanne Duval, wrote that “dandyism is a setting sun; like the declining star, it is magnificent, without heat and full of melancholy.” Diasporic Africans, whose bodies were reduced to mere commodities for centuries, have long used “stylin’ out” to subvert racial order, perform their identities far from a lost homeland, and “redefine blackness and cosmopolitanism,” as the historian Monica Miller noted in “Slaves to Fashion: Black Dandyism and the Styling of Black Diasporic Identity.”

headline: Talking About the Death Penalty, Court to Court
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Eighth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: At the Connecticut and United States Supreme Courts, will discussions lead the way to the end of capital punishment?
lead_paragraph: The Connecticut Supreme Court could have taken an easy route to finding the state’s death penalty unconstitutional in the decision it issued last week. The State Legislature repealed the death penalty in 2012, but it made the repeal prospective, leaving 11 men on death row. The reason for the prospective-only repeal was obvious to all: Two of the death-row inmates, Joshua Komisarjevsky and Steven Hayes, had committed a horrific home-invasion triple murder that shocked the state in 2007, and the prospect of barring their execution was unpalatable to Connecticut politicians and many members of the public.

lead_paragraph: Modernizing legends can be a tricky business. One must find the resonance between ancient and contemporary, blending incongruous elements in a way that seems not only right but inevitable: telling the story of a founding father with hip-hop lyrics, as in “Hamilton,” or presenting the myth of Theseus in the milieu of reality television as in “The Hunger Games.” Kekla Magoon manages a similar feat of legerdemain in “Shadows of Sherwood,” her compelling reboot of the Robin Hood myth.

headline: In Indonesia, Many Islands and Many Faces
abstract: From Papua to Bali, this sprawling country offers beauty, intimacy and great deals for travelers.
lead_paragraph: In the second grade, I spent many hours with a World Book Encyclopedia, an opaque projector and a vast stretch of butcher paper tacked to the classroom wall. My goal was to trace a map of Indonesia. It was for a report, which probably mentioned that Indonesia was the world’s fourth most-populous country and the one with the most Muslims, and that it was covered in rice paddies and exports oil. But what I remember was the map itself: There were so many islands that even a professional tracer would have found the job taxing.

headline: Canadian Maple Syrup ‘Rebels’ Clash With Law
keywords: ['Maple Syrup and Sugar', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Harvesters in Quebec, who provide 70 percent of the world’s supply, must sell through a central system, but some flout the requirement.
lead_paragraph: The scenic and narrow lane that leads to Robert Hodge’s sugar camp is surrounded by a cat’s cradle of plastic piping that draws sap from 12,000 trees. At the end of the lane, a ramshackle hut contains reverse osmosis pumps to concentrate the harvest. A stainless steel evaporator, about the size of a truck, finishes the conversion into maple syrup.

headline: Baseball’s Last Cuban Escapees
abstract: The next generation of the country’s athlete-émigrés most likely will be ordinary rookies instead of runaways. But these major-league players got here the hard way.
lead_paragraph: For foreign baseball players hoping to make it in America, just about every conceivable journey — the 1,300 miles from Venezuela, the 5,000 miles from Japan, the 7,000 miles from Australia — has been easier than the 90 short miles from Cuba. That trip, over the last 50 years, has involved almost mythic hardships: improvised rafts, drug lords, ransoms, death threats, forgery, machine guns on the high seas. And yet the Cuban players have come, drawn by the promise of freedom, glory and outrageous capitalist paydays.

headline: Dante at the Beach
abstract: In the midway of this his summer life, he found himself on a sunny shore, astray.
lead_paragraph: In the midway of this his summer life, he found himself on a sunny shore, astray.

headline: The Darker Side of Maple Syrup
keywords: ['Maple Syrup and Sugar', 'Small Business', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A barrel of maple syrup from Quebec is worth more today than a barrel of crude oil. Producers are reaping the benefits, but not all agree with the tactics that whipped the supply chain into shape.
lead_paragraph: A barrel of maple syrup from Quebec is worth more today than a barrel of crude oil. Producers are reaping the benefits, but not all agree with the tactics that whipped the supply chain into shape.

abstract: A New Tool to Scrutinize Wall Street | How Universities Hoard Money | The Bailout Architect Navigating Dual Roles
lead_paragraph: SLOW INFLATION MAKES FED CAUTIOUS OVER RATES | Sluggish inflation has made Federal Reserve officials uncomfortable about the prospect of raising rates this year, Binyamin Appelbaum reports. Minutes from their July meeting showed that they expected the continued improvement of the economy to push up prices, yet consumer prices continued to defy forecasts.

abstract: The Islamic State’s leaders publicize their enslavement of women and girls in their official publication, offering a theological argument - disputed by some scholars - for why the rape of infidels is allowed.
