headline: Recalls of Organic Food on the Rise, Report Says
keywords: ['Organic Foods and Products', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Organic food recalls have been driven by bacterial contamination such as salmonella, says an executive of Stericycle, which analyzed government data.
lead_paragraph: New data collected by Stericycle, a company that handles recalls for businesses, shows a sharp jump in the number of recalls of organic food products.

headline: R. L. Stine: By the Book
abstract: The author of the Goosebumps and Fear Street series avoids nonfiction: “I never read it. I hate anything real.”
lead_paragraph: The author of the Goosebumps and Fear Street series avoids nonfiction: “I never read it. I hate anything real.”

headline: Minnesota Theaters Embrace New Leaders, and Others May Follow
abstract: Leadership turnover is coming to America’s regional theaters, as the Guthrie and others see new faces in decision-making positions.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — At about the same time that Joseph Haj, the new artistic director of the Guthrie Theater, was getting a first panoramic glimpse of the Mississippi River from his office last month, new leaders were settling into the long-occupied bosses’ chairs at a handful of other significant theaters in the Twin Cities.

headline: Review: ‘Fear the Walking Dead,’ a Show About a Plague’s Start (What Zombies?)
abstract: This spinoff of “The Walking Dead,” which is beginning a six-episode run on AMC, opens with society still in denial about its lurching adversaries.
lead_paragraph: It’s either surprising or completely logical that “The Walking Dead” has become the most popular drama on television (by some measures) while also being one of the most unusual. The all-bets-are-off gore and violence made possible by its post-zombie-apocalypse scenario set it apart, of course. But even more distinctive are its dawdling rhythms, laconic performances and willingness to turn down the sound. Few shows, if any, are as quiet as “The Walking Dead.”

headline: A Barrier Breaker in the Steward’s Room
abstract: Erinn Higgins, 27, is the first woman to serve as a steward for the New York Racing Association, which includes Saratoga.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Erinn Higgins is a racetracker, and this is home. She is the daughter of a thoroughbred trainer and an exercise rider. Her childhood memories are of being lifted onto a pony on the backside of this historic racetrack and playing touch football outside the barn of the Hall of Fame trainer Allen Jerkens, who died in March.

headline: California Drought Is Made Worse by Global Warming, Scientists Say
abstract: The odds of California suffering droughts at the far end of the scale, like the current one, have roughly doubled over the last century, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: Global warming caused by human emissions has most likely intensified the drought in California by 15 to 20 percent, scientists said on Thursday, warning that future dry spells in the state are almost certain to be worse than this one as the world continues to heat up.

headline: Times Regrets ‘Slave Mistress’ in Julian Bond’s Obituary
abstract: Readers complained, rightly, that the expression was offensive.
lead_paragraph: After Julian Bond’s death on Saturday, The Times published a lengthy and well-written obituary summing up the life and work of the civil rights champion. But many readers were bothered by a single sentence in the front-page article:

headline: Israel’s Other Existential Threat Comes From Within
abstract: The deputy speaker of the Israeli Knesset argues that failure to reach a deal with the Palestinians may be as dangerous to the Jewish state as a nuclear Iran.
lead_paragraph: It used to be said by some in Israel that “only the right can bring peace.” But the brave, pragmatic Zionist right of Menachem Begin is gone.

headline: Maker of Addyi, ‘Female Viagra’ Drug, Being Sold to Valeant for $1 Billion
abstract: The deal for Sprout Pharmaceuticals came after the Food and Drug Administration granted approval this week for Addyi, a new libido drug for women.
lead_paragraph: Sprout Pharmaceuticals, which on Tuesday won regulatory approval for the first pill to aid a woman’s sex drive, will be acquired by Valeant Pharmaceuticals International for about $1 billion in cash.

headline: France and Britain to Unveil Calais Plan
abstract: The French interior minister, Bernard Cazeneuve, and the British home secretary, Theresa May, visited the Channel Tunnel site and are to announce measures later Thursday to stem the flow of migrants.
lead_paragraph: The French interior minister, Bernard Cazeneuve, and the British home secretary, Theresa May, visited the Channel Tunnel site and are to announce measures later Thursday to stem the flow of migrants.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump continues to overheat the Republican Party’s speech on immigration.

lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Ashley Madison Hack Shows We’re Too Dumb to Cheat
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'ADULTERY', 'Government Employees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: I can’t believe I’m paying the salaries of government workers who weren’t clever enough to get new emails to deceive their spouses.
lead_paragraph: America. We used to bestride the world like a colossus, a leader among nations, smarter, faster, braver, more forward-thinking than our rivals. Once, we were great, inventive and nimble, always pressing fearlessly ahead in the name of progress. Eradicating polio, inventing the airplane, the chicken nugget, the music video. Going to the moon.

headline: Egyptians Adapt as Cairo Is Redefined by a String of Bomb Attacks
abstract: At least 29 people were wounded in an attack on a branch of the Egyptian security agency, adding to a wave of militant violence in the capital over the summer.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Neighbors are growing more suspicious of strangers asking questions or taking pictures. Blast walls and other barriers are crowding the streets. Commuters say they have grown accustomed to changing their routes to avoid traffic snarled by the inevitable security cordons after each new explosion.

headline: Gloria Steinem Marches On
abstract: A front-line look at the feminist’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: A journalist from Ohio who once went undercover at Hugh Hefner’s Playboy Club for a story, Gloria Steinem emerged in the ’70s as the aviator-shaded face — and de facto voice — of the women’s movement. Her magazine, Ms., which she co-founded in 1971, was notable for being owned and operated entirely by women, and was one of the first mainstream publications to directly address the issues of reproductive rights and domestic violence. And while many of her detractors (Richard Nixon, Rush Limbaugh) have fallen by the wayside, Steinem remains relevant. Her forthcoming memoir, ‘‘My Life on the Road,’’ documents her travels as an activist, and, at 81, she is an icon for a new wave of celebrity feminists that includes Lena Dunham and Emma Watson. Here, a front-line look at Steinem’s legacy.

headline: New Concerns in Tianjin Blast After Dead Fish Are Found
keywords: ['Chemicals', 'Water Pollution', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The discovery came as officials said that wastewater runoff near the site contained hundreds of times as much cyanide as allowed by law.
lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — Officials grappling with the toxic fallout from a series of deadly explosions that rocked this northern port city last week found themselves struggling on Thursday to explain thousands of dead fish that washed up on a riverbank less than four miles away from the blast site.

headline: 3 Killed in Drive-By Shooting in Rochester
abstract: Seven people were shot Wednesday night after a basketball game at a Boys and Girls Club, the police said; the attack remains under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Three people were shot and killed after a basketball game at a Boys and Girls Club in Rochester late Wednesday night, according to the police.

abstract: As border enforcement has increased, immigrants have become less likely to return home.
lead_paragraph: Increased border enforcement in recent decades has had the unintended effect of keeping unauthorized immigrants in the United States when they might otherwise have left, a recent study has found.

lead_paragraph: The story of Albert and Dori began with a challenge match, a spectacle that became part first date, part first aid.

headline: 1940: Stocking-Tearless Seat Tested
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Manufacturer of new subway seats promises no more runs in stockings, in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Transportation has taken the first step toward eliminating the unspeakable feminine disaster of runs in stockings caused by frayed strands and slivers in the woven rattan covering of subway seats, it was learned yesterday [Aug. 20]. A new type of seat, made of spongy plastic material that cannot fray, has been installed experimentally on car 1,208 of the Independent subway, and if it proves successful it may be used in all new subway cars and installed in old cars whenever they are reconditioned. — New York Herald Tribune, August 21, 1940

headline: Daily News Sale Is Taken Off the Table by Zuckerman
abstract: The owner, Mortimer Zuckerman, sent a memo to staff members on Thursday, telling them he had withdrawn the paper from the market.
lead_paragraph: After months of exploring a sale, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News in New York, has decided to keep the newspaper, he said in a memo to staff members on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Europe’s migration crisis took on new dimensions Thursday as at least three countries announced added security measures to address the biggest movement of refugees and migrants seen here since the aftermath of World War II.

lead_paragraph: — Jeb Bush on his father, former President George Bush, 91, who is slowly recovering from a broken vertebra after falling at his Maine home this summer.

headline: Toné-Café Brings Georgian Cuisine to Gramercy Park
abstract: Food comes quickly, on paper plates or encased in plastic tubs, originally destined for takeout. Nevertheless, it is a feast.
lead_paragraph: In Georgian, supra is the word for both a feast and the tablecloth that vanishes under it, every inch colonized by dishes that only increase in number, hour after hour. (A proper supra may last three days.)

headline: ’Bama vs. Gators
abstract: Alabamians with a permit get to hunt “something that can hunt you back.”
lead_paragraph: BAY MINETTE, Ala. — When alligator season began last Thursday night in Alabama, those lucky enough to receive one of the state’s 260 prized hunting permits wondered if they might do what Mandy Stokes did last year. She and four others captured and killed the largest American alligator on record.

headline: Trump Hotel Goes Up, and His Latino Views Barely Raise Eyebrows
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The relative paucity of tension around Donald J. Trump’s lavish new venture may reflect how the country is changing — and how it is not.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Peruvian Nobel laureate Mario Vargas Llosa calls Donald J. Trump a “racist imbecile.” In Mexico, people are gleefully bashing Trump piñatas after his caustic remarks about Latino immigrants in the United States. In Guatemala, a liquor company is putting up posters of Mr. Trump using a term that, when translated charitably, describes him as a jackass.

headline: Doubt Is Raised Over Value of Surgery for Breast Lesion at Earliest Stage
abstract: Almost all women given a diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in situ, considered a possible precursor to breast cancer, have a lumpectomy or mastectomy, but data show they may not benefit.
lead_paragraph: As many as 60,000 American women each year are told they have a very early stage of breast cancer — Stage 0, as it is commonly known — a possible precursor to what could be a deadly tumor. And almost every one of the women has either a lumpectomy or a mastectomy, and often a double mastectomy, removing a healthy breast as well.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Need help finding something to do? The Times arts team has you covered.
lead_paragraph: Looking for something fun to do?

headline: The Rise and Fall of Shooting-Star Candidates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The kind of attention and excitement Donald Trump is generating right now feels unprecedented. But it really isn’t.
lead_paragraph: The G.O.P. presidential contest, barely a few weeks old, has been described in dizzying fashion. In Rolling Stone, Matt Taibbi called it “Western civilization’s very own car wreck.” Roger Simon, writing for Politico, described it as Donald Trump mooning America while the “Republican clown car” careens around the country with no driver. And in The New York Times, Ross Douthat hoped the “antics” would produce more than just “crazy cable-news entertainment.”

headline: Cafe Carlyle Kicks Off Season With Brian Stokes Mitchell
abstract: The club’s new season, which starts on Sept. 15, will include performances by Brian Stokes Mitchell and Kurt Elling.
lead_paragraph: Café Carlyle, the venerable cabaret in the Carlyle Hotel, has announced its fall season. It starts on Sept. 15 with the Broadway baritone Brian Stokes Mitchell, who is returning to nightclub performance in an all-new show. His residency, through Sept. 26, will be his first appearance in the room.

lead_paragraph: Washington Bureau Chief and Political Editor Carolyn Ryan talks with Times Insider about the paper’s campaign coverage. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: A Beating in Boston, Said to Be Inspired by Donald Trump’s Immigrant Comments
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

lead_paragraph: After a Hispanic man was beaten Wednesday by two Boston men, one of whom told the police that he was inspired by Donald J. Trump’s anti-immigrant message, Mr. Trump told reporters that his supporters were “passionate.”

headline: Reporter Joins Reddit Conversation on Prison Beating
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Michael Schwirtz describes the Reddit response to a story he and another reporter, Michael Winerip, wrote about the death of a prison inmate.
lead_paragraph: The article Michael Winerip and I wrote this week about the death of an inmate at Fishkill Correctional Facility had a huge following on social media. For a while on Tuesday it was the top item on the Reddit home page, which I’m told is a very big deal. It was another indication of how closely people pay attention to criminal justice issues these days.

headline: Wondering If I Hastened a Patient’s Death
abstract: At the very least, I was guilty of that act of hubris of which oncologists are often accused: giving chemotherapy to a person only days before his death.
lead_paragraph: In my outpatient exam room, we had arrived at that moment of silence that often marks the crossroads of unwelcome news and a difficult decision.

headline: Jamie Barton to Pinch-Hit at the Met in ‘Anna Bolena’
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Jamie Barton will fill in for Elina Garcanca in “Anna Bolena” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Barton, the acclaimed young mezzo-soprano, will return to the Metropolitan Opera in September as Giovanna Seymour in Donizetti’s “Anna Bolena,” the company announced Thursday.

headline: As Chase Utley Departs for Dodgers, a Look at the Phillies’ Fall
abstract: On Wednesday, one more key piece from the Phillies’ glory years left town when Utley was traded to the Dodgers for two prospects.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the Philadelphia Phillies were a formidable team. In 2008, they won their first World Series in 28 years and made the playoffs the next three seasons as well. They had power hitters, slick fielders and a strong rotation.

headline: Brooklyn Man Convicted of 2003 Murder of Fairfield Student Will Get a New Hearing
abstract: A judge ruled that John Giuca, who was found guilty of killing a college football player, will receive a hearing in which his lawyers and prosecutors can revisit the evidence in the case.
lead_paragraph: John Giuca, the Brooklyn man convicted of the 2003 murder of a college football player, will receive a hearing in which prosecutors and his lawyers can revisit the evidence in the case, a judge ruled Thursday.

headline: David Sweat, New York Prison Escapee, Is Arraigned
abstract: Mr. Sweat, a convicted killer who escaped from the Clinton Correctional Facility in June, did not enter a plea in his first court appearance since he was returned to custody.
lead_paragraph: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y. — A New York prison escapee who was at the center of a three-week manhunt faced charges on Thursday in his first public appearance since his capture.

headline: Banksy’s Latest: ‘Dismaland’ Theme Park
abstract: Banksy has created an “alternative to the sugar-coated tedium of the average family day out” in a town on England’s west coast.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The graffiti artist Banksy has unveiled his latest exhibition, a haunted, anti-theme park called “Dismaland,” featuring his art and works by about 60 other artists.

headline: Alexis Tsipras, Greek Prime Minister, Calls for New Elections
abstract: Mr. Tsipras, facing a revolt in his party over a bailout package, said he would submit his resignation and ask for new elections to be held on Sept. 20.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece called Thursday for new national elections in a bid to consolidate his power and press ahead with the 86 billion euro bailout plan he agreed to with European creditors.

headline: Can Black Art Ever Escape the Politics of Race?
abstract: Richard Wright, Chris Rock and the enduring dilemma of African-American artists.
lead_paragraph: For 18 months, the writer Richard Wright, late of Harlem and Biloxi, Miss., lay sick, then convalescent, then sick again, then dying, in France, writing thousands of haiku. This lasted from 1959 to 1960, years of chaos and promise and growth around the world, especially in Africa, where nation after nation threw off its colonial oppressors.

headline: Thwarted in Russia, ‘Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde’ Will Be Read at a Benefit in New York
abstract: Sally Field, Michael C. Hall, David Hyde Pierce and others will stage a reading of “Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde” in October.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to stage a gay-themed play about Oscar Wilde in Moscow foundered in June on the Russian government’s hostility toward homosexuality and the use of foreign funds for artistic productions. Now, the New York-based theater company that was partnering in that project will hold a one-night-only, impressively cast benefit reading of the play in October in Manhattan to focus attention on what it calls Russia’s suppression of the rights of gays and lesbians.

headline: 1965: Auschwitz Judge Weeps
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Judge Hans Hofmeyer weeps as the Auschwitz trial comes to an end in 1965.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Twenty months to the day after it started, Germany’s marathon Auschwitz trial came to an end this afternoon in a highly emotional heart-gripping tone.

headline: David Bailey’s Latest Muse: a Tod’s Handbag
abstract: The photographer’s latest portrait is a departure from the swinging ’60s images he’s known for.
lead_paragraph: The prolific photographer David Bailey, known for capturing the likes of the Beatles and Andy Warhol in the ’60s, turned his lens recently to an inanimate subject: the classic leather Tod’s Cape Bag. “Tod’s asked me to imagine the bag in whatever way I wanted,” says Bailey, whose summer photo exhibition, “Stardust,” was sponsored by the Italian house. “For the first time in my career, a bag is the lead character in my work. It’s not a fashion shoot, and it’s not editorial. It’s really a portrait.” Above is an exclusive first look at one of Bailey’s images, which he says “show a woman’s intimate and profound connection with this very special object.” The rest will debut online at tods.com beginning Aug. 31.

headline: Uncertainty Looms Over The Undefeated, ESPN’s Site on Sports and Race
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The Learning Network, a free blog about teaching and learning with The New York Times, has updated their student crosswords section. Teachers who have a subscription to the New York Times Crossword will enjoy sharing these topical puzzles, made by veteran Times constructor Frank Longo, with their students.

headline: Jeffrey Ubben Buys Minority Stake in United Talent Agency
abstract: The agency will use the investment of undisclosed size from the activist hedge fund operator for expansion, including the acquisition of a music agency.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s third-largest talent agency has sold a minority stake to the activist hedge fund operator Jeffrey Ubben and will use the money for expansion, including the immediate acquisition of a music agency.

headline: Birmingham Bounce: Raising the Minimum Wage in the South
keywords: ['City Councils', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'States (US)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: By instituting a city-level minimum wage, Birmingham, Ala. could help pave the way for a higher federal minimum.
lead_paragraph: By a vote of 7 to 0 with one abstention, the city council of Birmingham, Ala. adopted a citywide minimum wage this week of $10.10 by 2017, with increases for inflation every year after that.

headline: Nail Salon Sweeps Continue as Violations Are Found in Queens
keywords: ['Nails (Body Part)', 'Beauty Salons', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Wage and health violations in manicure shops extend beyond New York City; Connecticut and New Jersey authorities have recently taken action.
lead_paragraph: The four investigators holding clipboards and clad in navy New York State jerseys descended on Lyn’s Nail Salon I on Thursday morning. The owner, Andy No Tran, scrambled to show his papers, and stammered when explaining just how many employees he had.

headline: Overcoming Love Addiction: One Apple Martini at a Time
abstract: He said he didn’t like martinis, but she said to trust her. They went down like candy. They danced to the Bee Gees on the jukebox, and he kissed her.
lead_paragraph: I appeared as a love addict on a live morning television talk show in Detroit in the late 1980s, when I was 28. The producer, whom I knew through my job as a New York City book publicist, arranged for me to fly out to be a guest, along with an author who had written a book on love addiction.

headline: An Ashley Madison Recession? Or an Ashley Madison Stimulus?
abstract: Exploring the possible economic effects of the disclosure of millions of would-be cheating spouses.
lead_paragraph: The revelation of who opened accounts on the Ashley Madison site for adulterers got the attention of curiousity seekers and suspicious spouses. Josh Barro and Justin Wolfers had a different impulse. They wondered whether a surge in marital trouble resulting from the Ashley Madison hack could hurt the economy — or even, surprisingly, make it grow faster.

headline: Two Sisters, Two Weddings, Too Much
abstract: Between siblings, wedding competition; dealing with a neighbor’s disapproval; when leftovers beckon.
lead_paragraph: My sister and I have both been in long-term relationships. She got engaged in February, and I in May. We are both planning weddings for next year. She picked her date, then I picked one two months before it. She is unhappy about this. She told me I should not get married within three months of her date, before or after, which blocks out six months of the year. But my fiancé and I want the time of year we chose. Shouldn’t more happy events make people happier?

headline: Female Soldiers in Combat
abstract: What factors should the secretary of defense consider in deciding which positions, if any, should be kept off limits to women in the military?

headline: Britain to Reopen Embassy in Iran, Nearly 4 Years After It Was Ransacked
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'International Relations']
abstract: Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond is likely to reopen the embassy in Tehran on Sunday, in a significant indication of warming Western relations with Iran.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a significant indication of warming Western relations with Iran after a deal limiting its nuclear program, Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond will reopen Britain’s embassy in Tehran, probably on Sunday, British officials said Thursday.

headline: Tesla Stations at Airbnb Locations
abstract: A partnership between Airbnb and Tesla Motors will provide charging stations in a number of West Coast cities.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb and Tesla Motors are starting a partnership to bring Tesla car charging stations to 30 Airbnb properties along the West Coast in cities such as Los Angeles, Palm Springs and Healdsburg, Calif. Tesla has donated and installed the stations that are meant to give travelers freedom on their road trips, according to Chip Conley, head of global hospitality and strategy at Airbnb. “When considering accommodations, Tesla drivers are limited by how far they can get on their car’s battery charge, but this partnership alleviates that constraint,” he said.

headline: 1895: Churchill in Cuba
abstract: Mark Bulik takes a look at one of the first times that Winston Churchill was mentioned in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Leave a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Escaped Prisoner Appears at Arraignment
abstract: David Sweat, an inmate who escaped in June, appeared in court on Thursday, charged with two counts of escape in the first degree, and one count of promoting prison contraband in the first degree.
lead_paragraph: David Sweat, an inmate who escaped in June, appeared in court on Thursday, charged with two counts of escape in the first degree, and one count of promoting prison contraband in the first degree.

headline: Painstakingly Assembled Images of Sacred Spaces
abstract: Markus Brunetti spends weeks photographing churches in great detail — and even longer digitally assembling his pictures.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: A Day in the Life | Neville Jacobs
abstract: Marc Jacobs’s bull terrier spends a day at the office, where he goes on set with the stylist Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele and works out with his French bulldog pal Charlie.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs’s bull terrier spends a day at the office, where he goes on set with the stylist Carlyne Cerf de Dudzeele and works out with his French bulldog pal Charlie.

headline: Accuser in St. Paul’s Rape Case Defends Account in Cross-Examination
abstract: A defense lawyer for Owen Labrie, the St. Paul’s graduate accused of rape, pressed his accuser on the details of their May 2014 encounter.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — The day’s cross-examination began with questions about oral sex, emails and uncomfortable laughter.

headline: Marco Rubio Gives Hillary Clinton Staunch Challenge in Bellwether States, Poll Shows
abstract: In a Quinnipiac University survey of voters in Ohio, Florida and Pennsylvania, Marco Rubio beats Hillary Rodham Clinton in a general election matchup by the widest margins of any Republican presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida could be the toughest Republican challenger for Hillary Rodham Clinton in three crucial swing states if the two were to face off in the general election, a new poll from Quinnipiac University has found.

headline: Hytner and Starr’s London Theater Company Chooses Site on the Thames for Its Home
abstract: The London Theater Company, a new venture, say it will open in the spring of 2017 in theater on the south bank of the Thames.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London Theater Company — a commercial venture by Nicholas Hytner and Nick Starr, the former artistic director and executive director of the National Theater here —  will open in the spring of 2017 in a 900-seat venue on London’s south bank, the company announced Thursday.

headline: Who Is Marc Jacobs?
abstract: The trendsetting fashion designer finds himself at a crossroads.
lead_paragraph: HI, I’M MARC,” says a smiling, shortish, muscular man in a very white shirt and black trousers with even whiter socks. He has a housekeeper (“This is Reisa”) and a personal chef (“This is Lauren”), but he answers the door of his West Village townhouse himself, at least when reporters come over. He looks 38 or 39 and is definitely Jewish, but maybe he could also be Greek. “I thought it was so strange this morning,” says Marc, who is not going to say anything stranger than the fact that he’s actually 52, “but Nick said, ‘I left you a folder with Sarah, a picture of Sarah,’ and I was like, ‘Why, so I wouldn’t let someone else in the building?’ But no, the press office just did it. They put a picture of you, and like, who you wrote for. Like, as if that would change anything.”

headline: Can You Spot the Mimic?
abstract: Many species in nature mimic other organisms or features of their environment. Can you figure out which is the original and which is the mimic?
lead_paragraph: Many species in nature mimic other organisms or features of their environment. Can you figure out which is the original and which is the mimic?

headline: Evolving a Defense, Mimics Save Themselves
abstract: Many animals rely on elaborate disguises to hide from predators. But the disguises often seem to be more detailed than they need to be.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian tiger swallowtail caterpillar is a plump green creature that spends all its time munching leaves. It ought to be an easy meal for a bird, yet many birds pass it by.

headline: Neither Rain Nor Snow Nor Gloom of Night Stays Amazon Deliveries
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Letters', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: Amazon has given a welcome boost to the beleaguered United States Postal Service.
lead_paragraph: The giant e-marketeer Amazon may not have delivery drones in the air yet, but it does have letter carriers from local post offices busy delivering its packages to customers. In an innovative venture into e-commerce by the hard-pressed United States Postal Service, letter carriers in major cities have been making deliveries since October not only of the usual Amazon products but also of fresh milk, eggs, fish and other perishable commodities as Amazon continues its insatiable spread into the nation’s commercial aisles.

headline: Universal Conquers the Box Office, Without a Superhero
abstract: The studio has a string of nine hits out of its last 10 releases with a range of nonsuperhero films, including “Straight Outta Compton,” “Jurassic World” and “Minions.”
lead_paragraph: “No capes.”

headline: Palestinian Ends Hunger Strike, and His Condition Improves
abstract: A day after Israel temporarily suspended his indefinite detention, Mohammad Allan had officially agreed to give up his protest fast.
lead_paragraph: A Palestinian hunger striker whose deteriorating health has posed a challenge to Israel’s policy of indefinite incarceration has agreed to give up his fast, one of his lawyers said Thursday as doctors said his condition had improved significantly.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Raises Prospect of Removing Times Square Pedestrian Plazas
abstract: The area has come under scrutiny, with some New Yorkers complaining about the proliferation of performers who are said to be accosting pedestrians for tips.
lead_paragraph: When New York City installed pedestrian plazas in Times Square six years ago, replacing traffic-choked streets with beach chairs and picnic tables, the move prompted civic controversy, late-night monologue jokes and, eventually, widespread praise as an influential innovation in urban design.

headline: London Theater Journal: A Nonstop Carnival of Culpability
abstract: A throbbing, infection production of Euripides’ “The Bakkhai” stars Ben Whishaw as Dionysos; and Rory Kinnear plays Joseph K, Kafka’s bewildered and shame-stained hero, in “The Trial.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Wine was very much on the menu on the third night of my summer visit to this city. Not for me. (I’m still sticking to my anti-jetlag regimen of gallons of water and coffee.) But the juice of the grape was being extolled as absolutely essential to our daily diet at the Almeida Theater in Islington, where a riveting production of Euripides’s “Bakkhai” was hypnotizing a packed house.

headline: Jean-Marie Le Pen, Co-Founder of National Front, Is Ousted From French Far-Right Party
abstract: Jean-Marie Le Pen, who co-founded the National Front, was excluded on Thursday from the party following a disciplinary hearing.
lead_paragraph: NANTERRE, France — Jean-Marie Le Pen, a co-founder of France’s far-right National Front, was expelled from the party on Thursday after he repeatedly angered its current leader, his daughter Marine, by reviving the party’s anti-Semitic past, which she is eager to shed.

headline: Once Voters Get the ‘Narrative,’ Jeb Bush Says, They’ll Turn to Him Over Donald Trump
abstract: A day after being called “low-energy” by Donald J. Trump, Jeb Bush fired away by saying there was a big difference between him and Mr. Trump, especially on issues dear to conservative hearts.
lead_paragraph: KEENE, N.H. — The day after dueling New Hampshire town-hall-style meetings left Jeb Bush the recipient of snide attacks from Donald J. Trump, Mr. Bush offered some not-so-friendly fire of his own.

headline: Airstrikes Kill 43 Militants in Northwestern Pakistan, Military Says
abstract: After jets pounded parts of the North Waziristan tribal region, ground troops moved in to clear the area of militants, the military said.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military said Thursday that its ground troops had begun moving into Shawal, the last area in the North Waziristan tribal region to feel the force of the military’s offensive against militants.

headline: Exploring Assisi in Italy
abstract: A new kind of tourist is being drawn by the same mystical essence that more traditional religious pilgrims believe can be felt in the woods around Francis’ hometown.
lead_paragraph: A new kind of tourist is being drawn by the same mystical essence that more traditional religious pilgrims believe can be felt in the woods around Francis’ hometown.

headline: Bad Singing and Fire Eating: Actors on Their ‘Special Skills’
abstract: Common skills like speaking with accents, juggling and handling stage combat are standard. But others are special and considered valuable.
lead_paragraph: Look past the eyes, hair and height. Keep scanning down, after the college “Hamlet” and the regional “Little Shop of Horrors.” There, at the bottom of almost any actor’s résumé, in small letters, is a list of tricks that reads like an especially manic night at “The Ed Sullivan Show.” Acrobatics, martial arts, hula hoop: just some of the unusual and quirky kinds of expertise found under the category of Special Skills.

headline: Request for Grand Jury Records in Eric Garner Case Is Rejected
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: A Staten Island judge turned down the Civilian Complaint Review Board’s request for the documents, writing that the board had not demonstrated a need and disclosure would set a negative precedent.
lead_paragraph: A Staten Island judge on Thursday rejected a request from the Civilian Complaint Review Board for grand jury records related to the case of Eric Garner, who died last year after a police officer used a chokehold while trying to arrest him on suspicion of selling loose cigarettes.

headline: Jeb Bush Cites Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio in Defending Birthright Citizenship
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Jeb Bush mentioned two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination in defending birthright citizenship, saying they might not be able to run for president if some in the conservative wing of the Republican Party had their way.
lead_paragraph: NEW LONDON, N.H. — Jeb Bush invoked the names of two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination as he waded into the debate over birthright citizenship and immigration on Thursday, saying that Senators Ted Cruz of Texas and Marco Rubio of Florida might not be able to run for president if some in the conservative wing of the Republican Party had their way.

headline: Coca-Cola to Disclose Its Spending on Research Into Soft Drinks and Health
abstract: The company was criticized after disclosure that it had financial ties to a group that argues for less concern about eating habits and more emphasis on exercise.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola says it will begin disclosing its investments in scientific research and advocacy about the impact sugary soft drinks have on public health.

headline: Drought Brings Soul-Searching to California Winemaking
abstract: The drought has hit some regions hard, but others not. Extreme weather is causing some wineries to rethink how they use water and how they operate.
lead_paragraph: St. HELENA, Calif. — At the rustic Smith-Madrone Vineyards high up on Spring Mountain, nobody has been thinking about the drought, which has absorbed so much of the conversation about California this year.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Grandma’
abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Grandma.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews “Grandma.”

headline: Seventeen Transgender Killings Contrast With Growing Visibility
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: The brutal death of a 36-year-old transgender woman over the weekend is the latest in what activists are calling an alarming rise in anti-transgender violence.
lead_paragraph: The brutal death of a 36-year-old transgender woman in Kansas City, Mo., is the latest in what activists are calling an alarming rise in anti-transgender violence.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
abstract: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 20, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photographs from The United States, Indonesia, Egypt and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from The United States, Indonesia, Egypt and Spain.

headline: Daughter-in-Law of Senator Skelos Is Arrested in Domestic Dispute on Long Island
abstract: Ann Marie Skelos, who was charged with breaking her nephew’s glasses, is the wife of Adam B. Skelos, who faces corruption charges along with his father, Senator Dean G. Skelos.
lead_paragraph: The family of State Senator Dean G. Skelos, who was arrested on federal corruption charges in May with his son Adam, has some new legal troubles, though of a different order of magnitude.

headline: Top 15 Fantasy Football Running Backs
abstract: Jason and Justin Sablich, who provide fantasy football analysis for The New York Times, pick their 15 favorite running backs for 2015.
lead_paragraph: Jason and Justin Sablich, who provide fantasy football analysis for The New York Times, pick their 15 favorite running backs for 2015.

headline: Tracking a Rare Nautilus in Papua New Guinea
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: These ancient creatures with big shells are so good at hiding from researchers that they went decades without a definitive sighting.
lead_paragraph: These ancient creatures with big shells are so good at hiding from researchers that they went decades without a definitive sighting.

headline: Investors Hope to Ride Swell of SoulCycle Fever in Coming I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Health Clubs', 'Exercise', 'Hedge Funds']
abstract: Boutique fitness centers that cater to those willing to pay more for a good sweat are on the rise, and wealthy backers are betting this market is more than a craze.
lead_paragraph: Early on a summer morning in Manhattan’s Upper East Side, dozens of mostly young, svelte women file into a quiet, candlelit studio where they mount gleaming stationary bikes. Soft clicks can be heard as they fasten their shoes to the pedals.

headline: Spokesman for Hillary Clinton Offers New Take on Email Issue
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Brian Fallon, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s press secretary, said members of a House committee might have unwittingly handled classified material on unclassified systems, just like Mrs. Clinton apparently did when she was at the State Department.
lead_paragraph: As Brian Fallon, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s press secretary, defended her on Wednesday during a conference call about her email use, he made a novel argument that got lost in the haze of questions.

headline: Recipes From the Four Horsemen’s One-Month Anniversary Staff Meal
abstract: Brooklyn’s buzzy new restaurant and wine bar shares its roasted chicken.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer, at noon on what may have been the hottest day of the year, the buzzy new Brooklyn restaurant and wine bar the Four Horsemen hadn’t yet opened its doors for service — they usually serve from the late afternoon until late at night — but three tables had been pushed together and were being set for a feast. The restaurant, which debuted in June, is a collaboration between the consultant Justin Chearno and partners Randy Moon, Christina Topsoe and her husband, the musician James Murphy — who invited the rest of their staff and collaborators to celebrate something of a milestone: making it past the one-month mark and finally having a moment to breathe.

headline: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Answers to Questions About New Findings
abstract: A large study following 100,000 patients with ductal carcinoma in situ for 20 years raises doubts about the standard treatment for the conditions.
lead_paragraph: Q. What is D.C.I.S.?

headline: HP Profit Falls in Last Report Before Company Splits
abstract: Earnings fell 13 percent in the third quarter, illustrating the headwinds Hewlett-Packard is facing.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday that its profit fell 13 percent in the third quarter, a reminder of the grim challenges prompting a breakup of the company in the coming months.

headline: Greek Prime Minister Resigns
abstract: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece announced Thursday that he would resign after less than a year in office and that new elections would be called.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece announced Thursday that he would resign after less than a year in office and that new elections would be called.

headline: Review: In ‘Guidance,’ a High School Counselor as a Rotten Role Model
abstract: Pat Mills wrote, directed and stars in this black comedy about a former child star who fraudulently gets a job of giving advice to teenagers.
lead_paragraph: “Stay out of the sun,” a doctor warns David (Pat Mills) early in “Guidance,” a ferociously black comedy about growing older without growing up. On the heels of a diagnosis of Stage 3 melanoma, David makes a beeline for the tanning salon, cigarette in hand. He’s not in shock, he’s in denial.

headline: ‘Royal Hawaiian Featherwork,’ a Glimpse at Island Splendors
abstract: This show, opening soon at the de Young Museum in San Francisco, explores the iridescent wonders of feathered objects from centuries past.
lead_paragraph: Since at least the 15th century, collectors have competed for feathers sewn and glued onto fabrics, jewelry, fans and statues. New books and exhibitions have reunited widely scattered feathered objects made in Latin America and the Pacific islands, and growing archival evidence shows that the birds used for raw materials were treated relatively well — that is, plucked sustainably.

headline: A Rich Lode of American Ceramics Discoveries
abstract: Handmade wares from before the Industrial Revolution are inspiring a wealth of exhibitions and lectures.
lead_paragraph: The Industrial Revolution drove countless American ceramics workshops out of business. Traces of these wares, whether well-preserved porcelain cups or smashed storage jars, are inspiring lectures and exhibitions.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Aaron Flint Jamison’s Craft of Technology
abstract: Mr. Jamison’s exhibition at the Miguel Abreu Gallery considers the disruption of conventional systems.
lead_paragraph: AARON FLINT JAMISON

headline: Review: ‘Portraiture Now,’ a Group Show of Latino Artists
abstract: Organized by the National Portrait Gallery, the exhibition at the Americas Society reimagines the form in imaginative ways.
lead_paragraph: ‘PORTRAITURE NOW’

headline: Cadillac Has New Boss, New Address and Big Plans
abstract: Cadillac, which has moved to Manhattan, used aggressive design and performance to put its old image in the past, but that comeback has since stalled.
lead_paragraph: Can a South African-born former Audi executive, who recently spurned Japanese masters in Hong Kong, lead a Detroit luxury brand back to greatness — and from a new base in Manhattan?

headline: Review: ‘Empty House Casa Vazia’ Highlights Brazilian Artists
abstract: This exhibition at Luhring Augustine places the work of 18 Brazilian artists spanning generations on a historical and stylistic continuum.
lead_paragraph: ‘EMPTY HOUSE CASA VAZIA’

headline: Review: Tamuna Sirbiladze Combines Art and Decoration at Half Gallery
abstract: This Georgian artist splits the difference between painting and drawing in her first New York solo.
lead_paragraph: TAMUNA SIRBILADZE

headline: FanFest, for Yankees Stalwarts of All Ages
abstract: Three blocks in Little Italy will be turned over to Yankees-themed carnival games and autograph opportunities with former players. Then you can savor pastry treats and music.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees are taking over Little Italy. And not just on TV screens in bars and restaurants. Mulberry Street, from Canal to Broome Streets, will become a pop-up village for Yankees devotees as part of the annual FanFest, presented by the radio station WFAN.

headline: Podcast: Inside The Times’s Political Coverage
abstract: The Washington bureau chief and political editor, Carolyn Ryan, talks with Times Insider about the paper’s campaign coverage.
lead_paragraph: What presidential candidates warrant what kind of coverage?

headline: Review: Faile Mines the Dark Depths of Modern Youth With Two Exhibitions
abstract: Exhibitions by the duo Faile at the Brooklyn Museum and in Times Square feature appropriation of graphic signifiers from many times and places.
lead_paragraph: The title of an exhibition by the two-artist team Faile at the Brooklyn Museum is certainly promising: “Savage/Sacred Young Minds.” Considering American society’s neurotic preoccupation with youth and the hugely profitable exploitation of that obsession by a vast array of commercial enterprises, it’s a potentially rich vein for imaginative mining. In recent decades, artists like Mike Kelley and Jim Shaw have fruitfully excavated the weird, dark side of adolescent consciousness to reveal its narcissism, hypersexuality, grandiosity, and penchants for magical thinking and instant gratification.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday, With Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter
abstract: Jimmy Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, on Nov. 2, 1976, the night he was elected president.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Coming Up Red
abstract: A 1908 exhibition series introduced the Cincinnati Reds to its first class of baseball players from Cuba, and the team has had an eye for the island’s talent ever since.
lead_paragraph: A 1908 exhibition series introduced the Cincinnati Reds to its first class of baseball players from Cuba, and the team has had an eye for the island’s talent ever since.

headline: Western Wildfires Consume Manpower and Acreage
abstract: Even before three firefighter deaths Wednesday, fire managers had been struggling to find enough staff to combat blazes in the Northwest and Northern California.
lead_paragraph: CHELAN, Wash. — Firefighters often talk about wildfires as living things, each one different in its inherently dangerous behavior and fickle shifts of temper. They are so unpredictable that even a seemingly mundane part of the day — getting to the job — can turn deadly.

headline: Jets’ Reserve Lineman Suspended One Game
abstract: Oday Aboushi, a reserve offensive lineman for the Jets, was suspended one game for violating the N.F.L.’s substance-abuse policy and program.
lead_paragraph: Oday Aboushi, a reserve offensive lineman for the Jets, was suspended one game for violating the N.F.L.’s substance-abuse policy and program. He was the second member of the team to receive a drug-related ban, joining Sheldon Richardson, who was docked four games after testing positive at least twice for marijuana.

headline: Review: In ‘Sinister 2,’ a Murderous Being Returns for More Mayhem
abstract: In this horror sequel, a woman takes refuge in a rural home with her twin sons, who are then manipulated by evil.
lead_paragraph: In “Sinister,” from 2012, a true-crime writer (Ethan Hawke) moved his family into a house that had been the site of a multiple murder. In the attic he discovered grainy home-movie-like films of other killings. He also met a pagan entity, Bughuul, who in whisking the souls of children to a nether realm, creates minions who do his homicidal bidding.

headline: Review: L.A. Dance Project’s Tale of Murder, Sprightly and With Sneakers
abstract: Assembled by Benjamin Millepied, the company performed dances by Justin Peck, Roy Assaf and Mr. Millepied at Jacob’s Pillow on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — L.A. Dance Project came east to Jacob’s Pillow here on Wednesday with three works in tow and a new associate artistic director: the exceptional, recently retired Pacific Northwest Ballet principal Carla Körbes. The company’s Pillow performance also coincided with the final appearances of another esteemed dancer, Charlie Hodges, who served as the group’s rehearsal director.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Sinister 2’
abstract: The Times critic Andrew Webster reviews “Sinister 2.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Andrew Webster reviews “Sinister 2.”

headline: Egon Bahr, Who Laid Groundwork for German Reunification, Dies at 93
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Cold War Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'International Relations', 'Berlin Wall']
abstract: Mr. Bahr, an architect of Ostpolitik, West Germany’s Cold War policy of rapprochement, believed the best way to narrow Germany’s division was through negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Egon Bahr, a prominent Social Democrat whose efforts to improve West Germany’s relations with the Soviet bloc helped pave the way for German reunification 45 years after World War II, has died, the party announced on Thursday. He was 93.

headline: Credit Scores Are Rising, and Becoming More Visible
abstract: Wider access to free credit scores could be a factor in pushing the national average FICO score to its highest level in at least 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Consumers appear to be better these days at managing their use of credit: Average scores have reached new highs and delinquent payments have dropped.

headline: Afropunk Festival Brings Music, Dancing and Haute Street Fashion to Brooklyn
abstract: The Afropunk Festival in Brooklyn is growing in breadth, depth and appeal, with Grace Jones, Lenny Kravitz, Raury, Danny Brown and Death Grips among the performers.
lead_paragraph: Eleven years in, Afropunk Fest, Brooklyn’s weekend-long blowout celebration of the diaspora of black music and culture, is more wide-ranging than ever. It’s now possible to imagine the skate kids and fashion bloggers who populate the scene coming with their parents to catch headliners including Grace Jones, Lenny Kravitz and Gary Clark Jr. Up-and-coming acts like Raury, rap stars (Danny Brown) and punkers (Death Grips) are also on the bill for the festival, with doors opening Saturday at noon at Commodore Barry Park in Fort Greene; expect food trucks, on-site mural painting, interactive art and a dance-friendly D.J. stage.

headline: Review: Kamasi Washington and the West Coast Get Down Are Blowing Through Town
abstract: Touring after his first album was released this year, Kamasi Washington has recently taken part in musical projects beyond jazz.
lead_paragraph: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. — Kamasi Washington blew his tenor saxophone in heavy gusts — rangy and intemperate, or clipped and urgent — throughout the exultant sprawl of his concert at the Bearsville Theater here on Wednesday night. His sound assumed an almost tactile force in the room, an extension of his burly and stoic presence onstage. And yet that sound wasn’t the most impressive facet of the performance, which ran a little over two hours, with an intuitive, almost constant ebb and flow. What really drove the agenda was the smart, hurtling fury of Mr. Washington’s band, the West Coast Get Down, a Los Angeles demolition crew partway through its first tour. Among the remaining dates are two at the Blue Note in New York City, on Monday and Tuesday.

headline: Review: In ‘American Ultra,’ Jesse Eisenberg Is a Stoner and a Target
abstract: Kristen Stewart and Mr. Eisenberg pair up again in this film, an action adventure with C.I.A. trouble and occasional laughs.
lead_paragraph: Some of the many, many promotional spots for “American Ultra” make it seem like more of a comedy than it is. That’s not said as a criticism, just a warning. If you go, expect a diverting summer action adventure with occasional laughs, not a diverting stoner comedy with occasional action.

headline: In His First New York Show in Five Years, Shepard Fairey Is Still Questioning Everything
abstract: “On Our Hands,” at Jacob Lewis Gallery, examines familiar themes, but with a considerably more complex process.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 18, the street artist Shepard Fairey will open his first solo show in New York since 2010’s “Mayday” — the suitably colossal closing exhibition at the now-defunct Deitch Projects. Fairey’s latest offering, a series of new mixed-media paintings titled “On Our Hands,” will serve as his inaugural exhibition at Jacob Lewis Gallery, effectively consummating a 10-year friendship between the artist and Mr. Lewis, the gallery’s owner and the first director of the influential Pace Prints in Chelsea. “Jacob looks at every aspect of what the artist is doing, not just the genre, the price or how in fashion you are,” notes Fairey from his studio in Los Angeles, where he continues to finalize the collection. “If you look at the other artists he’s worked with, whether it’s Ryan McGinness or How and Nosm, they’re the only people doing what they do.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘American Ultra’
abstract: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews “American Ultra.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews “American Ultra.”

headline: A German Artist Colony, Suspended in Time, Stakes a Place in the Contemporary Scene
abstract: Worpswede has played host to creatives from Rainer Maria Rilke to Josephine Meckseper — and is now home to an ambitious residency program.
lead_paragraph: “How large the eyes become here! They want at all times to possess the whole sky,” wrote the young poet Rainer Maria Rilke in 1900. He had just arrived at Worpswede, the fabled artist colony on a stretch of German moorland so flat it becomes almost round as the view curves along the earth’s surface with scarcely a foothill, mountain or other perpendicular obstruction in sight.

headline: Review: ‘Can I Go Now?,’ a Biography of the Hollywood Agent Sue Mengers
abstract: Brian Kellow charts Ms. Mengers’s ruthless path to success with a client list that included Ryan and Tatum O’Neal, Barbra Streisand and Gene Hackman.
lead_paragraph: The biographer Brian Kellow, whose last subject was Pauline Kael, writes in “Can I Go Now?” that even he had doubts about whether the Hollywood agent Sue Mengers would make a good subject. The idea of doing a book about her came from his agent. And even allowing for any prejudices an agent might have about how interesting agents are, it was still a stretch. Ms. Mengers may have been the most glam, powerful, status-conscious, star-snuggling Hollywood power broker of the 1970s, but both she and her way of doing business had gone the way of the dinosaurs by the end of that decade. Now she is Sue Who? to the world at large.

headline: This Week’s Movies | August 21, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “American Ultra,” “Grandma” and “Sinister 2.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “American Ultra,” “Grandma” and “Sinister 2.”

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Theater Listings for Aug. 21-27
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: One Wall, Two Germanys
abstract: Before the fall of the Berlin Wall, Rudi Meisel spent a decade photographing East and West Germany with a subtle take that made it hard sometimes to tell one side from the other.
lead_paragraph: Before the fall of the Berlin Wall, Rudi Meisel spent a decade photographing East and West Germany with a subtle take that made it hard sometimes to tell one side from the other.

headline: New Surge of MERS Infections Hits Saudi Arabia
abstract: The authorities closed the emergency ward of one of the kingdom’s largest hospitals after 46 new cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome appeared.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia is facing a new surge in cases of Middle East respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that has infected more than 1,100 people and killed more than 480 in the kingdom since it appeared in 2012.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, Aug. 23 to 29, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Migrants in Kos Inspire Both Hospitality and Anger in Greeks
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: Dealing with the influx of refugees has forced the Greeks, with their own country’s long economic crisis, into a strange kind of double-think.
lead_paragraph: KOS, Greece — Dawn was breaking over a beach near Kos harbor, and the first swimmers threaded their way between orange beach umbrellas into the sea.

headline: 2 Graduating Rangers, Aware of Their Burden
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Two Army Ranger graduates are set to break new ground in the military as the Pentagon prepares to decide which combat positions should be opened to women.
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga. — First Lt. Shaye Haver, an Apache attack helicopter pilot who on Friday will be one of the first women to graduate from the Army’s elite Ranger School, wants to remain an aviator. But she takes away weighty lessons from her grueling Ranger training: “Your mind can take a whole lot more than your body,” she said.

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Place to Nap After Wine Tasting
abstract: Three famous (and centuries-old) vineyards have opened newly refurbished hotel rooms.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Italian vineyards are often treated to lavish wine-tastings, four-course lunches and, sometimes, a walk around 15th-century grounds. But soon after a big meal, one is faced with a challenge: How to drive back to the hotel? Now, three famous vineyards in Tuscany and Abruzzo have solved this quandary by opening hotel rooms — newly refurbished, and often little-advertised — on the vineyard grounds.

headline: Jazz Listings for Aug. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Review: ‘Digging for Fire,’ a Comedy by Joe Swanberg
abstract: While taking care of a client’s home, a couple whose marriage is already strained takes some time apart.
lead_paragraph: “Digging for Fire,” Joe Swanberg’s new feature is, like many of his previous movies, a case study in heterosexual ethics. Its scope is narrow and, the title notwithstanding, it plumbs no great depths. But like Mr. Swanberg’s “Drinking Buddies” and “Happy Christmas,” the film has an appealing honesty and an enjoyably low-key comic style.

headline: Nature’s Lesson on Understanding Ellsworth Kelly
abstract: The best teachers for artists and those who appreciate their work might just be the birds who migrate through the area or frequent a window feeder.
lead_paragraph: Ellsworth Kelly, renowned maker of abstract, odd-shaped monochromatic paintings, has said that he developed his eye for color and form as a bird watcher when he was a child in rural New Jersey. You can see evidence of this history: in the indigo bunting blue of “Blue Panel I” from 1977; in the pointed angles, like crests on northern cardinals, of “Red-Orange Panel” from 1980; and in the snowy span, like egret wings, of “Memorial” from 1993. Or at least you can start to see it once you’ve come to grips with other, more obvious features of Mr. Kelly’s art: its radical simplicity, its merger of painting and sculpture, its romance with architecture, its contribution to the history of modernism. But all of this absorbing takes time, the way bird watching does.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Here’s the latest.

headline: Comedy Listings for Aug. 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: New York Police Sergeant Commits Suicide After Sex-Crime Charges
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The sergeant, Joel Doseau, 43, who was accused of having sex with an underage girl he met online, was arraigned this month on 40 criminal counts.
lead_paragraph: A New York police sergeant who was arrested this month on charges that he had sex with an underage girl he met online committed suicide on Thursday, the police said.

headline: Bronx Legionnaires’ Outbreak Is Over, Health Officials Say
abstract: Officials also confirmed they had traced the source of the outbreak, which claimed 12 lives and sickened more than 120 people, to a contaminated cooling tower on top of the Opera House Hotel.
lead_paragraph: New York City health officials on Thursday declared an outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease in the South Bronx officially over, saying that no new cases had been reported since Aug. 3.

headline: Movie Listings for Aug. 21-27
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. A complete list of new releases is at nytimes.com/intheaters.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Review: Rupert Friend and Zachary Quinto in a Pas de Bullets, ‘Hitman: Agent 47’
abstract: In Aleksander Bach’s revival of a franchise based on a video game, Mr. Friend plays the genetically engineered assassin-hero.
lead_paragraph: Dumb as dirt and just as generic, “Hitman: Agent 47” trades brains for bullets and characters for windup toys. So it’s all the more shocking that honest-to-goodness actors like Zachary Quinto and Rupert Friend have signed on to play the film’s two leads; maybe the director, Aleksander Bach, told them they could have a lifetime supply of their smoking-hot suits.

headline: Dance Listings for Aug. 21-27

lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.
