abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and Sites

headline: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 21-27
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: 239th Anniversary of the Battle of Brooklyn

headline: First Female Ranger School Graduates
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: First Lt. Shaye Haver and Capt. Kristen Griest attended a news conference alongside fellow students who will graduate from the Army’s grueling Ranger School.
lead_paragraph: First Lt. Shaye Haver and Capt. Kristen Griest attended a news conference alongside fellow students who will graduate from the Army’s grueling Ranger School.

headline: Judge Says Hillary Clinton Didn’t Follow Government Email Policies
abstract: Judge Emmet G. Sullivan also set steps for the F.B.I. to examine Mrs. Clinton’s server for messages she may have deleted.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday said that Hillary Rodham Clinton did not comply with government policies in her exclusive use of a personal email account while she was secretary of state, challenging her longstanding position that she abided by the rules.

headline: ‘Force Majeure’ Explores Couples’ Expectations as Gender Roles Shift
abstract: The ever-shifting expectations of husbands and wives is explored in this scalding, satirically edged film by Ruben Ostlund.
lead_paragraph: The ever-shifting expectations of husbands and wives has rarely been explored with more depth than in the Swedish director Ruben Ostlund’s scalding, satirically edged 2014 film, “Force Majeure.” In this drama of marital disruption during a luxurious ski vacation in the French Alps, the fragile male ego is subjected to relentless microscopic examination.

headline: The Merode Altarpiece at the Cloisters Represents Time Immemorial
abstract: A hyper-realistic 15th-century triptych from the Netherlands depicts one of Christianity’s foundational myths.
lead_paragraph: The Merode Altarpiece,  a triptych at the Cloisters, ranks among the world’s most beautiful paintings. Produced in the South Netherlands workshop of Robert Campin between 1427 and 1432, it’s also a time machine that shuttles the mind across millenniums while orchestrating a convergence of the natural and the supernatural.

headline: Review: ‘The Iron Ministry’ Uses Train Passengers to Tell China’s Story
abstract: J. P. Sniadecki spent nearly three years filming this documentary on the trains that carry tens of millions across the nation each year.
lead_paragraph: If a pop culture web publication ever asked me to make a list of the most cinematic forms of transportation, the train would be at the top, probably followed by the horse. Car chases are cool and everything, but the very first publicly shown movie (at least according to legend) was about a train. Trains on film are both sublime and intimate: The camera can trace the muscular movement of railway cars across the land or venture inside to observe the complicated actions of people in motion.

headline: Vintage Sax Solo Improves With (Listener’s) Age
abstract: A 1946 Dial jazz recording session with Lucky Thompson on tenor saxophone strikes a mature ear differently than it did a young one.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Parker, the matchless alto saxophonist and bebop exemplar, had few better days in a recording studio than March 28, 1946. He was in Hollywood, leading his first session under an exclusive contract with Dial Records. His handpicked sidemen included the well-seasoned tenor saxophonist Lucky Thompson and a young trumpeter named Miles Davis, and by the end of the date they had recorded several of Parker’s most canonical tracks, including “A Night in Tunisia” and “Yardbird Suite.”

headline: A Shakespeare for All Seasons
abstract: As you grow older, Shakespeare’s characters and language tend to assert themselves in your consciousness in changing ways.
lead_paragraph: For many theatergoers, summer is the season of Shakespeare, in the way it’s the season of corn and tomatoes for those who want these foods fresh from the garden. Like such comestibles, Shakespeare can be devoured in hearty single sittings — and often alfresco — what with a crop of productions that present the theatrical equivalent of a jolly picnic. For New Yorkers, an abundance of movable feasts is available, from city parks and parking lots to more sylvan environs upstate. (On my August schedule: yet another “Hamlet,” this one starring Benedict Cumberbatch, in London.)

headline: Frederick Wiseman’s Documentaries Defy Straightforward Plot
abstract: His films, like “Titicut Follies” and “At Berkeley,” examine places, institutions and social phenomena by slowly revealing the subtle layers and patterns in their topics.
lead_paragraph: The closer it hews to the conventions of journalism, the more documentary filmmaking becomes an art of compression and acceleration. You know the drill. A social problem is explored, a famous or obscure person’s life story is told, a historical episode is illuminated, in a familiar rhythm and pace. Talking-head interviews alternate with archival clips or re-enactments, all in the service of an argument or a plot. Usually it’s all over in about 90 minutes, and you take away a neat little package of outrage, empathy or enlightenment. Even long-form documentaries, like “The Jinx,” Andrew Jarecki’s mini-series on the alleged crimes of Robert Durst, follow this formula, in that they depend on the quickening of the viewer’s attention.

headline: Holding Off Emily Dickinson’s ‘Complete Poems’
abstract: The poet’s famous line — “I’m nobody! Who are you?” — is not what you want to hear when you are younger than 30.
lead_paragraph: I’m embarrassed by how long I resisted Emily Dickinson’s “Complete Poems,” and I’m struck by how much my copy means to me now. As a daft young punk I too often sought out reckless emotion and vulgar effects, the same way one sometimes wants, when callow and feckless, to date a person with obvious physical attributes. Dickinson’s famous line — “I’m nobody! Who are you?” — is not what you want to hear when you are younger than 30, or, in my delayed maturity, closer to 40. It should have helped, but did not, when one of my favorite high school English teachers, Donald Glancy, explained that you could sing nearly all of Dickinson’s verse to the tune of “The Yellow Rose of Texas.”

headline: Eliane Radigue, Mining Wisdom From 11th-Century Buddhism
abstract: A work inspired by the life of the 11th-century Tibetan yogi and poet Jetsun Milarepa.
lead_paragraph: I came pretty late to “Jetsun Mila,” by the French composer Eliane Radigue, but it may be one of those things a lot of people will feel fine about coming to pretty late. Turn it on, and it just keeps teaching.

headline: Awakening to the Joys of ‘The Sleeping Beauty’
abstract: A dance critic learns to embrace the classicism and humanity of a ballet that at first seemed all surface.
lead_paragraph: At the age of 35, I tried counting. I found I’d seen the ballet “The Sleeping Beauty” 200 times. That was 1990, precisely a century after the composer Tchaikovsky and the choreographer Marius Petipa had first presented it in St. Petersburg. Since then, I’ve watched it on many more occasions — 10 so far in 2015 alone.

headline: Another Definition for Extended Play
abstract: Giving up hours of a day to an immersive theater experience can be a particularly pleasurable escape from the world.
lead_paragraph: I like a short show. A 90-minute play means more time to write, more time to relax, a chance to see my husband before he goes to sleep, no tedious intermission. But I also have a sneaking fondness for longer plays. Much, much, much longer ones.

headline: Mondrian’s Paintings and Their Pulsating Intricacy
abstract: Five works at MoMA summarize the artist’s quest to activate the surface of the canvas and open the viewer’s eyes.
lead_paragraph: The longer I look at Mondrian’s paintings, the more I see in them. This applies to lots of art, but I think Mondrian built real time into his paintings. They unfold with unusual deliberation in a semblance of symmetry and order that is actually precarious, even volatile. This is especially true of his mature works from the late 1920s to the early 1940s, with their tensile fusions of glowing white backgrounds, black scaffoldings and blocks of bright primaries. Everything about them, the tiniest decision, is evident and has visual repercussions.

headline: Revisiting ‘The X-Files,’ a Series Worth Another Watch
abstract: Endlessly imitated and never equaled, this show was ahead of its time in its subject matter, format and ability to balance mythology and procedural episodes.
lead_paragraph: Television is not an art of slow contemplation. Watching it in real time is more or less a requirement. (My DVR offers slow-motion playback, which has its uses, but they’re not artistic.)

headline: ‘It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia’ Converts a Skeptic
abstract: A critic says he has come to appreciate this sitcom, even how it invents new ways for its core characters to behave badly.
lead_paragraph: For years I was put off by the unrelenting crudeness of the television comedy “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia.” In 2011 I wrote a minute-by-minute comparison of its Season 7 premiere with the Season 3 premiere of another crass show, “Blue Mountain State,” assessing which was more vulgar. It was a tongue-in-cheek article, but the tsk-tsking undertone was undeniable.

headline: For Bruckner’s Seventh Symphony, a Long Delayed Appreciation
abstract: It was deeper immersion in Wagner and Schubert that opened a music critic to Bruckner, the master Austrian symphonist.
lead_paragraph: By the time I was a music major in college, with all the composers of the past competing for my attention, I had decided I could take a pass on Anton Bruckner. Many great artists, including the conductor Bruno Walter, whom I idolized, championed Bruckner (1824-1896) as a master Austrian symphonist. But from my impatient samplings of those symphonies, Bruckner struck me as a kind of ponderously monumental Brahms, or an inert and stretched-out Mahler.

headline: Running the Alps
abstract: A Swiss mountain guide crossed five 4,000-meter peaks in less than eight hours this month.
lead_paragraph: A Swiss mountain guide crossed five 4,000-meter peaks in less than eight hours this month.

headline: Review: ‘Learning to Drive’ Charts a Culture-Bridging Friendship
abstract: This grown-up drama stars Patricia Clarkson as a New York book critic, and Ben Kingsley as her Indian-American driving instructor.
lead_paragraph: Among the charms of “Learning to Drive,” a small, observant dual portrait of a New York book critic and her Indian-American driving instructor, are the detailed, lived-in performances of its stars, Patricia Clarkson and Ben Kingsley. The film belongs to a school of grown-up, low-drama two-handers, of which the most famous example is “Driving Miss Daisy,” but “Learning to Drive” isn’t half as sentimental. As this movie, directed by Isabel Coixet, tracks the deepening friendship between people from different cultures and backgrounds, it acquires an unforced metaphorical resonance.

headline: Kazakhstan’s Currency Plunges
abstract: Financial analysts say the currencies of Kazakhstan’s neighbors in Central Asia will likely fall, as well.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Kazakhstan’s currency, the tenge, plunged by about a quarter on Thursday after the central bank stopped managing the exchange rate, prompting fears that a wider emerging market currency rout could be coming.

headline: Review: Hapless Brothers and Their Lovers Intersect in ‘The Mend’
abstract: Two brothers contend with girlfriends past and present in John Magary’s character-driven study of masculinity.
lead_paragraph: Funny, rugged and raw, “The Mend” fits its story together from rough patches in the lives of two nose-diving New York brothers. Mat (Josh Lucas) is a freeloader (and sometime jerk) who is thrown out of the house by his girlfriend, Andrea (Lucy Owen). The slow-burning Alan (Stephen Plunkett) is treading water with his girlfriend, Farrah (Mickey Sumner), and hopes to take a big step when they are on a planned trip together. Directing his first feature after some shorts, John Magary digs into his characters with fresh eyes and a sly sense of adventure.

headline: The Art of Slow
abstract: Cultural critics of The New York Times suggest works that reward long and leisurely contemplation.
lead_paragraph: Cultural critics of The New York Times suggest works that reward long and leisurely contemplation.

headline: Writer’s Room: Jeanette Winterson
abstract: Inside the novelist’s rustic writing studio in Glouchestershire, England.
lead_paragraph: Inside the novelist’s rustic writing studio in Glouchestershire, England.

headline: ‘Female Viagra’ Poses Challenges for Buyer Valeant
abstract: Low efficacy, side effects and regulations all threaten to put a crimp in sales of the newly approved libido drug for women.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is popping a risky $1 billion libido pill.

headline: Review: ‘She’s Funny That Way’ Offers Tomfoolery Amid the Floodlights
abstract: Peter Bogdanovich’s first feature in more than a dozen years is a screwball comedy centered on a Broadway director and his circle.
lead_paragraph: If only the title of “She’s Funny That Way” were true, then maybe this creaky throwback padded with Hollywood names and fake accents could be forgiven its many failings. But there’s barely a whiz-bang punch line or smoothly executed setup to be found in a movie that longs to be a sparkling bedroom comedy and winds up a tortured, fizz-free farce.

headline: Gay Couples Are Eligible for Social Security Benefits, U.S. Decides
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: The Justice Department said the Social Security Administration would apply the Supreme Court’s June ruling declaring marriage a constitutional right retroactively.
lead_paragraph: Same-sex married couples who were living in states that did not recognize their unions and who previously filed claims for Social Security benefits will be able to collect those payments, the government said on Thursday.

headline: Review of Saltbox Restaurant & Bar in Montauk, in the O’Murphy’s Pub Space
abstract: The stylish restaurant, which offers pub fare with an Asian twist, has been embraced by locals and tourists alike in a changing town.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Saltbox Restaurant & Bar in Montauk would seem to be an easy target for local skeptics.

headline: ‘Ornithology,’ From ‘The Complete Dial Modern Jazz Sessions’
abstract: A track including a tenor saxophone solo by Lucky Thompson.
lead_paragraph: A track including a tenor saxophone solo by Lucky Thompson.

headline: ‘Human Resources’: Reality TV About a Recycling Company
keywords: ['Television', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Workplace Environment', 'Reality Television']
abstract: The show, on Pivot, features the workplace at TerraCycle, a quirky, authentic Trenton business that started out repurposing worm excrement.
lead_paragraph: If viewers who tuned into the second season of the workplace reality show “Human Resources” on Pivot this month came away feeling vindicated for Tony Rossi, the new guy who proved himself on trivia night, or relieved for Dan Harris, the sales director who scored an important new account, Tom Szaky, their boss, wouldn’t mind.

headline: Jarryd Hayne, Australian Rugby Star, Gives 49ers a Needed Jolt of Optimism
abstract: Hayne’s overnight transformation from foreign curiosity to roster contender has been a breath of fresh air for a team that has been engulfed in negativism.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — For a franchise in need of distraction, the Australian Jarryd Hayne arrived just in time.

headline: New York Schools With Many Students Who Skipped Tests Won’t Lose Money
abstract: State education officials ended months of uncertainty over how they would respond to a growing movement against standardized exams.
lead_paragraph: School districts will not be penalized for having large numbers of students refuse to sit for the New York State standardized tests this year, education officials said on Thursday, ending months of uncertainty over how they would respond to a growing antitesting movement.

headline: Review: Axia Taverna in Tenafly Is Home to Old-School Greek Dishes
abstract: The restaurant, which has been popular since it opened in 2006, offers generous main courses that are ideal for sharing.
lead_paragraph: The scene at Axia Taverna is so lively that it’s easy to forget that the mood in Greece — the country that inspired the restaurant’s cuisine and relaxed, joyous atmosphere — is probably more strained because of the current economic crisis. Everyone at Axia, including staff members, many of whom are from the Mediterranean country, seems to be in celebration mode. The crowds of regulars coming through the oversize wooden front door and the lively traditional music add to the energy.

headline: Brazil: House Speaker Is Charged
abstract: Prosecutors on Thursday filed corruption charges against Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of the lower house of Congress and one of Brazil’s most powerful political figures.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Thursday filed corruption charges against Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of the lower house of Congress and one of Brazil’s most powerful political figures. Investigators said that Mr. Cunha, 56, a conservative evangelical Christian radio commentator who broke from President Dilma Rousseff’s governing coalition, was involved in a money-laundering operation that was part of a graft scheme at Petrobras, the national oil company. His problems intensified in July when a consultant for a Petrobras contractor testified that Mr. Cunha had solicited and accepted a $5 million bribe. Mr. Cunha says that he is innocent and that he will remain in his post. The Supreme Court will decide whether he will stand trial.

headline: The Painted Ladies of Times Square Are Part of an Old New York Tradition
abstract: The nearly naked “desnudas” are just the latest incarnation of the subversive go-getter, an element integral to New York.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday afternoon this past winter, when my family and I were having lunch at the Metropolitan Museum of Art during a ritual viewing of mummies and armor with our 5-year-old son, I noticed a young man a few tables away staring at us. He had a notebook and began to sketch; he drew intensely and quickly. I was flattered and vaguely unsettled; he looked like someone in a Todd Solondz movie perhaps up to something not entirely sane.

headline: Two New Cosby Accusers Step Forward in New York
abstract: More Cosby accusers tell their stories in a news conference Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Two new accusers came forward on Thursday to add their names to the list of women with allegations of drugging or sexual assault against the entertainer Bill Cosby. They spoke at a news conference in New York held by the lawyer Gloria Allred, who is representing more than 20 other Cosby accusers.

headline: Review: ‘Some Kind of Beautiful’ Stars Pierce Brosnan as a Serial Seducer
abstract: Mr. Brosnan plays a womanizing college professor who impregnates a student (Jessica Alba) and then connects with her sister (Salma Hayek) after she dumps him.
lead_paragraph: The execrable romantic comedy “Some Kind of Beautiful” is the kind of embarrassment a studio dumps into the market in August while hoping no one will notice. Directed by Tom Vaughan from a screenplay by Matthew Newman, this witless, offensively sexist farrago stars a flabby Pierce Brosnan as Richard Haig, a self-satisfied professor of English romantic poetry at Cambridge and a serial womanizer who sleeps with his students. When his latest girlfriend, Kate (Jessica Alba), an American, informs him she’s pregnant, he promptly throws up.

headline: George Houser, Freedom Rides Pioneer and a Founder of CORE, Dies at 99
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The Rev. Houser was a Methodist minister whose contributions to the civil rights movement went largely unheralded.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. George M. Houser, a founder of the Congress of Racial Equality who was believed to be the last living member of the inaugural Freedom Ride — the volatile, sometimes violent bus trip through the South by a racially mixed group in 1947 — died on Wednesday in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 99.

headline: The Scene of a Nail Salon Sweep
abstract: Investigators from a New York State task force went through nail salons checking for health, safety and wage violations.
lead_paragraph: Investigators from a New York State task force went through nail salons checking for health, safety and wage violations.

headline: Review: In ‘Youth,’ Strains of Family and Country Fall on Brothers’ Shoulders
abstract: Crude fantasy seems to merge with the daily reality of a militarized society as brothers try to save their family from financial ruin in this Tom Shoval film.
lead_paragraph: Yaki and Shaul Cooper, teenage siblings played by the brothers David and Eitan Cunio in the Israeli film “Youth” look almost identical but for the fact that the 18-year-old Yaki, the older of the two, has scruffy facial hair. Their bond is so primal that when embracing, they resemble wrestlers standing head-to-head before trying to throw each other to the floor. You have the eerie sense of observing two halves of a severed whole struggling to reunite and break apart at the same time.

headline: Review: A Despairing Librarian Is Ready to Check Out in ‘After Words’
abstract: Romance is the last thing on the mind of Marcia Gay Harden’s character when she begins a tour of Costa Rica with a personal guide.
lead_paragraph: In September, television viewers will have a chance to see Marcia Gay Harden play a brusque, decisive, rule-bending doctor in the new CBS drama “Code Black.” Anyone who wants to see her play more or less the polar opposite of that character is hereby referred to “After Words,” a romance novel of a movie featuring the world’s most stereotypical librarian.

headline: Review: ‘Being Evel’ Examines the Life of a Notorious Stuntman
abstract: Daniel Junge’s latest documentary traces Evel Knievel’s record-breaking (and bone-breaking) career.
lead_paragraph: There’s something fundamentally American about the stunt motorcyclist Evel Knievel, as this latest informative documentary by Daniel Junge (a director of the Oscar-winning “Saving Face”) demonstrates. Robert Craig Knievel (1938-2007) — police officers tired of his persistent minor offenses created his nickname when he was growing up in Butte, Mont. — was determined to transcend humble origins.

headline: Nelson Peltz Picks Up Seats on Sysco’s Board Days After Buying a Stake
abstract: The food supplier Sysco added two seats to its board to accommodate the activist investor Nelson Peltz and another executive at Trian Fund Management.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after emerging as a big investor in Sysco, the activist investor Nelson Peltz has gained seats on the food service company’s board.

headline: Review: In ‘The Boy,’ an Unnerving 9-Year-Old Makes His Move
abstract: Craig William Macneill’s film centers on a strange youngster who lives with his despondent, inattentive father in a crumbling motel.
lead_paragraph: There are engrossing elements in Craig William Macneill’s “The Boy,” the tale of a creepy motel (no, it’s not “Psycho”) and a child sociopath (no, not “The Bad Seed”). Building on their Sundance short “Henley,” Mr. Macneill and his co-screenwriter, Clay McLeod Chapman, have developed a feature stunning to behold if somewhat unpersuasive in narrative.

headline: In Letter, Obama Tells Congress U.S. Will Still Press Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The letter reflects a shift in emphasis, to steps the administration could take outside the nuclear agreement with Iran to enforce the deal’s provisions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his most comprehensive effort to assure wavering Democrats, President Obama wrote in a letter to Congress that the United States would unilaterally maintain economic pressure and deploy military options if needed to deter Iranian aggression, both during and beyond the proposed nuclear accord.

headline: China Woes Send Stocks Into Tailspin
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market']

headline: ‘Searching for Home,’ a Cross-Generational Look at Military Veterans
abstract: Eric Christiansen’s documentary explores the struggles of veterans who returned home from World War II and succeeding conflicts, from the wars in Korea and Vietnam to those in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The oddest thing about “Searching for Home: Coming Back From War” is how often the military men interviewed talk about having been surprised that real war wasn’t like the movies. They make a Korean War veteran seem like a master of emotional distance and control when he sticks to real-life parallels in a speech about his memories.

headline: Frederick Payne, Decorated Fighter Ace in the Pacific, Dies at 104
abstract: Mr. Payne, a retired Marine Corps brigadier general, received the Navy Cross and other awards as World War II fighter ace in the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Payne, a retired Marine Corps brigadier general who was honored for his exploits as a fighter pilot in the Pacific in World War II, died on Aug. 6 at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 104 and the oldest of America’s surviving fighter aces.

Trump’s derisive thrusts with elliptical, indirect and sparing responses, Jeb Bush aggressively attacked Mr. Trump here on Thursday, portraying him as a Democratic-leaning poseur in the Republican field and expressing confidence that voters would come to the same conclusion.

headline: B&H Dairy in the East Village Reopens After Months of Red Tape
abstract: B&H Dairy in the East Village was not damaged by a fatal gas explosion on the same block, but it took months to pass reinvigorated city inspections and reopen.
lead_paragraph: At lunchtime Thursday, there wasn’t an empty stool or seat to be had at B&H Dairy, a venerable 400-square-foot restaurant in the East Village that survived the Second Avenue gas explosion in March but appeared doomed when it was bound and gagged in red tape. The place managed to reopen a few days ago, and everyone has come back. To go from the front door to the back, you had to walk sideways.

headline: Trial of Testosterone Supplements Sought
abstract: The F.D.A. called for drug makers to conduct a clinical trial of testosterone products marketed to older men to combat diminished levels of the hormone.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration called on Thursday for drug makers to conduct a clinical trial of testosterone products marketed to older men to combat diminished levels of the hormone. While marketers call the often-normal decrease “low T”; the F.D.A. calls it “age-related hypogonadism” and describes it as controversial. In a commentary in The New England Journal of Medicine, agency officials cited concerns over cardiovascular risks of testosterone treatment and suggested that the benefits claimed in ads are unsupported by substantial evidence. The supplements are approved by the F.D.A. for treating classic hypogonadism, which includes well-recognized medical conditions like testicular damage. But most men prescribed testosterone do not appear to have this condition, agency officials wrote, calling the trend troubling. To date, no randomized, controlled trials have been designed to evaluate cardiovascular outcomes in men taking supplemental testosterone.

headline: Military Prisons Considered for Guantánamo Detainees
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter said that the White House was assessing two military bases as possible places to bring detainees from Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of Defense Ashton Carter said on Thursday that the Obama administration was assessing two military bases that have prisons — Fort Leavenworth in Kansas and Joint Base Charleston in South Carolina — as possible places to bring detainees from the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Since 2009, when the Obama administration first began trying to close the Guantánamo prison, the executive branch has studied the logistical capacity of several bases to handle such prisoners. President Obama wants to close Guantánamo Bay before he leaves office in January 2017. Of the 116 detainees remaining there, 52 are recommended for transfer if security conditions can be met in the receiving country. But even if all of those lower-level detainees can be resettled, the United States would be left with 64 prisoners who are not approved for release.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) NATIONAL GALLERY (2014) In his 39th documentary, Frederick Wiseman tours the National Gallery in London (above). Docents decode the work of Leonardo, Rembrandt and Turner; restorers use magnifying glasses, eyedroppers, scalpels and cotton swabs to repair a tiny chip in a painting; senior executives politely battle younger ones, who believe the museum is too stodgy; and connoisseurs discuss the underpinnings of masterpieces by Vermeer, Caravaggio, Titian, Velázquez, Pissarro and Rubens. Mr. Wiseman also makes the point that art is the story of human relationships — in labor, commerce, patronage and even the exploitation of bodies. “Mr. Wiseman’s touch is deft but light here, and the experience of watching ‘National Gallery’ is pleasurable and immersive because he’s a wonderful storyteller,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this three-hour movie. “It is also unexpectedly moving. Because his other great theme is how art speaks to us, one he brilliantly expresses in the relay of gazes that finds us looking at museumgoers looking at portraits that look right back — at artists, art lovers and moviegoers — even as Mr. Wiseman, that sly old master, looks at all of us in turn.”

headline: ‘Little Pink Pill’ for Women Comes With Risks
abstract: Women who can benefit from the drug need to be aware of the risks and how to mitigate them.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration’s approval on Tuesday of a marginally effective drug to enhance the sexual drive of women with low libido came with appropriate safeguards to protect the safety of patients. We will probably never know whether the agency made a purely scientific judgment or whether it was unduly influenced by a campaign, partly financed by the manufacturer and organized with the help of one of its consultants, to depict the agency as gender-biased for never having approved a drug to treat sexual dysfunction in women while approving numerous drugs for men.

abstract: The Russian leader once again starts a food fight, and finds a way to blame the West in the process.

The jokes are cropping up again, many over Vladimir Putin’s zany crackdown on European flowers and food imports, like the satirical video “Death of a Parmesan,” in which the destruction of foreign cheeses becomes a ballad about a heroic military campaign. “This song is about the unusual stupidity of today’s Russia,” reads the caption.

headline: Can Our Transit System Get Any Worse?
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Public Authorities', 'Hudson River Tunnels Project']
abstract: Public authorities once paid their own way. ­Now they barely keep up.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — THIS has been a tough season for commuters in the New York region: the Amtrak crash in May, trains stuck in Hudson River tunnels in June, subway service disrupted by never-ending summer construction. Still, more than 5.6 million people take the subway each weekday, the most since 1949; New Jersey Transit’s ridership into the city has risen 75 percent in the past 15 years, and Amtrak’s Northeast Corridor carried a record of nearly 12 million riders last year.

headline: How to Be Naked in Public
abstract: Practice at home. Steel your nerves before disrobing.
lead_paragraph: Begin by practicing in private. ‘‘Sure, you can be nude in your own shower,’’ Stéphane Deschênes says, ‘‘but how about sitting in the living room watching TV? How about having dinner?’’

headline: ‘Beaux Arts’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: It’s a delight to see the way that poems (and poets) engage in conversation with other works of art. Chana Bloch’s poem is layered in its ekphrastic references, not only to a painting but also to “Musée des Beaux Arts,” a poem by W.H. Auden that has long been one of my favorites. Echoing the language of Auden’s poem (“About suffering they were never wrong,/The Old Masters: how well they understood”), “Beaux Arts” extends the meditation on art, myth and the representation of human emotion.

headline: The Great Pileup of 1998
abstract: A 13-car crash at the beginning of the Belgian Grand Prix that year was just a foretaste of the most accident-marred, topsy-turvy race ever at Spa-Francorchamps.
lead_paragraph: Considering that even in 1998 a Formula One car might have been an assemblage of at least a million dollars’ worth of parts, in the first few seconds of the Belgian Grand Prix that year at least $13 million washed away with the rainwater on the inundated track in the series’ biggest multiple-car crash, involving 13 cars at the first corner.

headline: At Las Cabras in Santiago, Pedigree Is All
abstract: While reminiscent of a diner, the food produced with first-rate ingredients in the hands of a well-regarded chef.
lead_paragraph: The fuente de soda is Chile’s particular take on the soda fountain, a culinary institution along the lines of the American diner — friendly, familiar, old-fashioned. You go to one to tuck your tie into your shirt and wolf down a churrasco completo (imagine a comically large hamburger, but made with sliced meat, mashed avocado, tomatoes and mayonnaise). Throw back a freshly made juice or a beer and you’re ready to get back to work.

headline: Getting Creative With Small Hotel Rooms
abstract: Niki Leondakis, the chief executive of Commune Hotels and Resorts, is preparing to launch Tommie, a chain of affordable hotels for those in search of creative accommodations.
lead_paragraph: One of the few female top executives in the hospitality business, Niki Leondakis, the chief executive of Commune Hotels and Resorts, knows a thing or two about running hotels.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel Croydon in Miami
abstract: Among its high-priced neighbors, the Croydon is a reasonably priced, convenient and comfortable option with perks that make choosing it worthwhile.
lead_paragraph: From $138.

headline: Code Red
abstract: A small act of self-expression, snuffed out by El Salvador’s gangs.
lead_paragraph: I started out dyeing my hair a few years ago with a color they call chocolate. Then I went blond, then platinum blond, then blond with green, then burgundy red, then cherry red, which is even stronger, and then intense red. I had it that way for two years. Until a few months ago, when I got on a bus route I never should’ve taken, and this girl sat next to me.

headline: Jerrold Nadler, New York Congressman, Endorses Iran Nuclear Deal
abstract: Mr. Nadler, a long-tenured liberal Democrat, became the lone Jewish member of Congress from the state to back the contested arms-control agreement.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jerrold Nadler was being pulled hard from all sides.

headline: Kevyn Aucoin’s ‘Making Faces’
abstract: A makeup bible that helps you decide who you want to be on any given day.
lead_paragraph: I was 14 when I discovered I have an oval face. I learned this from reading Kevyn Aucoin’s ‘‘Making Faces,’’ a glossy volume published in 1997 that quickly became a kind of sacred text among teenage girls. We all trekked to the Borders at Winrock mall in Albuquerque to buy a copy, using the savings we had built up by babysitting or halfheartedly frothing lattes for minimum wage. We lugged the book home (all 160 oversize pages of it) to commune in private with its thick, creamy paperstock full of wisdom about lip shapes, brow bleaching and false eyelashes. We propped it against the bathroom sink as we mashed our fingers into our cheekbones, feeling for deep bone structure. We pored over close-ups of celebrity pores, eager to claim affinity with the actress or supermodel whose skin most matched our own. The girls who learned from Aucoin that they had heart-­shaped faces let everyone at school know about it in the nasal braggadocio common to a certain breed of adolescent queen bee. They were special; the rest of us could only dream of possessing jawlines that ended in a point like valentines.

headline: Morning Agenda: Investors Get Fitness Fever
keywords: ['Addyi (Drug)', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'CHINA', 'Credit Scores', 'Currency', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Exercise', 'FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM', 'Gold', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Interest Rates', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Shenzhen Stock Exchange', 'Taxation', 'Viagra (Drug)']
abstract: Valeant Buys Maker of ‘Female Viagra’ Drug | Fresh Greek Elections | The Global Sell-Off
lead_paragraph: INVESTORS GET FITNESS FEVER | The self-help therapy pedaling session held in dim lighting to the sound of a primal dance beat has developed a cultlike following. Now the craze has spread from Victoria’s Secret models and hedge fund wives to Wall Street financiers, who want to ride to big bucks on the back of SoulCycle’s initial public offering, Julie Creswell reports in DealBook.

headline: As Workers Delay Retirement, Some Bosses Become More Flexible
abstract: More employers are introducing flexibility into their schedules or allowing employees to step slowly out of the work force with phased retirement.
lead_paragraph: Corliss Fanjoy is turning 65 this year, but she is not ready for retirement. And at a small handbag maker in Maine, where Mrs. Fanjoy spends her working hours cutting intricate patterns in leather, she is not alone.

headline: From Nicole Kidman to ‘A Delicate Ship,’ a Big Season for the Playwright Anna Ziegler
abstract: The writer has several plays preparing for production, including “Photograph 51,” which will star Nicole Kidman in London.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Anna Ziegler is not exactly decisive.

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “American Ultra,” “Sinister 2″ and “Grandma.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Trans Deaths, White Privilege
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A string of transgender women of color have been killed this year.
lead_paragraph: IT was snowing in Maine on Jan. 9. I’d been to the dentist’s the day before. The staff there were pleasant enough when I changed genders 12 years ago. “We’ll just change your forms,” the receptionist had said, cheerfully. “It’s no problem.”

headline: T City Guides: Los Angeles
abstract: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.
lead_paragraph: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

headline: It’s Been Fun, but…I’m Going On Vacation
abstract: The public editor’s office will be staffed, but I’ll be away for a week.
lead_paragraph: It’s late August and as usual, I’m exchanging my laptop and iPhone for a tennis racquet and a kayak paddle. My excellent assistant, Joumana Khatib, will be in the office, responding to reader mail. I’ll be checking in and consulting with her regularly. (But, then again, not too regularly.)

headline: Macedonian Police Clash With Migrants on Border With Greece
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: A day after the country declared a temporary state of emergency at border areas, officers used stun grenades and tear gas near the southern frontier.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Tensions at the Greek-Macedonian border erupted into clashes on Friday, when the Macedonian police used stun grenades to try to disperse a large group of migrants trying to cross the border into their country.

headline: Israel Carries Out 2nd Round of Airstrikes in Syria
abstract: A drone strike hit a vehicle on the Syrian-controlled side of the Golan Heights and killed the people inside, intensifying the most serious conflict in the area in months.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Israeli military mounted a second round of airstrikes in Syria on Friday morning, killing all of the passengers traveling in a vehicle and intensifying the most serious conflict in the area in months.

headline: Three Teacher-Tested Ways to Encourage Your Students to Follow Current Events This School Year
abstract: The Summer Reading Contest is now over, but here are some teacher-tested ideas for bringing its spirit into your classroom this fall, no matter how much time you have to give to current events.
lead_paragraph: Over 7,500 mini-essays answering the question “What interested you most in The Times this week?” flooded into our Sixth Annual Summer Reading Contest this June, July and August, and so far we have crowned eight winners, 79 runners-up and many, many honorable mentions. (And stay tuned: There are still winners to be named on Aug. 25 and Sept. 1., as well a special opportunity for honorees.)

headline: Art for Art’s Sake. Then Brick it Over.
abstract: Pajtim Osmanaj helps to tile over a mural he created in his spare time as a worker at a condo being completed in West Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Pajtim Osmanaj helps to tile over a mural he created in his spare time as a worker at a condo being completed in West Chelsea.

headline: Construction Site as Canvas
abstract: Pajtim Osmanaj turned an under-construction West Chelsea condo into a creative playground.
lead_paragraph: Pajtim Osmanaj turned an under-construction West Chelsea condo into a creative playground.

headline: Art Hidden Behind a Condo’s Walls
abstract: The construction site at 560 West 24th Street, a boutique condominium in West Chelsea near the High Line, was one worker’s personal canvas.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Pajtim Osmanaj moved to New York from Kosovo after working toward a degree in fine art. To pay his bills, he took a job in construction laying tile. By happenstance, earlier this year, he ended up working at 560 West 24th Street, a boutique condominium in West Chelsea near the High Line. Surrounded by art galleries, in the heart of New York’s contemporary art scene, he couldn’t help expressing himself.

headline: Freedom, Finally, After a Life in Prison
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Paula Cooper was imprisoned most of her life for killing a Bible teacher. Without mental health treatment, she couldn’t survive life outside.
lead_paragraph: WHEN she was 15 years old, Paula Cooper and three high school classmates in Gary, Ind., decided to cut school and steal some money to play games at a local arcade. They drank some cheap wine, smoked some pot and walked to the nearby home of a 78-year-old Bible teacher, Ruth Pelke. They figured she might have a jar of money somewhere.

abstract: Other web highlights included an analysis of police shootings and a tour of the abandoned college campuses of Second Life.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: An Insider's Guide to Paris's Alternative Beauty Scene
abstract: Thanks to French fashion folk, alternative treatments are starting to thrive in the conservative city.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to French fashion folk, alternative treatments are starting to thrive in the conservative city.

headline: Female BFFs: The New Power Couples
abstract: Today’s power couples are female friends. Are we happy about that?
lead_paragraph: Lately, we’ve been inundated with images of real-life best friends, triumphantly displayed. Are we happy about that?

headline: Fairy Tales
abstract: Why they still believe.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong is searching for the origins of the phrase “confidence fairy”. I’m pretty sure — you can never be completely sure, because things can stick in your mind — that it was an original coinage on my part, a snappy way to characterize the deep implausibility of the Alesina-Ardagna stuff that was sweeping Brussels and other corridors of power in 2010. Since then, a lot of further evidence has come in — and all of it confirms the original critique.

headline: Parents’ Parting Ceremony at Morehouse College
abstract: Parents affirm their love and acknowledge the importance of letting go; freshmen thank the elders for their support and vow to honor the family name.
lead_paragraph: Parents affirm their love and acknowledge the importance of letting go; freshmen thank the elders for their support and vow to honor the family name.

headline: Parents’ Ceremony Serves Up Elements of ‘Morehouse Gospel’
abstract: The college’s annual Parents’ Parting Ceremony offers a mix of African music and dance, black Christian preaching and liberation theology.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For the previous 364 days, the carved wooden chest rested unobtrusively atop a bookshelf in a dean’s office here at Morehouse College. Then, on a recent Wednesday afternoon, the dean, Lawrence E. Carter Sr., reclaimed the vessel for its annual duty as the repository of Morehouse’s hope and history.

lead_paragraph: Quarterback controversies are nothing new in the N.F.L. But they usually involve two candidates. The Bills find themselves this year with a legitimate three-way quarterback battle.

headline: Getting Workaholics to Stop and Recharge
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Meditation', 'Paid Time Off', 'Exercise', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Americans are taking less time off than ever, studies find, but nonstop workers who find ways to decompress can enjoy physical and mental benefits.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Hitt, chief executive of Engel & Völkers North America, a luxury property company, spends at least one week each quarter at his home in Maui, Hawaii. At this point, three years into the top job, he said he talks to his top lieutenants only 15 minutes a day when he’s there. The rest of the time he reads, practices yoga, rides his bicycle or otherwise tries to disconnect from the responsibilities of his job.

lead_paragraph: BIBLIOTECHWhy Libraries Matter More Than Ever in the Age of GoogleBy John Palfrey280 pp. Basic Books, $26.99.

headline: Cultural Anxiety
abstract: The subject of civilizational decline is a perennial favorite for many authors.
lead_paragraph: This week, Joshua Cohen reviews Mario Vargas Llosa’s “Notes on the Death of Culture.” The Nobel Prize winner Vargas Llosa begins his book by citing a 1948 essay about high culture by a fellow Nobel winner, T.S. Eliot.

headline: Letters: New Orleans, 10 Years Later
abstract: Readers respond to a recent essay by Walter Isaacson and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHAT IS VISIBLE, by Kimberly Elkins. (Twelve, $15.) As a young child in the 1830s, Laura Bridgman suffered a bout of scarlet fever that left her without sight, hearing, taste or smell. She rose to prominence after learning language, despite being both deaf and blind, at the institute that Annie Sullivan and Helen Keller would later attend. Her story is the basis of Elkins’s biographical novel, which imagines Bridgman’s inner life.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: EILEEN, by Ottessa Moshfegh. (Penguin Press, $25.95.) Through her fascinatingly twisted heroine, Moshfegh explores a woman’s relationship to her body — the disconnection, the cultural claims, the male prerogative.

headline: ‘Machines of Loving Grace,’ by John Markoff
abstract: A call to consider how far artificial intelligence technology should go in the quest to make life better.
lead_paragraph: Technologists rarely question technology in public. Yet last fall Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, suggested we might need to regulate the development of artificial intelligence “just to make sure that we don’t do something very foolish.”

headline: ‘Everybody Rise,’ by Stephanie Clifford
abstract: An ambitious New Yorker insinuates herself into the old guard in the years before the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century ago, Harper’s published an essay by Tom Wolfe titled “Stalking the Billion-Footed Beast: A ­Literary Manifesto for the New Social Novel.” Wolfe, whose best seller “The Bonfire of the Vanities” had been published two years earlier, called for a revival of the sort of novel that emerged during the 19th century: realist fiction that was wide in its scope and accurate in its detail, grounded in the kind of reporting that journalistic nonfiction demands.

headline: ‘The Shape of the New,’ by Scott L. Montgomery and Daniel Chirot
abstract: A pair of scholars tease out the central notions that have given rise to the modern age.
lead_paragraph: The world has been horrified but also puzzled by the rise of ISIS. How does one comprehend its brutality and success? What is its likely path? In March 2015, The Atlantic offered an answer, in an analysis by Graeme Wood that quickly became the most widely read essay in the magazine’s 158-year history. Titled “What ISIS Really Wants,” it focused on the ideology that animates the group. Understand its ideas, Wood suggested, and you will understand the phenomenon and how to fight it. Many other, more polemical explanations of jihadi terrorism today — from Bill Maher to Sam Harris — also shine a spotlight on the ideas behind the mayhem.

headline: ‘Young Eliot,’ by Robert Crawford
abstract: From his Midwest origins, the young T.S. Eliot moved on to the works that would make his name.
lead_paragraph: In an unheroic age, T.S. Eliot was ­poetry’s ideal antihero. Shy, indecisive, gangly, he essayed the Parnassian heights not baroquely turbaned like a Byron but buttoned down and gray-flanneled like a Walter Mitty. By day, he was a Lloyds banker in “a four-piece suit,” as Virginia Woolf reportedly described him; by night, a visionary poet, whose lyric fragments harmonized with the malaise troubling Europe after World War I. The Scottish poet Robert Crawford’s assiduous “Young Eliot” follows “Tom” from his earliest poetic finger exercises to the “ineradicably insinuating music” of “The Waste Land” (1922), in which April cruelly breeds lilacs as well as a bramble of textual notes.

headline: ‘Palimpsest: A History of the Written Word,’ by Matthew Battles
abstract: An inquiry into the history of the written word.
lead_paragraph: When an author assigns himself the task of compiling “a history of the written word,” a reader is likely to wonder: How well written is it? “Palimpsest” is a serious, well-researched book. Matthew Battles evokes the flexibility of human consciousness and the ability of the written word to absorb and deploy new technologies even though, as he explains, writing has always had its supposed shallows, from “penny dreadfuls” to propaganda and pornography. However, “Palimpsest” puts up a dull defense of its subject. It’s elliptically organized and full of workmanlike, hackneyed prose. It’s a history of the written word, but it’s also a repository of literary missteps.

headline: ‘Faith Ed.,’ by Linda K. Wertheimer
abstract: Is it possible to study world religions in today’s climate?
lead_paragraph: What should you do in a house of worship of another faith? This is a question that vexes many who write about religion and many who do not. Should non-Jewish men don kipas in synagogues? Should non-Muslim women cover their heads in a mosque? Should non-Catholics kneel during Mass? When everyone at an evangelical church holds hands and prays, should I keep mine by my side? Does not participating imply rudeness or does it simply say, I respect your faith enough not to pretend I am a part of it?

headline: ‘We Believe the Children,’ by Richard Beck
abstract: The fantasy of Satanic abuse at preschools in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1983, a California woman named Judy Johnson took her 3-year-old son Matthew to a hospital near her home in Manhattan Beach. She pointed the doctor’s attention to her child’s anus, which, she said, looked redder than it had that morning, before he had gone to his day care center. Whether out of genuine concern about foul play or to salve a worried mother, the doctor filed a suspected child abuse report. Johnson, who later received a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia, took her own suspicions to the police, who soon alerted parents whose children attended the McMartin Preschool to a possible abuser in their midst.

headline: Whose Side Are You On?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Children and Childhood', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: If you don’t have kids, you tend to identify with the children in any story.
lead_paragraph: When I was 15, I was playing with my 2-year-old sister and our 19-month-old cousin by a fountain in Amherst, Mass. Someone smiled and said, “They’re yours?” and I was shocked. Even if I’d had them in middle school, it was mathematically impossible to have given birth to both of them.

headline: What Alexis Tsipras’s Announcement Means for Greece
abstract: The prime minister’s call for new elections means voters may have to decide who would best navigate the next phase of the nation’s financial struggle.
lead_paragraph: A tumultuous summer in Greece could lead to an uncertain autumn as voters may have to decide who would best navigate the next phase of the country’s financial struggle.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Judd Apatow recently returned to performing standup comedy: “I don’t really care if anything succeeds anymore; I just like to be in the process of trying.”
lead_paragraph: The Kings of Comedy: The director Judd Apatow began interviewing his comedy idols while still in high school. In “Sick in the Head,” No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list, he compiles almost 30 years of conversations with legends like Mel Brooks, Steve Martin, Jerry Seinfeld and Chris Rock into a master class of the form — of why people come to comedy (Roseanne Barr: “My dad wouldn’t hit me if I got him with humor right between the eyes”) and how to do it well (Amy Schumer: “The stuff you’re copping to and the saddest, worst moments of your life — that’s the stuff people connect to and ­appreciate”).

headline: 1940: Britain Bans Import of Notes
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain bans the import of its banknotes from non-sterling countries in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Great Britain gave the economic screw another twist today by declaring worthless in the home market for the war’s duration the millions of pounds of British currency in non-sterling countries. Persons residing in the United States were given six days in which to cash into dollars whatever British currency they may hold, but the inhabitants of France and other European countries invaded by the Germans or living next door to them were allowed only a twenty-four-hour notice.

headline: Aging Extremist Laments Violence Now Used Against Palestinians
abstract: Yehuda Etzion, who plotted to blow up the Dome of the Rock in the 1980s, said he takes “partial responsibility” for not reaching out to young zealots “to try and straighten out their thinking.”
lead_paragraph: OFRA, West Bank — YEHUDA ETZION does not regret, exactly, helping plant bombs in the cars of Palestinian mayors and plotting to blow up the Dome of the Rock in the 1980s, nor does he express remorse. But he has reconsidered the role of violence in the quest for a Messianic kingdom of Israel, particularly as he contemplates a new generation of radicals he sees as bastardizing their shared ideology.

headline: The Very Bad Picture Book
abstract: Its colors are dull and it teaches an important lesson.
lead_paragraph: Its colors are dull and it teaches an important lesson.

headline: Aggressive Treatment for Early Breast Cancer: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Medical reporter Gina Kolata explains why stories like her front-page article about early stage breast cancer treatment frighten her.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, I got an e-mail from JAMA Oncology, a leading medical journal, saying that it planned to publish a paper and editorial on ductal carcinoma in situ, or D.C.I.S., a condition that has become increasingly controversial over the years. As many as 60,000 women are told each year that they have it: tiny clusters of abnormal breast cells, confined to a milk duct and too small to be felt. It’s often called stage 0 cancer, and it almost never was detected before the early 1980s when mammograms came into widespread use.

headline: The Person Behind Those ‘Bad Lip Reading’ Videos Has a Favorite Politician (No, It’s Not Donald Trump.)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: We asked the Bad Lip Reader about the 2016 presidential candidates — and to tell us when the next video is coming.
lead_paragraph: For years, an anonymous producer of “Bad Lip Reading,” a popular series of dubbed-over YouTube videos, has added absurdist humor to our already fairly absurd political process.

abstract: Nineteenth-century photographs go on display in Mumbai, India; an exhibition in Melbourne, Australia, shows how horses have been depicted in art throughout the centuries; a music festival gets underway in a Croatian fort.

abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘Hit Count,’ by Chris Lynch
abstract: A story about a fanatical high school football player meshes with current attention on the sport’s culture and risks.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing when a novel about a meaningful subject gets published at a time when a media storm surrounding that subject is beginning to brew. But add to the mix an author who can really get the crosswinds blowing and there is truly cause to marvel. That’s the case with Chris Lynch’s “Hit Count,” a powerful story that illuminates both the dangers of head trauma in athletes and the psyche of football players.

headline: ‘What This Story Needs Is a Pig in a Wig,’ and More
abstract: New early readers feature an antic dancer, wiggy pigs and a girl whose dog hits it big.
lead_paragraph: A children’s books editor once asked me what kind of books were needed most in libraries. My immediate response was, “Beginning readers!” Then I had a question: Why aren’t there more available? The editor’s reply was just as fast: “Because they’re too hard to write.”

headline: ‘Mama’s Nightingale,’ by Edwidge Danticat, and More
abstract: Four picture books show how immigrant children settle into a changed environment.
lead_paragraph: Picture books have long been concerned with helping children transition to an unfamiliar place. A child’s first day in a new school or a family’s move to a different neighborhood are by now classic subjects. But since the dawn of the 21st century, with the number of immigrants in the United States continuing to increase markedly, children’s authors and publishers have begun to take on a far more challenging task — helping immigrant children settle into a new cultural environment, one that even their parents may find inexplicable. Since the principal obstacle to understanding a culture is, of course, the language that expresses it, language can loom large in these books; and a language divide is a concept difficult to express pictorially. Given all this, a child’s experience of immigration is a subject matter that requires some inventive tactics, as four new books ably demonstrate.

headline: A Gay Baseball Player, in Statistical Perspective
abstract: When David Denson came out, it was a first for an active player, but there are probably dozens of gay men playing for teams in the majors and minor leagues.
lead_paragraph: Until this week, no active baseball player associated with a Major League Baseball team had ever publicly come out as gay. David Denson, a prospect playing for the Helena Brewers in one of baseball’s rookie leagues, has finally ended that streak.

headline: Kevin Henkes’s ‘Waiting,’ and More
abstract: In three picture books, toys choose to explore their surroundings or view the world from a windowsill.
lead_paragraph: As both subjects and protagonists, animals seem to rule the world of children’s books, and it’s easy to see why. They are cute, recognizable and fun to imitate. They play a part in every child’s life, sometimes a big one. But what about the toys and tools children use every day? These make more occasional literary appearances — in, for instance, classics such as “Corduroy,” about a stuffed bear alone in a department store, or even “The Little Engine That Could,” with its dolls and small clown — but they really deserve to be more frequent stars. Children have immediate associations with their treasured belongings in a way they might not with, say, a capybara. Three new books, all by prominent picture book authors, artfully use worldly possessions to approach larger themes, to varying degrees of success.

headline: Pyongyang Reacts to South’s Loudspeakers
abstract: A senior official from North Korea criticized the South’s use of loudspeakers to blare propaganda messages across the demilitarized zone, but the South Korean defense minister defended the broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: A senior official from North Korea criticized the South’s use of loudspeakers to blare propaganda messages across the demilitarized zone, but the South Korean defense minister defended the broadcasts.

headline: Maggie Thrash’s ‘Honor Girl’
abstract: At a camp for girls, a teenager finds herself infatuated with an older counselor.
lead_paragraph: At the start of every summer session deep in the Kentucky Appalachians, Camp Bellflower celebrates one camper chosen to be the Honor Girl. She is the female ideal, representing the noble qualities the camp aims to foster in its generations of girls. Fifteen-year-old Maggie Thrash is a Bellflower veteran, an old hand at the hokey traditions of the camp. She doesn’t bat an eye at the candlelit Honor Girl ceremony, or the daily Civil War re-­enactments (which consist of two groups of girls screaming “GRAY!” and BLUE!” at each other). She has her friends, her ankle leash to keep from sleepwalking, her entire pleasantly familiar summer stretching out ahead of her. Until one fateful lice inspection by an older counselor triggers a romantic awakening, in the last location she would have chosen.

headline: Why Jeff Bezos Should Care More for Amazon’s Employees
abstract: Working long and continuous hours isn’t a prescription for higher productivity, much less higher quality or more innovation.
lead_paragraph: Dear Jeff Bezos,

headline: House Tour | Scholten & Baijings
abstract: The Amsterdam-based designers Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings invite T into their colorful home, which they describe as a living still life.
lead_paragraph: The Amsterdam-based designers Stefan Scholten and Carole Baijings invite T into their colorful home, which they describe as a living still life.

headline: Vague Disclosures by Highflying Mutual Funds May Put Investors in Peril
abstract: Leveraged loans, a kind of obligation held by floating-rate income funds, carry risks that are often not fully disclosed to investors.
lead_paragraph: Desperate for richer yields on their portfolios, individual investors have thronged in recent years to mutual funds promising higher-than-usual income. The question is: Do these investors understand the higher-than-usual risks involved?

headline: Holly Holm, a Top Boxer, Will Be Ronda Rousey’s Next Opponent
abstract: Rousey told ABC’s “Good Morning America” on Friday that she would defend her women’s bantamweight title against Holly Holm in Las Vegas on Jan. 2.
lead_paragraph: The mixed martial arts superstar Ronda Rousey announced Friday that her next opponent would be Holly Holm on Jan. 2 in Las Vegas.

headline: Scholten & Baijings’s Bright Ideas
abstract: Scholten & Baijings are shaking up the world of Dutch design with candy colors and, even more shocking, a belief in mass production.
lead_paragraph: A husband-and-wife team is brightening up the sober Dutch design world.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a beach house in New Rochelle, N.Y., and Tudor in Fairfield, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a beach house in New Rochelle, N.Y., and Tudor in Fairfield, Conn.

headline: This Week’s Market Sell-Off May Not Be Such a Bad Thing
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A remarkable run-up in stock prices probably needed a breather at a time when a range of markets had been starting to look a little bubbly.
lead_paragraph: It has been a frantic week on Wall Street and in other financial centers, with stocks and other risky assets experiencing their worst week in years.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a beach house in New Rochelle, N.Y., and a Tudor in Southport, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: Review: ‘Becoming Dr. Ruth’ in Stony Point Is a Meditation on Home
abstract: In the one-woman play by Mark St. Germain, sex therapy may be the least interesting part of an amazing life.
lead_paragraph: Five countries, three husbands, four names. The one most people know her by, Dr. Ruth, has become synonymous with frank talk about sex, but in “Becoming Dr. Ruth,” the first-rate Mark St. Germain play now at Penguin Rep in Stony Point, sex is perhaps the least scintillating of the subjects under discussion. This 90-minute, one-woman show, set in 1997, finds our heroine, born Karola Ruth Siegel in 1928, preparing to move from the New York apartment she has shared with Fred Westheimer for 36 years.

headline: How the Social Mission of Ben & Jerry’s Survived Being Gobbled Up
keywords: ['Corporate Social Responsibility', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Despite a rocky start, Unilever’s acquisition of the ice cream maker became a case study in how small companies can maintain their identities inside conglomerates.
lead_paragraph: Big food companies have an endless appetite for smaller brands that make local, organic and socially responsible products. Over the years, Danone acquired Stonyfield Farm yogurt, General Mills bought Annie’s Homegrown and Campbell Soup swallowed up Plum Organics.

headline: A Reunion Screening of ‘O Brother, Where Art Thou?’ and More at the New York Film Festival
abstract: The festival announced an anniversary screening of the Coen Brothers film, along with new work from Paul Thomas Anderson.
lead_paragraph: All you men of constant sorrow can shed one less tear. The New York Film Festival will present a 15th anniversary screening of the Coen brothers comedy “O Brother, Where Art Thou?,” festival organizers announced today. In addition, the festival unveiled their special events lineup, which includes a screening of new work from Paul Thomas Anderson, the Holocaust drama “Son of Saul,” a documentary about Brian De Palma and a revival screening of his 1981 film “Blow Out.”

headline: On Edge
abstract: Cate Blanchett is known for playing women who are just barely holding it together. In life, she’s firmly in control.
lead_paragraph: It was Cate Blanchett’s second time climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge. She couldn’t really say why she wanted to do it, or what it is about heights that appeals to her. She has no interest in skydiving or bungee jumping or parachuting. She’s not especially sporty or athletic. It’s not thrills she likes; it’s control. She once drove her children to the edge of Mount Yasur, an active volcano on the island of Tanna.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: The ‘Flying Spaghetti Monster’
abstract: A team of BP drill workers discovered this deep sea creature off the coast of Angola.
lead_paragraph: A team of BP drill workers discovered this deep sea creature off the coast of Angola.

headline: Bookshelf: Schooling
abstract: New picture books include “Music Class Today!” and “Dad’s First Day.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Music Class Today!” and “Dad’s First Day.”
