abstract: With “Emotion,” the singer known best for “Call Me Maybe” embraces a seductive side to her music.
lead_paragraph: With “Emotion,” the singer known best for “Call Me Maybe” embraces a seductive side to her music.

headline: Feeling the Bass Deep in His Body
abstract: Houzaifa Konditamdé, a native of Burkina Faso, became deaf at age 6, but that did not stop him from dancing. And dancing has helped him begun to carve out a niche since arriving in New York last year.
lead_paragraph: Houzaifa Konditamdé, a native of Burkina Faso, became deaf at age 6, but that did not stop him from dancing. And dancing has helped him begun to carve out a niche since arriving in New York last year.

headline: Big Ticket | 42 West 71st Street
abstract: A five-story townhouse sold for $18,355,000 was the week’s second-largest residential real estate transaction.
lead_paragraph: A five-story townhouse sold for $18,355,000 was the week’s second-largest residential real estate transaction.

headline: Bookshelf: By the Numbers
abstract: New picture books include “Two Mice” and “The Great and Mighty Nikko!”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Two Mice” and “The Great and Mighty Nikko!”

headline: For $28 Million, Another Perch at One57
abstract: A sprawling three-bedroom apartment at One57 was the sale of the week, while the runner-up property was a five-story, fully renovated townhouse on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling aerie on the 67th floor of One57, Extell Development’s glassy-blue skyscraper, where the city’s priciest transaction for a single residence took place earlier this year, sold to an undisclosed buyer for $28,005,375 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Dr. Dre Apologizes to the ‘Women I’ve Hurt’
abstract: “Straight Outta Compton” ignored old allegations that Dr. Dre abused women. They resurfaced anyway.
lead_paragraph: For Dr. Dre, this summer was meant to be a victory lap in a successful career. “Straight Outta Compton,” a biopic about his hip-hop group, N.W.A., topped the box office last week with a $56.1 million opening. “Compton,” his first album in 16 years, debuted at No. 2 on the Billboard chart. Last year, the music company that Dr. Dre helped establish, Beats, was sold to Apple for $3 billion, making him the self-proclaimed “first billionaire in hip-hop.”

headline: Winner Take Less? (In Music)
abstract: Are the top bands losing share?
lead_paragraph: I very much liked Steven Johnson’s piece on the failure of the feared creative apocalypse to materialize. I do have a bone to pick, however: you do not write things like this:

headline: On Assignment: Exploding a Cherry Pie
abstract: New York Times staff photographer talks about his process photographing an exploding cherry pie for the May 21 cover of the Wealth and Finance section.
lead_paragraph: New York Times staff photographer talks about his process photographing an exploding cherry pie for the May 21 cover of the Wealth and Finance section.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘NeuroTribes’
abstract: This week, Steve Silberman talks about “NeuroTribes” and autism; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Elisabeth Egan discusses “A Window Opens”; questions from readers; Maria Russo talks about the season’s children’s books; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Steve Silberman talks about “NeuroTribes” and autism; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Elisabeth Egan discusses “A Window Opens”; questions from readers; Maria Russo talks about the season’s children’s books; and Parul Sehgal has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘NeuroTribes’
abstract: This week, Steve Silberman, Elisabeth Egan and Maria Russo.
lead_paragraph: This week, Steve Silberman, Elisabeth Egan and Maria Russo.

headline: Attracting Young, Diverse Mortgage Bankers
abstract: The industry is preparing for a coming shift in demographics among home buyers.
lead_paragraph: The Radius Financial Group, a mortgage lender in Norwell, Mass., recently made a $1 million investment in its future. The outlay wasn’t for technology, marketing or even office space. Rather, the company executives decided the future well-being of Radius depends upon its ability to attract younger employees from more diverse backgrounds.

headline: Track and Field Returns to Center Stage, as Do Doping Concerns
abstract: The world track and field championships are set to begin in Beijing, which hosted the 2008 Olympics and where the talk entering the meet has hardly been about the races.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In less troubled times, the eve of the world track and field championships would have been all about the return of Usain Bolt and his sport to the Bird’s Nest.

headline: Popcast: Carly Rae Jepsen Grows Up
abstract: With “Emotion,” the singer known best for “Call Me Maybe” embraces a seductive side to her music.
lead_paragraph: Carly Rae Jepsen arrived in the world like a hailstorm. Her song “Call Me Maybe” invaded from Canada in 2011 and by summer 2012, it had completed its assault on the country, a virus that infected America’s youth, its elderly, its sports teams and even its political leaders.

headline: A Deaf Dancer From Africa Makes a New Life in New York
abstract: Houzaifa Konditamdé, a native of Burkina Faso, became deaf at age 6, but that did not stop him from dancing, as the photographer Arthur Nazaryan has been documenting since 2014.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the small country of Burkina Faso in West Africa, Houzaifa Konditamdé could not hear. But that did not stop him from dancing.

headline: The Matisse of Mufflers
abstract: Lenny Prince sculpts objects far more elaborate than the usual stick figures fashioned from car parts that one sees outside some muffler shops.
lead_paragraph: Lenny Prince sculpts objects far more elaborate than the usual stick figures fashioned from car parts that one sees outside some muffler shops.

headline: The Time Is Right to Make Tomato Sauce
abstract: The main ingredient is at its peak. Following a few simple rules yields a perfect dish of pasta.
lead_paragraph: Tomatoes are now at their ripest and reddest, just right for a batch of fresh tomato sauce.

headline: Into the Teeth of the Storm
keywords: ['Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Floods', 'Levees and Dams', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Walter Baranger, senior editor for news operations, shares photos from his time coordinating The Times’s Hurricane Katrina coverage 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Walter Baranger, senior editor for news operations, shares photos from his time coordinating The Times’s Hurricane Katrina coverage 10 years ago.

headline: The Companies That May Be the Next 50 Start-Up Unicorns
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cloud Computing', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Delivery Services', 'E-Commerce', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Start-ups', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Which start-ups may be next to ascend to the $1 billion valuation club? Stay tuned for a list of 50, as compiled through an analysis from the research firm CB Insights.
lead_paragraph: It used to be a rare thing when start-ups were valued at $1 billion or more by their investors. Now it’s become so common that there are at least 131 start-ups boasting such valuations and a term — “unicorns” — to refer to the companies.

headline: 1890: Panic on Wall Street
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Wall Street stocks tumble out of sight in 1890.
lead_paragraph: This has been the most exciting day Wall Street has seen since the assassination of President Garfield. The stringency in the money market reached such a degree that it precipitated a panic among borrowers and carried the rate of call loans to nearly 190 per cent, the highest rate on record since the chaos resulting from the tragedy of ’81. The demand for funds at this anomalous rate of per cent per day, in addition to the regular rate of interest, cannot honestly be attributed to mere bear manipulation. The eagerness with which long stock was thrown on the market fully attested to the general need for money that prevails in Wall Street. While Wall Street was howling, stocks were tumbling out of sight. The threatened state of affairs on the Vanderbilt railroad system did not improve matters. Heavy liquidation in the entire group was one of the first conspicuous features of the session. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 22, 1890

headline: Challenging Mayor de Blasio Over Times Square Plazas
keywords: ['Street Performers', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Pedestrian Malls', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The idea of ripping up the pedestrian spaces and forcing people to dodge traffic again runs headlong into a policy to improve safety.
lead_paragraph: It was bad enough when the New York City police commissioner, William J. Bratton, reacting to tabloid headlines about topless women and costumed panhandlers in Times Square, suggested digging up the pedestrian plazas. That brought back memories of the 1980s, when New York officials refused to install benches in some city parks because they couldn’t figure out how to manage public space.

headline: A Staten Island Mechanic Turns Tailpipes Into Artwork
abstract: Mufflers may help stifle engine noise, but they amplified Lenny Prince’s creative tendencies and helped him become a sculptor of elaborate figures.
lead_paragraph: “No one can teach you to be an artist,” Lenny Prince likes to say. “The mufflers themselves trained me.”

headline: Doctors Behaving Badly
abstract: The decision by a prominent medical journal to publish an anonymous essay recounting appalling behavior by doctors while a patient was unconscious has sparked debate in the medical community.
lead_paragraph: What really goes on in an operating room?

headline: Mistrial for Charlotte Police Officer in Death of Unarmed Black Man
abstract: “We have exhausted every possibility,” said the jury foreman in the trial of Officer Randall Kerrick, accused of using excessive force in the shooting of Jonathan Ferrell.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — After nearly four days of jury deliberations, a judge declared a mistrial on Friday in the trial of a white Charlotte police officer who killed an unarmed black man almost two years ago.

headline: In ‘Hombre’ and ‘Kid Blue,’ the Antiheroes Wear Stetsons and Ride Tall on a Rebellion Frontier
abstract: Recent DVD releases recall the heyday of the western, and the way it mirrored social and political forces of the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: From the advent of the Cold War to the fall of Saigon, no American movie genre was more relevant than the western, with its allegorical echoes of race, crime, conquest and American exceptionalism.

headline: Restaurant Reviews: Little Drunken Chef in Mount Kisco and Little Mumbai Market in Pleasantville
abstract: Two more “Little” restaurants join the family. Little Drunken Chef offers tapas and an oyster bar; Little Mumbai Market says it is where Paris meets Mumbai.
lead_paragraph: There are already a lot of “Little” restaurants in Mount Kisco, but there was still room for one more.

headline: Usain Bolt vs. Justin Gatlin: Showdowns Await in Sprints
abstract: Bolt’s dominance in the 100 and 200 meters is expected to be tested at the world track and field championships in Beijing next week by Gatlin, a formerly barred runner from the United States.
lead_paragraph: For years, one of the few certainties at major international track meets was that Usain Bolt would outsprint everyone.

headline: Groups Press Hillary Clinton on Protecting Social Security
abstract: Martin O’Malley and Bernie Sanders, two Democrats running for president, have proposed expanding Social Security. Now progressive groups want to hear a similar view from Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton pleased progressives this week when she came out in opposition against drilling in the Arctic Ocean. Now they want to hear from her on Social Security.

headline: The Film Fatales Collective Trains a Lens on Gender Inequality
abstract: Film Fatales, a collective now in 20 cities around the world, helps female directors get their work seen at festivals.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s prehistoric attitude toward female directors, the filmmaker Leah Meyerhoff said, was epitomized by the recent “Jurassic World.”

headline: Restaurant Review: Lithos in Darien Is Built on a Greek Tradition
abstract: Building on classic Greek flavors, the owners of three diners in Connecticut step up with a restaurant, Lithos.
lead_paragraph: Lithos may sound like a Greek island in the Aegean or Ionian seas, or maybe one of the less Trumpian of the gods on Mount Olympus, but not so.

headline: A Hofstra Museum Exhibition Offers Views of the Past Through a Softer Light
keywords: ['Art', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: “Enduring Images,” which includes works by Andy Warhol and Yonia Fain, seeks to “showcase the artist’s role as a witness or participant in capturing moments of great turmoil,” the museum’s executive director said.
lead_paragraph: Even though all the art works in “Enduring Images,” an exhibition at Hofstra University in Hempstead, address themes like war, genocide, oppression and natural disasters, several of the paintings, prints and drawings use pastels or bright colors to illuminate the dark subject matter.

headline: The (Other) Sounds of Summer: Musical Scenes That Make Movies Sizzle
abstract: A look at a few sequences, from “Caddyshack,” “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” and other movies, that have helped make cultural milestones of hot-weather fare.
lead_paragraph: Savvy filmmakers know that when their releases are scheduled during the summer, it helps to include a musical sequence or set piece. This year, “Trainwreck” took appropriate precautions, with a cheerleader-dance finale set to a medley that included 2 Unlimited’s “Get Ready for This” (known for its appearance in “Space Jam”) and Billy Joel’s resilient “Uptown Girl.” It’s part of a long tradition — “Are you ready for the summer?” a chorus of excited children once inquired in Ivan Reitman’s sunbaked 1979 masterpiece, “Meatballs.” Here are a few highlights that have helped make hits and cultural milestones of hot-weather fare through the years.

headline: Facts & Figures: Carly Fiorina on Vaccines
abstract: Her implication that kids might be getting vaccines for noncommunicable diseases doesn’t hold water, according to FactCheck.org.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Carly Fiorina said that school districts should be able to deny admission to children who haven’t been vaccinated against “highly communicable diseases.” But, she added, “when we’re talking about some of these more esoteric immunizations, then I think absolutely a parent should have a choice and a school district shouldn’t be able to say, ‘sorry, your kid can’t come to school’ for a disease that’s not communicable, that’s not contagious, and where there really isn’t any proof that they’re necessary at this point.”

headline: Fafsa Follies: To Gain a Student, Eliminate a Form
abstract: Removing the application for federal aid would encourage more qualified low-income students to apply to college.
lead_paragraph: Many smart students forgo college in the mistaken belief that they cannot afford it. The financial aid system, which is intended to increase opportunities for low-income students, is largely to blame.

headline: London Theater Journal: Inside, Vodka and Stilettos; Outside, the Revolution
abstract: In Abi Morgan’s “Splendour” at the Donmar Warehouse, Sinead Cusack plays a dictator’s wife who drinks shots with her guests at the palace in a revolution-torn city.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Is it possible to achieve a contact high from alcohol? If so, I should be reeling. Strong drink is flowing freely – and damagingly – on this city’s stages. The night after I saw the Almeida Theater’s wine-soaked production of Euripides’ “Bakkhai,” I spent an evening at the Donmar Warehouse with four mutually contemptuous women who kept filling shot glasses with undiluted vodka.

headline: A Deadly Sin at the Aldrich, From the Comfort of an Armchair
abstract: Visitors to the Aldrich museum in Ridgefield can explore sloth and other iniquities in recline.
lead_paragraph: Strollers along Main Street in Ridgefield, Conn., will encounter a curious signpost planted in front of the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum. Each of its prongs is inscribed with one of the seven deadly sins followed by mileage information. Six aim westward: Lust, Gluttony, Greed, Wrath, Envy and Pride. The other points east, directly at the museum. It reads “Sloth 0.01 miles.”

headline: Study Finds Surprising Byproduct of Middle Eastern Conflicts: Cleaner Air
abstract: A paper published in the journal Science Advances found that Middle Eastern cities involved in wars or other crises showed fewer pollutants in the air.
lead_paragraph: Civil unrest and humanitarian crises can now be detected from space — because of, somewhat surprisingly, cleaner air.

headline: Classification Follies
abstract: Secret silliness, silly secretness.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton email “scandal” goes on — still no sign that she broke any rules, no sign that she sent or received anything labeled “classified”, but she may have received and even forwarded items that were later classified or “should” have been classified. By normal human standards this is a big nothing; but Clinton Rules apply, under which malign behavior is the default assumption and where there’s smoke there must be fire even if everyone knows that the usual suspects are operating big smoke machines. How many people still think that there really was a Whitewater scandal, or for that matter that Hillary is the subject of a criminal investigation?

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Caitlin Moran
abstract: The comedian and author lists the titles she’d bring with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his new bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next installment in the series comes from Caitlin Moran, the comedian and author, who shares her picks exclusively with T.

headline: Enthusiastic Crowd Will Greet Donald Trump in Alabama Stadium
abstract: Fans of Donald J. Trump, and supporters of change in the political discourse, waited outside Ladd-Peebles Stadium in Mobile, Ala., hours ahead of an appearance by the presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. – By midday Friday, with the temperature in the high 80s, Keith Quackenbush and Bill Hart decided it was time to buy an $89 pop-up tent from a nearby Walmart. It was how, they said, they were going to endure the wait outside a football stadium ahead of an appearance by Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate.

headline: Silent Beyoncé, a Bloomingdale’s Blunder and Lagerfeld’s Eye
abstract: Plus, Cookie at Saks, Dolce’s soul searching and more from the week in style.

headline: Tianjin Blasts Expose the Dangerous Proximity of Toxic Chemicals in China
abstract: The warehouse in Tianjin that exploded was just one of many buildings across China that store toxic chemicals near residential areas.
lead_paragraph: The warehouse in Tianjin that exploded was just one of many buildings across China that store toxic chemicals near residential areas.

headline: Rafael Nadal Accepts Another Early Loss, but Looks Ahead
abstract: After Nadal lost in the third round of the Western & Southern Open in Ohio on Thursday night, he said that he never considered himself immune to slumping.
lead_paragraph: MASON, Ohio — It used to be that Rafael Nadal’s crashing out of a tournament in an early round would prompt the biggest headlines in tennis. But in a year in which Nadal has consistently fallen short of the high standard he has set for himself, each subsequent loss seems less newsworthy.

headline: The Writer's Room
abstract: Under the canopy of a tree, near a closet full of sweets, with the ghost of a famous painter, six authors on the spaces where they work.
lead_paragraph: Under the canopy of a tree, near a closet full of sweets, with the ghost of a famous painter, six authors on the spaces where they work.

headline: Have You Cut the Cable Cord?
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Customer Relations', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Television']
abstract: “Never looking back,” said one of a number of readers who have given up cable.
lead_paragraph: Friday morning’s editorial on the growing number of Americans who are giving up cable- and satellite-TV service resonated with many readers. A number of them said in comments on the piece and on Facebook and Twitter that they, too, had happily given up cable.

headline: President Erdogan of Turkey to Call for New Election
abstract: After no deal emerged from weeks of talks, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he would call a Nov. 1 vote to break the impasse among the four main political parties.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said on Friday that he would call a snap election for Nov. 1 to break the impasse among the country’s four main political parties, an impasse that opponents say is partly of his own making.

headline: Pension Advisers Learn the Folly of Trying to Beat the Market
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: Two advisers in Nevada have learned that investors who try to pick stocks that will outperform the market will fail to do so over long periods.
lead_paragraph: CARSON CITY, Nev. — The Carson Nugget casino takes up the better part of a downtown block in this state capital, and a sign on the side beckons bettors with a promise of “Extremely Loose Slots.”

headline: Jacob deGrom, a Met Known for His Hair, May (Gasp!) Cut It
abstract: This season deGrom has established himself as one of the best pitchers in baseball, and his hair has become an identifiable — and marketable — signature.
lead_paragraph: Just before each spring training, Jacob deGrom has his hair cut in the kitchen of his parents’ house in DeLand, Fla. His older sister, Jessica, a former hairdresser, styles it. The whole scene has become something of an event for the deGroms. They find it funny to watch a major league pitcher squirm.

headline: Unseen Burdens in Chrome That Can Lead a Mac to Lag
abstract: Determining whether a browser might be the source of a computer’s sluggishness, and a look at Facebook’s “authentic identity” policy.
lead_paragraph: Q. I noticed my Mac was acting a little sluggish. When I opened the OS X system monitor to see what was going on, I found all these things called “Google Chrome Helper” listed. Is that a legitimate piece of software?

headline: A Lawyer Quit Her Job to Start a Climate Museum in New York
abstract: Miranda Massie describes the environment as a civil rights issue on which the survival of the species depends.
lead_paragraph: Miranda Massie may not be the most obvious candidate to create a museum in New York City devoted to the subject of climate change. As a child growing up in the Hudson Valley in the 1970s, she rebelled against her father’s early efforts at recycling. Later, after flirting with getting a Ph.D. in history, she became a lawyer specializing in civil rights and took a job in Detroit.

headline: What I Love | John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey
keywords: ['Music', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The husband and wife cabaret team rehearse their act and record their weekly podcast in an Upper West Side brownstone.
lead_paragraph: The husband and wife cabaret team rehearse their act and record their weekly podcast in an Upper West Side brownstone.

headline: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey’s Brownstone Rental
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Music', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Mr. Pizzarelli, the jazz guitarist and singer, and Ms. Molaskey, the singer and actress, live on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: The couple known to uptown sophisticates as the Nick and Nora of the cabaret world — and to the rest of us as John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey — rent the parlor and garden floors of a brownstone on the Upper West Side.

headline: Trading Barbs, India and Pakistan Seem on Verge of Canceling Talks
abstract: The escalation of tensions comes as the foreign ministries on both sides issued tough statements over Pakistan’s plans to meet with Kashmiri separatist leaders.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Talks between India and Pakistan, scheduled for next week in New Delhi, appeared on the brink of collapse Friday after the foreign ministries on both sides traded tough statements over Pakistan’s plans to meet with Kashmiri separatist leaders while in India.

headline: Carter, Reagan, and Machiavelli
abstract: Have your recession early!
lead_paragraph: Rex Nutting has a very nice article about the reality of Jimmy Carter’s presidency, which has been distorted out of recognition by the myth of Saint Reagan. As he points out, Carter presided over faster average job growth and lower unemployment than Reagan; unfortunately for Carter, his timing was bad, with vigorous growth for most of his presidency but a recession at the end.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The History of Autism
abstract: Steve Silberman talks about “NeuroTribes: The Legacy of Autism and the Future of Neurodiversity,” and Elisabeth Egan discusses her debut novel, “A Window Opens.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Jennifer Senior reviews Steve Silberman’s “NeuroTribes: The Legacy of Autism and the Future of Neurodiversity.” Ms. Senior writes:

headline: Revisiting Issue, Donald Trump Calls Attack on Homeless Man ‘Terrible’
abstract: Criticized for his initial response to an attack on a homeless Hispanic man in Boston, Donald J. Trump on Friday called the assault “terrible.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that he “would never condone violence” and that an attack on a homeless Hispanic man in Boston by two men who said they supported him was “terrible.”

headline: Review: Martha Graham’s ‘Embattled Garden,’ Deconstructed
abstract: A man, a woman, a serpentine fellow and another woman live in the paradise of this work, which was presented in a studio treatment with contextual comments.
lead_paragraph: In the August heat, Janet Eilber, the artistic director of the Martha Graham Dance Company, apologized for the “breathless and sweaty” conditions in the Martha Graham Studio Theater, a storied spot cooled only by fans. She also joked with the audience that the steamy atmosphere was exactly right for the work being performed on Wednesday evening, Graham’s “Embattled Garden,” from 1958.

headline: Bernie Sanders Speaks at a Rally in S.C.
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, spoke to a large crowd in Greenville, S.C., on Friday, stressing the benefits of his agenda to minorities.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, spoke to a large crowd in Greenville, S.C., on Friday, stressing the benefits of his agenda to minorities.

headline: Ex-Heavyweight Champion Riddick Bowe Steps Into a New Arena
abstract: After two boxing world titles, prison and bankruptcy, Mr. Bowe hopes to cement another legacy: as a restaurateur.
lead_paragraph: Three men stood on a street in Harlem, handing out fliers and pointing to a big man sitting alone inside a small restaurant with four tables called Bowe’s. He looked around, eager for company.

lead_paragraph: A molded rubber bag is a style mixture of the Birkin and Kelley bag details and a hit of the summer.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: Bernie Sanders draws crowds, the Iowa State Fair attracts White House hopefuls, and the president shows his form on the links.

headline: A New Day
abstract: T’s Women’s Fashion issue is rife with stories about transformation.
lead_paragraph: IT SEEMS ONLY FITTING that an issue kicking off the fall season should be rife with stories about transformation. Yet while it wasn’t actually our intention to thread together features on that theme, neither is it really a coincidence. Change — whether emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic or stylistic — is what this magazine seeks to understand and to celebrate. And so, a small sampling of what lies ahead: a renegade collective that is shifting the practice and conception of architecture from a focus on the grandeur of a building to its actual everyday use; an artist who turns the stuff of daily life (which is more compelling than most, as she collects male muses and creates avatars to reproduce her Internet sex chats) into challenging work; a successful garden designer who wanted to bust out of his formal clipped-hedge-and-boxwood box and apprenticed himself at one of England’s most revered flower gardens; a group of avant-garde young designers who are reimagining fashion: luxury and craftsmanship take on a different meaning when they involve slicing and reweaving T-shirts bought in bulk at Kmart; a foreign-born press that is turning artfully designed books of fiction into status symbols.

headline: Bill Cunningham | It Bag
abstract: A molded rubber bag, designed by Robert Verdi and the Great Bag Co., mixes style details from the Birkin and Kelly bags from Hermès and is a hit of the summer.
lead_paragraph: A molded rubber bag, designed by Robert Verdi and the Great Bag Co., mixes style details from the Birkin and Kelly bags from Hermès and is a hit of the summer. At $120, the bag is offered in vibrant primary colors, plus black, gray and white. A young man was observed this month on his way to work, carrying the bag in a different color on different days. Another young manwas seen with black and gray versions. Several times, women carrying the same bag stopped to show them off. Other bag news this August: red bags brightening black clothes. Other times, both during the day and evening, the bags were taxicab yellow and gave a new vitality and zip to black clothes.

headline: Ellen Page Confronts Ted Cruz at the Iowa State Fair
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The actress Ellen Page engaged Senator Ted Cruz in a four-minute discussion of same-sex marriage and gay rights as he was flipping burgers for fairgoers.
lead_paragraph: As he flipped pork on a large grill at the Iowa State Fair, Senator Ted Cruz was engaged in an active discussion over same-sex marriage and gay, bisexual and transgender rights with a hat-and-sunglasses-clad attendee.

headline: Five Mystery Birds Among Audubon’s Paintings
abstract: Among the hundreds of birds drawn and painted by John James Audubon, five “mystery birds” have not been identified or found in nature.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently saw a TV program that said several of the birds painted by John James Audubon in “The Birds of America” never existed. Could that be true?

headline: ABN Amro Nearly Doubles Earnings
abstract: The state-owned Dutch bank posted second-quarter earnings of 600 million euros.
lead_paragraph: ABN Amro, the state-owned Dutch bank that was the poster child of the financial crisis, has almost grown up.

headline: In Questions Over Shaun King’s Race, Activists See Challenge to Black Lives Matter Movement
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Reporters pointed out that the father named on his birth certificate is white, and critics compared him to Rachel Dolezal.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Black Lives Matter activist who has been accused of lying about his race was forced to discuss deeply personal issues after reporters pointed out that the father named on his birth certificate is white.

headline: Living in the Ring of Fire
abstract: In the Northwest, we calculate the odds of disaster.
lead_paragraph: THE West has been on fire all month, with dream homes falling to a combustive punch, wild horses seared by flame and suffocated by smoke, even a rare “firenado” dancing across a landscape in which seven million acres have been burned this year.

headline: New Condos in Astoria’s Kaufman Arts District
abstract: Home to Kaufman Astoria Studios, the neighborhood will soon include a seven-story building with 33 condominium units.
lead_paragraph: A 24-block section of Astoria, Queens, known as the Kaufman Arts District and home to Kaufman Astoria Studios — one of the world’s oldest continuously active movie studios — will soon see the addition of its first major new apartment building in years.

headline: Your Brain, Your Disease, Your Self
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Memory', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'AMYOTROPHIC LATERAL SCLEROSIS', 'Dementia', 'Frontotemporal Dementia', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: What kind of neural damage threatens your identity — and why?
lead_paragraph: WHEN does the deterioration of your brain rob you of your identity, and when does it not?

headline: Airstrikes Kill Dozens of Civilians in Yemen, Doctors Without Borders Says
abstract: The medical charity reported what could be one of the largest death tolls from the Saudi-led airstrikes in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Doctors Without Borders said Friday that Saudi-led airstrikes on a residential district in Yemen’s southwestern city of Taiz had killed more than 65 civilians, including 17 people from one family.

headline: Karen Stives, Acclaimed Olympic Equestrian, Dies at 64
abstract: Ms. Stives, riding Ben Arthur, won an individual silver medal and led the American team to a gold medal in three-day eventing at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Karen Stives, a fiercely gifted horsewoman who helped lead the American equestrian team to an Olympic gold medal in the sport known as three-day eventing, barely missing out on an individual gold medal herself, died this month at her home in Dover, Mass. She was 64.

headline: A Day Out in the Boxing Gym With John Leguizamo
abstract: At the Church Street gym in Lower Manhattan, the actor talks stage, screen and sparring.
lead_paragraph: Accidents happen. Few people know better than John Leguizamo, who was sparring the other day at the Church Street Boxing Gym in Lower Manhattan with his longtime trainer, Jenaro Diaz.

abstract: Some of the core participants dressed in the authentic flapper style.
lead_paragraph: Some of the core participants dressed in the authentic flapper style.

headline: 1965 | A Half Century of Civil Rights Coverage Begins
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Newspapers', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: David W. Dunlap looks back at a familiar byline that appeared on The Times’s front page, years after the reporter left the paper.
lead_paragraph: To those who grew up reading The Times’s coverage of civil rights, the byline over the front-page obituary of Julian Bond on Monday was almost as familiar a name as Mr. Bond’s: “By Roy Reed.”

headline: Evening Hours | Jazz Age Lawn Party
abstract: For the first time, it ended in a brief but dramatic thunder shower with many of the more than 20,000 participants taking cover under their picnic blankets.
lead_paragraph: The tenth annual Jazz Age lawn party on Governor’s Island concluded its two-weekend run. For the first time, it ended in a brief but dramatic thunder shower with many of the more than 20,000 participants taking cover under their picnic blankets. The original event was the idea of Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra, as part of an effort to popularize the century-old military island after its reopened as a public park.

headline: How Bentley Meeker, Lighting Designer, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Karate, farmer’s markets and a visit with his artist-in-residence are all part of Mr. Meeker’s weekend ritual.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Bentley Meeker left an anonymous note in the temple of the Burning Man festival, concerning his relationship with his son, who is now 15 and lives in California. After the temple burned down — as is the ritual at the annual Nevada event — he found resolution. Grateful, Mr. Meeker, 47, a lighting designer whose regular gigs include White House state dinners, approached festival organizers about contributing his skills to future temples. This summer, he plans to illuminate the “Temple of Promise” in collaboratoration with Scooter Wilson and Adam Crocker. His method: Edison tungsten spots, which he has also installed in the converted warehouse in East Harlem where he lives with his girlfriend, Alicia Boyes, 38, a restaurant consultant.

headline: Airstrike Kills a Deputy to ISIS Leader, U.S. Says
abstract: The White House said Fadel al-Hayali was second in command to the militant group’s leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A deputy to the leader of the Islamic State was killed in an American airstrike in Iraq this week, the White House announced Friday.

headline: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Readers React
abstract: An article Thursday about treatment for ductal carcinoma in situ prompted a wide range of responses, anger, sadness and relief among them.
lead_paragraph: An article Thursday on the results of a study indicating that aggressive surgical treatment of a possible precursor to breast cancer may be unnecessary prompted a wide range of responses from readers, among them anger, sadness and relief.

headline: Summer Berry Buckle
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a buckle with copious amounts of fruit and just enough batter to bind it together.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a buckle with copious amounts of fruit and just enough batter to bind it together.

headline: The Buckle Makes Great Use of Summer Fruit
abstract: Beneath its distinctive cratered top lies a moist, buttery filling. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to see how the crumble and the crisp got their names. Just look at their toppings. But for me at least, the buckle was more of a mystery.

headline: 2 American Service Members Foil Gunman in Train Attack
abstract: The two men averted carnage by tackling an armed, suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to France, officials said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The two American service members who tackled a suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris rushed him even though he was fully armed, then grabbed him by the neck and beat him over the head with his own automatic rifle until he was unconscious, one of them said in television interviews here on Saturday.

headline: Social Chatter: Deez Nuts For President
abstract: The presidential candidate Deez Nuts was surging on Wednesday, polling at 9 percent in North Carolina.  Here are a few of the reactions to his campaign.
lead_paragraph: The presidential candidate Deez Nuts was surging on Wednesday, polling at 9 percent in North Carolina.  Here are a few of the reactions to his campaign.

headline: Candis Cayne, From Chelsea Drag Queen to Caitlyn Jenner’s Sidekick
abstract: She was one of the first transgender actresses to appear on a network TV show. Then the roles dried up ... until “I Am Cait.” Now she seems determined to make sure her fame is not fleeting.
lead_paragraph: Long before Laverne Cox made the cover of Time magazine as a “transgender tipping point,” and long before Caitlyn Jenner made global headlines as a former Olympian transitioning from male to female at age 65, there was Candis Cayne.

headline: Ted Cruz Takes Up Iowa Couple’s Cause as He Courts Evangelicals
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Mennonite Churches', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Ted Cruz has taken up the cause of Richard and Betty Odgaard, a Mennonite couple who were fined $5,000 after they refused to rent their event space for a same-sex wedding in 2013.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES – When Senator Ted Cruz speaks to as many as 2,000 conservatives at a Rally for Religious Liberty on Friday night, he will feature on stage Iowa’s equivalent of the Christian bakers and florists who became cause célèbres by refusing to provide services for same-sex weddings.

headline: Thousands Stop to Smell a Flower (and Hope Not to Gag)
abstract: The long-awaited blooming of the Denver Botanic Gardens’ corpse flower, known for its potent stench, attracted long lines of curious observers.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It felt as if all of Denver was there, clutching their souvenir motion sickness bags and taking selfies as they waited for hours — and hours — for a glimpse and a whiff of this city’s celebrity of the moment: the corpse flower.

headline: Turning Puerto Rico’s Lament Into Hope
abstract: A photographer and writer return to the island to find both resentment and resilience among the middle class.
lead_paragraph: A photographer and writer return to the island to find both resentment and resilience among the middle class.

headline: N.Y.C. Nature: The Charming Pill Bug
abstract: Roly-polies are gentle, completely harmless creatures, and are often a child’s first invitation to nature in the city.
lead_paragraph: As cute as anything found under a log, pill bugs, or roly-polies, are often the first “bugs” a child invites to play. My brother and I spent many hours in Canarsie poking them into little balls and rolling them around at the bottom of bottles, impatiently waiting for them to unfurl. Pill bugs are gentle, completely harmless creatures, and are often a child’s first invitation to nature in the city.

headline: New York Bookshelf: The Last Big Colony and the First Suburb
abstract: Sam Roberts describes a new book about the Puerto Rican independence movement and one about Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico has been a United States possession for 117 years, or almost as long as the Eastern Seaboard was under British domination until Americans declared independence in 1776.

headline: Women’s Fashion, Fall 2015
abstract: The latest issue from T celebrates emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic and stylistic transformation.
lead_paragraph: The latest issue from T celebrates emotional, sartorial, intellectual, artistic and stylistic transformation.

headline: Friday Not Music: Talking New York
abstract: Home is where the “aw” is.
lead_paragraph: Somehow not feeling musical this week. But I recently took a relative to the wonderful Tenement Museum, where we listened among other things to a recording of someone who lived in the building just before it was condemned; it was fascinating, but what got my companion going was the accent, which she found hilarious and I found comforting. After all these years, it’s the sound of home:

headline: ‘Cuba: The Conversation Continues’ and ‘Live in Cuba’ Expand a Musical Dialogue
abstract: These two new albums feature performances from Arturo O’Farrill and the Afro-Latin Jazz Alliance and Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: As the American flag was raised over the United States Embassy in Cuba last Friday, the pianist and composer Arturo O’Farrill could be found in the immigration area at José Martí International Airport in Havana. Footage of the ceremony, symbolizing the restoration of diplomatic relations severed in 1961, was being piped into the room.

headline: A Russian Solider Story
abstract: As the tensions between Russian and Ukraine have continued, Pavel Volkov has explored the lives of young Russian conscripts with mixed reactions to the conflict.
lead_paragraph: As the tensions between Russian and Ukraine have continued, Pavel Volkov has explored the lives of young Russian conscripts with mixed reactions to the conflict.

headline: Review: On ‘Blunt Talk,’ Patrick Stewart Is Far From Home and Caught With His Pants Down
abstract: Mr. Stewart’s character, Walter Blunt, is having a late-life nervous breakdown, but neither Blunt nor the show takes his crisis very seriously.
lead_paragraph: It’s not accurate to say that Patrick Stewart hasn’t done comedy. He was funny playing himself as a poker-faced pervert in an episode of “Extras,” or dancing with Kelsey Grammer and telling him how sexy he looked in a tux on “Frasier.” And he’s lent his plummy voice to a raft of animated shows from “Family Guy” to “Robot Chicken.”

headline: Bobby Jindal Calls for Holding Mayors of Sanctuary Cities Responsible for Crime
abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said he could secure the Southern border within six months of becoming president and called for prosecuting officials in sanctuary cities.
lead_paragraph: Not to be outdone by his Republican presidential rivals on immigration, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said Friday that he could secure the Southern border within six months of becoming president and called for prosecuting officials in sanctuary cities when their undocumented residents commit crimes.

headline: Season 2 of ‘Survivor’s Remorse’ Handles Touchy Topics
abstract: “Survivor’s Remorse,” which begins its second season, has similarities to “Entourage,” but its real affinity is with other African-American family sitcoms.
lead_paragraph: Season 2 of the Starz comedy “Survivor’s Remorse” opens the same way Season 1 did: with a joyous family checking out its new digs, laughing and shouting and dancing through the rooms. In the first season, the setting was a lavish penthouse apartment; in the second (which begins Saturday night) the clan has moved on out to an imposing suburban mini-mansion.

headline: ‘¡Cuba, Cuba! 65 Years of Photography’ at the Southampton Arts Center
abstract: This exhibition, by the International Center of Photography, continues through Sept. 7 in Southampton, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Since the announcement of a thaw with the United States, Cuba seems suspended between potentially very different histories: what was, what is and what’s to be. Of the three, the knowable one is, of course, the past, and a substantial and dramatic part of the record is in the form of photographs. The International Center of Photography has a collection deep enough to tell that visual story, and is doing so, with some outside additions, in “¡Cuba, Cuba! 65 Years of Photography” at the Southampton (N.Y.) Art Center through Sept. 7.

headline: Two Good Reasons to Visit St. Albans, Queens
abstract: The Maria Rose International Doll House promotes cultural diversity, while the Roti Roadhouse offers organic dishes with generous helpings.
lead_paragraph: Household names and tastemakers — Fats Waller, Count Basie, Ella Fitzgerald, Lena Horne, John Coltrane, James Brown, Billie Holiday, Jackie Robinson, Joe Louis, Milt Hinton, Cootie Williams, Illinois Jacquet and Brook Benton — all lived at one time or another in Addisleigh Park, a stately enclave just north of Kennedy International Airport. The historic district is part of St. Albans, Queens, a predominantly black, middle-class neighborhood where another sort of nostalgia can be indulged at the MARIA ROSE INTERNATIONAL DOLL HOUSE, which opened in July.

headline: Gunman Kills Guard Then Himself at a Federal Building in Manhattan
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The gunman, a man in his late 60s from Fort Lee, N.J., fatally shot a security guard in a building housing several federal agency offices.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man walked into a federal building near the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan on Friday afternoon and fatally shot a security guard before killing himself, the authorities said.

headline: In the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Archives, a Magical Past and Present Unite
abstract: Through an expansion of its archives, the festival allows visitors to savor seemingly evanescent moments of its history in the Berkshires.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — Jacob’s Pillow, the oldest dance festival in the United States and always eclectic and international in taste, began in the early 1940s. But its founding director, Ted Shawn, had been here since 1931, and when he died in 1972, still at the helm, he left the festival with archival materials that went back to his own early days in dance.

headline: Nearly 51,000 Madewell Sandals Are Recalled
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Madewell, J. Crew’s slightly cheaper sister brand, has received eight reports of the shanks dislodging and breaking through the sole of their “Sightseer” sandals.
lead_paragraph: Madewell, J. Crew’s smaller but fast-growing hipster brand, is recalling about 50,900 pairs of sandals in the United States and Canada because they may cause wearers to trip and fall.

headline: Native American Artists Display Works in Santa Fe
abstract: The Santa Fe Indian Market and the Indigenous Fine Art Market showcase talent in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — Native American artists converged here this week to sell their work in the Indigenous Fine Art Market, an artist-led initiative that formed last year as an alternative to the Santa Fe Indian Market, produced by the Southwestern Association of Indian Arts.

headline: Jacob Bekenstein, Physicist Who Revolutionized Theory of Black Holes, Dies at 68
abstract: Dr. Bekenstein, whose proposition on entropy and space eventually won over a skeptical Stephen Hawking, was considered one of the few giants in the study of quantum gravity.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Bekenstein, a physicist who prevailed in an argument with Stephen Hawking that revolutionized the study of black holes, and indeed the nature of space-time itself, died on Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, where he was to give a physics lecture. He was 68.

headline: Review: ‘Pericles,’ Lashed by Sorrows, at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival
abstract: Joseph Haj’s new production, which includes sections set to music, charts the misfortunes of a prince whose daughter ultimately rescues him from despair.
lead_paragraph: ASHLAND, Ore. — Even among the beleaguered heroes and heroines of Shakespeare’s late romances, the title character of “Pericles” stands out for the weight of strange misfortunes that chase him around the Mediterranean, and more than once dump him in it when the ships he’s traveling aboard founder. (A favorite stage direction: “Enter Pericles, wet.”)

headline: Home Care Workers Prevail in Court
keywords: ['Home Health Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: For-profit home care agencies must pay their workers minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime, an appeals court has ruled.
lead_paragraph: A unanimous three-judge panel on the United States Court of Appeals in Washington, D.C. ruled on Friday that for-profit home care agencies must pay their employees at least the minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime.

headline: Black Man Shot by Police in St. Louis Died From Bullet to Back
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The police said Mansur Ball-Bey, 18, continued to run after he was shot, but the chief St. Louis medical examiner said the youth was most likely “incapacitated immediately.”
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old St. Louis man whom the police said they shot after he pointed a gun at officers died from a bullet that entered the middle of his back and lodged near his rib cage, the city’s chief medical examiner said Friday. The shooting, the latest killing of a black man by officers, has raised tensions in the region.

headline: Israel Came Close to Attacking Iran, Ex-Defense Minister Says
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ehud Barak told biographers that in 2010, 2011 and 2012, he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu were ready to strike, and why the attacks didn’t happen.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A former Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, revealed new details to his biographers about how close Israel came to striking Iran’s military facilities in 2010, 2011 and 2012 and why it did not despite his and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s desire to do so, according to interview excerpts aired on Israeli television Friday night.

headline: John Correnti, Steel Industry Executive, Dies at 68
abstract: At various times in his life, Mr. Correnti led Nucor, Big River Steel, Birmingham Steel and Severstal Columbus — and built steel mills from scratch, embracing new technologies.
lead_paragraph: John Correnti, who was a leader in the American steel industry during its heyday and clung to it even as it faded, died on Tuesday in Chicago while on a business trip. He was 68.

headline: Shirtless Bodies in Pointless Times Square War
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Street Performers', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Pedestrian Malls', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Topless women aren’t terrorizing the uncomfortably overcrowded Crossroads of the World. Mayor Bill de Blasio’s emergency task force is an overreaction.
lead_paragraph: In New York politics, as in Newtonian physics, there is action and reaction and, too often, overreaction.

headline: F.B.I. Releases Documents About 2012 Shooting in Queens
keywords: ['Freedom of Information Act', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In response to Freedom of Information Act requests by The New York Times, the F.B.I. has released three internal federal government reports about a July 2012 incident in Queens in which an off-duty agent shot a man apparently trying to burglarize his car. The F.B.I.’s shooting incident review group deemed the shooting unjustified, making it the first such “bad shoot” in decades in a case involving an intentional shooting of a suspect.
lead_paragraph: In response to Freedom of Information Act requests by The New York Times, the F.B.I. has released three internal federal government reports about a July 2012 incident in Queens in which an off-duty agent shot a man apparently trying to burglarize his car. The F.B.I.’s shooting incident review group deemed the shooting unjustified, making it the first such “bad shoot” in decades in a case involving an intentional shooting of a suspect.

headline: F.B.I. Shooting Incident Reviews, 1993-2013
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: Under the Freedom of Information Act, The New York Times obtained this collection of internal reports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation reviewing shootings by F.B.I. agents. In late 2013, for the first time since at least 1993 and likely longer, this administrative review process deemed an intentional shooting by an agent of a suspect to be a “bad shoot.”
lead_paragraph: Under the Freedom of Information Act, The New York Times obtained this collection of internal reports by the Federal Bureau of Investigation reviewing shootings by F.B.I. agents. In late 2013, for the first time since at least 1993 and likely longer, this administrative review process deemed an intentional shooting by an agent of a suspect to be a “bad shoot.”

headline: In Rare Case, F.B.I. Tries to Fire Agent Who Shot Queens Suspect
abstract: The bureau said an off-duty agent violated its lethal force policy in 2012 by firing at a man who had apparently helped break into his car outside his home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the first time in decades, the F.B.I. is trying to fire an agent for intentionally shooting a suspect, after finding that the agent violated bureau policy when he wounded an unarmed man who had apparently helped break into his Lexus outside his home in Queens.

headline: Man Killed and Woman Badly Hurt in Knife Fight on Harlem Sidewalk
abstract: The two faced off against a man and a woman on a crowded street on Friday morning, the police said; the cause is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: A man in his 30s was fatally stabbed and a woman he was with was seriously injured when they faced off against two other people in a knife fight on a busy Harlem street on Friday, the police said.

headline: Expanding Web of Scandal in Brazil Threatens Further Upheaval
abstract: Charges against a powerful lawmaker bring a combative reaction, and shift attention to the scandal-plagued Congress.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The charges are nothing less than sweeping: Prosecutors say that Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of Brazil’s lower house of Congress, took as much as $40 million in bribes for himself and his allies, plundering Petrobras, the government-controlled oil company, while laundering money through an evangelical megachurch.

headline: Americans Foiled Train Attack
abstract: Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve spoke after a shooting on a train left three people wounded, saying two United States citizens helped disarm the attacker.
lead_paragraph: Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve spoke after a shooting on a train left three people wounded, saying two United States citizens helped disarm the attacker.

headline: Decades of Data Fail to Resolve Debate on Treating Tiny Breast Lesions
abstract: The study’s authors said the data indicates that treatment has not made much of a difference, if any, for the tens of thousands of women a year who are told they have this condition.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years after the widespread use of mammograms set off a surge in the detection of tiny lesions in milk ducts, there is still debate about how — or even whether — to treat them. In an era when there has been so much study of how to treat more advanced cancer, it might seem odd that there is so much uncertainty about these minute sprinklings of abnormal cells, often called Stage 0 cancer, which some say are not cancers at all.

headline: U.S. Court Reinstates Home Care Pay Rules
abstract: The regulations, struck down by a lower court about nine months ago, were intended to remove an exemption in federal minimum wage and overtime laws for home care workers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday reinstated regulations drawn up by the Obama administration to extend minimum wage and overtime protections to almost two million workers who provide home care for the elderly and disabled.

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton had planned to spend the last two weeks of August on vacation, unwinding and fund-raising on the exclusive shores of Long Island. But, as it turns out, this is no time for a vacation.

lead_paragraph: The renovated laboratory was hailed as state of the art. One teacher even said it would be a “crown jewel” of the campus shared by several high schools in Marble Hill, its unveiling so eagerly anticipated that, one mother said, paper had been put up over windows to keep students from peeking inside.

headline: Sasha Petraske, 42, Dies; Bar Owner Restored Luster to Cocktail Culture
abstract: The founder of the influential New York cocktail bar Milk & Honey was found dead on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Sasha Petraske, who helped restore lost luster to the venerable cocktail as the founder of the New York cocktail bar Milk & Honey and other polished drinking spots around the world, was found dead on Friday morning at his home in Hudson, N.Y. He was 42.

headline: A Perilous Moment at the Korean Border
abstract: Any action by South Korea must be carefully weighed, with an emphasis on restraint.
lead_paragraph: The enduring, familiar tensions between North and South Korea are usually considered background noise by a world focused on other international crises. That was no longer possible after the two countries traded rocket and artillery fire across their heavily militarized border. Given North Korea’s nuclear weapons arsenal and its erratic leader, Kim Jong-un, any such confrontation must be taken seriously and managed carefully, with the United States and China playing key roles in urging restraint.

headline: Florida Legislators Fail to Agree on Congressional Districts
abstract: Lawmakers could not agree on a plan for redrawing congressional districts to present to the State Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida’s House and Senate on Friday failed to agree on a new congressional map mandated by the state’s Supreme Court, bringing to a futile close a legislative special session created to redraw congressional districts the court said were unconstitutionally gerrymandered.

headline: Investigation Lifts a Cloud Over President of Mexico
abstract: A seven-month conflict-of-interest investigation into the purchase of luxury homes by President Enrique Peña Nieto’s wife and his finance minister from a government contractor found no wrongdoing, Mexico’s comptroller said Friday.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A seven-month conflict-of-interest investigation into the purchase of luxury homes by President Enrique Peña Nieto’s wife and his finance minister from a government contractor found no wrongdoing, Mexico’s comptroller said Friday.

headline: Liz Perle, Writer and Former Publishing Executive, Dies at 59
abstract: Ms. Perle was co-founder of Common Sense Media, a nonprofit that helps children engage with the digital world responsibly.
lead_paragraph: Liz Perle, a writer and former publishing executive who co-founded Common Sense Media, a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping families navigate the complex worlds of entertainment, media and technology, died on Thursday at her home in San Francisco. She was 59.

headline: Daily News Struggles to Find Its Identity After Sale Is Called Off
abstract: Employees at The Daily News expressed relief after the publication’s owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, called off its sale.
lead_paragraph: The news at The Daily News — that the owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, had done an about-face and decided not to sell — brought consolation to the publication’s newsroom, at least for now. But questions remain about The News’s long-term prospects, and about its place in both the city and the turbulent media world.

headline: Microbeads, the Tiny Orbs Threatening Our Water
abstract: Once plastic microbeads enter the water, they attract toxic substances like PCBs and are eaten by fish.
lead_paragraph: Plastic is believed to be the main contaminant in the huge garbage gyres that pollute the oceans. Now researchers, led by Sherri Mason of the State University of New York at Fredonia, have found a stunning amount of plastic in the largest freshwater ecosystem on earth, the Great Lakes. And an increasing amount of it consists of the tiny plastic orbs used as abrasives in products like toothpaste and anti-acne lotions.

headline: Prospect of Self-Inspections by Iran Feeds Opposition to Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: A military base in Iran has become a symbol of whether international inspectors are interested in digging into the past, or will just be checking boxes.
lead_paragraph: To the most strident opponents of President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, the suspicious behavior at a military base about 12 miles southeast of Tehran has become a rallying call to defeat the accord, especially as it now appears that Iranian officials may be allowed to take their own environmental samples at the site and turn them over to inspectors.

headline: Three Killed in Washington Wildfire Are Mourned
abstract: The lives and deaths of Tom Zbyszewski, Richard Wheeler and Andrew Zajac offer a window into the close-knit world of wildland firefighting in the West.
lead_paragraph: CHELAN, Wash. — Tom Zbyszewski, 20, won a poetry-reciting competition but was studying physics at Whitman College, the small liberal arts school in southeastern Washington where he was about to enter his junior year. He also studied Mandarin Chinese and dabbled in theater, and got into firefighting to help pay for school.

abstract: The Times asked readers how violence in Cairo has affected their lives as nearly two years of bombings have gradually changed the feel of the city.
lead_paragraph: For decades Cairo was considered safe for residents and visitors. Not anymore. Nearly two years of escalating bombings in and around Cairo are gradually changing the feel of the city. Neighbors are becoming more suspicious of strangers asking questions, and commuters are getting used to changing their routes to avoid police cordons after each bombing.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) DUMB AND DUMBER TO (2014) Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels reprise their roles as the dimwitted Providence pals Lloyd Christmas and Harry Dunne, who set out once again on a cross-country road trip in their tongue-wagging puppy-mobile — this time to find Harry’s biological daughter. Both Mr. Carrey and Mr. Daniels “have slowed down without cleaning up their act,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Peter and Bobby Farrelly, which was a critical flop but a box-office success. “To that end, as it were, this sequel is just, uh, packed, or perhaps smeared, with a whole lot of poop jokes. There are diaper gags, lots of them, mostly pretty funny, and a couple of peekaboo looks at a feline rear end.” But, she added, “the Farrellys are still not much interested in film as a visual medium, and when Lloyd and Harry aren’t smacking each other or dropping their pants, you might as well be listening to a radio play.”

Famously thrifty, Ms. Brown, the legendary editor of Cosmopolitan magazine, commuted there on the M10 bus well into her 80s.

headline: Why Donald Trump Won’t Fold: Polls and People Speak

lead_paragraph: It is one of the most famous numbers in sports. Ted Williams had a .406 batting average for the Boston Red Sox in 1941, which was the last time a batter reached the .400 mark for a full season. But technically it was not the last time Williams hit .400. It was not even the highest batting average of his career.

lead_paragraph: WAS Hurricane Katrina “the best thing that happened to the education system in New Orleans,” as Education Secretary Arne Duncan once said? Nearly 10 years after the disaster, this has become a dominant narrative among a number of school reformers and education scholars.

headline: How Changeable Is Gender?
keywords: ['Gender', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Hormones', 'Research']
abstract: Our identity has a neural basis and exists on a spectrum.
lead_paragraph: THANKS to Caitlyn Jenner, and the military’s changing policies, transgender people are gaining acceptance — and living in a bigger, more understanding spotlight than at any previous time.

headline: The Ghost House of My Childhood
keywords: ['Memory', 'Death and Dying', 'Families and Family Life', 'Senses and Sensation']
abstract: There was a cosmology of lives lived here, meals of fried chicken and mashed potatoes at the kitchen table.
lead_paragraph: THE distant earth bristles with tiny imitations of houses and roads as I slide through the air in the silver ghost, a miracle of science. Now that my second parent has passed away, all things seem strange. Am I awake or asleep? I am flying back to Memphis, the place of my childhood, to settle the last of my father’s affairs and to see one final time the house where we all lived.

headline: A Look Inside Amazon
abstract: Readers discuss the management style of Jeff Bezos, which many view as overly harsh and inhumane.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the demanding, competitive environment promoted by Jeff Bezos.

headline: Ospreys: The Birds of Summer
keywords: ['Ospreys (Birds)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Pesticides', 'DDT (Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Clean Water Act']
abstract: The futures of this spectacular species and our own are now thoroughly intertwined.
lead_paragraph: THE other morning, as I sat on the porch having my coffee, an osprey came plummeting down toward me out of a smoky, overcast sky, with a fish caught in his talons. He was screeching, “See, see, seeeee!” over and over. I suppose there must have been another osprey in the neighborhood. The males can be shameless at showing off their catch, but it’s mainly for other birds, not me.

headline: Taking My Parents to College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: I­ was the first in my family to leave for school, so everyone came along.
lead_paragraph: IT was a simple question, but we couldn’t find the answer in any of the paperwork the college had sent. How long was my family supposed to stay for orientation? This was 1999, so Google wasn’t really a verb yet, and we were a low-income family (according to my new school) without regular Internet access.

headline: Target Shooters Bring Mayhem to National Forests
keywords: ['Editorials', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Firearms', 'Land Use Policies', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Gun Control', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']

lead_paragraph: Recreational target shooters call it “trigger trash” — tons and tons of refrigerators, car parts, televisions, sofas, bowling pins and other unwanted junk that shooters haul onto pristine federal woodlands and shred with gunfire for sheer enjoyment.

headline: Donald Trump Struts in His Own Pageant
abstract: Donald Trump, the erstwhile buffoon, makes buffoons of his rivals.

abstract: The wealthy want to show, and sometimes show off, their commitment to the environment even as they build ever bigger mansions, jets and yachts.
lead_paragraph: In the new arms race of conspicuous environmentalism, the wealthy have been building “green” mansions, driving hybrid supercars and buying carbon offsets for their private jets. But now the eco-conscious rich have reached a new high-water mark: the hybrid megayacht.

headline: In a Data-Driven N.F.L., the Pings May Soon Outstrip the X’s and O’s

headline: What the Psychic Showed Me
abstract: Though I was a skeptic, visiting a medium made me feel closer to my long-dead friend.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When I was 21, I made two promises to my best friend, Julie, who was dying. They were youthful vows, born of deep love and deeper grief. The first was that I would name a child after her, if I ever became a mother. The second was that I would visit a psychic medium after she was gone and attempt to find out how she was.

headline: Migrants Rush Across Border in Macedonia
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Thousands of refugees managed to get past a cordon set up to prevent them from crossing into the country from Greece.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — Hours after several hundred migrants bypassed a line of baton-wielding police officers on Saturday to enter Macedonia from Greece, nearly all those remaining on the Greek side of the border were allowed in, according to video footage and human rights activists at the scene. By Saturday evening, only around 200 people were left behind a fenced area on the line that separates the two countries.

headline: Dinner and Deception
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Serving elaborate meals to the super-rich left me feeling empty.
lead_paragraph: IT’S 4:25 p.m. I make my way through the kitchen, past the prep cooks, up to the locker room on the second floor. Getting dressed takes 10 minutes. That leaves 20 to get “family meal” before the porters break everything down. At 4:55, I’m ready. Lineup is in five minutes — “live at five.” I double-check my uniform, an expensive-looking suit issued by the restaurant, before I join the rest of the wait staff downstairs.

keywords: ['Olympic Games', 'Diving (Sports Event)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Cereals']

lead_paragraph: When Julie Sondgerath learned from the premiere of the HBO documentary “Greg Louganis: Back on Board” this month that Louganis, the transcendent Olympic diver, had never been on the cover of a Wheaties cereal box, she started a petition drive on Change.org to demand that General Mills correct an omission that has lasted more than 30 years.

He competed for his only time and finished third, behind Miriam Raphael and Nancy Schuster. Everyone knows how great a constructor Merl was. Who knew he was such a good solver, too?

headline: Yankees Retire Jorge Posada’s No. 20, With a Nod to No. 15

lead_paragraph: It has been 36 years now, Diana Munson said on Saturday, so very long since her world changed forever and the Yankees lost their captain. She is grateful that fans still revere her husband, Thurman, part of a proud line of Yankees catchers with retired numbers and plaques in Monument Park.

headline: Speaker of Pakistan Assembly Is Removed in Election Dispute
abstract: Sardar Ayaz Sadiq was unseated after an election tribunal declared that his victory in 2013 was marred by irregularities.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — The speaker of the Pakistani National Assembly, Sardar Ayaz Sadiq, was unseated on Saturday after an election tribunal declared that his victory in the 2013 general election was marred by irregularities. The election tribunal ordered a new election in Mr. Sadiq’s district in the eastern city of Lahore.

lead_paragraph: Ieng Thirith, the sister-in-law and close collaborator of the genocidal Cambodian leader Pol Pot, died on Saturday in Pailin, Cambodia. She was 83.

headline: Ohio Bill Would Ban Abortion if Down Syndrome Is Reason

headline: One Year After War, People of Gaza Still Sit Among the Ruins

But these days, there are also clusters of construction workers on Shejaiya’s dirt paths, finally pouring a few cement foundations and hammering together wood planks.

headline: Year After Death, Business as Usual at Arizona Gun Range

lead_paragraph: WHITE HILLS, Ariz. — Antonio Nárdiz, a Spanish tourist from Bilbao, said he had chosen a family vacation to America for one specific reason: to fulfill his sons’ dreams of firing real machine guns. In Spain, he noted, 10-year-old Jon and 12-year-old Toni, like all other civilians, are forbidden to use automatic weapons.

headline: Mets’ Bats Give Traveling Fans Plenty to Cheer
abstract: Several hundred Mets fans gathered down the left-field line at Coors Field on Saturday night, chanting “Let’s go, Mets!” whenever the team scored, which was so often it became a chorus of the night.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — More than 1,600 miles from New York, several hundred Mets fans gathered down the left-field line at Coors Field on Saturday night, forming a block of orange. They waved flags and towels and banners, and they chanted, “Let’s go, Mets!” whenever the Mets scored, which was so often it became a chorus of the night.

headline: In New York, Testing Grounds for Community Policing
abstract: The 101st Precinct in Far Rockaway, a low-income neighborhood wary of the police, has seen halting progress as the department seeks to reshape everyday interactions between officers and residents.
lead_paragraph: Residents on the street rarely return the greetings of the precinct commander. Officers complain that their overtures are usually rebuffed, but they travel even short distances by car and drive down pedestrian paths in housing developments, cruising past staring faces. Many leave the Queens precinct for meals, some crossing into Nassau County for coffee at Starbucks.

headline: North Korea Moves Forces Amid Talks With South
abstract: As negotiators from both sides resumed talks in a border village on Sunday afternoon, Pyongyang was deploying more artillery toward the border, the South said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea had deployed twice as many artillery pieces as usual along the border with South Korea on Sunday, and most of its submarines had departed from their bases, as high-level talks between the two Koreas aimed at breaking a tense military standoff stretched into a third day on Monday.

headline: 1940: Vichy Curbs Aperitif Drinking In Law Against Drunkenness
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Vichy government in France limits drinking of aperitifs to four days a week in 1940.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Drastic measures to suppress alcoholism and drunkenness in France are embodied in a law which will be published in the ‘‘Journal Officiel’’ tomorrow [Aug. 24]. According to the terms of this law, consumption of aperitifs (drinks before meals) containing more than 16 per cent alcohol will henceforth be prohibited. Furthermore, drinking of aperitifs will be limited to four days a week, namely Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays. The sale of these drinks is also forbidden to minors under twenty years of age.

headline: After a Father’s Heart Attack, a Well-Meant Lie Backfires on the Playground
abstract: My husband had a heart attack in Singapore, and I got on a plane without telling our son.
lead_paragraph: When my pilot husband had a heart attack overseas, I lied to our 11-year-old son. At the time, I thought it was the right decision. I was wrong.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A night at the world championships that many had feared would become a cautionary tale for track and field turned into a tale of two stumbles instead.

headline: A Basketball Life, Shown From a High School Locker Room
abstract: Ed Schmidt, a playwright and performer known for staging productions inside his home, is using the former site of La Salle Academy in the East Village for his latest one-man show.
lead_paragraph: “The stage, such as it is” is a phrase that has appeared in connection with at least one of Ed Schmidt’s critically acclaimed shows. It might have stung someone who was less determined, because the theater was his apartment in Brooklyn. For one production, the stage, such as it was, was his kitchen and dining room. For the other, it was his living room.

headline: Much at Stake in Academy’s Hunt for a 2016 Oscars Producer
