headline: People Sought in Bangkok Bombing May Have Fled Country, Police Say
abstract: Thailand’s chief of police appeared to be trying to lower public expectations that the main person being sought in the explosion at a shrine would be caught anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s chief of police said Sunday that those responsible for the deadly attack on a Bangkok shrine last week “may have already fled” the country, apparently trying to lower public expectations that the main person being sought would be caught anytime soon.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (AMC) FEAR THE WALKING DEAD In this prequel to “The Walking Dead,” a blended family — a tough-love mom (Kim Dickens), a nice-guy stepdad (Cliff Curtis) and their rebellious daughter (Alycia Debnam-Carey) and heroin-addicted son (Frank Dillane) — find themselves outmaneuvering zombies after a flu epidemic in Los Angeles turns out to be so much more, above. But if “The Walking Dead” is one of television’s quietest shows, this one — with the sirens, helicopters, news reports and cellphones of a functioning society — raises the decibels to amp up the suspense. It feels like a crutch, and also “a sign that the show’s creators, who include Robert Kirkman, the impresario of the ‘Walking Dead’ graphic novel and TV franchise, aren’t nearly as sure of their footing this time around,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. And the domestic-drama tropes — teenage rebellion, the messiness of divorce, dealing with addiction — seem tired in this context, he added. “There’s a point being made about the dissolution of everyday society, but watching it being made is like eating your vegetables — you’d rather skip ahead to the flesh.”

headline: Myanmar Striking Rohingya From Voter Rolls, Activists Say
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya who cast votes in elections five years ago are being excluded from voting this November amid rising anti-Muslim sentiment.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — As an elected lawmaker and member of Myanmar’s governing party, U Shwe Maung attended dinners with the president and made speeches from the floor of Parliament. But this weekend, the country’s election commission ruled that despite more than four years in office, he was not a citizen and thus was ineligible to run for re-election in landmark voting in November.

headline: 1965: Bubble Gum Blows Into Art World
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Bubble-gum art appears on the New York art scene in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — For those who feel the Theater of the Absurd has had it, there’s a whole new world of absurdities coming up strong in the field of art. Bubble-gum art, for example. Only a few weeks ago, an elaborate announcement extolled its possibilities. Attached to the announcement — and wrapped in hygienic cellophane — were six gaily colored pellets of bubble-gum, not to be chewed and loudly popped, but to be chewed, gingerly removed from the mouth and stuck on a blank canvas.

headline: ‘Compton’ Spends Second Week at Top of Box Office
abstract: The film, about the rap group N.W.A., which counted Dr. Dre as a founding member, collected an estimated $26.8 million over the weekend, for a two-week total of $111.5 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box office data.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Despite growing dismay that “Straight Outta Compton” glosses over Dr. Dre’s history of physical abuse toward women, that Universal Pictures drama was again the No. 1 movie in North America, easily defeating three R-rated newcomers.

headline: Clashes Break Out During Protests Over Trash Crisis in Lebanon
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Thousands of protesters streamed into downtown Beirut for a second day on Sunday to demand that the government resign over its inability to remove enormous heaps of garbage.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of protesters streamed into downtown Beirut for a second day on Sunday to demand that the government resign over its inability to remove enormous heaps of garbage from the city’s streets. The demonstrations led to clashes with the police, who turned fire hoses and tear gas guns on the crowds.

headline: Review: Helen Phillips Tweaks Corporate Culture in ‘The Beautiful Bureaucrat’
abstract: A young woman snaps up a data-input position at a soulless behemoth of a company and then discovers something is awry.
lead_paragraph: Helen Phillips’s unusual and deeply interesting third book, “The Beautiful Bureaucrat,” looks at first to be a piercing little satire (it’s just 180 pages) about the horrors of contemporary corporate culture. After a spell of unemployment, a young woman named Josephine Newbury gratefully snaps up the first job she can find: an entry-level, data-input position at a soulless behemoth of a company named AZ (or is it ZA?) in a place that may or may not be Brooklyn.

headline: ISIS Blows Up Ancient Temple at Syria’s Palmyra Ruins
keywords: ['Assyrian Civilization', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Islamic State militants have detonated explosives around the Temple of Baalshamin, one of the most grand and well-preserved structures at the ancient ruins.
lead_paragraph: Militants from the Islamic State set off explosions at a temple in the ancient ruins of Palmyra in Syria, activists and government officials said on Sunday, continuing a pattern of destruction that they have visited upon historical sites across the territory they control there and in Iraq.

lead_paragraph: DENVER — Matt Harvey looked comfortable sitting near the top of the Mets’ dugout Sunday, wearing a sweatshirt, with sunglasses perched atop his hat, as he leaned over to get a closer look at Logan Verrett striking out Carlos Gonzalez swinging on a nasty slider.

That includes Spotify, the music-streaming service, and Klarna, a Swedish online payments company valued at more than $2 billion. He has also backed several American tech giants like Facebook and Airbnb, the vacation-rental site.

Ms. Haneda regularly trims its shrubs and clips its narrow strip of grass, maintaining its perfect view of the sea.

lead_paragraph: Doudou N’diaye Rose, a master drummer and bandleader from Senegal who became an emissary of his native culture’s joyous and complex rhythms to the rest of the world, touring with percussion orchestras in Europe, Asia and the United States, died on Wednesday in Dakar, Senegal. He was 85.

lead_paragraph: It was not all that surprising that a march of a few dozen topless women (and fewer men) through Midtown Manhattan on a sunny Sunday afternoon would attract perhaps thousands of gawkers, bemused tourists, leering loafers, journalists and passers-by — every single one, it seemed, carrying a camera.

headline: Rhode Island Church Taking Unusual Step to Illuminate Its Slavery Role
abstract: The Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island is establishing a slavery museum and reconciliation center in an old cathedral as part of an effort to acknowledge its own complicity in the slave trade.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — One of the darkest chapters of Rhode Island history involved the state’s pre-eminence in the slave trade, beginning in the 1700s. More than half of the slaving voyages from the United States left from ports in Providence, Newport and Bristol — so many, and so contrary to the popular image of slavery as primarily a scourge of the South, that Rhode Island has been called “the Deep North.”

headline: Data on Home Prices and the F.D.A.’s Decision on a Cholesterol-Lowering Drug
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Consumer Price Index', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cholesterol']
abstract: This week, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve Repatha; several key pieces of housing data will be released; and Mylan shareholders may advance a takeover bid.
lead_paragraph: Several important data points on the United States housing market will be released this week. On Tuesday, a Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller index is likely to show that home prices in 20 cities rose over the year ending in June. Demand for homes is building, pushing up prices. Also on Tuesday, a report from the Commerce Department will probably show that purchases of new homes increased in July after a surprise decrease in June. More good news is expected from the National Association of Realtors on Thursday as the group reports pending sales of existing homes for July. Sales were unexpectedly down in June, but may well have bounced back. —Dionne Searcey

headline: Ryan Hunter-Reay Wins at Pocono
abstract: Hunter-Reay won the crash-filled IndyCar race which left Justin Wilson in a coma and critical condition when he was hit in the head by a piece of debris.
lead_paragraph: Before the Belgian Grand Prix in Spa-Francorchamps on Sunday, expectations of chaos were high because of a new rule designed to liven up the track action by giving full technical responsibility over clutch settings to the drivers at the start of the race, instead of having them take precise instructions from their team engineers over the radio. But the start went off practically without a hitch, and the explosive action came in the penultimate lap of the race, when the right rear tire of Sebastian Vettel’s Ferrari blew out while he was in third place. That handed Romain Grosjean and his Lotus team their first podium finish since the 2013 United States Grand Prix.

headline: Forest Whitaker Will Make Broadway Debut
abstract: Mr. Whitaker, the Academy Award winning film star, will make his Broadway debut next spring in a revival of “Hughie,” a short play by Eugene O’Neill.
lead_paragraph: Forest Whitaker, the Academy Award winning film star, will make his Broadway debut next spring in a revival of “Hughie,” a short play by Eugene O’Neill. Mr. Whitaker, who won an Oscar for playing Idi Amin in “The Last King of Scotland,” will play Erie Smith, a hustler who confides in a hotel night clerk. The play, set in Manhattan in 1928, was written in the 1940s but was not staged on Broadway until 1964, when Jason Robards played Erie Smith; a 1975 revival starred Ben Gazzara and a 1996 revival starred Al Pacino. This new revival will be directed by Michael Grandage, the former artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse in London, who won a 2010 Tony Award for his direction of “Red.” The “Hughie” revival will be produced by Darren Bagert along with the Michael Grandage Company and the Shubert Organization. The producers did not announce a date or theater for the opening, but said it would be next spring at a Shubert theater and would have a limited run.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Cinemax) MAPS TO THE STARS (2015) Havana Segrand (Julianne Moore, above), an actress on the verge of unraveling at any moment, has seen the apparition of her mother — a more famous actress, who died in a fire when she was young — and seeks therapy from a self-help guru (John Cusack). He happens to be the father of Benjie Weiss (Evan Bird), an obnoxious young star, and his older sister, Agatha (Mia Wasikowska), who was banished from the family after setting a fire that may have been intended to kill her brother, and which badly burned her. Eventually Agatha befriends a limo driver (Robert Pattinson) and turns an Internet acquaintanceship with Carrie Fisher into a job as Havana’s personal assistant. “Suavely directed by David Cronenberg from an elegantly waspish script by Bruce Wagner, it belongs to the venerable tradition of movieland self-loathing,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It takes a perverse effort of will to love ‘Maps to the Stars.’ It’s a little too chilly, and in some places too easy. But you may find yourself drawn back to it, and retracing its route from the familiar to the uncanny, from entertainment to revulsion, from dream to nightmare.”

headline: A Russian Soldier Story
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Men and Boys', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Photography', 'Youth']
abstract: As the tensions between Russian and Ukraine have continued, Pavel Volkov has explored the lives of young Russian conscripts with mixed reactions to the conflict.
lead_paragraph: After the Ukrainian revolution and Russia’s annexation of Crimea, Pavel Volkov wondered how young Russian Army conscripts felt about becoming part of the turmoil they — and the rest of the world — saw play out on television and in newspapers. Mr. Volkov traveled for eight months around military bases in Russia, taking photographs and asking questions. The resulting body of work is a portrait of Russian youth with mixed feelings.

headline: Clashing Views on E-Cigarettes
abstract: British and American studies disagree on the dangers of users going on to other smoking products.
lead_paragraph: A British government agency has issued a bullish assessment of the value of electronic cigarettes in helping people to quit smoking. It found that e-cigarettes can reduce the health risks of smoking by 95 percent because they deliver nicotine to satisfy an addiction, but far fewer harmful chemicals than regular cigarettes. It also found little evidence that large numbers of consumers who had never smoked were taking up e-cigarettes. That seemed to challenge the notion that e-cigarettes would be a gateway to more dangerous products.

IBM plans to ship home breast milk pumped on a work trip. Facebook and Apple will reimburse the costs for employees who want to freeze their eggs. headline: ‘Speak,’ by Louisa Hall
abstract: A poet’s novel is a meditation on robots, artificial intelligence, fairy tales and the human spirit.
lead_paragraph: A less artful title for “Speak,” Louisa Hall’s sidereal novel on artificial (and thus human) intelligence, might be “What We Talk About When We Talk About Computers.” This starfish of a book, five voices waving gracefully around a core of philosophical questions, wants to explore the nature of memory; the borders of personhood; how words can illumine and obscure and hoodwink and rescue.

headline: ‘The Incarnations,’ by Susan Barker
abstract: A hard-luck Beijing driver comes across a series of letters describing his past lives.
lead_paragraph: Traveling in China back in the early 1990s, I was waiting for my westbound train to take on water at a lonely halt in the Taklamakan Desert when a young Chinese woman tapped me on the shoulder, asked if I spoke English and, further, if I knew anything of Anthony Trollope. I was quite taken aback. Trollope here? A million miles from anywhere? I mumbled an incredulous, “Yes, I know a bit” — whereupon, in a brisk and businesslike manner, she declared that the train would remain at the oasis for the next, let me see, 27 minutes, and in that time would I kindly answer as many of her questions as possible about plot and character development in “The Eustace Diamonds”?

headline: Americans and Briton Receive Top French Honor for Stopping Train Gunman
abstract: President François Hollande awarded the Legion of Honor to four men for their role in subduing a gunman on a high-speed train.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France on Monday awarded the Legion of Honor, France’s highest award, to three Americans and a Briton for their role in stopping a gunman on a high-speed train traveling to Paris from Amsterdam on Friday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Global Markets Continue to Plunge
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'CHINA', 'Currency', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mortgages', 'Private Equity', 'RUSSIA', 'Shenzhen Stock Exchange', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'turkey', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Admission to the ‘Unicorn’ Club | The Rewards of Lending Boldly
lead_paragraph: GLOBAL MARKETS CONTINUE TO PLUNGE | Stocks continued last week’s slide, led by a rout in Asia, David Jolly and Neil Gough report in DealBook. Shanghai’s stock market closed down 8.5 percent, erasing its gains so far this year.

headline: Today in Politics: A New Character Joins a Rapidly Expanding Storyline
abstract: Donald J. Trump continues to drive the discussion on the trail and on the Sunday talk shows. But, as the August lull winds down, the intentions of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. are creating political intrigue.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning, as President Obama‘s vacation comes to an end and as Donald J. Trump continues to drive the discussion on the trail and on the Sunday talk shows. But, as the August lull winds down, another political intrigue, filled with whispers, speculation and a seemingly significant private meeting, deepens.

headline: No, You Do Not Have to Drink 8 Glasses of Water a Day
abstract: There is no science behind a formal, one-size-fits-all requirement of daily water consumption.
lead_paragraph: If there is one health myth that will not die, it is this: You should drink eight glasses of water a day.

headline: The Sidewalk Shed, a Ubiquitous New York Eyesore, Gets a Makeover
abstract: A High Line project and a design competition look to beautify part of the nearly 200 miles of scaffolding covering city sidewalks.
lead_paragraph: Zaha Hadid has designed some of the most remarkable buildings of this generation. Whether a striking factory for BMW, daring Olympic venues or museums in Rome, Glasgow and Cincinnati, the work of the Iraqi-born, London-based Ms. Hadid has brought her global renown and a Pritzker Prize, considered architecture’s Nobel Prize.

headline: Train Heroes Honored in France
abstract: Three Americans and a Briton received the Legion of Honor for disarming an attacker aboard a high-speed train headed to France.
lead_paragraph: Three Americans and a Briton received the Legion of Honor for disarming an attacker aboard a high-speed train headed to France.

headline: Rate Hike Fever
abstract: Punch bowl delusions.
lead_paragraph: Larry Summers argues that a Fed rate hike would be a big mistake; I completely agree. Yet he also suggests that the Fed “seems set” to do this foolish thing. Why?

headline: Lawyer for Huma Abedin, a Hillary Clinton Aide, Strikes Back at Accuser
abstract: Huma Abedin’s lawyer says Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, has unfairly tarnished her reputation by making “unfounded allegations” about her tenure as a State Department aide.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Huma Abedin, a top adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton, has accused Charles E. Grassley, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, of damaging Ms. Abedin’s reputation through “unfounded allegations” about her time at the State Department.

headline: Black Markets in China Still Driving World’s Tiniest Porpoise to Extinction
keywords: ['Black Markets', 'Dolphins and Porpoises', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Smuggling']
abstract: Chinese demand for swim bladders from a rare Mexican fish is still propelling the world’s smallest cetacean toward extinction.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sobering update on efforts in Mexico, Hong Kong and mainland China to stave off the extinction of the vaquita, a critically endangered porpoise inhabiting Mexican waters at the north end of the Gulf of California that is the world’s smallest, and rarest, cetacean.

headline: U.S. Marine Testifies in Killing of Transgender Woman in Philippines
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In his first public account, Lance Cpl. Joseph Scott Pemberton said that he choked a transgender woman but didn’t say he killed her, the prosecutor in the case said.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A United States Marine accused of killing a transgender woman in the Philippines acknowledged on Monday that he had choked her until she was no longer moving, but he stopped short of saying that he had killed her, according to the prosecutor assigned to the case.

headline: If You Want to Be a Famous Fashion Designer, Here Are the Best Colleges
abstract: Central St. Martins is, of course, on the list, but so are some other schools you wouldn’t expect.
lead_paragraph: It had to happen sooner or later. There’s a ranking for everything these days, after all, and August is a pretty slow news month (At least in fashion terms, hence the desire to create interest with idle speculation such as the “Is Phoebe Philo leaving Céline?” rumors. O.M.G.! O.M.G.! The brand, not surprisingly, says no).

headline: Israeli Villages Near Gaza Rebound Warily Year After the War
abstract: As new families move in and development plans are made, residents of kibbutzim near the border live with apprehension about the possibility of another conflict.
lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ SUFA, Israel — Looking out across the perimeter fence of this small rural community in southern Israel, along the border with Gaza, Eyal Shalev, 23, sees a battlefield.

headline: 1890: Cholera Epidemic Hits Spain
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A cholera epidemic hit Spain in 1890.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Reports received to-day from the cholera-infected districts show a heavy increase of the epidemic in Toledo, where there are fifty-one new cases in the city and twenty-seven in the suburbs and in Valencia. In the other provinces the epidemic is stationary. The official record for the 22nd was seventy-one new cases and fifty-one deaths and for the 23rd it was 139 new cases and sixty-six deaths. The total figures for the whole of Spain since the commencement of the epidemic are: Number of cases 2,393, number of deaths 1,203. The fumigation to which travelers arriving at Seville are subjected is so severe that many have been made seriously ill. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1890

headline: Selfies in Voting Booths Raise Legal Questions on Speech and Secrecy
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Privacy', 'Elections', 'Social Media', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Photography']
abstract: A federal ruling against a New Hampshire ban on the display of marked ballots — “ballot selfies” taken in a voting booth — has fueled a debate about whether they are a protected form of speech.
lead_paragraph: People post selfies with their strawberry daiquiris and their calico kittens, with strangers and friends, with and without clothes. So it was inevitable, perhaps, that some might take photographs inside the voting booth to show off their completed ballots.

abstract: We’re looking for up to 10 students to participate in this experimental first fall semester — but, if it works the way we hope it will, we’ll open up applications to other students in the spring.

lead_paragraph: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea insisted on Monday that North Korea apologize for planting land mines. Otherwise, she vowed, anti-Pyongyang propaganda broadcasts will continue.

headline: 36 Hours in Nashville: The Food Scene

lead_paragraph: “36 Hours,” a television program inspired by The Times’s 36 Hours column, airs Mondays at 8 p.m. Eastern on Travel Channel. The second episode, “Rockin’ Nashville,” dovetails with our column from last September.

abstract: Veterinarians on Sunday examined a cub born on Saturday to Mei Xiang, a giant panda at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Veterinarians on Sunday examined a cub born on Saturday to Mei Xiang, a giant panda at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo in Washington.

headline: As Stock Market Plunges, Donald Trump Takes a Worldview
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Donald J. Trump, who has made most of his money in real estate rather than investing, said that such market volatility was another sign that the fortunes of the United States are too closely tied to the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: Plunging stocks have rattled investors on Monday, but Donald J. Trump sees them as one more reason he is needed in the Oval Office.

headline: ‘I Am Cait’ Episode 5 Recap: We v. Them
abstract: The producers of this show sure do keep you guessing.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 5: “Take Pride”

headline: Stephen Colbert Announces Guest Lineup for First Week of ‘Late Show’
abstract: Kendrick Lamar, Amy Schumer and Scarlett Johansson will be some of Mr. Colbert’s first guests.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of how its new host’s eclectic tastes are already having an effect at CBS’s “The Late Show,” Stephen Colbert has unveiled the roster for his first week’s worth of guests and the list not only includes film, TV and music stars, but notable figures from the worlds of politics, business and literature.

headline: College Football Preseason No. 1s Have Gone 10 Years Without a Title
abstract: Ohio State is the Associated Press poll’s first unanimous preseason No. 1, but no preseason favorite since U.S.C. in 2004 has finished in the top spot.
lead_paragraph: Ohio State is the defending national college football champion. The Buckeyes return 15 starters and have such depth at quarterback that the player expected to lead the team last season has been converted to a receiver.

headline: A Reluctant Teenager, a Barbershop Quartet and a Revelation
abstract: A critic recalls the ultimate arts-consumer experience: Going into a performance expecting nothing, coming out transformed.
lead_paragraph: The memory is hazy, but I can’t imagine that I went enthusiastically into a concert hall in Portland, Maine, on May 18, 1974. The groups on the bill were not the kind that most 19-year-olds were flocking to see. Yet my mind was blown just as thoroughly as if I’d seen Kiss or Queen. It was blown by a barbershop quartet named the Gentlemen’s Agreement.

headline: Obama Flies to the Nevada Desert to Promote Solar Energy
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: While promoting the benefits of all renewable energy, including wind power, the president focused largely on solar energy, part of an increasingly intense effort to counter global warming.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — President Obama flew west into the blistering sun of this desert oasis on Monday not so much to issue a dour warning about the dangers of climate change — moralizing does not become this freewheeling city — but to speak with great hope about solar and other renewable forms of energy.

headline: Italian Neighbors Build a Social Network, First Online, Then Off
abstract: An idea that began with a Facebook page started by two people looking to make friends has expanded beyond the narrow confines of Via Fondazza in Bologna.
lead_paragraph: BOLOGNA, Italy — When Laurell Boyers, 34, and her husband, Federico Bastiani, 37, moved in together in Bologna in 2012, they did not know any of their neighbors. It was a lonely feeling.

headline: Daily Report: Potential Unicorns, Meet a Rough Market
abstract: Already, there are grumblings that the downturn in the stock market could alter the booming tech industry.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets around the world plunged last week, capped off on Friday when some benchmark indexes had their biggest losses in years, partly from turmoil in China. Tech stocks did not escape the fall, with some companies being hit particularly hard, including Netflix, which tumbled more than 16 percent over the course of the week. Twitter, which has been on a slide for a few weeks, ended the week below its I.P.O. price. The selloff in global markets continued on Monday.

headline: Turkey Announces Anti-ISIS Operation
abstract: Turkey’s foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, speaks on a new agreement with the United States to flush Islamic State fighters out of northern Syria.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, speaks on a new agreement with the United States to flush Islamic State fighters out of northern Syria.

headline: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: An End-of-Summer Reading List
abstract: Any month includes new work by Shirley Jackson and Laura Ingalls Wilder is a good month.
lead_paragraph: August was (and is) a great month for books.

headline: Jordy Nelson Injury May Not Ruin Packers’ Season
abstract: Nelson, who made the Pro Bowl after a 98-catch season, sustained a serious knee injury in Sunday’s preseason game and will miss the rest of the season.
lead_paragraph: When N.F.L. fans watch their favorite team play its exhibition games, they seldom care too much about winning and losing. Instead, they hope to see veterans look sharp and rookies look promising. But most of all, they hope the key players come out unscathed.

lead_paragraph: The lawyer for Huma Abedin, a longtime confidante of Hillary Rodham Clinton, wrote a letter to the State Department disputing concerns that Senator Charles E. Grassley raised about a possible conflict of interest involving her.

headline: The Inexorable Forces of Nail Growth
abstract: It’s like the movement of a tectonic plate at the end of your finger, or toe.

headline: At WWE’s ‘SummerSlam,’ Jon Stewart’s Chair-Throwing Incites Fans
abstract: Stewart, who retired from “The Daily Show,” delivered some drama in another arena during a key match.
lead_paragraph: Hard on the heels of his retirement from “The Daily Show,” Jon Stewart hosted World Wrestling Entertainment’s 28th annual SummerSlam on Sunday, and divided wrestling fans by influencing the outcome of a key match.

headline: NASA’s Cassini Takes a Last Look at Saturn’s Moon Dione
abstract: The spacecraft, in orbit around Saturn since 2004, has two more years of work before it runs out of fuel. Last week it made its final flyby of Dione.
lead_paragraph: The spacecraft, in orbit around Saturn since 2004, has two more years of work before it runs out of fuel. Last week it made its final flyby of Dione.

headline: Why the Stock Market Is So Turbulent
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: Last week, global financial markets were churning, but it really only mattered if you were an oil trader, a Chinese bureaucrat or a hedge fund manager.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Donald Trump on Black Lives Matter
abstract: Mr. Trump compared Martin O’Malley to a “disgusting little weak pathetic baby” for his apology to Black Lives Matter demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: Asked about the Black Lives Matter movement during a Fox News appearance, Donald Trump responded, “I know nothing about it.” However, he did have some thoughts about Martin O’Malley’s apology for his response to Black Lives Matter demonstrators. “He apologized,” Mr. Trump said, “like a little baby, like a disgusting little weak pathetic baby, and that’s the problem with our country.”

headline: Apple Stock Reacts After Tim Cook Email Praises China Sales
abstract: The chief executive of Apple said business was booming in China, where the company has long laid the groundwork to reap big sales.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last week, Jim Cramer, the boisterous host of CNBC’s “Mad Money,” had a company called Skyworks Solutions on his show. The company, a chip supplier for Apple, said its sales were strong in China, but its stock plummeted afterward anyway, following the global markets into the red.

headline: Ellie Baker and the Seamstress’s Conundrum
abstract: Can you unravel this three-dimensional puzzle by the artist and computer scientist, Ellie Baker?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Ellie Baker, a freelance computer scientist and artist who beautifully combines the disciplines of sculpture and mathematics to bring us a counter-intuitive 3D challenge. Let’s try our hands at —

headline: 1915: Britain Shells Belgian Coast
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A British squadron attacked the Belgian coast in 1915.
lead_paragraph: ROTTERDAM — This morning a British squadron of considerable strength carried out a great bombardment of the German positions on the Belgian coast. The attack was the most important in the number of ships engaged and the fierceness of the fire since the enemy’s occupation of the littoral. It is reported that great damage was done, principally to the military works at Zeebrugge. The thunder of the fleet’s guns was heard all over Zeeland, where the windows of houses at places miles inland rattled. The sound carried distinctly to Flushing. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1915

headline: Hot Tech Start-Ups May Face a Long and Bumpy Fall
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital', 'Start-ups', 'United States Economy', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The worldwide market gyrations will filter down to Silicon Valley, with start-ups that need cash likely to be the first to undergo tougher scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As stock markets have tumbled, public company shareholders were not the only ones wondering what would become of their portfolios. Venture capitalists also began fretting about whether the plunge — which resulted last week in the worst week for American stocks since 2011 and a renewed sell-off on Monday — would cool the heady market for shares of private companies, especially in Silicon Valley.

headline: Divorcing a Narcissist
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Narcissism']
abstract: Being married to a narcissist can be tough. But it’s even tougher if you try to divorce a narcissist, which is the topic of the latest Well Book Club.
lead_paragraph: Is there a narcissist in your life?

headline: Travel Diary: Tokyo
abstract: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden’s travels in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden’s travels in Tokyo.

headline: How Do You Talk to a 3-Year-Old About a Divorce You Don’t Want?
abstract: When one parent is planning to leave a marriage, how can both spouses prepare a preschooler for the change?
lead_paragraph: In our occasional parenting Quandaries, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice. Today’s question comes from a commenter many will recognize as a long-time member of the community—Ramona, from Toronto. If you have advice, and particularly if you’ve been where she is and come through it, please help.

headline: Two Panda Cubs at the National Zoo Present Special Problems
abstract: Raising healthy twins is a unique problem for the zoo’s mother panda: Only two mother bears have successfully done so in captivity.
lead_paragraph: Two tiny giant panda cubs, each weighing about as much as a stick of butter, are the focus at the National Zoo in Washington of an intense, round-the-clock effort to keep them alive, but the odds are against them.

headline: Small Food Brands, Big Successes
abstract: New food companies are giving the established names a run for the money as consumers seek out novel products and better ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows someone who has dreamed of starting a food business. That next-door neighbor who thinks his chocolate chip cookies are better than Tate’s Bake Shop’s. The niece whose friends beg for her homemade hot sauce and who wonders how it would stack up against Trappey’s or Texas Pete.

headline: Inside the Maple Syrup Beat: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Reporter Ian Austen provides insight into his reporting on Canadian maple syrup and the disquiet in that country’s sugar camps.
lead_paragraph: While reporting from the Tour de France in July, I encountered a rare reminder of Canada one morning. In the hotel’s breakfast room there was a bottle of Maple Joe Absolutely Pure Maple Syrup. Just as prominent on the label was the English phrase “Produce of Canada” and, presumably to drive home that point, a drawing of broad-shouldered Joe, who has an improbable beard and wears a plaid shirt and red hunter’s cap. It was a vivid reminder of the article I wrote about Quebec maple syrup, a barrel of which is worth more today than a barrel of crude oil.

headline: Videos: How ISIS Recruits Around the World
abstract: In this series of videos, The New York Times reports on young people in the Middle East, Europe and the United States who have been lured by the group, also known as ISIS or ISIL.
lead_paragraph: In this series of videos, The New York Times reports on young people in the Middle East, Europe and the United States who have been lured by the group, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

headline: Racially Disparate Views of New Orleans’s Recovery After Hurricane Katrina
abstract: A survey found a stark divide among black and white residents over the local economy, the state of schools and the quality of life 10 years after Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — As the 10th anniversary approaches of Hurricane Katrina and the catastrophic levee breaches in New Orleans, a new survey finds a stark racial divide in how residents here view the recovery.

headline: As Turkey Targets Militants, War Grips Kurdish Lands Once Again
abstract: A war that had long been stilled by a truce is now threatening to undo an economic turnaround and adding a battlefield to a region already consumed by chaos.
lead_paragraph: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey — Across the Kurdish lands of southeast Turkey, a bitter war that had long been stilled by a truce has suddenly come roaring back, threatening to undo a hard-won economic turnaround here and adding a new battlefield to a region already consumed by chaos.

headline: Avoid Worrying About a Future That May Never Happen
abstract: Concentrating on the present can help goals become reality, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: I love spending time in the mountains. So a few weeks ago, I jumped at the opportunity to join a friend, my son and seven of his friends on a trip into the Uinta Mountains. This range sits about an hour east of our home in Park City, Utah.

headline: Palestinian Authority Is Ordered to Post $10 Million Bond in Terror Case
abstract: A judge also ruled that the group must pay an additional $1 million monthly to appeal a huge damages award for its role in six terrorist attacks in Israel that killed and injured Americans.
lead_paragraph: In a widely watched terrorism lawsuit that drew the attention of the Obama administration, a federal judge in Manhattan ruled on Monday that the Palestinian Authority would have to post $10 million and an additional $1 million monthly to appeal a huge damages award for its role in six terrorist attacks in Israel that had killed and injured Americans.

headline: Luke Bryan Stays at No. 1, and N.W.A. Enters Top 5
abstract: What’s happening lower on the chart may be more notable this week, as Dr. Dre’s “Compton” sits at No. 3.
lead_paragraph: The country singer Luke Bryan’s grown-up new album, “Kill the Lights,” notched a second straight week at No. 1 — the first country album to do so in two years, according to Billboard. But what’s happening lower on the chart may be more notable.

abstract: The ruins of the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra are shown in a video from March 2014, before the Islamic State took control.
lead_paragraph: The ruins of the ancient Syrian city of Palmyra are shown in a video from March 2014, before the Islamic State took control.

headline: A New Way to Charge Insider Trading
abstract: The Justice Department pursued a different track in a recent case, arguing that it didn’t have to prove that a benefit flowed from a recipient to a tipper.
lead_paragraph: An acquittal in an insider trading case is no longer much of a “man bites dog” story, even when the United States attorney hailed the indictment, proclaiming that “sooner or later, you will be brought to justice.” But the jury verdict last week in Atlanta in favor Steven E. Slawson, co-founder of the hedge fund Titan Capital Management, may be much more important for signaling a new way of charging those who receive tips that may avoid requirements thought necessary to prove insider trading.

abstract: Remembering “Hawaii’s best-known citizen” on his 125th birthday. Here’s his New York Times obituary from Jan. 23, 1968.
lead_paragraph: If you’re one of the billion or so people who use Google.com, you no doubt spotted the tribute to Duke Kahanamoku on what would have been his 125th birthday.

headline: Square Root of Kids’ Math Anxiety: Their Parents’ Help
abstract: So-called math-anxious parents who provided frequent help on homework actually hurt their children by passing on their anxiety, a study found.
lead_paragraph: A common impairment with lifelong consequences turns out to be highly contagious between parent and child, a new study shows.

abstract: The furniture designers and artists live and work in a former light bulb factory.

headline: Review: ‘Purity,’ Jonathan Franzen’s Most Intimate Novel Yet
abstract: This is Mr. Franzen’s most fleet-footed, least self-conscious and most intimate novel yet.
lead_paragraph: In a very funny passage in his dynamic new novel, Jonathan Franzen draws a very funny portrait of a writer struggling to write a novel “that would secure him his place in the modern American canon.” “Once upon a time,” this writer named Charles thinks, “it had sufficed to write ‘The Sound and the Fury’ or ‘The Sun Also Rises.’ But now bigness was essential. Thickness, length.”

headline: Do You Have Math Anxiety?
abstract: You may not like taking a quiz to measure your math anxiety. But don’t worry. There are no right answers, and you don’t have to show your work.
lead_paragraph: You may not like taking a quiz to measure your math anxiety. But don’t worry. There are no right answers, and you don’t have to show your work.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: Nearly all of the world’s top soccer leagues are up and running, providing many watching opportunities on television this week.
lead_paragraph: Yes, the summer’s almost over. The upside? Nearly all of the world’s top soccer leagues are now up and running. The downside? There’s an unwatchable number of hours of soccer to watch every week. This week’s highlights:

headline: Man Charged in Pellet Shooting of Officer Outside Gracie Mansion
abstract: Michael Verbitsky, 19, was charged with second-degree assault and several misdemeanors, including reckless endangerment, criminal possession of a weapon and two counts of criminal mischief.
lead_paragraph: The pop of an air gun came from above as two members of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s security detail stepped from an unmarked Ford Interceptor sedan outside Gracie Mansion at about 7:15 on Sunday evening. A pellet struck one in the back, causing a minor injury.

headline: A Childhood Obsession Leads to a Cereal Bar at Kith
abstract: Enjoy cereal while shopping for sneakers and clothing at Kith in Brooklyn; Kee’s Chocolates offers flavored milk; a wine store encourages sampling; and more.
lead_paragraph: New York has its first dedicated cereal bar. A small white-tiled alcove just inside the renovated Kith clothing and sneaker store in Brooklyn has 24 brand-name cold cereal varieties, with toppings. The cereals come packaged in single-serving Mylar bags that fit into small shoe boxes, from which the cereal can be eaten. The boxes are designed by sports figures — Andre Agassi has done the first one. There is no salad-bar-style display because the owner Ronnie Fieg does not like food out in the open. Milk, coffee and cereal-flavored soft-serve are also sold. Mr. Fieg says he has been obsessed with cereals since he was a teenager, mainly because he was not allowed to have sweet ones. Before the store opens, there is an express window to the street for cereal: Cereals from $6 with milk, ice cream from $5.50, Kith Treats, 233 Flatbush Avenue (Bergen Street), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 347-889-6114, kithnyc.com.

headline: ‘My Generation Will Never See One Dollar From Social Security’
abstract: “I know that the program will not exist for me,” wrote a reader in response to Paul Krugman’s recent column.
lead_paragraph: The sense of doom expressed in one younger reader’s comment about the Social Security system opened an intergenerational conversation about the program’s actuarial predicament.

headline: Migrants Race North as Hungary Builds a Border Fence
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Border Barriers', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: On a chaotic path through the Balkans, tens of thousands of migrants are pushing to reach northern Serbia before Hungary seals the border.
lead_paragraph: TISZASZIGET, Hungary — Roiling everything in its path, a wave of tens of thousands of migrants and refugees — many fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan — has worked its way up the length of the Balkans in recent days.

headline: In Watts, Turning an Old Light Bulb Factory Into a Home
abstract: The designers Andrew Paulson and Sean Dougall live and work in a renovated space filled with art, objects and looms.
lead_paragraph: “We’re making the sprawl work to our favor,” says Andrew Paulson, a self-taught weaver and one half of the Los Angeles-based design duo Dougall Paulson. Paulson and his partner in life and work, the ceramist Sean Dougall, live in Watts, a neighborhood that’s recently begun to show signs of a renaissance 50 years after the 1965 riots, thanks to chefs like Roy Choi and Daniel Patterson, who are opening a new restaurant there later this year, and Frank Gehry, who is set to collaborate on a local community center for the Children’s Institute Inc. “People ask us, ‘Is that the new neighborhood?’” says Dougall, noting the 75 blocks that separate Watts from downtown’s flourishing arts district. “We’re not feeding off of an existing art scene. We’re trying to build our own visual language, on an island.”

headline: Water Parks Add High-Tech Thrills
abstract: Water parks are getting a techno­logical upgrade, with new rides, some of them simulating surfing, from Great Wolf Lodge, Wet ’n Wild and others.
lead_paragraph: Water parks are getting a technological upgrade. Great Wolf Lodge in the Poconos and the Wet ’n Wild park in Las Vegas have both introduced a ride called Slideboarding, which its inventors describe as “Guitar Hero inside a water slide.”

headline: New Cinema Planned for Lower East Side
abstract: The two-theater Metrograph is to open early next year and run independent, international and repertory films.
lead_paragraph: A new two-screen arthouse cinema, capable of playing 35 millimeter and digital films, is set to open on the Lower East Side of Manhattan early next year, flying in the face of doomsday reports that independent theaters are in steep decline.

headline: How Emotion Hurts Stock Returns
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: People feel losses more sharply than gains. So watch ESPN or do anything to avoid looking at your sinking portfolio.
lead_paragraph: As investors watched global stock markets tumble, the behavioral economist Richard Thaler, who is also an occasional contributor to The New York Times, offered the following advice: “Inhale, exhale. Repeat. Then watch ESPN.”

headline: Details Released in Ashley Madison Hack
abstract: A spokesman for the Toronto Police Service said that the company behind the website Ashley Madison was offering a reward for information leading to the arrest of the site’s hackers.
lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the Toronto Police Service said that the company behind the website Ashley Madison was offering a reward for information leading to the arrest of the site’s hackers.

headline: Mutation Reduces Pregnancy Complications for Africa’s Khoe-San People
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The gene variant can alter the formation of the placenta, resulting in larger, healthier babies, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: The Khoe-San people of southern Africa carry a genetic mutation that reduces pregnancy complications, according to a study in the journal PLOS Genetics. The gene variant can alter the formation of the placenta during the early stages of pregnancy, resulting in larger, healthier babies and reducing the likelihood of pre-eclampsia, a disorder that can be fatal. The click-speaking Khoe-San are thought to have broken off from other African groups 100,000 years ago and, like other sub-Saharan populations, have high genetic diversity.

headline: Jet Lag ‘Cures’ Aplenty, but None That Work for All
abstract: Although science is closer to understanding the basic mechanisms that make many travelers feel so awful when crossing time zones, there is no one-size-fits-all cure.
lead_paragraph: Rita Gunther McGrath, a Columbia Business School professor, is one of those business travelers who do not care about delays, cancellations or navigating a new location. What does concern her is the seeming inability to conquer jet lag, and the accompanying symptoms that leave her groggy, unfocused and feeling, she says, “like a dishrag.”

headline: A Stock Slide That Started in Asia
abstract: Monday’s wild ride in the markets began in Asia, where indexes opened lower and continued slipping through the day. Shanghai’s composite index closed 8.5 percent lower, erasing all of the gains it had made this year.
lead_paragraph: Monday’s wild ride in the markets began in Asia, where indexes opened lower and continued slipping through the day. Shanghai’s composite index closed 8.5 percent lower, erasing all of the gains it had made this year.

headline: Louisiana State Trooper Is Killed in Shooting at a Traffic Stop
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: A suspect was held in the death of Senior Trooper Steven J. Vincent, who was shot in the head after he stopped to investigate a pickup truck in a ditch.
lead_paragraph: A Louisiana state trooper died on Monday after being shot in the head a day earlier during a traffic stop, and the authorities said the man charged in the shooting was being investigated in connection with another fatality.

headline: Bigger Hospital Rooms for Bigger Patients
abstract: Parkland Hospital in Dallas was built to accommodate the growing number of obese patients that hospitals across the country increasingly care for.
lead_paragraph: When the revamped Parkland Hospital in Dallas opened recently, each of the 862 single-patient rooms in the sprawling new 17-story tower was ready to accommodate the growing number of obese patients that hospitals across the country increasingly care for.

headline: Plan for New Nepal Districts Draws Deadly Protests and Attacks on Police
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Attacks on Police', 'Constitutions', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Tharu (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Ethnic Tharus have been seeking the creation of a province in western Nepal so that they will have more political power.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — An angry protest against a draft constitution in Nepal turned deadly on Monday when demonstrators broke a curfew and attacked police officers with knives, spears and sickles.

headline: Letters to the Editor
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Electroshock Therapy', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: After Ashley Madison Hack, Police in Toronto Detail a Global Fallout
abstract: The fallout continues from a data breach of Ashley Madison, the adultery website, as international authorities search for the hackers.
lead_paragraph: Canadian officials are bracing for long-term fallout from the unauthorized release of user data from the adultery website Ashley Madison, they said at a news conference on Monday.

headline: New Luxury Cruise Through France
abstract: The eight-passenger Finesse barge will cruise along France’s River Saône and the Canal du Centre next spring.

headline: A Piece of the Earliest Baboon Ever Found
abstract: A two-million-year-old skull fragment was found in the same South African cave that turned up specimens of an early ancestor to humans in 2010.
lead_paragraph: A two-million-year-old skull fragment comes from the earliest baboon ever found, a new study reports. The fossil was found in Malapa, a cave in South Africa and a Unesco World Heritage site where specimens of Australopithecus sediba, an early ancestor of modern humans, were discovered in 2010.

headline: U.S. Army Reopens Criminal Inquiry Into Afghan Civilians’ Deaths
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The investigation focuses on at least 17 murders in 2012 and 2013 that Afghan officials blamed on an Army Special Forces team based in Wardak Province.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United States military has reopened a criminal investigation into a series of at least 17 murders of civilians in 2012 and 2013 for which Afghan officials blamed an Army Special Forces team, a senior Western official here said on Monday.

headline: John Kasich Balances His Blue-Collar Roots and Ties to Wall Street
abstract: A chapter in Mr. Kasich’s life story conflicts with the narrative about his working-class past: the nearly eight years he spent as an investment banker with Lehman Brothers.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — As the people of Ohio already know — and Republican voters elsewhere are just beginning to find out — Gov. John R. Kasich grew up in working-class McKees Rocks, Pa., the son of a postal worker and the grandson of a coal miner. His grandfather was so poor, Mr. Kasich recently told voters in New Hampshire, that he would bring home scraps of his lunch to share with his children.

headline: Heroes Thwart a Train Attack, Yet Europe Remains Vulnerable
abstract: As four men receive France’s highest honor, the exposure of European passenger rails to terrorists requires urgent review.
lead_paragraph: The four men — three American and one British — who received France’s highest honor, the Legion of Honor, on Monday from President François Hollande richly deserved it. Their courage in tackling an attacker wielding an AK-47 and other weaponry inside a packed high-speed train traveling from Brussels to Paris last Friday prevented a possible blood bath.

headline: Asia Society Names New Museum Director
abstract: Tan Boon Hui, a former director of the Singapore Art Museum, replaces Melissa Chiu.
lead_paragraph: The Asia Society has appointed a new director of its museum to replace Melissa Chiu, who left last year to become director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington.

headline: Richard Christiansen and Vanessa Holden’s Travels in Tokyo
abstract: In their fourth travel diary for T, the duo visits Hotel Okura, a Bonsai nursery and plenty of tiny, thrilling bars.
lead_paragraph: Richard Christiansen, the founder of Chandelier Creative and Vanessa Holden, former senior vice president of West Elm, document their three-week trip around the world searching for creative inspiration exclusively for T.

headline: A Way to Make Depth-Sensing Cameras Better
abstract: The cameras can detect how far away something is. But they didn’t work well in bright light. A new technology is changing that.
lead_paragraph: Depth-sensing cameras can detect how far away a person or object is. Though these cameras have broad applications — in self-driving cars and navigation tools for the blind, for instance — they do not work well in bright sunlight.

headline: White House on Biden’s Potential Run
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, sidestepped questions on Monday about whether President Obama wants Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to enter the 2016 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, sidestepped questions on Monday about whether President Obama wants Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to enter the 2016 presidential race.

headline: European Leaders React to China’s Slump
abstract: Government leaders and representatives from Europe expressed optimism about the state of China’s economic health as the country’s stock market plunged on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Government leaders and representatives from Europe expressed optimism about the state of China’s economic health as the country’s stock market plunged on Monday.

keywords: ['Editorials', 'Hudson River Tunnels Project', 'Transit Systems', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo writes that he “vigorously” supports a new rail tunnel under the Hudson and says a federal commitment is necessary.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Widening World of Hand-Picked Truths
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Science and Technology', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Global Warming']
abstract: More than ever, the best available science doesn’t seem to change minds in a civilization of competing ideologies.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a century ago, in what passed as outrage in pre-Internet times, people across the country became incensed by the latest edition of Time magazine. In place of the familiar portrait of a world leader — Indira Gandhi, Lyndon B. Johnson, Ho Chi Minh — the cover of the April 8, 1966, issue was emblazoned with three red words against a stark black background: “Is God Dead?”

headline: Southern Company to Pay $12 Billion for AGL Resources
abstract: The deal between the two crosstown Atlanta rivals will make Southern the second-largest United States utility, with about nine million customers.
lead_paragraph: Southern Company’s acquisition of AGL Resources could yet find its true north. The power producer is buying its crosstown Atlanta rival for $12 billion, including $4 billion of debt. Although the premium looks rich for the utility sector, there is at least a chance that the price can be justified.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photographs from Syria, Serbia, Malaysia and Britain.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Syria, Serbia, Malaysia and Britain.

headline: Rich in History, Metropolitan Open Will Celebrate a Milestone at Winged Foot
abstract: Although it does not draw the top golfers it once did, the Met Open, which will be played this week for the 100th time, has had champions including Walter Hagen, Gene Sarazen, Tommy Armour and Craig Wood.
lead_paragraph: The course where the first Metropolitan Open was held in 1905, Fox Hills Golf Club on Staten Island, is long gone. It has been 75 years since the tournament — won by nine players who were eventually inducted into the World Golf Hall of Fame — regularly attracted the sport’s best.

headline: Review: ‘Dancing Through the Bronx’ Allows Local Artists a Moment in the Sun
abstract: Each part of this two-part program at Owen F. Dolen Park was organized by a veteran dancer who was either born in the Bronx or was a longtime resident there.
lead_paragraph: Owen F. Dolen Park in the Bronx is not the sort of public green that would normally warrant a visit by anyone outside the neighborhood. Despite a $5 million renovation in 2013, it’s still just a few plots of grass and trees amid busy streets in the shadow of the elevated No. 6 train. On Friday evening, though, some dancers attempted to spruce up the place a bit.

headline: Scott Walker Joins Growing Chorus in Attacking China
abstract: With China’s currency devaluation and stock market downturn rattling American markets, Gov. Scott Walker called on President Obama to cancel the visit of China’s leader, President Xi Jinping, to Washington next month.
lead_paragraph: With China’s currency devaluation and stock market downturn rattling American markets, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Monday called on President Obama to cancel the visit of China’s leader, President Xi Jinping, to Washington next month.

headline: Steroid Shots No Better for Back Pain Than Placebo
abstract: A new review of 30 placebo-controlled studies found that epidural steroid injections provided some short-term relief, but no more.
lead_paragraph: Steroid shots are commonly used for back pain, but evidence that they work no better than placebos is mounting.

headline: Women’s Project Will Present 2015-16 Season in a New Home
abstract: A season that includes two New York premieres.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s Project Theater will begin its coming season in a new home, at the McGinn/Cazale Theater on Broadway, at 76th Street. This Off Broadway company dedicated to promoting female artists announced its three-year residency at the theater along with its 2015-16 season, which includes two New York premieres.

headline: Can Data Capture the True Health of the Creative Economy?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Music', 'Art', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A response to the critics of this week’s magazine cover story.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the Future of Music Coalition, a musicians’ advocacy group, published a blog post taking issue with some of the arguments and data from my Aug. 23 cover story in the magazine, “The Creative Apocalypse That Wasn’t.” I take their comments very seriously for several reasons: First, their concerns — that musicians be appropriately compensated in this digital age — are my concerns. Second, they have assembled some important studies of the new economics emerging in the music business, many of which I drew upon in writing the article. And finally, they’re a terrific organization doing important work.

headline: Potential Joe Biden Run Puts White House in a Bind
abstract: An exchange between reporters and the White House press secretary shows how awkward the prospects of a nomination fight between Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Hillary Rodham Clinton would be for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: How awkward would it be for President Obama and the White House if Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. challenged Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic nomination?

headline: Book Review: ‘The Butterflies of North America; Titian Peale’s Lost Manuscript’
abstract: With “The Butterflies of North America; Titian Peale’s Lost Manuscript,” today’s readers can appreciate both the insects and the striking images.
lead_paragraph: To most of us, butterflies are charming ephemera that flutter in and out of our lives. But for a certain species of 19th-century gentleman, the stalking and archiving of butterflies was the very height of outdoors adventure.

headline: T’s Five to Follow: Monday, Aug. 24
abstract: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.
lead_paragraph: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

headline: Joylynn Holder of Brooklyn Forest and Her Steadfast Batter Bowl
abstract: For a founder of the series of outdoor classes, a deep blue stoneware bowl that has traveled with her is better than a food processor any day.
lead_paragraph: Joylynn Holder is wandering in the wilderness, or as much wilderness as New York City parks allow. As a founder of Brooklyn Forest, she runs classes for parents and children in the glades of Central and Prospect Parks, going outdoors whatever the weather, with exceptions made for thunder, hurricanes, snowstorms and February.

headline: Rick Perry’s Campaign Takes a Hit With Departure of Iowa Chairman, Sam Clovis
abstract: Rick Perry’s scuffling presidential bid suffered another blow with the departure of the chairman of his campaign in Iowa, Sam Clovis.
lead_paragraph: Rick Perry’s scuffling presidential bid has suffered another blow.

headline: Atop Medal Table at Worlds, Kenya Is Also Under a Cloud
abstract: Kenyans swept the men’s 3,000-meter steeplechase at the world track and field championships on Monday, but allegations of doping are said to be taking a toll on national pride.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It appeared to be business as usual for Kenya at the world track and field championships Monday night.

headline: Victim’s Family Testifies in Holmes Case
abstract: Rena Medek, whose daughter Micayla was killed by James E. Holmes at a Colorado movie theater in 2012, described in the sentencing phase for Mr. Holmes how the shooting changed her life.
lead_paragraph: Rena Medek, whose daughter Micayla was killed by James E. Holmes at a Colorado movie theater in 2012, described in the sentencing phase for Mr. Holmes how the shooting changed her life.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Premiere Draws Record Viewers
abstract: “The Walking Dead” spinoff had 10.1 million viewers on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: AMC’s new spinoff series, “Fear the Walking Dead,” drew 10.1 million viewers on Sunday night, making it the most viewed series premiere in cable TV history. The show also drew 6.3 million viewers in the 18- to-49-year-old demographic, another record.

headline: Review: ‘Drop Dead Perfect,’ Winking Melodrama, Returns to St. Clement’s
abstract: This one-act parody lives mainly for its adolescent double entendres and Everett Quinton’s delicious performance.
lead_paragraph: “Drop Dead Perfect,” which opened at the Theater at St. Clement’s last year, reopened there on Sunday night. Following is Anita Gates’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on July 23, 2014.

headline: A Volcanic Eruption That Reverberates 200 Years Later
abstract: Investigators are still struggling to understand the most powerful eruption in recorded history, which gave rise to icy weather and pandemics, but also to great literature and art.
lead_paragraph: In April 1815, the most powerful volcanic blast in recorded history shook the planet in a catastrophe so vast that 200 years later, investigators are still struggling to grasp its repercussions. It played a role, they now understand, in icy weather, agricultural collapse and global pandemics — and even gave rise to celebrated monsters.

headline: Style at the Afropunk Festival’s Fancy Ball
abstract: Revelers turned out for the kick-off night of the 11th annual music festival, featuring a performance by Grace Jones.
lead_paragraph: Revelers turned out for the kick-off night of the 11th annual music festival, featuring a performance by Grace Jones.

headline: Euro Leaders Back Cease-Fire in Ukraine
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France stood alongside President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine to call for greater security on the Ukraine-Russia border.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France stood alongside President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine to call for greater security on the Ukraine-Russia border.

headline: Scenes From the Afropunk Festival’s Fancy Ball
abstract: Attendees wore jewel-encrusted lapels, masks and floral suits to see Grace Jones perform.
lead_paragraph: Rules rarely spark a good time. Yet upon entering Commodore Barry Park for the Afropunk Festival’s inaugural Fancy Ball on Friday night — a fundraiser which opened the 11th annual music spectacle in Fort Greene, Brooklyn — attendees were greeted by eight commandments: no sexism, no racism, no ableism, no ageism, no homophobia, no fatphobia, no transphobia, no hatefulness. “It’s like the most polite people I’ve ever met,” said Manzell Glover, a male bartender in a sleeveless vintage dress who identified as a QPOC (Queer Person of Color). “There was a crowd, but when people have their tapestries down or their blankets down, nobody stepped on anyone’s anything. I’ve never heard ‘excuse me’ so many times,” he said. A retail fashion stylist seated on one of those blankets, Ramie Mitchell, said, “It feels like a no-judgment zone.” Amy Van Doran, a professional matchmaker in a Tang-colored wig, was more blunt in her assessment: “Everyone here is super kind because there is less white privilege,” she said. Headliner Grace Jones took the stage a very civilized 10 minutes early, though she did tell the crowd, drolly and with an expletive appended, “Put down your phones and clap your hands. Put it between your legs if you have to.”

headline: European Leaders Make a Show of Support for Ukraine on Its National Day
abstract: In two speeches, President Petro O. Poroshenko spoke of Ukraine’s tension with Russia, and the leaders of Germany and France again voiced support for a deal negotiated this year.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Clinging to a deal on Ukraine that has never been fully enacted, the leaders of Germany, France and Ukraine called on Monday — the 24th anniversary of Ukraine’s independence — for the bloodshed to end.

headline: Louisiana State Police Discuss Shooting
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The state police said Monday that a Louisiana trooper, Steven J. Vincent, had died after being shot in the head Sunday night during a traffic stop.
lead_paragraph: The state police said Monday that a Louisiana trooper, Steven J. Vincent, had died after being shot in the head Sunday night during a traffic stop.

headline: Elisabeth Moss on Her Emmy Nomination and How to Follow Success of Peggy Olson
abstract: Ms. Moss discusses portraying Peggy on “Mad Men” for seven seasons, earning six Emmy nominations for the role.
lead_paragraph: Over seven seasons, the character Peggy Olson on “Mad Men” grew from mousy secretary to advertising dynamo. While that AMC show may have started out focusing on the man in the corner office, in the end it was Peggy’s journey that captivated and compelled many viewers. While Don Draper battled inner demons, Peggy battled society, pushing the boundaries of what women could achieve in the work force of the 1960s.

headline: Scene City: A 24-Hour Party at the Guggenheim
abstract: Downtown artists including Agathe Snow, Dan Colen and Nate Lowman relive a fabled party from 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Downtown artists including Agathe Snow, Dan Colen and Nate Lowman relive a fabled party from 10 years ago.

headline: China, Japan and Europe Are Flashing Economic Warning Signs
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Interest Rates', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: World leaders need to come up with credible policies quickly to energize the sputtering global economy.
lead_paragraph: Even before the recent plunge in commodity and stock markets, the world economy was weak. But recent data from China, Europe, Japan and other countries suggest that growth is slowing more sharply than many analysts had anticipated. That puts the burden on policy makers in these countries to come up with more credible ways to bolster their economies.

headline: Scene City: A 24-hour Party at the Guggenheim
abstract: Downtown artists including Agathe Snow, Dan Colen and Nate Lowman relive a fabled party from 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, the artist Agathe Snow hosted a 24-hour dance party at the Guggenheim Museum that commemorated an epic party that took place 10 years ago. An electric crowd of artists, fashion insiders, downtown scenesters and teenagers participated.

headline: In Fight for a Stretch of the Rockaways, Surfers and New Residents Collide
keywords: ['Surfing', 'Swimming', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: A campaign for an expanded surfing area has run up against the objections of residents of a new development that occupies that same stretch of beach.
lead_paragraph: The growing popularity of surfing in the Rockaways has created a resurgence, attracting large beach crowds, fueling new businesses and generating other economic boosts.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Taking Another Look at the Reconstruction Era
abstract: The National Park Service is trying to reshape public views of the still hotly contested effort to rebuild the American South after the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: BEAUFORT, S.C. — Growing up in Kingstree, S.C., in the 1960s, Michael Allen never knew the town had elected a black mayor in the years after the Civil War. There was no monument dedicated to the man’s memory. He was never mentioned in school.

headline: Review: Edward Burns’s ‘Public Morals’ on TNT
abstract: Mr. Burns’s 10-episode series is set in the 1960s in Hell’s Kitchen and somewhere around the corner from Damon Runyon.
lead_paragraph: Edward Burns’s new series, “Public Morals,” is set in Hell’s Kitchen in the 1960s and filmed in New York, at Silvercup Studios and at locations like the Russian Tea Room, the Park Lane Hotel and Barrow’s Pub in Greenwich Village. It doesn’t seem to take place anywhere in the real world, though. It’s in an imaginary American neighborhood — around the corner from Runyon, down the block from Scorsese, within sight of Mamet — where characters are nicknamed Beantown and Specs and say things like, “I get a one-way ticket to Palookaville.”

keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Terrorism', 'Aurora, Colo, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
