headline: Viewing Copenhagen Bridge’s Construction
abstract: Time-lapse footage showing construction of the Cirkelbroen (Circle Bridge), which was designed by Olafur Eliasson and opened Monday.
lead_paragraph: Time-lapse footage showing construction of the Cirkelbroen (Circle Bridge), which was designed by Olafur Eliasson and opened Monday.

headline: Review: Charlie Parker Jazz Festival Subtly Recalls Its Inspiration
abstract: The festival’s final installment, on Sunday night in Tompkins Square Park, included the saxophonists Joe Lovano and Rudresh Mahanthappa.
lead_paragraph: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival comes by its name with a blissfully casual reverence. The festival, whose 22nd edition ran over the weekend, involves free outdoor concerts in Harlem and the East Village, neighborhoods where Parker, the pioneering alto saxophonist and bebop lodestar, once lived. It always falls near his birthday. (Born on Aug. 29, he would have turned 95 this year. He died at 34.)

headline: Son House Inspires a Rochester Blues Festival
abstract: A four-day festival, Journey to the Son, will explore the music of Son House, whose Rochester years will also be commemorated with a Mississippi Blues Trail marker.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — A sign about eight miles east of this city’s storied Corn Hill neighborhood points out a historical landmark, the rail yard where the blues musician Son House worked as a porter in the 1940s. The vowel in House’s nickname (he was born Eddie) is an odd size, rising about a half inch above the letters on either side. An explanation of sorts can be seen in the abrupt curvature at the top of the first O: The original sign misspelled his name as “SUN,” and the U was rounded off after the fact.

headline: New Report of ISIS Using Poison Gas in Syria
abstract: Local rebels and an international aid group accused the militant group of using mustard gas against civilian and rival insurgents in northern Syria last week.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Islamic State may have used chemical agents in an attack against civilians and rival insurgents in northern Syria late last week, according to local rebels and an international aid group.

headline: Punchless Yanks Squeak By on a Sacrifice Fly
abstract: Only one run proved to be enough to beat the Astros as Carlos Beltran delivered a game-ending sacrifice fly in the ninth inning.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees had gone eight fruitless innings without scoring a run, their swooning offense looking mostly lifeless and unimposing. Then, in the ninth, the Houston Astros called on a familiar face: Oliver Perez.

headline: Wild Cards Remain as Democrats Add Supporters on Iran Deal
abstract: The party’s leaders are still lobbying the undecided lawmakers, but are worried that Republicans might try to add politically charged amendments to the deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Senator Harry Reid’s undiluted endorsement Sunday of the Iran nuclear accord, followed by Senator Debbie Stabenow of Michigan on Monday, supporters of the deal are closing in on the number they need to ensure it goes into force.

headline: ‘Puppies’ Unrewarded at Sci-Fi Book Awards
abstract: This year’s Hugo Awards had turned into a test of the genre’s politics.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Hugo Awards, given to the best in science fiction, turned into a referendum on the genre’s politics. Two blocks of conservative authors and fans, calling themselves the Sad Puppies and the Rabid Puppies, have argued that the Hugos have become a litmus test of political correctness, valuing the racial and sexual identities of authors over their storytelling skills. This year, the groups used their leverage to fill categories with their own preferred nominees.

headline: The ’60s: In and Out of the Limelight
abstract: David Hurn’s celebrity photos helped shape popular memories of the 1960s. But he was more drawn to the stuff of daily life.
lead_paragraph: David Hurn’s celebrity photos helped shape popular memories of the 1960s. But he was more drawn to the stuff of daily life.

headline: The Stock Market Loses 5 Percent In a Week: What Happens Next
abstract: A look at the last five times the stock market lost 5 percent in a week.
lead_paragraph: A look at the last five times the stock market lost 5 percent in a week.

headline: Uncertainty in the Market May Imperil Deal-Making
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Private Equity', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: Prolonged turmoil may end the continued deal-making that has brought about one of the biggest waves of mergers and initial public offerings in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: Even as stock markets again tumbled across the world, deal makers — among the most optimistic lot on Wall Street — aren’t ready yet to call an end to one of the biggest waves of mergers and initial public offerings in recent memory.

headline: Stupid China Stories
abstract: Obama did it! Somehow!
lead_paragraph: So a stock crash in China triggered a big decline around the world, while I was trying to have a personal life (and succeeding, actually). Leaving aside whether this really made sense, why should events in China matter for the rest of us?

headline: Netflix to Add Films and TV Series for Teenagers
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Movies', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television']
abstract: The streaming service will introduce exclusive films and television series as part of a strategy to position itself as a digital entertainment hub for the postmillennial generation.
lead_paragraph: Netflix is entering the awkward teenage years, at least with its latest programming push.

headline: Reform Chief Questions United States Involvement in FIFA, Defends Sepp Blatter
abstract: François Carrard denigrated the game in the U.S., and bemoaned its interests in policing the sport.
lead_paragraph: Somebody needs to tell François Carrard, the Swiss lawyer recently named to lead  FIFA’s reform committee, that he should really stop being so annoyingly impartial and tell the public how he really feels.

headline: Analysis Finds Higher Expulsion Rates for Black Students
abstract: While black students represented just under a quarter of public school students in the 13 Southern states studied, they made up nearly half of all suspensions and expulsions.
lead_paragraph: With the Obama administration focused on reducing the number of suspensions, expulsions and arrests in public schools, a new analysis of federal data identifies districts in 13 Southern states where black students are suspended or expelled at rates overwhelmingly higher than white children.

headline: Lebanese Activists Mock ‘Beirut Wall’ Meant to Block Protest
abstract: Lebanese bloggers ridiculed the authorities for trying to stifle dissent by erecting a concrete blast wall around government buildings in Beirut.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of Lebanon’s “You Stink” protest movement — who were confronted with water cannon and tear gas over the weekend when they took to the streets to demand a solution to the trash crisis in Beirut — ridiculed the authorities online Monday for trying to stifle dissent by erecting a concrete blast wall around the seat of government.

headline: Jeb Bush Talks About Immigration
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate responded to Donald J. Trump’s immigration proposals, as well as his own use of the term “anchor baby.”
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate responded to Donald J. Trump’s immigration proposals, as well as his own use of the term “anchor baby.”

headline: From Venezuela to Iraq to Russia, Oil Price Drops Raise Fears of Unrest
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The downward spiral of oil prices and the reluctance to reduce production are threatening to destabilize economies and governments in many places that are already fragile.
lead_paragraph: Oil, the lifeblood of many countries that produce and sell it, appears to be rapidly turning into an ever-cheaper economic curse.

headline: One Direction Says It Is Taking a Break, but Not Splitting Up
abstract: After rumors, One Direction members clarify that they are simply taking a break.
lead_paragraph: After more than 24 hours of fan panic, members of the British boy band One Direction have addressed tabloid chatter that said the group would go on an indefinite hiatus — or worse, break up — next year.

headline: Jeb Bush Takes a Cue From Donald Trump’s Playbook: Punch Back
abstract: After enduring slings and arrows from Mr. Trump for weeks, Mr. Bush is punching back — with force.
lead_paragraph: The schoolyard taunts from Donald J. Trump arrive on a daily basis, raining down on Jeb Bush’s sober, careful and policy-minded campaign with growing acerbity.

headline: ISIS Speeds Up Destruction of Antiquities in Syria
keywords: ['Assyrian Civilization', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The cumulative toll inflicted on antiquities by militants, who destroyed a fifth-century monastery and a first-century temple recently, has reached staggering levels, archaeologists and officials say.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic State militants have razed a fifth-century Roman Catholic monastery and blown up one of the best-preserved first-century temples in Palmyra, the ancient Syrian city that is one of the world’s most important archaeological sites, according to government officials and local activists.

headline: Merl Reagle, Whose Crossword Puzzles Delighted Clued-In Solvers, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Reagle contributed devilishly inventive puzzles to numerous publications, relishing his roles as a wisecracker, provocateur and tease.
lead_paragraph: Merl Reagle, a playfully irreverent crossword puzzle constructor whose clues set off spirited cerebrations from his fans rather than frustrated surrenders to dictionary arcana, died on Saturday in Tampa, Fla. He was 65.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Take Aim at China as U.S. Markets Tumble
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: One candidate, Scott Walker, called on President Obama to cancel a state visit by the Chinese leader, as another candidate, Donald J. Trump, warned that Beijing will “bring us down.”
lead_paragraph: Republican presidential candidates began shifting their focus on Monday from the dangers posed by illegal immigrants to a new target: China, whose currency devaluations and stock market plunges are starting to hurt the savings of American investors.

headline: Cynthia Macdonald, Poet Known for Humor and Ability to Shock, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Macdonald’s idiosyncratic blend of humor and the grotesque made her a distinctive voice on the American poetry scene.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Macdonald, whose idiosyncratic blend of humor and the grotesque made her a distinctive voice on the American poetry scene, died on Aug. 3 in a nursing home in Logan, Utah. She was 87.

headline: Jordan Spieth Reassesses a Career Path From the Top, Where Time Is Short
abstract: Spieth spoke to a group of young golfers in New Jersey about the lessons he had learned on the way to becoming the world’s top-ranked player at 22 years old.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Four rows of young golfers, all active in local chapters of the First Tee, a youth development group, fidgeted in their seats in the midday sun. Filling out the rows behind them were grown-ups wearing belts and shirts bearing the names of some of the country’s most prestigious courses. On the dais, Paul Fireman — a founder, with his son, Dan, of one such place, Liberty National — was answering a question about personal legacies.

headline: A Warning on China Seems Prescient
abstract: Kenneth Rogoff, a Harvard professor, has made a career of studying financial crises, and he has long warned of one coming to China.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Rogoff has long warned of a potential financial crisis in China.

headline: Ferguson Announces an Amnesty on Warrants
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The efforts are a response to the sharp criticism of the court system in the Missouri city that emerged after the killing of Michael Brown last year.
lead_paragraph: The City of Ferguson, Mo., announced Monday that it was withdrawing thousands of arrest warrants for municipal violations and taking steps to prevent the incarceration of people who cannot pay fines and fees, a response to the sharp criticism of its court system that emerged after the killing of Michael Brown last year.

headline: Advisers Work to Calm Fearful Investors
abstract: On some days, market psychology can count for more than long-term fundamentals, pushing panicked investors to sell.
lead_paragraph: Even a pep talk from the chief executive of Apple, the single biggest American company by market value, did little to soothe investors on Monday.

headline: Loved Ones Recount Their Pain at Hearing for Aurora Gunman
abstract: James E. Holmes was sentenced to life in prison in August, but this week’s hearings focus on the other nonlethal crimes for which he was also charged.
lead_paragraph: CENTENNIAL, Colo. — The family members of the people killed and injured by a gunman in an Aurora, Colo., movie theater in 2012 took the stand on Monday to give some of their most emotional testimony yet, approaching a lectern in a courtroom here and delivering searing accounts of the depression and loss they felt after the massacre.

headline: Puerto Ricans Seeking New Lives Put Stamp on Central Florida
abstract: A population change is transforming the Orlando region economically, culturally and politically.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — When Manuel Hernandez, a teacher in Puerto Rico, looked at the reasons to stay home or to take a chance on joining the ever-growing Puerto Rican diaspora in Central Florida, it was not a hard call.

headline: Government and Protesters in Lebanon Weigh Next Move in Trash Dispute
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Demonstrators regrouped and the government tried to get a handle on events on Monday in Beirut, where weekend protests over uncollected garbage boiled over into violence that left scores of demonstrators and police officers injured.

lead_paragraph: From his getaway cabin deep in the woods, an experienced adviser to wealthy hedge fund investors was hopping from one conference call to another to manage clients’ mounting anxiety.

headline: David Wright Quickly Sets Tone in Return to Mets
abstract: Wright hit a home run — and his teammates added seven more — in his first game back with the Mets since going on the disabled list April 15.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Imagine if David Wright’s leadership powers worked this way all the time. With his first swing Monday after coming off the disabled list, Wright launched a home run into the second deck of Citizens Bank Park. His teammates followed his example to absurd lengths: They set single-game Mets records for homers and extra-base hits in a 16-7 thrashing of the Philadelphia Phillies.

headline: Bus Slams Into House in Queens, Injuring Six
abstract: The bus, which was shuttling people from the Resorts World Casino in Queens, veered off a busy road in the Rego Park neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A bus shuttling people from the Resorts World Casino in Queens veered off a busy road in the Rego Park neighborhood on Monday afternoon and slammed into a three-story house, injuring six people and leaving a gaping hole in the building, officials said.

headline: Review: In A. R. Gurney’s ‘Love & Money,’ a Grandson Materializes to Claim His Fortune
abstract: A young stranger interrupts a wealthy old widow’s plan to give away everything she owns in this new play at the Signature Theater.
lead_paragraph: The money is vividly apparent as soon as the lights go up on “Love & Money,” the slender new play by A. R. Gurney that opened at the Pershing Square Signature Center on Monday. The sumptuous but tasteful set, by Michael Yeargan, depicts the parlor floor of a brownstone on the Upper East Side, stocked with expensive-looking furniture, paintings and books. And one expensive-looking person, Cornelia Cunningham (Maureen Anderman), who owns the townhouse and all those mouthwatering goodies.

headline: The Art of Punning
abstract: A good time with John E. Bennett’s puzzle, and a reminder of Merl Reagle’s art.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — No one — not the constructor John E. Bennett, and certainly not Will Shortz — meant for this to happen, but this was a tough puzzle for me to solve. Not from a solving point of view, but from an emotional one. This is the first crossword I’ve solved since I learned of Merl Reagle’s death, and it haunts me for a couple of reasons.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Campaign Takes Steps to Rein In Spending
abstract: Cuts were said to be not a result of fund-raising shortfalls, but intended to correct needless spending before the campaign gets into the heat of the election season.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush’s presidential campaign has asked various divisions to be mindful of their spending, in a reminder that despite his giant “super PAC” bankroll, campaign dollars are ultimately more valuable.

lead_paragraph: Justice Department prosecutors scolded Senator Robert Menendez and his lawyers on Monday, rebuking the indicted lawmaker for what they described as a disingenuous attempt to have corruption charges against him thrown out in federal court.

headline: Ouster of ‘Disruptive’ Book Club From Napa Train Prompts Racial Bias Charge

lead_paragraph: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce won her third straight world title in the women’s 100 meters on Monday at the world championships in Beijing. She finished in 10.76 seconds, followed by Dafne Schippers of the Netherlands and Torie Bowie of the United States.

headline: Mets Rout Phillies, Bashing 8 Homers and 15 Extra-Base Hits
abstract: On the night that David Wright returned from a four-month absence, the Mets overcame a bad start by Jacob deGrom and an early five-run deficit by setting two franchise records.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — David Wright lay flat on his back, on a mat in a hallway outside the Mets’ clubhouse here Monday afternoon, going through a series of stretches. He looked vulnerable as he tried to loosen up his back. But as his teammates and coaches passed him, stopping to chat, they went on laughing from the gut, and Wright’s familiar cackle echoed throughout the clubhouse.

Kentucky will next face California, which defeated Rhode Island, 10-3.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Cinemax) DALLAS BUYERS CLUB (2013) A fiercely gaunt Matthew McConaughey, in an Oscar-winning role, portrays Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician and rodeo rider who, after learning in 1985 that he is H.I.V.-positive, decides to treat himself by hunting down medication that is not then legal in the United States. He eventually begins a subscription service, selling contraband medicine for a monthly fee. Jared Leto, in another Oscar-winning performance, plays Rayon, a transgender woman who becomes Ron’s business partner. And Jennifer Garner is the doctor who turns into an ally. What is largely missing from this drama, directed by Jean-Marc Vallée and inspired by real events, “is the sense that Ron’s efforts are part of a larger movement,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Ron’s bravery and determination are entirely credible, thanks to Mr. McConaughey’s disciplined, high-spirited performance and the filmmakers’ interest in the complexity of the character. But his actions unfold in something of a vacuum.”

headline: The Big Decisions
abstract: The most important decisions in life should be based not on what we think we want, but on what or whom we admire.

Your friends who have undergone the transformation say the experience is incredible. They drink animal blood, not human blood, and say everything about their new existence provides them with fun, companionship and meaning.

headline: ‘Give Us the Ballot,’ by Ari Berman
abstract: A narrative history of the continuing efforts to weaken the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, when President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act on Aug. 6, 1965, he felt, his daughter Luci said, “a great sense of victory on one side and a great sense of fear on the other.” According to Ari Berman, a political correspondent for The Nation, he knew the law would transform American politics and democracy more than any other civil rights bill in the 20th century, but he also feared that it would deliver the South to the Republican Party for years to come. Both predictions proved to be accurate. “The revolution of 1965 spawned an equally committed group of counterrevolutionaries,” Berman writes in “Give Us the Ballot.” “Since the V.R.A.’s passage, they have waged a decades-long campaign to restrict voting rights.” Berman argues that these counterrevolutionaries have “in recent years, controlled a majority on the Supreme Court” and “have set their sights on undoing the accomplishments of the 1960s civil rights movement.”

headline: 4 State Parties Sign Fund-Raising Pacts With Clinton Campaign
abstract: Democratic state parties in Mississippi, Virginia, Wisconsin and the crucial proving ground of New Hampshire have committed to fund-raising agreements with the Clinton campaign, news that came as a surprise to national party officials.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign has received commitments from four Democratic state parties, including in the crucial proving ground of New Hampshire, to enter joint fund-raising agreements with the campaign just as the nomination battle is beginning.

headline: Today in Politics: Obama’s Delicate Spot With Joe Biden as Hillary Clinton Maneuvers
abstract: Politics can be tough on friendships, as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is seeking to put a home-state senator in a tough spot, while President Obama might find himself in a similarly awkward position if his vice president decides to run for president.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning. Politics can be tough on friendships, as Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is seeking to put a home-state senator in a tough spot, while President Obama might find himself in a similarly awkward position if his vice president decides to challenge his former secretary of state in a bid to replace him. And to the surprise of some in her party, Hillary Rodham Clinton is proposing joint fund-raising agreements that typically occur after the nomination has been won.

headline: ‘Moment’ Is Having a Moment
keywords: ['English Language', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When we identify a special “moment” in political campaigns or pop culture, we are really trying to contain the chaos of the world.
lead_paragraph: In normal everyday life, time is a liquid that flows around us all unceasingly — a kind of existential syrup. During election season, this syrup is captured, boiled down, dehydrated and separated into its constituent grains — grains that we like to call, without fail, ‘‘moments.’’ Thus Donald Trump is (according to The New York Times) ‘‘the man of the moment,’’ and although he was briefly ‘‘out-­Foxed’’ (according to The Belfast Telegraph) ‘‘by a Megyn moment’’ (Jim Rutenberg's coinage in this magazine), he went on to recover with a ‘‘big, symbolic moment’’ (according to Mark Halperin on the ‘‘Today’’ show) at the Iowa State Fair. Hillary Clinton, meanwhile, might be having an ‘‘Al Capone moment’’ with regard to the legality of her private email server (The Washington Post), but she still found time to have a ‘‘celebrity moment’’ (The Times again) by taking a selfie with Kim Kardashian and Kanye West. No nexus of events is too large or heterogeneous — no geopolitical weather too swirlingly turbulent — to avoid being reduced to the shorthand of the moment.

headline: Coca-Cola Says It’s Close to Water Replenishment Goal
abstract: The beverage company announced a plan in 2007 to replenish the amount of water equivalent to its sales volume — about 160 billion liters — by 2020. It could get to that point this year.
lead_paragraph: The Coca-Cola Company is years ahead of schedule in its efforts to replace the water that it uses around the world to make its beverages, it announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Meaning of Serena Williams
abstract: On tennis and black excellence.
lead_paragraph: There is no more exuberant winner than Serena Williams. She leaps into the air, she laughs, she grins, she pumps her fist, she points her index finger to the sky, signaling she’s No. 1. Her joy is palpable. It brings me to my feet, and I grin right back at her, as if I’ve won something, too. Perhaps I have.

headline: For History-Minded Tourists, London Marks Blitz Anniversary
abstract: This fall, London’s robust tourism industry will commemorate the 75th anniversary of the capital’s time under siege.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in the autumn of 1940, German Luftwaffe pilots bombed London for 57 consecutive nights. It began on Sept. 7, when 348 German bombers and 617 Messerschmitt fighters appeared in the clear skies above the British capital and began to pound the area with explosives. In the months that followed, great numbers of aghast Londoners fled to the countryside. But many more stayed put, through air raids that flattened great swaths of the city and killed 20,000 residents. When the bomb shelters filled up, tens of thousands of Londoners filed into Underground stations, where they slept, packed like sardines, on the concrete platforms.

headline: Waukesha Plan for Lake Michigan Water Raises Worries
abstract: The city wants to pipe water from the nearby lake to address a problem with its own water. But a 2008 compact prohibits that sort of thing.
lead_paragraph: WAUKESHA, Wis. — This city, once famous for its bubbling natural springs, sits about 17 miles from the shore of Lake Michigan. So when the state and federal authorities began demanding that the city address a growing contamination problem in its aquifer, the answer seemed simple: Get water from the big lake.

headline: Deal Between North and South Korea Defies Their Mutual Disdain

abstract: Some observers say the agreement that ended a military standoff opens up at least the possibility that the relationship could now improve to some degree.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The agreement that ended a tense military standoff on the Korean Peninsula on Tuesday taught a lesson about North-South dynamics: Though they heap verbal abuse on each other’s leaders, the two sides can still do a deal when it suits their interests.

headline: Morning Agenda: China Cuts Rates After Stocks Plunge
keywords: ['CHINA', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Education', 'Hang Seng Index (Hong Kong)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Interest Rates', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Rough and Tumble for Hedge Funds | A Prescient Warning on China | Dampening the Deal-Making
lead_paragraph: CHINA CUTS RATES AFTER SHANGHAI STOCKS PLUNGE | China’s central bank cut interest rates after Shanghai’s stock market went into free fall on Tuesday, closing 7.6 percent lower after an 8.5 percent plunge on Monday, Chris Buckley writes in The New York Times. The move brought interest rates down by 0.25 percent, lowering the one-year lending rate to 4.6 percent. The People’s Bank of China also reduced the reserve rate requirement by 0.5 percent.

headline: Donald Trump Offers Stock Market Advice: ‘You Are Better Off Holding’

headline: Heroes in Polos and Khakis

headline: Part of the Problem: Stocks Are Expensive
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: Relative to long-term corporate earnings, stocks remain more expensive than at any point from the late 1940s through the early 1990s.
lead_paragraph: The smart advice during a falling stock market is not to panic. Selling out of panic often leads investors to miss out on the market recoveries that typically follow a drop, because it’s all but impossible to predict when such a recovery will begin.

headline: Popcast: ‘Where Are Ü Now’
abstract: Times music critics discuss the intention of the song, and its possible yearning to override predetermined systems of songwriting, technology and artistic persona.
lead_paragraph: “Where Are Ü Now,” released last February and a contender for consensual song-of-the-summer status, was a result of a fairly typical songwriting process: piano chord changes and a sung topline, later developed through digital manipulations into a dance track. The singer was Justin Bieber (who developed the core of the song with his collaborator Poo Bear), and the digital manipulators were Skrillex and Diplo, who were putting together their “Jack U” collaboration album.

headline: Bets That the Fed Will Delay Interest Rate Rise Could Be Premature
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: As stocks slumped, sentiment grew among investors that the central bank, which takes a broad view of the economy, would hold off on raising rates this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As markets quake and stock prices fall, investors increasingly are betting that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates this year.

headline: The Inside History of ‘Where Are Ü Now’
abstract: How Diplo and Skrillex turned a ballad by Justin Bieber into an E.D.M hit.
lead_paragraph: On the radio, where it has been ubiquitous all summer, the million-selling single “Where Are Ü Now” by Skrillex and Diplo with Justin Bieber is four minutes of high-tech bliss: a sweet-voiced mixture of longing and recrimination, a lonely plaint with a dance beat.

headline: Why Vouchers Won’t Fix Vegas Schools
abstract: Paying families to leave the school system won’t help low-income students, or their struggling families.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — FOR the past year, I’ve lived next door to a public elementary school. With my windows open in the morning, I can hear children’s laughter on the playground, and at 9 a.m., the Pledge of Allegiance over the intercom. My afternoon commute takes me past the entrance, where I see a diverse group of parents collecting their children, from white moms in yoga pants to Muslim women in hijab guiding their kids carefully through the crosswalk.

headline: 1890: Kerchief Keeper Called Insane
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A handkerchief collector is sent to an asylum in Vienna in 1890.
lead_paragraph: There is good news from Vienna. A man who has devoted himself to collecting ladies’ handkerchiefs has been decided to be insane and has been placed in an asylum. If the collector of handkerchiefs is adjudged to be a lunatic, how can the collector of postage stamps be regarded as sane? Handkerchiefs have an intrinsic value and ladies’ handkerchiefs may be full of poetic and sacred associations, whereas the used postage stamp is valueless, ugly and devoid of any associations worth mentioning. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 26, 1890

headline: Readers’ Turn: Eliminate Fafsa?

lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

lead_paragraph: Cornel West, the influential scholar and civil rights activist, has endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders for president, bolstering a candidate who has drawn huge crowds but also skepticism from black voters.

lead_paragraph: When thinking about the market madness and its possible real effects, here’s something you — where by “you” I mean the Fed in particular — really, really need to keep in mind: the markets have already, in effect, tightened monetary conditions quite a lot.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The Belgian authorities carried out searches Monday night in an operation linked to the attack last week on a high-speed train traveling to Paris from Amsterdam. No arrests were made.

headline: The Cost of Lower Standards for Women in Marine Recruitment
keywords: ['Gender', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: By forcing women to adhere to a lower standard than men, and by effectively punishing them for exceeding their given standard, the Marine Corps is setting them up for failure, Kyleanne Hunter writes.
lead_paragraph: The recent success of two female officers, both West Point graduates, in passing the Army’s grueling Ranger School has bolstered arguments for the full integration of women into the military’s front-line combat units. In becoming the first women to receive the coveted Ranger tab, the two officers proved that women can handle not just the physical challenges but also the psychological and leadership tests posed by the nine-week course.

headline: Showing Courage on Iran
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vetoes (US)']
abstract: Rep. Jerrold Nadler was right about Iraq. That should give some weight to his support for the Iran deal.
lead_paragraph: Intense lobbying and heated (often demagogic and hateful) rhetoric has made deciding whether to support the Iran nuclear deal an excruciating process for many members of Congress. None have come under more pressure and scrutiny than Jewish-American lawmakers. And among those, Representative Jerrold Nadler stands out. He represents a district of New York City from the liberal Upper West Side to ultra-Orthodox Borough Park in Brooklyn that is believed to have the largest Jewish population in the country.

headline: U.N. Predicts 3,000 Migrants a Day Will Pass Through Balkans
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police', 'Neo Nazi Groups']
abstract: The forecast came a few hours after a sports hall intended to shelter asylum seekers burned down in Germany, which has taken in more migrants than any other country in Europe.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Three thousand migrants a day will pour into the Balkans trying to reach Western Europe in the next few months, the United Nations forecast on Tuesday, a few hours after a suspected arson attack destroyed a sports hall in Germany where some migrants were to be sheltered.

headline: Unnatural Obsessions
abstract: Always time for a rate hike.
lead_paragraph: One enduring constant of the world economy since 2008 is the chorus of sober-sounding people declaring that the Fed must act responsibly and raise rates. A few years back, rising commodity prices and a flood of money into emerging markets were proof that low rates were dangerously inflationary and must be hiked. Now we have plunging commodity prices and a flood of money out of emerging markets; clearly, this shows that the Fed must do the right thing, and raise rates.

headline: Guatemala’s Corruption Investigations Make Swift Strides
abstract: High-profile arrests and peaceful protests in a country long silenced by civil war raise a question: Will lasting change occur?
lead_paragraph: GUATEMALA CITY — Just about every weekend for months, Jorge Castiglione, a 70-year-old engineer with a thinning ponytail, has gone to the Plaza de la Constitución here to support what has become a ritual in this nation: weekly protests calling for the resignation of the president and an end to political impunity.

headline: 1965: French Find U.S. Worth a Visit
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. sees more and more French tourists in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French are discovering the United States, and finding it’s something to write home about. Following the ‘‘big’’ year of 1964, when the number of Frenchmen visiting the United States rose by 31.9 percent, and a continuing increase this year, French publishers are rushing travelogues into print. The reports go beyond the traditional observations about Americans putting mayonnaise on fruit salad. Articles and serials, some of them inspired by a Trans World Airlines tour of America for 25 French journalists in May, have appeared in publications throughout the country. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 26, 1965

headline: Pro-Choice Questions, Pro-Life Answers, Part II
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Miscarriages', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A further response to Katha Pollitt on abortion.
lead_paragraph: This the second part of my extended response to Katha Pollitt’s questions for abortion opponents, inspired by the still-ongoing release of Planned Parenthood sting videos; you can find the first half of my response here. If you like you can consider this a strange sort of counterprogramming for the global economy’s current China-driven jitters, and fear not: Full-spectrum Trump coverage will no doubt resume shortly.

headline: Marco Rubio to Take On China in Foreign Policy Address
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

headline: The Crimes of Palmyra
keywords: ['Editorials', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Assyrian Civilization', 'Terrorism', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Islamic State’s destruction of Palmyra’s ancient ruins is not only a crime against Syria but a tragedy for collective human history.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State, the ultrafundamentalist group better known as ISIS, has laid a trail of unspeakable horrors in its march through Syria and Iraq — videotaped beheadings, ritualized rape and all manner of grisly torture and murder of anyone who does not subscribe to its extreme version of Islam.

headline: Following the March of Migrants Along the Balkans
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Alison Smale provides an in-depth account of her reporting on the tens of thousands of migrants traveling across the Balkans, a movable feast of despair.
lead_paragraph: I set out from my base in Berlin for southern Hungary to write about the wave of tens of thousands of migrants and refugees — many fleeing wars in Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan — that has worked its way up the length of the Balkans in recent days. How, I wondered, even with the skills of our local fixer and translator, Helene Bienvenu, might one expect to find migrants on the move? Or officials willing to talk about the challenges.

headline: London Theater Journal: En Travesti, Both Sides Now
abstract: David Suchet plays Lady Bracknell in Oscar Wilde’s “Importance of Being Earnest” at the Vaudeville Theater and, across the river, Michelle Terry is the cross-dressing heroine of “As You Like It” at Shakespeare’s Globe.

People are of, course, queuing up to witness Benedict Cumberbatch, who plays the problem-solving title character of the BBC’s “Sherlock,” transform himself into the problem-evading Prince Hamlet at the Barbican.

headline: A 21st-Century Migrant’s Essentials: Food, Shelter, Smartphone
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Smartphones', 'Social Media', 'Human Trafficking', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: For the tens of thousands of migrants flooding into Europe, smartphone maps, global positioning apps, social media and WhatsApp have become essential tools.

But there is also one other thing they swear they cannot live without: a smartphone charging station.

headline: Donald Trump, the Green Lantern Candidate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: Mr. Trump, with a brash style but no superpowers that we know of, is exploiting the myth of an all-powerful president.
lead_paragraph: Why is Donald Trump leading the polls in the G.O.P. presidential race? One explanation is his celebrity and the media attention he attracts. But he has also exploited our vulnerability to pleasing fictions about presidential power.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Clocktower in Midtown South
abstract: The Clocktower, in the New York Edition hotel, is a Stephen Starr restaurant with the English chef Jason Atherton in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: If you hope dinner at the Clocktower will get you a backstage view of the ticking cogs at the top of the former Metropolitan Life Tower, forget it. The restaurant is on the second floor of the New York Edition hotel, which opened in the skyscraper at the foot of Madison Avenue in May. Marriott and Ian Schrager, who run the place, brought in the restaurateur Stephen Starr to operate the Clocktower.

headline: New Jersey’s $225 Million Settlement With Exxon Mobil Is Approved

headline: Museums Engage in Virtual Collection Swap Via Instagram

headline: Anna Kashfi, Actress Who Was Brando’s First Wife, Dies at 80
abstract: Ms. Kashfi, whose background was much disputed, was married to Brando for just two years and was the mother of their son, Christian.
lead_paragraph: Anna Kashfi, an actress who appeared in several Hollywood films in parts calling for, in the parlance of the day, an exotic beauty, but who became better known for playing a continuing role in a real-life soap opera as Marlon Brando’s first wife, died on Aug. 16 in Woodland, Wash. She was 80.

headline: French Prosecutor Discusses Train Attack

headline: Julianne Moore and Film Producer Start Petition to Remove Confederate General From School Name
abstract: Both are alumni of J.E.B. Stuart High in Fairfax, Va., and want to rename it after Thurgood Marshall.
lead_paragraph: The fight against Confederate symbols nationwide has lined up some Hollywood supporters. Julianne Moore and the film producer Bruce Cohen have started a Change.org petition to rename their high school, J.E.B. Stuart High in Fairfax County, Va. Founded in 1959, the school was named for a Confederate general who befriended Robert E. Lee during their West Point days. The name was chosen, the petition says, as a rebuke against the 1954 Brown v. Board of Education ruling that ended public school segregation.

headline: Russia Gives Ukrainian Filmmaker Oleg Sentsov a 20-Year Sentence
abstract: The filmmaker, Oleg Sentsov, was convicted of terrorist acts in the Crimean Peninsula, which Russia annexed last year.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian military court sentenced a Ukrainian filmmaker, Oleg Sentsov, to 20 years in a prison camp on Tuesday after convicting him of terrorism in the Crimean Peninsula after its annexation by Russia last year.

headline: Bold Fall Fashion, Grounded in Boyish Basics

headline: A Corn Gratin Welcomes Chard Into the Fold
abstract: Blanched and chopped, the hardy and versatile summer green jumps into the mix.
lead_paragraph: A neighbor posted on our shared email list that she had harvested from her garden more chard than she could use. If anybody wanted it, she would leave it on her front porch for pickup.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 9 | My Jon Stewart Withdrawal Syndrome
abstract: Our top winner is Arjun Ganga, who wrote about how Jon Stewart helped prepare him for adulthood. We also selected 19 runners-up and 23 honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: Week 9 of our Summer Reading Contests delivered so many outstanding entries from students that we had trouble choosing our favorites.

headline: Jeb Bush Falls Into a Trap
abstract: The Republicans' immigration expert takes the issue on, really, really badly.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush went to the border town of McAllen, Tex., on Monday to raise money and to talk about immigration, in English and fluent Spanish. Because the Republican presidential campaign has been so fixated on border security and the immigrant peril — thank you, Donald Trump — it was a chance to see how the supposed expert on this fraught subject handled it.

headline: Sheen Center Announces Lineup for Opening Festival
abstract: A new arts center in Greenwich Village run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York aims to attract Catholics and non-Catholics alike.
lead_paragraph: Sacred dance from several traditions, a Hollywood premiere, panels on religion and politics, and “an evening of music and chocolate” are among the events scheduled for the three-week grand opening festival of the Sheen Center for Thought and Culture, a new arts center on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village run by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

headline: Vaucluse Moves In on the Upper East Side
abstract: The Altamarea Group is turning to France for inspiration; the actor Chazz Palminteri will open a place; and more.
lead_paragraph: Vaucluse Proof that the Upper East Side is not prepared to abandon elegance in favor of salvaged barn siding comes with this palatial new restaurant from Michael White and Ahmass Fakahany, partners in the Altamarea Group. With well-mannered neutral-toned surroundings and white tablecloths, they have turned to France for inspiration instead of their usual Italy. Mr. Fakahany pointed out that several French restaurants, including Voisin and Le Périgord Park, have anchored the space, and Mr. White has cooked in France with Roger Vergé and Jacques Chibois. “I can now use lavender, thyme and bay, ingredients that I don’t get to use often,” Mr. White said. Though the name refers to a region of Provence, the food is not Provençal. The menu is broad brasserie-style, offering sections devoted to chilled seafood, vegetables, starters, fresh pastas, main courses and a list of daily specials like blanquette de veau (Tuesdays). The executive chef is Jared Gadbaw. The bar area on the mezzanine has been widened, and a stunning vaulted ceiling has been uncovered; the light fixtures suggest Art Deco. The dining room on the upper level is somewhat less formal-looking than the main room and is accented with cushy dark-sea-green leather chairs. (Opens Sept. 2): 100 East 63rd Street, vauclusenyc.com.

headline: Boy Avoids a Fall, but Punches a Hole in a $1.5 Million Painting
abstract: A 12-year-old in Taiwan tripped at a museum and caught his balance, damaging a Paolo Porpora work.
lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old in Taiwan lived out many museum-goers’ nightmare (and many parents’) when he tripped and caught his balance by punching a hole in an oil painting that is over 300 years old and valued at $1.5 million.

headline: Joe Biden to Hold Unusual Call With Democratic Party Officials
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. may not be attending the Democratic National Committee’s summer meeting this week, but he’s making his presence felt as he mulls a run for the party’s 2016 presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. may not be attending the Democratic National Committee’s summer meeting this week, but he’s making his presence felt as he mulls a run for the party’s 2016 presidential nomination against Hillary Rodham Clinton, Bernie Sanders and others who will be speaking at the party gathering.

headline: Test for Donald Trump: Turning Crowds Into Real Voters
abstract: Donald J. Trump is putting in place a robust field operation in Iowa, but converting raucous crowds into votes in primaries and caucuses remains a challenge.
lead_paragraph: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump, it is abundantly clear, is not a conventional candidate. And neither is his approach to recruiting campaign activists.

headline: The Price of Silence on Wall Street
abstract: Barclays offered a termination deal to Peter Sivere, a compliance officer and whistle-blower, but he chose instead to take his story public.
lead_paragraph: What is the price of silence on Wall Street? That is the question confronting Peter Sivere, a 46-year-old soon-to-be former compliance officer at Barclays in New York.

headline: Patty Murray Comes Out in Support of Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the only member of the Democratic leadership who had not weighed in on the Iran nuclear deal, broke her silence and backed it, saying it was “the best chance we have at a strong diplomatic solution.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Patty Murray of Washington, the only member of the Democratic leadership who had not weighed in on the Iran nuclear deal, broke her silence on Tuesday and threw her weight behind the accord.

headline: Adam Lippes’s Guide to the Berkshires
abstract: The designer recommends things to do, eat and see near his home in Monterey, Mass.
lead_paragraph: “The Berkshires are so not about fashion,” says the designer Adam Lippes, summing up the appeal of his country escape in the mountains of western Massachusetts. “I love that the spirit of the area is so eclectic and genuine. It’s this non-high-heel lifestyle.”

headline: Curt Schilling Off Little League Broadcasts After ‘Unacceptable’ Tweet
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Little League World Series']
abstract: ESPN pulled Schilling from a Little League World Series broadcast on Tuesday after he wrote a post on Twitter comparing Muslims to Nazi-era Germans.
lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling, the ESPN “Sunday Night Baseball” analyst and former major league pitcher, was pulled from calling a Little League World Series game Tuesday night because of a post he shared on his Twitter account that suggested extremist Muslims were comparable to Nazis. The post featured an image of Adolf Hitler.

headline: South Florida’s Construction Boom Heads North
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Condominiums', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Developers have little room to maneuver in the Miami Beach area, so they’re moving to Broward County, which has beachfront locations and cheaper land, but lacks charisma.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Known for years as little more than a retirement community with a racetrack and a few pastel-hued motels that had seen better days, this small oceanfront town is not the first place that comes to mind when wealthy Brazilians and Russians seek out expensive condominiums.

headline: In Colorado, Bush Explains Asian Comment
abstract: Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, responded on Tuesday to a question about his use of the term “anchor babies.”
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, responded on Tuesday to a question about his use of the term “anchor babies.”

headline: Israel Begins Releasing African Migrants From Detention Center
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The move complied with a recent Supreme Court ruling that reduced the time that migrants could be held at the center.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel began releasing hundreds of African migrants and asylum seekers from a detention center in the southern Negev desert on Tuesday, in line with a recent Supreme Court ruling that reduced the time they could be held there to 12 months from 20 months.

headline: Math Anxiety? A Reporter Knows the Subject All Too Well
abstract: The reporter Jan Hoffman writes about the personal story behind her article about well-intentioned parents who transmit math anxiety to their children.
lead_paragraph: I know exactly when my severe math anxiety began: with my third-grade teacher, Miss S. (I am afraid to write her full name because even if she is no longer among the living, her ghost will most certainly come roaring back and thrust more work sheets at me).

headline: The Idea Lab Behind Harry & Ida’s
abstract: Siblings and their friends take a science-fair approach to food with delicious results.
lead_paragraph: Siblings and their friends take a science-fair approach to food with delicious results.

headline: The Family Spirit of Harry & Ida’s and Ducks Eatery
abstract: A young crew in the spirit of a 1970s-style theater troupe drive Harry & Ida’s and Ducks Eatery.
lead_paragraph: It is possible to wander into Harry & Ida’s Meat and Supply Co., a delicatessen and provisions shop that opened in June in the East Village, with expectations of nothing more than a good pastrami sandwich.

headline: Fall of ‘Beirut Wall’ Reminds Some of Berlin, Others of Miley Cyrus
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Social Media', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Lebanese officials, who were mocked on Monday for sealing themselves off from protesters, were mocked again for giving up on that plan on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Lebanese officials might still be struggling to solve the trash crisis engulfing Beirut, but they seemed to acknowledge on Tuesday that blocking themselves off from protesters enraged by the stench behind a high concrete wall was not helping.

headline: Alibaba’s Stock Still Looks Expensive
abstract: Growth worries have afflicted all technology stocks and Chinese ones in particular. But Alibaba’s core e-commerce business is still highly valued compared with its rivals.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba’s stock price still looks expensive despite the recent sell-off. Less than a year after the Chinese web giant’s record $25 billion initial public offering of stock, its shares are near their $68 initial price. Though macroeconomic worries have afflicted all Chinese companies, the company, founded by Jack Ma, is still highly valued when compared with rivals.

headline: On the Road, in Accessories Form
abstract: The designer Adam Davidson of AANDD rethought ’70s driving paraphernalia for his collection of small leather goods.
lead_paragraph: “I might have an escape fantasy,” suggests the New York-based accessories designer Adam Davidson of AANDD, speaking to T from a factory in Mexico. “I certainly fixate on modes of travel,” he continues, mentioning that many of the five-year-old brand’s early shapes and detailing relied on nautical references. For his fall 2015 collection — which includes, for the first time, small leather goods — Davidson found himself thinking about the open road. His Accordion Wallet streamlines motorcyclists’ money-holders and the Key Lanyard resembles the hooded fobs once commonly affixed to car keys. The currant, ochre, white and cobalt blue (or “mineral”) of 1970s auto upholstery hold together the line that’s rounded out by AANDD staples, like the Pyramid Pouch, inspired by a knotted bodega bag. “It’s not a noble inspiration, but it has a good attitude that I can reinterpret in my own aesthetic,” Davidson says. “I’m always watching the way people carry things, wherever I am.”

headline: Political Risks May Foil Economic Reform in China
abstract: There is scant historical evidence that an authoritarian, undemocratic government like China’s could pull off the kinds of reforms it is being called on to make.
lead_paragraph: Can China pull it off?

headline: Under Armour Seeks to Do for Maryland What Nike Did for Oregon
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Uniforms', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment']
abstract: The University of Maryland is trying to emulate the University of Oregon, riding the largess of a multibillion-dollar apparel company to athletic prominence.
lead_paragraph: Within a few years, the midcentury red-brick field house in the center of the University of Maryland campus will be a glassy, sunlit home of medical facilities and classrooms, as well as an athletic conditioning center, a locker room and three football fields — two outdoors and one inside.

headline: Review: ‘Billion-Dollar Ball’ Explores the Economics of College Football’s Top Programs
abstract: In this book, Gilbert M. Gaul examines how a small percentage of teams generate big revenue, often leaving others to sustain losses while trying to keep pace.
lead_paragraph: When it is reported that the University of Alabama pays its head coach an annual salary of $6.5 million a year, or that the University of Oregon erected a $42 million academic support center for it players, or that the University of Texas assesses its fans as much as $20,000 in the form of “seat donations” for preferred locations, it is clear that college football is no longer just a game.

headline: Serena Williams, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi Play Tennis in the Street
abstract: Tennis greats convened for a U.S.-Open-themed spectacle.
lead_paragraph: Tennis greats convened for a U.S.-Open-themed spectacle.

headline: American Coaches Have a Field Day, but for Other Countries
abstract: Randy Huntington of Michigan led the Chinese to their first long-jump medal at a global championships on Tuesday, and the top two finishers — British and Australian — are also coached by an American.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Randy Huntington’s laugh boomed through the hallways of the Bird’s Nest stadium after the long jump competition, making him something of a rarity at the world track and field championships on Tuesday: an American with something to celebrate.

headline: Sydney Theater Company Names New Artistic Director
abstract: The artistic director of the Chichester Festival Theater, Jonathan Church, has been picked to lead the Sydney Theater Company, replacing Andrew Upton.
lead_paragraph: After months of speculation, the Sydney Theater Company has appointed a new artistic director to succeed Andrew Upton, who announced his exit from the position in February.

headline: Tennis Greats Convene for a U.S.-Open-Themed Spectacle
abstract: Pete Sampras, Andre Agassi, Serena Williams and more played tennis in the street in front of fans last night.
lead_paragraph: In 1995, Andre Agassi and Pete Sampras appeared together in a commercial for Nike. In the ad, a taxi pulls up to a bustling New York intersection; the players run onto the street, unfurl a net and begin a game of pick-up tennis. Last night, in honor of its 20th anniversary — and to mark the 2015 U.S. Open, which begins next week — Sampras and Agassi reconvened to restage the ad, taxi and all, in another made-for-TV (and now, publicist-orchestrated) moment: They played a quick round of tennis in front of fans on a pop-up tennis court in the Meatpacking District. They were joined by Serena Williams, Maria Sharapova, Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer — and many more. Photographer Dina Litovsky was on hand to capture the scene.

headline: How Stressful Work Environments Hurt Workers’ Health
abstract: Workplace stress is about as dangerous to workers’ health as secondhand smoke, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people would not work in a place where co-workers smoke. And most people will never be faced with that decision because smoking is typically banned in the workplace on the sensible ground that secondhand smoke is dangerous to everyone.

headline: Chris Christie Pushes Cory Booker to Oppose Iran Deal
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey urges Senator Cory Booker to oppose President Obama’s deal to curtail Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie stood before an audience on Tuesday as “the leader of our state,” the golden seal of New Jersey adorning the lectern before him, and excoriated President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran, accusing the president of lying to the American people and putting the entire world in danger.

headline: Rutgers Investigating Football Coach Over Possible N.C.A.A. Violation
abstract: The coach, Kyle Flood, was said to have emailed a faculty member about a star player’s grade.
lead_paragraph: Rutgers confirmed Tuesday that it was investigating its football coach, Kyle Flood, over an allegation that he improperly contacted a faculty member about the academic status of a top player.

headline: Midwest Gasoline Prices to Normalize After BP Refinery Repair
abstract: Gas prices in the Great Lakes states had jumped after a distillation unit at a BP refinery outside Chicago broke down on Aug. 8.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — BP has restarted a large distillation unit at a refinery outside Chicago that broke down on Aug. 8 and caused a jump in gasoline prices across the Midwest.

abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of “Blue: The LAPD and the Battle to Redeem American Policing” and more.
lead_paragraph: L.A. Laws

headline: Lebanon’s Garbage Crisis Underscores Government’s Disarray
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: As bids for new collection contracts were rejected, the prime minister gave up on an attempt to keep the protest movement known as “You Stink” at bay.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The haplessness of the Lebanese government was evident on Tuesday when its attempts to contain a political crisis over festering garbage were thwarted on several fronts.

headline: Looking Back on ‘Mr. Robot’ and a Season of Hacker Drama
abstract: This USA show’s star, Rami Malek, and its creator, Sam Esmail, discuss sociopolitical causes, millennial angst, loneliness and the joys of voice-over.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene during the sixth episode of USA’s “Mr. Robot” in which the lead character, a painfully anxious computer hacker named Elliot, pulls off an extraordinary feat. He cripples a prison’s security system to free a single inmate: a drug dealer whose thugs have been holding Elliot’s girlfriend captive. After he frees the bad guy, he is handed the keys to the car he’s been riding around in all day. In the trunk lies his girlfriend, dead.

headline: 10 Things That Influence Ira Kaplan
abstract: The Yo La Tengo musician shares the diverse inspirations — from bakeries to baseball announcers — that have inspired his music.
lead_paragraph: The Yo La Tengo musician shares the diverse inspirations — from bakeries to baseball announcers — that have inspired his music.

headline: Twyla Tharp’s Rehearsal: On Day Eight, Just One More Time
abstract: With 14 rehearsal days left before starting my 50th Anniversary Tour, it is harvest time.
lead_paragraph: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

headline: Viola Davis, on Finding Creative Space in TV With No Limitations
abstract: The “How to Get Away With Murder” actress, a two-time Tony winner and Oscar nominee, talks about being nervous about the Emmy Awards and about other projects.
lead_paragraph: Viola Davis is a two-time Tony winner and Oscar nominee and yet she had to go to television to find a role that would put her out front in Hollywood. “I was always the Academy Award nominee who was only in two or three scenes and was grossly underused in a film,” she says. “I was tired of that. I didn’t want to do television, but in film I was just a supporting character. The fear of the television schedule ultimately did not outweigh my love for the role.”

headline: ‘Queen of Earth’ (With Movie Trailer): Alex Ross Perry Narrates a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Alex Ross Perry narrates a sequence from “Queen of Earth,” featuring Elisabeth Moss.
lead_paragraph: What was meant to be a relaxing time away at a vacation house turns to anguish in “Queen of Earth,” Alex Ross Perry’s intimate, fractured follow-up to his 2014 literary comedy, “Listen Up Philip.” Here, the writer and director departs from the humor and coyness of his previous work and uses tools from the ’70s psychodrama playbook to tell the story of Catherine (Elisabeth Moss) and Virginia (Katherine Waterston), two women whose friendship begins to disintegrate as Catherine becomes more distant and isolated. In this scene, Catherine attends a party that turns out none too cheerful.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Queen of Earth’
abstract: Alex Ross Perry narrates a sequence from “Queen of Earth” with Elisabeth Moss.
lead_paragraph: Alex Ross Perry narrates a sequence from “Queen of Earth” with Elisabeth Moss.

headline: Review: ‘The Carmichael Show,’ With Jabs and Jokes, Has Its Debut on NBC
abstract: This sitcom, which features the stand-up comic Jerrod Carmichael, makes an effort to include some controversial topics amid its one-liners.
lead_paragraph: You remember your mother’s admonition: “If you can’t say something nice, don’t say anything at all.” In that spirit, let’s just say that “The Carmichael Show,” a comedy that begins Wednesday on NBC, is marginally better than the awful “Mr. Robinson,” another comedy the network disgorged this month.

headline: Review: Elisabeth Moss at All Angles in ‘Queen of Earth’
abstract: Alex Ross Perry’s narrative experiment, starring Katherine Waterston and Ms. Moss, turns out to be an art house film in quotation marks.
lead_paragraph: When you first see Catherine, she’s looking upward, her teary, blotchy face filling the frame. She’s suffering, all right, you better believe it, although she doesn’t seem to be doing a particularly good job of convincing the guy who’s mostly off-camera. She looks like a mess — pathetic, really, with her smeared black eye makeup and the tears that just keep pooling and dribbling. The funny thing is that with her wet raccoon eyes and red nose, Catherine — a sensational Elisabeth Moss — also looks like a sad clown. All that’s missing is the black velvet background.

headline: Yo La Tengo’s Ira Kaplan on 10 of His Influences
abstract: The musician shares the books, bands and bakeries that have helped to shape his work.
lead_paragraph: Of all the indie bands considered indispensable to the ’80s and ’90s underground, perhaps none have aged more gracefully, or with as little ceremony, as New Jersey’s own Yo La Tengo. The husband-wife team of Ira Kaplan and Georgia Hubley, along with bassist James McNew, who joined the band in 1992, are known equally well for their heart-rending melodies as they are for ear-splitting guitars. For Yo La Tengo’s new record, “Stuff Like That There,” which falls firmly in the former category, the band looks backward to “Fakebook,” an LP that came that out 25 years ago and remains a fan favorite today. Like its predecessor, “Stuff Like That There” is made up predominantly of covers — both of classic acts (Hank Williams, The Cure) and of Yo La Tengo themselves (“Deeper Into Movies,” “The Ballad of Red Buckets”). “We kind of took some of the things from ‘Fakebook’ and said, ‘It’s 25 years later, let’s see what happens if we do it again.’ It’s definitely a companion, in our mind,” Kaplan says.

headline: Review: Benedict Cumberbatch in ‘Hamlet’

lead_paragraph: LONDON — He is, he complains sulkily, “too much in the sun.” That is correct on so many levels.

headline: Weighing the Odds in Fight Over Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Vetoes (US)', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The coming fight over the disapproval of the nuclear agreement with Iran raises the possibility of another national security veto clash between Congress and the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Congress passes foreign policy legislation that the president strongly opposes, he vetoes the bill, saying it unlawfully restricts executive authority. Lawmakers refuse to accept the action and override the veto, with the Senate quickly following the House.

abstract: The new NBC family sitcom stars the rising comic Jerrod Carmichael.
lead_paragraph: The new NBC family sitcom stars the rising comic Jerrod Carmichael.

headline: On YouTube, Iran Activists Urge America to Back Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Social Media', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The messages of support from Iranian human rights activists are a new element in the emotional campaigns for and against the deal in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of Iranian human rights activists and artists, including a Nobel laureate and people who have spent time in prison for their views, are asking Americans in a social media campaign to support the nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: Trump-ward, Christian Soldiers?
abstract: The veneration of The Donald affirms the selective morality of the religious right.
lead_paragraph: Let me get this straight. If I want the admiration and blessings of the most flamboyant, judgmental Christians in America, I should marry three times, do a queasy-making amount of sexual boasting, verbally degrade women, talk trash about pretty much everyone else while I’m at it, encourage gamblers to hemorrhage their savings in casinos bearing my name and crow incessantly about how much money I’ve amassed?

headline: American Pharoah Is 1-5 Morning-Line Favorite in Travers Stakes
abstract: The Triple Crown winner American Pharoah has not lost since his debut more than a year ago, winning eight straight races with one breathtaking performance after another.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Three Triple Crown champions over the years have ventured to the historic racetrack here, amid mineral springs and pastel-colored Victorian houses, to compete in what is called the Midsummer Derby, the Travers Stakes. Only one, Whirlaway in 1941, left victorious.

headline: Luxury Shoppers in London Seem Unfazed by Market Free Fall
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Despite creeping fears worldwide of a global economic meltdown, high-end consumers continued to patronize some of Britain’s ritziest stores.
lead_paragraph: London — Twenty-four hours after the world’s financial markets sustained a temporary free fall, wiping out almost $3 trillion in value from global stocks over three days, the dark clouds had yet to dampen the spirits of luxury shoppers on the streets of London.

headline: Review: ‘No Escape,’ Starring Owen Wilson as a Man in the Cross Hairs
abstract: An American businessman and his family are trapped in the middle of a gruesome uprising in a Southeast Asian country.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, already developing a comic acting career, Owen Wilson tried to stretch. In “Behind Enemy Lines,” he played a naval aviator shot down and pursued by bloodthirsty Serbian paramilitary units. Not quite an action hero, he conveyed the intense fear and desperation of a fugitive in the cross hairs.

headline: A Conversation With David von Spreckelsen
abstract: Mr. von Spreckelsen is president of Toll Brothers City Living, New York, a division of the luxury home builder Toll Brothers that he started in 2004
lead_paragraph: Mr. von Spreckelsen, 52, is the president of Toll Brothers City Living, New York, a division of the luxury home builder Toll Brothers that he started in 2004. Its current condominium projects include 400 Park Avenue South and the Pierhouse at Brooklyn Bridge Park.

headline: In Latin America’s Rich Lands, Poor People
abstract: As Gustavo Jononovich documented, the bounty of natural resources in Latin America can sustain a community, but also destroy it through pollution and overdevelopment.
lead_paragraph: As Gustavo Jononovich documented, the bounty of natural resources in Latin America can sustain a community, but also destroy it through pollution and overdevelopment.

lead_paragraph: Silvermine, an enclave that overlaps Norwalk, Wilton and New Canaan, Conn., has a cachet bound up with its past.

headline: Inquiry Weighs Whether ISIS Analysis Was Distorted
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The inspector general is looking into a claim that military officials reworked assessments about the U.S.-led campaign in Iraq against ISIS to be more optimistic, according to several officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon’s inspector general is investigating allegations that military officials have skewed intelligence assessments about the United States-led campaign in Iraq against the Islamic State to provide a more optimistic account of progress, according to several officials familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Malia Obama, Fashion Influencer
abstract: The first daughter employs bold colors and patterns but manages to come across as an approachable teen.
lead_paragraph: The first daughter employs bold colors and patterns but manages to come across as an approachable teen.

headline: Review: Taking In the New York International Fringe Festival, From Ferry to Theater
abstract: With nearly 200 productions, navigating this festival can be difficult, but it can also be a surprisingly happy theatergoing experience.
lead_paragraph: The tall young man in the baseball cap was upwind of me, which should have made me cautious, but my attention was a bit divided. It was Monday night and I was at a play, part of the New York International Fringe Festival. I was also standing at a railing on the Staten Island Ferry as it churned toward Manhattan, and the actor Tom Nelis was speaking into my ear.

headline: New Superintendent Named at New York Prison Where Inmate Died
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The new superintendent at Fishkill Correctional Facility, Robert Cunningham, is tasked with focusing on a section of the prison where Samuel Harrell, an inmate, died after an encounter with guards.
lead_paragraph: The state corrections department on Tuesday named a new superintendent for the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., and vowed to review “safety concerns” after the April death of a prisoner who inmates said was handcuffed and badly beaten by a group of corrections officers.

headline: Just Mayo Spread Violates Mayonnaise and Label Rules, F.D.A. Says
abstract: The agency told Hampton Creek, which makes Just Mayo, that the term “mayo” and the egg logo “may be misleading” by implying the products contain eggs.

headline: Among Friends: Linda Rosenkrantz on ‘Talk’
abstract: Ms. Rosenkrantz discusses her recently reissued 1968 book, which is made up of candid conversations about psychoanalysis, sex and art.
lead_paragraph: Linda Rosenkrantz spent the summer of 1965 in East Hampton recording conversations between herself and two close friends. The resulting book, “Talk,” is formatted like a play, with the three characters discussing their ambitions in the buzzing 1960s New York City art world and cultural sea changes in psychoanalysis and sexual politics. (“How does a ménage à trois work?” someone asks. “Doesn’t it make you feel competitive?”) When it was published in 1968, the book was called fiction.

The assertion, by Hassan Qashqavi, deputy foreign minister for consular, parliamentary and expatriates’ affairs, was a response to what he described as news media reports about such an exchange. “There are no talks on the swap of Jason Rezaian,” he was quoted as saying.

headline: China: Legal Ordeals for Brothers of a Journalist
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'News and News Media', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: A court in China’s western region of Xinjiang tried two brothers of an American reporter on charges of endangering state security and leaking secrets.
lead_paragraph: A court in China’s western region of Xinjiang tried two brothers of an American reporter on charges of endangering state security and leaking secrets, according to a spokesman for Radio Free Asia, the journalist’s employer. No verdict has yet been announced in the trials of Shawket Hoshur on Tuesday and his younger brother Rexim Hoshur, which took place on Aug. 19, Rohit Mahajan, a spokesman for the United States government-funded R.F.A., said in an interview. Their brother, Shohret Hoshur, is a United States citizen whose reports on the Chinese government’s crackdown on Xinjiang’s Uighur ethnic group have been criticized by Beijing. The plight of Shohret Hoshur’s brothers — a third brother, Tudaxun, was convicted of endangering state security last year and sentenced to five years in prison — has become an issue between the two countries before President Xi Jinping’s summit meeting with President Obama in Washington next month.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:45 P.M. (IFC) SNAKES ON A PLANE (2006) The F.B.I. agent Neville Flynn (Samuel L. Jackson) is escorting a witness on a flight to Los Angeles to testify against the murderous gangster Eddie Kim (Byron Lawson). Kim makes sure that a lot of snakes are hidden in the plane’s cargo hold and that a pheromone is present that provokes them to attack. When the snakes slither into the cabin, Agent Flynn must leap into action. “There are snakes and smoke, giggles and shrieks, slamming edits and lots of goosy, lurch-in-your seat moments,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mostly, of course, there are snakes and Sam. At once hard-working and hardly working, Mr. Jackson turns in one of his customary performances, meaning that he glowers, barks and periodically unleashes a 13-letter epithet the way only he can.”

headline: False Alarm on a Crisis in China
abstract: Relax. What we’re seeing isn’t a meltdown, it’s an overdue correction.
lead_paragraph: Washington — CHINA, many believe, is in a financial and economic meltdown causing anxiety and panic everywhere. China’s stock market dive first dragged down other emerging markets and has now spread to the United States, slicing trillions of dollars off the value of stocks traded here and in other global markets. Since China is the world’s second largest economy and has growing financial ties around the world, developments there clearly have enormous potential implications for both developed and emerging markets.

headline: Silvermine, Conn., an Enclave Attached to Its Past
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Historic and artistic, Silvermine overlaps Norwalk, Wilton and New Canaan, Conn.
lead_paragraph: The Silvermine Tavern was once a defining landmark for the wooded Silvermine area that overlaps Norwalk, Wilton and New Canaan, Conn. Set along the Silvermine River among other historic buildings from the area’s early days as a mill village, the white-clapboard tavern in Norwalk drew out-of-towners with its reputation as a Sunday brunch destination, wedding backdrop and jazz spot. For locals, the tavern, in a 200-year-old building, provided something more fundamental.
