headline: Netflix Looks to ‘Narcos’ for a New Audience
abstract: The new series, a cops-and-smugglers tale, looks at the bloody rise of the Medellín cartel in Colombia in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: “Say yes to your life,” Nancy Reagan commands near the end of the first episode of Netflix’s new series “Narcos.” It’s a moment from the famous “Just Say No” speech that she delivered with her husband, President Ronald Reagan, in 1986. “And when it comes to drugs and alcohol,” she continues, “just say no.”

headline: ‘Paradise of the Pacific,’ by Susanna Moore
abstract: The novelist Susanna Moore explores the history and culture of Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: The most peculiar place on this planet, as I see it from my vantage point in Wales, is the 50th state of the American union, the Pacific archipelago called Hawaii. Everything about it is peculiar. Its capital, Honolulu, is one of the remotest big cities on the face of the earth. Its geography is weird, consisting as it does of some 130 assorted islands and atolls, scattered across 1,500 miles of ocean. Its history is spectacularly unexpected, beginning with mass immigrations of Pacific canoeists and culminating in the virtual extinction of an American fleet by several hundred Japanese airplanes. Its indigenous culture is a marvel of intricate legends, faiths, musics and superstitions, and its native written language is a prodigy of alliterations.

headline: ‘The Story of the Lost Child,’ by Elena Ferrante
abstract: In the fourth and final installment of Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan series, we have arrived at the 21st century and Elena, its narrator, is growing old.
lead_paragraph: Elena Ferrante has written her story twice: once in a group of intense, highly modeled short novels whose action unfolds over a brief time span; and again in the four sprawling, rambunctious, decades-spanning works that compose her Neapolitan saga. That these two modes of storytelling — the compact and the commodious; the modern and the historical; the distilling of life into metaphor and its picaresque, riotous expansion — are so obviously the obverse of each other constitutes yet another narrative, the story of how an individual (more specifically, a woman) arrives, after the ­vicissitudes of living, at a definition of self. “Do you want the long answer or the short?” is the customary divide between explanations versus outcomes in the retelling of events. Ferrante gives us both the long answer and the short, and in doing so adumbrates the mysterious beauty and brutality of personal experience.

headline: Today in Politics: Conference Call Could Give Democrats Reason to Hold for Joe Biden
abstract: As he ponders a possible presidential candidacy, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has invited hundreds of members of the Democratic National Committee to a conference call Wednesday afternoon to discuss provisions of the nuclear agreement with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning. Before telling a large crowd in Iowa that “the Summer of Trump” had been great for his ego, Donald J. Trump got into a heated exchange with a journalist from a Spanish-language network, adding to a season of early twists and surprises in both parties. And another could be in the works as Mr. Trump might have to soon move over to make room in the spotlight.

headline: Can I Wear Jewelry If I Don’t Support Its Origins?
abstract: The ethicists consider a sentimental necklace that goes against the letter writer’s values.
lead_paragraph: When my mother passed away, I inherited an antique necklace made of carved ivory beads. I love the look of — and am sentimentally tied to — this necklace, but I am also a supporter of anti-poaching programs and organizations. I have avoided wearing the necklace because I don’t want to appear to support the ivory trade. On the other hand, I hate not being able to wear one of the few pieces of jewelry that I have from my mother. What should I do with the necklace? J. F., TUSTIN, CALIF.

headline: Zip-a-Dee-Doo-#&$!
abstract: A mobile app turned voice recordings into 3-D animated videos. Americans were determined to put a twisted spin on them.
lead_paragraph: The creators of Zoobe intended to make their program cute, clean and simple: a mobile app that turns voice recordings into 3-D animated videos, starring woodland creatures with gigantic heads. It was introduced in 2013 as a playful alternative to text messaging and quickly became a hit on its home turf in Germany. Users record brief messages on their smartphones, and anthropomorphic beings recite them back, in a video that can be shared with friends or posted online. The craze soon spread to neighboring countries, especially social-media-obsessed Russia, spawning some 170 million short videos that delivered short messages from the app’s cast of bears, rabbits and foxes.

headline: Jamaica Will Always Be Home for Damian Marley
abstract: The son of the legendary reggae artist Bob Marley, who spends much of his time touring and also lives in Miami, talks about the joys of going back to Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: As a celebrated musician and bearer of the most recognizable name in reggae, Damian Marley is often on tour.

headline: Who Gets to Play Tennis?
abstract: On the South Side of Chicago, a campaign to diversify the game.
lead_paragraph: When the Hyde Park Racquet Club opened in the late 1970s, amid the country’s short-lived tennis boom, there wasn’t another indoor facility in Chicago for 10 miles. The club occupied a section of 47th Street, near the lake, that long served as the boundary between the aging mansions of Kenwood and the greater South Side beyond. Across the street was a record shop that sold house music and a drive-through liquor store that peddled home brew in gallon jugs with the promise ‘‘Won’t go flat!’’ In a hot-dog stand on the block, two teenagers once pummeled me with their fists while three of my tennis buddies could only watch, as we were useless at hitting anything other than yellow balls. The original owners of the club soon bailed. The many racquetball courts they had built went mostly unused. The sauna wasn’t properly ventilated and rotted the locker room. A fitness chain eventually rented the space, filling half the tennis courts with weight benches and treadmills; the other five courts remained playable but were invariably coated in tennis ball fuzz, many of their overhead lights askew and glaring or altogether dark.

headline: Larry King Is Preparing for the Final Cancellation
abstract: Five years after CNN pulled the plug on his show, the TV host is thinking about whom he’ll book for his funeral.
lead_paragraph: “Bring me a plate of radishes.’’

headline: 10 Years After Katrina
abstract: The New Orleans of 2015 has been altered, and not just by nature. In some ways, it is booming as never before. In others, it is returning to pre-Katrina realities of poverty and violence, but with a new sense of dislocation for many, too.
lead_paragraph: The New Orleans of 2015 has been altered, and not just by nature. In some ways, it is booming as never before. In others, it is returning to pre-Katrina realities of poverty and violence, but with a new sense of dislocation for many, too.

headline: $785,000 Homes in Maine, Seattle and Virginia
abstract: This week’s properties include a house with downtown views in Portland, Me., a floating house in Seattle, and a cabin in Onancock, Va.

headline: Vacation’s End
abstract: A picture book captures the bittersweet mood of the end of summer.
lead_paragraph: Among the possible drawbacks of a family vacation is that it requires leaving somewhere, then arriving somewhere, twice over. With certain children, that is far more challenging than it sounds. The narrator of “The Specific Ocean” is this kind of child – sensitive, internal, averse to change. She’s reluctant to leave her home and friends in the city for a trip to the beach far away. We see her curled up on her bed, wearing her backpack, as her father tries to lure her out the door. Even arriving at their breathtaking destination — “a boxy house on the Pacific Ocean” — does not impress her. There is “dull, droning, dreary water” all around. The next day she stays in the house while her mother and brother go down to the beach.

headline: Potential for Democratic Filibuster on Iran Deal Angers Key Republican

headline: 1940: London Bombed in Nazi Raid
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: London endures a long air raid in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The longest air raid London has undergone during the war, lasting almost six hours last night and early today, brought a scattering of bombs in the capital area and its outskirts. Flash followed flash as one raider dropped a salvo of bombs in a London area early this morning. The raider sped away, only to return from a different point some minutes later. Buildings were damaged on the outskirts of London by another salvo of bombs. Through the early morning hours the drone of German war planes continued. — New York Herald Tribune, August 27, 1940

headline: Ex-Broadcaster Kills 2 on Air in Virginia Shooting; Takes Own Life
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

And when he sought revenge on Wednesday, gunning down two former colleagues, he used the tools of social media to ensure that his crime was broadcast live, recorded from multiple angles and posted online.

headline: A Toothy Welcome to a Family Fish Restaurant on Long Island
abstract: On the roadside in Center Moriches, entered through a yawning shark’s mouth, Atlantic Seafood Restaurant and Fish Market offers a bounty of good will.
lead_paragraph: Heading out toward eastern Long Island, just before the patina of the Hamptons’ wealth starts to emerge, the Montauk Highway slips past quaint hamlets and faded farmhouses and watery fingers of Moriches Bay. On the roadside in Center Moriches, through a yawning shark’s mouth, Atlantic Seafood Restaurant and Fish Market offers a bounty from the sea — to eat in, take out or prepare at home — but the main attraction is the welcoming feel of the place, orchestrated by the establishment’s owner, Dennis Donovan, a local for 50 years.

headline: Vulture Populations Wane, Poisoned by Man
abstract: Birds that once feasted on misfortune are collapsing — part of a broader decline in vultures that illustrates the far-reaching effects of human interventions.
lead_paragraph: MASAI MARA NATIONAL RESERVE, Kenya — Death feeds life on the Mara.

headline: What We Learn From Old Recipes
abstract: The cookbooks of the past — free of today’s relentless ambition, optimization and ease — remind us what it means to be a human eater in the world.
lead_paragraph: Out with the old and in with the new! Or so the saying goes. But it often goes the opposite way for me: In a reading life full of recipes, I like old ones better. I didn’t realize how much, or why, until I recently started writing a book updating a hundred of them — mostly from the 20th century, but all with timeworn roots.

headline: ‘Landfalls,’ by Naomi J. Williams
abstract: Mostly true stories form a novel about an 18th-century French expedition across two oceans.
lead_paragraph: When the explorers in “Landfalls” confess their purpose — “We were . . . ready below with maps outspread and the journals of our predecessors open to the relevant pages, ready on deck and aloft with our keen young eyes and burnished telescopes” — they also describe the parallel joys of history and fiction, those most sympathetic bedfellows. Both demand an engagement with humanity that must skate across time and space to achieve any sort of context, any degree of relevance or reach. The best kind of historical fiction, then, should involve intelligence, experimentation, boldness and curiosity.

headline: An Unlikely Debut
abstract: Naomi J. Williams couldn’t have predicted the nature of her debut novel: “I’m just the most unlikely person to have written this book.”
lead_paragraph: A map changed Naomi J. Williams’s life. The author of the debut novel “Landfalls,” reviewed this week, received an antique map of Alaska from her husband, and became curious about two ships listed on it: the Boussole and the Astrolabe. “Next thing I knew,” she said in an email interview, “a decade had passed and I had this book.”

headline: Church Inquiry May Pit Pope Against a Popular Bosnian Shrine

lead_paragraph: MEDJUGORJE, Bosnia and Herzegovina — At exactly 6:40 p.m. one sultry day this month, the peal of church bells rang though the main square of this town, bringing countless pilgrims instantly to their knees.

headline: California Agriculture Posted Record Revenues During Drought
abstract: The industry has fared surprisingly well in recent years, a new report has found, in part by passing the costs of the drought on to others.
lead_paragraph: California’s drought has brought with it stories of acres of farmland fallowed and billions of dollars lost. Farmers have undeniably been affected by water shortages, some more than others, but a new report has found that the state’s agriculture industry as a whole has actually posted record revenues in the midst of the drought.

headline: An Injury Away From Michael Vick: Is That Good or Bad for Steelers?

lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Steelers are a Super Bowl contender this year, in large part because their offense, as always, is in the safe hands of the dependable star quarterback Ben Roethlisberger.

headline: From the Bench, a New Look at Punishment
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Police', 'Ex-Convicts']
abstract: Some federal judges are questioning minimum sentences and giving fresh consideration to expunging convictions that they say are holding defendants back.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Otero’s request to the judge, made in neat handwriting, was simple: She wanted a second chance. Ten years after she was convicted of driving an illegal immigrant across the border, her felony record meant she could not get work in the medical field. “I have learned from my past mistakes and am headed down a positive path,” Ms. Otero wrote.

headline: Groups Press Hillary Clinton to Take On Wall Street’s Revolving Door With Government
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton is being pressed to address Wall Street excesses, with groups urging her to focus on the issue of “golden parachute” compensation packages for Wall Street executives who go on to take government jobs.

headline: Keith Richards on ‘Crosseyed Heart’: It’s Solo Rock ’n’ Roll, but He Likes It
abstract: Mr. Richards, at 71, reflects on age, the Rolling Stones and “Crosseyed Heart,” his first solo album in 23 years.
lead_paragraph: Sometime around 2011, Keith Richards was ready to retire from his life in rock ’n’ roll. Approaching half a century with the Rolling Stones, he had done it all. “I know what luck is. I’ve had a lot,” he reflected in an interview this month.

headline: Sept. 13, 2005 | The Hard Road to the Big Easy
abstract: Joseph B. Treaster’s entry in The Times internal newsletter described writing about Hurricane Katrina at the time of the storm.
lead_paragraph: Joe Treaster, who has been racing hurricanes for Times readers for many years, made sure that on the Monday morning the storm hit we were the rare newspaper with a story from New Orleans itself. As thousands scrambled to escape the area before sundown the day before, Joe drove alone, from Mississippi, into the city. The locals thought he was crazy.

headline: St. Paul’s Student Takes the Stand, Denying Rape

lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — The student accused of rape in a case that has cast a harsh light on sex culture at an exclusive New England boarding school took the stand on Wednesday, denying that he had sex with the girl and presenting himself as a model of virtue: a high-achieving soccer captain who won an award for his character before graduating last year.

David Frank, then deputy picture editor, recounted at the time the logistical, physical and technological challenges that our photographers faced.

headline: The Appeal of Free: 75 Million Users Download Windows 10 in First Month
abstract: The early audience-building of both users and developers is crucial for Microsoft, and the early results look encouraging.
lead_paragraph: Free Windows is proving to be a very attractive price indeed. Seventy-five million users have downloaded Windows 10 to their personal computers and tablets in the first month of its release, Microsoft announced on Wednesday.

headline: 1890: Murder on Paris Boulevard
keywords: ['Jealousy and Envy', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Parisian service girl is murdered by her rival in 1890.
lead_paragraph: A dramatic murder was committed last evening on the boulevard Malesherbes. The victim was Marie Guérin, a young girl in service who was to have been married on Thursday, and the murderess is a cook named Madeleine Colange. The motive of the crime, so far as it has been possible to ascertain it, seems to have been jealousy. As Marie was walking arm in arm with the young man to whom she was engaged they were accosted in front of the tramway station by her rival, who, after a few abusive words, drew a knife and with one blow stabbed her through the breast. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 27, 1890

headline: Market Turmoil Prompts New Speculation on the Fed’s Timetable
abstract: William C. Dudley said the case for an interest rate increase next month had become “less compelling."
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Turmoil in global financial markets has reduced the chances the Federal Reserve will raise its benchmark interest rate in September, a senior Fed policy maker said on Wednesday, but the possibility of a rate increase remains on the table, provided markets regain balance and economic problems in other countries do not disrupt the slow but steady performance of the domestic economy.

headline: Verbatim: Hillary Clinton Reacts to Shooting in Virginia
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton expressed condolences and reacted after two TV journalists were shot and killed in Virginia on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton, expressed condolences after the killing of two television journalists working for WDBJ7 of Roanoke, Va., on Wednesday.

headline: Staying Private in Windows 10
abstract: Microsoft collects personal data on users of Windows 10, but privacy controls can be adjusted.

headline: Frank Dillane of ‘Fear the Walking Dead,’ Dodging Zombies and Seeking a Pub
abstract: A brief conversation with the British actor somewhere in Sussex, England, as he pursues a quest for an elusive destination.
lead_paragraph: When your first movie role is the youthful incarnation of one of the all-time great villains, where do you go from there? For Frank Dillane, who at 16 won an open casting call to portray Tom Marvolo Riddle — the boy who would be Lord Voldemort — in “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince,” you get thee to the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. By auditioning with Hamlet’s soliloquy, no less.

headline: For Rafael Nadal, a Little ‘Strip Tennis’ Before the U.S. Open
abstract: The tennis star is the new global ambassador for the Tommy Hilfiger brand.
lead_paragraph: It was 90 degrees in the sun, the spectators were wilting in the heat, and there on the court, Rafael Nadal was slicing and lobbing balls back over the net — in a full tailored suit.

headline: Amy Bezunartea’s ‘New Villain’ Taps a Discomfort Zone of Terse Insights
abstract: The singer-songwriter is playing Rockwood Music Hall in advance of the Sept. 25 release of her second album.
lead_paragraph: A clear voice and an unsparing eye define the songs of Amy Bezunartea, who is playing Rockwood Music Hall in advance of the Sept. 25 release of her calmly implacable second album, “New Villain” (Kiam). She keeps the music slow and sparse, sometimes just a lone guitar or piano note, deliberately exposing the way her terse lyrics and finely chiseled melodies carry uncomfortable insights about herself and others.

headline: National Geographic’s TV Outlets Examine Elephant’s Plight
abstract: The documentary programs “Warlords of Ivory” and “Elephant Queen” explore human threats and environmental ones.
lead_paragraph: It has been a summer full of shark programming, but National Geographic’s outlets are devoting the last Sunday of August to elephants and their struggles to survive. At 8 p.m., the National Geographic Channel brings back “Explorer” with an episode called “Warlords of Ivory,” a disturbing look at how extreme elephant poaching is in Africa. The journalist Bryan Christy puts a tracking device inside a fake tusk in an effort to determine what path it travels on its way to the black market, and who profits as it does. Mr. Christy has a self-aggrandizing style, but the episode demonstrates that the ivory trade is no longer limited to a lone poacher with a rifle; mass slaughter with automatic weapons shot from helicopters is part of the problem.

headline: App Smart | Start School Right
abstract: Whether back-to-school means college or high school, apps can help a student stay organized and productive.
lead_paragraph: Whether back-to-school means college or high school, apps can help a student stay organized and productive.

headline: Video Feature: Back-to-School Apps for the Organized Student
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Education (K-12)', 'Android (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education']
abstract: Make your own flashcards and other study aids, and keep on schedule with some education apps.
lead_paragraph: Students enjoying their last days of summer break have the threat of back-to-school time hanging over their heads, like the sword of Damocles. If that Damocles reference has you confused, why not look up the ancient story using the Google app? Then continue reading this column to discover other apps that can help students with their studies and make the back-to-school transition smoother.

headline: MoMA Presents an Exhibition on Eastern European and Latin American Art
abstract: “Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America, 1960-1980” will present some 300 artworks in numerous mediums, many on view for the first time.
lead_paragraph: It’s always interesting to learn what a rich, acquisitive institution like the Museum of Modern Art has added to its collection. The latest report is the exhibition “Transmissions: Art in Eastern Europe and Latin America, 1960-1980,” which opens on September 5 and will present some 300 artworks in numerous mediums, many on view for the first time. Nearly all date from around 1968, a period when art radically diversified, sometimes dematerializing altogether. These works represent artists from distant regions whose efforts ran parallel in terms of strategies (largely Conceptual, frequently performance-oriented), political contexts (often oppressive) and interests (protest, mass media, popular art). Some names — Valie Export, Ana Mendieta, Edward Krasinski, Juan Downey, Fernando Botero — will be familiar; others will be much less so. The show will surely reflect the MoMA’s desire for a broad global reach, but perhaps also the aesthetic narrowness of its relentless elevation of Conceptual-oriented work. (Through Jan. 3, moma.org.)

headline: Virginia Governor Discusses Shooting
abstract: In a radio interview, Gov. Terry Mcauliffe of Virginia said the suspect in the on-air shooting of two journalists was believed to be a disgruntled employee.
lead_paragraph: In a radio interview, Gov. Terry Mcauliffe of Virginia said the suspect in the on-air shooting of two journalists was believed to be a disgruntled employee.

headline: ‘Costume en Face’ Adds Sketches and English Translations to Notes on Butoh
abstract: Tatsumi Hijikata’s 1976 work “Costume en Face” is now enhanced by notes taken by Moe Yamamato, an English translation of those notes and a series of hand-drawn sketches.
lead_paragraph: It’s not exactly beach reading, but “Costume en Face: A Primer of Darkness for Young Boys and Girls” (Ugly Duckling Presse) is one of the strangest and most beautiful dance books to come along in a while, though it’s not exactly a dance book either. The slender volume contains notations of “Costume en Face,” a 1976 work by Tatsumi Hijikata, who created the Japanese performance art Butoh. The note taker was the lead performer, Moe Yamamoto; his record of Hijikata’s words, in Japanese, alternates with Sawako Nakayasu’s English translation, spattered with hand-drawn sketches and symbols.

headline: German Leaders Visit Refugee Shelter
abstract: President Joachim Gauck and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany visited a former government building in Berlin that is being used to house refugees.
lead_paragraph: President Joachim Gauck and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany visited a former government building in Berlin that is being used to house refugees.

headline: ‘Gloria Grahame: Blonde Ambition,’ a Film Retrospective at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is presenting a 12-film retrospective featuring the actress, who specialized in playing dangerous, damaged women.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has seen Fritz Lang’s 1953 crime noir “The Big Heat” will never forget the image of Gloria Grahame, her face half-hidden behind a bandage and prosthetic makeup, playing Debby Marsh, an abused gangster’s moll. The role gave Ms. Grahame, who specialized in portraying dangerous, damaged women, one of her most pungent lines: “You’re about as romantic as a pair of handcuffs.”

headline: Tennis Is Big at U.S. Open, but Not on Screen
abstract: Hollywood doesn’t lack for sports movies — except for tennis. On the eve of America’s biggest tournament, a look at why volleys and aces haven’t made the cut.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood has often looked to sports for inspiration. Be it the never-say-die underdogs in “Hoosiers” and “Rocky,” the championship pedigrees of “Ali” and “Remember the Titans” or the ragtag madness of “Slap Shot” and “Major League,” practically every sport has enjoyed its indelible moment on the big screen.

headline: Katrina: A Turning Point at The Times
abstract: Walter Baranger looks back at Katrina coverage, a turning point in the paper’s history.
lead_paragraph: Walter Baranger is Senior Editor for News Operations, managing communications and logistics for Times news bureaus.

headline: ‘The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe’: Cloak and Dagger and Farce
abstract: In “The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe,” Pierre Richard is mistaken for a spy; in NBC’s “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,” secret agents swing.
lead_paragraph: A French comedy that treats the invasion of privacy as a condition of modern life, “The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe” (on Blu-ray and DVD from Film Movement) may be even more topical now than when it was released in 1972.

headline: Carl Apfel, a Textile Veteran and Husband to Iris Apfel, Dies at 100
abstract: He ran Old World Weavers, a company that sourced and produced fabrics, with his wife.
lead_paragraph: He ran Old World Weavers, a company that sourced and produced fabrics, with his wife.

headline: Who Threw the First Brick at Stonewall?
keywords: ['Boycotts', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Movies', 'Police', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: The trailer for the movie “Stonewall” has sparked controversy for its treatment of characters of color and transgender characters, a scholar of LGBT history explains.
lead_paragraph: The trailer for the movie Stonewall, which dramatizes the 1969 riot that helped spark the gay rights movement, has generated consternation and anger among many lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people.

headline: Glorya Kaufman School of Dance Adds a New Dimension to Arts in Los Angeles
abstract: Classes began last week, and the 55,000-square-foot center at the University of Southern California will open next year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Ah, I recommend it,” Jodie Gates sighed, adopting the tone of someone advocating an exotic spa treatment or sky diving. The satisfactions she meant are much harder to come by. How many people get a state-of-the-art building of nearly 55,000 square feet designed to their specifications? Ms. Gates was standing near the construction site of such an edifice: the Glorya Kaufman International Dance Center, the future home of the University of Southern California’s new Glorya Kaufman School of Dance.

headline: Remembering Carl Apfel: A Style Icon in His Own Right
abstract: Iris Apfel’s husband of 68 years, and a veteran in the textile business, passed away earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: There is a moment in the film “Iris” — the recent documentary made by Albert Maysles — when Iris and Carl Apfel are interviewed together in their New York apartment. “There was something about her that just got into me; it’s always there,” says Carl of his wife of more than six decades. Iris cuts in, laughing: “And I figured he was cool, and he was cuddly, and he cooked Chinese, so I couldn’t do any better.”

headline: Homeowner Insurance: Your Credit Score May Raise the Premium
abstract: Insurers are putting greater emphasis on consumer credit in most states, which makes it increasingly important to pay your bills on time.
lead_paragraph: If you own a home, there’s yet another reason to maintain good credit: Insurance companies may give significant weight to your credit history when setting rates for homeowner coverage.

headline: Ben Brantley on London Theater, Where Characters Drink to Dull the Pain of Life
abstract: “Bakkhai,” “Splendour” and “The Trial” are among the worthy offerings on London stages this summer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wine is very much on the menu at the Almeida Theater in Islington these days. It is served, of course, at the bar that adjoins the theater. But more important, wine is being extolled as absolutely essential to our daily diet on the Almeida stage, where a riveting production of Euripides’ “Bakkhai” is hypnotizing packed houses.

headline: 36 Hours in Istanbul, Asian Side
abstract: The less-harried Asian side of Istanbul is a greener, cleaner swath of the city that offers its own multicultural mix of Ottoman palaces, intriguing cuisine and hipster night life.
lead_paragraph: The less-harried Asian side of Istanbul is a greener, cleaner swath of the city that offers its own multicultural mix of Ottoman palaces, intriguing cuisine and hipster night life.

headline: Onassis Cultural Center Announces Festival
abstract: The first Onassis Festival NY, from Oct. 8-11, will include events inspired by the myth of Narcissus.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Jonah Bokaer, the dance historian Jennifer Homans, the actor Paul Giamatti, and the fashion designers Mary Katrantzou and Narciso Rodriguez are some of the artists who will be featured in the first Onassis Festival NY, hosted by the Onassis Cultural Center NY. In announcing the event on Wednesday, the center said that the annual festival of arts and ideas will center on a different theme each year.

headline: Jason Sudeikis Courts With Comic Flair in ‘Sleeping With Other People’
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” alumnus finds his romantic side in a new comedy also starring Alison Brie.
lead_paragraph: Four and a half years ago, Leslye Headland went on a blind date of the working variety with Jason Sudeikis, a man she knew only as “that goofy guy from ‘Saturday Night Live.’ ”

headline: Flexible Venue Rules Play Important Role in Multimillion-Dollar Bankruptcy Filings
abstract: There are trade-offs regardless of where a company files, but it can be beneficial for large companies to choose to file in locations where the judges have a lot of experience with bankruptcy cases.
lead_paragraph: While many of us were enjoying some August beach time, Judge Russell F. Nelms of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Fort Worth decided to use a ruling in a local case as a chance to drop a bombshell on the restructuring community.

headline: The Melting of Mark Zuckerberg’s Donation to Newark Schools
abstract: “The Prize: Who’s in Charge of America’s Schools?” looks at how applying business principles to education can go awry.
lead_paragraph: The national debate over how to best educate our children is usually undertaken at a high level of abstraction. Constructive dialogue is often hampered by intense philosophical preconceptions that drive the perceptions and characterizations of all key players in the underlying drama: union leaders, charter operators, philanthropists, school administrators, politicians and teachers. The great strength of Dale Russakoff’s heartbreaking and disheartening book, “The Prize: Who’s in Charge of America’s Schools,” (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2015) is its steadfast insistence on avoiding generalities and explaining realities.

headline: 36 Hours in Istanbul, Asian Side
abstract: The less-harried Asian side of Istanbul is a greener, cleaner swath of the city that offers its own multicultural mix of Ottoman palaces, intriguing cuisine and hipster nightlife.
lead_paragraph: The lines to enter major sites on the European side of Istanbul, Turkey’s cultural capital, can stretch for hours. But just across the Bosporus lies the less-harried Asian side, a greener, cleaner and often more conservative swath of the city that offers its own multicultural mix of Ottoman palaces, artsy hotels, tasty cuisine and hipster night life. Here, at the gateway to Anatolia, hilly pine-forest trails in former fishing villages offer opportunities to burn off the baklava, while shady tea gardens abound for those who prefer relaxing with a water view. Wealthy Turks live in villas to the north, while miles to the south, party-friendly Kadikoy is bursting with vegetable and fish markets and bookstores, and is home to a street devoted to bars.

headline: Questions for Syngenta as Monsanto Walks Away
abstract: The $47 billion merger required aggressive assumptions and carried risks. Syngenta’s management now needs to prove its reluctance to a deal was worth it.
lead_paragraph: Monsanto, the world’s largest seed maker, has abandoned its $47 billion pursuit of the Swiss agricultural chemical company Syngenta, and that may turn out to be the best thing for both sides. But Syngenta’s management must now show why its reluctance to entertain the offer was well founded.

headline: New York Police Dept. Creates Unit to Monitor Times Square Issues
abstract: The officers in the new unit will address quality-of-life concerns amid rising complaints over the costumed characters and topless women in the area’s pedestrian plazas.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department is forming a new unit to patrol Times Square and address quality-of-life issues amid growing concerns over the jumble of costumed characters and topless women in its pedestrian plazas.

headline: South Sudan’s President Signs Deal
abstract: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan expressed reservations as he signed a peace accord on Wednesday amid international pressure and threats of an arms embargo.
lead_paragraph: President Salva Kiir of South Sudan expressed reservations as he signed a peace accord on Wednesday amid international pressure and threats of an arms embargo.

headline: Student Accused of Rape Testifies
abstract: Owen Labrie, a former student of St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire took the stand after being accused of rape by a fellow student, during a school tradition known as a “senior salute.”
lead_paragraph: Owen Labrie, a former student of St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire took the stand after being accused of rape by a fellow student, during a school tradition known as a “senior salute.”

headline: Review: ‘The Girl in the Spider’s Web’ Brings Back Stieg Larsson’s Detective Duo
abstract: The Swedish author David Lagercrantz has picked up this series, centered on the punk hacker Lisbeth Salander and her sometime partner, the investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Stieg Larsson’s captivating odd couple of modern detective fiction — the genius punk hacker Lisbeth Salander and her sometime partner, the crusading investigative journalist Mikael Blomkvist — will not be disappointed by the latest installment of their adventures, written not by their creator, Stieg Larsson (who died of a heart attack at the age of 50 in 2004), but by a Swedish journalist and author named David Lagercrantz. Though there are plenty of lumps in the novel along the way, Salander and Blomkvist have survived the authorship transition intact and are just as compelling as ever.

headline: On One Paris Street, Shopkeepers Specialize in Only One Thing
abstract: For this series, T celebrates shops around the world that sell just a single kind of product.
lead_paragraph: For this series, T celebrates shops around the world that sell just a single kind of product.

headline: Pregnancy Apps Do Everything but Ease Labor Pains
abstract: Now that downloads help track labor and a baby’s development and can help a child fall asleep, one must ask: How did we ever have babies before apps came along?
lead_paragraph: Three months ago, my wife, Chrysta, and I were driving along Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles when she let out a harrowing cry.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BOOK OF STRANGE NEW THINGS, by ­Michel Faber. (Hogarth, $17.) At the request of an alien population several galaxies away, a Christian missionary travels to a distant planet, leaving his wife behind on Earth. Faber, whom our reviewer, Marcel Theroux, called “a master of the weird,” skillfully handles the otherworldly in this speculative novel.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE PRIZE: Who’s in Charge of America’s Schools?, by Dale Russakoff. (Houghton Mifflin Har­court, $27.) This brilliantly reported account of Newark’s attempt to right its public schools stars Cory Booker, Chris Christie and Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: Pope Francis May Pass Through Central Park During New York Visit
abstract: The archdiocese is considering a public motorcade that would allow more New Yorkers to catch a glimpse of the pope, an official said.
lead_paragraph: When Pope Francis visits New York City next month, the best place to catch a glimpse of the popular pontiff may be in Central Park.

headline: Mormon Church Will Keep Ties With Boy Scouts Despite Objecting to Gay Leaders
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The church ended speculation that it would sever ties with the Boy Scouts of America because of the Scouts’ decision to let openly gay adults serve as leaders.
lead_paragraph: The Mormon Church announced Wednesday that it would continue its close association with the Boy Scouts for now, ending speculation that it would sever ties because of the Scouts’s decision last month to let openly gay men and women serve as leaders.

headline: Details Revealed in Gunman’s Death
abstract: Sgt. Rick Garletts of the Virginia State Police details the car chase and subsequent death of the shooting suspect, Bryce Williams, whose real name is Vester Lee Flanagan.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Rick Garletts of the Virginia State Police details the car chase and subsequent death of the shooting suspect, Bryce Williams, whose real name is Vester Lee Flanagan.

headline: Allyson Felix Is Back With a Better Sense of Limits, and Schedule Is One
abstract: Felix, a three-time world champion in the 200 meters, could not attempt a 200-400 double at these championships because of the event schedule. She chose the 400, the greater challenge.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Allyson Felix has the sniffles: a cold during the summer and the world track and field championships. But in view of the challenges she has overcome to get back to the Bird’s Nest and the challenges her sport continues to face to its integrity, that seems a minor concern.

headline: Official Discusses Virginia Shooting
abstract: Sheriff Bill Overton of Franklin County, Va., talked about the shooting on live television that resulted in the deaths of the journalists Alison Parker and Adam Ward.
lead_paragraph: Sheriff Bill Overton of Franklin County, Va., talked about the shooting on live television that resulted in the deaths of the journalists Alison Parker and Adam Ward.

headline: Suspect in Insider Trading Case Granted Bail
abstract: A federal judge decided that Vitaly Korchevsky was unlikely to flee the country because his family lives here and he is a pastor at his church.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania man accused of being the biggest beneficiary of a brazen scheme that blended sophisticated computer hacking with old-school insider trading may be getting out of jail, more than two weeks after he and four other men were arrested by federal authorities.

headline: Kids Cooking Pizza Two Ways: On the Grill and in the Oven
abstract: Making pizza at home: a 3-year-old can help; two 9-year-olds can nearly do the job themselves.
lead_paragraph: The master plan? Raising children who can be independent in the kitchen, able to prepare a few healthful meals and snacks and with the confidence to tackle a new recipe or task. In our Kids in the Kitchen series, Motherlode’s KJ Dell’Antonia and Cooking’s Margaux Laskey move their very differently aged families toward that goal. Margaux finds ways for her 3-year-old and toddler to help cook, while KJ stands back and coaches her two 9-year-olds and her 11- and 14-year-olds in cooking on their own. This week, both families made pizza.

headline: WDBJ Executive Discusses Gunman
abstract: Jeffrey A. Marks, the general manager of WDBJ, said the man suspected of shooting two employees of the Roanoke, Va., TV station was quick to take offense at co-workers’ comments.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey A. Marks, the general manager of WDBJ, said the man suspected of shooting two employees of the Roanoke, Va., TV station was quick to take offense at co-workers’ comments.

headline: The St. Paul’s Rape Case Shows Why Sexual-Assault Laws Must Change
abstract: In many states, laws requiring evidence that force was used in a rape would have made it difficult for the accuser to bring charges at all.
lead_paragraph: In the rape trial of Owen Labrie, unfolding this month in a county courtroom in Concord, N.H., this much is settled: When Labrie was an 18-year-old senior at the boarding school St. Paul’s, he competed with other male students over who could “score with” or “slay” the most girls. In the days before his graduation in June 2014, Labrie invited a girl, then 15, via email to join him for a “senior salute,” which could involve anything from kissing to sex. He had a key, passed around by students, to a mechanical room at the school, and the girl went there with him.

headline: Video Review: Toyota Tacoma Adds Machismo, but Retains Its Reliability
abstract: With an upgraded structure, a reduction in noise and more, the 2016 model is a far better truck than the one it replaces.
lead_paragraph: THE Toyota Tacoma’s reputation for reliability is legendary, but after a decade without major changes, the truck had become a bit long in the tooth. Yet it owned the midsize pickup market, with the Nissan Frontier and Honda Ridgeline far behind.

headline: Driven | 2016 Toyota Tacoma TRD Off Road
abstract: The Tacoma’s 800-pound gorilla is new, improved and facing new competition.
lead_paragraph: The Tacoma’s 800-pound gorilla is new, improved and facing new competition.

headline: Jonathan Franzen’s ‘Purity’
abstract: Jonathan Franzen’s protagonist, a young woman named Pip, makes her way in the world.
lead_paragraph: At the center of Jonathan Franzen’s new novel, “Purity,” is a young college graduate called Pip, whose full first name, ­bestowed by her not-quite-sane mother, is Purity. Pip is burdened by college debt, a lack of direction and a sharp intelligence; she is also burdened by her mother, who has brought Pip up alone in a tiny cabin in the Santa Cruz Mountains and now works at the checkout in a market. Pip’s general situation in a dead-end job is not helped by her obsession with a married man who lives with his wife in the same house in Oakland as Pip and some others. When Pip meets a nice boy in a coffee shop, a guy who seems to like her, she leaves him alone in her bedroom in a state of some sexual arousal and stays away for more than an hour while she fills in a questionnaire for a friend downstairs. She seems surprised and becomes angry when she finds a text he sends to another guy: “U can have her # if you have a taste for weird.”

headline: ‘Murder by Candlelight,’ by Michael Knox Beran
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: This book urges us to consider our own hearts of darkness.
lead_paragraph: Murder. Dismemberment. Rape. Cannibalism. Jack the Ripper. The Newtown shooter. Why are we fascinated by murders and murderers, by acts of evil and those who perpetrate them?

headline: Novels by Kathleen Alcott, Vu Tran and Alaa Al Aswany; a Memoir by David Payne
abstract: Also out is a novel about a Cuban-American’s experience by Jennine Capó Crucet and a historical novel based on the 18th-century voyage of two French frigates.
lead_paragraph: THE AUTOMOBILE CLUB

headline: Cruising With Crosby, Stills & Nash
abstract: The band Crosby, Stills & Nash will perform three concerts aboard Cunard’s Queen Mary 2.
lead_paragraph: Crosby, Stills & Nash return to Europe with a Sept. 12 show in London, but fans of the band can catch David Crosby, Stephen Stills and Graham Nash on stage three times during the week leading up to their monthlong tour. The Rock and Roll Hall of Famers will be performing those shows at the Royal Court Theater aboard Cunard’s Queen Mary 2 ocean liner.

headline: Surviving the Nazis
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: New books include Alex Kershaw’s “Avenue of Spies.”
lead_paragraph: AVENUE OF SPIESA True Story of Terror, Espionage, and One American Family’s Heroic Resistance in Nazi-Occupied FranceBy Alex Kershaw286 pp. Crown, $28.

headline: Susan Casey’s ‘Voices in the Ocean’
abstract: Exploring a watery world of intriguing creatures and the people they captivate.
lead_paragraph: At a time when many of us might turn to religion or to mood-altering substances, Susan Casey turned to dolphins.

headline: ‘The End of Tsarist Russia,’ by Dominic Lieven
abstract: A scholar approaches World War I from the standpoint of Russian foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: World War I was the greatest empire slayer of all time. Down went the Ottoman Empire, ruling from Bosnia to Basra. Hapsburg shrank into tiny Austria. Germany and Russia remained largely intact, but Wilhelm II ended up in exile, while the Romanovs were murdered by the Bolsheviks. Exit sultans and kaisers; enter authoritarians and totalitarians.

headline: ‘Girl Waits With Gun,’ by Amy Stewart
abstract: The bad guys are no match for a bullied woman in 1914.
lead_paragraph: Amy Stewart’s first novel, “Girl Waits With Gun,” follows her award-­winning nonfiction — “The Drunken Botanist,” itself a dram of good cheer after her previous, excellently informative ­doses of bad news in the shape of rampant earthworms (“The Earth Moved”), poisonous bouquets (“Flower Confidential”), toxic vegetation (“Wicked Plants”) and lethal insects (“Wicked Bugs”).

headline: U.S. to Support Sri Lanka Plan to Investigate War Crimes
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The announcement signals a reversal of Washington’s longstanding insistence on an international inquiry into possible war crimes during the final stages of the island’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The United States will sponsor a resolution on Sri Lanka next month at the United Nations Human Rights Council backing Colombo’s plans for reconciliation and to conduct an investigation into possible war crimes during the final stages of the island’s civil war, a top American diplomat said Wednesday.

headline: ‘That Winter the Wolf Came,’ by Juliana Spahr
abstract: Poems take on the political, from oil spills to Occupy Oakland.
lead_paragraph: Nobody has to tell Juliana Spahr that the personal is political: She has spent her career inventing verse and prose forms that show how our intimate feelings emerge, like knots in nets or waves at sea, from systems much larger than any one person’s control. “This Connection of Everyone With Lungs” (2005) ­examined the global effects of 9/11 through the metaphor of polluted air; the piled-up details in “Well Then There Now” (2011) looked at Spahr’s years in Hawaii, and at her ­origins in Appalachia, as if to ask where she could call home.

headline: ‘Harriet Wolf’s Seventh Book of Wonders,’ by Julianna Baggott
abstract: A writer with a cult following has turned her life into six well-loved novels. But where is the last one?
lead_paragraph: Many things are hidden in Julianna Baggott’s intricate, tenderhearted novel about a writer, her children and a legacy of loss. Love letters, folded into origami cranes that never take flight, are tucked under a mattress. A newborn child, mute and sallow, is spirited away from her mother and secreted in an institution. A young man supports himself as a professional hider of things, until he too must go into hiding. A wife is lost, a husband is lost, a mother is lost and so is a father. Indeed, an entire book, Harriet Wolf’s seventh novel, has disappeared. And, like so many precious lost things, it may be hiding in plain sight. All this sounds somber. But in groping for what’s lost, Baggott’s characters also stumble across pleasure, joy — and recognition.

headline: Amitav Ghosh’s ‘Flood of Fire’
abstract: The main characters in the final volume of Amitav Ghosh’s trilogy all have something to hide.
lead_paragraph: To read Amitav Ghosh’s “Flood of Fire” is to enter a world of sepoys, sahibs and rajahs, traveling with them from Assam to Calcutta to Canton, all the while learning about their pasts and dreading or hoping for their futures. It is a fictional journey both physical and temporal and, like real journeys, best appreciated when one is willing to accept detours and adventures.

headline: Closing the Book
abstract: A writer struggles to read while grieving for her parents.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t surprise me, when my parents were dying, that I couldn’t write. But it shocked me, as a writer of fiction, that I couldn’t read.

headline: The 2016 China-Bashing Race
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Scott Walker and Donald Trump are eager to criticize China, but they don’t have any smart analysis to offer.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to foreign policy, American presidential candidates have often found it easy, even beneficial, to criticize China. In recent decades, China’s growing economic, military and political clout has generated concern among many voters in this country. Frankly, there has been plenty to criticize, including Beijing’s reprehensible treatment of its own citizens.

headline: Ann Beattie: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “The State We’re In” reads more novels and stories than anything else — “except, maybe, cookbooks. I avoid mysteries, since I never understand what happens.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “The State We’re In” reads more novels and stories than anything else — “except, maybe, cookbooks. I avoid mysteries, since I never understand what happens.”

headline: Walmart to End Sales of Assault-Style Rifles in U.S. Stores
abstract: The retailer will stop selling modern sporting rifles, which are similar to the AR-15 assault rifle, which has been used in prominent mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: Walmart said on Wednesday that it would no longer sell high-powered rifles in its stores in the United States. The decision followed years of public pressure on the retailer to stop selling some of the most lethal weapons associated with many of the nation’s mass shootings.

headline: London After the Blitz
abstract: The city is marking the 75th anniversary of its time under siege during World War II. The most heavily hit areas were rebuilt in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: The city is marking the 75th anniversary of its time under siege during World War II. The most heavily hit areas were rebuilt in the 1960s.

headline: Obama Honors 2014 W.N.B.A. Champions
abstract: The president praised the Phoenix Mercury women’s basketball team for the W.N.B.A. championship, saying that the players served as role models for girls.
lead_paragraph: The president praised the Phoenix Mercury women’s basketball team for the W.N.B.A. championship, saying that the players served as role models for girls.

headline: Obama Honors 2014 W.N.B.A. Champions
abstract: The president praised the Phoenix Mercury women’s basketball team for the W.N.B.A. championship, saying that the players served as role models for girls.

headline: Jonathan Martin, Former N.F.L. Player, Says He Attempted Suicide
abstract: A central figure in the Dolphins’ 2013 bullying scandal detailed his struggles to fit in on the field and off it in a social media post, but ended on a positive note.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Martin, the retired football player who left the Miami Dolphins in 2013 after accusing teammates of bullying, said Wednesday that he had attempted suicide “on multiple occasions” because of long-simmering identity struggles and the stresses of the N.F.L.

headline: Facebook Tests a Digital Assistant for Its Messaging App
abstract: Facebook is wading into the increasingly crowded field of digital personal assistants with a new offering called M.
lead_paragraph: In the future, the world’s largest tech companies, like Apple, Amazon and Microsoft, want to make completing everyday chores as simple as asking a question of a digital assistant.

headline: Hillary Clinton Takes ‘Responsibility’ for Email Use, Saying It ‘Wasn’t the Best Choice’
abstract: Though it was “allowed by the State Department,” Mrs. Clinton says in Iowa, her use of a personal email account as secretary of state “clearly wasn’t the best choice.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that she understood why people had questions about her decision to use only private email while she was secretary of state and that she took responsibility for that decision, a shift from her past remarks about an issue that has dogged her since shortly before she began her presidential campaign.

headline: Missing Two Key Bats, Yankees’ Offense Seems Adrift
abstract: Without Mark Teixeira or Jacoby Ellsbury in the lineup Wednesday afternoon, the Yankees dropped their fifth game in seven days.
lead_paragraph: After his team’s latest hollow effort to score runs, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi could only raise his arms in mock surrender.

headline: Virginia Shooting Gone Viral, in a Well-Planned Rollout on Social Media
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'News and News Media', 'Television']
abstract: A gunman orchestrated his own moment in the limelight, a frightful twist in an age of online sharing and ubiquitous video documentation.
lead_paragraph: In one sad sense there was nothing new, or even very unusual, about the televised killing of two journalists in Virginia on Wednesday morning.

headline: ‘Mr. Robot’ Finale Postponed After Virginia Shootings
abstract: The episode will air next Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Season 1 finale of “Mr. Robot,” USA’s much lauded hacker drama, will not air Wednesday night as previously scheduled. The episode contains a scene of gun violence that is particularly resonant given the shooting of two journalists in Virginia Wednesday morning.

headline: A Gorilla Match (or 5) at the Bronx Zoo
abstract: Because gorillas live in troops, matching them isn’t just a matter of a male bonding with one female. In the case of Ernie, who lives at the Bronx Zoo, he must get along with Julia, Layla, Tuti, Kumi and Suki.
lead_paragraph: On a bright summer’s day at the Bronx Zoo, four adult female gorillas nursed their babies until the little gorillas were so full of mother’s milk, they fell asleep in the hot afternoon sun. In the distance, on a hill, a 5-foot-tall, 505-pound male silverback named Ernie gazed out over it all, chewing on a celery stalk.

headline: Carly Fiorina Cries Foul at the GOP Debate Cutoff
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The former Hewlett-Packard CEO argues that CNN’s method for picking debate participants could unfairly leave her out.
lead_paragraph: Will Carly Fiorina manage to get on the big stage next month in the second Republican presidential debate? The question is in part a technical one involving how poll numbers are weighed in rating Mrs. Fiorina before and after the Fox News debate earlier this month, where she stood out as a considerable winner despite being relegated to the also-ran set of candidates. It is also a question of how sensitive Republican leaders are to charges that the party habitually treats women as second-class citizens. Mrs. Fiorina, despite rising significantly in recent polls, argues that the Republican National Committee and CNN, the debate sponsor, are using a mix of old and new polling numbers that could unfairly block her from the prime-time show next month.

headline: Joseph F. Traub, 83, Dies; Early Advocate for Computer Science
abstract: Mr. Traub, who founded the computer science department at Columbia, helped the emerging academic discipline garner respectability and resources.
lead_paragraph: Joseph F. Traub, who founded the computer science department at Columbia University and who helped develop algorithms used in scientific computing in physics and mathematics as well as on Wall Street, died on Monday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 83.

headline: A Kurdish Political Star in Turkey Confronts Escalating Violence
abstract: Just two months ago, Selahattin Demirtas was basking in the afterglow of his party’s historic election showing. Now, he will have to face the voters again.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Emerging from a daylong meeting with party officials, Selahattin Demirtas was anything but the dynamic Kurdish politician whose coolness and rhetorical skill have evoked comparisons to President Obama. He was frazzled as he paced back and forth, addressing his advisers before charging into his next meeting, vowing to bring an end to the reignited war between the Turkish state and Kurdish militants.

headline: Business Group Assails Donald Trump for Urging Higher Taxes on Some Companies
abstract: The conservative Club for Growth took issue with Donald J. Trump’s proposal to increase taxes on companies such as Ford if they source parts or make cars in countries like Mexico.
lead_paragraph: His political platform is based largely on his business acumen, but Donald J. Trump is making a habit of rankling the business world with his ideas on trade and taxes.

headline: Review: The Weeknd Makes a Bid for Pop Outreach on ‘Beauty Behind the Madness’
abstract: The Weeknd is a slightly nicer, and much more firmly structured, songwriter on his new album which has echoes of Michael Jackson.
lead_paragraph: Abel Tesfaye, the Canadian songwriter who calls himself the Weeknd, used to be pop’s bleakest, creepiest Don Juan. The come-ons he sang in his high, sweet tenor — and in the scratchy moan that sometimes replaced it — were more like warning labels. They detailed how loveless, drugged-out, callous, self-destructive and self-absorbed he could be.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Beach House Releases ‘Depression Cherry’
abstract: The new album by this dream-pop band withholds ideas so you can insert your own.
lead_paragraph: BEACH HOUSE

headline: Review: Cécile McLorin Salvant Wields Her Power, Drawing From Her Album ‘For One to Love’
abstract: Cécile McLorin Salvant is performing with the Aaron Diehl Trio, drawing in large part from “For One to Love,” out Sept. 4.
lead_paragraph: Cécile McLorin Salvant, the finest jazz singer to emerge in the last decade, combines the rigorous sensitivities of an artist with the wary calculation of a critic. Her whole bearing as a performer — judicious, confiding, theatrical, skeptical — suggests a watchful distance from the persona she so persuasively embodies.

headline: James Holmes Gets 12 Life Sentences in Aurora Shootings
abstract: Judge Carlos A. Samour Jr. sentenced Mr. Holmes to life in prison for each of the 12 people killed in the massacre, plus 3,318 years for nonlethal crimes.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — In an emotional end to the court drama that has preoccupied Colorado, Judge Carlos A. Samour Jr. on Wednesday issued 12 life sentences in prison to James E. Holmes, who fatally shot 12 people in a movie theater in the Denver suburb of Aurora three years ago and wounded 70 others. The judge also imposed 3,318 years in prison on Mr. Holmes for his nonlethal crimes, including attempted murder.

headline: Misty Copeland Makes Her Broadway Debut in ‘On the Town’
abstract: Ms. Copeland, of American Ballet Theater, is briefly playing the role of Ivy, a.k.a. Miss Turnstiles, in the hit Jerome Robbins revival at the Lyric Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Who, me?”

headline: The Calming Quiet of Outer Cape Cod
abstract: A flock of artistic and literary types are finding summer refuge in Wellfleet and Truro.
lead_paragraph: WELLFLEET, Mass. — In flight from the bottles-and-models excesses of the Hamptons, the drag-queen hucksters of Provincetown and the hedge-funder mosh pit that Nantucket Island has become, a flock of creative types has steadily traced a route to an alternative getaway.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
abstract: South Korea and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: South Korea and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Sidewalk Blackboards Offer Some Chalk ’n’ Chew
keywords: ['Signs and Signage', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Coffeehouses', 'Restaurants', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Art', 'Sidewalks']
abstract: Curbside billboards become a public forum for wit and promotion.
lead_paragraph: Phil Ashworth studied illustration at the Rhode Island School of Design. His influences include the “simple graphic lines” of Shel Silverstein and New Yorker cartoonists, and his work has been shown at Gallery Nucleus and Hero Complex Gallery, both in Southern California. He has designed a T-shirt graphic that Vans skateboard shoes is printing and is starting to work on a book proposal.

headline: A ‘Fame’ Screening in Central Park Draws Alumni Extras
abstract: Students of LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts, the extras in the 1980 film, remember their movie moment.
lead_paragraph: For two and a half hours in Central Park on Tuesday night, Leslie Cohn wasn’t the manager of a Twist Frozen Yogurt shop in Westwood, N.J., a 53-year-old single mom with two grown sons.

headline: Director at Uzbekistan Museum Is Dismissed and Accused of Crimes
abstract: Marinika M. Babanazarova, director of the Savitsky Collection in Nukus, Karakalpakstan, in Uzbekistan, was dismissed after running the museum since 1984.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A significant trove of modern Russian art, preserved not least by its obscure location, was engulfed in controversy on Wednesday after its longstanding director was summarily dismissed on accusations of forgery and theft.

headline: Architect Sought for Obama’s Presidential Library Complex
abstract: The foundation overseeing the Chicago library’s development has invited firms worldwide to apply for the project, which is to include a community garden.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The foundation overseeing the development of Barack Obama’s presidential library began a global competition on Wednesday to select the architect who will design the elaborate Chicago complex.

headline: Op-Photo: Remembering the Ruins of Palmyra
abstract: A photograph taken between 1900 and 1920 shows the ruins where Islamic State militants recently bombed an ancient temple.
lead_paragraph: Islamic State militants recently detonated explosions at the ruins of Palymra in Syria, shown here in a photograph taken between 1900 and 1920.

headline: For ‘Pearl,’ a 4,200-Gallon River Runs Through the Koch Theater
abstract: A show’s director transforms New York City Ballet’s stage by adding a river, expanding over the orchestra pit and dispensing with wings.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ezralow may be a champion of dance, but he’s not elitist about it. He choreographed the opening ceremony of the Sochi Olympics, Julie Taymor’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” and, in February, a version of “The Rite of Spring” for the Russian rhythmic gymnastics team at the Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg.

headline: A Crystal Healer’s Guide to Curing What Ails You
abstract: In Los Angeles, Azalea Lee offers up the five stones that she finds especially resonant today.
lead_paragraph: “You are drawn to the one you need,” says the crystal healer Azalea Lee at the end of another summer in Los Angeles. Everything is in retrograde, and the variety of soothsayers is exceeded only by the number of patients coming to them, but Lee is reluctant to recommend a crystal to cure a malady — preferring to let her clients find their own. “We have spent our whole lives trusting other people’s authority,” explains Lee about using crystals for healing. “It’s the same with intuition: I want to help people see that they know more.”

headline: Marcy Borders, ‘Dust Lady’ Who Survived 9/11, Dies at 42
abstract: Ms. Borders became known as the “dust lady” from a defining photograph of her covered in ash and grime on Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: Marcy Borders, who became known as the “dust lady” from a defining picture of her covered in ash and grime on Sept. 11, 2001, died on Monday. She was 42.

headline: August 26, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from South Korea, Greece, Hungary and Chile.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Korea, Greece, Hungary and Chile.

headline: Setting a Stage for Kindness in Chinese Society
abstract: A powerful mix of hierarchy and authoritarianism is stopping people in China from expressing kindness much of the time, especially toward strangers.
lead_paragraph: At the Drum Tower West Theater in Beijing last week, Circus Master was torturing Little Flower because she would not speak and was ruining the show.

headline: Market Tumult Erases This Year’s Gains at William Ackman’s Hedge Fund
abstract: The billionaire chief of Pershing Square cited the declines in global stocks and the fear that slowing growth in China will have repercussions around the world.
lead_paragraph: Not even one of Wall Street’s most successful investors has been spared from the recent rout in stock markets around the world.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
