headline: Amy Poehler on Enjoying the View From the Losers’ Circle and Moving On
abstract: In an interview, Ms. Poehler talks about the lessons she learned from “Parks and Recreation” and how she’s approaching its final chances at Emmy glory.
lead_paragraph: At the start of a conversation about “Parks and Recreation,” Amy Poehler said with a sentimental laugh, “Part of me is like, ‘Is this the last time I’ll ever speak of it?’ I’m getting so nostalgic about it, even though it still feels like a very present thing.”

headline: Roger Stone Rides Donald Trump’s Well-Tailored Coattails
abstract: A longtime fashion plate and political adviser stepped into the media glare after a public split with Donald Trump.

headline: The 24-Hour Party at the Guggenheim
abstract: Agathe Snow, a darling of the downtown New York art scene, resurrected a fête from 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Agathe Snow, a darling of the downtown New York art scene, gave a 24-hour party. More than 300 artists and creative types gathered to dance in a grimy loft on Ann Street in Lower Manhattan that was still tinged by the Sept. 11 attack. Ms. Snow filmed the entire affair.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
abstract: Lacoste is offering clothes and tennis lessons; the debut Gabriela Hearst collection is available; a Billy Reid sample sale; and more.
lead_paragraph: Lacoste has a store event at 541 Broadway on Thursday from 6 to 8 p.m. where you can meet the tennis player John Isner and shop for gear like a polo with zippered collar in striped ultradry pique ($90) and a pleated tennis skirt ($90) in support of the City Parks Foundation. On Sunday, it will host a clinic from noon to 2 p.m. with free tennis instruction by the Lacoste player Murphy Jensen, snacks and prizes; Central Park Tennis Courts, Central Park West and 96th Street.

headline: El Cortez in Bushwick: Comfort Tex-Mex and Throwback Cocktails
abstract: A Brooklyn neighborhood in flux hosts a new spin on an old-school dive.
lead_paragraph: With its lowbrow menu of greasy chicken and old-man cocktails, the Commodore brought a dive-bar atmosphere to a corner of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that was on the verge of rapid change. Its owners have a similar playbook at El Cortez, a Tex-Mex bar and restaurant in Bushwick, likewise in flux. On a Sunday night in July, El Cortez was flooded with refugees from Tiki Disco nearby. As “Soul Makossa” pulsed, revelers in Nets jerseys and shades swarmed. One woman, on her back, churned her legs like an eggbeater.

headline: Clinton Urges Response to Gun Violence
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton said she was “stricken” after the latest shooting in Virginia, while calling for stricter controls on guns.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton said she was “stricken” after the latest shooting in Virginia, while calling for stricter controls on guns.

headline: Tehran Claims U.S. Is Holding 19 Iranians
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'News and News Media', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The request came as the United States is pressing Iran to release three American citizens — including a Washington Post correspondent — and provide information about a fourth missing for eight years.
lead_paragraph: Turning the tables on the United States, Iran’s Foreign Ministry said Wednesday that the American authorities were holding 19 Iranian citizens on what it described as unfounded charges of sanctions violations and called for their release.

headline: Tom Harkin Cautions Joe Biden Against Running for President
abstract: Former Senator Tom Harkin, a fixture in Iowa Democratic politics for over four decades, discouraged Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. from entering the presidential race, suggesting that Hillary Rodham Clinton, if elected, could name him to a top diplomatic post instead.
lead_paragraph: Former Senator Tom Harkin, a fixture in Iowa Democratic politics for over four decades, discouraged Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Wednesday from entering the presidential race, suggesting that Hillary Rodham Clinton, if elected, could name him to a top diplomatic post instead.

headline: New Orleans, 10 Years After Katrina
abstract: The city that went under in the surging waters of Hurricane Katrina has not returned, not to how it used to be. A decade later, New Orleans is an improvisation, one that is establishing a new normal.
lead_paragraph: The city that went under in the surging waters of Hurricane Katrina has not returned, not to how it used to be. A decade later, New Orleans is an improvisation, one that is establishing a new normal.

headline: Kristof: Lessons From the Virginia Shooting
abstract: Wednesday’s killings provide further evidence of the need for more restrictive gun policies in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The slaying of two journalists Wednesday as they broadcast live to a television audience in Virginia is still seared on our screens and our minds, but it’s a moment not only to mourn but also to learn lessons.

headline: Security Blogger May Have New Lead in Ashley Madison Hacking
abstract: Fallout from the breach of the adultery dating site spreads as law enforcement investigates further. A song from the rock band AC/DC has a role in the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Ashley Madison is the hacking that doesn’t want to go away.

headline: Classical Playlist: Mahler and Killer Tuba Songs
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: Mahler: Symphony No. 1 Thierry Fischer, conductor; Utah Symphony(Reference Recordings)A cycle of Mahler symphonies was a nice way for the Swiss conductor Thierry Fischer, 57, who took over the Utah Symphony in 2009, to celebrate both its 75th anniversary (in 2015) and the memory of Maurice Abravanel, the orchestra’s great music director from 1947 to 1979. Abravanel, after all, recorded the first Mahler cycle by an American orchestra with the Utah Symphony Orchestra, as it called itself then, from 1963 to 1974 for the Vanguard label. (Leonard Bernstein’s groundbreaking 1960s survey for Columbia, mostly with the New York Philharmonic, disqualified itself with an Eighth Symphony with the London Symphony Orchestra.) You would hope that the new performances and recordings would automatically supersede the old ones, but this first disc does not necessarily bear that out. Abravanel’s 1974 First Symphony, as remembered, relies perhaps a bit too much on sheer nervous energy, but it is also more respectful of the subtleties of Mahler’s score.

headline: Biography of Jimmy Carter Is in the Works
abstract: Kai Bird, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, will write a biography of former President Jimmy Carter for Crown Publishing Group.
lead_paragraph: Kai Bird, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author and political biographer, is at work on a new book about former President Jimmy Carter.

headline: ‘The Czech Lute,’ a Baroque Masterpiece, Gets Filled In
abstract: Adam Michna’s 13-song work has long been revered, if incomplete. Only recently were its surprising ritornellos discovered in a monastic library.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the Czech musicologist Petr Danek was in the Franciscan library in Slany, about 20 miles northwest of Prague, searching for Renaissance and early Baroque musical prints. He noticed large bound volume on a high shelf and, taking it down, realized it was a special find: the bass parts for a rare collection of vocal polyphony from the beginning of the 17th century.

headline: After Katrina, Man and Water in Louisiana
abstract: A decade after the devastating hurricane and five years after the BP oil spill, Frank Relle has been looking at how Louisiana residents coexist with water.
lead_paragraph: A decade after the devastating hurricane and five years after the BP oil spill, Frank Relle has been looking at how Louisiana residents coexist with water.

headline: Why China Rattles the World
abstract: China’s economy is faltering, prompting concerns that are now shaking global stock markets.
lead_paragraph: China’s economy is faltering, prompting concerns that are now shaking global stock markets.

headline: Documents Show Vester Lee Flanagan’s Turbulent Tenure at TV Station Before Virginia Shooting
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Documents filed in a civil court case in 2012 showed that soon after Vester Lee Flanagan’s arrival at WDBJ, co-workers were deeply concerned about his conduct.
lead_paragraph: In March 2012, Vester Lee Flanagan II achieved what he had been seeking: a return to television news after a long hiatus. But documents filed in a civil court case showed that soon after Mr. Flanagan’s arrival at WDBJ, a television station in Roanoke, Va., station executives and rank-and-file employees were deeply concerned about his conduct.

headline: Frank E. Petersen, First Black General in Marines, Dies at 83
abstract: He overcame bruising racial indignities to forge a long and distinguished career in the military, retiring as a three-star lieutenant general.
lead_paragraph: Frank E. Petersen Jr., who suffered bruising racial indignities as a military enlistee in the 1950s and was even arrested at an officers’ club on suspicion of impersonating a lieutenant, but who endured to become the first black aviator and the first black general in the Marine Corps, died on Tuesday at his home in Stevensville, Md., near Annapolis. He was 83.

headline: Gap Says It Will Phase Out On-Call Scheduling of Employees
keywords: ['Working Hours', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Workplace Environment', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The clothing chain’s five brands — Athleta, Banana Republic, Gap, Intermix and Old Navy — plan to start giving workers 10 to 14 days’ notice of their schedules.
lead_paragraph: Facing increasing pressure to curb erratic scheduling practices, Gap announced that it would stop requiring employees to make themselves available for last-minute shifts.

headline: Killings of Journalists Bring Gun Violence to Dark New Level
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The gunman's staging of the attack, and his posting of it on social media, made the tragedy distinctly horrific.
lead_paragraph: It is an increasingly horrific fact of life and death in the United States that easily available guns offer troubled Americans the power to act out their grievances in public. This trend, dramatized in recent years by macabre shootings in schools, churches, movie theaters and workplaces, was taken to a dark new level on Wednesday in southwestern Virginia by a disturbed former reporter who chose not only to murder two journalists as they reported live for a television station that had fired him, but also to record and broadcast the crime on social media.

headline: Court Rules Clerk Must Issue Licenses for Same-Sex Marriages
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal appeals court in Kentucky on Wednesday affirmed a ruling ordering a county clerk who objects to same-sex marriage on religious grounds to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in Kentucky on Wednesday affirmed a ruling ordering a county clerk who objects to same-sex marriage on religious grounds to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

headline: U.N. Says Aid Increase Would Cut Migration
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The under secretary general of humanitarian affairs, fresh from visits to embattled nations, urged affluent nations to step up aid as a way to stem the flow of refugees.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The new top emergency relief official here urged the world’s rich countries on Wednesday to step up aid to war zones in the Middle East and Africa so that refugees are not forced to seek safety in Europe.

headline: Testy News Conference Exchange Puts Donald Trump’s Quirks on Display
abstract: The remarkable 30-minute news conference over which Mr. Trump presided in Iowa on Tuesday night crystallized his quirks and contradictions.
lead_paragraph: It was Donald J. Trump at his neediest, pleading with the television anchor in front of him to acknowledge a poll that, he said, showed that Hispanics really do love him. “You saw that, right?” he asked. “Did you see it? Wait. Did you see it?”

headline: San Francisco Firefighters Become Unintended Safety Net for the Homeless
abstract: One of the city’s engines was cited as the busiest in the country last year, but less than 2 percent of its runs involved fires.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the emergency bell sounds at Fire Station 1 here, firefighters pull on boots and backpacks, swing into Engine 1 and hurtle out the door in almost a single motion, a blast of red lights and caterwauling sirens. More often than not, there is no fire.

headline: Smaller of Panda Cub Twins Dies at the National Zoo
abstract: The other cub appears to be healthy and officials are optimistic it will survive.
lead_paragraph: The smaller of twin giant panda cubs, who faced long odds for survival after it was born at the National Zoo in Washington on Saturday, died on Wednesday despite round-the-clock efforts to help the mother with the difficult task of balancing two babies.

headline: Saudi Arabia: King Plans to Visit U.S.
abstract: King Salman will visit the White House next week for the first time since ascending to the throne, Saudi officials said.
lead_paragraph: King Salman will visit the White House next week for the first time since ascending to the throne, Saudi officials said, as part of a trip intended to patch over differences with President Obama over the Iran nuclear agreement. While White House officials refused to confirm the Sept. 4 visit, John Kirby, a State Department spokesman, said Wednesday that he would not contradict an announcement on the trip by the Saudi authorities. “If the Saudi government announced it, I’m certainly not in any position to characterize it any other way,” Mr. Kirby said. King Salman, who became king in January, pulled out of a summit meeting with Persian Gulf leaders at Camp David in May. The Saudis have been concerned about the Iran accord but endorsed it three weeks ago, along with other Gulf states, after receiving assurances from American officials. Prem G. Kumar, a Middle East expert at the Albright Stonebridge Group, said the Saudis’ biggest concern was “how the U.S. will counter Iran’s destabilizing behavior in the Middle East.”

headline: Hong Kong Christian Groups Feel New Scrutiny From Mainland
abstract: An effort by Chinese officials to limit the influence of religion has raised concerns about encroachment on the city’s autonomy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For years, the Rev. Philip Woo, the feisty leader of a small Protestant church here, has delighted in testing the limits of China’s restrictive laws on religion. From his perch in Hong Kong, he has delivered fiery sermons on human rights, led seminars on social problems for mainland students, and ordained pastors in the mainland without permission from the ruling Communist Party.

headline: Guatemala’s Embattled President
abstract: A corruption inquiry that has ensnarled President Otto Pérez Molina shows how much the country’s judicial sector has improved, with outside help.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, corruption in Guatemala was regarded as an indomitable, institutionalized plague. It was possible to scrape off a few layers, but hopeless to try to root it out.

headline: China Falters, and the Global Economy Is Forced to Adapt
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Series', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With deepening economic fears about China, multinational corporations and countries are having to respond to a new reality as a once sure bet becomes uncertain.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The commodities giant BHP Billiton spent heavily for years, mining iron ore across Australia, digging for copper in Chile, and pumping oil off the coast of Trinidad. The company could be confident in its direction as commodities orders surged from its biggest and best customer, China.

headline: Viewers of Virginia TV Station Wake Up to Watch a Nightmare
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media', 'Television']
abstract: In the hours after gunshots rang out, killing two journalists on WDBJ-TV, a heave of sadness, shock and anger could be felt across the region.
lead_paragraph: ROANOKE, Va. — The signal from WDBJ-TV carries across hundreds of miles of southwest Virginia, and on Wednesday morning, so did the grief.

headline: Amelia Boynton Robinson, a Pivotal Figure at the Selma March, Dies at 104
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Images of Mrs. Boynton Robinson being left for dead by the police during the march in 1965 were seen worldwide and played a part in winning popular support for the Voting Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: Amelia Boynton Robinson, who was called the matriarch of the voting rights movement — and whose photograph, showing her beaten, gassed and left for dead in the epochal civil rights march known as Bloody Sunday, appeared in newspapers and magazines round the world in 1965 — died on Wednesday in Montgomery, Ala. She was 104.

headline: A Different Kind of Yankee Rotation
abstract: To keep pitchers’ arms fresh, the Yankees have recalled or demoted a pitcher in 43 transactions this season, about once every three games.
lead_paragraph: MOOSIC, Pa. — Ruth. Gehrig. DiMaggio. Jeter. Scranton?

headline: Palestinians Want to Raise Flag at U.N.
abstract: The General Assembly received a draft resolution calling for the organization’s two “nonmember observer states” to be granted the right to raise their flags.
lead_paragraph: Palestinians want to raise their flag at the United Nations next month, a matter that could set off a diplomatic dispute in the General Assembly. Nearly 20 Arab countries, as well as Senegal and Venezuela, submitted a one-page draft resolution to the General Assembly this week calling for the organization’s two “nonmember observer states” to be granted the right to raise their flags at the gates of United Nations headquarters. The Palestinians gained nonmember observer status in 2012. The only other entity to hold that status is the Holy See. The Vatican did not add its name as a co-sponsor of the resolution. The effort has already met with a rebuke from Jewish groups like B’nai B’rith, which said in a statement that raising a flag was a “privilege” accorded to a member state and that part of the Palestinian territories is under the control of Hamas, “which is openly committed to the destruction of an existing U.N. member state, Israel.”

headline: Free Tuna Being Offered After StarKist Settles Lawsuit
abstract: People who bought certain varieties of StarKist tuna are eligible for $25 in cash or $50 worth of tuna, after the settlement of a class-action lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: You may have free tuna waiting for you.

headline: In the N.F.L., CBS Has a Thursday Night Anchor
abstract: Thursday night football games have done their job for CBS by helping it promote new programs, build up its Monday programming and show fewer repeats.
lead_paragraph: When CBS began carrying “Thursday Night Football” in September, the network did not expect one blowout after another during the first four weeks. It had promoted its new prime-time package throughout the CBS empire and moved a durable ratings hit, “The Big Bang Theory,” to Monday nights. For its efforts and a $275 million rights fee, CBS was getting this?

headline: Girl, 8, Dies After Being Hit by an S.U.V.
abstract: An 8-year-old girl died on Wednesday after being hit by a sport utility vehicle as she crossed a Brooklyn street, the police said.
lead_paragraph: An 8-year-old girl died on Wednesday after being hit by a sport utility vehicle as she crossed a Brooklyn street, the police said.

lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — Motorists traveling southbound on Interstate 95 out of Manhattan will pass Rory McIlroy, who gazes down at them from a billboard promoting the Barclays at Plainfield Country Club.

headline: Raid of Rentboy, an Escort Website, Angers Gay Activists
abstract: Several activists and sex workers said federal authorities had unfairly targeted the website, whose chief executive and several employees are facing prostitution charges.
lead_paragraph: For some gay activists, it had shades of bathhouse raids and gay-bar roundups from decades ago. On Tuesday, federal authorities burst into the Union Square office of the gay-escort website Rentboy.com and arrested the chief executive and several employees on prostitution charges.

abstract: This play, set five years after the Rwanda genocide, examines the slipperiness of truth, the difficulty of ever determining what happened and why.
lead_paragraph: “All I want is the truth.” That’s what Charles (Joshua David Robinson), a discredited New York Times reporter, tells a potential source.

lead_paragraph: Investigators found a sunken fishing boat off New Jersey on Wednesday after it was seen taking on water the day before, the authorities said.

lead_paragraph: As colleges struggle to control the public-relations damage caused by athletes’ criminal behavior, prominent conferences have begun measures to keep players with troubling pasts out of their teams’ nationally televised colors.

headline: Hillary Clinton Speaks About Farming, and Much More, in Iowa
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: As Mrs. Clinton laid out her plan to help rural America, she drew the agricultural world into the broader messages of her campaign, touching on everything from immigration to drug addiction.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — It was a speech intended to introduce her plan to help rural America in one of the most agricultural parts of Iowa. But the framing that Hillary Rodham Clinton took to lay out her plan here drew the agricultural world into the broader messages of her campaign, touching on everything from immigration to drug addiction.

headline: World Markets Jump as Investors Seek Signals in the Noise
abstract: The S.&P. 500 and the Dow rose strongly and the Nasdaq turned positive for the year as better economic news buoyed trading.
lead_paragraph: Every major stock market in the world soared higher on Thursday, rebounding from the lows they had hit earlier in the week.

headline: Opera in Park, Harmonizing (Mostly) With City’s Hum
abstract: Singers with Opera Collective, taking part in an outdoor concert series, said their previous performances in subway stations had prepared them to drown out the cacophony of sirens, traffic and chatty parkgoers.
lead_paragraph: The singers had performed underneath the Port Authority Bus Terminal. They had brought Puccini to the Times Square subway, Rossini to the depths of Union Square and Verdi to Pennsylvania Station, where they found a semicaptive audience among the beer-swilling commuters of the Long Island Railroad.

headline: Arizona: State Ends Deal With Prison Contractor
abstract: Gov. Doug Ducey said on Wednesday that the state had canceled its contract with a private prison operator over a series of security and training lapses that set the stage for riots at a prison in July.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Doug Ducey said on Wednesday that the state had canceled its contract with a private prison operator over a series of security and training lapses that set the stage for riots at a prison in July. He also ordered the Department of Corrections to assess operations of all private prisons in the state. Mr. Ducey, a Republican, described the riots, at a minimum-security prison operated by the Management and Training Corporation in Kingman, as “frightening, disturbing and completely unacceptable.” The riots, which began on July 1, forced the transfer of 1,100 prisoners from several housing units that were destroyed. Nine corrections officers suffered minor injuries.

headline: Joe Biden Isn’t Sure Family Is Ready for Run
abstract: The vice president told Democratic National Committee members that in the wake of the death of his son, he and his family may not be able to dedicate themselves fully to a 2016 presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: In a conference call on Wednesday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. told Democratic National Committee members that he was uncertain if his family had the “emotional fuel” for another presidential campaign.

headline: A New Mets Outlook, and the Wins Keep Coming
abstract: There is a different aura surrounding the Mets, who are guaranteed to enter September in first place after a win Wednesday night in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Terry Collins was hired as the Mets’ manager in 2010, the situation he inherited was not exactly viewed as desirable.

headline: China Holds 23 Linked to Fatal Blasts in Tianjin
abstract: Chinese leaders have moved vigorously in recent days to quell outrage over the blasts, which rattled top leaders and raised questions about the safety of China’s industrial zones.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese authorities, facing enormous pressure to account for catastrophic chemical blasts that killed more than 100 people two weeks ago, said Thursday that they had detained or placed under investigation 23 people in connection with the disaster.

lead_paragraph: 1:45 P.M. (IFC) THE BLUES BROTHERS (1980) Jake (John Belushi, above left, with Dan Aykroyd) and Elwood (Mr. Aykroyd) are on a mission from God to come up with $5,000 so that the Chicago orphanage in which they were raised can pay its taxes and avoid closing. They have to get the Blues Brothers Band back together to play shows to raise the money, which leads them through a series of screwball misadventures, with appearances by John Lee Hooker, Aretha Franklin, James Brown, Ray Charles and others. John Landis (“Animal House”) directed this film.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AFTER a year of intense diplomatic negotiations, the Turkish government is now permitting the United States to use Turkey’s Incirlik Air Base, which will allow American aircraft to fly missions in Syria and Iraq with greater operational effectiveness and economic efficiency.

headline: Let Fear Guide Early Stage Breast-Cancer Decisions
abstract: Our emotions can make the unlikely risks of early stage breast cancer feel highly probable, or cloud the perceived benefit of treatment.
lead_paragraph: TWO patients, I’ll call them Sara and Janine, both learned that they had ductal carcinoma in situ (D.C.I.S.), often referred to as Stage 0 breast cancer. Both underwent lumpectomies in their early 50s. Told that worrisome cells were found, both had another surgery. Then a third surgery was recommended.

headline: Rethinking Warren G. Harding
abstract: A president usually ranked among the worst had a lot going for him, including being ahead of his time on race.
lead_paragraph: THE last year or so has not been kind to Warren G. Harding, who was the 29th president, from 1921 to 1923. Last summer the Library of Congress released his steamy love letters to his neighbor Carrie Phillips. More recently, some of Harding’s descendants had their DNA tested, to see if there was any truth to the claim of Nan Britton, the author of the tell-all book “The President’s Daughter,” that she had borne Harding’s child. They released the results last month. It turns out she had.

As a recent exhibition at the Pompidou Center showed, his buildings, books, and beliefs continue to stoke vigorous debates.

lead_paragraph: Has this ever happened to you? It’s 90 degrees outside and yet you’re shivering — or wrapped in a jacket or a blanket — because the air-conditioning is blasting.

headline: The Lessons of Anwar al-Awlaki
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Targeted Killings', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Four years after the United States assassinated the radical cleric in a drone strike, his influence on jihadists is greater than ever. Was there a better way to stop him?
lead_paragraph: Type ‘‘Anwar al-Awlaki’’ into YouTube’s search bar, and you get 40,000 hits. Most of them bring up the earnest, smiling face and placid voice of the first American citizen to be hunted and killed without trial by his own government since the Civil War. Here is Awlaki on what makes a good marriage; on the nature of paradise; on Jesus Christ, considered a prophet by Muslims; on tolerance; on the holy month of Ramadan; and, more quirkily, on ‘‘obesity and overeating in Islam.’’ Here is Awlaki, or Sheikh Anwar, as his many admirers still call him, easily mixing Quranic Arabic with American English in chapters from his 53-CD series on the life of the Prophet Muhammad, once a best seller among English-speaking Muslims.

headline: A Tour of Lake Michigan, My Inland Sea
abstract: Chicago. Sand dunes. A ferry crossing. A voyage reveals striking topography, time-worn communities and the reassuring permanence of an unchanging lake amid it all.
lead_paragraph: We left to the south and returned from the north. In doing so, we fulfilled the grandest dream of Magellan, the dream of circumnavigation. Our compass was GPS and our logic was simple. If we kept the lake always on our left and traveled continuously, we would eventually reach the place from which we started — Chicago, with its seismic chart of skyscrapers, protracted sunsets and canyon-like streets, closing the circle by visiting every beach and port on the greatest lake of all, Michigan.

headline: Defying Tradition, and Working Out, to Wear Bridal Crop Tops
abstract: The new trend of two-piece wedding dresses sees women eschewing the princess look.
lead_paragraph: When Cammy Hébert began planning her May wedding to Nick Miller, she knew a froufrougown would not do. Visions of Emilio Pucci danced in her head: specifically, a photo she came across years ago, in which a model wore a tight short-sleeved crop top and a long skirt reminiscent of a bunch of doilies.

lead_paragraph: Ukraine and its main creditors agreed on Thursday to restructure $18 billion of the country’s foreign debt, in a rare deal between bond funds and a wobbly, emerging-market government.

headline: Today in Politics: Ad Portrays Donald Trump and His Rivals as a Single Voice on Immigration
abstract: Priorities USA, the “super PAC” supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton, has released a digital ad that uses Donald Trump’s statements to paint the entire Republican presidential field as hostile toward immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. Donald J. Trump‘s heated back-and-forth in Iowa on Tuesday with a respected anchor for a Spanish-language station was a clear display of Mr. Trump’s quirks, but it also highlighted the rising tension his statements and policies on immigration have caused in the party. And a group with ties to Hillary Rodham Clinton is about to pounce.

lead_paragraph: One of Southeast Asia’s lesser-known cuisines is getting its due in Siem Reap.

headline: The V.C.s of B.C.
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Assyrian Civilization', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: A cache of clay tablets provides an unusual look at an ancient but strikingly familiar-looking economy — and confirms a modern truth about trade.
lead_paragraph: One morning, just before dawn, an old man named Assur-idi loaded up two black donkeys. Their burden was 147 pounds of tin, along with 30 textiles, known as kutanum, that were of such rare value that a single garment cost as much as a slave. Assur-idi had spent his life’s savings on the items, because he knew that if he could convey them over the Taurus Mountains to Kanesh, 600 miles away, he could sell them for twice what he paid.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Brock Lesnar
abstract: A real, proven fighter who returned to professional wrestling, the world of the unreal fight.
lead_paragraph: A World Wrestling Entertainment production tends to be a ridiculous spectacle: a brash, crass, gleefully obnoxious passion play where herculean men scream, threaten and belittle at the tops of their lungs, then work through their interpersonal issues in front of millions of viewers by pretending to pummel one another senseless, all while wearing colorful spandex. It’s hard to take seriously — that is, until Brock Lesnar enters the arena.

headline: In Siem Reap, Cambodia, Local Fare Gets a Chance to Shine
abstract: New restaurants offer a deep dive into one of Southeast Asia’s lesser-known cuisines.
lead_paragraph: On my first visit to Siem Reap a dozen years ago, I ate pizza, bibimbap and chocolate croissants. What I didn’t eat much of was Cambodian food. As the jumping off point for Angkor Wat, Siem Reap (pronounced SEE-ehm REE-uhp) has long catered to international appetites. Yet it’s only relatively recently that visitors keen to explore local dishes have been able to do so beyond street stalls and mediocre buffets.

headline: Scrutiny Falls on a Spanish Mosque After Foiled Train Attack
abstract: The authorities say a mosque played a crucial role in the transformation of the suspect, Ayoub El Khazzani, but its members say the preaching there was not to blame.
lead_paragraph: ALGECIRAS, Spain — Before he boarded a Paris-bound train last week, armed with an assault rifle and the intent, the authorities say, to carry out a blood bath, Ayoub El Khazzani had spent the final chapter of his troubled time in Spain in this gritty port city, living in a run-down apartment block with his parents within walking distance of the local mosque.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Support: Even More Unequal Than U.S. Incomes
abstract: Rich in support in some ways, Mr. Sanders has done poorly so far in competing outside his liberal strongholds.
lead_paragraph: The supporters of Bernie Sanders keep telling me that I’m wrong about their coalition, which I’ve written is too narrow to succeed. At this rate, Mr. Sanders doesn’t have nearly enough support among moderate, nonwhite and Southern voters to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: In Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s ‘Pondling,’ a Girl Who Only Looks Innocent
abstract: Origin’s 1st Irish Festival, starting this week, includes this dark play and Fishamble’s “Little Thing, Big Thing.”
lead_paragraph: Genevieve Hulme-Beaman’s dark and eerily transfixing play “Pondling,” seen at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a year ago, is headed to New York as part of the annual Origin’s 1st Irish Festival, which starts next week. The show, written and performed by Ms. Hulme-Beaman, is about a young girl who at first seems innocent enough, but soon her crush on an older boy brings out a darker side.

headline: Review: ‘Narcos’ Follows the Rise and Reign of Pablo Escobar
abstract: This Netflix series tells the story of the ruthless Medellín cartel, which ruled the international cocaine trade in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: The small screen offers plenty of post-Vietnam, pre-Sept. 11 nostalgia these days, but don’t expect a warm and fuzzy feeling from “Narcos,” an irresistible drama that begins streaming Friday on Netflix. Expect instead a reminder of a time when a few lawless men did a lot of societal damage by spreading cocaine far and wide.

headline: London Theater Journal: Make ‘Em Dream
abstract: “Bend It Like Beckham: The Musical,” with its focus of dreams of the future, has many parallels to “Billy Elliot: The Musical.” Then, also in London, there is the Hitler-era “Grand Hotel.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When a show talks about dreaming as much as “Bend It Like Beckham: The Musical” does, a theatergoer can start to feel drowsy. This family-friendly hit, which opened at the Phoenix Theater in June, begins with an open-faced young woman named Jess (Natalie Dew) in a soccer jersey looking, well, dreamy as she croons about how people “say that I’m a dreamer” and “that wishing for the moon will never get me anywhere.”

headline: Introducing Film Club: A New Teaching and Discussion Forum About Short Times Documentaries
abstract: At least two Fridays a month this school year, we plan to post thought-provoking short films that teenagers and teachers can discuss on the blog.
lead_paragraph: You probably already know that The New York Times is increasingly publishing video to accompany its articles, but you may not know that The Times is also home to hundreds of short films that go well beyond just reporting the news.

headline: After Virginia TV Shooting, Grief and Calls for Stricter Gun Laws
abstract: WDBJ in Roanoke honored Alison Parker and Adam Ward, who were killed Wednesday, and Ms. Parker’s father was joined by Democrats in calls for legislative changes.
lead_paragraph: ROANOKE, Va. — Colleagues of the journalists slain a day earlier had a grief-filled return to work here on Thursday, clinging to one another for support and unsure if it was safe to venture out, while Democratic politicians and one victim’s father said the shooting showed the need for tougher gun laws.

headline: Grisly Discovery in Migrant Crisis Shocks Europe
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Smuggling']
abstract: A truck filled with the decomposing bodies of migrants was found in Austria as European leaders were meeting nearby to devise ways to cope with the migration crisis.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The legions of desperate migrants fleeing war and mayhem in the Middle East and Africa have long known they were risking harm from unscrupulous smugglers and death at sea to reach the safety of Europe. But it became shockingly clear on Thursday that they now face the same dangers within Europe’s own borders.

headline: As Economies Gasp Globally, U.S. Growth Quickens
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Unemployment', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: The U.S., long considered the tortoise in the world economy, continues to chug along, while the onetime hares in Asia, South America and elsewhere are flagging.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the United States was considered the tortoise of the world economy, at least in comparison to emerging powers like China and Brazil.

headline: In L.A., a Cheaply Constructed Pop-Up Bar That’s a Work of Art
abstract: Four artists in residence recreated Vienna’s American Bar, an architectural gem designed in 1908 by Adolph Loos, where they serve PBR and schnapps.
lead_paragraph: It’s a hot August afternoon, and four artists-in-residency at the Los Angeles outpost of the Vienna-based MAK Center are surveying the damage to their collaborative art installation. Empty liquor bottles are everywhere, a banquette needs repair and the paintings lining the wall need to be straightened. This Saturday-afternoon assessment is a weekly ritual after the previous night’s debauchery at Los Bar. Their project, built in the garage of the midcentury architect Rudolph Schindler’s 1939 Mackey Apartments, where the artists are housed for six months, is a 0.65:1 scale replica of the famous Loos Bar in Vienna.

headline: Bargemusic’s ‘Here and Now Labor Day Festival’
abstract: This ambitious contemporary music program offers nine works in either world or New York premieres.
lead_paragraph: The week leading up to Labor Day is typically the least-scheduled stretch in New York’s classical music season. But the intrepid Bargemusic, Brooklyn’s floating recital hall, always steps into the brink with a gala program. It does so this week with “Here and Now Labor Day Festival,” an ambitious contemporary music program, repeated four times, offering nine works in either world or New York premieres. There are premieres of two pieces by Dalit Warshaw; a solo cello Soliloquy by Andrew Rudin; David Del Tredici’s Duo for Violin and Cello (“To Be Sung on the Water”); Richard Sussman’s Trio for Violin, Piano and Laptop; and David Taylor’s Concertino for Bass Trombone and Trio. Works by Morton Subotnick, John Zorn and Gordon Beeferman receive New York premieres. Among the enticing roster of 11 performers are the pianist Kathleen Supové, the violinist Jennifer Choi and the bassoonist Peter Kolkay. (8 p.m., Wednesday, Friday and Saturday, with a final performance next Sunday at 4 p.m., bargemusic.org.)

headline: Airbnb Appoints Chris Lehane, Former Aide to Bill Clinton, as Head of Policy
abstract: Airbnb is appointing Chris Lehane, once a top political adviser to Bill Clinton and Al Gore and a longtime strategist, as its head of global policy.
lead_paragraph: For years, Chris Lehane has known how to wage political war inside the Beltway. More recently, he’s been focused on fighting political battles from inside of Silicon Valley.

headline: Only Man Who Can Topple Usain Bolt: A Photographer on a Segway
abstract: Bolt retained his position as the world’s dominant sprinter and was unhurt in a postrace collision with a cameraman. Allyson Felix won the women’s 400.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — American sprinters like Justin Gatlin? Usain Bolt keeps beating them and then beating his chest, as he did in winning his latest gold medal, in the 200 meters at the world track and field championships.

headline: China Sentences 45 in Restive Region of Xinjiang
abstract: The names of the defendants indicated that they were Uighurs, a Turkic minority in the ethnically volatile region that has become increasingly estranged from the government.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Courts across Xinjiang, the volatile region of western China, have sentenced 45 people to prison in recent days after convicting them of supporting organizations accused of terror attacks or of helping others flee abroad, Xinhua, the main state news agency, reported on Thursday.

headline: 1965: Marriage Mania in Las Vegas
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Men rush to get married to avoid the draft in 1965.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The beat-the-draft marriage mania that raged over many parts of the nation last night was best illustrated in Las Vegas, Nev., where 171 couples were married in the rush hours before midnight. By plane, bus and hot rod, the young couples poured into Las Vegas — Nevada requires neither blood test nor prewedding waiting period. In the top of their minds was one frantic thought — President Johnson’s order earlier in the day that a marriage after midnight yesterday would not exempt a man from the draft. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 28, 1965

headline: Daily Report: The Ugly and Antisocial Side of Social Media
abstract: It is passé to say these days, but maybe it bears repeating after Wednesday: Social media is a powerful thing.
lead_paragraph: It is passé to say these days, but maybe it bears repeating after Wednesday: Social media is a powerful thing.

headline: From Indie to Franchise in a Single Bound
abstract: How directors of independent films make the franchise leap.
lead_paragraph: Independent film for decades has been seen as a way for directors to hold the greatest creative control over their projects. They work with meager means to create something close to their hearts, without the crushing pressure for it to be a global financial success. But having little or no cash to make art can be difficult, so many directors see indies as a steppingstone to the mainstream, a calling card to show studios how their intimate ideas could translate to big-budget projects. That may mean making a number of small films, then a climb up the studio ladder.

headline: The High Bridge, a Scenic and Serene Cousin of the High Line
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The Bronx has its very own linear park, but with far fewer tourists and a fresh view of the city skyline.
lead_paragraph: FOR as long as New York has been New York, its inhabitants have looked for ways to escape the city’s frenzy. They have sought out breathable air, fresh vistas or a simple patch of greenery.

headline: Exploring ‘Hamilton’ and Hip-Hop Steeped in Heritage
abstract: Anthony Tommasini and Jon Caramanica discuss Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: In the hit Broadway musical “Hamilton,” Lin-Manuel Miranda tells the story of Alexander Hamilton, once the most overlooked founding father, by seamlessly weaving hip-hop into a musical theater framework. It’s a novel hybridization, but is Mr. Miranda successfully paying tribute to both traditions or somehow weakening one of them? How specific are his references? How skillful is the rapping? Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The New York Times and an avowed musical theater enthusiast, spoke with Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The Times, about technical fluency, Stephen Sondheim and Biggie Smalls. These are excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Can You Match These Artists With Their Childhood Works?
abstract: Prominent contemporary artists shared some of their earliest works with T. Can you match the past with the present?
lead_paragraph: Prominent contemporary artists shared some of their earliest works with T. Can you match the past with the present?

headline: Planned Parenthood Videos Were Altered, Analysis Finds
abstract: A review by a private research company says the secret recordings released by abortion opponents “do not present a complete or accurate record.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Planned Parenthood on Thursday gave congressional leaders and a committee that is investigating allegations of criminality at its clinics an analysis it commissioned concluding that “manipulation” of undercover videos by abortion opponents make those recordings unreliable for any official inquiry.

headline: Before Obama’s Alaska Trip, Climate Group Charges Hypocrisy
keywords: ['Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: A mash-up of a White House-produced video ahead of President Obama’s trip to Alaska has a progressive group criticizing him for allowing Arctic oil and gas drilling while simultaneously seeking to combat climate change.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s environmental critics are using his own words and images against him as they argue that his planned trip to Alaska next week is proof of what they call his “self-defeating hypocrisy” on global warming.

headline: Business Travelers Warming Up to Car-Sharing
keywords: ['Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Business Travel', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing']
abstract: While traditional car rental companies still account for 95 percent of the market, services like ride-sharing services are making inroads.
lead_paragraph: IN March, William Petz departed from his usual routine of logging on to Travelocity or Orbitz to rent a car from Budget or Hertz while traveling on business.

headline: Francis Sejersted, 79, Dies; Steered Nobel Peace Prize Into Controversy
abstract: Mr. Sejersted led a committee that angered many by giving the awards to Shimon Peres, Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat, and to F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela.
lead_paragraph: Francis Sejersted, a Norwegian historian who as the chairman of the Nobel Peace Prize committee presided over several controversial awards, including the one shared by the Israeli leaders Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, died on Tuesday at his home in Oslo. He was 79.

headline: Rising Anxiety That Stocks Are Overpriced
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: There are reasons to question whether the recent sharp drop in an overactive stock market was enough, or whether a longer decline is ahead.
lead_paragraph: Over the five trading days between Aug. 17 and Aug. 24, the United States stock market dropped 10 percent — the official definition of a correction, with similar or greater drops in other countries.

headline: U.S. Open 2015: Who Will Break Out?
abstract: All the attention will be on Serena Williams this year, but keep an eye on these players. Vanderbilt tennis coach Geoff Macdonald sizes up their chances.
lead_paragraph: All the attention will be on Serena Williams this year, but keep an eye on these players. Vanderbilt tennis coach Geoff Macdonald sizes up their chances.

headline: Catholic Exceptions and Catholic Rules
abstract: What to expect if the church authorizes exceptions to its communion and remarriage rules.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a little while since I’ve written anything about the still-percolating issue of communion for Catholics who divorce and remarry without an annulment — with Pope Francis’s visit to the U.S. in September and the synod the following month, there will be ample opportunity for Catholic argument this fall — but I didn’t want to let this John Allen column slip too far into the past without highlighting its argument.

headline: Williams Sisters Leave an Impact That’s Unmatched
abstract: It is difficult to imagine tennis without Venus and Serena Williams, who have influenced a generation of female players and left a mark that no siblings in sports can equal.
lead_paragraph: For a sizable portion of nearly two transformative decades, one family surname has competitively dominated tennis and continually inundated its news. Think about how an emerging generation of female players has never known a tour without the headlining Williams sisters, Venus and Serena.

headline: Donald Trump’s Critics Aren’t ‘Politically Correct.’ They’re Outraged
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mr. Trump is twisting the meaning of the term “political correctness” to excuse his sexist and racist rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: It came as no surprise this week that Donald Trump put on a mock Chinese accent and spoke in broken English to criticize the leaders of China and (more to the point) President Obama for even talking to them.

headline: ‘The Daily Show’ Gets Ready to Go Viral
abstract: The Comedy Central news satire show has hired Baratunde Thurston to oversee digital content that it will create under Trevor Noah, the new host.
lead_paragraph: Though “The Daily Show” is generally consumed as a once-a-day experience, the political offenses and media misdeeds it chronicles are a 24-hour phenomenon, as any glance at your Facebook or Twitter feed will tell you.

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Human Trafficking', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Crime and Criminals']

lead_paragraph: Chancellors Werner Faymann of Austria and Angela Merkel of Germany expressed sorrow on Thursday after police discovered at least 20 bodies of presumed migrants piled in a truck east of Vienna.

lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” supporting Carly Fiorina is defending her record as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard in a full-page ad in The New York Times that promotes her strength as a leader of the technology company.

headline: Reflections on Virginia Shooting Victims
abstract: The boyfriend of Alison Parker, who was killed in a shooting on live television on Wednesday, and the husband of a woman who was injured spoke about their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: The boyfriend of Alison Parker, who was killed in a shooting on live television on Wednesday, and the husband of a woman who was injured spoke about their loved ones.

headline: The Food Sermon
abstract: The bright flavors of the Caribbean in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The bright flavors of the Caribbean in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

headline: At the Food Sermon, Keeping the Faith in Crown Heights
abstract: The Brooklyn restaurant offers Caribbean cuisine that will have you believing that food is a matter urgent for the soul.
lead_paragraph: The cross-shape sign says, “Jesus Saves,” or almost: The first S has fallen away. All along this stretch of Rogers Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, battered-looking storefronts speak of miracles and end times. So the Food Sermon, standing on a corner with its windows shining and its name in letters as yellow as the noon sun, may be mistaken at first for a sleeker, more modern place of worship.

headline: Tyler, the Creator Barred From the United Kingdom
abstract: The rapper Tyler, the Creator has been barred from the United Kingdom, which claimed that his music potentially “encourages violence and intolerance of homosexuality.”
lead_paragraph: Tyler, the Creator, a rapper in the hip-hop collective Odd Future, has reportedly been barred from the United Kingdom because of his provocative lyrical content.

headline: Google Rebuts Europe on Antitrust Charges
abstract: The American technology giant would face fines worth billions of dollars if it is found to have broken the European Union’s competition rules.
lead_paragraph: Google on Thursday rejected claims from the European Union’s top antitrust official that the company favored some of its own search results over those of rivals, saying there was significant competition in the region’s online search market and that the company’s services increased choice for local consumers.

headline: Germany Urges Sharing of Migrant Burden
abstract: While offering aid to Balkan countries hit by the recent wave of migrants, Germany’s foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, called on European Union states to cooperate to solve the crisis.
lead_paragraph: While offering aid to Balkan countries hit by the recent wave of migrants, Germany’s foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, called on European Union states to cooperate to solve the crisis.

headline: Sinkhole Swallows Five People in China
abstract: At least four were injured Saturday when a sinkhole suddenly opened at a bus stop in northern China. A surveillance camera at a nearby noodle shop caught the collapse.
lead_paragraph: At least four were injured Saturday when a sinkhole suddenly opened at a bus stop in northern China. A surveillance camera at a nearby noodle shop caught the collapse.

headline: Children React to Panda Cub’s Death
abstract: Children visiting the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington shared their feelings on the death of one of the twin cubs born to a giant panda named Mei Xiang.
lead_paragraph: Children visiting the Smithsonian National Zoo in Washington shared their feelings on the death of one of the twin cubs born to a giant panda named Mei Xiang.
