abstract: A Nashville-based line strives for less-is-more.
lead_paragraph: A Nashville-based line strives for less-is-more.

headline: Outrage Over Images of TV Shooting on Newspaper Front Pages
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Publications in the United States and Europe gave readers a killer’s vantage point, but there was condemnation of their decisions.
lead_paragraph: Was it newsworthy or over the line? News outlets had to confront that question after Vester Lee Flanagan II fatally shot two television journalists in Virginia on Wednesday and then posted a video of the shooting to his Facebook account.

headline: As Trash Piles Up, So Does Contempt for Lebanon’s Government
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: To protesters, the garbage piles are one indignity too far, the ultimate manifestation of a failed system that has left the state unable to perform basic functions.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Mohammad Rizk sat glumly in his sandwich shop on Wednesday, waiting for customers. The scent of roasting chicken mingled with the fumes of a trash pile just outside. The garbage heap, which seemed to have taken on a life of its own, now dominated the curb where his drive-by clients once idled.

headline: Dark Shades for a Children’s ‘Hamlet’
abstract: A look at David Habben’s dark artwork for a production of the Shakespeare tragedy at the Utah Children’s Theater.
lead_paragraph: David Habben had one man in mind when he created the eerie artwork for a new production of “Hamlet” at the Utah Children’s Theater in Salt Lake City.

headline: A Basics Line That Strives for Less-Is-More
abstract: The founder of Elizabeth Suzann aims to design pieces that don’t have a “trend-driven expiration date.”
lead_paragraph: “I started this company to avoid the excess I saw in clothing — to create comfort and inspire confidence through well-made garments that don’t speak louder than the person wearing them,” says Elizabeth Pape, the 25-year-old founder of the Nashville-based direct-to-consumer label Elizabeth Suzann.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Handling of Email Issue Frustrates Democratic Leaders
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Concerns are growing that Hillary Rodham Clinton is not treating the matter seriously, or doing enough to put it to rest before it harms her 2016 run and other Democrats’ campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders are increasingly frustrated by Hillary Rodham Clinton’s failure to put to rest questions about her State Department email practices and ease growing doubts among voters about her honesty and trustworthiness.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
abstract: Need help finding something to do? The Times arts team has you covered.
lead_paragraph: The Times arts team is here to help.

headline: Dr. James H. Duke Jr., Texas Trauma Surgeon, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Duke was famous for his health reports on NBC and for having attended to President Kennedy and Gov. John Connally in Dallas after the deadly shooting in 1963.
lead_paragraph: Dr. James H. Duke Jr., a Houston trauma surgeon who treated Gov. John Connally of Texas on the day of the Kennedy assassination and reached a national audience through his syndicated television reports on medical topics and his frequent appearances on “Today” and the “NBC Nightly News,” died on Tuesday in Houston. He was 86.

headline: U.S. Open Draw Unveils Serena Williams’s Grand Slam Path
keywords: ['Tennis', 'Records and Achievements', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Open (Tennis)']
abstract: Maria Sharapova, Venus Williams and Madison Keys could all get a shot at knocking off Serena Williams in the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: The first player standing between Serena Williams and a historic U.S. Open title: Vitalia Diatchenko, a Russian ranked 86th.

headline: 1915: Roosevelt Calls Pacifists ‘Sissies’
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Colonel Roosevelt calls pacifists “sissies” in 1915.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Colonel Roosevelt, addressing the New York business men who are training as soldiers at the military instruction camp at Plattsburg, N.Y., to-day, declared that America should support the President only if he was right, and denounced ‘‘hyphenated’’ Americans as enemies of their country and humanity. He also held up to scorn the professional pacifists who require other men to defend them, calling them ‘‘college sissies’’ and ‘‘men with mean souls.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 28, 1915

headline: Carolyn Maloney, New York Representative, Will Oppose Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Ms. Maloney’s announcement helps solidify New York’s status as a focal point of opposition to President Obama’s agreement, a top priority for his administration.
lead_paragraph: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney said on Thursday that she would vote against President Obama’s proposed nuclear deal with Iran, joining Senator Chuck Schumer and other New York Democrats in opposing the White House’s top diplomatic priority.

headline: Closing Remarks in St. Paul’s Rape Trial
abstract: J.W. Carney Jr., the lawyer for Owen Labrie, the 19-year-old who is accused of raping a girl at St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire last year, made his closing remarks on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: J.W. Carney Jr., the lawyer for Owen Labrie, the 19-year-old who is accused of raping a girl at St. Paul’s School in New Hampshire last year, made his closing remarks on Thursday.

headline: Insane Things Republicans Say: Bobby Jindal Edition
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Governors (US)', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Louisiana governor has asked President Obama not to mention climate change when he visits New Orleans to mark the 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: Political candidates who are trying to stave off what seems like inevitable defeat often do the kinds of desperate things that ordinary mortals would find too humiliating to contemplate.

headline: MSNBC Moves Al Sharpton’s Daily Show to Sundays
abstract: The Rev. Al Sharpton’s “PoliticsNation” show on MSNBC will become a weekly broadcast on Sunday mornings starting Oct. 4.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton’s “PoliticsNation” show on MSNBC is moving from its daily 6 p.m. time slot to a weekly broadcast on Sunday mornings at 8 a.m. starting Oct. 4, the cable news network announced late Wednesday.

headline: Junaid Hussain, ISIS Recruiter, Reported Killed in Airstrike
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Hussain, a 21-year-old Briton, hacked into American military networks and was a central figure in the Islamic State’s online recruitment campaign.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 21-year-old hacker from Birmingham, England, who tapped into American military networks and was a central figure in the Islamic State militant group’s online recruitment campaign, has been killed in Syria by an American airstrike, according to three senior American officials.

headline: Money Managers Look for Stock Bargains in Turmoil
abstract: Fund investors are looking for opportunities in global stock markets, where share prices have been battered in recent days.
lead_paragraph: The steep market sell-off has spared hardly anyone. Even some of the country’s top-performing portfolio managers have been hit. A fund run by William Miller, the Legg Mason Opportunity Trust, gave back all of this year’s gains of 14 percent. Bill Smead, who manages the Smead Value Fund, lost about 10 percent over the last month. Both funds are now roughly flat over the last year.

headline: Stephen King: Can a Novelist Be Too Productive?
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: How much you write isn’t a reflection of how well you write.
lead_paragraph: THERE are many unspoken postulates in literary criticism, one being that the more one writes, the less remarkable one’s work is apt to be. Joyce Carol Oates, the author of more than 50 novels (not counting the 11 written under the pseudonyms Rosamond Smith and Lauren Kelly), understands perfectly how little use critics have for prolific writers. In one of her journals she wrote that she seemed to create “more, certainly, than the literary world allows for a ‘serious’ writer.”

headline: Champions League Draw: Manchester City in Tough Group With Juventus
abstract: City and Juventus were matched with Sevilla and Borussia Mönchengladbach in the group stage.
lead_paragraph: Manchester City, which has weathered difficult Champions League draws in recent years, will have to do so again after being grouped with Juventus, Sevilla and Borussia Mönchengladbach at the draw in Monaco on Thursday.

headline: Dole C.E.O. and Aide Found Liable for $148 Million in Buyout
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A judge ruled that David Murdock and his top lieutenant drove down the stock price in order to buy the company more cheaply.
lead_paragraph: Taking the Dole Company private in 2013 was nothing new to David H. Murdock, the nonagenarian billionaire who first bought out the fruit seller in 2003.

headline: The Slow Process of Countering the Emerald Ash Borer
abstract: Scientists hope to help North American ashes defend against an Asian beetle that has caused widespread damage throughout the U.S.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, ash trees began dying in Detroit, and no one could say why. Then glittering green beetles were discovered crawling out of an ash log.

headline: Carly Fiorina, Gaining in Polls, Moves to Secure Spot in 2nd G.O.P. Debate
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Carly Fiorina, the former Hewlett-Packard executive, wants to be on the main stage at the event, and she is waging a public war with CNN and the Republican National Committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Carly Fiorina found herself relegated to the “undercard” for the first Republican primary debate this month, she seized the opportunity to stand out. Clad in a bright pink suit, the only woman in a sea of men, she delivered a forceful performance that catapulted her into the national spotlight and generated a bounce in public polls.

headline: Spike Lee, Gena Rowlands, Debbie Reynolds to Receive Honorary Oscars
abstract: They will receive their honors at the Governors Awards in November.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES—Spike Lee, fiercely independent in both his films and public remarks, will receive an honorary Oscar from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, as he joins the actresses Gena Rowlands and Debbie Reynolds among those to be honored at the group’s Governors Awards on Nov. 14.

headline: No Comment Necessary: “China Is the World’s Biggest Democracy”
abstract: An op-ed in a Chinese state-run newspaper touts China’s democratic bona fides.
lead_paragraph: Those who describe India and the United States as the world’s biggest democracies are missing something, according to Han Zhen, the head of Beijing Foreign Studies University. “We should speak with great confidence that China is the world’s biggest democracy,” he wrote on Thursday in an op-ed in a Chinese state-run newspaper. “If we don’t, it means we have admitted we are a non-democracy.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Likens Republican Views on Women to Those of Terror Groups
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Presidential Election of 2016', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton compared Republican presidential candidates to terrorist groups when it comes to their views on women, arguing that their “extreme” positions are not right for 21st-century America.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton compared Republican presidential candidates to terrorist groups when it comes to their views on women, arguing that their “extreme” positions are not right for 21st-century America.

headline: At La Garagista, Hybrid Grapes Stand Up to Vermont’s Elements
abstract: Deirdre Heekin’s wines are only one facet of the diverse working farm Ms. Heekin operates with her husband, Caleb Barber.
lead_paragraph: BARNARD, Vt. — Wine is now made in all 50 states, though few suggest much of it is any good. But on a hillside just outside this small town in central Vermont, a little east of the Killington ski resort, Deirdre Heekin makes wines under the label La Garagista that are so soulful and delicious, they challenge crucial assumptions long taken for granted.

headline: No One to Rescue Me From My Drinking
abstract: Though my ex-boyfriend tried, the only person who could save me from alcoholism was myself.
lead_paragraph: “It’s sort of lounge-y in here,” I remarked to my co-worker as I walked past his office late one April afternoon. The room’s fluorescent lights were off, and jazz floated quietly from his computer.

headline: Second City Assesses Losses After Fire
abstract: Personal memorabilia was destroyed in a fire that ripped through the offices of Second City on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A day after a fire ripped through the offices of Second City, the comedy theater and school in Chicago, the theater’s staff members were coming to terms with their loss.

headline: ISIS Suicide Attack Kills 2 Iraqi Generals Near Ramadi
abstract: Two explosives-rigged American-made Humvees blew up near the generals’ convoy, dealing another setback to the faltering campaign to retake Anbar Province.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In a further setback to the faltering American and Iraqi campaign to retake Anbar Province from the Islamic State, two Iraqi generals were killed in a suicide attack by the group Thursday morning outside Ramadi, the provincial capital.

headline: School Lunches Becoming Healthier, Statistics Indicate
abstract: Substantially more schools are offering two or more fruits and two or more vegetables than in 2000, according to federal data.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The humble school lunch, that staple of most every American child’s diet, has become healthier.

headline: Joe Biden Has Meeting With Head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has a get-together scheduled on Thursday with the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The meeting is said to have come at the vice president’s request.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is meeting Thursday with Richard L. Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., a person briefed on the get-together confirmed.

headline: When a Child Comes Knocking, Selling Candy
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Waiters and Waitresses', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Plus: macabre jewelry; a private message told; and a sassy answer to a waitress’s question.
lead_paragraph: I am a gay woman who lives near a single mother and her sweet 9-year-old son. The boy goes to a Roman Catholic parochial school. Every other minute he is knocking on my door, trying to sell me something to benefit the school. (This week it was candy for the athletic department.) I like these neighbors, but I have little interest in supporting private schools and even less interest in supporting church schools that take a dim view of my marriage. How can I deal with these neighbors nicely?

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Style
abstract: The performer’s fashion choices and physique make of her a natural avatar for a post-gender generation.
lead_paragraph: The performer’s fashion choices and physique make of her a natural avatar for a post-gender generation.

headline: Local Nets, Not Faraway Markets, Key to New Zealand’s Dolphin Decline
keywords: ['Dolphins and Porpoises', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Environment', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fishing, Sport', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: While Mexico’s porpoise problem is driven by Asian seafood smuggling, the threat to New Zealand’s dolphins is local.
lead_paragraph: In my latest piece on how Chinese appetites for an endangered fish are indirectly driving Mexico’s tiny porpoise, the vaquita, to extinction, I passingly mentioned the world’s other deeply imperiled toothed whale — New Zealand’s Maui’s dolphin. This diminutive marine mammal is a subspecies of that country’s Hector’s dolphin. The subspecies is down to fewer than 50 individuals by some counts, largely because of drownings in towed and anchored fishing nets.

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Style: An Exuberant Sexuality
abstract: The performer’s fashion choices and physique make her a natural avatar for a post-gender generation.
lead_paragraph: Like dog years, media hours multiply. Although Miley Cyrus is 22, so much of her life has been spent in front of the camera that it seems as if we’ve been studying her image for an exponentially longer period of time, watching her evolve in front of the mechanical lens and in a fast-changing society.

headline: Many Psychology Findings Not as Strong as Claimed, Study Says
abstract: Only 35 of 100 studies that the Reproducibility Project looked at held up fully to scrutiny. But some questioned the process of replication itself.
lead_paragraph: The past several years have been bruising ones for the credibility of the social sciences. A star social psychologist was caught fabricating data, leading to more than 50 retracted papers. A top journal published a study supporting the existence of ESP that was widely criticized. The journal Science pulled a political science paper on the effect of gay canvassers on voters’ behavior because of concerns about faked data.

headline: A Fake Goldman Sachs Underlines a Real Chinese Strength
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'Trademarks and Trade Names']
abstract: The investment bank joins a long list of counterfeits that includes Apple stores and British villages. They’re easy to mock, but they show an ingenuity and pluck that could be powerful.
lead_paragraph: The Goldman Sachs leasing company in Shenzhen is as genuine as the Apple store in Kunming and the $5 bottle of Château Lafite-Rothschild in Beijing. Wall Street’s best-known investment bank has joined an illustrious list of Chinese fakes that belie a very real Chinese strength.

headline: SoundCloud Sued for Copyright Infringement by PRS for Music
abstract: PRS for Music, an agency that represents more than 100,000 songwriters and publishers, claims the streaming service has failed to obtain licenses and pay royalties.
lead_paragraph: SoundCloud, a popular music-streaming website that has previously clashed with the music industry, has been sued in connection with copyright infringement by a British agency that represents songwriters.

headline: Kari Soinio’s “City of Ghosts” Series
abstract: The photographer manipulates his photos to create a Manhattan that seems, as he says, “both familiar and utterly foreign.”
lead_paragraph: The photographer manipulates his photos to create a Manhattan that seems, as he says, “both familiar and utterly foreign.”

headline: Untangling the Mysteries of Personal Technology
abstract: Tech Fix, a new feature, will try to make using devices less frustrating by examining the causes of problems and coming up with solutions.
lead_paragraph: In tech land, it has become commonplace to obsess over every shiny new device — and forget why we buy all this stuff in the first place.

headline: Haunting Images That Make New York Landmarks Feel New Again
abstract: Kari Soinio manipulates his photos to create a Manhattan that seems, as he says, “both familiar and utterly foreign.”
lead_paragraph: When he landed in New York City as a first-time tourist in 1990, the Finnish photographer Kari Soinio — like so many visitors before and after him — was struck by the breathtaking sweep of the Manhattan skyline. When he returned to live downtown for an artist residency in 2006, his gaze was again drawn upward. “I was amazed by the canyon of high-rises,” he says, “and the whole idea of the newcomer looking up.” It was with this view in mind that he embarked on an ongoing series, “City of Ghosts,” which combines street and architectural photography. Soinio captures the beauty of the city’s renowned landmarks — the Washington Square Arch, the Flatiron and Woolworth buildings — and pulls them into the foreground, while unwitting passersby become shadowy, anonymous characters in a duet between pedestrian and monument. Shooting with a 4x5-inch camera with no viewfinder, the defocused scene is “both familiar and utterly foreign,” as Soinio puts it, thanks to his manipulation of the images’ depths of field. “In the happy accident of photography, if you really know your camera, you can do so much,” he says. As “City of Ghosts” has continued, Soinio has shifted his attention to the changing urban landscape and the new glass towers that now reach skyward. In an age during which it’s never been more tempting to keep your eyes glued to a screen while traversing the urban landscape, his photos are a welcome reminder: Look up!

headline: A Home’s Story, Told in Dust, Bacteria and Fungi
abstract: An analysis of dust from 1,200 homes across the continental United States provides new information about the fungal and bacterial communities within.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of dust from 1,200 homes across the continental United States provides new information about the fungal and bacterial communities sharing the great indoors with us.

headline: Fines for College Football Players? Not So Fast
abstract: Recent remarks from two prominent coaches revealed that confusion still exists about how to treat athletes who are ostensibly amateurs and yet now receive checks from their teams.
lead_paragraph: In the lead-up to the first college sports season in which players for the nation’s biggest programs will receive stipends worth as much as several thousand dollars per year, recent remarks from two prominent football coaches have revealed that confusion still exists about how to treat athletes who are ostensibly amateurs yet now receive checks from their teams.

headline: Labor Board Ruling Eases Way for Fast-Food Unions’ Efforts
abstract: A ruling by the National Labor Relations Board made it substantially easier for unions to bargain for higher wages and benefits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Labor Relations Board, in a long-awaited ruling, made it easier on Thursday for unions to negotiate on behalf of workers at fast-food chains and other companies relying on contractors and franchisees.

headline: Trump Reads The Times at a Rally
abstract: Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, reacted to an article about himself in The New York Times on Thursday at a campaign rally in Greenville, S.C.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate, reacted to an article about himself in The New York Times on Thursday at a campaign rally in Greenville, S.C.

headline: Donald Trump’s Latest Target: The New York Times
abstract: On Thursday, during a speech in Greenville, S.C., he deployed a new prop: a copy of The New York Times, from which he read, on and off, for about eight minutes — alternately praising and mocking a front-page story about him.
lead_paragraph: Theatricality is a staple of Donald J. Trump’s campaign events. On Thursday, during a speech in Greenville, S.C., he deployed a new prop: a copy of The New York Times, from which he read, on and off, for about eight minutes — alternately praising and mocking a front-page article about him. When he was done, Mr. Trump dramatically flung the newspaper into the air, allowing it to slowly descend over the audience.

headline: Pull on My Hair, Donald Trump Says: ‘I Don’t Wear a Toupee’
abstract: Donald J. Trump brought his free-association presidential campaign to Greenville, S.C., even inviting a woman in the crowd to pull on his hair.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump brought his free-association presidential campaign to Greenville, S.C., on Thursday, following up a cavalier reference to the “silent majority” that supports him with an annotated reading of a New York Times front-page article about him and then with an invitation to a woman in the crowd to yank his hair (“I don’t wear a toupee — it’s my hair”).

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — This weekend, Miley Cyrus is throwing a rager. Everyone’s invited, and MTV is footing the bill.

headline: Architectural Salvage at a Brooklyn Church
abstract: A Manhattan salvage business is stripping the interior of the Church of the Redeemer, which was sold to a real estate company last year.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan salvage business is stripping the interior of the Church of the Redeemer, which was sold to a real estate company last year.

headline: At This Brooklyn Church, Everything Must Go
abstract: The new owner of an Episcopal church scheduled for demolition is selling its doorways, pews and stained-glass portraits of saints.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday morning, dust choked the air, and debris rained inside the Church of the Redeemer in Brooklyn, just south of the Atlantic Terminal transit hub. Shards of stained glass panes had fallen onto remnants of floral floor tiles, near stacks of dirt-covered hymnals and mangled metal ceiling panels. Workers were hammering apart walls and carrying walnut pews, which were to be offered for sale at the Demolition Depot in Manhattan.

keywords: ['Censorship', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Organized Labor', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Judges in Bangladesh have ruled that a film about the 2013 building collapse that killed over a thousand garment workers cannot be screened.
lead_paragraph: This has not been a good year for free speech in Bangladesh. Self-styled defenders of Islam have killed several bloggers who dared to write critically about the religion and its followers. And now, a court has banned the release of a film about a building collapse that killed more than 1,100 garment workers in 2013.

headline: A Male Túngara Frog’s Mating Signal
abstract: A male túngara frog calling within a chorus in Gamboa, Panama, in search of a potential mate.
lead_paragraph: A male túngara frog calling within a chorus in Gamboa, Panama, in search of a potential mate.

headline: A Twist to How a Túngara Frog Finds Her Prince
abstract: Given a choice of two males, a female will pick the most attractive. But, researchers say, that’s not necessarily the case when a third male is added.
lead_paragraph: Given a choice of two males, female túngara frogs will select the most attractive — those with calls of a low frequency and long duration. But when a third male who is inferior is added to the lineup, researchers have found, females often choose the less attractive of the first two. In a study published in the journal Science, scientists at the University of Texas, Austin, and at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute suggest that when a social situation becomes too complex, obvious decisions become too burdensome for the frogs. A similar effect has been observed in humans, suggesting that irrationality in mate selection may have deep biological roots.

headline: Living With Cancer: Collateral Damage
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Lung Cancer', 'Medicine and Health', 'Prostate Cancer']
abstract: In a quandary that stalks oncology, procedures that prolong lives also impair them. Yet cancer patients who must forfeit quality of life to gain quantity of life rarely receive adequate warning before treatment or guidance afterward.
lead_paragraph: When I was invited to attend a prostate cancer group called “Us Too” in my town, its members were meeting in a private room in our public library. About eight men, some accompanied by their wives, had great difficulty communicating their discomfort about urine leaks and diapers. They wanted to know what strategies my gynecological cancer group used to talk about sexual issues. To alleviate their daily problems, the participants needed professional help that I could not furnish.

lead_paragraph: The N.Y.C.-based chefs Max and Eli Sussman wrap up their summer residency at Ruschmeyer’s in Montauk with a lobster boil. Their secrets? The freshest seafood and lots of Old Bay seasoning.

headline: A Ruschmeyer’s-Style Lobster Boil, Starring the Sussman Brothers
abstract: The Brooklyn-based chefs also share the perfect side dish.
lead_paragraph: Like many true New Yorkers, Eli and Max Sussman of Brooklyn’s Samesa are spending the summer in Montauk, as executive chefs at Ruschmeyer’s restaurant. “Working closely with Hamptons farms and fishermen has been an incredible experience — both the personal, daily relationships and the ability to obtain the freshest products possible,” Eli tells T. “And living this close to the beautiful beaches is a very solid way to spend the summer.” Here, the Sussmans (who are originally from Detroit) demonstrate how to make a lobster boil, Ruschmeyer’s style. And below, they share a recipe for the perfect starter or side dish, a light ceviche that plays on different flavors, “but fits perfectly into the seafood theme of an East Coast boil.”

headline: Eric Cancel, an Apprentice Jockey at Saratoga, Listens and Learns
abstract: Cancel, 19, is the new kid in the jockeys’ room, and while his success has been gratifying, the lessons from other jockeys about professionalism have been invaluable.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It was the nightcap, the final race on Monday’s card, and all Eric Cancel had to show for his afternoon was dirty riding pants. His horses had so far managed to beat only two horses in three races. When he got a leg up on his final mount of the day, Confessa, the words of his agent and mentor, Angel Cordero Jr., rattled in his head.

lead_paragraph: The long goodbye for “China: Through the Looking Glass” just got a little longer: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is extending hours for the exhibition’s final weekend.

abstract: Beyoncé, Ed Sheeran, Kendrick Lamar, Mark Ronson and Taylor Swift all departed from their public images.
lead_paragraph: NOWADAYS, music videos are anomalous in MTV’s programming; the debacles of teenage moms and “catfished” romantics claim the airspace once occupied by Britney Spears and Michael Jackson. But the network’s Video Music Awards show — now headed for its 32nd installment — endures as an annual spectacle of theatrical pop performances, salacious onstage antics and reliable scandals. (Bet on that this year, as the reigning V.M.A.s provocateur Miley Cyrus will host.)

headline: The Role of Décor in Hitler’s Life
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ANTIQUES', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A new book, “Hitler at Home,” details how the dictator showed “an enthusiastic interest in even the smallest detail” of home design.
lead_paragraph: A new book by the architectural historian Despina Stratigakos, “Hitler at Home” (Yale University Press), arriving next month, details how that dictator showed “an enthusiastic interest in even the smallest detail” of his décor. His favorite interior designer, Gerdy Troost, who died in 2003 at 98, saved her voluminous papers.

headline: Review: In ‘When Animals Dream’ a Teenager’s Secret Is a Revelation Even to Her
abstract: This Danish thriller regards its monstrous heroine with empathy rather than horror, and is as much a romantic coming-of-age story as a thriller.
lead_paragraph: In American popular culture, lycanthropy has typically been a guy thing. For the hapless Eisenhower-era protagonist of “I Was a Teenage Werewolf” and for the studly Jacob Black in the “Twilight” movies, sprouting fur, fangs and claws was a metaphor for uncontrollable adolescent male rage. But girls are angry, too, and the teenage werewolf in “When Animals Dream,” a spare and smart Danish thriller, comes of age in particularly infuriating circumstances.

headline: Agent Cleared Over 2010 Florida Shooting Inquiry, but Lawyer Lashes Out
abstract: Rusty Rodgers did not commit any crime in his investigation, a special prosecutor said, but his lawyer responded to the prosecutor’s criticism of the St. Augustine, Fla., agent.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, a Florida state investigator was drawn into a highly contentious case involving a young single mother who was in the process of breaking up with her boyfriend, a St. Johns County deputy sheriff, when she was killed with the officer’s service weapon.

headline: U.S. to Join Inquiry Into Death of New York Prisoner
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The United States attorney in Manhattan will investigate the death of Samuel Harrell, a prisoner at the Fishkill Correctional Facility who inmates say was beaten severely by guards.
lead_paragraph: The office of the United States attorney in Manhattan announced on Thursday that it was joining the investigation into the death of Samuel Harrell, a prisoner at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y., who inmate witnesses say was handcuffed and beaten severely this year by a group of corrections officers.

headline: Review: ‘The Sympathizer,’ a Novel About a Soldier, Spy and Film Consultant
abstract: The narrator of Viet Thanh Nguyen’s novel is a Vietnamese Army captain exiled in Los Angeles, a hit man, a spy and a movie consultant.
lead_paragraph: There’s a great comic interlude in Viet Thanh Nguyen’s novel “The Sympathizer” when the unnamed narrator, a Vietnamese Army captain exiled in Los Angeles, critiques the screenplay of a gung-ho Hollywood movie about America’s heroism in the Vietnam War.

lead_paragraph: In the first half of this year alone, at least 137,000 men, women and children crossed the Mediterranean Sea to reach the shores of Europe, according to the United Nations. Thousands are traveling across the Balkans now.

lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS – They weren’t exactly beating down the door shouting “Run, Joe, run!”

headline: Days of Unrest Turn Deadly in Indian State of Gujarat
abstract: The clashes, in which as many as eight people were killed, came amid protests by members of the Patidar caste who are demanding job opportunities.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The authorities in the Indian state of Gujarat struggled to restore calm on Thursday after two days of widespread unrest and deadly clashes between residents and the police. Curfews remained in Ahmedabad, the state’s largest city, and a state court ordered an inquiry into allegations of police brutality.

headline: Review: In ‘Z for Zachariah,’ an End-of-Days Love Triangle
abstract: Margot Robbie stars in Craig Zobel’s post-apocalyptic film about three survivors of the nuclear holocaust caught in a triangle.
lead_paragraph: “Z for Zachariah” may not be the most eventful post-apocalyptic drama, but its grip is strong and sure. Set in a verdant valley (with New Zealand standing in for the American South) that has somehow survived the fallout from an unspecified nuclear catastrophe, this minimalist but deeply affecting morality play slowly tugs you in.

headline: Loving Queens: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The reporter Kirk Semple describes his abiding interest in the borough of Queens, New York.
lead_paragraph: For years, an old Redbird subway car sat on a patch of land next to Queens Borough Hall on Queens Boulevard. It had been hauled from a rail yard somewhere and repurposed as a tourist information center, the borough’s one and only.

headline: U.S. Open Stars Juggle Preparation With Publicity
keywords: ['Tennis', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: The week leading up to the tennis tournament is a marketing extravaganza for companies represented by elite players.
lead_paragraph: Nike organized street tennis for Maria Sharapova, Roger Federer and others in the meatpacking district. Tommy Hilfiger opted for strip tennis with Rafael Nadal in Bryant Park. Delta Air Lines held a celebrity karaoke night with Serena Williams near Times Square. And American Express staged what it called a “hydro-interactive tennis experience” featuring Ms. Sharapova along the Hudson River.

headline: Review: ‘Made in the Americas’ Explores Globalism From Way, Way Back
abstract: This museum show in Boston illuminates the influence of Asia on the arts of colonial North, Central and South America.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — One of the great gifts that multiculturalist thinking gave us was final freedom from the tyranny of purity. Simply put, that old ideal was revealed as an illusion. It doesn’t exist, at least not in art. There, in reality, everything is a mix. Wonderfully, the longer and closer we look, the richer the mix becomes. And this has always been true. Globalism, which we take to be so 21st century, with its networks and mash-ups, is as old as the hills.

headline: A New Mexican Restaurant That Doesn’t Skimp on the Spice
abstract: To celebrate the opening of the Mexican chain’s fifth location, Tacombi West Village, its chef shares a recipe for sopa de lima.
lead_paragraph: The restaurateur Dario Wolos began making tacos a decade ago, selling them out of a Volkswagen bus in Mexico. Since then, he’s moved to New York and opened four restaurants, all called Tacombi, around the city, each focusing on a different Mexican regional cuisine. The fifth, Tacombi West Village, opens on the corner of Bleecker and Cornelia streets in September. Wolos and his chef, Jason DeBriere — who honed his kitchen chops at restaurants Washington Park, Barbuto and Peels — traveled throughout the Yucatán, stopping at roadside stands and markets in search of dishes and flavors they could bring back to New York. “We wanted to focus and bring these flavors from the Yucatán, because there wasn’t a lot of representation,” DeBriere says.

headline: Review: ‘Grand Illusions’ Showcases Deceptive Photography
abstract: This exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art presents 40 works that form a freewheeling introduction to staged photography.
lead_paragraph: “Grand Illusions: Staged Photography From the Met Collection” is a small, choice, concentrated exhibition. Ensconced in modest galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, its 40 works are drawn entirely from that museum’s collection and form a freewheeling introduction to staged photography. This tactic — arranging objects or people for the camera — began with photography’s invention; figured prominently in portraiture, commercial and Surrealist lines of work; and entered mainstream art full throttle in the 1980s, with the arrival of the Pictures Generation and postmodernism.

headline: Segerstrom Center Says It Is Nearing Its Fund-Raising Goal
abstract: The Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif., says it has raised nearly two-thirds of a new $68 million campaign to transform its plaza.
lead_paragraph: The Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif., which has established itself in recent years as a leading dance theater, announced Thursday that it had raised nearly two-thirds of a new $68 million campaign to transform its plaza into a more welcoming public space, create a Center for Dance and Innovation, and establish more partnerships with community groups.

headline: Review: ‘Endless House’ Expands the Definition of Home
abstract: Through drawings, photographs, video, installations and architectural models, this exhibition at MoMA highlights variations on the single-family home.
lead_paragraph: If modern architecture has a quintessential building type, it is the apartment block — those functional, rigidly structured urban compressors that made architecture a form of social planning. The single-family home, by contrast, was a more suspicious thing. It stood for individualism, and therefore against progress — or at least the kind of progress envisioned in the grand metropolitan plans of the last century.

headline: Venturing Outside for Opera and More on the Big Screen
abstract: Outdoor cinema across town will offer a little something for everyone, the most notable being the Metropolitan Opera’s Summer HD Festival.
lead_paragraph: As the end of summer nears, the options for outdoor cinema begin to dwindle. But judging from the lineup over the next several days, summer is not yielding just yet. On outdoor screens across town, there will be a little something for everyone, the most notable being the Metropolitan Opera’s Summer HD Festival.

headline: Review: Elaine Lustig Cohen’s Paintings Move Into Philip Johnson’s Glass House
abstract: An exhibition at Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., includes paintings by Ms. Lustig Cohen as well as examples of her collaboration with Johnson.
lead_paragraph: NEW CANAAN, Conn. — Philip Johnson left behind a complicated legacy, which is entering an expansive new phase with exhibitions like the current one of Elaine Lustig Cohen’s paintings from the 1960s and ’70s at his 49-acre estate in New Canaan, Conn.

headline: When Airlines Looked Cool and Showed It
abstract: A conversation with Matthias C. Hühne, the author of “Airline Visual Identity, 1945-1975,” a collection of hundreds of vivid and colorful posters from the golden age of flying.
lead_paragraph: In more ways than one, “Airline Visual Identity, 1945-1975” (Callisto Publishing) is a hefty piece of work, landing at 430 pages, weighing 14 pounds and selling for $400. But the true size of its ambition is how it reveals the optimism of the Jet Age through nearly 400 posters and images from airlines like Pan Am, TWA, and United, evoking a time now seen as the golden age of flying.

headline: Record Number of Claims Filed Against New York Police a Year Ago, a Report Says
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The city comptroller’s office also found that preliminary data for the most recent fiscal year indicated an 11 percent decrease in personal-injury and other tort claims.
lead_paragraph: Personal-injury and other tort claims filed annually against the New York Police Department soared to a new high of 9,448 one year ago, according to a report released Thursday by the city comptroller’s office.

headline: The City that Lingers Between Day and the Dark
abstract: Lynn Saville’s photographs of New York at night capture that near-dark moment when one state of being is just about to become something else.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Saville’s photographs of New York at night capture that near-dark moment when one state of being is just about to become something else.

headline: Obama, in New Orleans, Praises Results of Federal Intervention
keywords: ['Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Ten years after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, President Obama argued that his efforts had not only restored the city to its pre-storm state, but made it even better.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — President Obama came to this once-stricken city on Thursday to make a case for his entire presidency: that when disaster strikes, the federal government should help not only to rescue the stranded but also to rebuild better and fairer than before.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Almost 100 years after his death, Marcel Proust has finally cracked the best-seller list. Sort of.
lead_paragraph: Proust For The People: Almost 100 years after his death, Marcel Proust has finally cracked the best-seller list. Sort of. The French artist Stéphane Heuet’s illustrated interpretation of “Swann’s Way,” the first volume of Proust’s sprawling semiautobiographical novel “In Search of Lost Time,” is at No. 5 in its seventh week on the graphic novel hardcover list.

headline: New York Captured Between the Day and the Dark
abstract: Lynn Saville’s photographs of New York during that near-dark moment when one state of being is just about to become something else.
lead_paragraph: These last nights of summer, the dark never quite arrives, not in the city. It lingers in the future, along with the fall harvest and the winter cold, not so much an absence of light as the ink for a page unready to be written yet. It will come, bringing definition and clarity. For now there is just miasma.

headline: Melody Patterson, Wrangler Jane on ‘F Troop,’ Dies at 66
abstract: The actress played the scrappy postmistress and storekeeper at a military fort in the Old West staffed by bumblers.
lead_paragraph: Melody Patterson, a winsome actress best known for playing Wrangler Jane on the sitcom “F Troop” in the 1960s, died on Aug. 21 in Hollister, Mo. She was 66.

headline: When the Tragedy You’re Covering Is Your Own
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Journalists who have worked in Roanoke, Va., react to the deadly on-camera shootings of a reporter and cameraman.
lead_paragraph: ROANOKE, Va. — The young journalists had just been reported dead when the calls and messages started pouring in late Wednesday morning. They came by email and phone, via Twitter and Facebook: The diaspora was calling home.

lead_paragraph: In the industrial city of Changzhi, some factories are sputtering on and others have gone quiet, but with a slowing economy, none have much reason to expect a return to boom times.

headline: Colombians Flee Venezuela’s Crackdown on Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Deportation', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Smuggling']
abstract: With more than 1,000 people deported by order of President Nicolás Maduro, others are leaving voluntarily rather than face an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO DEL TÁCHIRA, Venezuela — At night and in the early morning, they wade across the thigh-deep river in Colombia, with televisions, refrigerators and other household possessions on their backs. By day, watched by gun-toting soldiers, they line up to cross what was once a busy international bridge now under military lockdown, dragging roller suitcases while their children shoulder school backpacks.

headline: Obama’s Sanctions Chief to Defend Iran Accord in Israel
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Adam J. Szubin, who helped negotiate the accord, will meet with Israeli government officials and foreign policy experts to make his case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s sanctions chief will arrive in Israel on Friday to defend the nuclear containment deal with Iran and try to reassure a government and public deeply opposed to the accord that the United States is still prepared to inflict severe financial penalties on Tehran for its sponsorship of terrorism and support for military proxies.

headline: Ashley Madison Users Face Threats of Blackmail and Identity Theft
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Identity Theft', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Scammers and extortionists are combing through stolen data on 30 million to 40 million Ashley Madison users in search of targets.
lead_paragraph: First, members of the adultery website Ashley Madison had their personal information unveiled to the world by hackers. Now, a bigger threat looms.

headline: Darryl Dawkins, Lovable N.B.A. Figure and Fierce Dunker, Dies at 58
abstract: Dawkins arrived in professional basketball as a gigantic teenager and became one of the game’s fiercest dunkers and most notoriously lovable characters.
lead_paragraph: Darryl Dawkins, who arrived in professional basketball as a gigantic teenager and became one of the game’s fiercest dunkers and most notoriously lovable characters, a backboard-smashing, referee-dissing, fun-loving manchild known to fans as Chocolate Thunder from Planet Lovetron, died on Thursday in Allentown, Pa. He was 58.

headline: Customers Embrace Shark Fin Substitutes
abstract: A year after New York State banned the possession and sale of most shark fins, there seems to be little clamor for the traditional delicacy.
lead_paragraph: In the narrow aisles of Golden Profit Trading, a store on Mott Street in Chinatown selling dried seafood and medicinal herbs, shelves are stocked with crates and glass jars full of ingredients not usually found outside this Manhattan neighborhood. It has dried squid, bird’s nest, abalone and, for the enhancement of energy and virility, sea cucumber.

headline: Why Carly Fiorina Has a Tough Climb to Make the Next Debate Cutoff
abstract: No matter how you work the numbers, her big deficit in the polls before the first debate will be hard to overcome.
lead_paragraph: Carly Fiorina has surged in the polls after her strong performance in the so-called kiddie debate — the debate for candidates who weren’t in the top 10 in public opinion polls to qualify for the main Fox News debate on Aug. 6. She has moved up to sixth place in the Huffington Post Pollster average.

headline: Rights Groups Stirring Over Sudan President’s Travels
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Omar al-Bashir has eluded prosecution on international charges of war crimes in Darfur, but two scheduled trips are drawing new attention to his case.
lead_paragraph: Plans by Sudan’s president to attend a World War II victory commemoration in China next week and a United Nations session later next month have angered rights groups seeking to remind the world about the international warrants for his arrest.

headline: How a Gun in a Suitcase Became a Permanent Ball and Chain
abstract: A Virginia woman’s 1985 felony conviction is an example of how the merciless application of justice can harm a person for life.
lead_paragraph: At 27, Adele Langkil, mother of a 4-year-old son in Virginia, got her first extended break from her jobs as a single parent and waitress when her parents took the boy for a weekend. She spent a few days in New York.

headline: Jessica Mendoza to Replace Curt Schilling for ESPN Broadcast
abstract: Mendoza, a gold medal-winning Olympic softball player, will fill in Sunday for Schilling, who was pulled after a controversial Twitter post.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Mendoza, a gold-medal-winning Olympic softball player, will replace Curt Schilling on ESPN’s broadcast Sunday night of the Chicago Cubs-Los Angeles Dodgers game. ESPN pulled Schilling from Sunday’s game as well as a Little League World Series game earlier this week because he shared a meme on Twitter that suggested extremist Muslims were comparable to Nazis.

headline: Sit-In Leaders Are Charged in Hong Kong
abstract: Three students who led last year’s pro-democracy Umbrella Movement in Hong Kong were charged over their roles in setting off the massive rallies and sit-ins.
lead_paragraph: Three student leaders of last year’s pro-democracy Umbrella Movement in Hong Kong — including the rail-thin teenager who at 17 became the face of the protests — were charged on Thursday over their roles in events that set off the huge rallies and sit-ins.

headline: Brisk Business at Bronx Hotel, Center of Legionnaires’ Outbreak
abstract: Guests at the Opera House Hotel have mostly been unfazed by the building’s link to the worst spreading of Legionnaires’ disease in New York City’s history.
lead_paragraph: The Opera House Hotel had to turn off its air-conditioning one hot day this month so that a cleaning crew could scrub away the Legionella bacteria lurking in the cooling tower on its roof.

headline: 2 Killed Near Chicago After Report of Hazardous Material in Home
abstract: A third person from the home was taken to the hospital in critical condition, but the authorities did not identify the material or how it got in the home.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and five others were sent to the hospital on Thursday after an encounter with hazardous material at a suburban Chicago home, the authorities said.

headline: Carlyle Finds Hedge Funds Hazardous as Its Private Equity Business Dominates
abstract: Carlyle’s core buyout business continues to exceed Wall Street’s expectations, but its track record on hedge funds has been mixed, raising questions on its ability to diversify.
lead_paragraph: If nothing else, the last week has proved it can be very difficult to run a hedge fund. The Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, has known that for much longer.

headline: Wary of Crowds, Bubba Watson Finds Himself in One Atop the Barclays Leaderboard
abstract: Watson posted a five-under-par 65 on Thursday to share the first-round lead with Spencer Levin, Camilo Villegas and Tony Finau.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — By the time the seventh threesome of the morning arrived at the tee box for its starting time Thursday at the Barclays, all 94 seats in the grandstand behind the 10th hole at Plainfield Country Club were filled, and an overflow stream of fans spilled down the stairs like an overturned cup of beer, the breakfast drink of choice for a few of the spectators.

headline: Virginia Shooting Spotlights Riddle of Workplace Safety
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: What to do with a volatile, aggrieved worker like Vester Lee Flanagan II, who killed two television employees during a live broadcast Wednesday, can be a nightmare for employers.
lead_paragraph: The problems were flagrant, and his boss began to document them, only months after Vester Lee Flanagan II started working as a reporter at television station WDBJ in Roanoke, Va.

lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of Queens surfers, Bronx Zoo gorillas and young immigrants.

headline: Virginia Killings Produce Vow From Alison Parker’s Father
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Since the murder of his daughter, Andy Parker, once a low-profile talent recruiter for small banks who also dabbled in politics and theater, is the nation’s latest crusader for gun control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Until Wednesday, Andy Parker was a low-profile talent recruiter for small banks who also dabbled in politics and theater. Today, with his 24-year-old daughter having been gunned down on live television, he is the nation’s latest crusader for gun control.

headline: The Apprentice
abstract: Eric Cancel, 19, is an apprentice jockey, or bug boy, at Saratoga, achieving some success while learning valuable lessons from fellow riders.
lead_paragraph: Eric Cancel, 19, is an apprentice jockey, or bug boy, at Saratoga, achieving some success while learning valuable lessons from fellow riders.

headline: A Life of Listing Grievances, and Then Virginia Gunman’s Final Homicidal Explosion
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ANGER (EMOTION)']
abstract: A fax, letters and interviews described Vester Lee Flanagan II as someone who felt demeaned as a black man, a gay man and a son of a successful father.
lead_paragraph: ROANOKE, Va. — For two years after losing yet another television job, Vester Lee Flanagan II lived in a nondescript apartment across the street from WDBJ Channel 7, the station that had fired him. He worked in modest jobs at several insurance companies nearby. As thoughts of murder and revenge were swirling around his brain, he did his best to keep them out of sight.

headline: Donald Trump Weighing Whether to Sign Pledge to Back Republicans’ Eventual Nominee
abstract: In South Carolina, where the candidate is discovering surprising levels of support, the state party is requiring a signature as a condition of running in the primary.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Donald J. Trump said in an interview on Thursday that he would soon decide whether to sign a pledge to support the ultimate Republican presidential nominee, something the South Carolina Republican Party is requiring to compete in the state’s critical primary.

headline: Birdie on Last Regulation Hole Leads to Playoff and Metropolitan Title
abstract: Ben Polland captured the 100th Metropolitan Open in a three-hole playoff against the 2011 champion, Tyler Hall, at Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: MAMARONECK, N.Y. — Ben Polland has a master’s in business administration from Campbell University. He is also a pretty good study on the golf course.

headline: Ahead of Party Meeting, Hillary Clinton Sends Memos to Democrats Detailing Her Strengths
abstract: On the eve of the Democratic National Committee summer meeting, the Clinton campaign released four memos from the first voting states that spell out her deep networks in each one.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s speech at the Democratic National Committee summer meeting on Friday, her campaign released four memos from the first voting states that detail the deep networks she has built in each one.

headline: California Beats Water Conservation Goal for 2nd Straight Month
keywords: ['Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Water', 'Drought', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: The state used 31 percent less water last month than in July 2013, surpassing the target of 25 percent in the second month of mandatory statewide cutbacks.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Californians cut water use by more than 31 percent in July, the largest savings the state has logged since a drought emergency was declared last year.

headline: A Patch of the Bronx Where the Corn Is as High as a Cabdriver’s Eye
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: About 15 years ago, a group of cabdrivers started an urban farm in the Spuyten Duyvil neighborhood. They grow corn, beans and tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: As Pedro Santana waited to pick up his first fare on a recent Saturday night, he stepped away from his cab, leaned over and plucked an ear of corn from a tall green stalk growing next to a sidewalk in the Bronx, shucking and halving it in one motion.

abstract: Johnson joins Matt Flynn, signed last week, and the rookie Bryce Petty at a position that could benefit from some clarity before the Jets’ season opener.
lead_paragraph: The Jets’ depth chart at quarterback is murky beyond the starter Ryan Fitzpatrick, and it grew a little more muddled Thursday when they signed the veteran Josh Johnson.

headline: Consumer Reports Gives New Tesla Its Highest Score Ever
abstract: After an initial score of 103 out of 100, editors adjusted the magazine’s scoring system to leave the electric car with a rating of 100.
lead_paragraph: Consumer Reports gave the Tesla Model S P85D sedan its highest score ever for a car, breaking the magazine’s scoring system by initially giving it 103 out of 100. Editors were forced to adjust the scoring system, leaving the electric car with a mere 100 out of 100.

keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A decision by the de Blasio administration not to appeal a state court ruling has put the Iron Triangle of Queens in limbo.
lead_paragraph: From his office in a trailer in a salvage yard in Queens, Sam Sambucci — 6’ 1”, 300 pounds — appeals for grace in one of the most graceless corners of the city.

abstract: Campaigning in South Carolina, Donald J. Trump mocked some of his fellow Republican candidates, including Sen. Lindsey Graham, who he congratulated for polling at 4% in his home state.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning in South Carolina, Donald J. Trump mocked some of his fellow Republican candidates, including Sen. Lindsey Graham, who he congratulated for polling at 4% in his home state.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A lawyer who energetically represented Christian churches whose crosses were torn down by the Chinese government has disappeared, probably into police custody, a colleague and supporters said on Friday.

headline: With Nine Unanswered Runs, Mets Finish Sweep

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Shortly after the Mets’ lineup was posted outside their clubhouse, Daniel Murphy walked over to inspect the blue card taped to the wall.

headline: What’s On TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) CASABLANCA (1942) Casablanca, Morocco, is a refuge from Nazi-occupied Europe during World War II. Rick (Humphrey Bogart) runs a cafe, where, one evening, his ex-lover Ilsa (Ingrid Bergman, above with Bogart) turns up with her husband, Victor (Paul Henreid), and Rick becomes tormented by the memory of his life with Ilsa in Paris. Eventually, the cafe is occupied by Nazis as well, and Rick becomes tangled up with them, Ilsa and Victor. The film won three Academy Awards. “Mr. Bogart is, as usual, the cool, cynical, efficient and super-wise guy who operates his business strictly for profit but has a core of sentiment and idealism inside,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The Times in 1942. “In short, we will say that ‘Casablanca’ is one of the year’s most exciting and trenchant films. It certainly won’t make Vichy happy — but that’s just another point for it.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 28, 2015.

headline: On the Jersey Shore, Las Vegas Meets Coney Island
abstract: The kitschy hotels that turned Wildwood into a postwar destination for a generation of baby boomers are vanishing. But not before Mark Havens photographs them.
lead_paragraph: If Marty McFly could do a “Back to the Future” reboot on the Jersey Shore, he might have found Wildwood strangely familiar. To see it for ourselves, there’s no need for a DeLorean or plutonium. Your sedan will do the trick. Just set your GPS to Ocean Avenue, and marvel at an anomaly of space and time called the 1950s.

headline: Kim Jong-un Says North’s ‘Military Muscle’ Made Korean Deal Possible
abstract: The agreement “was by no means something achieved on the negotiating table,” North Korea’s official news media quoted the country’s leader as saying.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in his first public comments on the recent deal struck with South Korea to defuse border tensions, said leverage provided by the North’s nuclear arms program had made the “landmark” agreement possible, Pyongyang’s official news media reported on Friday.

headline: Europe Reels From More Migrant Deaths on Land and Sea
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: Deaths of about 150 people at sea near Libya and 71 found in a truck in Austria came as the United Nations reported a surge in 2015 migrations.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Europe reeled from fresh shocks in its escalating migration crisis Friday, with reports that 150 people drowned in the Mediterranean and news that far more bodies had been found crammed in an abandoned refrigeration truck in Austria than first thought. Damage to the vehicle’s side raised the possibility that victims had struggled to escape.

headline: Calls for Gun Control After Shooting of TV Broadcasters
abstract: Two readers call for America to finally take action against gun violence after the latest shooting.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Small-Beer Donors in the Big Money Casino
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Elections (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The donors carrying the Bernie Sanders campaign are a refreshing break from the egregious money bundlers.
lead_paragraph: As a measure of democracy, one of the more encouraging statistics of the 2016 presidential race is the fact that the average contribution to the long-shot campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders is $31.30. It would be hard to buy any politician for $31.30. That is exactly the message Mr. Sanders intends, in renouncing fat-cat, super PAC campaigning that is turning American politics into an exercise in plutocracy.

headline: When ISIS Rapists Win
abstract: A look at the shocking means the Islamic State uses to spread its ideas.
lead_paragraph: The ISIS atrocities have descended like distant nightmares upon the numbed conscience of the world. The first beheadings of Americans had the power to shock, but since then there has been a steady barrage of inhumanity: mass executions of Christians and others, throwing gay men from rooftops, the destruction of ancient archaeological treasures, the routine use of poison gas.

headline: A Refugee Tragedy in Austria
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Europe remains divided on how to handle the migrant crisis, even after a grim discovery in Vienna.
lead_paragraph: European leaders attending a summit meeting Thursday in Vienna had already shifted their focus to Europe’s growing refugee crisis when the terrible news came: the decomposing bodies of more than 70 people, assumed to be refugees smuggled into Europe, were discovered packed in a truck only miles away, apparently abandoned by human traffickers.

headline: How Common Core Can Help in the Battle of Skills vs. Knowledge
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'No Child Left Behind Act']
abstract: High-stakes testing isn’t the only problem, and it’s time for schools to change their approach.
lead_paragraph: Washington — STANDARDIZED tests are commonly blamed for narrowing the school curriculum to reading and math. That’s one reason Congress is considering changes in the law that could lead states to put less emphasis on test scores. But even if we abolished standardized tests tomorrow, a majority of elementary schools would continue to pay scant attention to subjects like history and science.

But the big party is with the Democrats as they meet in Minneapolis to hear the candidates try to curry favor with the party’s leaders.

headline: Bill Bryson Fears Humans More Than Bears
abstract: The travel writer on animal attacks, a mugging at knifepoint and Midwestern decency.
lead_paragraph: Park rangers along the Appalachian Trail are preparing for a huge influx of visitors, thanks to the release of ‘‘A Walk in the Woods,’’ the movie based on your book about trying to hike the whole thing. What type of person do you think would see that movie and think, I want to do that, too? Well, that’s a good question, because I’ve had at least as many people tell me that my book has put them off the idea of walking the Appalachian Trail.

lead_paragraph: First, get the right safety equipment. Before you rev up your saw’s two-stroke engine, invest in padded, cut-resistant chaps. A chain saw ‘‘can be a dangerous tool,’’ says Takao Hayashi of Yamaguchi, Japan, winner of this year’s U.S. Open Chainsaw Sculpture Championship in Eau Claire, Wis.

headline: Before Saying Farewell at U.S. Open, Mardy Fish Intends to Stay for a While

headline: ‘Mirror. Memory’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Cultural memory often involves a good measure of willed forgetting, an overlooking of some parts of experience in favor of a dominant narrative. In this poem, the precise imagery of faces reflected in a kettle — “misted and revealed” — hints at how these subjects are at once obscured and plainly seen. Here, the memory of people who are often left out of history is set against the imagery of the painting, connected by the single long sentence from which the poem is made.

headline: European Publishers Play Lobbying Role Against Google
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Magazines']
abstract: An alliance of newspaper and magazine publishers has taken an increasingly active role in fighting the growing dominance of the tech giant.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In private sessions this summer, giant publishers and media companies from Germany, France and elsewhere have met with European officials about proposals to regulate Europe’s digital economy. The discussions have covered a broad range of contentious issues, according to public disclosures and several people who attended or were briefed on the meetings. Central to almost all of them has been limiting the reach of a single American company: Google.

headline: Tirana, Breaking Free From Communist Past, Is a City Transformed
abstract: The Albanian capital’s brightly colored buildings and palpable energy are indicative of the long way the capital has come since the fall of its Communist regime in 1991.
lead_paragraph: You begin to understand Tirana, the capital of Albania, the first time you try to cross the city’s main road, which locals simply refer to as Boulevard. There are zebra-striped crosswalks, and cars stop if they must, but the feat is something akin to stage diving into a free-form automotive ballet. Confidence is the operative word here — coupled with an understanding that Albanians live by a rhythmic, improvisational code: Fill space when it’s free.

The Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index had climbed 6 percent from the low of Tuesday’s close by the end of Thursday.

headline: Steady Financial Advice, With Friendship as a Bonus
abstract: It is rare to meet actual orphans with stock portfolios, let alone ones who have hung on to investments for nearly 50 years.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Anxiety-prone investors looking for safety in the stock market have sometimes found it in so-called widows-and-orphans stocks. At their best, they pay dividends for decades and bounce around a bit less when the markets convulse, as they have over the last week. For years, AT&T was the textbook example. Procter & Gamble was another.

headline: Tennessee Williams Short Stories, Now as One-Acts

headline: Play About Incarcerated Women Wins Best of Edinburgh Award
abstract: Catrina McHugh’s “Key Change,” directed by Laura Lindow, was commissioned by a development company in England that specializes in work with prisoners.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — The real stories and experiences of women in a United Kingdom prison form the basis for “Key Change,” this year’s winner of the annual Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award, to be announced here on Friday. The award is presented each year to a single theater production at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe that has never been presented in New York City, and the winning show is produced the following winter in New York. Past winners of the prize include “The Object Lesson,” written and performed by Geoff Sobelle, and David Greig’s “The Events.”

lead_paragraph: “There’s an absurdity to living in an age when everything is photographed,” Mishka Henner, a Belgian-born artist, said recently from his home in Manchester, England, emphasizing, in particular, that every square inch of the earth seems to have been photographed and all of it is accessible online — including some of the world’s most secret places.

headline: A City Rises in Queens for the U.S. Open
abstract: A miniature metropolis quickly takes shape in Flushing Meadows every August. With a stadium under construction this year, “quickly" became an understatement.
lead_paragraph: Every August since 1978, a city within a city has popped up in Flushing Meadows, Queens. In just a few weeks, the corner of an almost 900-acre public park is transformed into the United States Open, along with its six fully staffed restaurants and 60 concessions stands, 20 stocked and staffed stores, five active loading docks, dozens of artfully landscaped tennis courts and strolling areas, a police force the size of a small Montana town, and three stadiums filled with passionate tennis fans, some of whom will probably soon be dancing the “Whip/Nae Nae” for the “spider cam” at Arthur Ashe Stadium. All of this hustle and bustle will help to bring in an estimated $700 million-plus for the New York area.

headline: 1998 in 2015
abstract: We’ve seen a lot of this movie.
lead_paragraph: David Beckworth has a good if possibly over-elaborate discussion of China’s flirtation with crisis. What I find striking is the extent to which China has managed to put itself into something like the situation many of its neighbors faced in the late 1990s. The renminbi “wants” to depreciate, partly because of a slowing economy and monetary easing, partly because of a crisis of confidence and capital flight. But Chinese authorities aren’t willing to let it drop all the way, perhaps because of fears of trade conflict but also perhaps because the private sector and state-owned enterprises now have a lot of foreign-currency debt.

lead_paragraph: Ireland’s show jumping team was looking good to qualify for next summer’s Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro. The Olympic medalist Cian O’Connor was perfect through 10 fences.

headline: 1890: France-U.S. Trade Dispute
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: Trade disputes arise between the U.S. and France in 1890.
lead_paragraph: No one denies that if the American pig is addicted to the dissemination of trichinosis and if French wines are unwholesome, France has legally the right to exclude pigs from her territory and the United States has the right to exclude French wines. But is it not rather absurd to exclude pigs and wine and admit tourists? In old days the ocean passage was so long that if a traveler had contracted a contagious or infectious disease before starting, it was certain to be developed before the passage was ended.

headline: Fear of Asymmetry
abstract: Why nerds don’t want to understand politics.
lead_paragraph: David Roberts has a very nice essay on American politics, framed as an analysis of what nerds don’t get; but it’s not just nerds who seem weirdly blind to the reality here.

headline: Tax-Free Savings Accounts for Disabled Are Expected in 2016
abstract: The plans, known as 529A or Able accounts, are being created in most states and could grow to $100,000 without jeopardizing federal benefits.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL savings accounts for people with disabilities are likely to become available in most states next year.

headline: 1940: Color Television to Start Jan. 1
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: Color television awaits broadcasting in 1940.
lead_paragraph: A demonstration of television in full color was shown privately to James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, by the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday in its laboratories at 485 Madison Avenue. Paul W. Kesten, vice-president of C.B.S., said the company expected to be broadcasting color television commercially by Jan. 1. The system used, which was developed by Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, C.B.S. chief television engineer, would not render existing television sets obsolete, Mr. Kesten said. The receiver used in the demonstration was of standard type, adjusted to a minor extent and equipped with a simple attachment which can be produced at comparatively small costs, while other tests proved that standard sets without any adjustment would receive black and white images broadcast by the new method. — New York Herald Tribune, August 30, 1940

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Glenn Ligon
abstract: The artist shares the titles he’d most want to take with him on a desert island.

The next installment in the series comes from the conceptual artist Glenn Ligon, who shares his picks exclusively with T.

headline: Governor Christie’s Gift to Exxon Mobil
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'States (US)', 'Water Pollution', 'Wetlands']
abstract: The company will have to pay just $225 million for its pollution of New Jersey’s wetlands.
lead_paragraph: For years, New Jersey officials have been trying to make Exxon Mobil Corporation pay for their “staggering and unprecedented” pollution of the state’s northeastern wetlands. The price tag for damages and cleanup of more than 1,500 acres in the Linden and Bayonne areas was estimated at $8.9 billion. Gov. Chris Christie settled for a payout of $225 million from Exxon, a paltry sum that won the approval of a state judge earlier this week.

headline: Virginia Shooting Victims Were Hit in Head, Autopsies Show

lead_paragraph: The Virginia television reporter and cameraman whose murder on live television has renewed a national debate over gun violence both suffered gunshot wounds to the head, the chief medical examiner’s office in Roanoke said Friday.

headline: Inventive Menus at Soho House Berlin’s New Restaurant
abstract: The Store Kitchen, off the lobby of Soho House in Mitte, is drawing a stylish crowd with its creative takes on ambitious, vegetable-focused dishes.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday evening in the fashionable neighborhood of Mitte, a crowd of artists and D.J.s descended on a large marble-top table loaded with seasonal dishes: radishes served with freshly churned kefir butter; Dutch oysters flavored with ponzu ginger and chile. Within 20 minutes, the platters were empty. This record release party took place at the Store Kitchen, a new restaurant within a recently opened design emporium called the Store, off the lobby of Soho House.

lead_paragraph: For much of the city’s Asian community, the center of New York City is not in Manhattan, but in downtown Flushing, Queens, the bustling shopping district at the end of the No. 7 subway line. Soon this crowded commercial hub will grow even busier as sales start early next month at Flushing Commons, a mixed-use development that has been in the works for a decade.

headline: Fans in Cary, N.C., Protest as FIFA Scandal Hits Their Little Home Team
abstract: The Carolina RailHawks of the North American Soccer League face existential questions as a result of a crackdown on corruption at the sport’s highest levels.
