headline: Reminder: Private Mortgage Insurance Is Temporary
abstract: A compliance bulletin from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau suggests that lenders sometimes collect premiums longer than they should.
lead_paragraph: Home buyers who can’t put at least 20 percent down usually have to carry private mortgage insurance, often an expensive proposition. One good thing about mortgage insurance, though, is that it doesn’t last forever.

headline: Ashley Madison Chief Steps Down After Data Breach
abstract: The change came after hackers stole the online dating service’s data and released personal information related to more than 30 million accounts.
lead_paragraph: In the last two years, online attacks have led to executive casualties at prominent companies like Sony Pictures Entertainment and Target. Now add to the list the chief executive of the company operating the adultery website Ashley Madison, a lesser known but far more salacious victim.

headline: The Key to Soupe au Pistou: Lots of Vegetables
abstract: In the South of France, this hearty soup can vary from village to village. Just keep the ingredients fresh and flavorful.
lead_paragraph: My first experience of soupe au pistou, that vegetable soup from the South of France, was in a freezing cold Paris garret. From a can, in the middle of winter. It remains one of my warmest and most nourishing memories.

headline: U.S. Citizen, Once Held in Egypt’s Crackdown, Becomes Voice for Inmates

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — MOHAMED SOLTAN knew he had one thing going for him when the Egyptian police came to his door: He was a United States citizen, raised primarily in Ohio.

headline: No Retrial for North Carolina Officer Who Killed Unarmed Man

lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — North Carolina will not retry a white police officer who killed an unarmed black man who had just survived a car crash, state officials said Friday. The officer’s trial ended in a hung jury.

She had taken LSD at a Grateful Dead concert one weekend in 1989. When Mrs. Sacher called to check on her that Monday, Keisha wasn’t making sense.

abstract: It is baffling that the agency would be so worried about a website for male escorts.

lead_paragraph: Al Arbour, who coached the New York Islanders to four consecutive Stanley Cup championships in the 1980s and finished his career with the second-most coaching wins in National Hockey League history, died on Friday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82.

Trump and other Republicans for “hateful” remarks — “The party of Lincoln has become the party of Trump,” she said acidly — and pledged to rebuild the Democratic political machine to help candidates win races nationwide.

headline: Eric Betzig’s Life Over the Microscope
keywords: ['Microscopes', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Chemistry', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Physics']

lead_paragraph: In October 2014, the Nobel Prize in Chemistry went to three scientists for their work developing a new class of microscopes that may well transform biological research by permitting researchers to observe cellular processes as they happen.

headline: The Birkenstock Doctor
abstract: Business is booming for Tom Lonergan, a retiree in Ohio who is one of the brand’s few independent repairmen.
lead_paragraph: To track the rise of Birkenstocks, one might look to their reinterpretation in Céline’s Spring/Summer 2013 collection, peep under the tables of any Brooklyn coffee shop, or read Vogue’s seal of approval (“Pretty Ugly: Why Vogue Girls Have Fallen for Birkenstocks”). Alternatively, one could simply call Tom Lonergan. The sixty-something retiree living in Ohio doesn’t know a thing about couture (“Selena? Selena who?” he responded when asked about the Céline tipping point), values comfort in attire above all else and has never paid any attention to the strange, mercurial shifts in fashion. But two years ago, Lonergan’s mail order Birkenstock’s repair business doubled in orders overnight. For years, orders had come from Vermont, Maine, New Hampshire and Florida, but suddenly, return labels increasingly sported ZIP codes in New York and California. Women sent in pairs they’d worn at college in the ’90s and wanted to refurbish; millennials mailed damaged, rare styles they’d found on eBay.

headline: Upper East Side Penthouse for $37.94 Million

headline: Rudolph Giuliani’s Outrage on Homelessness, and Richard Gere’s
abstract: In an interview with NBC’s local news channel in New York, former mayor Rudy Giuliani complained about a homeless man who had taken up residence on his block.
lead_paragraph: If the offenses of Donald J. Trump weren’t getting played out by the hour at the volume of a jackhammer in competition with a Nascar event, then recent comments by another New Yorker synonymous with unchecked expressiveness, and also touched by the pixie dust of presidential aspiration, might be generating more outrage. In an interview with NBC’s local news channel in New York, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani explained, with both glee and self-regard, that not long ago he had paid a visit to the 19th Precinct station house on the Upper East Side to complain about a homeless man who had taken up residence on his block.

headline: On Patrol With the Black Mambas
abstract: Portraits of a majority-female South African anti-poaching squad.
lead_paragraph: For the past two years, the majority-female Black Mamba Anti-Poaching Unit has patrolled the Balule Nature Reserve, a private wildlife reserve in northern South Africa. The Balule has an open border with Kruger National Park, an Israel-size reserve that has in recent years been besieged by poachers in pursuit of the park’s famed wildlife — particularly its rhinoceroses, whose horns are now worth hundreds of thousands of dollars on the international black market.

headline: The History of the Sweeney Building in Brooklyn
abstract: The Sweeney Building, once home to the W.H. Sweeney Manufacturing Company in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, is now a residential property.
lead_paragraph: Q. Many years ago, when I was still Mrs. Sweeney, our three boys in Brooklyn Heights never had to ask us, “Where did we come from?” because the answer was plain to see: the Sweeney Manufacturing Company, just to the right of the Brooklyn Bridge. Alas, the sign is gone. What happened?

headline: Superiority Burger, a Vegetarian Ode to White Castle in the East Village
abstract: Despite its name, Superiority Burger’s burgers have no hamburger meat, and the cheese steak has neither cheese nor steak.
lead_paragraph: Is there such a thing as vegetarian food for carnivores? Superiority Burger, which opened near Tompkins Square in June, is a shoebox-size, white-tiled ode to White Castle, with a chef who comes from the tonier, meat-oriented Del Posto. The new restaurant’s name alone would seem likely to deter the quinoa-faithful.

headline: How Heather McGhee, President of Demos, an Advocacy Group, Spends Her Sundays

lead_paragraph: Heather McGhee, the president of the left-leaning research and advocacy group Demos, often begins her Sundays by giving her mother something to talk about. “She’s the person who has a lot of opinions about my appearance,” said Ms. McGhee, 35, a frequent guest on morning talk shows and on MSNBC. Besides doing on-camera stints, she likes a day without meetings, conferences or fund-raising talks, instead pursuing culture with friends. She lives in Greenwich Village with two cats.

headline: 6 Great Things About the Great New York State Fair
abstract: Organizers claim it is the oldest state fair in the United States, dating back at least to 1841. Big names like Melissa Etheridge and Snoop Dogg are scheduled to perform this year, but there are smaller reasons why the fair still matters.
lead_paragraph: Organizers claim it is the oldest state fair in the United States, dating back at least to 1841. Big names like Melissa Etheridge and Snoop Dogg are scheduled to perform this year, but there are smaller reasons why the fair still matters.

headline: The Drunk Man in the Park
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Unaccustomed to people drinking alcohol in public, a group of Syrian refugees is bemused by a Belgrade resident who is helpful, but drunk.
lead_paragraph: Unaccustomed to people drinking alcohol in public, a group of Syrian refugees is bemused by a Belgrade resident who is helpful, but drunk.

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Tongue Launches a Thousand Selfies
abstract: The singer’s trademark expression has spread throughout the Web.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, two icons of commercialized youth rebellion will come together: the MTV Video Music Awards and Miley Cyrus’s tongue.

headline: Robyn, the Space-Age Disco Queen With a Dark Bent
abstract: Robyn may be known for her uptempo dance music, quirky lyrics and sky-high platform shoes, but pain and sorrow lurk beneath her raver-style armor.
lead_paragraph: Robyn, the 36-year-old Swedish pop star, was in Los Angeles recently, decked out in a pale blue bustier and lying on a bed, as part of the video shoot for her latest single, “Love Is Free.”

headline: India Virtually Eliminates Tetanus as a Killer
abstract: The country sees success in its 15-year campaign against lockjaw, in part by providing incentives for mothers to give birth in clean conditions

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dancers in an Eclectic Menu at Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: The company opened a yearlong anniversary celebration with a program that mostly included recent works by European men.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — The ghost of Ted Shawn, who turned a farm here into the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival and worked tirelessly to present dancing as a manly activity, might have been pleased to see a burly guy chopping wood on Thursday on the barnlike stage of the Ted Shawn Theater. Shawn might have been tickled, too, to learn that the man wielding the ax was a member of the dance troupe of his old student and partner Martha Graham.

headline: Review: ‘Fireface’ Explores Incest, Jealousy and Pyromania
abstract: The German writer Marius von Mayenburg’s play about troubled adolescent siblings is at the Brick Theater in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: There are rules about shouting “Fire!” in a crowded theater. But it’s almost unbearably tempting to yell it during Third Space’s production of “Fireface,” particularly when a Zippo-wielding sociopath begins splashing what is ostensibly gasoline across the narrow stage floor of the Brick, near enough to spray your sandals.

headline: New York Theater Ballet Announces Season
abstract: New York Theater Ballet returns to the stage on Sept. 19
lead_paragraph: A blend of family-friendly fairy tales and revivals of dances by Merce Cunningham and Pam Tanowitz are in store for New York Theater Ballet’s coming season.

headline: The Battle for the Soul of the Hamptons
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: This summer, a particularly aggressive gold-rush mentality is transforming sleepy enclaves of the East End into redoubts of McMansions and party zones.
lead_paragraph: More than 150 years ago, Manifest Destiny drove American pioneers westward. A horde of speculators and moguls staked claim to everything before them as they pressed onward to the Pacific, their mission being to “overspread the continent allotted by Providence for the free development of our yearly multiplying millions,” as the journalist John L. O’Sullivan wrote in 1845.

headline: New Jersey Barbecue Joints Find Their Secret in the Smoke
abstract: Hambone Opera in Trenton and Big Harlie’s Barbecue in Sayreville are aiming to make a name for barbecue in the Garden State.
lead_paragraph: What sensation the word barbecue evokes depends on the region you have in mind. Texas barbecue summons the smell of mesquite smoke, the brawn of beef. Think North Carolina and get a whiff of vinegar, the crackle of a pig on a spit. The meat may be fine in Georgia, but what I remember is those bags of sliced white bread. Now close your eyes and consider what the following phrase conjures: New Jersey barbecue.

headline: Protecting Your Mac From Malware and Viruses
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Software', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security']
abstract: How to see if a Mac has been infected and what to do about it; plus, changing uppercase to lowercase, and vice versa, in Microsoft Word.
lead_paragraph: Q. I thought Macs were supposed to be protected from malware, but I’ve gotten those fake tech support pop-ups and ads in Safari. I have to force the browser to quit to get away from them. Could my Mac be infected?

headline: Review: ‘Dumbo,’ With Glitter and Lap Dances, Takes Flight at Jack
abstract: Bailey Nolan’s performance piece also incorporates hula hoop tricks and some loud singing along.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much distance there is between yourself and seventh grade, that outcast feeling never really disappears: Dumbo lives inside us all.

headline: Injured ‘Wicked’ Actress Seeks Evidence in Court
abstract: A member of the “Wicked” ensemble who fell from a rope during a performance is asking a court to order the show to preserve evidence of what happened to her.
lead_paragraph: A 35-year-old actress who fell from a rope during a performance of “Wicked” has asked a court in Manhattan to order the show to preserve evidence of what happened to her.

headline: Review: ‘A Delicate Ship’ Plumbs the What-ifs of Love and Heartbreak
abstract: Two men tussle, verbally and philosophically, for the affections of a woman in Anna Ziegler’s memory play about the fragile dynamics of relationships.
lead_paragraph: Snowflakes drift lazily down, a view of a cityscape looms through the blurry night, and the crisp scent of a freshly cut Christmas tree fills the air as the lights go up on “A Delicate Ship,” a lovely drama by the newly (and justly) hot playwright Anna Ziegler. But the serenity evoked by this atmosphere soon gives way to storms of philosophical debate and emotional turbulence in this memory play about the fragile dynamics of young relationships, and the mysterious workings of time.

headline: Erdogan Approves Caretaker Government in Turkey
abstract: The prime minister assigned the interim government, which includes cabinet ministers from a pro-Kurdish party for the first time, until elections on Nov. 1.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The short-term interim government approved Friday by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey allowed pro-Kurdish party lawmakers to take up ministerial posts for the first time in the country’s history. But the two ministers who were appointed are not expected to survive this fall’s election.

headline: New Jersey Festivals Offer Jazz, Bluegrass and a Chance to Do the Twist Again
abstract: Live music is an attraction at a half-dozen block parties, carnivals and the like around the state in September, including new gatherings in Clark and Asbury Park.
lead_paragraph: For fans of live music, the end of summer signals the tapering off of festival season, not to mention barbecues and beach trips. But in New Jersey, September is shaping up to be as robust a month for outdoor multi-act concerts as June or July.

headline: August 28, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Hungary, Libya, India and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Hungary, Libya, India and South Africa.

headline: Review: ‘Pearl’ Visits the Many Worlds of ‘The Good Earth’ Author
abstract: Diversions and diversities abound in this dance-theater spectacle about Pearl S. Buck, the revered writer who interpreted China to the West.
lead_paragraph: Before seeing the new dance play “Pearl,” the chief questions in my head were: “Why tell the life of the writer Pearl S. Buck in dance? And how?” But this production at the David H. Koch Theater, directed and choreographed by Daniel Ezralow, answers those quickly, repeatedly and variously.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads about New Orleans and the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: A Great Night for Hurling
abstract: Whether it is a low-level match on a rural field in County Galway or the intercounty final at Croke Park in Dublin, hurling is an amateur endeavor that sparks Ireland’s passions.
lead_paragraph: Whether it is a low-level match on a rural field in County Galway or the intercounty final at Croke Park in Dublin, hurling is an amateur endeavor that sparks Ireland’s passions.

headline: A Passion for Hurling, the All-Ireland Game
abstract: Hurling can be likened to a mash-up of lacrosse, field hockey and baseball, but in truth, it is a game all its own.
lead_paragraph: KINVARA, Ireland — Thirty men battle on a deep-green field, each one wielding what looks like a field hockey stick moonlighting as a broken oar. They chase a ball that fits snug in the hand, sometimes balancing it on their sticks as they run, sometimes swinging the sticks in midsprint to arc the ball toward a goal’s uprights.

headline: Europe’s Halting Response to Migrant Crisis Draws Criticism as Toll Mounts
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The escalating death toll has highlighted the bloc’s failure to quit squabbling and come up with a unified plan for a crisis months in the making.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The daily toll among refugees and migrants desperately trying to reach Europe — 71 suffocated in a truck in Austria and 150 drowned off Libya this week — has dramatically underscored the European Union’s scattered, halting response to increasing waves of asylum seekers.

headline: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, campaign barbecue and an outstanding teenager in New Hampshire in this week’s political pictures.
lead_paragraph: The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, campaign barbecue and an outstanding teenager in New Hampshire in this week’s political pictures.

headline: Restaurant Review: Lost & Found in Long Beach Has a Chef Who Goes for the Flavor Bomb
abstract: This culinary hideaway is tucked among the rowdy bars in this seaside town. It can be tough to find, and the regulars like it that way.
lead_paragraph: Lost & Found, a culinary hideaway tucked among the rowdy bars of Long Beach’s West End, can be hard to find. During the day, the blinds are drawn, the phone goes unanswered and the only sign of life is a discreet stenciled logo on the front window.

headline: Review: Majorca, a Hartford Restaurant Where the Tastes of Spain Shine
abstract: A meal at Majorca transports diners to the romance of the Mediterranean island.
lead_paragraph: I recall the island of Majorca in Spain from a long-ago visit — blaring azure vistas, vertiginous roads and vaguely racy-sounding villages (Fornalutx) where tiny cafes served exciting food: raw and peppery sobrasada, eggplant ratatouille, roast suckling pig and lots of olives, almonds and garlic.

headline: Rebekah Brooks Said to Be Returning to News Corp. in Britain
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Just over a year after being acquitted of charges in a phone-hacking and bribery scandal, a longtime protégée of Rupert Murdoch is set to take on a senior role in his company.
lead_paragraph: Rebekah Brooks, the editor and publishing executive who four years ago became embroiled in a phone-hacking scandal in Britain, is set to return to Rupert Murdoch’s media empire in a senior role, an executive with knowledge of the company’s plans said on Friday.

headline: Antiterrorism Laws Prompt British Library to Distance Itself From Taliban Project
abstract: A project to digitize Taliban documents was shelved by the British Library after the institution determined that publishing the collection could breach antiterrorism laws.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A decision by the British Library not to host a huge collection of Taliban-related documents, despite years of close involvement with the project, has added to concerns that Britain’s sweeping body of antiterrorism legislation is impinging on academic freedom.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
abstract: The 10th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, campaign barbecue and an outstanding teenager in New Hampshire in this week’s political pictures.

headline: At Wave Hill, Photos of New York’s Trees, ‘Living Archives’ of the City
abstract: The Manhattan photographer Benjamin Swett’s exhibition at Wave Hill in the Bronx evokes the sense of place of 10 natural monuments.
lead_paragraph: The first image visitors see when exploring “New York City of Trees,” an exhibition of 10 photographs by Benjamin Swett at Wave Hill, in Riverdale, the Bronx, is bound to leave the wrong impression.

headline: Martin O’Malley Rails at Democrats for Debate Schedule ‘Rigged’ to Aid Hillary Clinton
abstract: The former Maryland governor accuses Democrats of trying to suppress debate among their presidential candidates while Republicans are spewing “racist hate.”
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS – Martin O’Malley had one clear chance to make waves within the Democratic National Committee, and he seized it, delivering a fiery speech Friday that condemned his party’s leadership for what he called a process “rigged” to help Hillary Rodham Clinton — namely, curtailing the number of presidential primary debates.

headline: U.N. Official to Visit Central African Republic Amid Scrutiny Over Peacekeepers
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations’ top human rights official, is to meet with the new acting leader of the peacekeeping mission, which has been roiled by sexual abuse allegations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The way the United Nations has handled sexual abuse allegations against peacekeepers in the Central African Republic has come under sharp scrutiny, including on the high commissioner for human rights, Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein.

headline: Art Show Captures the Wrenching Effects of Closing a School
abstract: “reForm” is set in a model classroom from a Philadelphia school, with a blackboard, cubbies, books — and oral testimony about the school’s closure.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A school may be made of bricks and mortar, but when one closes, the loss can feel like a death in the family.

headline: Bernie Sanders Warns Democrats They May Not Win in 2016 Without Him
abstract: Taking his outsider message into the heart of the Democratic establishment, Bernie Sanders warned party leaders that the huge crowds he has drawn may not vote for Democratic candidates in 2016 unless he is at the top of the ticket.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS – Taking his outsider message into the heart of the Democratic establishment, Senator Bernie Sanders, the Vermont independent, challenged hundreds of the party’s leaders on Friday to embrace his candidacy, warning that the huge crowds of supporters he has drawn may not vote for Democratic candidates in 2016 unless he is at the top of the ticket.

headline: Beatles and Abba Items to Be Auctioned
abstract: Items associated with the Beatles and Abba will be auctioned over the next month.
lead_paragraph: Money can’t buy you love, but enough of it can buy the rare Beatles memorabilia being auctioned this weekend in Liverpool.

headline: Restaurant Review: The Diversity of Indian Cuisine Is at RaaSa in Elmsford
abstract: The chef Peter Beck, a maestro of spice, takes the menu for RaaSa beyond the typical north Indian offerings.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, when Peter Beck was the chef at the Indian restaurant Chola in Manhattan, Ruth Reichl, then The New York Times’s restaurant critic, regarded it highly enough to give it two stars.

headline: Precious Objects From Vanishing Estates on Long Island
abstract: An exhibition at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages displays lavish furnishings and fine pieces from mostly vanished palatial estates.
lead_paragraph: Did Otto Hermann Kahn, a banker, financier and arts patron, have a rival Long Island estate on his mind as he built his own palatial house, Oheka, in Huntington in 1917?

headline: Georgia Engel, a ‘Mary Tyler Moore Show’ Sidekick, Takes a Star Turn
abstract: Ms. Engel, best known for Georgette on the 1970s sitcom, returns to the stage in the play “John,” which features her in her first leading role.
lead_paragraph: On the closing night of Annie Baker’s adaptation of “Uncle Vanya” at Soho Rep three years ago, Ms. Baker took the actress Georgia Engel aside and whispered in her ear: “I’m writing a play for you.”

lead_paragraph: Uber is continuing its hiring spree of top technical talent by recruiting two respected computer security engineers, Charlie Miller and Chris Valasek.

lead_paragraph: Newport coaching weekend, where hats added to the festivities.

headline: Edinburgh Festival Fringe Offers Stories That Are More Personal, Less Political
abstract: Intimate struggles — autism, depression, cancer — were significant themes among the theater offerings at this festival.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — Despite loathing audience participation, there I stood onstage in a small black box performance space here recently, gyrating my hips and spinning a hula hoop before a packed house. Nearby, a couple of people were clumsily attempting to spin plates on sticks, and others in the audience were trying the same with anything suitable they could find in pockets or handbags.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Garden Party
abstract: Hats added to the festivities at the coaching weekend in Newport, R.I.
lead_paragraph: A highlight of the Newport coaching weekend was a luncheon given by Eaddo and Peter Kiernan (No. 1) at their home, where the Frederick Law Olmsted gardens have been restored to their original splendor. A tent for 200 guests was set among the gardens that overlook Narragansett Bay. The 11 coaches from the morning drive were parked on the lawn that sweeps down to the bay. Hats added to the festivities.

headline: Evening Hours | Newport Coaching Weekend
abstract: Newport coaching weekend included a white-tie dinner dance for coach drivers at the Breakers, the former home of Cornelius Vanderbilt II.
lead_paragraph: Newport coaching weekend included a white-tie dinner dance for coach drivers at the Breakers, the former home of Cornelius Vanderbilt II.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Yale Students Campaign for All That Jazz
abstract: After learning that their ensemble was suspended for the coming year, band members are fighting back.
lead_paragraph: Michael Hoot and his compatriots value their hard-won seats in the Yale Jazz Ensemble, a Yale University-sponsored big band. So it did not sit well when Thomas C. Duffy, who as university director of bands had led the ensemble for 34 years, suspended its operations for the coming year — and possibly beyond — citing a loss of rehearsal space and a lack of qualified brass players.

headline: Iran and Israel United in Opposition to Daniel Barenboim Concert
abstract: Iran, citing the conductor’s Israeli citizenship, will block a performance of the Berlin Staatskapelle, a concert that an Israeli official denounced.
lead_paragraph: Cultural diplomacy can be as knotty as any other kind. The conductor Daniel Barenboim’s efforts to lead the Berlin Staatskapelle at a concert in Tehran drew criticism this week from the Israeli culture minister, who called the performance anti-Israel, and a rebuff from Iranian officials, who said on Friday that they would block the concert because of Mr. Barenboim’s Israeli citizenship.

headline: Oil Prices Jump 17 Percent in Two Days, Despite Glut
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Economy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The United States benchmark rate passed $45 a barrel on concerns of Middle East turbulence, still 50 percent below last summer’s levels.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Oil prices jumped for a second day on Friday, sending the United States benchmark past $45 a barrel, a gain of 17 percent in only two days.

headline: Pilot Killed in Crash of Home-Built Plane at Stewart International Airport
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Air Shows and Air Racing', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The pilot, who was from Texas, was scheduled to perform this weekend in the New York Air Show at the airport in Newburgh, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A small plane crashed shortly after takeoff at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., on Friday afternoon, killing the pilot.

headline: Poetic Connections: Nice View; Rough Delivery
abstract: Poems of the fumblings of love in the Hamptons, “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of Craigslist.
lead_paragraph: There’s a tendency to think of the Hamptons as a municipal collective of elegant perfection, the sort of place where lovers meet at just-so garden parties or sneak away to moonlit beaches where nothing can go wrong. But at least according to the following poems, the posh East End communities are as plagued by erotic mischance, romantic awkwardness and the plain old fumblings of love as anywhere. The poems were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are reprinted verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

headline: Ruth Sivard, Economist Who Scrutinized Military Spending, Dies at 99
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Ms. Sivard drew attention to the disparity between social and military spending for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Sivard, an economist who for more than three decades drew attention to the disparity between social and military spending around the globe, even after the Pentagon objected to her making that comparison for a federal agency, died on Aug. 21 at her home in Washington. She was 99.

headline: Obama Tries to Soothe Divided Jewish Community on Iran Deal
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Speaking to Jewish umbrella organizations, President Obama defended his nuclear accord with Iran and called for a more civil debate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama appealed to a divided and troubled Jewish community on Friday, defending his nuclear accord with Iran as in the security interest of both the United States and Israel, and calling for a more civil debate with a congressional vote just weeks away.

headline: Child Goddesses in Nepal
abstract: Among the Newar people of Nepal’s Kathmandu Valley, some girls are worshiped as living goddesses, or Kumaris.
lead_paragraph: Among the Newar people of Nepal’s Kathmandu Valley, some girls are worshiped as living goddesses, or Kumaris.

headline: Consumer Anxiety in China Undermines Government’s Economic Plans
abstract: Middle-class Chinese are reining in spending amid the economic slowdown, damaging the ruling party’s hopes to push consumer spending as a new engine of growth.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In recent days, an advice column has circulated widely on China’s most popular social media phone app. Titled “Guide on Safe Passage Through the Economic Crisis,” it is aimed at young Chinese urban professionals. Its nuggets of wisdom include: “Work hard at your job so you are the last to be laid off” and “In an economic crisis, liquidity is the number one priority.”

headline: Countries Under the Most Strain in the European Migration Crisis
abstract: European Union officials struggle to cope with the growing crisis.
lead_paragraph: European Union officials struggle to cope with the growing crisis.

headline: American Pharoah Awes Saratoga Springs on Eve of Travers
abstract: American Pharoah, the Triple Crown champion, is a 1-5 favorite at the New York racetrack known as the Graveyard of Champions for humbling previous Triple Crown winners, including Gallant Fox, Secretariat and Affirmed.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — They have come here from Boston and Los Angeles, Atlanta and Cincinnati, and places in between, all to see the Big Horse, a title long thrown around lightly but now deservedly worn by American Pharoah. He is the sport’s 12th Triple Crown champion, the winner of eight straight races, each punctuated with a performance more impressive than the last.

headline: Psychologists Welcome Analysis Casting Doubt on Their Work
keywords: ['Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: To some, the news that most studies do not hold up when retested came as a relief, like the field had “come clean,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: The field of psychology sustained a damaging blow Thursday: A new analysis found that only 36 percent of findings from almost 100 studies in the top three psychology journals held up when the original experiments were rigorously redone.

headline: Bystander Shot by Undercover Police Officer Dies
abstract: The 61-year-old man was hit in Mount Vernon, N.Y., during an investigation into a suspected illegal arms dealer that went awry, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A bystander accidentally shot by an undercover New York City police officer on Friday afternoon during an illegal firearms sting gone awry has died, the Police Department said on Saturday.

headline: Tony Finau’s Unorthodox Path to Tour Success
abstract: The first stick that Finau learned to maneuver was not a golf club but one with knives on either end that is used in a warrior dance in Samoa, where his ancestors are from.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — Tony Finau finished a television interview Friday as Scott Piercy was making his way to the nearby 10th tee for the start of his second round at the Barclays. Piercy slowed to bump the fist of Finau, whose one-under-par 69 at Plainfield Country Club had moved him into a tie for the early Friday lead in the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs.

headline: Now Playing Around the World, the ‘Trump Show’
abstract: Donald Trump is derided as “a nutcase” in France and “a racist” in China, and his anti-immigrant rhetoric baffles Germany, where his grandparents were born.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that Donald J. Trump, who has dominated the race for the Republican presidential nomination for the past month, has become  a reviled figure in Latin America for his inflammatory remarks about Hispanic immigrants. His statements have won him plaudits from nativists at home, but his showy candidacy has not gone unnoticed in other parts of the global village.

headline: Man Is Fatally Shot and 3 Others Are Injured at Brooklyn Hookah Bar
abstract: The police have yet to publicly identify the assailant in a shooting that unfolded at the Buda Hookah Lounge on Flatbush Avenue on Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: The first bullets hit Chrispine Phillips in the chest, arm and head. As he fell fatally injured inside a crowded hookah bar in Brooklyn on Friday morning, the assailant ran for the door, shooting as he went.

headline: Ruling Limits Protests Outside Supreme Court
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Sidewalks', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An appeals court upheld restrictions on protesters’ First Amendment rights to gather and wave signs on the plaza in front of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday upheld 65-year-old limits on protesters’ First Amendment rights to gather and wave signs on the grand plaza in front of the Supreme Court, reversing a district court ruling that had found the restrictions “plainly unconstitutional.”

headline: Friday Night Music: Courtney Barnett, Avant Gardener
abstract: A cheerful song about asthma.
lead_paragraph: In honor of my coming visit to Australia. Saw her at SXSW; a bit rawer than my usual taste, but very good.

abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article on mass transit problems.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mets Set Team Home Run Records in an August to Remember
abstract: Bolstered by trades and the return of some injured players, New York has already broken a franchise record for home runs in a month.
lead_paragraph: Terry Collins studied the itinerary for the Mets’ last road trip and noticed a common theme. The Mets would be playing at Camden Yards in Baltimore, Coors Field in Denver and Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia. All are home run havens.

headline: NASA’s New Horizons Spacecraft Has Next Mission After Pluto
abstract: The spacecraft will visit 2014 MU69, another piece of the frigid debris beyond Neptune along the Kuiper belt.
lead_paragraph: The next destination for NASA’s Pluto probe is to be a much smaller ice ball in the outer solar system, the space agency announced on Friday.

headline: Grim Findings in Austria and at Sea Push Migrant Crisis Into Public View
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Human Trafficking', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The discovery of 71 bodies in a truck in Austria, and the drowning of more than 150 people off the Libyan coast have led to new calls to focus on human trafficking.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — They were the lucky ones. Packed into a small white truck, 34 migrants, 10 of them children, had made the hourslong drive from Serbia, begging for air in broiling summer temperatures. According to the police, the three people smuggling this human cargo into Austria refused to stop.

headline: Ban Abortion for Down Syndrome?
abstract: Readers discuss an Ohio bill that would prohibit women from having abortions after a diagnosis of Down syndrome in the fetus.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Arizona: Lawyer Paid to End Suit Against Homeland Security
abstract: The department reached a settlement with the top lawyer in the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency in Arizona, who had claimed discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security has reached a settlement with the top lawyer in the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency in Arizona, who sued the department in 2014 claiming discrimination. The lawyer, Patricia M. Vroom, said she was bullied and harassed by officials in Washington because she raised concerns about an Obama administration policy applying prosecutorial discretion to spare some immigrants from deportation. Ms. Vroom will be paid $399,999 to end the suit, and a recent annual performance rating will be revised upward to “achieved excellence.” She had said top legal officials lowered her rating after she moved cautiously to allow the release of some undocumented immigrants with criminal records, a rebuke she said amounted to age and sex discrimination. Her lawyer said that as part of the agreement, Ms. Vroom would retire on Oct. 1 after 30 years working for the federal government. Homeland Security officials did not admit wrongdoing.

headline: Dementia and the Breakdown of Moral Judgment
abstract: Readers recall the experience of relatives.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Ruling With a Bonus for Fast-Food Workers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Organized Labor', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Franchises', 'Corporations', 'Minimum Wage', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: Corporate parents may have to take responsibility for franchise workers, giving a big lift to the Fight for $15 movement.
lead_paragraph: The “Fight for $15” campaign is about more than higher pay for fast-food workers. It is also about fighting for the right of workers to form strong unions without retaliation. That goal looks much more achievable this week after a National Labor Relations Board ruling that may force corporate parents, like McDonald’s or Yum Brands, to take responsibility for workers at franchises.

headline: A Break in the Khobar Towers Case
abstract: Saudi Arabia seems to have finally apprehended the mastermind of the 1996 bombing that killed 19 American airmen. He should be tried in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The 1996 terrorist attack on Khobar Towers in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 United States airmen was among the defining events of America’s recent experience in the Middle East. But there has been no judicial accountability. With the reported arrest of the man accused of masterminding the crime, a resolution of the case may be closer.

headline: In Alaska, Obama Will Be in Middle of Oil and Climate Change Battle
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As the president visits Alaska to examine the effects of climate change, the state is battling over oil, its chief source of revenue, and the implications of drilling.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE, Alaska — Gov. Bill Walker ticks down the things he wants President Obama to see in visiting this vast northern state starting on Monday, and glorious glacial vistas are not at the top of the list.

headline: Show Some Spine, Federal Reserve
abstract: It needs to raise interest rates. But it’s scared of the stock market.
lead_paragraph: THE financial markets and the Federal Reserve Board have been playing out a tragicomedy in three acts. Here’s how it works: Initially, a flurry of news stories appear about how, a few months hence, the Fed intends to raise short-term interest rates for the first time in years. Second, the predictable market swoon, as Wall Street traders ponder the fact that the morphine drip of free money that they have been enjoying since the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis might be pulled out of their arms. Finally, the Fed backs away from its much-overdue policy change, causing traders to rejoice and the artificially stimulated bull market in both stocks and bonds to continue. The curtain comes down, and the audience roars its approval.

headline: How to Halt the Violence
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: We must treat mental illness much more aggressively.

headline: Marks of Derision

lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — The people who write to me to say that they would never dare attempt to solve a Saturday New York Times crossword puzzle should really try this one by Evan Birnholz.

headline: Buying Sex Should Not Be Legal
keywords: ['Prostitution', 'Women and Girls', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Decriminalizing prostitution will hurt, not help, women.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — HERE in my city, earlier this month, Amnesty International’s international council endorsed a new policy calling for the decriminalization of the global sex trade. Its proponents argue that decriminalizing prostitution is the best way of protecting “the human rights of sex workers,” though the policy would apply equally to pimps, brothel-keepers and johns.

headline: U.S. Open Qualifiers Brave a Gantlet Into the Main Draw

lead_paragraph: For some, the qualifying draw of the United States Open is a launching pad. For others, it is a place to land, comfortably or not, after enjoying greater heights in tennis. For 16 men and 16 women, it was a gantlet to reach the main draw.

headline: Jets’ New Practice Drill Leads to a Few Dings. Of a Bell.
abstract: Using a bell, suspended 7 or 8 yards behind the offensive lineman, adds incentive but also provides a landmark for pass-rushers during practices.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Walking out to the Jets’ first padded practice of training camp, Nick Mangold spotted a contraption that left him stumped. From a distance it resembles a cherry picker without a bucket: A long, adjustable arm sprouts from a post, and at the end of it hangs a bell, and below that a speed bag dangling about seven feet above the ground like pugilistic mistletoe.

headline: U.N. Urges the Netherlands to Stop Portrayals of ‘Black Pete’ Character

headline: With Two Big Bats Out of Lineup, Yanks Still Feast on Subpar Pitching
abstract: Without Alex Rodriguez and Mark Teixeira, and unable to use a designated hitter in a National League park, the Yankees pounded out 16 hits in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The slumping Yankees staggered south without their two most threatening bats in the lineup, one because there is no place for a designated hitter in a National League park and the other because his troublesome shin showed no sign of getting better.

headline: Texas: Sheriff’s Deputy Is Fatally Shot at Gas Station
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A uniformed Harris County deputy was fatally shot in suburban Houston late Friday as he was pumping gas, the sheriff’s office said.
lead_paragraph: A uniformed Harris County sheriff’s deputy was fatally shot at a gas station in suburban Houston late Friday. The deputy, a 10-year veteran, was pumping gas when he was shot multiple times by an unknown assailant who approached him from behind, said Ryan Sullivan, a spokesman for the Harris County Sheriff’s Office. The sheriff’s office later identified the deputy as Darren Goforth. The shooting took place around 9 p.m. at a busy intersection in unincorporated Harris County. Other law enforcement agencies joined the sheriff’s office in an intensive search for the gunman late Friday night. “We’re currently working to ascertain the physical description or identity of the suspect,” Mr. Sullivan said shortly before midnight.

headline: Inside-the-Park Homer Brings Mets’ 7-Game Winning Streak to an End
abstract: Matt Harvey shut down Boston for six innings, but the Red Sox responded with a three-run seventh and went ahead for good on a 10th inning inside-the-park home run by catcher Blake Swihart.
lead_paragraph: Tucked in the lower-right-hand corner of the giant video board in center field at Citi Field, a new graphic appeared Friday. It promoted a matchup that is still more than a month away, when the Washington Nationals visit on Oct. 2, the final weekend of the regular season.

headline: What’s On TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2 P.M. (Showtime 2) AMERICAN GRAFFITI (1973) It’s the last night of summer in 1962, and a group of recent high school graduates prepares for college, Vietnam and the rest of life in this film by George Lucas. They hang out at Mel’s Drive-In, cruise up and down the main strip of town while listening to Wolfman Jack and attend one last school dance. A young Harrison Ford drives a black Chevrolet. “American Graffiti exists not so much in its individual stories as in its orchestration of many stories, its sense of time and place,” Roger Greenspun wrote in The New York Times. “Although it is full of the material of fashionable nostalgia, it never exploits nostalgia.” He continued, “It is a very good movie, funny, tough, unsentimental.” The film also stars Ron Howard and Cindy Williams (together above), Richard Dreyfuss and Charles Martin Smith.

As it entered its final week, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s spring Costume Institute show, “China: Through the Looking Glass,” was attaining blockbuster status.

headline: Before Trump or Fiorina, There Was Wendell Willkie
keywords: ['Presidential Elections (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', "New Deal (1930's)", 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mr. Willkie is rare among major-party candidates: He was a political outsider whose main qualification was to have been the chief of a large company.
lead_paragraph: If either Donald Trump or Carly Fiorina receives the 2016 Republication presidential nomination, it will be a rare achievement. Only once in American history has a major political party granted its prize to someone whose principal qualification was to have served as a corporate chief executive. That was in 1940, when Wendell Willkie was the Republican candidate against President Franklin Roosevelt, who was seeking a third term.

headline: Artificial Unintelligence
abstract: Despairing thoughts on what passes for sophistication.
lead_paragraph: In the early stages of the Lesser Depression, those of us who knew a bit about the macroeconomic debates of the 1930s, and realized how relevant the hard-won insights of Keynes and Hicks were to the post-financial crisis world, often felt a sense of despair. Everywhere you looked, people who imagined themselves sophisticated and possessed of deep understanding were resurrecting 75-year-old fallacies and presenting them as deep insights.

headline: Prison Vendors See Continued Signs of a Captive Market
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: As judges and policy makers debate sentencing changes to curb incarceration, those who sell goods to jails and prisons find little cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything that cannot be turned into a weapon? Walk around the exhibitors’ hall at the conference of the American Correctional Association, held in Indianapolis in early August, and at some point the question will answer itself. Apparently, with enough malign intent and the right tools — a lighter, for instance — even disposable plates can be transformed into shivs.

abstract: After bring routed by the Yankees, 21-5, in late July, Texas made moves to stabilize its pitching staff, and its offense was on a tear in the second half.
lead_paragraph: The bold summer revival of the Texas Rangers began immediately after they hit bottom. On July 28, three days before the nonwaiver trading deadline, the Rangers scored five runs in the first inning against the Yankees. Then they gave up the next 21 runs of the game, without getting a hit.

abstract: With warming seas creating new opportunities at the top of the world, nations are scrambling over the Arctic. But Russia may be beating the United States to the punch.

headline: Lebanese Protesters Aim for Rare Unity Against Gridlocked Government

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Lebanese demonstrators gathered on Saturday evening to protest towering garbage piles, corruption and political dysfunction, infusing new momentum into a campaign for better governance that seeks to unite citizens often divided by religion and politics.

headline: Mets Find Lineup Solutions in a Single, Mysterious Chart
abstract: Manager Terry Collins has a new tool as he tries to maximize the Mets’ offensive output daily, although he has been instructed not to reveal too much.
lead_paragraph: Before every series, Mets Manager Terry Collins receives a three-ring binder full of scouting reports, charts and numbers. Collins combs through the information, wearing his glasses, highlighting things as he goes, making notes in pencil. He uses the binder to help fill out his lineup each day, a task that has become much more complex lately.

headline: Rousting the Book Pirates From Google
abstract: A writer finds her e-book in Google Play with a different author’s name on the cover, revealing Google’s slow response to complaints of pirated works.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler will now don his professorial tweeds because he starts this episode in teacher mode. All of the action below revolves around the Google Play store, an online destination that may be unfamiliar to Apple fans. So a brief explanation. You know iBooks, iTunes and the App Store? Well, Google Play is all of those rolled together, for anyone using devices with the Android operating system.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With his own decathlon world record in reach but with 1,500 meters still to run, Ashton Eaton did anything but stay in the moment.

headline: In Sharing Baseball’s Joys, Mourning Something Lost
abstract: Nearly three decades after making a baseball cross-country trip with buddies, a reporter takes his young sons on a truncated version and sees how different things are.
lead_paragraph: With our road trip just days away, I was having second thoughts. Was this going to be too much baseball? I asked my son. “No such thing as too much baseball!” he answered. I smiled. We were ready.

keywords: ['Horses', 'Careers and Professions', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Every Thursday, a Spanish interpreter leaves the bustling city behind to spend an afternoon volunteering as a mounted National Park Service patroller.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday at noon, I ditch the San Francisco courthouse where I work as a Spanish interpreter and high-tail it home to swap my conservative suit for breeches and dusty paddock boots. I arm myself with allergy pills, nasal spray and a puff from an asthma inhaler. Patches on my windbreaker and baseball cap identify me as a National Park Service volunteer.

lead_paragraph: With a stadium bearing his name at the United States Open, an obvious link binds the jazz legend Louis Armstrong to tennis. But one of Armstrong’s recordings with Ella Fitzgerald, “Let’s Call the Whole Thing Off,” at times encapsulates a subtle feature of matches.

abstract: The attacks, which killed at least 12 people, came after an insurgents’ takeover of a strategic district in Helmand Province on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents killed three prominent local government officials and at least nine other people in three separate attacks in southern Afghanistan on Saturday.

headline: The Summer That Never Was
keywords: ['Summer (Season)', 'Age, Chronological', 'Seasons and Months', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In middle age, the last days of August bring not just melancholy, but a sense of desolation, as of a possibility lost forever.
lead_paragraph: I NEVER went to Iceland. I suppose I should say I didn’t go to Iceland this summer — never sounds a little melodramatic, possibly terminal. It’s not as if I’ve died and all hope of ever having gone to Iceland is obviated. But for some reason this missed opportunity is causing me more than the usual, near-toxic level of regret. I’ve had a free apartment in Reykjavik on offer for several years, and somehow I’ve never made it there. The owner of the apartment sends me photos of the aurora borealis that break my heart.

headline: Casey Harris
abstract: The visually impaired keyboardist for the X Ambassadors on the importance of the reader in audiobooks and good dialogue in TV shows.
lead_paragraph: Casey Harris is the keyboard player for the indie rock band X Ambassadors, whose song “Renegades” has been No. 1 on Billboard’s Alternative chart for the past 11 weeks.

headline: Diet Advice That Ignores Hunger
abstract: Researchers say, cut calories. But they don’t take into account what that means over the long term.
lead_paragraph: TOWARD the end of the Second World War, researchers at the University of Minnesota began a legendary experiment on the psychology and physiology of human starvation — and, thus, on hunger. The subjects were 36 conscientious objectors, some lean, some not. For 24 weeks, these men were semi-starved, fed not quite 1,600 calories a day of foods chosen to represent the fare of European famine areas: “whole-wheat bread, potatoes, cereals and considerable amounts of turnips and cabbage” with “token amounts” of meat and dairy.

headline: The Real Threat to Hillary Clinton
abstract: Is John Kasich the toughest Republican for a Democrat to face?
lead_paragraph: THE predicted Republican front-runner flails. The actual Republican front-runner rails, peddling insults instead of ideas. And the story line caroms from misogyny to xenophobia to a tussle over tresses: toupee or not toupee?

abstract: America’s visionaries left us a wilderness where egalitarianism thrives.
lead_paragraph: THE other day, my teenage daughter and I were idly browsing real estate porn, a monument to American inequality: a private island in the Bahamas selling for $17.9 million; a 900-acre retreat in Washington State for $11 million; and an 83-acre estate in Colorado for a cool $100 million.

headline: Raging as My Sister’s Light Dims
abstract: After she’s gone, I won’t have one family root left in the ground. Not one person who remembers. Or wants only the best for me.
lead_paragraph: Don’t let anyone try to soft-pedal what is going on, use metaphors and literary allusions to turn my sister’s cancer into a great meeting with the blessings of life.

headline: Donald Trump, Traitor to His Class
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: The future of the Republican Party may hinge on whether it absorbs much of his message of discontent or tries to ignore it.
lead_paragraph: THE Donald Trump phenomenon is a great gift to pundits because it can be analyzed and criticized in so many different ways. But two shorthands seem particularly useful. First, Trump is essentially using the Republican primary to run a third-party campaign, not a right-wing insurgency. Second, Trump’s appeal is oddly like that of Franklin Roosevelt, in the sense that he’s a rich, well-connected figure — a rich New Yorker, at that — who’s campaigning as a traitor to his class.

headline: Bush and Clinton Dynasties Hit Trump Bump
abstract: Jeb Bush’s and Hillary Clinton’s sense of entitlement to ascend politically has left each vulnerable.

headline: Tea With the Queen? In Their Dreams
abstract: It’s hard for Britons to imagine a post-Elizabethan monarchy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — QUEEN ELIZABETH II, at 89, is a very old lady. By day, her subjects see less of her than they used to. But by night, it’s different. Then she and her family visit millions of households up and down the kingdom. Up to a third of Britons have dreams about Her Majesty and the royals.

headline: Optimistic About Inflation, Stanley Fischer Suggests That Fed Will Stick to Plan on Rates
abstract: The remarks of the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman were highly anticipated after days of turmoil in financial markets that raised questions about whether the Fed’s plans had changed.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The Federal Reserve’s vice chairman, Stanley Fischer, said on Saturday that he saw “good reason” to expect that inflation would rebound to a healthier pace as the American economy continued to grow.

headline: The Battle for Biomedical Supremacy
abstract: Some medical schools are making lucrative offers to star researchers from other schools. This is not necessarily a bad thing.
lead_paragraph: States from coast to coast are using public funds to help their medical schools recruit scientific stars from other states or to prevent their own stars from being lured away by lucrative offers. There have long been recruitment battles among academic institutions, but today we’re in the midst of what The Chronicle of Higher Education calls a “boom in academic poaching.”

headline: As the Stock Market Swings
abstract: After recent ups and downs, it’s hard to escape a vague sense of unease.
lead_paragraph: By the close of the stock market on Friday, the recent ups and downs in share prices had worked out to a mild correction. In all, the market was down 6.6 percent from its all-time high in May.

headline: A Peace Plea for South Sudan
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Even after the recent deal, the United States and others must apply continued pressure to finally end the civil war.
lead_paragraph: It would be satisfying to celebrate the peace deal signed in South Sudan as an end to the warfare that has been the lot of the land’s 12 million people for most of the past 60 years, including the extraordinarily cruel civil conflict that has ravaged the country since independence in July 2011. But at least eight cease-fires have collapsed since civil war erupted in December 2013, some within hours of being signed, and both sides have already accused each other of continuing attacks. Only continued pressure by the United Nations and the United States on the South Sudanese leaders will give the peace any chance.

headline: The Water Receded. The Anger’s Still Here.
keywords: ['Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Levees and Dams', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s been 10 years since the flood. Why can’t New Orleanians just move on?
lead_paragraph: New Orleans — WHY are we still so angry? Even sympathetic newcomers can’t quite figure out why we New Orleanians are not over it a decade later.

headline: Texas Deputy Killed ‘Because He Wore a Uniform,’ Sheriff Says
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Officials said they had not confirmed a motive for the killing of Texas Deputy Darren H. Goforth, who was fueling his patrol car outside Houston, but tied it to protests over police shootings.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A 30-year-old Houston man was arrested Saturday in the fatal shooting the night before of a sheriff’s deputy who was filling the gas tank of his patrol car.

headline: Europe to Bolster Railway Security After Thwarted Train Attack
abstract: European officials, meeting in Paris, agreed to increase checks at stations and on trains, and called for better sharing of intelligence.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — European countries have agreed to increase security checks in railway stations and on trains, and are calling for improved cooperation among intelligence services, France’s interior minister said Saturday after an emergency meeting of European officials in Paris.

headline: The Art of the Presidential Exit
abstract: Obama’s second act may be more like Clinton’s than the Bushes’.
lead_paragraph: Washington — OVER dry martinis and drawn-out dinners with artists, authors, tech billionaires and Hollywood moguls, President Obama has begun to contemplate life after the White House.

headline: Topless Women in Times Square
keywords: ['Street Performers', 'Women and Girls', 'Pedestrian Malls', 'Nudism and Nudity']
abstract: Some readers bemoan and others revel in the carnival-like atmosphere that includes mostly naked women painted patriotically.
lead_paragraph: The X-rated establishments of days past have given way to almost naked painted women and Elmos seeking tips from tourists.

headline: A Decade After Katrina, New Orleans Is Partying Again, and Still Rebuilding
abstract: A lineup of citywide volunteer projects, prayer services, festivals and parades marked what was an unseasonably mild day 10 years after the storm made landfall.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — “Today is ceiling drywall,” said Dani Babon, a 24-year-old site supervisor for the St. Bernard Project, a volunteer group that was started the year after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: With Ruble’s Decline, Russian Tourists Gain Appreciation for the Motherland
abstract: Since the ruble’s fall late last year put foreign vacations out of reach of many in the middle class, more Russians are choosing to vacation at home.
lead_paragraph: VYATSKOYE, Russia — The tourists streamed out of the tall white bus onto an asphalt parking lot in the middle of this spruced-up village. Wearing sun hats and wielding cameras, they peered into the gardens of brightly painted houses and listened to a tour guide talk about enterprising peasants.

headline: New Alternatives to Statins Add to a Quandary on Cholesterol
keywords: ['Series', 'Praluent (Drug)', 'Repatha (Drug)', 'Statins (Cholesterol-Lowering Drugs)', 'Cholesterol', 'Heart', 'Medicine and Health', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Diabetes', 'Doctors', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Doctors find it difficult to ignore patients’ complaints about statins, which are much cheaper, even though clinical trials have found that they have minimal side effects.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Doctors have long faced a conundrum in prescribing statins to lower cholesterol and heart attack risk: The drugs are cheap and effective for most people, and large, rigorous clinical trials have found minimal side effects. But as many as 25 percent  of those who try them complain of muscle pain. Others stop taking the drugs because, they say, they cause a hazy memory or sleep problems, among other side effects not documented in studies.

headline: California Death Penalty, Struck Down Over Delays, Faces Next Test
abstract: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit will review a ruling last year that found the state’s capital punishment system to be dysfunctional.
lead_paragraph: Whether California’s application of the death penalty is so drawn out and arbitrary that it amounts to cruel and unusual punishment will be argued on Monday before a federal appeals court in Pasadena.

headline: American Pharoah Is Calm Amid the Saratoga Storm
abstract: As he prepared for the Travers Stakes, the Triple Crown winner took the adulation and attention in stride.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — It was 3 p.m. Friday and the Triple Crown winner American Pharoah was taking a stroll near Barn 25, where he was stabled ahead of Saturday’s Travers Stakes at Saratoga Race Course. He stopped to pose for members of the news media and his adoring fans at each end of the wooden green barn, where security barricades had been set up since his arrival Wednesday.

headline: In a Venezuelan Border Town, a State of Emergency Is Barely Perceptible
abstract: A state of emergency at the border town of San Antonio del Táchira has shown arbitrary policing and few changes in daily public activity.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO DEL TÁCHIRA, Venezuela — President Nicolás Maduro has declared a state of emergency in this Venezuelan border town in what he says is nothing less than a fight for national survival. More than 1,000 Colombian immigrants have been deported and some basic guarantees, like the right to hold most public gatherings, have been suspended.

headline: As Homicide Rate Rises, Washington Mayor Pledges Action
abstract: Two men were fatally shot on Friday in Washington, bringing this year’s homicide count to 105, a more than 40 percent increase over the same period a year ago, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The police in Washington on Saturday were investigating the fatal shootings of two men the night before, the latest in a city that has seen a sharp increase in homicides this year.

headline: A High Point on the Appalachian Trail
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The storied Appalachian Trail, which begins 2,190 miles away in Georgia, ends with a final scramble up Mount Katahdin, Maine’s highest peak.
lead_paragraph: The storied Appalachian Trail, which begins 2,190 miles away in Georgia, ends with a final scramble up Mount Katahdin, Maine’s highest peak.

headline: As Hikers Celebrate on Appalachian Trail, Some Ask: Where Will It End?
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Faced with increasing crowds and partylike behavior by a few, officials are threatening to reroute the Appalachian Trail so that it does not end atop Maine’s highest peak.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT KATAHDIN, Me. — The storied Appalachian Trail, which begins 2,190 miles away in Georgia, ends here, with a final scramble up Maine’s highest peak — some of it nearly vertical, much of it blocked by boulders. For those who have trekked five or six months, Katahdin’s iconic summit is an exhausting challenge with a rewarding end.

headline: Keen Ice Defeats American Pharoah at Travers Stakes
abstract: Keen Ice edged American Pharoah at Saratoga Race Course, known as the Graveyard of Champions, where iconic horses like Gallant Fox, Affirmed and Secretariat had lost.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — They were fully aware of this historic racetrack’s reputation for felling iconic horses like Gallant Fox and Affirmed, as well as immortal ones, like the great Secretariat. They also knew of its charms, how racehorses are not only loved here but revered and how the people who follow them believe this is truly Valhalla.

headline: Venezuelan Border Town Remains Active Despite President’s Order
abstract: A state of emergency at San Antonio del Táchira, which shares a border with Colombia, has spurred little change in daily public activity.
lead_paragraph: A state of emergency at San Antonio del Táchira, which shares a border with Colombia, has spurred little change in daily public activity.

headline: Conflicting Advice
abstract: Lee Taylor has us coming and going.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There is a concept in psychology called the “backfire effect,” and basically it explains why no one will ever win an argument on the Internet.

headline: Paul Royle, Who Fled Nazis in a ‘Great Escape,’ Dies at 101
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Prisoners of War', 'Prison Escapes', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Paul Royle briefly escaped from Stalag Luft III in 1944 with 75 other Allied soldiers, an episode that inspired the 1963 Steve McQueen movie “The Great Escape.”
lead_paragraph: Paul Royle, whose escape from a German prisoner of war camp in 1944 with 75 other Allied soldiers inspired the 1963 Steve McQueen movie “The Great Escape,” died on Aug. 23 in Perth, Australia. He was 101.

headline: Johan Renvall, American Ballet Theater Principal, Dies at 55
abstract: Born in Stockholm, Mr. Renvall was a figure-skating champion before joining the Royal Swedish Ballet at the age of 18.
lead_paragraph: Johan Renvall, a principal dancer at American Ballet Theater whose range there from 1978 to 1996 could stun audiences with spectacular classical technique and — in dramatic ballets — powerful intensity, died on Monday in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: The Jordanian Aid Worker
abstract: A veteran aid worker finished a stint in South Sudan and then decided to tour the Balkans. He came to Belgrade, saw refugees in the parks and soon discovered Refugee Aid Serbia, a donation center.
lead_paragraph: A veteran aid worker finished a stint in South Sudan and then decided to tour the Balkans. He came to Belgrade, saw refugees in the parks and soon discovered Refugee Aid Serbia, a donation center.

headline: George Cleve, Conductor Who Interpreted Mozart, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Cleve, who was born in Vienna, fled with his family to the United States and spent most of his American career on the West Coast.
lead_paragraph: George Cleve, a conductor known to New York audiences for his guest appearances with the Mostly Mozart Festival and the New York City Ballet, died on Thursday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Bystander’s Death Shows Risks in Gun-Buy Stings
abstract: Hazards of undercover police work were made clear when an investigation into illegal firearms sales in the Bronx quickly turned into a deadly shooting in Mount Vernon.
lead_paragraph: In a dangerous profession, it is among the most dangerous of jobs. The police officers who go undercover to arrest illegal firearms dealers can quickly find themselves at the mercy of their targets, conducting big-money transactions in close quarters with jumpy, suspicious criminals quick to draw guns.

headline: Torpor Overtakes the Mets in a Second Straight Loss at Home
abstract: The Mets, who mashed 23 home runs in nine recent road games, were stifled by the Red Sox’ Joe Kelly, failing to produce anything in seven opportunities with runners in scoring position.
lead_paragraph: After a rollicking trip in homer-happy parks like Baltimore, Colorado and Philadelphia, the Mets were as confident as they had been in years when they returned to Citi Field on Friday. But so far, in two games back home, their offense has crash-landed with a pronounced thud.

headline: Ryan Palmer Plays On Despite a Painful Loss
abstract: Palmer, whose father recently died, shot a five-under-par 65 and was tied for fourth at the Barclays, the first event in the FedEx Cup playoffs.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — Fathers and sons go together in golf like tee boxes and drivers. Where you find one, the other typically follows. For many of the top players, their fathers were the ones who breathed life into their golf dreams. That was certainly the case for Ryan Palmer, a Texan who was 9 when his father, Butch, introduced him to the game.

headline: Andrelton Simmons and Didi Gregorius Share Journey: Small Island to Big Leagues
abstract: When Gregorius and Simmons, shortstops for the Yankees and the Braves who grew up in Curaçao, reunite, old stories are not all that they share.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The first time Andrelton Simmons set eyes on Didi Gregorius, what he noticed was not Gregorius’s strong throwing arm, his fleet feet or anything he did with a bat in his hands. They were, after all, only 5 years old.

headline: Kyle Jean-Baptiste, Actor in ‘Les Misérables,’ Dies at 21
abstract: Mr. Jean-Baptiste, who fell off a fourth-floor fire escape in Brooklyn, was the first black actor to play the lead role of Jean Valjean in the Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Jean-Baptiste, the first African-American actor to play the lead role of Jean Valjean in the popular Broadway musical “Les Misérables,” died on Friday after falling from a fire escape in Brooklyn. He was 21.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Episode 4 Recap: Extradition Blues
abstract: What’s the best way to get America involved in the fight against Escobar? Invoke the specter of communism.
lead_paragraph: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: Met Extends Show on China’s Fashion Influence
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “China: Through the Looking Glass” is attaining blockbuster status, Vanessa Friedman writes. It’s proven so popular, including with Chinese visitors, that it will be extended through Sept. 7, Randy Kennedy reports.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s “China: Through the Looking Glass” is attaining blockbuster status, Vanessa Friedman writes. It’s proven so popular, including with Chinese visitors, that it will be extended through Sept. 7, Randy Kennedy reports. Read more »

headline: ‘Hannibal’ Series Finale Recap: Give Us a Hug
abstract: A satisfying ending to this season, but a deeply disappointing way to end this series.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 13: “The Wrath of the Lamb”

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Finds Rhythm as Jets’ Offense Shows a Pulse
abstract: Fitzpatrick, thrust into a starting role after Geno Smith sustained a broken jaw, engineered two scoring drives on the Jets’ first four possessions in a preseason win over the Giants.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Every day, Ryan Fitzpatrick says, his connection with the Jets’ receivers gets a little better. Their timing improves, their relationships blossom, and their tendencies become more and more familiar to one another.

headline: Luis Severino’s Strong Outing Carries Yankees to Victory
abstract: The Yankees never trailed, but they never built a comfortable lead, instead relying on Severino, who pitched six shutout innings to keep the team a game and a half behind the Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Luis Severino pitched six shutout innings, and Didi Gregorius and Brian McCann delivered key hits for the second consecutive game as the Yankees beat the Atlanta Braves, 3-1, on Saturday.

headline: Giants Have Rough Night but See a Sliver of Hope
abstract: Early on, the Giants’ offense was sputtering and the defense was being manhandled. But at the beginning of the second quarter, the offense put together a long drive.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Saturday did not begin well for the Giants. When a team’s extensive injury list lengthens during a leisurely pregame warm-up, it figures to be a long day.

headline: Fan Dies After Falling From Upper Deck at Atlanta’s Turner Field
abstract: A middle-aged man wearing a Braves cap fell more than 40 feet during a game against the Yankees. He was pronounced dead after being taken to a hospital.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A man in his early 60s died Saturday night after falling more than 40 feet from the upper deck at Turner Field during the seventh inning of the Yankees’ 3-1 win over the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 30, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 30, 2015
lead_paragraph: “The fault is not with those who cultivate the opium. It’s with the idiots who consume it.”
