Lipson of Washington. Rabbi Daniel A. Sklar, a cousin of the groom, is to officiate at Riverside on the Potomac, in Leesburg, Va.

headline: Lauren Pueschel, James Allen Jr.
abstract: The bride is a resident at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx, and the groom is a vice president at Mic, a media company in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lauren Camille Pueschel and James Kevin Allen Jr. were married Saturday at the Brewster Inn in Cazenovia, N.Y. Joseph Greenman, a village justice of Manlius, N.Y., officiated.

headline: Irina Lisker,  Michael Weil
abstract: The couple met through JDate.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Irina Lisker and Michael Joseph Weil are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Ronald Roth at the Estate at the Florentine Gardens, a party space in River Vale, N.J.

headline: Genevieve Kimberlin,  Devon Jarvis
abstract: The wedding took place at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Genevieve Steele Kimberlin, a daughter of Joni S. Kimberlin and Kevin B. Kimberlin of Greenwich, Conn., was married Saturday to Devon Michael Jarvis, a son of Carol A. Jarvis and Jackson M. Jarvis of Fairfield, Iowa. The Rev. Jack Davidson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.

headline: Merrill West, Ryan Hardy
abstract: The bride is a dancer and choreographer, and the groom is a criminal defense and family lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Elizabeth West and Ryan Wayne Hardy are to be married Sunday at Cherry Hill in Central Park. The Rev. Dr. R. Scott Colglazier, a Congregationalist minister and a friend of the bride’s family, is to officiate.

headline: Lauren Piro, Ryan Lemanski
abstract: A senior web editor for Good Housekeeping and House Beautiful magazines marries Ryan Lemanski, who works at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Elizabeth Piro, a daughter of Linda M. Piro and Richard G. Piro of Hazlet, N.J., was married Saturday to Ryan Thomas Lemanski, the son of Karen M. Lemanski and Richard E. Lemanski, also of Hazlet. The Rev. Daniel Kirk, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Benedict Catholic Church in Holmdel, N.J.

headline: Sarah Sicher and Adam Salky
abstract: The bride is a psychiatrist; the groom is a film director.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sarah Dorothy Sicher and Adam Ross Salky are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Karen Kriger Bogard at Congregation Anshai Emeth in Peoria, Ill.

headline: Jayne Kang, Phillip Kim
abstract: The bride is an architect in Winston-Salem, where the groom is a medical student.
lead_paragraph: Jayne Kang, a daughter of Junghee Kang and Byung Jae Kang of Austin, Tex., was married Saturday to Phillip Kim, the son of Grace Kim of Blue Bell, Pa., and the late Sang Kwon. The Rev. Gerald Donnelly officiated at the Bermuda Run Country Club in Winston-Salem, N.C.

headline: Kathleen McCarthy, Brendan Kelleher
abstract: Kathleen McCarthy is a Boston Red Sox fan, and Brendan Kelleher is a Yankees fan. That didn’t keep them from getting married.
lead_paragraph: Kathleen Anne McCarthy and Brendan William Kelleher were married Saturday at Our Lady of Victories Catholic Church in Boston. The Very Rev. Brian R. Kiely, an uncle of the groom, performed the ceremony.

headline: Puerto Rico Postpones Debt Plan
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Citing time lost to a tropical storm, the government put off by one week a plan for a “negotiated moratorium” on $72 billion of debt.
lead_paragraph: Citing time lost to a tropical storm, the government of Puerto Rico on Saturday postponed by one week a plan for a “negotiated moratorium” on $72 billion of debt.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 A.M. (BBC America) THE MATRIX (1999) The Wachowskis wrote and directed this sci-fi thriller, which won four Oscars. Neo (Keanu Reeves, above), a hacker, learns from Morpheus (Laurence Fishburne) that life is really a computer-generated fiction called the Matrix, imposed on humans by robotic overlords who harvest their energy. They must protect the last real human city, Zion, while battling the machines and the evil Agent Smith (Hugo Weaving). “With enough visual bravado to sustain a steady element of surprise (even when the film’s most important Oracle turns out to be a grandmotherly type who bakes cookies and has magnets on her refrigerator), ‘The Matrix’ makes particular virtues out of eerily inhuman lighting effects, lightning-fast virtual scene changes (as when Neo wishes for guns and thousands of them suddenly appear) and the martial arts stunts that are its single strongest selling point,” Janet Maslin wrote in The Times. “As supervised by Yuen Wo Ping, these airborne sequences bring Hong Kong action style home to audiences in a mainstream American adventure with big prospects as a cult classic and with the future very much in mind.”

headline: Corrections: August 30, 2015
abstract: Correcting appearing in print on Sunday, August 30, 2015.
lead_paragraph: METROPOLITAN

headline: Oliver Sacks, Casting Light on the Interconnectedness of Life
abstract: Whether writing about his patients, his love of chemistry or the power of music, Dr. Sacks leapfrogged among disciplines, shedding light on the connections between science and art.
lead_paragraph: It’s no coincidence that so many of the qualities that made Oliver Sacks such a brilliant writer are the same qualities that made him an ideal doctor: keen powers of observation and a devotion to detail, deep reservoirs of sympathy, and an intuitive understanding of the fathomless mysteries of the human brain and the intricate connections between the body and the mind.

headline: Dr. Oliver Sacks, Explorer of the Brain
abstract: Dr. Oliver Sacks was a neurologist and best-selling author who explored the brain’s strangest pathways. His work touched Hollywood, theater, even opera, and his legacy lasts in the stories he told.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Oliver Sacks was a neurologist and best-selling author who explored the brain’s strangest pathways. His work touched Hollywood, theater, even opera, and his legacy lasts in the stories he told.

headline: Oliver Sacks, Neurologist Who Wrote About the Brain’s Quirks, Dies at 82
abstract: Dr. Sacks explored some of the brain’s strangest pathways in best-selling case histories like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,” achieving a level of renown rare among scientists.
lead_paragraph: Oliver Sacks, the neurologist and acclaimed author who explored some of the brain’s strangest pathways in best-selling case histories like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,” using his patients’ disorders as starting points for eloquent meditations on consciousness and the human condition, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Defection of Perry Aide to Trump Camp Has Iowans Fearing for Image
abstract: The defection of Rick Perry’s top campaign aide in the state to Donald Trump “sends a perception that we’re pay-for-play,” a Republican official said.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Is Iowa for sale?

headline: Behind Deadly Tianjin Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules
abstract: Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft.
lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — One partner was the son of a local police chief, the other an executive at a state-run chemicals firm. After meeting at a dinner party, they started a company here to handle the export of the most dangerous chemicals made in China, promising “outstanding service” and “good results.”

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your week.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: Apps to Bring Math and Science Skills Back After Summer’s Slide
abstract: Some skills, especially math, can get rusty over the summer. Apps can sweeten necessary review.
lead_paragraph: After a summer of fun, the shift back into schoolwork can be tough for kids. Feeling out-of-practice when it comes to math facts, logical thinking or even, for younger kids, the alphabet can make the transition even harder. It’s time for a little review, but that review will go over much more sweetly if it seems more like fun than work.

headline: Tianjin Explosion Reveals Company That Exploited Weak Governance
abstract: More than two weeks after explosions at its warehouses killed 145 people, Rui Hai International Logistics has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with corruption.
lead_paragraph: More than two weeks after explosions at its warehouses killed 145 people, Rui Hai International Logistics has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with corruption.

headline: Oil, Oligarchs, Climate and Obama’s Arctic-Focused Alaska Trip
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Environment', 'Geography', 'Glaciers', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Ice', 'Icebreakers', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama’s Alaskan trip aims to remind Americans they have an Arctic shore.
lead_paragraph: The Arctic seems hot these days, and not just because of rising temperatures and retreating ice, or because President Obama plans to speak at an Arctic policy meeting and visit an Arctic community on an Alaska tour starting Monday.

headline: Defying Expectations, Mayor Ras Baraka Is Praised in All Corners of Newark
abstract: The mayor, who took office last summer, is gaining attention for his efforts to curb crime and spur economic development.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Mayor Ras J. Baraka came into office last summer practically taunting his doubters.

headline: ‘Narcos’ Episode 5 Recap: There Will Be a Future
abstract: One of the encouraging things about “Narcos” is that it emphasizes how much the war against Escobar is a Colombian war, not a case of true-hearted gringos sweeping in.
lead_paragraph: Read all of our “Narcos” recaps.

headline: Iowa Poll Suggests Dangers for Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump’s Strengths
abstract: The most respected Iowa poll finds that Mrs. Clinton’s lead over Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has shrunk to just 7 percentage points, while Mr. Trump’s favorability with Republicans has sharply increased,
lead_paragraph: In Iowa, when J. Ann Selzer talks, people listen.

headline: Jason Rezaian’s Status Unclear After Iran Sentences 2
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'News and News Media', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The judiciary did not release the names of the two people convicted of spying for the United States and Israel.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s judiciary sentenced two people to 10 years in prison on Sunday for spying for the United States and Israel, but their names were not released, local media reported.

headline: ‘The Witches of Venice’ by Philip Glass to Have American Premiere
abstract: The production of the whimsical, magical piece — based on the children’s book by Beni Montresor — will be directed and choreographed by Karole Armitage for Opera Saratoga.
lead_paragraph: Philip Glass’s “The Witches of Venice,” an opera-ballet for children first performed two decades ago at La Scala in Milan, will be given its American premiere next summer during Opera Saratoga’s 2016 Summer Festival in upstate New York, the festival announced Sunday.

headline: The Time an 11-Year-Old Took Down Nadal
abstract: When the United States Open starts on Monday, Estee Ackerman will be on hand, still savoring the memory of when she trounced Rafael Nadal in a tennis match played on a table.
lead_paragraph: “So, about Nadal,” Estee Ackerman said in her unassuming way, about to relive the summer of 2013 serve by serve, volley by volley, point by point.

headline: ‘Straight Outta Compton’ Is No. 1 for Third Week at Box Office
abstract: Second place went to “War Room” (Sony), a PG-rated newcomer with a religious theme; costing $3.5 million to make, the movie sold $11 million in tickets, more than double what box office analysts had expected based on pre-release surveys.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – With the return to school preoccupying a major chunk of the movie-going audience, and Hollywood holding back significant new releases as a result, theaters in North America were relatively uninhabited over the weekend.

headline: 1965: Dr. King’s Children Enroll in White School
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Dr. Martin Luther King enrolled two of his children in a formerly all-white school in 1965.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. and his top assistant in the civil rights movement today enrolled five of their children in a previously all-white elementary school as classes began. Dr. King’s wife Coretta brought two of her children, and Mrs. Ralph Abernathy, whose husband is vice president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, enrolled three of her children in the Spring Street school.

headline: Republican Candidates Address Donald Trump and Volatility in Polls
abstract: As the summer of Donald J. Trump winds down, some of the real estate mogul’s rivals took to the Sunday political talk shows, discussing plans for emerging from Mr. Trump’s shadow in the Republican field.
lead_paragraph: As the summer of Donald J. Trump winds down, some of the real estate mogul’s rivals took to the Sunday political talk shows, discussing plans for emerging from Mr. Trump’s shadow in the Republican field.

headline: Obama’s Alaska Visit Puts Climate, Not Energy, in Forefront
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: The president will issue his call to action in Alaska just weeks after he allowed offshore oil and gas drilling to go forward in the Arctic Ocean.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will travel to Alaska on Monday to call for urgent and aggressive action to tackle climate change, capitalizing on a poignant tableau of melting glaciers, crumbling permafrost and rising sea levels to illustrate the immediacy of an issue he hopes to make a central element of his legacy.

headline: Big Apple Circus to Focus on Early Travel in 38th Season
abstract: The Big Apple Circus returns to Lincoln Center in October.
lead_paragraph: The Big Apple Circus’s new show, “The Grand Tour!,” will arrive at Lincoln Center in October. The production is a tribute to early-20th-century travel, and will feature performers from every continent, except Antarctica.

headline: Food Trucks Divide a Missouri Town Looking for Sizzle
abstract: A pilot project is facing resistance from restaurants in North Kansas City, which wants to add urban cool while preserving its small-town intimacy.
lead_paragraph: NORTH KANSAS CITY, Mo. — This region for years has prized its trendy and innovative side — from the shiny, modern performing arts center that resembles a seashell to the custom homes that look more Malibu than Midwest to the streetcar that is near completion.

headline: 1940: Arab World ‘Sitting on Fence’ As War Nears Its Threshold
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Arab world remained curiously quiet in the face of the advance of war in 1940.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As the British Middle East concentrates its attention on preparing to resist the expected Italian drive from the Libyan Desert eastward into Egypt, the Arab world, which in some of its parts flamed into revolt against the Ottoman power during the World War and seldom has been entirely peaceful since, remains curiously quiet.

headline: VMAs 2015: Moments to Watch
abstract: Miley Cyrus hosts this year’s show, which includes appearances by Nicki Minaj, Pharrell WIlliams, Taylor Swift and more.
lead_paragraph: “Enough of the finger pointing and the slut shaming,” Jon Caramanica wrote in 2013 in response to the moral panic that gripped the nation over Miley Cyrus’s twerk-filled, tongue-wagging MTV Video Music Awards performance. The haters haven’t gone away, but Ms. Cyrus rolls on, ready to court controversy, as she teased in an interview with The Times last week. There will be skits, “psychedelic” and “raw” elements, and thousands of Twitter fingers ready to critique her every move. “I didn’t want this V.M.A.s to be like they’ve been in the past,” she said. Since it’s the Viacom executive Van Toffler’s last year, anything goes: It’s one big party, and MTV is footing the bill. (The show starts at 9 p.m. on MTV.)

headline: Hillary Clinton Secures Backing of Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire
abstract: Ms. Shaheen, the popular Democrat from New Hampshire and the first woman to be elected senator and governor in the state, will publicly endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton next Saturday, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign said.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jeanne Shaheen, the popular Democrat from New Hampshire and the first woman to be elected senator and governor in the state, will publicly endorse Hillary Rodham Clinton next Saturday, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign said.

headline: Protesters Demand Restoration of Mephistopheles Sculpture in St. Petersburg
abstract: Prosecutors have opened a criminal case into the destruction of the piece which is said to be inspired by a performance by the opera singer Feodor Chaliapin.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Hundreds of St. Petersburg residents and cultural preservationists gathered on Sunday to protest the destruction of a bas-relief sculpture of Mephistopheles that was removed from a historic 1910 apartment building last week and demand that it be restored.

headline: To Jar North, South Korea Used a Pop-Music Barrage
abstract: Old-school propaganda, juiced up with a synthesized K-pop beat, still has the power to get under the skin of North Korea’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Chirpy bubble-gum harmonies bop across the desolate Demilitarized Zone. “Look at me, I’m your genie, your dream, your genie,” the K-pop band Girls’ Generation beckons as grim-faced soldiers patrol the border.

headline: After American Pharoah Is Dethroned, Baffert Has Plan to Cement His Place
abstract: Baffert said he was disappointed but satisfied with his colt’s gritty performance on Saturday and made it clear that he wanted him to race one last time, in the Breeders’ Cup Classic.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Neither American Pharoah nor his trainer, Bob Baffert, looked worn out or deflated the morning after the colt was run down by Keen Ice in the final strides of the 146th running of the Travers Stakes. The white-haired Baffert smiled as he led his big bay colt outside his barn here, stopping to let a little girl feed him carrots.

headline: Battling Arm Injuries, a Tennis Player Changes ... Hands
abstract: Most players change their strings or their swing, but this left-hander decided to start playing right-handed, and found that retraining his brain was no easy task.
lead_paragraph: My forehand sailed deep — not just behind-the-baseline deep, but over-the-fence deep. I’ve played tennis for more than four decades, yet I was staring at my right hand as if it had never swung a racket, which was sort of true.

headline: Soul-Searching in TV Land Over the Challenges of a New Golden Age
keywords: ['Television', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Cable Television', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: With the number of shows approaching 400 this year, John Landgraf of FX Networks says the cluttered TV landscape is challenging viewers and the industry.
lead_paragraph: John Landgraf’s comments arrived like a thunderbolt.

headline: Egypt Defends Ruling Against Two Al Jazeera Journalists
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: John Casson, who was in the courtroom when two journalists were sentenced to prison, said the move would damage confidence in the rule of law in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian Foreign Ministry said Sunday that it had summoned the British ambassador to object to his comments on a recent court ruling to jail two journalists, escalating the government’s defense of its crackdown on dissent.

headline: 4x400 Relay Offers Bright Moment, but U.S. No Longer Dazzles
abstract: The Americans finished third in the gold medal count, their lowest ranking at a track and field world championships in history, and had quite a drop in their overall medal count.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The last gold medal went to the United States as the veteran LaShawn Merritt ran another poised and powerful anchor leg to clinch victory in a tight 4x400-meter relay.

headline: Mets Hang On to Edge the Red Sox
abstract: Michael Cuddyer hit a tiebreaking single in the seventh inning and reliever Tyler Clippard and closer Jeurys Familia finished off Boston as the Mets avoided a three-game sweep.
lead_paragraph: A familiar sound, a nervous murmuring, emanated from the crowd during the seventh inning as Manager Terry Collins hurried out of the Mets’ dugout toward the mound.

headline: On China’s Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Economic fears about China culminated last week in a global market rout.
lead_paragraph: Economic fears about China culminated last week in a global market rout.

headline: Mount McKinley Will Again Be Called Denali
abstract: On the eve of his visit to Alaska, President Obama announced the restoration of the Alaska Native name for the tallest peak in North America.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced on Sunday that Mount McKinley was being renamed Denali, using his executive power to restore an Alaska Native name with deep cultural significance to the tallest mountain in North America.

headline: Tennis Players Are Helped by Products (at Least They Think So)
abstract: Relatively inexpensive accessories like vibration dampeners and kinesiology tape may provide benefits for recreational players, but some experts believe there is a placebo effect.
lead_paragraph: In recent years there has been a proliferation of so-called smart rackets and other high-tech gadgets, including Sony’s Smart Tennis Sensor and Babolat’s Play racket, that compile data on strokes. This fall, Babolat will introduce POP, a wristband that will provide similar analysis when used with any racket.

headline: The Phone Charger Situation
abstract: A group of Syrian refugees gathered around a single power strip to charge their phones.
lead_paragraph: A group of Syrian refugees gathered around a single power strip to charge their phones.

headline: A New Look for the Wadsworth Atheneum
abstract: Photos of the renovated museum in downtown Hartford.
lead_paragraph: Photos of the renovated museum in downtown Hartford.

headline: The Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford Puts Final Touches on a Comeback
abstract: On Sept. 19, this Hartford institution will present the results of its five-year, $33 million renovation.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — At the Wadsworth Atheneum, they called it the Leak Tour, and sometimes the Horror Tour.

headline: Review: ‘Todrick,’ on the YouTube Star Todrick Hall’s Relentless Pursuit of Fame
abstract: This is a television show about the making of YouTube videos by a singer who once tried to become famous by performing on TV and failed.
lead_paragraph: “Todrick” is a television show about the making of YouTube videos by a singer who once tried to become famous by performing on TV and failed. Which is to say that either the performer has changed, music has changed, or TV has.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dancers Explore Myth and Machismo at Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: The company opened a yearlong anniversary celebration with a program that mostly included recent works by European men.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — The ghost of Ted Shawn, who turned a farm here into the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival and worked tirelessly to present dancing as a manly activity, might have been pleased to see a burly guy chopping wood on Thursday on the barnlike stage of the Ted Shawn Theater. Shawn might have been tickled, too, to learn that the man wielding the ax was a member of the dance troupe of his old student and partner Martha Graham.

headline: Zhang Huoding of Peking Opera Takes a Turn in the United States
abstract: Ms. Zhang is part of Beijing’s use of the performing arts to promote good will overseas, and she’s the subject of a documentary planned by the director Wong Kar-wai.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When “The Legend of the White Snake” opens Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center, an American audience will get its first glimpse of Zhang Huoding, one of China’s biggest Peking Opera stars, as she makes her United States debut.

headline: Review: LoftOpera Brings Mischief, and a Crowd, to Berlioz and Mahler
abstract: A large and youthful crowd gathered for two song cycles performed by a company that has built a following with its roving, intimate productions.
lead_paragraph: I’ll admit, with a certain degree of shame, that my predominant feeling on Friday night when I entered the Muse, a warehouse deep in Bushwick, Brooklyn, usually used as a circus school, was surprise, even shock. I hadn’t trusted that 10 love songs by Berlioz and Mahler had much power to draw a crowd; after all, lieder has long been opera’s poor relation, and even opera, some say, today struggles to find an audience.

headline: Review: Choosing a Husband or a Lover in Dell’Arte Opera Ensemble’s ‘Rosina’
abstract: The troupe, at the Baruch Performing Arts Center, presented this work adapted from the Beaumarchais Trilogy.
lead_paragraph: Did you hear? Rosina has a baby. From Cherubino! They’ve moved to Madrid. He paints — mostly her — but that doesn’t pay the rent. Rumor has it that Count Almaviva is looking for Rosina, but nobody knows if he’s out to kill her for her infidelity or beg forgiveness for his own string of escapades, which helped push her into the arms of his young page.

headline: Review: At Indian Dance Festival, Subtleties in the Sway of a Torso
abstract: Five numbers showed five different dance languages at the Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance.
lead_paragraph: Since India has many languages, it would take a true polyglot to comprehend all its poetry. On Friday, when the Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance held an indoor program enticingly called “An Evening of ‘Poetry, Danced’ ” at Pace University’s Schimmel Center, the audience was given words in five different languages. If we accept Frost’s theory that poetry is “what is lost in translation,” probably most of those present lost a great deal. Much, however, remained.

headline: The Stress of the Slam
abstract: At the U.S. Open, the pressure will be on Serena Williams to achieve a milestone that has been reached only six times — by Don Budge, Maureen Connolly, Rod Laver (twice), Margaret Court and Steffi Graf.
lead_paragraph: In the days leading up to the 1969 United States Open, pressure was mounting on Rod Laver. He had won the Australian Open in grueling fashion and followed it up with victories at the French Open and Wimbledon.

headline: In Lorde’s Wake, a Groundswell of Female Rebels in Pop
abstract: Industry attempts to construct another Taylor Swift generally fizzled, but that’s no obstacle to attempts to build another Lorde.
lead_paragraph: From a distance, this seems like a great moment for female friendship in pop. Look at Taylor Swift’s current tour, which includes appearances from people she admires, often women: Serena Williams, Selena Gomez, Mary J. Blige, Ellen DeGeneres, Lisa Kudrow (hmmm), Joan Baez (what?).

headline: Supplanting CBS and Tennis Channel, ESPN Empire Will Show All U.S. Open Matches
abstract: Serena Williams’s three victories in the past four women’s finals have attracted an average of 5.3 million viewers on CBS, many more than recent men’s finals.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams’s quest to complete the Grand Slam at the U.S. Open will be a production of the ESPN empire, viewable only on ESPN, ESPN2 and ESPN3.

headline: Review: ‘The End of Tsarist Russia’ by Dominic Lieven
abstract: This book, subtitled “The March to World War I & Revolution,” looks to place Russia “where it belongs, at the very center” of the war.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Lieven’s stated reason for this contribution to the centenary literature on World War I is to place Russia “where it belongs, at the very center” of the war’s history. Certainly the war proved to be at the center of Russian history, leading to revolution, dictatorship, repression and more war.

headline: What’s New at the U.S. Open? Start at the Top
abstract: Arthur Ashe Stadium has a different look after the construction of part of a retractable roof. Another change is that the men’s final is scheduled for a Sunday instead of a Monday.
lead_paragraph: The most visible change at the U.S. Open this year is hard to miss. Long before fans get to the U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center by road or by rail, they will notice the new shape of Arthur Ashe Stadium.

headline: M’s and N’s
abstract: Michael Dewey attempts to cool us off.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Who knew there were three different ways to invite us into the pool?

headline: Review: ‘Phantom,’ on the Trail of Mumbai Terrorists
abstract: This revenge thriller by Kabir Khan stars Saif Ali Khan and Katrina Kaif as secret agents in a film with city-wrecking action sequences.
lead_paragraph: Daniyal (Saif Ali Khan) and Nawaz (Katrina Kaif), the hapless secret agent heroes of Kabir Khan’s revenge thriller “Phantom,” could have used some pointers before being sent into the field.

headline: Susan Rice, Obama’s Security Adviser, Urges Pakistan to Do More Against Militants
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Foreign Aid', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a daylong visit to Pakistan, the national security adviser urged leaders to stop militants from using Pakistani territory to stage attacks in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Obama’s national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, urged Pakistani civilian and military leaders on Sunday to do more to stop militants from using Pakistani territory to stage attacks in neighboring countries.

headline: Review: ‘Magic Trick,’ the Tale of a Breakup in the World of Burlesque
abstract: This play finds a young woman who uses a wheelchair experiencing a breakup with her boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: A relationship dramedy set in the world of burlesque, Mariah MacCarthy’s “Magic Trick” lives low to the ground. This is partly by necessity: The play’s main character is a young woman who uses a wheelchair, and much of the action occurs as she and others are sitting or lying down.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 31
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Kanye West to Perform an ‘808s’ Concert
abstract: Mr. West will perform a one-off concert celebrating his 2008 album, “808s & Heartbreak,” at the Hollywood Bowl next month.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West will perform a one-off concert celebrating his 2008 album, “808s & Heartbreak,” at the Hollywood Bowl next month. That album, which featured heavy use of auto-tune and synthesizers, did not receive universal acclaim upon release but now is regarded as a pivotal influence on current hip-hop and R&B stars, including Drake, the Weeknd and Future. “  ‘808s & Heartbreak’ sounds like none of his other albums, nor any rap album of note,” Jon Caramanica wrote in his review for The Times. “At best, it is a rough sketch for a great album.” Mr. West later described it as “the first black new wave album” in an interview with Mr. Caramanica. The concert will take place on Sept. 25. Tickets go on sale Friday.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Authorizes Emergency Measure to Aid Homeless People
abstract: The $10 million initiative, modeled on an emergency measure to assist families with children, is expected to provide rental assistance to as many as 1,000 adults.
lead_paragraph: With few beds available in New York City’s homeless shelters, Mayor Bill de Blasio has authorized another emergency measure to provide rental assistance to people facing homelessness.

headline: Captain’s Death Rattles a Marina in New Jersey

headline: Car Sales, Samsung’s New Smartwatch, and the Jobs Report
abstract: This week automakers are expected to report healthy sales of new vehicles, Samsung plans to introduce another smartwatch and the Labor Department will report the latest data on hiring and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: Major automakers are expected on Tuesday to report healthy August sales of new vehicles in the United States, despite posting an overall decline from the same month last year, which included the Labor Day weekend. Industry analysts project that year-over-year sales will drop slightly, but will still exceed 1.5 million vehicles for the month. So far this year, consumers have flooded vehicle showrooms to buy pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, while sales of passenger cars have declined. The trend has benefited the Detroit automakers, which are expected to report sales increases in August. Analysts do not expect the recent stock market fluctuations to have had much effect on the auto industry. —Bill Vlasic

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:35 P.M. (MAX) THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL (2014) In this Wes Anderson film, Zero Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham) tells an author (Jude Law) the story of how he came to own the Grand Budapest Hotel. The film flashes back to 1932, detailing the friendship between the young Zero (Tony Revolori, center, with Tom Wilkinson, left, and and Owen Wilson) and the hotel concierge, Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes). Gustave is framed for the murder of an aristocrat (Tilda Swinton) and flees with Zero. They are pursued by her family and henchmen (Adrien Brody, Willem Dafoe) while trying to protect a prized painting. Zero, meanwhile, deals with romance. “There is no doubt that Mr. Anderson possesses a distinctive sensibility and a consistent visual style, and that instead of striking out in new directions, he tends to embroider and elaborate on familiar themes and pictorial habits,” A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. “You will see many of them here: static, densely packed, fussily composed frames; traveling shots in which the camera glides alongside the characters like a low-flying bird; action sequences that refuse the usual digital hocus-pocus in favor of the older, artisanal magic of stop-motion animation, matte paintings and rear projection. You will also meet eccentric characters possessed by a kind of madcap melancholy, soulful and silly in equal measure.”

headline: A Heckuva Job

abstract: As some Republican candidates have shown, it’s not too difficult to fool many of the people for quite a long time.
lead_paragraph: There are many things we should remember about the events of late August and early September 2005, and the political fallout shouldn’t be near the top of the list. Still, the disaster in New Orleans did the Bush administration a great deal of damage — and conservatives have never stopped trying to take their revenge. Every time something has gone wrong on President Obama’s watch, critics have been quick to declare the event “Obama’s Katrina.” How many Katrinas has Mr. Obama had so far? By one count, 23.

headline: When Bad Doctors Happen to Good Patients
abstract: If hospitals and the medical community won’t police incompetent physicians, who will?
lead_paragraph: ONLY in Albany can a bill pass the Assembly with overwhelming bipartisan support, be sponsored by a majority of the State Senate, be endorsed by Gov. Andrew M. This summer, the Senate majority leader, John J. Flanagan, a Republican, wouldn’t allow the bill to be voted on, effectively killing it.

headline: The Selfie-Drone: Invasion of the Vacation Snatchers
abstract: The newest drones are capable of recording breathtaking video footage, but can also be a nuisance for other travelers seeking tranquil moments.
lead_paragraph: It was a blistering hot Sunday in Provence. The painted shutters of the houses in Arles were closed. Visitors were scarce. In the Roman amphitheater, built to hold some 20,000 spectators, I sat among empty bleachers, above homes with orange tile roofs, looking past ancient arcades and terraces to the blue horizon. Was this the sort of stillness van Gogh experienced when he was in Arles on this same June day in 1888? I began to entertain the thought but was distracted by a soft whirring; a faint electric hum. Something was drawing near. I looked around and saw nothing — until it and I were eye to eye.

headline: Can We Improve?
abstract: It’s easy to believe in our own moral progress, until the next personality crisis, the next bad decision, the next war.
lead_paragraph: Human beings have made progress in various areas, though it is often fitful, double-edged and reversible. But are we capable of substantial moral improvement? Could we someday be much better ethically than we are now? Is it likely that members of our species could become, on average, more generous or more honest, less self-deceptive or less self-interested? I have known individual people who have improved morally in various ways (and many who have made the opposite journey) but I’m not sure that as a species as a whole we are any better than we were 100 or even 10,000 years ago.

headline: What We Don’t Talk About When We Talk About Alcohol: Binge Drinking
abstract: You may have talked with your children about drinking. But have you talked about the way teenagers really drink?
lead_paragraph: As a parent, you’ve probably talked to your young children about alcohol (“See this drink I’m having? It’s not for you”) and to teenagers about drinking (“Don’t do it, and if you do don’t drive, and did I ever do it? Ooh, look, a woodpecker!”). But have you talked to your children, particularly your high schoolers and soon-to-be college students, about drinking the way it’s often done at that age — hard, fast, and with the intent of getting drunk?

headline: Dora Charles Moves On From Paula Deen, and Makes It All About the Seasoning
abstract: A cook who worked with the celebrity chef now has her own book, filled with both the flavors and the culture of black life in the South.
lead_paragraph: GARDEN CITY, Ga. — In the kitchen of her double-wide trailer, Dora Charles sets spare ribs kissed with flour into a deep fryer and sautés yesterday’s collard greens with rice and onions. Her cooking is practiced and deliberate, learned at the hand of her father and her grandmother Hattie Smith, who showed her that seasoning something well and cooking it slowly encouraged flavors to bloom.

headline: One Thing You Can Do With Your Portfolio Right Now
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Social Security (US)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Before reacting to volatile markets, write down a financial plan to make sure your investment goals are aligned.
lead_paragraph: When the markets get scary, there’s an overwhelming temptation to do something, anything really, with our portfolios. But we know better. We all know on an intellectual level that selling during a dip is a bad idea, and the data confirms that successfully timing the market is, at the very least, highly unlikely. Yet it feels crazy to just sit in front of what feels like an oncoming train.

headline: A Dream Parisian Cafe, Brought to Life
abstract: Decades later, plans for Shakespeare & Company’s new space are finally realized.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, George Whitman, the late owner of the legendary Shakespeare & Company bookshop in Paris, had visitors make sketches of his dream cafe, which he intended to open in the adjacent building, if he ever managed to take it over. Unearthed after his death by his daughter, the current co-owner Sylvia Whitman, the drawings depicted a convivial meeting place with outdoor seating and books aplenty. Now, after more than 50 years of vacancy, the space next door has undergone a massive overhaul (the retro floor tiles were one of the few things preserved), complete with large windows through which the bookish set will be able to gaze at Notre Dame while snacking on literary treats such as Proustian madeleines and Salinger-inspired ‘‘Love and Squalor’’ pie.

headline: You Can Reduce Your Blind Spot, a Study Says
abstract: After 20 days of repeated stimulation with a waveform, the blind spot of research participants shrunk by about 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: The human eye has a blind spot, though few of us realize it. Now, a new study suggests that it is possible to reduce the spot with training.

headline: Breaking the Grip of the Gaokao, China’s SAT
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Creativity', 'Education (K-12)', 'Mathematics', 'Puzzles', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Try a few short problems from The Math League, an extracurricular activity used in China to balance the tedium of studying for the Gaokao, China’s college entrance exam.
lead_paragraph: The notorious Gaokao, (高考, or “High Test”) is China’s SAT on steroids, with a score on the nine-hour test being the sole criterion for admission to Chinese universities. Preparing for the test is a years-long obsession for both students and parents. (In case you missed it: Brook Larmer’s Inside a Chinese Test-Prep Factory.) And for many, the unfortunate consequence is that the lengthy preparation destroys, rather than enhances, academic ability. Student enthusiasm and curiosity are crushed.

headline: Angela Merkel Calls for European Unity to Address Migrant Influx
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The German chancellor warned that the Continent’s open-border policy was at risk unless all European countries showed an equal willingness to help.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Faced with a humanitarian crisis that shows no signs of letting up, Chancellor Angela Merkel gave her fellow Germans and other Europeans a pep talk on Monday, praising those assisting the thousands seeking asylum here but warning that the Continent’s open-border policy was at risk unless all European countries showed an equal willingness to help.

headline: Kathy YL Chan and Her Coveted Tea, Never to Be Brewed
abstract: The tea specialist says her four tiles of highly prized pu-erh tea are too precious to drink.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, a member of a private tea society in Shanghai presented Kathy YL Chan with a small box as slender as a cigarette case. Inside were four tiles of highly prized pu-erh tea, conjoined like a chocolate bar and almost black, twined with green and ocher.

headline: A Montauk Home Where the Windows Are Always Open

abstract: Jayma Cardoso, owner of the Surf Lodge, takes T on a tour of her just-finished summer house.
lead_paragraph: The hotelier and nightlife entrepreneur Jayma Cardoso has been involved in a handful of high-profile Manhattan projects: SoHo’s GoldBar, Lavo in Midtown. But none is unmistakably hers as the Surf Lodge, the Montauk mainstay now wrapping up its sold-out eighth season: like the hotel, Cardoso is unfussy and welcoming, with an accent left over from her native Brazil and a throaty laugh she deploys often.

headline: Denali’s Name Change Upsets a Senator
abstract: Senator Rob Portman called the renaming “another example of the President going around Congress,” but he hasn’t always felt that Congress should concern itself with names.
lead_paragraph: I know it’s a tricky thing to expect consistency from politicians, but I was struck by Senator Rob Portman’s indignation at President Obama’s decision to change the name of Mount McKinley in Alaska back to Denali, which is the name that local Native Americans gave it.

headline: The Long, Winding Interview With Miley Cyrus
abstract: Miley Cyrus talks drugs, Caitlyn Jenner and being in love with an astronaut.
lead_paragraph: Last night, after hosting the MTV Video Music Awards in a typical polarizing performance, Miley Cyrus surprise-released a free, 23-track new album, “Miley Cyrus & Her Dead Petz,” written and recorded largely at her home with members of the Flaming Lips. In a five-hour interview the previous weekend, Ms. Cyrus, 22, discussed the experimental project, which you can read about here. But along the way, she also touched on her budding friendship with Caitlyn Jenner, learning about herself through drugs, and how she’s learned to handle the media.
