headline: 1965: Russia Rejects U.S. Proposal
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Soviet Union dismisses an American proposal on non-proliferation in 1965.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Soviet Union formally rejected today [Aug. 31] the American-proposed disarmament treaty which was designed to try to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. Soviet delegate Semyon K. Tsarapkin told the 17-nation disarmament conference the U.S. treaty draft presented Aug. 17 was unacceptable even as a basis for discussion. He described the draft as a cynical Western attempt to admit West Germany to the nuclear club by the back door. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, September 1, 1965

headline: Oliver Sacks: Diverse Elements in Harmony
keywords: ['Brain', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: What was striking about Dr. Sacks was his capacity for enthusiasm about whatever idea or object had caught his attention.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, shortly after his book, “Uncle Tungsten: Memories of a Chemical Boyhood,” was published, I asked Dr. Oliver Sacks which of the chemical elements he had written about was his favorite.

headline: Challah and Brisket, Rethought for Rosh Hashana
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Festivals', 'Food', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Rosh Hashana']
abstract: Plus: Lithuanian honey liqueur, Moroccan sauces and a Puerto Rican food festival bring a range of flavors, and a Vermont inn is ready to serve you.
lead_paragraph: Most challah is made from wheat flour. But rye, barley, spelt and oats may also be used according to Jewish law. This year, in time for Rosh Hashana, Breads Bakery is using a mixture of spelt and wheat to make a handsome and tasty round loaf. It is not kosher. The gluten- and dairy-free By the Way Bakery is making challah primarily from oat flour, under rabbinical supervision, so it’s kosher and pareve. It is baked in a ring shape and is dense and thickly studded with raisins for a bread that’s earthy and sweet: Spelt challah, $8.50, beginning Friday at Breads Bakery, 18 East 16th Street, and Breads Bakery kiosk in Bryant Park, breadsbakery.com; oat challah, $12, Sept. 11, 13, 18, 21 and 22 from By the Way Bakery, 2442 Broadway (90th Street); 574 Warburton Avenue, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., BTWBakery.com.

headline: Rick Perry’s Woes Continue as Iowa Staff Is Cut to One Person
abstract: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has whittled his staff in Iowa to one paid operative amid continuing fund-raising struggles.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Rick Perry’s campaign continues to retrench.

headline: Carrie Brownstein’s Book Tour to Kick Off in Brooklyn
abstract: Carrie Brownstein will be traveling to 11 cities across the United States this fall to promote her memoir, “Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl,” due in October.
lead_paragraph: From “Portlandia” to Portland, Ore., and Brooklyn, too, Carrie Brownstein will be traveling to 11 cities across the United States this fall to promote her memoir, “Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl” (Riverhead Books), due in October.

headline: The Eerie Realism of ‘Mr. Robot’
abstract: The USA Network’s summer hit is closer to real life than you might think.
lead_paragraph: In the first episode of “Mr. Robot,” a drama that is nearing the end of its first season on the USA Network, Elliot — the show’s main character, played by Rami Malek — delivers a memorable monologue about his disillusionment with society. Elliot’s Margaret Keane-size eyes go blank as he describes feelings of isolation and disconnection from popular culture.

headline: Tracking People Like Packages: Republicans’ Inhumane Immigration Ideas
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Foreign Workers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Japanese-Americans', 'Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: Chris Christie’s latest proposal is just one of many Republican strategies that treat immigrants like objects, diseases or invaders.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates just can’t help themselves on immigration. That subject is a rhetorical sinkhole that, like Donald Trump’s mouth, just seems to keep getting bigger, swallowing candidates left and right.

headline: A New Place to Sleep in Old Barcelona
abstract: A hotel housed in a 19th-century building toes the line between classic and modern.
lead_paragraph: Despite not being particularly known for its contemporary art scene or flashy architectural projects, Barcelona is one of those rare cities that somehow always feels up to date. The same, however, can’t be said for its hotels, which are either Old World-stodgy or genera-minimalist. But the affordable new Casa Bonay, located in a stately, sun-washed 1869 building in the city’s central, semi-industrial Dreta de l’Eixample neighborhood, is changing that. The co-owner Inés Miró-Sans, who worked with the Brooklyn-based design firm Studio Tack to restore the space without destroying its 19th-century charms, preserved as many details as she could, from old fireplaces to the mosaic floors, while keeping the feeling super simple.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: With most of the world’s top leagues off for the international break, Andrew Das points viewers to Euro 2016 qualifying matches and Concacaf exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Most of the world’s top leagues have the week off for the international break, but the world’s top players, as usual, will get no rest. The Times’s soccer editor, Andrew Das, an unapologetic Ajax fan, suggests what to watch on television.

headline: Third World Trade Center Parachutist Is Sentenced
keywords: ['Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', '1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Marko Markovich, who had been found guilty of reckless endangerment and violating a New York City ordinance, was sentenced to 300 hours of community service and a $2,000 fine.
lead_paragraph: The last of three sky divers convicted on misdemeanor charges for parachuting off 1 World Trade Center two years ago was sentenced on Monday to 300 hours of community service and a $2,000 fine.

headline: Monsters Unleashed
abstract: Ahead of a premiere, this one in Dallas, ugly thoughts can rear their heads.
lead_paragraph: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

headline: London Theater Journal: Discipline, Punish and Put on a Play
abstract: Timberlake Wertenbaker’s “Our Country’s Good” has been given a big, handsome and somewhat literal-minded revival at the National Theater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Plays about putting on plays – including knockabout farces like “Noises Off” – almost invariably raise a lump in the throat of the sentimental theatergoer. But even those resistant to this sub-genre’s charms may well mist up during a certain scene in Timberlake Wertenbaker’s “Our Country’s Good,” which has been given a big, handsome and somewhat literal-minded revival at the National Theater here.

headline: Born in Chiapas
abstract: A look at the traditional midwife in southern Mexico, and at modern inroads into childbirth
lead_paragraph: A look at the traditional midwife in southern Mexico, and at modern inroads into childbirth

headline: Training Midwives to Save Expectant Mothers in Chiapas
abstract: The Mexican state, like many poor areas, has a high death rate among mothers in childbirth. In an effort to change that, village midwives are being linked to modern medicine.
lead_paragraph: Chiapas, the southernmost state in Mexico, is a mix of wonder and sadness. It is home to rain forests, Mayan ruins, waterfalls, rugged highlands — and some of the country’s highest death rates among women in childbirth.

headline: Reformist Iranian Politician Is Said to Be Held
abstract: Some in Iran disputed reports that Ali Shakorirad had been arrested hours after he held a news conference thanking President Hassan Rouhani for a more open political climate.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian security forces arrested a prominent reformist politician on Monday, hours after he held a news conference thanking President Hassan Rouhani for a more open political atmosphere, several Iranian news agencies reported.

headline: Slowing Growth Exposes Chinese Banks’ Debt Debris
abstract: Although overall bad debt levels remain relatively low, continued deterioration threatens to reverse years of profit growth.
lead_paragraph: China’s economic slowdown is exposing the debt debris in its banking sector. Shaky credits on the balance sheets of the country’s four biggest lenders jumped by 28 percent to 592 billion renminbi ($92.8 billion) in the first half of the year. Further deterioration would send earnings growth into reverse.

headline: A Kugel to Savor for Rosh Hashana
abstract: The salt-and-pepper version is the favorite of many families.
lead_paragraph: This savory kugel is from my 102-year-old mother, Pearl, who in 1950 put the recipe in a spiral-bound cookbook to raise money for her temple. Rather than raisins and sugar, it calls for onions and garlic, with what were then considered secret ingredients, Worcestershire and Tabasco.

headline: Favorite to Lead Britain’s Labour Party Is Criticized for Bin Laden Comments
abstract: Critics of Jeremy Corbyn are on the attack after the surfacing of comments he made in 2011 in which he referred to the death of Osama bin Laden as “a tragedy.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The effort to undermine Jeremy Corbyn, the consensus front-runner for the leadership of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, continued on Monday with reports that Mr. Corbyn called the death of Osama bin Laden “a tragedy” in a 2011 interview just after the event.

headline: A Complicated Love Story
abstract: This story begins with two couples living in Seattle. The men are in a band. When one of the women gets into the City University of New York School of Law, everyone moves to New York together.
lead_paragraph: This story begins with two couples living in Seattle. The men are in a band. When one of the women gets into the City University of New York School of Law, everyone moves to New York together.

headline: From Seattle With Love: A Tale of 4 Friends and One Band
abstract: The story of Ifrah Ahmed and Benjamin Verdoes begins in Seattle, ends in Brooklyn and has a punk-surf music soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: This is a complicated summer love story. It involves four people and one band that plays trippy surf music with elements of punk. It starts in Seattle and ends in Brooklyn. The tale is highbrow (Walt Whitman) and lowbrow (Pabst Blue Ribbon). It has a soundtrack that might be confusing.

headline: A Warhol-Worthy Watch
abstract: Piaget recreates a timepiece once owned by the artist.
lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol’s prediction of a future in which everyone would be ‘‘world-famous for 15 minutes’’ has largely come true. And yet, nearly 30 years after his death, his own fame lives on: Maison Piaget’s Black Tie Vintage Inspiration watch, with a spare black onyx face framed in white gold, is an updated version of a 1973 model from the artist’s own collection.

headline: Eating on the Move May Lead to Later Overindulging
abstract: Women who had eaten a cereal bar while walking as part of a study ate much more during a later taste test, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Eating on the go may be worse than eating in front of the television, a new study reports, and may lead people to overindulge later.

headline: Supplements Don’t Fight Cognitive Decline, N.I.H. Study Says
abstract: Often marketed to promote brain health, omega-3 fatty acids and antioxidants failed to outperform a placebo in a test of older adults.
lead_paragraph: Omega-3 fatty acids and antioxidants are often marketed to promote brain health. But one study to test these supplements has found no evidence that the pills stave off cognitive decline in older people.

headline: Amid Attacks over Mountain Names and Arctic Oil Leases, Obama Seeks Alaska Survival Tips from Bear Grylls
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Names, Geographical', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: On Alaska trip, Obama tries to focus the nation on climate – and seeks wilderness survival tips amid a flurry of partisan attacks.
lead_paragraph: Kicking off his Alaska tour, President Obama is scheduled to talk about climate change, oil and the Arctic later tonight at an ambitiously titled Anchorage event — the Conference on Global Leadership in the Arctic: Cooperation, Innovation, Engagement and Resilience.

headline: S.E.C.’s In-House Judges Not Too Tough, a Review Shows
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The administrative law judges have shown that they are capable of reprimanding the agency.
lead_paragraph: The Dodd-Frank Act allowed the Securities and Exchange Commission to bring almost any claim that it can file in a federal court before its own administrative law judges. The agency has since taken up this power against a panoply of inside traders and others accused of securities fraud.

headline: The Most Prized (and Totally Random) Possessions of Nine Famous People
abstract: T asked some recognizable friends to share the things that mean everything to them — and nothing to anyone else.
lead_paragraph: Each weekend, T hands over the keys of its Instagram account to a single editor to post pictures of whatever he or she is feeling at the moment. The most recent curations have been all-summer-everything: T’s deputy editor Hanya Yanagihara and senior online editor Isabel Wilkinson each posted images of remote places in which to take a dip (hotel pools and swimming holes, respectively); art director Shawn Carney celebrated the dog days with a survey of seasonal album covers; and features associate Lauren Poggi honored summer’s finest elements through the lenses of art and photography.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: When Your Sex Life Doesn’t Follow the Script
abstract: Suddenly, sex is something everyone must do, and judgments are passed on frequency and performance.
lead_paragraph: If someone had told me 10 years ago that I would one day announce in The New York Times how old I was when I lost my virginity, I would have died of embarrassment.

headline: Judge Allows Moral, Not Just Religious, Contraception Exemptions
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'ABORTION', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A federal court ruled in favor of March for Life, a secular nonprofit that argued religious-only exemptions to employer insurance requirements violated equal protection principles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Employers do not need to provide insurance coverage for contraception even if their objections are moral rather than religious, a federal judge here ruled on Monday.

headline: D.A. Recounts Shooting of Police Officer
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Devon Anderson, the district attorney for Harris County, Tex., described the fatal shooting of Deputy Darren Goforth. Shannon J. Miles has been charged with murder.
lead_paragraph: Devon Anderson, the district attorney for Harris County, Tex., described the fatal shooting of Deputy Darren Goforth. Shannon J. Miles has been charged with murder.

headline: ‘On the Town’ Takes Box Office Leap Thanks to Misty Copeland
abstract: The musical revival had one of its best weeks ever with the addition of the popular ballet star.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s most famous ballerina has now conquered Broadway too.

headline: Prosecutors Say Shannon Miles Shot Texas Deputy 15 Times
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police']
abstract: A 15-round handgun was emptied into Deputy Darren H. Goforth’s back and the back of his head, the Harris County authorities said in the suspect’s first court appearance in the killing.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The man charged with killing a sheriff’s deputy at a suburban gas station Friday emptied his 15-round handgun into the back and the back of the head of the deputy, as witnesses watched in horror and surveillance cameras captured the shooting, prosecutors said Monday.

headline: Mediator on Failed Brady Talks
abstract: Jay Feely of the N.F.L. Players Association spoke to reporters, and the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, and the New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady left court after settlement talks failed.
lead_paragraph: Jay Feely of the N.F.L. Players Association spoke to reporters, and the N.F.L. commissioner, Roger Goodell, and the New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady left court after settlement talks failed.

headline: Afghanistan’s Electoral Reform Plan Is Met With Skepticism
abstract: Some of the reactions to the proposals made clear that they would not signal a quick end to the reform process and the gridlock within the Afghan government.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Months late, Afghanistan’s electoral reform commission has delivered a list of proposals, in a critical step to holding overdue parliamentary elections.

headline: Faking Doctors’ Notes to Escape Gaza War Zone
abstract: Israeli permits to cross the border are reserved mainly for merchants and medical patients, spurring a black market for fake medical referrals.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — The medical report details some worrying conditions: chronic dyspnea — a shortage of breath that could be a sign of heart or lung disease — and bronchial asthma. It says the patient, a 28-year-old woman from Gaza City, relies on “continuous medication” and an inhaler.

headline: Amal Clooney Discusses Al Jazeera Case
abstract: Amal Clooney, a lawyer representing the Canadian journalist Mohamed Fahmy of Al Jazeera during his trial in Egypt, reiterated her call for the Canadian prime minister to intervene.
lead_paragraph: Amal Clooney, a lawyer representing the Canadian journalist Mohamed Fahmy of Al Jazeera during his trial in Egypt, reiterated her call for the Canadian prime minister to intervene.

headline: India’s Supreme Court Suspends Ban on Starvation Ritual
abstract: A state-level court had banned santhara, considered essential to followers of the Jain religion, ruling that it was tantamount to suicide, which is illegal in India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Monday suspended a state-level court’s ban on a religious practice called santhara, a fast to the death most often undertaken by the sick and aged.

headline: ‘The Cost of Cable Is Preposterous’: Readers Sound Off on Set-Top Boxes
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Digital Video Recorders', 'Home Appliances', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Television', 'Television Sets and Media Devices']
abstract: Many readers of a recent editorial were dissatisfied with rented cable boxes, but some had already bought their own — and others have given up cable entirely.
lead_paragraph: Our editorial this morning calling on the Federal Communications Commission to make it easier for people to buy their own cable boxes attracted hundreds of comments from readers. Not surprisingly, most of the people writing in were unhappy with cable and satellite companies, which generate nearly $20 billion in revenue from renting out boxes to their customers.

headline: Can a Computer Tell Whether Something Was Written by a Man or a Woman?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Gender', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Computer Vision', 'Software', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A reader wonders whether a computer can divine an author’s gender. Researchers once used a program to do just that.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can a computer tell from published documents whether the author is a man or a woman?

headline: Ponchos Are the New Frontier
keywords: ['Cowboys and Cowgirls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Five styles for the modern pioneer. (Go West, young man.)
lead_paragraph: Five styles for the modern pioneer. (Go West, young man.)

headline: MTV’s V.M.A.s Dominated Social Media, but Had Fewer Viewers
abstract: MTV’s Video Music Awards drew about a half a million viewers fewer than watched last year’s show, but was the most tweeted-about nonsporting event in the past four years.
lead_paragraph: MTV’s Video Music Awards drew 9.8 million viewers on Sunday, about a half a million viewers fewer than watched last year’s show, according to Nielsen.

headline: ‘SpongeBob’ Musical Will Open in Chicago, With Sights on Broadway
abstract: “The SpongeBob Musical,” with original songs by David Bowie, John Legend, Cyndi Lauper, T.I. and Steven Tyler and Joe Perry, is planning to move to Broadway in the 2016-2017 season.
lead_paragraph: He might live in a pineapple under the sea, but next year SpongeBob SquarePants hopes to make his home onstage on Broadway. First: Chicago.

headline: Wes Craven, a Filmmaker Who Invaded Your Dreams
abstract: The legacy of Mr. Craven, who has often been underestimated, involved pushing horror in new directions for three decades.
lead_paragraph: When Wes Craven started making horror movies, he had hardly seen any. “I didn’t even know what a horror film was,” he told me several years ago. “I kind of made it up as I went along.”

headline: White Supremacist Convicted of Killing 3 at Kansas Jewish Centers
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Jurors deliberated for about two hours before convicting Frazier Glenn Miller Jr., 74, a former Ku Klux Klan leader with a history of racist and anti-Semitic actions.
lead_paragraph: OLATHE, Kan. — A white supremacist was convicted of capital murder on Monday in the shooting deaths of three people a year ago at a Jewish community center and an assisted living facility in suburban Kansas City.

headline: Review: ‘Puffin Rock’ Joins Parade of Shows Aimed at Youngest Viewers
abstract: Streaming services are offering more shows for very young viewers, including Netflix’s new “Puffin Rock.”
lead_paragraph: The newest Netflix series, “Puffin Rock,” arrives on Tuesday full of action, suspense and topicality. A valuable cargo is hauled across a beach under a ticking deadline. The story’s heroine disappears, and her father sets out to find her. The whole cast gathers to take in the supermoon.

headline: In Topping Charts, Disturbed Accomplishes a Rare Feat
abstract: The metal band Disturbed has the No. 1 album this week with “Immortalized” (Reprise), pushing Luke Bryan’s “Kill the Lights” to the No. 2 spot.
lead_paragraph: The metal band Disturbed has the No. 1 album this week with “Immortalized” (Reprise), which sold 93,000 copies and had just over three million streams, according to Nielsen. It is the band’s fifth consecutive release to open in the top slot, a rare chart feat — Metallica and the Dave Matthews Band are the only other groups to have done it, Billboard reported.

headline: Mourning Kyle Jean-Baptiste, ‘Les Misérables’ Actor Who Plunged to His Death
abstract: Cast members and classmates recalled a young man of warmth and ambition who was the first black actor to play Valjean on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Several hundred people gathered at the Bethesda Fountain in Central Park on Monday afternoon to celebrate the life of Kyle Jean-Baptiste, the 21-year old actor who died last week in a fall from a fire escape in Brooklyn. Mr. Jean-Baptiste was the first African-American to play the role of Jean Valjean in “Les Misérables” on Broadway, as well as the youngest.

headline: Strict Enforcement of FIFA Rules Sidelines Young Players Abroad
abstract: A dispute over a FIFA rule designed to protect young players has left some of them, including an American teenager in Barcelona, unable to play in matches.
lead_paragraph: Ben Lederman still gets up early for school every morning so he can be finished in time for soccer training. He still practices, every day, at La Masia, the famed youth academy of F.C. Barcelona. He still spends much of his time at a place where he occasionally crosses paths with stars like Lionel Messi.

headline: Transgender Inmate Who Sued Georgia Gets Unexpected Parole
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole']
abstract: A lawsuit filed by Ashley Diamond, who served less than a third of her 12-year sentence, sought hormone therapy and more protection from rape in the men’s prisons where she was incarcerated.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Diamond, the transgender inmate who sued Georgia in February for access to hormone therapy and protection against prison rape, was unexpectedly paroled on Monday after serving less than a third of a 12-year sentence for burglary.

headline: Review: ‘Atomic Orbital’ and ‘Midway Avenue,’ Examining Electrons and Memories
abstract: Laura Peterson and Nichole Canuso share a bill at Here, one with a dance nodding to quantum physics, the other with a look at her parents’ divorce.
lead_paragraph: Choreography may not be quite as perplexing as quantum mechanics, but it is a mysterious art. “Atomic Orbital,” Laura Peterson’s contribution to a shared program at Here this past weekend, is an abstract dance whose clean lines, attention to detail and complex sense of stage space recall the work of Merce Cunningham. And yet something is missing, the something that makes such abstraction dramatically absorbing. It’s hard to say exactly what that something is.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Locrian Chamber Players, With Music Wrapped in Temporary Mystery
abstract: This ensemble, which offers program notes only at the end of its concerts, played a collection of newish, pretty pieces at Riverside Church.
lead_paragraph: Two rules govern concerts by the Locrian Chamber Players: The music cannot be older than 10 years, and program notes are provided only after the event, at the exit.

headline: Review: Madboots Dance Ignores Gender Boundaries
abstract: This all-male troupe, founded in 2011, debuted two works at Jacob’s Pillow last week in Becket, Mass.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — In the final week of this year’s Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, much of the warmest applause was directed at the woman giving the preshow speeches: Ella Baff, who is moving on after 17 years as the festival’s executive and artistic director. Her closing round of introductions addressed America’s oldest dance troupe, the Martha Graham Dance Company, and one of its youngest, Madboots Dance.

headline: Michigan Lawmakers Misused Aides to Cover Up Affair, Report Finds
abstract: Michigan Representatives Todd Courser and Cindy Gamrat forced staff members to do political and personal work on state time, according to an internal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Two Michigan legislators forced their aides to do political and personal work on state time, including helping cover up their affair, and then lied repeatedly about their actions, according to an investigation by the State House of Representatives, whose findings were released Monday.

headline: Tennis Fans Excited for U.S. Open
abstract: Tennis fans lining up outside Arthur Ashe Stadium in New York, excited to see their favorite players, including Serena Williams, in this year’s U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: Tennis fans lining up outside Arthur Ashe Stadium in New York, excited to see their favorite players, including Serena Williams, in this year’s U.S. Open.

headline: T-Mobile Says It Will Ban Abusers of Unlimited Data Plan
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: T-Mobile USA’s chief executive took to Twitter to announce the carrier would eliminate customers abusing its unlimited data plans. That prompted questions on the use of the word “unlimited.”
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA, one of the few phone carriers to still offer an unlimited data plan, has run into a classic Homer Simpson problem: The company says it will get rid of abusers of its all-you-can-eat data privileges, similar to when Homer was thrown out of a restaurant for eating too much seafood at an all-you-can-eat buffet.

headline: Review: From Taka Kigawa, a Class on Resonance at Le Poisson Rouge
abstract: Mr. Kigawa plays with a fundamental gentleness, even in intense passages, but he brings a precision to the relentless pricks and bristling repetitions in these pieces.
lead_paragraph: Summer school has been in session in New York piano recitals. Recently, at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center, Pierre-Laurent Aimard gave a lesson in canons and fugues, a prelude to his performance of George Benjamin’s combination of those two forms in “Shadowlines.” And on Aug. 24 at another intimate space, Le Poisson Rouge, Taka Kigawa held a class on reverberation and resonance.

headline: Review: In ‘Make Me,’ Lee Child Adds Another Layer to Jack Reacher
abstract: The 20th installment of Mr. Child’s Reacher series presents a gutsy new challenge for its hero, and offers a faint indication that something about him may change.
lead_paragraph: “Grain, meet the railroad” Jack Reacher tells himself, after he’s picked the latest sinister little Nowheresville in which to spend a book’s length of time. He appears to have gotten off a train in the middle of wheat country, for no better reasons than he liked the cryptic name of the town, Mother’s Rest, and that he’s got foolproof instincts for sniffing out trouble. Lee Child’s Reacher series has hit Book No. 20 with a resounding peal of wisecracking glee (“Are you going to be a problem?” “I’m already a problem. The question is, what are you going to do about it?”). Everything about it, starting with Reacher’s nose for bad news, is as strong as ever.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: August 31, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, Russia and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, Russia and Nepal.

headline: An Outpouring of Reader Reflection After the Death of Oliver Sacks
abstract: When Oliver Sacks, the neurologist and author, died of a cancer, Times readers took to the online comments section of his obituary to share what he meant to them.
lead_paragraph: When Oliver Sacks died at age 82 on Sunday, readers flocked to his obituary to pay their respects. Many wrote of their connections to the neurologist as patients, mentees and, largely, as readers. In his essay last February “My Own Life,” Dr. Sacks acknowledged the impact his readers had had on his life, writing, “I have had an intercourse with the world, the special intercourse of writers and readers.”

headline: In Vienna, Trains Packed With Refugees Are Welcomed and Ushered On
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Arriving from Hungary, hundreds of determined migrants switched trains at the Westbahnhof rail station as they pressed on for Germany.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Six trains packed with migrants arrived on Monday at the Westbahnhof rail station in Vienna from Budapest and Hegyeshalom, a Hungarian village near the border with Austria.

headline: Jorge Ramos Is Not Walter Cronkite
abstract: What Hispanic viewers see when they watch the country’s most influential Spanish-language journalist.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Donald Trump’s bodyguard forcibly removed him from a press conference in Dubuque, Iowa, the Univision news anchor Jorge Ramos declared that the ejection had caught him by surprise. As he told George Stephanopoulos on “Good Morning America,” “Never in my life, and I’ve been a journalist more than 30 years, have I been thrown out of a press conference.” Technically, Ramos’s statement is true. But anyone who has read his books knows that he has tangled with bodyguards before, even if they weren’t at a press conference.

headline: Obama Makes Urgent Appeal in Alaska for Climate Change Action
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: President Obama said at an international conference that “we’re not acting fast enough,” challenging leaders and citizens to reduce emissions to “protect the one planet that we’ve got while we still can.”
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — President Obama on Monday issued a global call for urgent action to address climate change, declaring that the United States was partly to blame for what he called the defining challenge of the century and would rally the world to counter it.

headline: Why Students With Smallest Debts Have the Larger Problem
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Student Loans', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Income']
abstract: Defaults are concentrated among the millions of students who drop out without a degree, and they tend to have less debt.
lead_paragraph: Politicians who complain about college costs frequently cite two numbers: one trillion and seven million. Student borrowers owe more than $1 trillion, and seven million borrowers are in default, according to the latest Department of Education data.

headline: At Manhattan Marriage Bureau, a Union of Matrimony and Bureaucracy
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages']
abstract: The number of marriage ceremonies at Lower Manhattan’s cradle of codified romance has jumped by nearly 50 percent since 2008.
lead_paragraph: The brides wore white, temporarily, retrieving ticket No. C685 from a kiosk inside the Manhattan marriage bureau — that great municipal deli of matrimony — and waiting to be served.

headline: A Day at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Marriages', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Two changes have helped fuel greater use of the bureau: the legalization of same-sex marriage and an effort by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to make it a premiere wedding destination.
lead_paragraph: Two changes have helped fuel greater use of the bureau: the legalization of same-sex marriage and an effort by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to make it a premiere wedding destination.

headline: Greenlight Capital Down 14% for Year; David Einhorn Surveys Investors
abstract: The recent market turmoil has not spared one of Wall Street’s smartest stock pickers.
lead_paragraph: David Einhorn has earned a reputation as one of the savviest stock pickers on Wall Street. But the recent market turmoil has not spared him, and this year is shaping up to be one of the worst in his big hedge fund firm’s two-decade history.

headline: Iran Nuclear Deal Gains Momentum With Endorsements of Four House Democrats
abstract: Three members from New York and another from Florida lent fresh momentum to the pact from quarters that once appeared leery of it.
lead_paragraph: Three House Democrats from New York and a House Democrat from Florida who is running for a Senate seat endorsed President Obama’s nuclear deal with Iran on Monday, lending fresh momentum to the pact from political quarters that once appeared most leery of it.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Takes to Twitter for a Lunchtime Chat
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio held a brief, unannounced question-and-answer session on Twitter, addressing topics personal and political.
lead_paragraph: The message went out just before 1 p.m., lurching into the social media wilderness of lunchtime on a late summer Monday.

headline: Calling the Midwife, in Chiapas
abstract: In Chiapas, Mexico, a midwife may be the only person there to help a woman when she gives birth.
lead_paragraph: In Chiapas, Mexico, a midwife may be the only person there to help a woman when she gives birth.

headline: Teenage Motherhood in France
abstract: Vivane Dalles labored to find the money — and outside interest — to pursue an intensive project on teenage mothers in France.
lead_paragraph: Vivane Dalles labored to find the money — and outside interest — to pursue an intensive project on teenage mothers in France.
